name: Parada para dormir
description:
We stopped at a vacancy, facing the gym, it was quiet.

Paramos em uma vaga, de frente para academia, foi tranquilo.

name: Rua próximo à praia
description:
We spent the night here and already guaranteed our place to enjoy the beach the next day.

Passamos a noite aqui e já garantimos nossa vaga para curtir a praia no dia seguinte.

name: Rua sem saída
description:
Quiet night, safe place, facing a restaurant.

Noite tranquila, local seguro, de frente pra um restaurante.

name: Praia de Tambaba
description:
We slept in the beach parking lot, the moon was beautiful, it was super quiet.

Dormimos no estacionamento da praia, a lua estava linda, foi super tranquilo.

name: Na rua da praia do amor
description:
We spent the night here and it was very quiet, the only problem was the heat!

Passamos a noite aqui e foi bem tranquilo, único problema foi o calor!

name: Rua do centro
description:
We spent the night here in the city of Escada-PE

Passamos a noite aqui na cidade de Escada-PE

name: Posto de gasolina
description:
We spent the night here, there are several truck drivers, a quiet place.

Passamos a noite aqui, ti ha vários caminhoneiros, local tranquilo.

name: Vitória da Conquista
description:
A small square in front of Unimed's history, quiet night.

Uma pracinha em frente o historial da Unimed,  noite tranquila.

name: Posto BR
description:
Great place to spend the night, it has security, water, hot bath and Wi-Fi.

Ótimo lugar para passar a noite, tem segurança,  água, banho quente e Wi-Fi.

name: Bairro Piracicaba
description:
We spent the night here, very quiet, with Wi-Fi open!

Passamos a noite aqui, muito tranquilo, com Wi-Fi aberto!

name: Frente ao mercado
description:
We stopped here on the street to spend the night and it was very quiet!

Paramos aqui na rua para passar a noite e foi bem tranquilo!

name: Abel gasolina
description: I was worried I would not make it to the next gas station (because the last one only had diesel) and as luck would have it, there was a sign in this far out of the way town (Purísima, B.C.S.). I was concerned a little about getting gas not at a station, but I needed the gas so I took the chance. The guy was friendly, spoke English, fair, and fast. Also, his dogs were chill, which is super important for anyone that is traveling with a dog. I drove over 100 miles already and no issues with my truck. I am super grateful for him. I am adding it on here because there was not one already. Hope this helps others, like it did me!

name: Public Parking
description:
A public parking lot, very quiet, some comercial activity near. Restrooms at a gas station and pharmacy near.
Great area to walk a dog.

name: Creel/Batopilas junction
description: On the road, near junction with Creel and Batopilas. Large spot side road. Very quiet. Couple of spots.

name: Caligas
description: Large Caligas With Parking Refills Portables

name: next to a small church-plaza
description: I found this place in a quit alley next to the church of the small town. The only noise came from some sheep at sunset. Ok for one night

name: Salto Bendiction warm springs
description: an old park with 3 rundown pools fed by warm spring water. Apparently in the 60' they were looking for petrol and came out this water! Quiet on weekdays  and the caretaker let me sleep inside the gated area for a tip..some telcel internet signal

name: Beachfront camping
description: Great spot right on the beach. Just 50 meters from the road. Lots of space for big rigs but be weary of the soft sand in places. lovely to wake up to waves crashing and watch the whales breaching a couple hundred meters offshore.

name: Chedraui Reforma
description: More expensive than places like Soriana and Aurrera but the best grocery store in Oaxaca, favored by locals as well. High quality brands including dog food.

name: Carmen & Rosalina
description:
Cute little restaurant. Open Saturdays and Sundays 9am to 5pm. No set menu as far as I can tell. We told her we were vegetarians and she made us quesadillas with a side of beans and salad. So good!

Since there were no menus there were no prices until the bill came. An order of quesadillas with a side of beans was 100 p. A  large salad was 60 p.

name: welder
description: we came here to get our awning fixed and welded the base of the awning back to our van. also welded a piece underneath the bus. 30000 clp for about an hour of work. friendly guy. not sure if we paid too much.

name: Acción Animal
description: Got our dog an updated health certificate here to travel to Belize. Cost is 550 pesos. We called ahead, but they did not require an apt, just told us to come between 9am and 1pm. Vet spoke English fluently and was very friendly/helpful.

name: Scenic drive: Mazatlan to Durango (libre)
description: Very scenic drive: many curves and hairpins, while climbing higher and higher. I did this on a motorcycle 13 years ago and this time, we made quite a detour to be able to see it again. Great news: since last time, there now is a toll road with all commercial traffic running in parallel. Few speed bumps, little traffic on this free, very scenic road.

name: Mariscos quatro x 4
description: Fantastic lunch!! Right off hwy 1 on the edge of La Paz. Super fresh seafood cocktails, ceviches, tacos & quesadillas. My husband had the seafood soup (180p) and I had a shrimp quesadilla (95p). Both were fantastic!! The soup was huge!

name: Gas Baja
description: The other propane place in Colonet was closed. This one was thankfully open. It’s across the street from the Mercado Balanza (Red and Yellow Building).

name: pequeño lugar agradable cerca de cascada. pasamos la noche en nuestro vehículo y muy tranquilo
description: Excellent. near a waterfall. sure. place to eat tacos very close --- excelente. cerca de una cascada. seguro. lugar para comer tacos muy cerca

name: Tecozautla plaza
description: we slept in front of the square of this recent magical town.  We find a lot of peace and silence at night.  there are public bathrooms from 9 am to 9:30 pm which cost $ 5

name: Acceso a cascada de la Cebolla.
description:
we spent 4 nights here. It rests great. At night the sound of crickets is fantastic. There is a good internet signal and shops a few meters away where you can get everything. We are at the beginning of the Cascada de la Cebolla trail, which is located approximately 60 meters away.
We recommend using the water that falls from the large waterfall and not from the other sector. The last light on the street is a few meters from us, who wants light on the street is a matter of moving a few meters. No one bothered us at any time and we were alone all the time. We highly recommend it.. --- pasamos 4 noches aquí. Se descansa genial. En las noches el sonido de los grillos es fantástico. Hay buena señal de internet y comercios a pocos metros donde se consigue de todo. Estamos al comienzo del sendero de la Cascada de la Cebolla que está ubicada a unos 60 metros aproximadamente. 
Recomendamos utilizar el agua que cae de la cascada grande y no del otro sector. La última luz de la calle está a pocos metros de nosotros, quien desee luz en la calle es cuestión de moverse a pocos metros. Nadie nos incómodo en ningún momento y pasamos solos todo el tiempo. Lo recomendamos mucho..

name: Pemex pronta a inagurar
description: we slept here one night. There are no services but a good neighbor (in front) who offered his bathroom. We slept very peacefully. There is street lighting all night and places to eat nearby. Good mobile internet signal. The police are constantly circulating. Although it is not an attractive place, it is very good to spend a night. There is a water faucet available. --- dormimos aquí una noche. No hay servicios pero si un buen vecino(en frente) que ofreció su baño. Dormimos muy tranquilos. Hay luminaria en la calle toda la noche y lugares para comer cerca. Buena señal de internet del celular. La policía se ve circular constante. si bien no es un lugar con atractivo es muy bueno para pasar una noche. Hay una llave de agua disponible.

name: kiosco de Tamazunchale
description: We spent 3 nights in front of the central square/park (kiosk). There is light at night and a lot of security for being next to the municipality that is guarded 24 hours. There is a lot of commerce nearby, a very cheap permanent tianguis (fair) that starts on the corner. There is a public bathroom open almost all day and until 10 pm approx. The police greet us and greet our dogs but they never approached us to speak to us. At night it is very quiet. There is a kind of stage in front of the kiosk that has its columns to charge electrical devices. --- pasamos 3 noches frente a plaza/ parque central ( kiosco). Hay luz durante la noche y mucha seguridad por estar al lado de la municipalidad que está vigilada 24 hs. Hay mucho comercio cerca, un tianguis (feria)  muy barata permanente que comienza en la esquina. Hay un baño publico abierto casi todo el día y hasta las 22 hs aprox. La policía nos saluda y saluda a nuestros perros pero jamás se acercaron a hablarnos. De noche es muy silencioso. Hay una especie de escenario frente la kiosco que en sus columnas tiene para cargar aparatos eléctricos.

name: Omitlan de Juárez
description: We arrived here by chance and we didn't want to move. This pueblito is more beautiful than many other magicians we have known. Have many precious rinconcitos. We slept in front of the kiosko/plaza where there is very good and free wifi. There are public bathrooms very close to shops, pharmacies, market. There is where to charge electrical appliances publicly. The people are kind and friendly. We recommend it 100% --- llegamos aquí de casualidad y no nos hemos querido mover. Este pueblito es más bello que muchos otros mágico que hemos conocido. Tiene muchos rinconcitos preciosos. Dormimos frente al kiosko/plaza donde hay wifi bastante bueno y gratis. Hay baños públicos muy cerca, comercios, farmacias, mercado. Hay donde cargar aparatos eléctricos de forma publica. Las personas son amables y amistosas. lo recomendamos al 100%

name: Puestos de comida cerca de la laguna
description: Parking lot of small places where we ask permission to spend the night to a man who works here (open at dusk) and tell us very kindly that you. The police arrived in the night and offered us to take care of them in their path. We felt very safe here and had a lot of silence to rest. There are enchanted places to walk. Signal internet and cell phone. --- Estacionamento de unos pequeños puestos donde pedimos permiso para pasar la noche a un señor que trabaja aquí ( cierran al oscurecer) y nos dijo muy amablemente que si. La policía se acercó en la noche y nos ofreció cuidarnos en su recorrido. Nos sentimos muy seguros aquí y hubo mucho silencio para descansar.  Hay lugares encantados para caminar. Llega señal de internet y celular.

name: Parque/ plaza central
description:
Excellent, quiet and illuminated place to spend the night. We asked the police for permission and they authorized us without any problem. At night they watered the square and offered us water. At night only crickets were heard. In times of little rain (winter) there is a small stream with lots of vegetation about 600 meters from here that in times of rain must be a beautiful river.
---
Excelente, tranquilo e iluminado lugar para pasar la noche. Pedimos permiso a la policía y nos autorizaron sin problema. En la noche regaron la plaza y nos convidaron agua. En la noche solo se escuchaban grillos. En en épocas de poca lluvia( invierno) hay un pequeño arroyo con mucha vegetación a unos 600 metros de aqui que en épocas de lluvia debe ser un hermoso río.

name: Plaza/ parque frente a Guardia Nacional
description:
The National Guard authorized us to sleep here. There is a Neto supermarket 100 meters away, the municipal market on the corner, electricity throughout the night, food stalls, public toilets. It was hot, we slept with the windows open and even the back door ajar. The only detail (good or bad depending on who sees it) is the singing of the birds late at night and at 5:40 in the morning the great choir begins.
we recommend this place.
If you pass through here, do not forget to go to the lagoon, in particular we loved it, we took a bath in its waters of beautiful temperature in an incredible environment and the waves give it an incredible touch.
---
Nos autorizó la guardia Nacional para dormir aqui. Hay un supermercado Neto a 100 metros, el mercado municipal en la esquina, luz durante toda noche, puestos de comida, baños públicos. Hacia calor, dormimos con las ventanas abiertas e incluso la puerta trasera entreabierta. El único detalle( bueno o malo según quien lo vea)  es el cantar de los pajaritos a altas horas de la noche y a las 5:40 de la mañana comienza el gran coro.
recomendamos este lugar.
Si pasas por aquí no dejes de ir a la laguna, en lo particular nos encantó, tomamos baño en sus aguas de hermosa temperatura en un increíble entorno y las olas le dan un toque increíble

name: bodega Aurrera
description:
We spent the night in the parking lot of the Bodega Aurrera with free Wi-Fi and the National Guard very close to us. very quiet at night, with lighting and security cameras. We asked the supermarket workers if it was possible to spend the night and there was no problem
---
pasamos la noche en el estacionamiento del Bodega Aurrera con wifi gratuito y la guardia Nacional muy cerca nuestro. muy tranquilo de noche, con iluminación y cámaras de seguridad. Preguntamos a los trabajadores del supermercado si era posible pasar la noche y no hubo problema alguno

name: río ostuta
description:
If you want to meet beautiful people and enjoy a pure river, with water all year round, free with shade and excellent temperature, you should stay here. We have spent whole days in the water. We arrived on a very hot Sunday and there were a lot of people, but on Monday it was just people from the area. We slept next to Chema's palapa that he had already shared with other travelers who passed through here and he invited us to park next to him. People gave us mangoes (it was the season) and the children of the children of other palapas who had already shared with other travelers and wanted to spend time with us came to chat. He tries to bring something to entertain them, all the other travelers are teaching him to do different things and we assure you that it is worth it. There are public restrooms for $5 and you can also consume whatever you need in the palapas or in town. Internet works with a code that is bought at the palapas.
---
Si quieres conocer personas lindas y disfrutar de un río puro, con agua todo el año, gratis  con sombra y de excelente temperatura debes quedarte aquí. Hemos pasado días entero dentro del agua. llegamos un domingo muy caluroso y había mucha gente pero ya el lunes solo era gente de la zona. Dormimos junto a la palapa de Chema que ya había compartido con otros viajeros que pasaron por aquí y nos invitó a estacionamos pegaditos a él. Las personas nos regalaban mango (era temporada) y se acercaban a charlar los niños de los hijos de otras palapas que ya compartieron con otros viajeros y querían pasar tiempo con nosotros. Intenta traer algo para entretenerlos, todos los otros viajeros le van enseñando a hacer diferentes cosas y les aseguramos que vale la pena. Hay baños públicos por $5 y también consumir en las palapas o en el pueblo lo que necesites. internet funciona con un código que se compra en la palapas.

name: Bodega Aurrera supermercado
description:
Excellent place. We asked permission to sleep in the parking lot and they authorized us without a problem. There is WIFI. Free toilets. The super available to buy cold products, to cook or already prepared food. At night nothing was heard. We recommend it.
---
Excelente lugar. Pedimos permiso para dormir en el estacionamiento y nos autorizaron sin problema. Hay wifi. Baños gratis. El super disponible para comprar productos fríos, para cocinar o comida ya preparada. En la noche no se escucho nada. Lo recomendamos.

name: Passeo Montejo
description:
Street parking close to the historic center. The street and the parking line are wide enough to be parked without disturbing the traffic.
You are surrounded by colonial houses and palace and it’s quiet enough for the night hours.
Starbucks pretty close for Wifi & restrooms and descent town wifi service.
---
Parking dans la rue à proximité du centre historique de Merida.
La route et la ligne de Parking est suffisamment large pour se garer sans problème.
Vous serez entouré de maisons et palaces coloniaux et c’est suffisamment calme pendant la nuit.
Starbucks à proximité pour wifi et toilettes et signal wifi de la municipalité correct.

name: Oscar Restaurante
description:
Great shrimp and beef taco! (See pictures)  Amazing margaritas 
Have Pizza and pastas too. 
Good owner and price. Clean 

Recommended !!

name: Oasis Parking
description: Day time parking on the water in the oasis, great break from the desert. I wouldn't stay here overnight, but there are two wild camps nearby also on the water and they advertise hot water.

name: Nice place for a night with view
description: Worth stopping here for the night. It's close to the road so expect some road noise but you are surrounded by plants here and you have a good view into the valley

name: La Espirituosa at Jardín Cerrillo
description:
Here you can taste and buy Pox, ancient Mayan liquor, made with the original receipt 70% corn and 30% sugarcane, difficult to find as now most are made 100% of sugarcane. Also different varieties mixed with extract of Jamaica and cacao.
If you take the free walking tour they brings you here.

name: BoaBoa
description: Simply wonderful. Expensive I guess but worth it for a change and some comfort

name: Los Brothers Asadero
description: One of the cleanest taco places I've been to in Baja.  Amazing carne asada, much more than just tacos. I got 2 tacos.and they were huge and delicious with the best guac!

name: Malecón
description:
We spent 2 nights parked on the boardwalk. In the afternoon, many people spend exercising and walking.
Very quiet and safe.
We recommend visiting the Salto Grande waterfalls.
--
Pasamos 2 noches aparcados sobre el malecón. Por la tarde hay pasan muchas personas haciendo ejercicio y paseando.
Muy tranquilo y seguro.
recomendamos visitar las cascadas de Salto Grande.

name: El Xate
description: Very nice kinda hipster restaurant just 50m from Mika’s place (Hostal Mozocco - which sadly as of July 2022 is now closed). Good pizza and excellent house wine. Lots of other dishes on the menu. Open for dinner from 6:00 to 10:00 pm. Definitely worth a visit!

name: Dry river bed
description: This side river of the Río Nazas is dry most of the year (it carries water from June to August) and about 3 kilometres (or 2 miles - as the crow flies) from the paved road. Camping anywhere - including close to the main river. No protection from the sun. Some garbage (broken bottles) and remains of a fire. Friendly owner of the house on the cliff East (500 meters/yards) said camping was allowed. Slight traffic noise, otherwise quiet. Telcel 3G signal.

name: taller mecánico lara
description:
mechanical service of all brands specializing in VW, Nissan, Toyota 

————————————————————————————-

servicio mecánico de todas las marcas especialista en VW, Nissan, Toyota

name: Las Vegas st
description: Long street of Las Vegas about 2 miles with multiple pull outs on either side that are level. Train runs loud every couple hours not many cars pass at night. Decent amount of trash piles everywhere but did not encounter any homeless. I parked behind the bushes on a little road next to train tracks. There’s also a really nice space under the bridge just up the way a little. I fit with a 27ft skoolie and there’s plenty of more space for a bigger rig.

name: Policia turistica chetumal (there is a kindergarden in front and police parking in the morning so wake up early)
description:
When you search for san remo restaurant that is uploaded in this location in ioverlander,  then check the next street (boulevard) of the square...there is the policia turistica that lets you sleep in front of them, and they are awake all night long.
Quiet and safe zone.

name: free water for human consumption
description: here's a tap where you can get all the food what do you want it's free

name: Vitale
description: 11 pesos for a big bottle. They clean as well

name: Baltimore Inner Harbor
description: Side street parking area. Pay to park 8am-8pm

name: home supply
description: Free wifi open from Home supply. Average speed

name: Entrance to Ojo de Liebre
description:
Just the guard check the car plate and let you enter. 

le gardien note votre plaque d'immatriculation et vous laisse rentrer.

name: Ostiones ”La Recarga”
description: Really amazing grilled oysters. $100 pesos for 12. Worth it!

name: Walmart Léon
description:
good spot for the night, Bear the road but quiet night. the guard ask if you sell food or something. (like a foodtruck). we ask if it's possible to stay the overnight. No problem.

Nous sommes restés la nuit ici. proche de la route mais silencieux la nuit. le vigile à moto nous as demandé si nous étions des vendeurs. Nous lui avons demandé si c'était bon pour passer la nuit. c'est ok. pas de problème.

name: estacionamiento publico
description: This is a large, grassy, and gated lot at the end of the street. We didn’t camp here, but in broken Spanish we asked just for you…the owner said he allowed camping for a few nights. There weren’t any other cars parked here, didn’t see hookups, or ask about wifi. But, there were bathrooms, ATT LTE, and except for a few misquitos and the oddly clanged church bell, Yuriria is super peaceful.

name: Santo Domingo Restaurante
description:
Great traditional restaurant in a beautiful garden setting in Santa Catarina Minas that will allow you to park/camp outside overnight if you purchase something. The parking lot is shielded from the road by the restaurant itself, so when it closes ~8pm, it’s incredibly quiet, private, safe & comfortable. There’s even a little toilet and sink available outside. 

We ate both dinner and brekky here! The food is excellent (we recommend the mole coloradito on enchiladas or chilaquiles) and the prices are very reasonable— 70p for most meals and we had left-overs. Friendly staff & overall a wonderful experience to stay here!

name: Cervecería Cholula
description:
Great local brewery in Cholula with a spacious & level parking area. We ate lunch & had a few beers before asking to camp here and ended up spending 2 nights (we spent some more money on the second day just to be courteous). Both times, we also left a small tip for the security guard with one of the waiters (at their request), but we never did see a guard, so aren’t sure if it was just pocketed. Either way, a great option for overnighting in Cholula!

Walking distance to the centre of town and Cholula Pyramid, very conveniently located but also quiet (especially after close and before opening, at 2pm). Safe!!

The brewery itself is also lovely, they have tasty local food, excellent craft beer & a good happy hour (2x1 cocktails & 50p for pints, 5-7pm). View of Popó from the beer garden is gorgeous on a clear day!

name: Rocky beach colorfull clift
description: Rocky sand beach calm water! We watched dolphins jumping in the morning really close to the shore. No need of a 4wd, cliff with beautiful green and red colors.

name: La Punta
description: Just before the Surf Break spot at the the point’s edge, there is a flat spot with a fire ring. Beautiful view of the secluded surf spot. Very windy. Fishermen come and go to the Surf Break spot. Road is doable with 2WD. No cell signal.

name: A/C repair Automotriz Olachea
description: Automotive A/C repair shop. Added more refrigerant for my sprinter van. 200 pesos to recharge. 300 pesos to recharge and check for leaks. Nice guys, fast service. Some speak English.

name: Holistik Temazcal
description:
Amazing traditional temazcal operated by Lucia & her family on a little hill overlooking Santiago Matatlan. We met one of her son’s at El Pirul (an excellent restaurant in town) & he offered for us to camp at his mum’s home nearby— she road up to the house in our van & showed us around the property, which has an amazing view and several adorable kitties. Such generosity to invite us to camp!

We’d already done a temazcal, but I decided to take another the following morning & it was the most incredible experience. Lucia has Zapotec ancestry & her connection the land through this tradition is truly inspiring. I’ll post the recent prices as a photo for reference, but it is 1000% worth it! She even invited us to camp a second night after the temazcal!

name: Hotel Viva Villa
description: Hotel nice, restaurant, parking lot … cheap price

name: Lavamatica Lupita
description: Clean laundry service with nice machines. She charges by the load, wash and dry. Roughly 20 lbs of laundry was 220 MXP washed and folded.

name: La Cava de Marcelo / Cava de Queso
description:
It’s actually a Ranch, where they produce fresh cheese. 
Family has Swiss Background, the Ranch was founded 1911 and in belongs the one of the founders Grand-Grand son Marcelo. 
They offer a Tour how the cheese is produced, with tasting of 8 different kind of cheese, incl. glass of wine. 
Later you walk through the cheese cellar, who is probably the only one   in this style in Mexico. 
Later is another tasting with 4 cheese and two different beers. 
The Tour incl. Tasting cost’s 350 Peso’s per Person, highly recommended. 
If you are hungry, the Restaurant offers really delicious food, if you like Pasta, try the Linguini, served in a Cheese. 
Opening Thursday-Sunday 1pm-6pm. 
If you either take a Tour or eat at the Restaurant, you can overnight for free, really Countryside. 
If you come from the Mex 3, just follow the sign Cava de Queso and not Google Maps, it’s about 9km, the last 3km are not paved, for every kind of Vehicle duable.

name: Hidden and away from the main road
description: Spot(s) on an unused, unfenced area in between two dirt roads leading to two small communities. Some scrubs, a few trees and grass on mostly level ground. Quiet: about 1.6 kilometres (1 mile) from the main road. Some shade under one larger tree. Almost invisible from the closest dirt road (can go further to be really invisible). Broken beer bottles. No cell coverage.

name: (Actual) Aguas termales de Recowata
description: These are the thermal baths (picture taken at 17:00 - not the best light). Note the altitude (1900 meters) of the waypoint: 400 meters below the parking lot.

name: Paseo de Gloria
description: This is a very sweet small picnic/campground. Was VERY quiet except for a few trucks. No services/ pit toilet only.  $150 pesos. Two streams run through happily.  An oasis on a stretch of dry lonely road in a part of Mexico considered by some to be risky. Gate closes at 6 pm. A bit buggy.

name: Palmahia
description:
It's a nice ecotourism campground with a pool and big garden.
Has bathrooms, showers, WiFi.
Big rig friendly.
Prices varies between 80 and 150

Wish I had known about this place when I came in Campeche first!

name: Public Bathroom by Cactus Sanctuary
description:
Lupe at the Cactus Sanctuary told us about this bathroom just down the road in the town of El Rosario. Flush toilet and sink. Cleanish. No toilet paper. 

There are two in the small blue building past the basketball court. If one is out of order try the other.

name: Cava Valentina
description:
Lovely outdoor patio that sells local products (salsa, jam …etc) as well as Sangria, wine & coffee.
Huge sangrias for 100p. Super friendly service.

name: Ixpanpujal Skywalk
description: Super fun canopy hike (~2km) featuring 6 suspension bridges. A few of them are extremely high/long, which was exhilarating to walk across. If you have a drone, bring it- you'll get insane shots. We also saw/heard LOUD howler monkeys almost the entire time.  At the top there's a view and some hammocks to chill in. The cost was $20USD per person, but felt worth it because you got to be WAY up in the rain forest canopys without having to be on ziplines (like most other places.) The park does also have an optional zip line tour, which we didn't do. We spent the rest of the day in the park just chilling. Relaxing vibe

name: Mountain view
description: A large side road with a stunning view on the mountain. Very quiet. Telcel signal

name: Asadero La Higuera
description: Super nice place, grassy and shade . Owners have cabanas $700 pesos la noche. Camping not sure how much but plenty of space and she’s keen on letting people camp. Pool, toilets and showers

name: Level bluff with view
description: End of the road campsites on bluff overlooking ocean. Great 180 degree view. No garbage. Could be windy. Visited by locals mostly on the weekend driving regular street cars.

name: River crossing in wet season
description: At the end of the dry season, this river is ... dry. But that's not the problem: navigation systems regard it as impassable and will reroute users hundreds of kilometres. Have your GPS guide you to the West side of this crossing (if coming from the North) or to the East side and continue after crossing, which may or may not be possible during the wet season. Ask locals about the current situation.

name: In the river
description: This river is almost dry (at the end of the dry season) and has big trees for shade both on the banks and in the middle of the river bed. The dirt track here runs in parallel and across the river; we parked our 4x4 in the middle, in the shade of a majestic tree, but there are numerous other opportunities. Weak Telcel 3G or 4G (it varies) signal.

name: Las Gemelas
description:
Las Gemelas is a field at the end of a dirt road one kilometer off the paved coastal highway called Carretera Playa Hermosa. The turn off is at the north end of Colonia Revolucion and there is a sign. The dirt access road is rocky but easy for our Promaster van and we also saw a giant tour bus from Mexico City parked here so big rigs should be fine. 
Facilities include cold showers and clean toilets. No WiFi, cellphone, or electrical. Find your spot in the field alongside the river. 
30 pesos per person for the day or 80 pesos a person to camp. 
There is a deep swimming hole under the waterfalls that are the main attraction and draw Mexican day visitors. We were here on the weekend to camp and vendors  brought lots of food to buy.

name: Small roadside restaurant
description: Tiny, local place directly across from the church. No menu, server just told us what they had. Simple items-burritos & quesadillas the day we visited (Sunday). 4 quesadillas, 1 burrito & 2 cokes $290p.

name: Clay Cactus RV Camp
description: A beautiful desert garden camping ground with water hook ups, wifi, hot water shower,  toilets, two communal kitchens and power stations for your phones tablets and lap tops.

name: Valle de Ayoloco
description: Good place for camp and see the moon, stars,tec. at night. Very close to waterfall buble, just follow the signs up the hill!

name: Bodega Aurrera
description:
Excellent place to spend the night. We slept here 2 nights and it was really very quiet. There are cameras in the direction of our vehicle, free toilets from 8 a.m. to 9 p.m. free wifi and the possibility of buying products in the supermarket at a very good price
------------
Excelente lugar para pasar la noche. Dormimos aquí 2 noches y fue realmente muy tranquilo. Hay cámaras en dirección a nuestro vehículo, baños gratis desde las 8 al y las 21hs. wifi gratis y la posibilidad de comprar productos en el súper de muy buen precio.

name: Barra de Nexpa
description: It is reached under the Nexpa bridge at 400 by dirt road, you have to open fences to get to the place, you can fish in the river

name: El encuentro
description: Beatiful place, swimming Pool, green área, excelent attencion. Close to Parras de la Fuente, Coahuila.

name: la perlita
description: Small restaurant with lot of palapas. We asked a policeman who told us no problem to stay and sleep here, police patrol and militaries near.

name: Cleanest Agua Purificada in Baja
description:
Great purificado with hose for RV fill ups.
Irvine speaks great English and is super friendly.
Great experience and easy parking

name: Street parking in safe area
description: This is a street parking where we were allowed to park, right in front of Universidad Femenina de Veracruz llave. Very safe area with families, children, nice local people. We spent 3 nights here. There is a Pemex very near with toilet and a playground. Beach is 2 minutes walk.

name: Cenote Mani-Chan
description:
Two beautiful cenotes on this property. Owned/ managed by a lovely family. They have landscaped everything beautifully - stunning nature all around. 200MX per person incl camping, which we thought was a lot at first until we saw the cenotes and we were the only ones there. Dog was free snd she had so much space to run around. Worth every peso - we gave them an extra 100 tip. One cenote is underground and well lit, great to see in the evenings, the other is naturally lit from 10am and is approx 10 mins walking from the campsite - the owner walks you there and you can stay as long as you like totally alone. Amazing experience.

We arrived just after 5pm which was perfect - cant check in much after 6pm. Do not follow Google maps, unless on moto or small car as branches are too low for big rigs. Instead, take the long road and there is much better clearance for taller rigs - takes longer but way less stressful! When heading towards Homun from Cuzama on the 10, turn right at these coords: 20.741165,-89.307939 then follow on Maps until you reach Mani Chan.

Clean basic toilets and showers. They light campfires in the evening. Small tienda with basic snacks. We found these cenotes from all the amazing reviews and photos on Google maps, and we're so glad we did - it is so peaceful here and so nice to visit clean, quiet cenotes without any other tourists

name: Mezquital Overlook Tent Spot
description: Good spot for a single tent (2 person max) for Trans Mexico Norte riders. Small path through brush to take you away from the road and out of sight, with an overlook of the valley below.

name: Small Village Tienda
description: Small shop in a village. Advertising gasoline and internet.

name: Michilia Camping
description: Good spot out of sight from the road and on the public land outside the ranch boundary fence. Possible tent site for Trans Mexico Norte riders. Nothing special about it. Just a place to crash if needed in a pinch.

name: Restaurant by Pemex
description:
Great little restaurant by the Pemex. Very cheap tacos, gorditas, Tortas, etc. Soft drinks available.

The tacos dorado were really great and came with an amazing sour cream!

name: Palo verde
description: It seems to be a nice place to camp. There is a fire ring. No vista but if you need to stop on this rough road that would do it.

name: Km 28
description: A flat spot to stop on this rough road. It seems to be a rock exploitation. Vista of the surrounding mountains.

name: Banbajio Cajero ATM
description:
ATM with little charge. 7500 mexican Pesos and a 23 mexican peso fee
---
ATM avec peu de frais. 7500 dollars mexicain pour  23 dollars mexicain de frais

name: Beach Access #1
description: At the end of the road, this is a parking lot for beach access. No signs to indicate that overnight camping is not allowed. One camper was leaving as we arrived, and another arrived after us.  It was a relatively quiet night except for some nearby music.  It appears that they are building a structure of some sort which appears to have showers to rinse off after swimming in the ocean.

name: Restaurante Dona Gormita-Marvcarmen
description: Comida corrida for 60 pesos. Good food, local, simple. Boss very friendly.

name: Estación de carburación
description: We load a Mexican cylinder of 4 kilos at 13.26 per liter --- Cargamos un cilindro mexicano de 4 kilos a 13.26 el litro

name: ABD Supermercado
description: New, well stocked Grocery store. May have relocated from center of town.

name: Mulege travelling_thomsens
description: Great place to overnight with palapas, telcel signal is good

name: Antojitos dona Martha
description:
This place is nestled in between two buildings. It is only steps away from the street. It’s like eating at someone’s house for a bbq!

They have tacos for 50p each and everyday it changes. Also breakfast, lunch and dinner!! Seafood and sometimes bbq specials. Jamaica comes with free refills

name: Lavanderia Local AF
description: Laundry. Nice AF guy. $160 pesos for a single big -ass load. 3 hour drop-off to pick up. Dried and folded. Easy as all hell…get your drawers done already. FRESH.

name: samahua gas
description:
This is a new place.
The place if of a dirt road just across the pemex.
Filled up our fixed tank on the van, Very helpful. 13.70 pesos the liter.

name: Los Taquitos de Roy
description:
Chuleta tacos are THE reason to come here.  Sure, you could mess around with the other types of tacos they have (we've tried a bunch) but the chuleta is the best.  Chuleta is famous in Taxco, and if you ask the locals where to come for the best, they'll all say here.  

Chuleta is crispy fried, thinly sliced pork chop on a bed of homemade beans tucked in two fresh corn tortillas, topped with salsa verde con chicharron.  If you like things a little spicy, don't skip the pickled chiles, carrots and onions. $24 pesos a taco is a great deal for the size of these tacos.  Only two or three should do the trick if you're hungry!

Provecho

name: Estebans house
description:
Moderator Note: Make sure to ask the locals before you set up camp, if camping is permitted!

Left of hotel Relax, a little entrance that leads to a reasonably big paved parking lot ( fits 10 cars ). The lot is surrounded by a few little houses and in one of them lives Esteban. We asked to park here after enjoying a day in the natural pools of the park next door ((Balneario Santa Isabel 100pp ) crowded on a Monday but really nice.) Stayed here for free with a locked gate.

name: Pillone, next to the road
description: Flat spot next to the road, where you can drive in far enough to be away from the dust made by other vehicles. Hard enough to drive in and park big rigs. We were happy to find this spot after driving the bad, but very scenic road on the Altiplano. Almost no traffic on this road. Because of the very bad road conditions since we left Arequipa, we used a lot more fuel. We were happy to find gasoline in the little village Carmen de Chaclaya. Limited to 4 gallons, but should be enough to reach Ichuña, where is a fuel station.

name: Central Park calera
description:
It is a very quiet town, with very friendly people, everything is very cheap, the wind is very strong, it has no services but you can ask in a business if they sell you water, the Calerano bread is delicious
------
Es un pueblo muy tranquilo, con gente muy amable, todo es muy barato, el viento es muuuuy fuerte, no tiene servicios pero puedes preguntar en algún negocio si te venden agua, el pan calerano es delicioso.

name: Cuban Caffe
description:
Ideal when on route for breakfast or lunch (daily lunch special). Very popular with the locals. Large portions, everything freshly and lovingly prepared and, of course, endless coffee.

-----------------
Ideal auf der Durchfahrt zum breakfast oder lunch (tägliches Lunch Spezial). Sehr beliebt bei den Einheimischen. Große Portionen, alles frisch und liebevoll zubereitet und natürlich Kaffee bis zum abwinken.

name: toll plaza
description: regular toll plaza with police. 145$ pesos

name: Natural Gracers
description:
for all organic / vegetarian and vegan oriented

------------------------

für alle Organic / vegetarisch und vegan orientierten

name: Finca Kookay
description: Finca kookay is owned by Armando.  On the road to the cenotes of Puerto Morelos in the jungle, after our visit he decided to give access to this beautiful place to other eco-responsible travelers because rare are the quiet places where we can land in the Yucatan and this without exploding his  budget.  Cenote water basin to cool off, showers and toilets (men/women), outdoor kitchen, wood barbecue available, non-potable water available, gray and black water disposal possible, NO ELECTRICITY but sun for your  solar panels 😉.  Local restaurants nearby very cheap and quality cuisine 5 'walk away.  Possibility of delivery.  Local convenience stores also nearby.  All in a jungle setting where you can see Toucans, monkeys perhaps, exotic birds far from the tourist animation.  20 minutes from Puerto Morelos beach.  Ideal position if you like cenotes.  By reservation only (4 locations) Whatsapp Armando who speaks English, French and Spanish +52 998 109 5032

name: BacalarMed
description:
Doctor (GP) speaks very well English/Spanish.
We just walked in but you can call as well
We got the Covid recovery letter from there.
Fast and simple.

www.bacalarmed.com
contacto@bacalarmed.com
+52 983 135 0419

name: Hotel Omega
description: Nice hotel to spend the night, in center of the city next to very old church and town Square, secure parking, new air conditioners in the rooms.

name: Llantas Llyasa Ensenada
description: Big formal mechanic shop with proper paperwork and quotes. A bit more expensive than the local smaller shops, but he worked super efficiently. Changed our ball joint and did alignment in 2 hours for 4100 pesos including parts (about 1000 pesos more than the slow local guy we had doing some other stuff). Definitely recommend for suspension work.

name: Cooking class
description: This boutique hotel offers cooking classes/market tours for about US $80 /pp the market tour was pretty cool, the English speaking guide explained a bit about Merida history on the way and showed us the regional Ingredients.  We felt like we learned a lot in the class, found a great salsa recipe and really enjoyed everything we made in the class (panuchos, taquitos, chorizo, pork)

name: behind military base
description:
Easy to access spot right off the main highway. Take the road past the military entrance and continue until the road ends and turn left. 
Open space so big rig friendly. There are lots of cars here during the day but okay at night. Ask the guard and said we could camp here as long as we want. Great view and quick access to downtown San Felipe. 5 bars telcel but speeds vary.

name: Speed trap
description: As you start out on Route 2 from 85, there are a few 100 kmh signs. After that there are several 60 kmh signs, then none for a while and then the “fake” sign. In other words, the posted limit is 60 until you get within about 10km to the turn to the bridge where there is an 80kmh sign. There may be a radar trap, but the speed limit seems to be accurate.

name: purificadora
description:
purifier passing the river
 6 pesos the jug 

——————————-

purificadora pasando el río 
6pesos el garrafón

name: Toll booth
description: Toll booth, paid $226 MXN for our Jeep gladiator

name: Agua Purificadora Poseidon
description: Very friendly place to get filtered water. $16/garfon.

name: One way street
description:
The first part of this street is two way, but after the corner it's one way (and OpenStreetMap (maps.me, osmand, OSM Garmin etc) doesn't know about it and will route you through). The 'forbidden to turn right' sign is on the opposite side of the corner.

Police patrol it and we were caught. We detest corruption and made them do it by the book. Usually, that gets us off the hook, but not with this commissioner (in the station a few blocks from here).

Be aware of this unusual traffic situation (or be prepared to pay MXN 500 to dirty cops or drive to La Paz on weekends to get your driver's license back).

name: Rte 3 checkpoint
description:
Checkpoint on rte 3 before merge with 5. 

Heading East asked where we were going, cursory check of camper. Quick. Polite.

name: Hotel Rosario
description:
This is a cute Airbnb Hotel but you can also book directly if you call or WhatsApp Rosario or her daughter Julieta.

Comfortable roomes with 2 doble beds, fridge, microwave, aircondition, hot water and fast Internet... The parking is not closed but with active video system and some lots without hight restrictions. 

The owners are super friendly. 
We paid 550 per night with Airbnb and 500 booking directly. 

Phone numbers:
Rosario (spanish): +52 488 105 7092
Daughter (Englisch and spanish) +52 81 2040 6944

name: Alpe herrería premium
description:
Général metal work

Thé made me a battery casing for my camping trailer 
Gréât job, good prices

name: Cyclist Camping Along Creek
description: I believe only possible for cyclists or some adventurous Motorcycle. Descend and cross stream, walk upstream 100m and there is a decent spot under a tree for camping. A few cows in the morning but that was it.

name: Parque Ecológico Uzahzil-Edzna
description: Small campsite recently opened in the village next to the playground. You can set tents, with toilets, outdoor shower, tables, palapas. The place is safe and close. The people who manage are very friendly and helpful. Tiendas/comedor around to eat and buy basic stuffs. Price: 250 pesos/night for 1 tent and 4 persons.

name: Restaurant El Negro Chon
description: We set our tent there for a night. The owners, a friendly family, welcome us warmly. We did not pay for the tent, but we have eaten in the restaurant for diner and breakfast. Showers & toilets are available. They also proposed some tours in lancha in the rivers & mangrove. warning: there are many mosquitoes!!

name: Playa Venetia
description: A small beach probably 200ft between granite rocks, wind protected. There are lots of road to come here, preload google map satellite picture to navigate better, couple other beaches before getting here but black sand, this is finer granite sand. To get here you have to pass a sign that say private property, there is a guy in rough shape in a shack, he ask for something his Spanish was bad Probbbably no English at all, we give him 100 pesos, not to share if is legit, but we thought 100 pesos could help him. No one around, the road has some rough spot need high clearance a 4x4 could help. No cell coverage

name: Valle Girl Vino at El Corcho Ros
description: Wine bar/restaurant. They allow free camping on Fridays and Saturdays. Live music on Saturdays. Big open field for parking. Restrooms. Noise from the restaurant went on until midnight but other than that it was a good stay. Restaurant serves snacks and pizza. They serve wine and craft cocktails. The ones and all the staff were very nice. They look the gate at night so if you want to leave before 11 you need to tell them and they will leave it unlocked. Space for big rigs may be limited during business hours if the restaurant is busy.

name: Junco Rest Area
description: Large paved parking rest area with a great view of the Sea of Cortez. At the north end of the lot you can hop the wall and there is a path down to the water. We spent one night there as the paid RV parks were full and the other "wild" spots had sand too soft for our vehicle. Even though we were very close to the road, it was a very quiet night. We even spotted a big horn sheep watching us from the east side of the road.

name: Road block
description: We drove on Sunday March 20th, 2022 from Comitán to Lagos de Colón. A Pick up blocked the road an 3 men without uniform but with machine guns came and asked where we want to go. We asked if there is a problem and they told us that they just care about our security. One of the men want to open our door, but it was closed and he got angry. But the other men calmed him down and told us that they are not criminals. After about 10 minutes they let us continue. When we asked the people in Lagos de Colón they told us that since about 6 month there are fights between Narcos which came from Michoacan and those who come from Guatemala. They told us that they are not always there, but often and that the best time to travel would be between 8 a.m. and noon time.

name: Titire, road to Ichuña
description: Because we wanted a quiet and safe place to stay overnight, we took the unpaved road to Ichuña. Few kilometers in this road we found this place, flat and next to a small stream with clear water. Close to the road, but almost no traffic here. No traffic at all during the night, seen the long difficult road. So extremely quiet. Surrounded by nice views and alpacas.

name: Pay showers & toilet
description: 10 pesos for a cold outdoor shower, 5 pesos for a clean toilet. Men’s toilet stayed unlocked overnight when we were there March 2022. No one to collect $ before 9:30am nor after sunset.

name: Mobile w/ UBA
description:
This is a Mobil station that advertises  Ultra Bajo Azufre (UBA - aka USLD). According to Mobil’s Mexico website diesel is imported from the US and contains fewer than 15  ppm sulfur. 

We also saw many similar Mobil stations in San Luis Potosí , Leon , and Queretaro. Which contradicts the common wisdom shared with us before our trip to Mexico “there is no USLD south of the border.” 

Our advice if you’re bringing a modern diesel vehicle (bring some def and keep an eye out for more at the myriad autozones for when you run out) - map out Mobil stations and call ahead to make sure they have UBA on hand.

name: Hotel Adriana
description: This is a good hotel to spend a night -Affordable, good motorcycle and car secure parking. Good food available.

name: The Free Hostel
description: This is an amazing hostel - the place is clean, the food great, the team friendly and helpful. There is secure motorcycling. The manager is a great wealth of knowledge.

name: Estancia Villa Real
description: This hotel is a beautiful site and affordable. The rooms have hot showers, air conditioning, TV, and good wifi. Breakfast is included. Restaurants near by. Weekday rates from $690.P

name: 245 Morelos
description: This is a beautiful quiet hotel in this rural area. The rooms are clean, with Air Conditioning, good Wifi, and hot showers.  Large yard to relax in. Good restaurants in the community. Rooms starting at $695 P

name: La Birriera de Jareth
description: Amazing quesabirrireras. Cannot recommend enough. cheesy deliscious birriera quesadillas. Next time for two people would order 2 x quessabirriras each and a orden media to share.

name: Sugarport Trailhead
description:
Street parking next to an old ruin. It is also the trailhead to the hike to the old port and up the mountain with scenic views.

Can fill up with hikers during the weekend. A little noise during the day from the nearby San Cristobal hotel. Road is sandy but 2wd is fine, just careful where you park. 4wd up a short sandy bank could get you off the road and behind the ruin.

You can turn around towards the end of the road where there are stairs up to the newer road on the right.

The hotel is a 5 minute walk and has a high end restaurant. You might need reservations though.

name: Hochob Ruinas
description: Very nice but small set of Chenes ruins with a mostly intact monster mouth. Pothole ridden road to get here but worth a visit if you’re into off the beaten path Mayan ruins!

name: Near El Salado
description:
Nice picnic place with lots of places to camp at the end of a tiny village, east of El Salado. Didn't camped cause we had to rush north. Farmes where very friendly. 
This is nothing special but a save place away from the road. Main road is paved from the south and dirt from the north. 
High clearance helps to reach this place. 
No Telcel service.

name: waterhole
description:
Quite place next to a manmade waterhole. maybe a bit muddy when wet. The waterhole was dry when we where there. nothing special but really quite and hidden. No fences and no people. 
No Telcel connection.

name: Southbound Redpetroil with DEF
description: DEF advertised on sign outside of filling station - fairly rare in this part of Mexico.

name: zocalo
description: Nice place to stay one or more days on the zocalo. Restrooms in the main building, noisy but safe. Patrol of police during the night. Nobobody bothers us.

name: street place
description:
Nice street place near a small park. Local people advise us to this location. Perfect for one night after leaving the park when it close at 06 pm.

Un bon emplacement indiqué par un local.

name: Octopus Garden Hostel
description: Nice little hostel with a courtyard and tables. Prices vary by room, see photo. They have a big outdoor upstairs yoga/dance studio and offer classes every day for 150 pesos. No parking, but we slept in our truck camper right in front of the entrance and paid 50 pesos per person to use the hot shower and wifi. Great bar with live music next door.

name: Octopus Garden Hostel
description: Hot showers for 50 pesos per person at this hostel. They were happy to let us use their wifi too. Water pressure isn’t the greatest, but water is nice and warm! We stayed the night in our truck camper outside on the street.

name: La Gran Reserva
description:
Beautiful campspots close the the entrance of La Gran Reserva. There are 2 offical camping areas that should have toilettes, we didn't check. Lots of wild camping options if you are not to high, otherwise stay in the official camping. we are 2,60m and had no problem. The road is a little bit bumpy dirt road. high clearance helps but is not necessary. 
You can get free non portable water in the village before the preserve and there is a sign that says 100 pesos per vehicle. Not sure if this is for camping or to enter the preserve. Nobody wanted any money and we didn't got into the preserve cause of the signs that say private property. 

There are black Bears in the area, lots of Jays and if you are lucky you can see the very endangered maroon fronted parrot, that lives in this pine juniper forest. 

No Telcel connection.

name: Street camping near the cemetery
description: I asked in town and was recommended to come to this place. A wide street close to the panteón and opposite Ribba restaurant, flattest closest to the cemetery. A little exposed (I parked next to the single tree and that helped), otherwise all good, had a lovely peaceful night. Beats the Pemex!

name: Street Parking - Cerro de la silla
description: Level street parking along the outside of a neighborhood wall. This area was recommended by a police officer stationed at the entrance of adjacent community which houses the "Cerro de la silla" trailhead. This area  had heavy evening use as overflow parking for the hike, but was very quiet after ~10pm.  Stayed one night in high roof Sprinter without issue.

name: Muelles y Suspensión del Pacífico
description:
Both my camper trailer suspensions broke 
They were promptly repaired for 2,000 pesos
Professional and very friendly staff

name: Sutherland Park
description: Great street parking close to nice park with facilities and wifi

name: Puente Valle (Town Center)
description: Free and fast wifi access throughout high-end shopping mall. Acceptable speed to download movies, books, etc.

name: Balneario Dona Celia
description: After being told I could not camp at the lake campground because I had a dog, I stopped at this Balneario and asked if I could camp. At first she said no but when I asked again she said yes. There are 2 nice dogs here. Way up in the mountains and 2 big pools. So thankful after being led way out of the way by google maps.

name: Pemex Acacoyagua
description: Pemex truck stop in town. Busy but quiet at night. Asked for and was cheerfully given permission to stay.

name: Town Center
description: Parked on the side of the road next to the colourful town sign and centre park. Semi spent the night behind us and had no trouble.

name: Pemex
description: Stopped for lunch and gas but this place has lots of parking accessible north and south and out in the country. Would make an excellent overnight. Restaurant has strong WiFi if you eat there and park nearby.

name: San Felipe Beach Condos and RV
description: 22 cramped sites, no room for big rv, mainly camper vans and tents. Offers full hookups on back in sites with sewer placed higher then sites totally useless. Wifi like so many here is spotty. at $55.00 us a nite makes this ridiculous or emergency stopping only.

name: Pawnee buttes
description: Part of the Pawnee buttes national grassland. Sign says open range. Fire ring when you first pull in. If you drive about 1/2 mile over the other side of the small hill there’s a large grass pullout with flat areas for big rigs to fit. Stayed 4 nights. People drive by every so often. Very quite and peaceful. Not much out here but grass and fracking. The main part of the Pawnee buttes trail head 20 mins north of here is closed to preserve nature March to June. All other parts of the grassland are open to travel around for scenic drives. 1 bar Verizon to look some stuff up if necessary.

name: El Doradito Tacos y Ceviche
description:
Small, unassuming restaurant serving AMAZING seafood tacos, tostados & ceviche in Salina Cruz. Among the absolute BEST camarón tacos we’ve had on the mainland!!

Service is a bit slow, but it’s definitely worth the wait. Most tacos/tostados cost 40-50p and are large enough that you only need 2 for a full meal, plus the complementary lobster consomé and totopos. Such a gem!

name: Transmissions mechanic - Auto Transmisiones Cuauhtémoc
description:
Recommended by another local mechanic - replaced the whole transmission on our RV in one day.
Price seemed reasonable (fifteen hundred US) including labor.

name: Windstar Es Las Fuentes Gasolina (CAUTION)
description: BEWARE: Purchased gas here and charged our credit card 100MXN more then the pump reads. When we asked the station attendant about it, he sheepishly handed us 100MXN cash.

name: Zapatistas road block
description: 2 men wearing scary looking masks were blocking the road asking for money. They let you go once you give any amount.

name: Liss Ropa y Calzado (amazing shop)
description: Best shop in town — high quality, locally hand made garnments for men and women, unique jewelry, and some children stuff too. Shoes are amazing. I gave them all my money and wish I had more with me !!

name: Air BnB Xalapa-Enríquez
description:
Camping options being very limited in Xalapa, we opted for an Air BnB. This unit is less than 10 min walk to the Olmec MAX museum, which is the real reason to visit Xalapa. Has secure parking fir a small van and our Vanagon fit with much room to spare

https://www.airbnb.com/rooms/34415213?adults=2&children=0&infants=0&location=Xalapa%2C%20Ver.%2C%20México&pets=2&check_in=2022-04-02&check_out=2022-04-04&source_impression_id=p3_1648916433_aiwSUzW0b3KXgX3m

name: Restaurant La Doña
description: Great fish tacos, (I had the fish tacos and the shrimp tacos) the service was a little slow but worth the wait!

name: Taqueria May
description: Tacos 10p ea, they also have burritos and hamburgers. Good stop if you're in the area.

name: agua purificada
description:
Good service, close to Malecon, closes at 8 pm.

buena atención, cerca de malecon, cierra 8 pm

name: Macario
description:
A bug restaurant with an even bigger parking lot out back. We have a massive 36’ skoolie so paying the $500MXN they asked was worth the hassle of turning around.

The sound systems went into the night but that’s to be expected of this area. The price for the location was great to visit the fancy resort areas of tulum without the Bouigee price! 🙏🏽 just ask when you turn in for parking and they charge per day. Smaller vehicles can negotiate more, maybe $2-300MXN

name: Crocodile lookout at Laguna del Carpintero
description: Free lagoon boardwalk and park, you can spot the crocodiles from here. Great views of the city. Free parking too

name: Private place Senhor Blas
description: Private parking near house mother from Senhor Blas (Guisset en El Meco). His brother live also here. Quiet place. Nearby a campsite. Mr Blas is very sympatic. He asked us for 100 pM for our RV and 2 adults and 2 children. Telephone number is on the picture.

name: Little Paradise with Seaweed
description: A very nice place next to Cocos Palms and the Ocean. If you drive behind the bushes, its not visible from the road. Calm. Twice there were friendly locals that walked the beach with their dogs, for the rest we didn't see anyone. No facilities, no cell service. Sprinter or even a slightly bigger rig could fit (but all streets in this area are quite narrow). Unfortunately lots of seaweed and trash like everwhere on this coast south of Mahahual. I wouldn't drive down South for this spot because of that reason but if you are near anyways and need a place to sleep, this one is great.

name: Pemex
description: Great little place to spend the night on the Eastside of Guadalajara. Gas station is small but allowed us to park to class a RVs 40 foot plus. Was bright and safe but noisy.

name: Mira Mango
description: Super nice spot right in front of the point — for 10$ you get a shower and a bathroom. They also have small cabinas and hammocks for rent. Fresh breeze and no mosquito! Friendly cat that will come hang with you for sure too

name: La Mulata
description: The friendly owners of Mulata Restaurant, Ivan and Patty, let you stay on their carpark or on their property at the beach (4X4 vehicles) if you eat at their Restaurant. The good is very delicious. Both speak english and staff is very friendly. Toilets and cold showers are available.

name: Ochentos pizza and brewery
description: We were the only ones here but apparently it is very busy on weekends. There are lots of tables spread around the garden. Can't comment on pizza as we came for the beer.

name: El Chamon Guisados
description: Amazing gorditas. Small place. Newly open. Isaac, the owner/chef, was incredibly friendly and served us six smoked Marlin, pastor, carne asada, barbacoa and chicharron gorditas with rice and beans plus a lentil soup and sodas for 200 pesos. Best food we had in Guerrero Negro. Don’t be turned away by exterior appearance.

name: wifi gratis
description: Nice to have a wifi connexion for free. Not very strong but works great. Thanks a lot to the El Cuyo people.

name: Flamand rose
description:
The right place to see flamingos morning and evening, also stay left to sleep on the sea side.
La bonne place pour voir les flamands soir et matin; également pour dormir sur le côté gauche de l embranchement. Mer moins accessible.

name: Yogulato
description:
Amazing sorbets and ice cream here. Perfect place if you are feeling too hot or need to be refreshed.
You can choose between cone or cup with two toppings. The freshness of the flavors are incredible! We loved maracuya, taro and matcha.

name: Marisqueria Prima Vera
description: Great fish and shrimp tacos (in crispy tempura batter) and ceviche. All really fresh - can see the chef making it. Clean toilets too. Very friendly service, our waiter even spoke amazing English! Great stop on the way to San Cristobal from Villahermosa

name: Cenote complex
description:
5 cenotes and caves
250 pesos per car or 60 pesos per person if you park inside the gate and walk around. open everyday 9 to 4pm (goggle and their sign says open on Saturdays and Sundays only though)
Cenote verde is amazing for swimming, turquoise clear water and lots of wildlife.
Cenote zacaton is stunning but no track to go to the water.
No many signs or map so a bit tricky to find all the cenotes.
20 minutes on gravel road from main road

name: oil change and mechanic
description: got a last minute oil change before going back to the states. BYO oil and filter. paid 100mx. to the left of the yellow shop

name: tinting
description: great quality work and good price. paid 150mx for a large van window. just make sure you get your van to be tinted to a legal Mexican level or the cops will be after you. the guy is helpful for this. whatsapp 8361033763 or 8361141560 open till late. also accessories and parts

name: Rancho "El Eden" balneario el TELECHI
description:
Wonderful place to camp and swim and cool off. We had planned to stay 1 night and stayed 3. A lovely couple and their grown son live here and take care of many fruit trees. There is a side road with easy access and relatively flat camping for several vehicles, a toilet room with a flush bucket, and a patio with table, chairs & electrical outlet we used to heat up water for coffee.  There is even a sweat lodge frame by the river, and a rope swing to jump in it!

The family is super friendly and the mom is an amazing cook - refreshing beverages and huge, delicious meals at great prices.  Camping is 30pesos per person and includes use of facilities incl the river.  Locals come for the day to swim and picnic. We were the only campers at this time. 

There are hot springs very close for 10 pesos and 50 pesos. We soaked at the 10 pesos one because the more famous 50 pesos hot spring didn't allow dogs. 

Small biting bugs come out at dusk and dawn. Using insect repellent or staying covered did the trick.

They have 1 German Shepard here which is pretty chill. The neighbors dogs do come over sometimes but they are friendly too.   The weekend was busier than midweek but it's pretty mellow here every day, not as crowded as the neighbors.  Highly recommend this special place and special hosts.

name: El Rancho El Encanto
description: Beside a beautiful turquoise river, has zip line, suspended bridge, space for swimming, 2 cabanas for rent and space for campers and rvs. You can walk to the nacimiento in a 5-10min walk along a beautiful path in the bosque

name: RPM Garage
description: Workshop, not brand specific, but well equipped (Autel diagnostic computer, snap-on tools, aircon filling manometers, 30 ton press), tidy shop and knowledgeable mechanic Umberto.

name: police check point
description: regular police checking. just ask for our license and title. nice policeman.

name: Mexico to USA border crossing entry
description:
Use this waypoint to find the entrance for crossing the border by vehicle (other side streets are blocked). Note that once you pass this waypoint, you cannot go back, AND that you will see no more Mexican officials. Make sure you're stamped out of Mexico and have your TIP cancelled (if not returning before it expires) before entering here.

Opening hours: 6:00 am to 10:00 pm.

name: Litibu beach - 2nd access road
description: A lovely, quiet, short dirt road to the beach. We arrived late afternoon and there was only one other car here. Decided to stay here instead of the next road over, as it seemed cleaner and less busy. Felt safe for us and our van. Enjoyed having the beach steps away, even saw some whales! Blissful.

name: The Chones Store
description: Lavanderia, 100 pesos per load more or less. Count your things, we heard a story that they took and were selling some clothes once. Ours were all there, no issues! Came back clean and we smell nice for a change!

name: Solka cabanas
description: This place is new, you can put your tent in it, and the river is very near. you can have a swim, it’s a really good place if you want to relax .

name: Hostel tenabo
description: You can stay here with aircon for $250 and very nearby you can eat something too

name: La Mestiza de Uxmal
description: Yo can camp here for $150 on grass with toilet

name: Maria de la Torre
description:
Parking station service, very nice service, quiet and secure. 
....
accueil très sympa, tranquille, sécurité

name: monclova
description:
Street in cul de sac, I asked the residents about parking for the night, no problem, security, tranquility, no service.
.....
Rue en cul de sac, j'ai demandé à stationner pour la nuit au riverain, pas de problème, sécurité, tranquillité, pas de service.

name: Mapimi
description:
We asked the police where we could spend the night safely, they allowed us to park in front of the police station near the church, quiet quiet, no service, lavenderia a few streets further.
....
Nous avons demandé au police estal ou nous pouvions passer la nuit en sécurité, il nous on autorisé devant le poste de police près de l'église, tranquille quiet, pas de service, lavenderia quelques rue plus loin

name: Hidalgo del Parral
description:
Parking around the small square with a kiosk. During the day we stored the truck in a box, in the evening stored along the sidewalk straddling 3 boxes. Quiet at night, in the morning no more traffic for half an hour for the start of the school year. The police came by several times without speaking to us.
---
Parking autour de la petite place avec un kiosque. Dans la journée nous avons rangé le camion dans une case, le soir rangé le long du trottoir à cheval sur 3 cases. Tranquille la nuit, le matin plus de circulation pendant une demi heure pour la rentrée des écoles. La police est passée à plusieurs reprise sans nous parler

name: Tornel
description: Do not come here ! I previously posted a review about the great service only to drive 15000 miles and have my tires explode on the highway due to them being 10 yr old tires they sold me ! Stay away !!

name: La Pintada
description:
Wonderful & Romantic Restaurant. Awesome Vibe here. 
Great Food ! Great Service and prices are not crazy expensive.

name: Taller automotriz el Abie Li
description: Daniel is the mechanic. Very nice and honest guy . He needed to order parts for us but recommended we can go to la Paz after verifying my bus is safe to drive. The other mechanic that’s listed on iOverlander is closed

name: Lavanderia Isabel
description: Nice older lady who does your laundry for you. She charges 80 pesos only which is the cheapest in town. It’s just a shack with the name on the gate but her service is great

name: Cabañas El Edén
description: Camping area in the beautiful Sierra de Santiago, all services, pool, cabins, 2km from the National Highway, an excellent encounter with nature

name: Road blockage
description: 190 blocked in both directions for unknown reasons from (at least) noon until 17h today (a Friday before a holiday weekend). Apparently it happens often, sometimes only opening up at midnight. No possibility to pass, and detouring is not recommended according to the locals standing in line.

name: Hotel Kiko
description: Cheap hotel in Mazatlán with secure parking (we paid 440 pesos). Cars and motorcycles are parked inside the hallway outside your room if on the first floor. Inexpensive Breakfast 8am - 10am. This is a classic Mexican hotel, can be noisy at times. 300 yards from ferry to Stone Island and beaches. Close to La Paz ferry. Hosts are very gracious. Rooms are clean. Air conditioning. Hot showers. WiFi.

name: Ventanilla parque acuatico
description: Little “parque acuatica”. Perfect for a day at the pool. 80 pesos pp without our own food (restaurant on site is not expensive) or 120 pesos pp with our own food.

name: Road block for money
description: Very long Road block. We passed in front on everybody by the left lane.  They ask for 500 pesos but they finally accept 200.  The other road to go to tonala was blocked too…

name: Shade
description: New restaurant in La Fortuna, decent prices, good food and drink, great view. Opens at 10am for breakfast.

name: Hotel Los Arcos
description: Lots of parking in secure courtyard. 3 of us who booked a room. Paid 650 peso. I don’t see any other notes from iOverlander for this town… I’m sure the owners would let RVs park here for a nominal fee

name: Hotel Las Palmas
description: Clean hotel on main road, secure parking. 2 double beds with wifi and ceiling fan were 400peso

name: Hotel Asuncion
description: Very budget hotel. Friendly staff. Secure motorcycle parking. Any other car will need to find parking. Lots paid lots in this area. Paid 330 for 2 double beds, 3 people. Good wifi for rooms if closer to front desk

name: Hotel Las Palmas
description: Got a room with 2 double beds and ac for 500. Very secure parking

name: Vidrio and Glass
description: Super cheap and fast glass shop. Got a new wing mirror cut for my 84 Dodge Ram b250 in less than 24 hours for 200mx. Guys are super knowledgeable and approachable

name: Thermal Pools Car Park
description: We arrived at 4.30 and paid for entrance to the park the following day as well as parking (150 pp + 30 parking) when we arrived at the Y in the road (left to go to river, waterfall, caves, formal campsite and right to go to thermal pools, suspension bridge) we went right and parked in the flat car at the end of the first bend. We have access to the pools today and tomorrow and parking until tomorrow without incurring the second day fee. The pools are 5min walk down the canyon perfect for first access in the morning. Maybe it was a mistake on the staff’s side but worth a shot for anyone else, beats the bud parking way up the hill. Great view of the canyon too. There are toilets and showers on the way down to the pools that you can access from the car park.

name: Hotel Los Pescadores
description: Martha from Black Dog Cycle Works told us about this cool little hotel! Super friendly owner (Patty) and nice staff. Check it out if you need to get off your bike or out of your camper for a bit!

name: Tixkokob
description: There is a place near the football player that you have water, it is not potable but you can use for another use, usefull

name: Shell Gas Station
description: Uninspired full service gas station setting with Oxxo. Large dirt area next to gas station serves as a truck stop. Filled up and parked not very level and quite noisy all night. Asked no permission and parked our van among trucks. Useful overnight spot. Strong Telcel signal for internet browsing.

name: Ichuña - behind the church
description: Nice spot behind the church, we stayed here several nights. We asked at the community building (on the Maine square, in front of the church) if we could stay here, no problem. It’s a small empty lot between a house and a wall, but they told us it belongs to nobody. Good for 1 big rig. There is also a possibility to stay overnight little further in the small road, aside the church. They told us we could choose. Very quiet, almost no vehicle passes here. A friendly lady knocked at our door, she was worried and asked if we had food, or if she could cook us a meal. Tip for big rigs: To reach this place, take the narrow unpaved side road to the right from the way out of the village, direction Puno. Don’t try to reach it from the main square.

name: Ichuña - typical village on the altiplano
description:
Icuña is a typical village on the Altiplano where in 2003 a university was opened, in cooperation with a Belgian organisation. We visited this small village in 2005 and were welcomed very warmly, visited the institute, the mayor and did an excursion together with the students. It was very interesting. 
Now we are in Peru again, we wanted to go there again and see the evolution. The village has grown a lot, people are still as friendly and welcoming, it’s still a traditional Altiplano village. They immediately organised for us a visit to the 2 different institutes they have now (pedagogic and technological), they organised meetings with the staff of both, who explained us about their institutions. We were invited by the mayor, and the day after at an event where students were involved, it was the last day of an environmental project that they did during 2 months of the holidays, planting trees in the whole region. It was an unforgettable experience.
People of the village are not used to see visitors, but they are very interested to meet more foreign people. 
The people of the institutions asked us to tell our friends and fellow travellers about their institutions. They like to invite them for a visit, they will be happy to have more international contacts. All visitors are very welcome, those who like to speak with students will be free to do so, even those who like teaching once or for a certain period will be very welcome. Accommodation can be organised.
Contact: Jenny (English teacher) jemazenteno@gmail.com 
or Wilmer (in Spanish) Wilmerr@gmail.com 
The mayor asked us to tell people about the village and the region. He wants to share the local culture with all visitors who are interested. 
Besides our visit to Ichuña, we also enjoyed a lot the very scenic road on the Altiplano. Although it was a very rough road, we will certainly pass there again, on our way up north.

name: Cowboy Garage Melaque
description: 3500 pesos or 150€ to change the clutch. We had the part from Switzerland. The snowbirds from Canada and USA recommended this garage to us. They are serious, and their price is correct compared to ours.

name: Baja Burro
description: Great place to have amazing tacos. They also have burritos and other things in the menu yet we have come here for years for the tacos. The family is very friendly and accommodating to our sometimes big group (during Baja 1000 race).

name: Bungalow Dorothy
description: Hotel block. Our basic en-suite room was 600 a night, comfy mattress and Tv with sky. Kitchens were available at extra cost. Lovely town full of Mexicans on holiday, worth a stay!

name: Nativo Restaurant
description:
Restaurant on the road, good food quality, cheap and good attention! With parking for big RV
Recommended
See pictures 


Restaurante en la carretera, buena calidad de alimentos, económico y buena atención! Tiene estacionamiento para grandes RV
Recomendado!

name: Gas station /water
description: Gas station. Vert friendly. You can ask for water

name: Alta Mecanica
description: Very friendly, helpful and professional mechanic. He helped us immediately and showed us everything in detail and explained what he had found out. The advice and work was excellent.

name: Pinturas
description: Ancient paintings on the rocks. Not perfect visible, but epic.

name: Hotel Leos
description: Nice, cheap hotel with comfortable rooms and secure parking. MXN 300 for a room with a fan for one person and 400 for a room with AC.

name: doble check point
description:
2 police check point . 1km between them. 
in palenque to Guatemala way the first one stop us because we don't have immatriculation plate on front. ask for were we are from, were we go. he wants to see our passeports. we give him some copies.
looks like he wants found "something" ask also multiple time to know if we are just the 2 of us.
at the end no problem. 
the second checkpoint watch more the other way.

name: Guanajuato overlook
description:
We reached the area in the early afternoon and after a nice hike in the surrounding desertic mountains, we went to Calderones, the next village, to buy groceries. The visit to the village was great, with very nice interactions in the tiendas.

We decided to set up camp next to the antenna towers which had the most accessible overlook of Guanajuato.

We set up cameras to capture timelapses of the sunset and city lights. By 10pm, we realized one of the cameras was missing. Checking the footage of the other, we realized someone had been creeping around our camping site for more than an hour, watching us from different directions and getting really close to our tent and gear.
After reviewing the footage, we quickly packed up and headed to the city to get a hotel room.
