name: Estacionamiento gratis
description:
Translation:Free parking with shade and 200 meters from the beach.  On unpaved street.  quiet at night
Estacionamiento gratuito con sombra y a 200metros de la playa. Sobre calle No asfaltada. Tranquilo de noche.

name: Pemex
description: Welcoming overnight on the road north, a sister station is also available on the south side. They were very welcoming, plenty of parking, great quick overnight among the way.

name: Estacionamento Guyacan
description:
Nice big shady parking secure parking lot, fairly quiet. Big rigs might struggle through the entrance, there’s a top strung sign. There was another sprinter here when we were there too. There is only a toilet, no shower (but has a hose that we used!). 5-10 minute safe walk to the market at the main square. Cool cafe/bar with wifi 2 doors down. Nice stay! 
Cost was $150 for the night (we paid 120, some wiggle room there). 
Call if you arrive at night: Whatsapp Marino +52 777 3067284

name: Casa Balam
description:
Dorm style hammocks with mosquito nets for 200$, camping out back in the cozy garden. 2 outdoor showers, 1 shared indoor. 
There’s composting and recycling and they press their own paper! 
No space for vans/rigs. I parked in front with my 4runner and it was tight

name: El Pinecate - Craters
description:
This is the only access to the El Pinecate craters at the moment. There has been a land dispute at the entry on Mex 8 and that dirt road is now blocked with boulders. 
Others have stated that you have to get a permit at the Schuk Toak visitor center on Mex 8. We were there but they didn't ask us to pay, they just gave us directions which I uploaded as screenshots. They did say we had to pay at the entrance on Mex 2 (this one), but there was nobody to collect the fee.

The craters are stunning and worth a visit! The road in is a dirt road, mostly washboard with some soft patches and loose rock. We drove in with our 2wd VW Crafter (Sprinter van), but there were locals with their city cars too. I wouldn't recommend anything bigger than a Sprinter van, it's a little narrow sometimes with prickly plants. 4x4 not necessary, a bit higher clearance than a regular city car is a plus.

name: Praça principal
description:
We spent the night in a street with no exit, opposite the tourist information point, with Wi-Fi, water and bathrooms.
....
Passamos a noite em uma rua sem saída, em frente o ponto de informações ao turismo, com dores Wi-Fi, água e banheiro.

name: Pemex
description: Big Pemex with lifesaving cold showers for free. Didn't attempt to spend the night as it's right between two fast roads and suspect would have been noisy - but very much appreciated use of their showers after a super sweaty 9-hr drive to the border!

name: Soriana/Cinemex car park
description:
Big car park on a very gentle slope. I found a spot under an overhanging tree at the back which gave perfect shade in the morning. Felt a little exposed once the cinema closed for the night and all the cars left - lights all got turned off around 1.40am and was very dark thereafter - but had a nice peaceful night. 

Swelteringly hot and humid while I was there - some 90% humidity! Note the free showers at the Pemex a couple of kms away!

Toilets in the Soriana during opening hours.

Free WiFi, average speed in the spot I was in.

name: ATM
description: There is an ATM inside this oxxo!

name: agua purificada inmaculada
description: 16 pesos por 20L de agua potable. they clean the bottle before refill. quick and easy. good service

name: Pemex
description: gaz station with bathroom, air and water

name: Lac promenade
description:
free overnight parking. big RV can easilly park here and then take colectivo to go to city center. we ask to stay for the  night at the office and they said yes, but don't park close to the building because of refill water truck.
Quiet night here. 4G is good

name: McDonald's
description: Free WiFi at McDonald's. accessible from the parking lot close to the building

name: Armed men
description: I tried to cross this dam during the evening, early April 2022 around 5pm solo on an obviously loaded overlanding motorcycle. A black truck with 4 armed men in the bed backed up to the north side of the dam as soon as I reached the bridge road over the dam from the south. They did not signal me in any way, but they immediately began shooting at me with rifles across the dam. I quickly turned around and went back up the hill, but they continued shooting until I was completely out of sight. Luckily they were 100+ meters away so they missed. There were no obvious signs that this area was dangerous or off limits before the truck of armed men came out of the woods. Avoid at all costs!

name: Parque Recreativo El Naranjo
description:
A local recommended this spot for camping, because they don't change entrance. and indeed, it is for free.
The place is full with locals during the afternoon and evening, and it might be hard to find a flat spot, but at very end of the parking area it's quite level. 
Later in the evening and morning, it was super quiet and peaceful, you will sleep with the sound of the water.
The water will be right next to your vehicle, it is an amazing place.

name: El Pinecate road block
description: Due to the land dispute discussed in other posts about the El Pinecate craters, this road is blocked with boulders. Do not try to pass. Coming from the south (Puerto Penasco) you have to go around via Mex 8 and Mex 2. Coming from the north (the craters) you will need to backtrack a mediocre, soft sand, dirt road.

name: San Ignacio Oasis
description: Just off Hwy 1, must stop here if passing through San Ignacio. Large open parking area next to the oasis with plenty of room to turn around and park big rigs for day activities. The oasis is directly accessible from the parking lot and you can swim. Beautiful spot, definitely stop even just to have a look if you are passing through on the Hwy 1.

name: café hôtel posada del rio
description: Nice little café with WiFi. good choice for refreshing beverage. enought place to park under the brige for long or tall camper

name: guarded parking
description:
parking lot 20 quetzales by car. 
closed at 10 pm when there is nobody. or 2am when people are here. ok to stay overnight when it's closed
little spot in front of multiple bars and restaurant. musique could be very loud late in night when it's week-end or day off (like semana santa when we are
there some shade, little beach (not really clean) and a recreation water parc open between 9am and 5pm.
for us music start again at 7am the next morning, so for us it's too noise for what we like.
good spot if you wanna eat, dance and have fun with local.
WiFi  restrooms in restaurants

name: Estacionamiento Veracruz
description: A big, shady parking lot right in the center of town. Mike the owner is incredibly nice, speaks great English. Doors open from 8-8pm. He and his family live here. Clean bathroom. charged us $150 for about 24hrs. Surprisingly quiet on a Friday night.

name: Rocky Beach Camping
description:
Great camping spot right in a rocky/sandy beach. Beautiful bay with turquoise warm water, the bottom is all sand.

No hookups or bathrooms or anything but had cell service, it was quiet, and what a beautiful spot!

Not much privacy at the beach spots so you need to walk back to the bushes if you want privacy when going to the bathroom.

Can get a bit windy here but it wasn’t too bad when we were here. Got a little windy early morning.

name: Puerto Santo Tomas
description: Campsites on the beach! $16/night.  Bathrooms too.  All good out here.

name: Vital Agua Purificadora
description:
Large purificadora with plenty of space to pull over on the side of a wide road. You have to stick your containers entertainingly through a little hole at the base of the wall, then go in and pay the cashier. Charged me $10 for 22l of water in odd-sized bottles.

Open 7am till 5pm, Monday to Saturday, according to the sign on the wall - though I turned up at 20 past 5pm on Saturday and they were still going.

name: Pizzeria Camping
description: Alma Pizzeria - Space for a few vans at 150 MXN per vehicle per night, as well as cabinas for rent (don't know the price). Clean bathroom with hot shower. Friendly and helpful owners. The pizza at the restaurant here is really good!

name: Tenango De Arista Hotel
description:
I wasn’t too sure about this hotel from the outside, as there does even appear to be a name, just a huge Hotel sign, but I arrived late and was desperate. Great hotel! Just $250MEX solo. Big double room with a good hot shower. Nice firm bed and pillows.

The door locks on the inside, but there is no key. The guy downstairs didn’t seem to think one was needed, and I wasn’t too worried, as rooms are internal.

There was a descent sized walled car park from what I could see too.

I don’t worry about wifi, so don’t know if it has it or not.

name: AV.88 Snacks & Coffee
description:
The town isn’t much to write home about, but this coffee joint really stands out. Their burritos are US style; a choice of meat with rice, cheese, and salad all wrapped up. They are a decent size too.

They also list pancakes with eggs and bacon which looks pretty good for breakfast.

Other than that there are sandwiches, hamburgers (inc chicken), pasta, and some more local dishes.

name: Hotel Juarez
description:
Great budget hotel option right in the zocalo. Basic room with comfy bed, en-suite, and pedestal fan. Hot water and wifi all fine.

Bicycles were fine to take into the room, but you may have to lift them over the bed to find a good spot to situate them.

name: La Mina Birrieria
description:
We've been almost 3 months in Baja and this is easily top three tacos we have eaten, and we eat tacos every couple days hahaha.

Only open weekends, but fantastic birria.  We had 2 quesedillas/quesotaco (tons of meat) a consome and a coke for 145 pesos.

name: Pemex
description:
Another pemex right on toll road 150D going north only.
Pemex guy and the Parking attended was friendly, but they do charge 50pesos to stay the night between trucks. Felt safe.
It's very loud since trucks use loud breaks coming down the hill. would only recommend with enclosed van/rv.
Coffee shop on site that has wifi

name: La Gaviota
description: Great food, not expensive, open 2-10 every day except Thursday. Best food we had in LB!

name: La Cabaña del Cava - Fresh juices and smoothies
description: Wonderful fresh juices and smoothies. Best we’ve had in Baja! The man working there is so sweet and will answer any questions around ingredients! Juices were $50 pesos each.

name: Community Toll before Las Nubes
description:
Right before reaching Las Nubes, locals have placed a rope across the road & are asking for a toll to enter, which apparently supports road maintenance. They requested 100p per person, but we gave 80p total and they seemed happy enough. 

For what it’s worth: if you camp at the first site labeled on iOverlander (slightly south of the Centro Ecoturístico), you actually avoid this toll AND get to camp for free.

name: Tacos Miranoa
description: Awesome taco stand, super busy and lots of toppings!

name: Canto del agua
description: Rooms only but a fairy-tale like spot down at the river. Highly recommend.

name: Assault at Hotel El Mirador / Corrupt Police
description: Locals staying at the hotel drugged and attempted to assault my travel partner and assaulted me when I intervened. The police then came and I was taken to jail with no reason given, leaving my partner to stay at the hotel next door to her assaulters. She was not told where I was taken and the police did not give me food, water, or a phone call during my stay while others in the cell were given those things. My partner was forcibly removed from the hotel in the morning by staff. Avoid.

name: Hierve el Agua
description:
Wonderful beautiful circular trail about 4 kilometers. Unique is the petrified waterfall, which also formed some pools. After the round tour a wonderful cooling. Entrance fee is 50 pesos per person.
The approach is from Mitla on a dirt road over a pass about 2300m high about 15 kilometers costs 15 pesos per person.
Many cabs and colectivos go there.
It may be possible to spend the night in the car in the parking lot, we did not ask.

name: Hierve el Agua
description:
Wonderful beautiful circular trail about 4 kilometers. Unique is the petrified waterfall, which also formed some pools. After the round tour a wonderful cooling. Entrance fee is 50 pesos per person.
The approach is from Mitla on a dirt road over a pass about 2300m high about 15 kilometers costs 15 pesos per person.
Many cabs and colectivos go there.
It may be possible to spend the night in the car in the parking lot, we did not ask.

name: Street Parking
description: We tried parking right on the beach but got stuck in sand. It looks solid but its not. Fortunately, a group of Good Samaritans helped pull us out with their truck! We circled around and decided to park at the end of this dirt street under a few palm trees that were growing on an undeveloped lot, a few meters from where we got stuck. Police drove by several times on the beach but did not ask us to move our rig. Nice ocean breeze at night and no mosquitos. Close to bars, restaurants and lots of yoga studios.

name: Mariscos Las Carretas de los Fernandez
description: Small quirky taco shack under new ownership. We had lots of great fish tacos in Baja but these were worth mentioning, you get an entire fillet of fish per taco and it is breaded, not just battered like most. The tacos are like 5% taco and 95% fish, which is amazing. They also serve really good horchata (sweet Mexican rice milk) which goes down great on a hot day. Owner speaks great English and was very friendly. Worth checking out.

name: Town Plaza
description: Town square, gazebo in center, workout stations!  Across the street from the Catholic Church Rectory.  Seems like a safe neighborhood. A lot of roosters crowing. A good place for the night, if you are crossing the border (40km) in the morning.

name: Sierra Inn and small Camper parking
description:
This is a decent hotel right beside the road. They let us park our pickup camper in the parking area for the night for free. We would have stayed in a room but they don't take dogs. Rooms looked fine though at 650peso/2pax. Wifi if staying at hotel, and good there's TelCel and AT&T
Villa Ahumada seems famous for it's burritos so we ate at the fun food court beside the hotel

name: Laguna RV Park
description: $10 for dump $5 for water, very convenient

name: paquimé
description:
Excellent stopover in a pretty Pueblo, with the authorization of the police, just in front of the church where we attended the religious service, the priest came to shake hands with us as a sign of welcome. Very quiet, security. We had a little BBQ in the parking lot. Restaurants nearby
---
Excellente étape dans un joli Pueblo, avec l'autorisation de la police, juste devant l'église ou nous avons assisté à l'office religieux, le curé est venu nous serrer la main en signe de bienvenu. Très tranquille, sécurité. Nous avons fait un petit BBQ sur le parking. Restaurants à proximité

name: casares
description: overnight parking with water and garbage dump

name: East Cape Glamping, at La Fortuna
description: Nice camping with facilities, and all services plus lunch place.

name: Gringo Burger
description: Tiny burger joint on the side of the mountain road. Good food, good prices. Get the Gringo Burger :)

name: Parque Las Peñas de Dexcani Alto
description:
I paid 25 pesos to drive through the gate, and park in a large gravel parking lot. There are bathrooms and plenty of space for tents. The gatekeeper came around in the morning to collect 25 more Pecos. 

On the weekends many people visit, but they are long gone before night, and on Sunday more people didn't show up until after 10:00am. I am surprised this place isn't on here already, it's a perfect spot for Vans, cars, and tent camping.

name: Hotel Media Luna parking lot/campsite
description: You can park at the hotel and spend the night there for $150 pesos and they give you access to the pool, bathroom, showers, restaurant..... next door you have the Diving center. They also have a campsite but only for tents.

name: Hotel Madero
description: Basic hotel, room has a shower and bed. Not the cleanest but okay for a night. Some Off street parking. Felt safe.

name: Augusta waterfall
description:
We managed to get here with our little camper, but only 4x4 will work as the road is very bad.
.....
Conseguimos chegar aqui com nossa casinha, mas só chega de 4x4 a estrada é bem ruim.

name: Mirante
description:
We spent the night here and it was amazing, the moon was stunning. Only accessible with 4x4.
.....
Passamos a noite aqui e foi incrível, a lua estava deslumbrante, só se chega de 4x4.

name: Pull out
description: Large pullout. highway noise and trash. Good for a quick night's rest.

name: Love's Travel Stop
description: propane and a dump station for $10 and gas and food

name: La Esperanza
description: It’s a beautiful place to stay. really nice and very comfortable. we love this place. and you can also eat very cheap and delicious. We would like to stay more time. The rent is cheap. Also OK, if you have tent.

name: Rufina
description: Nice cafe with an extensive menu for breakfast and lunch. Lots of healthy options,  sandwiches and salads are awesome! Has wifi also.

name: Beach Showers
description: Two outdoor showers located under the palm trees. good pressure too.

name: Grass field
description: Beautiful spot in between 2 dirt roads, only a few minutes away from the #1 Hwy. We entered an open gate and drove down a dirt and a bit bumpy road, no 4wd needed, big RVs might have trouble to get here though. Nice view, no noise. A few cars drove by in the evening and in the morning and waved us. We asked one of them about sleeping here and he said "no problems, very safe place".

name: Campamento Las Brisas
description: Best of the best that I found in this area. Just steps from the amazing river here. A less populated campground with beautiful mountain views, mango and banana trees. I have the place to myself. Not exactly big rig friendly but I made it in my truck camper 10ft tall /21 long. Plenty of room with a grassy field and lots of shade parking. 70p, no hook ups. See for yourself, you won't be disappointed.

name: Convento San Bernardo
description: Parking spots nearby the convento San Bernardo. No amenities whatsoever but very convenient to spend a night and attend the night show that takes place every night at 9.00pm. Noisy in the morning but quiet night all together.

name: El Bosquecito
description:
If you can't bear the stifling heat and humidity of Tapachula, this is a literal breath of fresh air. Rustic campsite, popular with local people on weekends and holidays. $10 to park for the day, after some consideration they charged me $50 for the night. Flattish field with pine trees on one side, under which are benches and tables, BBQ grills and space for hammocks etc. Bucket flush toilets, a small restaurant and tiendita, they also rent a bunch of stuff, from hammocks to balls, at reasonable prices. It's on the slopes of the volcano with good views up on a clear day.

I believe it's possible to hire a guide for the trek up from here if you wish - 7 or 8 hours to a campsite below the summit, an hour and a half or so to the crater from there, then back down - so a two-day trip total - they quoted $3000.. apparently possible to do without guide, ideally around December when there are lots of people hiking - but they warned me that the cost of a rescue is closer to $10,000!

Not really set up for vehicles I think - the road is accessible but a little steep and rough towards the end - they asked me to move my van away from the trees once I was up, and park it over in the far corner.

What sporadic phone reception there is, comes from the Guatemalan side, so unless you have an active Guatamala SIM it's not much use to you. Mexican signal in Union Juarez below. Check out the mirador in Cordoba, and if you want to stretch your legs there's a shortish but steepish hike through the jungle down to a small waterfall from there too. Pity the folk who commute to and from school and work from there daily!

name: Pepsol Gas Station
description: Saw a Pepsol gas station that hadn't been marked. Felt people should know about gas in this area. Attached Oxxo. About $22Mex per.

name: Gravel Road
description:
This is a camp spot we found after pulling off the Mex 1 onto a gravel road. A few yards after pulling off the 1, we went over a cattle grate. We passed several small pull outs along this road but took the gravel road about 1 km back to get a spot with less trash. 

Great site for camping over night. Quiet and not a lot of noise from the highway. Also far enough back, so you are out of view. We are camping in a truck and we were able to reach this site w/o using 4 wheel drive. Site would work great for camper vans and such. RVs might work if on the smaller size.

name: Tika Aya Restaurant
description: Superb little very Authentic Oaxaca Restaurant. 8 course Taster menu. Every dish Superb. . Highly recommended experience. Service Quality  and presentation Excellent

name: Leather Shop
description:
Old historic leather maker where he raises his own cows for their hides and tans his own leather and also makes saddles. Has a small shop with belts, purses, shoes, koozies and will do custom orders if you have a couple of days to wait. His work is absolutely beautiful and quality, much prefer his detailed work than what you find in some of the tourist shops in town. We wish we had a few extra days to have a custom pouch made for our tablet. No English. 
Directions to find: Right before you reach Miraflores and their welcome sign, on the left side on a small hill a white concrete building with metal roof and collections of cars and tires in front that looks like it's abandoned, but it's not. His shop is usually open around 10am and if he's not there he is tending his cows and will leave someone there that may speak some English.

name: Aceites y Lubricantes Riva
description:
Nice guy, brought my own filters and oil, charged me 100p for labor

He has filters and oil as well for sale

name: Hot Dog Restaurant
description: Nondescript little hot dog stand, about 100 feet south of here. Classic, cheap, and good Mexican street food. Seemed *very* popular with locals and multiple passing truckers. It was open for a late dinner around 10:00PM. A classic Mexican street dog, with all the toppings, was 25 pesos. Some locals also got a beef burrito looking thing that looked excellent.

name: Muelle de Catazaja
description:
Translation: Its boardwalk and docks are very picturesque. It is a very small town. Some afternoons there is live marimba. People are very friendly and looking to chat. The weather is hot during the day but generally cool at night. The water is earth-colored and you can swim in few places. It is possible to embark and get to know the streams that are full of beautiful birds and you can see some crocodiles diving. The sunsets on the pier are exceptional. It is a paradise if you have the capacity for enjoyment. We slept with the doors of the Camper open next to the lagoon and nobody and nothing has bothered us for a week. The police came just to greet us and tell us local stories. I wish they could come and enjoy how simple and harmonious this place is. Perfect to relax. If you have a hammock, it can even be placed on top of the dock. Other travelers pitched tents under the roof of the pier and at the end of the road without being bothered by anyone. There is very short grass between the lagoon and the houses to walk with puppies or with the family. Honey, I hope you enjoy it as much as we do.

Su malecón y muelles son muy pintorescos. Es un pueblo muy pequeño. Algunas tardes hay marimba en vivo. Las personas son muy amigables y buscan conversar. El clima es caliente de día pero fresco de noche en general. El agua es color tierra y se nada en pocos lugares. Es posible embarcarse y conocer los arroyos que están plagados de bellas aves y se puede ver algunos cocodrilos sambullirse. Los atardeceres en el muelle son excepcionales. Es un paraíso si tienes la capacidad de disfrute. Dormimos con las puertas de la Camper abiertas al lado de la laguna y nadie ni nada nos ha incomodado en una semana. La policía llegó solo a saludarnos y contarnos anécdotas locales. Ojalá pudieran venir y disfrutar de lo simple y armonioso que este lugar. Perfecto para relajarse. Si tienes una hamaca, se puede colocar inclusive arriba del muelle. Otros viajeros armaron carpas bajo el techo del muelle y al final del camino sin que nadie los incomodara. Hay pasto muy corto entre la laguna y las casas para pasear con perritos o en familia.Cariños, ojalá lo disfruten cómo nosotros.

name: Authentico Mexico
description:
Translation: Martin can welcome you with your RV in his street. it is useful for filling up with water, wifi, poste restante (for Amazon orders), mechanics, DIY. Very nice for a stopover.

Martin peut vous accueillir avec votre RV dans sa rue. il rend service pour le plein d'eau, le wifi, poste restante (pour des commandes Amazon), mécanique, bricolage. Très sympa pour faire une halte.

name: Booze Station
description: Best bar to visit. Perfekt drinks on the sidewalk. Good meszcal, good music and such a nice owner. He’s always up for a nice chat (Spanish/ English) Go there!

name: Camping Dhipak
description:
Great family run campground right in Aquismón. Best suited for vans and smaller rigs, but if you are big and in a bind they will call their neighbor and you can park in the empty lot next door and they'll run an extension cord for your electric. Will cost you a bit extra (you have to pay the neighbor, too), but still reasonable. 100 pesos per person for the regular campground, has good shade, showers, electric, good Verizon/Telcel service, some tables and chairs and bbqs.

Also they helped me find an awesome and affordable mechanic who came to the campground and fixed me up. Highly recommend.

name: Desierto Azul Expeditions
description: They have trips to Isla espiritu santo by boat, where you can swim with sea lions, senderism near balandra area, and whale shark when its the season, yo have too book at least 24 hours before, via instagram or facebook, you can find them as desierto azul expeditions, david the guide was great! very helpful too learn more about the history of La Paz.

name: mecanco Richard especial suspensiones
description:
Combi suspension specialist mechanic
 excellent attention
 fair price and lets you sleep in the workshop and use its bathroom and shower
--------
mecanico especialista en suspensiones de combi 
excelente atención 
precio justo y te deja dormir en el taller y hacer uso de su baño y regadera

name: Mike parking
description:
Excellent place
 super nice person
 free
-----
excelente lugar 
persona super agradable 
free

name: parque de los bomberos
description:
it is a great place to spend the night
 very quiet and safe and it's free
 It has a game for the children
-----
es un excelente lugar para para pasar la noche 
muy tranquilo y seguro y es gratis 
tiene juego para los.niños

name: casa familiar Vargas
description:
it is a house of a family that receives travelers
They can support you if you need to do some repairs in your mobile home
-----
es una casa de una famila que recibe viajeros 
te pueden apoyar si ocupas hacer alguna compostura en tu casa rodante

name: Free camping near sea
description:
You can stay anywhere on this coast, it's quiet, peaceful, no people. There are exits from the road, small areas between the road and the sea. You can often find shelters with palm leaf roofs for shade. 
For one night is a great place.
In the sea we did not swim very stony shore.

name: Overland center Puerto Morelos
description:
Overland center Puerto Morelos is a travellers assistance center. 

we are very happy to have discovered it during our world tour. Real overland center like it misses on the road. 

Vehicle storage, shower, mechanical assistance, wifi, water, mailing address, street camping and much more.  Repair workshop for your camper.  fiberglass, carpentry, metal job, infiltration.  

the owner, Mart is Canadian. real vanlife and travel enthusiast.  he will surely help you as much as he did with us.  he helped us a lot to adjust our vehicle before Central America.  he even had campers for sale for travelers.  call him before arriving to find out if he can help you 55-1237-8557 and Whatsapp

name: Martin El Gordo
description:
multi brand mechanic shop but specializes in vw sedan and knows about combis.
------
taller de mecánica multi marca pero se especializa en vw sedan y sabe de combis.

name: Minerals and Gems
description: Next to the entrance leading up to El Puente and the mines is a local store selling rocks and minerals. Very friendly owner has space for one campervan or a few tents. We could stay there for free, but bought some interesting rocks from him. Toilet and showers available. It's close to the road, but no traffic during the night.

name: 5 Tacos and a Beer
description: Good selection of cheap pork, carne, and vegetarian tacos. Margaritas are great. Overall great flavor and great value. Can’t beat $1 Taco Tuesday

name: La Gran Torta
description: Best al pastor tortas!!! An establishment in the city. Yum yum yum! Some unique salsas on the tables with them, the yellow and red ones are super good. They have daily specials, Tuesday’s was 3 tortas for 70 pesos. Look up and see if the balcony table is open, nice view of the street! (They also sell tacos and other things)

name: Bakery Rovianda Plus Madero
description: Amazing huge bakery! Lots of fresh selection. Also has a deli and some specialty sauces and fun treats!

name: Violently robbed
description: By a group of 20 men and 2 women. No cellphone reception so no help.

name: Propane station
description: Propane fill up station. There is one on each side of the road. On the west side of the road, it’s behind the concrete brick wall.

name: Lakeside spot
description: Peaceful, safe, family-oriented wild camping with a few other locals. All spaced out around the lake. A local told us to go here, when we entered at Brockman.

name: Showers
description:
Showers and bathroom in a campground. 
$20 p/p

name: Roadside car camping
description:
A wide dirt road, next to the main road. I have a smaller truck, so I parked alongside the mural, over the wall from the hotel. I saw semi trucks overnight parked in the big dirt lot right across the street, so that might be an option for bigger rigs. Wasn't bothered by anybody.
Normally I wouldn't mark this spot down, but the other overnight spots in the city seem to have issues. There's probably better street camping spots somewhere in the city, but this worked when it was dark and I needed a spot in a pinch.
If you want free parking and have daylight hours left, I'd encourage people to check out the marked dune camping clusters, 15 minutes north or south of the city.

name: Bull run regional park
description: large park very quite at night. no sign of no camping

name: La Casa Palma
description: Is a food Truck from an Argentinian couple that sell piza and pasta. Is a really good option to chill out, eat cheap and overlander are welcome. There is a huge mural with full of colours in front of the house

name: Centro Cultural El Brazo Fuerte
description: There are movies everyday at 8 p.m. for $25 and workshop and art show. Fredy and Carla, the owner are really friendly and they22 offer you a shower!! So It's worth knowing

name: Near san everesto
description: great quite spot,  need 4x4 to get down to the beach but can be 2 wd if stay upper beach. go trough the salt field.

name: Laundry Mama Maria
description:
Great laundry, $20 mx per kg.
Owner very friendly. 
Wash dry, complete service 
See the pictures for rates !

name: Soriana Parking Lot
description:
Giant parking lot in front of Soriana. Good free location for malecon, resturants, shops, etc. Stayed here one night, no issues, security friendly.

The Taquiria San Pablo across street to north is best al pastor in mexico!

name: Mechanico y Autopartes Ortiz
description:
My belt and tensor went out on my promaster and I was having issues with power steering, ignition, and ac. I also needed a oil change, general inspection, and tire rotation.

The tensor for my promaster did not exist in mexico and the only solution was pay 700 usd and wait two weeks. I asked if they could find a better solution and after calling and poking around, they found a brand new one off a jeep with same engine for 250 usd, to be installed the next day.Total I spent about 350 usd for the new belt, tensor, and 6l of good synthetic oil and the installation. I provided filter.

With belt off, it was not safe to drive so I camped on street out front. Zero issues.

name: Pemex/Akron
description: Camped here one night after getting in late from GDL. GN was parked so felt very safe. Decent mexico gas station bathrooms. There was a free open wifi network by the blue building on east side of station.

name: Street Parking in Roma Norte
description:
Paid street parking 0800-2000 mon-sat. It is roughly 50 pesos for 6hrs of parking. You can pay at stations or via app. You can pay after 2000 for the next morning. You can only pay for 6hrs max in one sitting

Excellent location with great food and bars and next to metro for exploring CDMX. If you time meters and use app, you can stay here for days with no issues. 

Free decent wifi throughout neighborhood.

Note: make sure you pay. Failure to pay will result in getting booted and a huge hassle. The only bribe I had to pay in mexico was when I snoozed my 0745 alarm to feed meter and I woke up to being booted at 0815. I paid to get boot off (700p on street vs 1000p at office and wait hours for them show up to remove it). Cop was very firm.

name: Aduana if heading west to Tabasco from Chiapas or Yucatan
description: All vehicles headed west from Yucatan/QRoo/Chiapas must clear Mexican customs here, even if you never left Mexico. They will demand to see TIP and may even do a thorough search of van! Make sure you know this ajd hide ajy goodies very well when traveling west from the Yucatan or Palenque!

name: street parking
description: Overnite street parking in front of the Science Museum.  Relatively quiet.  Museum has 24hr  wifi, opens at 10am.

name: Weird traffic lights
description: The traffic lights are weird moving pictures in this town. Almost missed the first red one. Keep an eye out.

name: Tacos el Poblano
description: My favourite tacos in Baja so far, and we have eaten nothing but tacos for two weeks! No fish, but carne asada and chorizo, the latter was my favourite. They have corn and flour Tortillas, flour was great, didn't try the corn. Great value ($30mxn per). They have basic baños. Eat in or take out. 10/10

name: Carnitas Los Michoacanos La Rivera
description: These guys do a whole pig roast on Saturday and Sunday with crackling, rinds and tacos. It is only open Saturday and Sunday. It is a brightly coloured spot on the main drag. If you are here on the weekend, definitely stop in. On Google it says they close around 1730, however we were here on a Sunday and they close at 1630! Enjoy!

name: Bar
description: Great bar. $15 peso beers. Come here to have fun

name: El Jardín de Karmitha
description:
This place is really amazing. 
I was unfortunate to spend 12 days in the hospital after an accident. After that, I booked a stay in Karmitha's garden on Airbnb to recover before my flight back home.
Karmitha is just an angel, she helped me sooo much... she is so disinterested and kind. Making me tea, giving me organic fruits from her garden... Organizing my taxi to the airport, organizing cleaning of my wounds. She has lots of contact and she is willing to help at all time.
Comfortable room, king size bed. 
Amazing garden, stunning flowers everywhere, so relaxing with the little pools.
Kitchen available for you to cook, secure parking as well. Karmitha also owns an organic estetician/SPA thing. Totally recommend and ridiculously cheap for what you get (around $12 a night).

name: Orilla de playa
description:
Very nice place, steps from the sea, a beautiful view, suitable for staying big and small cars, good internet signal, excellent place for one or several nights, next to Las Palmas Restaurant, and an RV where there are bathrooms and showers with hot water, 10 and 15 pesos
....muy agradable lugar, a pasos del mar, una hermosa vista, adecuado para quedarse autos grandes y chicos, buena señal de internet, excelente lugar para una o varias noches, a un lado de Restaurante las Palmas, en seguida un RV dónde hay  baños y regaderas con agua caliente, 10 y 15 pesos

name: RV Park and campground
description: Wonderful family run place right on a gorgeous river. No hookups, but they do have running water, toilets, and showers. they also provide drinking water and will cook meals for you for a small extra fee. It's not too far down a dirt road, totally worth it, close to lots of waterfalls. No cell service, no wifi.

name: Tiny Oak Farm
description: Super nice family run place.  Casual and laid back environment , friendly atmosphere, fire pits, music, farm animals, plenty of tranquil space to lounge, space for children to run and play.

name: Oaxaca
description:
A parking place in the city center. 
Suitable for Big rig  and storage, covered. Max hight 3.9 meters. 210 pesos per 24 hours for big rig, guarded all time, closed on Sundays  but one can leave car inside, it will be open again on Sunday night

name: Hamburguesas El Gallo
description: Awesome little hamburger and taco stand right off the route! Easy pull off to stop, great service!

name: Villa Olaya
description:
6 charming rooms available (2 in individual cabañas) and camping space available at the entrance of the land. The owners Virma and Miguel as well as their kids are amazingly friendly. We arrived 2 nights ago as I write and will end up staying 2 weeks.
Camping is 100 pesos per person. Bathroom by the pool (small and cute).
Can come to eat only at lunch time.
Road to the villa is asphalt. Steep leaving Xilitla, slow slope for the rest of the road.
Surrounded by nature and views of the mountains on the road.
Will update as we stay.

name: hotel El Senador
description:
Nice hotel, well located, nest value for your buck. paid 35$ CAD 
king size bed, clean and large room, secure parking can accomodate the biggest rigs.

name: Las guacamayas
description: This is a brand new restaurant that just opened. Had amazing service. They have a restaurant in Cabo and we tried it. So happy they opened a new place in la Ventana. Fairly priced, if you are looking for authentic Mexican food this is the place to go.

name: dead fish  alley beach
description: 4x4 needed,  soft beach driving, not easy to get to. very remote, stunning beaches , and small cliffs....only small trucks recommended

name: VendoGas (Estación de gas "Sumidero")
description:
After going to both GASCOM posted on iOverlander. We finally got our (American) tank filled at this location. The guy said he didn't have  the connection for this tank, but after taking it out, he tried with another connection and it worked!!! we were so worried that we weren't gonna find a place around. the coordinates are very close to the point but in case type on Google maps "VendoGas (Estación de gas "Sumidero")
 29010, Calz. al Sumidero 357, Nueva Delicias, Tuxtla Gutiérrez, Chis.

name: El Arca de Los Bichos
description: Vet services open 24/7 every day of the year for emergencies and routine services. Facebook page often advertises free rabies shots but I didn’t need that so I’m not sure how often that is available. They administered a bordetella booster for my dog one day after being contacted, 350 pesos. Email arcadelosbichos@hotmail.com, WhatsApp 967 135 9165.

name: Chamaki Parking Lot
description: Small parking lot, 5 minutes walking from main square. Ask for Edgar, very friendly owner that will let you camp for a small rate. The place has Toilets but no showers yet, but he is working on it. Gate is closed during the night. Better for small rigs, class B (Vans) or smaller.

name: Street Parking near cathedral
description: Street Parking very close to downtown behind a beautiful colonial cathedral. Only small vehicles max 7meters.

name: Paid parking lot next to popular San Jose Del Cabo street
description: Paid parking next to Blvd Antonio Mijares, very popular tourist spot. We asked if we can stay overnight and they said it was ok. 30pesos for day and night, we tipped an extra 1usd to the lady taking the money. Stop by Abbys restuarant for an awesome meal and wifi. If you park by their spot on the far wall you can get their wifi in your van.

name: International dealership Canada La Paz
description: International diesel repair shop. Our parking break actuator was messed up and we had recently got it fixed in Canada at an international dealership. We went here, they diagnosed the issue very fast and ordered the part immediately. Also did our coolant flush. Great great people, some soeak enough English to communicate

name: City Sushi / Torimeshi Sushi
description: AMAZING sushi patio. Not touristy. Locals eat here. Prices are phenomenal and the vibes are great. Really recommend it. There is a big parking lot and lots of street parking nearby

name: Great laundry place
description: Great clean laundry place. Did probably about 5 loads of laundry for 500 pesos. All of it was really neatly folded. Next day turn around

name: Restaurant Sazon Veracruzano
description: We had dinner at the restaurant Sazon Veracruzano and they let us stay for the night at their parking lot. They have wifi and we had access on the parking lot, plus they gave us a bit of water for our tank.

name: Playa el faro
description: We didn't camp there because we only discovered this place after a few days in Chacahua. Seems to be a nice place to do some wild camping in front of the beach el faro. We saw 2 motorhomes staying there.

name: Alameda de Arteaga
description: Arteaga is one of the pueblos magicos of Mexico and the main square is very nice to park a van, except on Sundays, when a famous market happens. Also, the weather is usually a little bit colder than Saltillo, so very nice to avoid the heat.

name: Taqueria Los Pioneros
description: Tastiest tacos in town, open only for breakfast until 2pm. I recommend the Barbacoa tacos and tacos de cachete.

name: Parking San Agustin Waterfalls
description:
After we visited the beautiful waterfalls we asked the parking lot staff if we could spend the night here in the van. They said yes, we paid the entrance fee of 100 pesos for two people for the next day and could stay overnight.
At night we were alone.
No wifi and no telcel signal.

name: Purificadora “El Capitan”
description: They are very friendly and can connect YOUR hose. Easy parking in front of the place.

name: la tiendita
description: camping and restaurant. nice place to sleep or eat. Just side the River. beatiful decorated. nice coffee

name: Llantera Mulege
description: Place to repare or change tires. We had a flat tire and the guy repared it for 100 pesos, very nice guy.

name: Fishermen beach
description:
Large place, easy to access (we had a little car), very quiet. We have spent a cool night (finally!) here in tent. Some fishermen on the early morning. Negative point : a lot of trash .

———————————————————

Grande place, facile d'accès (nous avions une petite voiture), tranquille. On a passé une nuit au frais (enfin!) dans notre tente. Quelques pécheurs tôt le matin. Point négatif : beaucoup de déchets.

name: Family vet
description:
Bring my puppy for dewormed and do a health certificate to cross to USA by Colombia brigde.

Certificate cost 150pesos. 

Can communicate in english a little bit. Very friendly.

name: Pracinha
description:
We spent the night here, facing the square, I asked for the Wi-Fi password at the bar and we were very quiet.
.....
Passamos a noite aqui, de frente para a praça , pedi a senha Wi-Fi no bar e ficamos bem tranquilos.

name: pacific coast
description: Super remote, hard to get to too, endless camping opportunities along the coast, great sunset, cold when windy, bring fire wood.

name: Iran, Kashan
description: Nice family house with perfect people. 11$ for your room, with shower. Garage for motorcycle

name: Poohsho camp
description: We were settled in here for one night alone. Saturday another carload showed up. Then another, then another. At dark a motorcycle showed up. Motorcycles are not allowed in the park. Bonfires are not allowed. Huge bonfire. Ultimately 15 people invaded our camp. The camps above and below are empty.  Welcome to Mexico.

name: Grande Camp
description: This is a large area to camp with 3 nice palapas. There are 2 large shelters. You park just outside and take your stuff into this camping area.

name: El Alcazar
description: Basic camp with tent places and latrine. Can walk to the peak from here.

name: Tacos
description: Best street food tacos (only evening). Fabulous chorizo and beef tacos on a street food stand. Super reasonable prices, 15 Pesos each. Opens around 5pm. Place where the locals go.

name: Hotel Terreza Del Sol
description:
Decent hotel right on the coast. 500MXN (asked 600), breakfast included, for a room with a/c, king bed, tv, private bath.

Large secure parking in basement for 12+ vehicles, 2.3m (7ft) height restriction 

3 pools on the 2nd level (2 at 1.2m deep, 1 kid pool 0.5m deep)

Interesting city. Lots of abandoned hotels/buildings intertwined with nice restaurants and stores. I actually quite enjoyed the unique contrast. Beautiful coastline (though I heard they (at least used to) dump raw sewage directly into the beach)

name: Mediterráneo: El Puerto del Atún
description: Great burger & hotdog place. I don't know what they do to burgers in Mexico, but they're always fantastic, and this place is no different. I got the Americano beef burger and it was delicious

name: REPSOL Gas Station
description: Beware of fuel scams here! We made the mistake of looking away for just a moment to remove our spare tanks, and the 2 men filling blanked out the fuel pump. They then claimed the power went out to the pump and we owed then 2000P. We insisted on a receipt, we knew they hadn't filled that much based on the fuel level. after 20 minutes of arguing a receipt was magically produced, showing our total of just 1000P. After some more arguing and insisting to pay by CC we were able to leave, and not get scammed! but beware!! Like all fuel stations, watch your pump closely, and always insist on proof of the amount distributed!!

name: Brisa del Mar RV park
description:
Lovely, new RV park with approx 8 spots for smaller rigs. Spots are level, gravel w/cement pads set for truck tires. 
The owner, Captain Vic & his wife Gloria are phenomenal. Amazingly accommodating, especially for our overland rigs (excited to check out our setups). They graciously let us use plenty of water to rinse all of the salt off of our vehicles & even drove into town to pick up some pizzas for us. 
The establishment is new, still some construction to do (Vic was painting when we rolled up). Hot showers, pool, Wi-Fi, outdoor kitchen, BBQ, clean restrooms, roof-top deck (adding sun shades soon). We’ll absolutely come back if we’re ever in town. Great view of the sea!

name: Beto and Chario’s cabañas
description:
Beto and Chario are the owner of this place. They’ve a few cabins, and and unbelievable place for staying in San Blas. 

We stayed three nights on their parking lot with our van. It’s not a place for big rigs, but if you have a van or similar you should come here.

150 pesos per person, and you get a pretty decent WIFI and extremely clean bathrooms and showers.

Beto and Chario are super nice and friendly. They’ll help you with anything

This is a gem in San Blas

name: Cactus Jack
description: Easy 2wd dirt road that goes out of the highway and has plenty of nice spots for the night. Some turns are a bit sharp, might be a problem for big RVs. Surrounded by cacti. Nice sunset.

name: Hotel Dorado
description:
Nice hotel, 540 single 610 double, see pics for all prices. Pretty spacious, incredibly clean, a/c, tv, comfy bed.

Very large secure parking with no height restriction. They might even let you sleep in your camper out there if you ask- they have the space!

name: Don Tomas Viñedo
description: Full service vineyard with restaurant and glamping, very nice place and not horribly expensive.

name: Rancho Campanario Gadiel and Juana
description:
The house of Gadiel and Juana is on the river. they are very welcoming and love when people come and stay. we camp in our car at there property, its a quite place in the forest, close to one Cascada that is in there property and another Cascada that is 10 minutes walking. 
there is electricity, no cell reception or Wi-Fi in the meantime (they intend to have wifi soon),  very basic toilets and shower.

that asked us to pay what we can, we gave 300 for the night and 3 meals we ate and even cooked with them. the place is really beautiful and they are special, we sat with them and talked and they helped us with everything we needed. 

Important! the way to the place is not on the map and neither the place itself since its deep into the forest, but make the effort! it worth it. 
in order to get there: FIRST: get to the San Mateo Rio Hondo pueblo. Second: ask the people in the town how to get to the Italian restaurant Rancho Colibri (everyone know it here) its outside the town on a not paved road inside the forest. 
Third: at the Colobri restaurant asked about the Rancho Campanario and the house of Gadiel and Juana. they have there a card with Gadiel's phone but also they explain well how to get to the area of the Rancho Campanario, its about 2 kilometers from the restaurant. 
Forth: when you get to the entrance of the Rancho Campanario,  they will ask you for 20 pesos per person for entrance to the area, we payed but than Gadiel told us that if we say we coming to his house we should not pay this fee. anyway at this entrance ask where is the house of Gadiel, they will help you get there, its not more than 3 kilometers down the forest. 

the road is not easy, it is very recommended to do it with 4x4 but don't have to, we were here in the dry season and still from the restaurant to the Rancho and to Gadiel house there is some hard up/down hills specially on the way back when its uphill.

name: Alongside river
description:
We followed the river from Concá to this place (on the same side of the river). Sometimes it wasn't easy to follow because we were stuck by rocks. Swimming or making our own way fighting with plants were the unique options. We also passed a cow-space (the cows are gentle). Also: doable in May. Not sure it's doable when it's the rainy season.
The wildcamping space itself is super quiet, along the river, on sand. We made a fire and swom in the 70cm deep and warm water. The riverbed is sand: paradise! The next morning we crossed the water with our stuff and took some stairs that led to Villa Riviera. From there you can access the main street and than hitchhike.

Note: you can basically wildcamp wherever you want along the river. Fishing and swimming friendly.

name: Claudia’s Compound
description: I had to add this place as a spot to stop near the border. It’s several rooms surrounding a shared courtyard but priced to move at 340 pesos for a double room.  Message at 844 160 3140 on WhatsApp. When we told Claudia and her husband it was our honeymoon they went and bought us flowers and cookies. Sweet people and nice accommodations with amenities.

name: Waterfall Pluma Hildago
description: 70m tall skinny waterfall with little pool you can swim in, really pretty. Empty on a Sunday afternoon. Don’t follow Google maps, follow the signs from Pluma Hildago town. On Google Maps, the roads don’t look like they connect, but they do. It’s maybe 20 minutes from town. Rough dirt road with steep parts. You could do it in a 2 wheel drive with decent clearance, easier with 4x4.

name: Farmacia del Ahorro - COVID antigen test
description: Easy place to get COVID antigen test. No need to make an appointment, walk-in. Can only get COVID tests at Farmacia del Ahorros that have an attached clinic. Scan QR code in pharmacy door to see which ones have an attached clinic. Walk into pharmacy, pay for test (360 pesos), get ticket/number, go into clinic and physician will do nasal antigen test, result in 15 minutes, he prints out paperwork with your name and negative result.

name: entre mer et route
description:
On a beach with a shadow tree, noisy with the road next to it but practical for one night.

sur une plage avec un arbre pour l'ombre, bruyant avec la route à côté mais pratique pour une nuit.

name: Meritus de Mexico (NYK agencia)
description: 1st step if you shipped with NYK Line to Veracruz. This is the place to revalidate your BL. Make sure you already paid NYK/Multimar and have confirmation they correctly received it.

name: Carmelita Zona Verde
description: Little eco-friendly supermarket - lots of vegan products including cheese and yoghurt, seeds, grains, recyclable cutlery etc - and decent priced chocolate (see the food bins the far side of the counter).

name: Copias
description: Great place to make copies of paperwork. 1 peso/copy

name: Hotel Cervantino (great for motos)
description: Clean. Friendly staff. 550 pesos/night single room. A/C. Free coffee. Can park bike in lobby next to your room or in back secured parking lot. 24/hr security. Locked gates. Pharmacy for COVID test down the street. Copy place next to hotel. Honda motorcycle dealer around corner. Central/walking to everything (restaurants, banks, park, etc).

name: RV Park Eco Tours
description: Super place to spend a few days. Ask for Oscar. There is a very nice restaurant. WiFi and toilet. very peaceful place and amazing view. Possibility of Hiking Las Virgenes, and other trips.

name: Reserva El Palmar
description: Between Sisla and Celestun, it's possible to pass at low tide for 200m you need to cross by salt water max 600mm (2 feet) with dead tree as obstacle. The rest of the road it's hard and soft sand and narrow. We pass with a Jeep with low tire pressure. Not for big rig or RV.

name: Centro Ecoturístico Río Grande
description:
We found this spot on Google Maps. The nature here is beautiful, it is 100% safe and quiet. 
The owner of this place rents cabins but we could stay for 100 pesos (2 persons) in our Van. 
There are dogs and chicken running around. 
We were allowed to use the shower and the bathroom. 
It’s very simple but with a lot of space and near a lagoon. At the moment this lagoon is almost dried out. 

We asked for the WiFi password as we had to upload an assignment and the women who lives here with her kids gave it to us for this purpose.
We used the water from the showers to clean our dishes 

What has to be notes is that it is not very even so it is recommended to put blocks underneath the tires. 

The perfect place to relax in nature

name: Hotel Rojo Canela
description:
MODERATOR NOTE: Description provided by owner or manager.

Comfortable and accessible rooms.
 Each room has a bathroom and shower, WiFi service, Dish and Megacable.
 –Double room $200.⁰⁰ pesos.
 –Double room $400.⁰⁰ pesos.
 *Reservations to phones: 2361082418 and 7712062361
------
Habitaciones cómodas y accesibles.
Cada cuarto cuenta con baño y regadera, servicio de WiFi, Dish y Megacable.
–Habitación matrimonial $200.⁰⁰ pesos.
–Habitación doble $400.⁰⁰ pesos.
*Reservaciones a los teléfonos: 2361082418 y 7712062361

name: Gas z
description:
he can refill us bottles of propane. 

il a pu nous remplir notre bouteille de propane américaine

name: Currency Exchange
description: Little shop to the right of the Medcel store. Sold my remaining pesos for slightly over the current exchange rate (I profited 25c, woo)

name: Indie Park Mulege
description: Indie park Mulegé It is the best place if you are looking for something cheap, beautiful and a glamping experience unique in mulege; he is 7 different stays, prices from $450 pesos, shower with hot water, air conditioning in all its rooms, a kitchen community toilets shared, and your own restaurant.

name: Mar y tierra restaurante indie park
description: the best seafood restaurant in Mulege; You should definitely try their famous shrimp burger, they sell everything from margaritas, cold beer, wings, etc. 100% recommended nice place, cozy, affordable prices, good customer service.

name: Ananda
description: Cheapest we could find in this neighbourhood (relatively quiet, but still close to the vibe) that wasn’t actively under construction. 800/night for 2 people with kitchen and unobstructed ocean view! Hot showers, no AC but it’s quite open to the sea breeze. Free drinking water. Street parking out front on quiet street.

name: Hotel San Antonio
description:
Firm mattress. Powerful hot shower. No height restriction at the entry and reasonably priced. $70 for a night, American breakfast included. 
Shopping nearby.

name: Wyndham Garden Inn
description: Nice enough accommodations. Parking available for small class B rvs. Visited here with my dog. Decent Wi-Fi, close to groceries and some restaurants.

name: Chateau San Felipe Winery
description: A winery and restaurant with a large dirt parking lot. Strong WiFi. No water. Trash and porta potties. The restaurant does wine tastings and food. Excellent pizza. Kilometer 170 north of San Felipe on the highway which has little traffic at night.

name: Kabaña Mar y El
description: Very nice place to camp by the Ocean! Was amazed by how kindly we were received. Would definitely recommend if camping with the family or even just for a romantic night with that special person. Has restrooms and showers available. It's a must when visiting Marquelia Guerrero Playa la Bocana

name: cave paintings
description: 30km from hwy 1 on gravel road doable in 2wd. road ends and there's a ranch, you have to take a guide wich charged me $800mx then he takes you on 15min ride in his pickup truck and 15min hiking to the cave. paintingsare 7500 years old.

name: La Joya Honda trail
description: Gate to La Joya Honda was closed so we camped. by the entrance. Gate stayed closed the following day. Nice and quiet, not much shade. Watch for cactus needles.

name: Brembo Distribuidor Autorizado
description:
Eumir Marnon is a very nice owner.
He speaks Spanish and good English and can be reached via WhatsApp at +52 222 194 8576.
He has repaired a gearbox damage on my VW T5 well and cheaply. Absolutely recommended.
17 norte 2202 col Lazaro Cardenas CP 720100

name: Don Ventura
description:
25 minutes from Tuxtla we found this place to get away from the city and participate in a farmer's market called Sanfer, a very quiet place, outside the Emmanuel IAP foundation, good ventilation and safe.

A 25 minutos de Tuxtla encontramos este sitio para alejarnos de la ciudad y participar en un ecotianguis llamado sanfer, lugar muy tranquilo, afuera de la fundación Emmanuel IAP, buena ventilación y seguro

name: Kiosk por do Sol
description:
Kiosk on the edge of the Paraguaçu River, a beautiful and peaceful place with water, electricity and wi-fi.
You can spend the night just talking to Mr. Gel.
-------------------
Quiosque na beira do rio Paraguaçu, lugar lindo e tranquilo com água, luz e wi-fi.
pode passar a noite só conversar com o senhor Gel.

name: Parking area for Los Pericos Climbing Zone
description:
Parking space next to the road, used during the day by climbers visiting Los Pericos.
The caretaker of the private property next to it confirmed it's ok to spend the night here.
He also said you can camp with a tent inside the climbing zone.
To access the climbing zone, enter the private road (BY FOOT ONLY) and take the clearly marked trail on the left before the green gate & private property sign inside the road.
The climbing zone is great and has an amazing view of the lake. It's also very popular with local climbers.

Full details for climbing at thecrag.com
LTE: 2 to 3 bars with Telcel, good speed!

name: X-Fly Valle de Bravo
description: Camp site and rv parking, whit toilet and shower, just in front of the lake, soccer, and volleyball... electricity, wifi.

name: Clary
description: Good place to meal a stop and have a good food and slip.

name: Sand field
description: Tried to get to Shell Beach using directions in that post, but a large pond had overtaken the sandy road we were taking. I would guess it dries up in a month. We’re 2wd mini van so we just pulled over and tent camped. This area has A LOT of flat sandy spots for tents, vans, anything. Well packed sand this time of year (maybe year round?). Pretty quiet, clean, and empty. No view of the water even though we’re pretty close. Barely hear the highway. Very pleasant. AT&T 3g 2-4 bars. Verizon off and on.

name: Tortuga Bar
description: The owners allowed me to stay in an extra space that they had purchased next to the bar. it is unfinished now and I slept in my tent. Had toilet and shower available.  Great people. You just need to check in at the bar to see if the space is available.

name: Casa Anita
description: Great little hotel with super friendly staff. $50 for a big room with kitchenette, balcony, and king sized bed. Great views, 2 pools, and an off-street parking area out front with no roof so larger vehicles can fit. Would not work for a big rig but our truck and camper fit.

name: Kilometer 72 Overlook
description: Large dirt pullout with a half built cinderblock structure as a landmark.  No services or facilities obviously except a Telcel signal that comes and goes. Short easy walks allowing excellent views across the valley. Total silence and clear skies at night. Hardly any traffic by day. Precisely at Kilometer 72 next to the pavement.

name: Synto motorcycles. Rafa
description: my KLR650 needed clutch plates. he had a box and matched my plates up... the saved me 3 to 5 days of waiting for parts.. he works in big bikes and had me 9n the road in 4 hours! I was super lucky. Contact RAFA. +529981153233

name: Alkapura
description: This place is great. They offer purified water $12mxn and alkaline purified water $25mxn. Without even asking they completely cleaned my water containers inside and out!! Much needed! So great

name: Walmart/Sam’s Club
description: Couldn’t park at Soriana, came here and asked the Walmart manager for permission, he said no problem. Great spot! Huge parking lot, no guards, no hassle. All alone at night, quiet! Restaurants and lots of street food during the day! Awesome 3 nights!

name: Aguas Termales, Uruapan
description:
Hot springs piped into private bathing rooms can be used as a bath or shower. 30 pesos for non locals (not sure if that is for a fixed amount of time or open ended). 

Also laundry on site (hand washing, and machines, hang dry) popular with Tue locals.

There may be a communal/recreational pool/spring, I did not check.

Reached by taking the exit for Ejido Uruapan and driving through town into the countryside. There are signs. Many vineyards visible in the hills, market in town sells local wine at a reasonable price 80 pesos per bottle and fresh local cheese (fresco, cojita, or oaxaqueno) at good prices.

name: Hotel Casci's
description: Decent hotel with hot water (good water pressure), air conditioning, and secure parking (motorcycles can be parked right outside of reception overnight). Paid 895 pesos for a double room (May 2022).

name: miahuatlan de porfirio dias
description:
large empty place with trees on one side and a football field on the other.
very quiet, very nice place to spend a night.
no facilities at all.
there is an large antenna at the entrance

name: Hotel Principado Durango
description: Nice hotel, centrally located with secure parking in an adjacent garage. Rooms are small but clean, and have air conditioning. Bathrooms are some of the best ones in this price class: very clean, hot water, good water pressure, and great flushing toilets. We paid 880 pesos for a double (May 2022).

name: Hotel Los Girasoles
description: Good hotel! Air conditioning, hot (!) water, good water pressure, clean toilets & showers. Secure parking is available in a separate lot on another block. We paid 485 pesos for a double (May 2022), plus 20 pesos for parking.

name: Aluminum & Glass
description: Shop that sells aluminum pieces and glass, can cut to size. On Google Maps, “Vidrios & Aluminios.”

name: Hotel Casino Plaza
description: Very nice hotel! Not your typical overlander hotel, but we were celebrating. Has all of the western amenities: air conditioning, nice beds, clean bathrooms, hot water with good water pressure, room safe, nice TV, and secure parking. We paid 1200 pesos for a double (May 2022).

name: Aluminum & Glass
description: Manuel made us a wonderful, secure aluminum door for our propane compartment when we realized ours had flown off. Was able to do it within an hour or so, really friendly and enthusiastic to help us and for a great price.  Phone number is in the picture.

name: Restotur La Rosadita
description: Nice little cafe with good coffee, waffles, lunch, drinks, and desserts. Friendly staff. The man running the place speaks English very well.

name: Kenn Laundry
description: Did our laundry here, but was pretty expensive (30 dollars or 550 pesos). Plus some of our clothes got burned in the dryer.

name: Pemex
description:
Pemex. Free showers for 24 hours for customers. Lots of trucks, enough space to park.
..... 
Ducha gratis las 24 hs para los clientes 
Paran camioneros, bastante espacio para parquear.

name: Maral’s
description:
Amazing mexicain food with a hint of american. 
You have to try the volcanos or something like that. Decent prices and super friendly service. The owner was cooking + serving. We had an amazing time. Best food in mexico so far! Family of four with drinks cost 300 mxc pesos

name: Mi casa comida Taiwanesa
description: Amazing food. Feels different from the rest! we tried all the apetizers and we were surprised of how good it was! Definitely recommending if youre looking for something different then the usual

name: Hotel Haciendo
description:
Spent a night here because it was getting dark and we ran out of time. Nice place, good restaurant, nice rooms with A/C, hot water, tons of parking for big rigs. There is a big pool. Fast wifi

A little expensive, we paid 900 pesos for the night but we ran out of options and it was a nice sleep. Felt very safe to leave our camper in the parking lot. Very quiet. 

They say no dogs but they allowed our dog (medium sized calm dog)

name: Grassland plain
description: Nice free camping spot on a plain overlooking the canyons. Many little trees and grass around (dry in May). If you walk few hundred meters further there is a nice view of the canyons. Easy 2wd dirt road.

name: Road closed
description: The road on the dam is closed for cars. You can go through on foot or by bike. The lake is pretty cool, but you can't swim in there.

name: Wild Sierra
description: Nice private spot on a dirt road. We spent a nice night here. There are plenty of nicer spots further down the road. Easy for 2wd.

name: Nuestra Signora de Guadalajara
description: Beautiful wild camping spot in the forest right next to Guadalajara. Nice view on the city and plenty of shade. The dirt road is a bit rough, doable with 2wd, some clearence helps. Not for big RVs. There is a "no pase" sign on one of the 2 entrances of the road, we asked a local and he said it's fine to drive here. The road keeps going and there are also other spots further into the forest.

name: Purificadora
description:
Purified water 12 pesos/carafe
---
Agua puruficada 12 pesos/garafon, very friendly people!

name: La Mora
description: Great place by the river inside a gorgeous canyon

name: car park just outside the national park gates
description:
I arrived at around 8pm aiming for the other sites mentioned, which are up in the mountains in the national park. the entry gate was shut (not sure whether this was because it was a Sunday, because of the time or due to covid restrictions). I asked the police who were manning the busy exit gate and they told me I could park in the large car park by the dry diver bed.

it was full of people sitting around, flying drones, having late picnics and playing music, but by 10pm or so was pretty much empty. Very pleasant and peaceful night - I imagine weekends might be less quiet. lots of space, lovely surrounded by the mountains. no amenities.

name: Automotriz Rodriguez
description:
Super friendly mechanic who knew his stuff - engine was making a horrible sound; I called in as I was passing and he dropped what he was doing, replaced part of my starter motor and fixed my AC at the same time, for $1000. Magic! 

Ask for Martín, 8181623171

name: Beautiful spot just off the road
description: Found this place while heading up late at night; most of the way up (or a short way down!) a steep winding hill. Flat, shaded, relatively discreet if you go to the end, beautiful views and peaceful by night. Fires not permitted

name: Centro de Salud
description:
Small clinic but had post-exposure rabies vaccinations available (and, the second time I went, also the hard-to-find immunoglobulin). Beware letting the coatis on Serro de la Silla get too close! 

All vaccines in Mexico are free of charge; small charge of $70 applied for a consultation with the doctor. Very limited parking, no space for big rigs. Try to get there early to be sure that all services are available, and definitely before 4pm.

name: Track off the main road
description:
Night caught us here as we were heading for Cuatrocienagas. A track off a side road off the main road, which peters off into a walking track. A little lower down than the highway so protected from view, if not completely invisible. Not the perfect spot but had a peaceful night and didn't see a soul. A few biting insects and a little rubbish scattered about, but bright stars and nice view of the Milky Way. Fine in a pinch!

Space to park up a big rig but you might want to back in from the side road as I wouldn't like to try and turn one round on the track.

name: Slightly hidden spot just off the road
description: Down a little track to the left off the highway when driving south from Cuatrocienagas is a spot behind a mound that's partly hidden from the road. Not the perfect spot but it was complicated finding somewhere to stay; all the parks (mines, dunes and pool/river) asked for $650pp for the night! Super bright stars & milky way, clean, and very peaceful aside from slight occasional road noise.

name: Centro antirrabico/Rabies centre
description: Primarily a vet's but also provide vaccinations for humans, should you find yourself in need.

name: Agua Inmaculada
description: Manned purified water filler-upper - they seem harder to find in the north for some reason! $15 for a garrafon; I paid $7 per 4l bottle.

name: Grutas del Rosario
description: Pleasant diversion; 1.5 hours or so of having formations pointed out to you by a guide. There's a fairly steep stair climb up to the cave mouth and lots more stairs once you're in, which can make it slow going if you have very young, old or unfit people in your group.

name: Clínica ISSSTE
description: Hospital clinic. Stocks the Verorab rabies vaccine

name: Boundary of military area
description: I was trying to get to Naica; 42km before reaching it came across a gate staffed by military. The whole area from there to Naica is off-limits to civilians; had to drive an extra 110km to go the long way round instead!

name: Cueva de las Monas
description: Funky cave paintings tucked away in a beautiful area. As I understand it there are still studied ongoing to determine their age and artists. Makes a nice day trip from the city (and was about the only thing around that wasn't closed for the pandemic in Oct 2020!). Fairly well-maintained dirt road for much of the distance, with one or two slightly loose sections - was ok taking it slowly in my rwd Astro (see my other comment on tje nearby point). Might be trickier if wet, and I wouldn't want to take a very big rig up there.

name: US Fuel - cheapest in town!
description: No shortage of gas stations in the city but this one imports from the States and is reliably the cheapest in town - 50 centavos to a peso per litre cheaper than the rest. Adds up! Be prepared to queue.

name: Segórachi gas station
description:
Gas station just outside of town; people I asked were dubious about backstreet camping or staying up at the Christ statue in town. I asked permission and they were happy to let me stay, pointing me to a spot tucked away in the corner. Comfortable enough that I returned several nights over the couple of weeks I was using Creel as a base. They close at 10pm and chain off the entrance; nice clean toilets close at the same time; dark and quiet after that. Felt totally safe. Beware of the big open ditch in the corner; easy to miss after dark!

There's a pizza place attached to the gas station that's reputed to be good; I didn't go so can't comment!

name: Open ground between road and river
description:
Followed a track down from the road towards the river until it opened out into this long, wide flat strip of ground among the trees - looks like it might once have been an airstrip. 

There's a wide path to walk down to the river about 2/3 of the way along, nice clear water and perfect to cool off and wash in.

You could fit 50 big rigs with room to spare, but anything wider than my little Chevy Astro van might struggle with the access track and certainly risks getting a bit scratched on the way down.

name: Hotel Dolisa
description: Enter opposite the Elektra shop and there's an automated agua purificadora on the left ($2 a gallon or $10 a garafon). Behind that is a laundrette - they charged $71.50 for one machine load and it was done in under 3 hours

name: Parque la Colorada car park
description:
Sizeable car park at the entrance to the lovely 'park' (see associated comments). Very dark, very peaceful, surrounded by the park and hotels. I met one of the group who manage the park and she assured me that it was a very secure area; felt safe.

Somebody from the lodge opposite came with a torch to look over the car park and close the gates between 9 and 11pm on each of the three nights I spent here; saw me but didn't look concerned and left me to my own devices. Not sure what time the gates open but there were always a couple of cars around by 8 or so am - it was much busier during the weekend. 

Space for big rigs if you can make the slightly narrow turn in (it's not too bad but I saw a small bus struggle). No facilities.

name: Hospital de Camaras Digitales
description: Camera repair shop. Mine was full of dust and grit from the El Chepe smoke - Gustavo took it overnight, gave it a full service and had it back to me as good as new (almost - to be fully restored I'd need to order a new lens from Mexico City, but it's much, much better than it was!), including replacing a couple of missing screws, and had it ready for 1pm the following day, for $600.

name: Purificadora de Agua Gutma
description:
Staffed water purification place. Friendly and thorough, washed bottles inside and out, dried then after filling and helped me carry them out. - $20 for 25ish litres of various awkward-sized bottles!

Open till 8pm, note actual location is a couple of doors down from this point.

name: Mirador pull-off
description:
I aimed for the nearby marked spot but then carried on a bit further out of curiosity and found this little spot - follow the little road a bit further down the hill and just after a sharp right turn there's a spot you can pull off onto a small track that is really a broad walking track - I reversed into a flat spot just off it with a gorgeous view down over the valley. There are dwellings not far off so it's not massively private; I could hear voices in the evening, plus dogs and roosters - but in most of a day and night there I only had about 3 or 4 vehicles pass, and nobody on foot. 

Ok Telcel reception, no facilities. Anything longer than a 6m or so rig and you may struggle to manoeuvre. Felt safe.

name: Parque Sierra de Alicia
description:
Pretty park next to the aquaduct; I spent a couple of peaceful nights here - tried the park marked nearby but it's a bit too slopey unless you get lucky with your spot! If you're interested in art the little Francisco Goitia museum is iinteresting, and don't miss the Templo de Fatima above, it's beautiful! 

It's reasonably busy by night but vehicles dissipate after dark and I think you'd be able to fit a sizeable rig in after that. The police patrol regularly but never bothered me; felt safe.

name: Baños Termales del Ojocaliente
description:
Thermal baths with rentable private pools, claiming medicinal properties for eg rheumatism. A few people recommended them to be while I was here. The baths start at $170 for one/two people and range up from there

I didn't try them but the rooms look nice, beautifully tiled etc. I did get a shower however, hot and decent pressure, and a bargain at $35.

name: Hotel Mexico Plaza
description: Commercial plaza without barricades. I was advised by two different people that the Valencia car park above was unsafe, so found this place instead. Told it was safe; it's lit and has a 24hr pharmacy on one side. Flat, Soriana for food and wifi, a Pemex with $3 toilet across the road. Space for fit big rigs. Quiet between 11pm and 8ish am; had a peaceful night here.

name: Soriana car park
description:
Big car park, flat in places and very gently sloping in others, some trees for shade - hot in Iguala! Just off the highway but if you stick to the side closest to the shop you can barely hear it. I asked permission and was told no worries; there are cameras and police patrols - the police came to say hi and check all was well around 10pm; otherwise all calm. 

Open wifi if you're close to the building.

name: Cabañas Rubi
description:
Cabañas, camping and space for a small rig on almost level ground on the roadside - with a bonus beautiful cenote at the back of the grounds. Doña Rubi and Don Luis and family are very friendly and hospitable. Cabañas cost $600 for two people, $700 for four, and $1300 for six. Camping is $150 a night and use of facilities (with kitchen) if parked outside is $50 per night. Decent wiifi available at $20 per hour, otherwise phones pick up the signal from Guatemala rather than Mexico so no service unless you have a Guatemalan SIM.

Pets not permitted in the cabañas, otherwise well-behaved ones welcome - the owners have a friendly cat so must be good with those!

name: Parabrisas Gabriel
description: Windscreen repair place. I had a tiny chip that I wanted to get fixed before it grew; nobody in San Cristóbal would do it but they recommended this place. It took an hour or so, $200; seemed good and thorough.

name: Poza Reyna
description:
