description: Another night, another campground.  Full hookups, hot showers, no wifi  Price:  $15/tent site

name: Clam Beach County Park
description: This is a very small campground for cars and RVs. Paved lot right by the ocean with toilets (a bit scary), and a picnic site. Maximum stay is 3 nights and fees were $23/night. There appears to be a camp host across the road. Verizon good.

name: Doran County Park
description: Busy campground on a spit outside of Bodega Bay, CA.  Reservations are required for camping due to pandemic. Cost for a basic (no hook-ups) site is $32/night + $9.50 "reservation fee". Flush toilets, pay for hot showers, no wifi but good Verizon coverage. Lots of day use folks on sunny days. Water is potable but tastes pretty salty/bad.

name: KOA Chula Vista
description: Stayed dec 30 &31 and paid $50 for the first night. The second night was supposed to be $90 but the super nice staff gave it to us for $65. It was a huge splurge but we had been sick and in rain for a week and just wanted nice facilities. Thus place was amazing! Dare I say even worth the price? Fenced dog park, trails,one mile to the beach, super clean facilities, garbage pickup at your site, tons of activities for kids, pool, hot tub, laundry, store but best of all perhaps THE best staff of any place of any kind we have ever stayed. Every single employee was friendly and efficient and went out of their way to be helpful- truly wonderful.

name: Willard Bay State Park
description:
State park with pull through at campsites. $20 per site. Pretty view of the lake. Lots of freeway and train noise. There is a second campground adjacent that has hookups for rvs. 
Note: GPS Coordinates have been updated. Location is now correct: 41.41994,  -112.054806. This park in is Utah, just off Highway 15.

name: National Forest Outside Durango
description: Free.  Great quiet camping in canyon next to river.  National forest.  At end of First Fork road (12 miles on a good dirt road), a few miles east of Durango on the way to Pagosa Springs.  Trails.

name: National Forest outside Ouray
description: Beautiful mountain scenery along this 40 mile dirt road which crosses Owl Creek mountain pass, between Ridgway and Montrose.  Cold at night.  No facilities, free.  Plenty of boondocking opportunities.

name: National Forest outside Crested Butte
description: Free. Beautiful mountain scenery, 15 minutes on dirt road outside town of Crested Butte.

name: National Forest outside Glenwood Springs
description: Free.  National Forest camping off a dirt road, with good views in all directions.  Quiet, only sound you hear are distant cows.  No facilities.

name: Wild Horse Area
description: Free camping in the middle of the Sand Wash Wild Horse area.  No facilities, BLM land.  This spot is next to a small natural pond where lots of wild horses and other animals like pronghorn come to drink.

name: Flaming Gorge national Forest
description: Free wild camping in Flaming Gorge.  Great mountain scenery.

name: The Cove at Fish Lake
description: A great spot to go camp for the weekend, rent a boat and go fishing. There are lots of established camp sites. Few sites have hookups, be sure to make a reservation if you need them.

name: Wolf Gap Campground
description: This is a beautiful free campground on the border of Virginia and West Virginia. There are ten sites, each with a picnic table, a BBQ pit, a fire pit, a large tent pad, and a parking spot. There is also a large parking lot for extra vehicles or for day use. The day use area has several BBQ pits and tables. There are also pit toilets, and a water spigot, although we didn't check if it worked since we always carry plenty just incase. Two trail heads start at this site. It is located about 55 minutes NW of Luray on the 675. The road in is good, but narrow and winding. Very beautiful. You can stay for free up to 21 days! US National Forests are amazing. The photos we've included are of different sites. The blue dot on the screenshot is Wolf Gap, the green marker is Luray, VA, for reference. No generators, please. Keep this peaceful place peaceful.

name: Trout Pond Recreational Area
description: Excellent campground with good facilities.  Nearby hiking opportunities and very few people in the colder months.  Great lake for boating or fishing.

name: Rocky Gap State Park
description: Great campground open year-round.  Most people stay at the casino which is  nowhere near the campground.  Campground is very peaceful during the colder months.  Excellent hiking and recreational opportunities at the site.

name: Patapsco Valley State Park - Hollofield Campground
description: Great campground near Baltimore.  Place can be crowded at times, and a little noisy, but all in all good place to stay so close to a populated area.  Some good hiking and epic mountain biking nearby.

name: Liberty Campground
description:
Free. BLM campground at the head of the Liberty / Table Mountain 4WD trail system. Vault toilets that are well maintained. No water or hookups. There are 15 campsites total.

The homeowners a few hundred yards east on Liberty Road sell ice.

name: Palmer State Fairgrounds
description: Gated fairgrounds, full hook ups

name: Browns Lake
description: Located on Browns lake. Sate camp site with fees and can be busy during the week end. During the week however it can be almost deserted.

name: Brandywine Group Campground
description: Great group area near main facilities.   Large swimming area and secluded camping spot.

name: T.L.C. Auto Repair
description: Excellent Toyota mechanic at TLC Auto, Fred took great care of us even finding ways to save us money. They charged $50/hr labour. www.tlc-auto.com 858 541 0852.

name: South Ruby Campground
description: $15 per camping unit, gps location corrected on July 5, 2016

name: Big Run Falls
description: This is a primitive site located along a forest road in Monongahela National Forest. The forest road is graded in sections, but is unimproved in other sections. Four-wheel drive may not be required, but is strongly recommended. The site is marked by a fire circle, and a large, deteriorating picnic table. There is room for roughly a half dozen vehicles, or a couple of modately-sized off-road campers. While we've never encountered other campers there, it is evidently a popular spot. It is a superb destination for hiking, biking, and exploring. There are a number of amazing waterfalls in the immediate vicinity.

name: Rest Stop After Tonopah, NV
description: Rest area with basic amenities: restrooms, picnic table, parking area for RVs.

name: Rest Stop On Highway 40
description: Free parking, big rig friendly. Not very level.

name: Mountain View RV Ranch
description: Close to the border, former KOA, friendly staff. $29 plus tax for full hook up. Spent the evening watching Monday night football on the aging big screen TV with the camp host Charles. Also available is propane, small store with beer, and coin op laundry.

name: Guajome Regional Park
description:
Cheapest camping you will find anywhere near Carlsbad or San Diego, and we didn't need reservations in the summer (everywhere else is full).  Extremely clean, pay hot showers, full hookups. Now $29 USD.

Tent, RV, van, camper trick, CABIN Available! Established city run & maintained park with full hookups, dump station, recreation abound! Booked 2 nights, will update upon stay!

	Park office 760-724-4489 reservations 877-565-3600

name: Cherry Tree Hunter's Camp
description: Small open area in the forest, no creeks or other water sources. Has a quality fire ring, and plenty of space for tents. thick pine canopy stops underbrush from growing too thick. Really pleasant campsite.

name: Jobie's market
description: Fill during open hours only

name: Essence Of Tranquility
description: Hot tubs (artesian) and camping or cabins. Also a communal kitchen and Rec room. Fee includes soaks, showers, use of facilities.

name: Trinidad County Rest Area
description: Apparently in California, you can stay at a State rest area for up to 8 hours. The rest area has running water, picnic tables and flush toilets. Another nice thing to find out, is that you can use stoves (either at the picnic tables, or outside of your vehicle). They are patrolled by both state troopers and highway patrol and I would think are pretty safe. California has a lot of vagabond travelers through (vehicle, bicycle and foot) so be sure to lock your stuff up. These rest areas may be just the thing for the camper trying to put in a long day, or one that has run out of affordable options.

name: The Mill Casino & RV Park
description: This casino is just outside of Coos Bay Oregon, and has two options: The casino no longer offers Dry Camping. But they still have lLegitimate RV park camping  and showers are for registered guests only. The RV camping has nice paved spots with a bit of green space and picnic tables. Water and Electricity is available at each RV spot. There are nice clean washrooms and showers, a small frontage store selling bare essentials, and a laundry mat. Although the noise is a bit louder than a state park, the price is right. Restaurants are in the Casino, and be sure to check the local deals at the casino restaurants as they have different buffets a couple times a week.

name: Jedediah Smith State Park
description:
Note - no facilities available out of season
Although this campsite was $35.00/night, it was beautiful. At that price (with no electricity at the sites) some would say it was overpriced, but you are in the heart of the Redwood forest! It was quiet, and so serene. There are warm showers ($0.50/5 min) and running water in the washrooms. The water from the taps along the campsite loops was drinkable as well. There is a short nature walk that takes you through the Redwood glades and then along the bank of the Smith River. The River also has a day-use area and beach that was pretty cool as well. The water is crystal clear, and we spent some time at the Day-use area swimming once we had reached the noon check-out time. The sneaky idea is to make sure you do not pass through the park exit before going to the day use. The Campground also sells firewood and has great pits for mingling with your neighbors after dark.

name: Hot Well Dunes
description: This is a BLM site with a $3 per night fee. Includes pit toilets, picnic tables, trash cans and two hot spring outdoor HOT TUBS!!  Spaces are dispersed in the desert sand and privacy is easy to find. Hot tubs fill from solar pump so only hot/flowing during the day. The tubs are full after sunset but cool way down. Great location, great price.

name: Top of Daniel at Uwharrie National Forest
description: Free site since its National Forest land. Takes a fairly capable 4x4 vehicle to get up the trail. Cleared campsite with rock fire pits at the top. Primitive camping

name: Cal Anderson Park
description: We rolled into Capitol Hill, Seattle thinking that it would be easy to poach a spot on the street, only to find that the streets were all over crowded with bumper to bumper parking. We did find the Gold mine though - Cal Anderson Park, just off of Broadway and Pike Street - One of the places where Grunge Rock started. Cal Anderson park was nominated for some kind of "wholesome award" and was indeed a fantastic place to park for the night (in small Camper Van style -Not a place for big rigs). The pay parking ends at 20:00 and then it is free until 08:00 weekdays and weekends. It is located right beside the park itself which has a well lit Soccer field (lights out around 23:00), Tennis courts, basketball, a walking area, and is well used by Seattle-ites. There are some fantastic pubs like The Unicorn, or Nuemo's (Nirvana played there) a couple blocks away on Pike Street. The parking spots are Back in- Horizontal spots, so again- No Big rigs (Sorry).

name: Fort Stevens State Park
description: NO RESERVATIONS - Got a spot! We arrived late at 9:00pm and checked the information board at the welcome center. They had a list of available sites posted up. We did self check in and slept in our car. It was wonderful! Sure, it is pricey at $35/ night, but the Oregon coast doesn't seem to have many pull out spots, so we were grateful for this awesome spot! The walking trails, beach and shipwreck were AMAZING! Such a great spot!

name: Trailers Inn RV Park
description: Stayed in 31-S which fits up to 20 feet. USD 46.30 for full hook up. Wifi is now upgraded so was fast. Don’t expect friendly reception. rest was okay being only 12 miles from downtown price is for the location not view. Small book exchange, TV room next to office. Toilets clean.

name: Bussey Point Campground
description:
Enjoy nature at its finest. Located at the entrance of Bussey Point wilderness recreation area- a 2,545 acre peninsula on J. Strom Thurmond Lake- the campground provides a relaxing getaway for the nature enthusiast for hiking, mountain biking, or horseback riding. The Bussey Point horse trail was created by horseback riders for horseback riders. This trail circles the peninsula and is 12.5 miles long. Along with the horse trail, there are an additional 20 miles of roads and trails located within the area that all are welcome to use (no motor vehicles please). Located within the area are 15 food plots, six hike/bike/ride/boat in camping/picnic sites, and several natural beaches. Ample deer and turkey inhabit the area along wiht other mammals and birds to provide on of the best opportunities on teh lake to view wildlife in its natural setting. Adjacent to the area is the campground with 14 primitive campsites without water or electic, however, there are picnic tables, fire rings, and grills located at each site. There is also a boat launching ramp, hand pump for drinking water, and rustic toilets locatd throughout the area. 
Camping fee is $10 per night per site and day use is free.  There are restrooms on site, but no showers.

             Lantern Posts
	•	Tent Pads
	•	Trailhead Parking
	•	Grills
	•	Lake Access
	•	Horseback Riding Trails
	•	Tables
	•	Campfire Rings
	•	Vault Toilets
	•	Hitching Racks
	•	Pit Toilets
	•	Boat Ramp
	•	Bank

name: Magnolia Springs State Park
description: Primitive, prepared and RV sites available.  Full capability cabins are available. See website for nightly cost (2014 cost $20 for tent walk in and $28 for site with electric).

name: Crazy Horse
description: Average campsite, good place for a base camp for visiting several attractions in the area. We paid $ 20 USD a night , internet included. Laundry at $ 1.00/ load.

name: Gold Ranch RV
description: Best little RV park in the Reno/Sparks area. Cost is around $20.00/night (good for the area). Great stop off point on the East side of the Sierras.

name: Oceano Dunes State Vehicular Recreation Area
description:
Great on beach camping for RV and tent. Cost is $10.00/night. You will be driving on the beach, so watch tide info and know your sand driving skills. Remember, this is a boondocking area. But there are porta johns, restaurants in the near by towns, rangers patrolling. Also know that this is a OHV area and there are a lot of sand riders on the weekend. Ok surf and good surf fishing.

There are guys driving in truck and selling water - 75c/gal.

Entrance/Fee station is at end of Pier Ave in Oceano.

name: Silver Strand State Park
description: $50.00 offseason, on the beach.

name: Devil's Half Acre Meadow
description: Primitive road. One fire pit. Enough space for multiple tents and vehicles. Big open meadow. Another area across the road as well.  Road is closed during the snow season.

name: Near Batty Pass Caves
description: Near the base of Fifty-Mile mountain. Two large, flat, primitive sites can accommodate fairly large groups. This location is very near Batty Pass caves, three old rancher caves worth visiting if you are in the area. This location is also near (on the other side of the Hole-in-the-Rock road) Peek-a-boo and Spooky gulches (part of the upper end of Coyote gulch), two popular, short, and excellent non-technical slot canyons. Dogs are allowed in this location, but note that if you are here for Coyote Gulch features, dogs are not allowed there.

name: West of Blanding
description: Very scenic overlook.

name: Zapata Falls Campground
description: Road was recently redone. Dirt/gravel road accessible with any rig. Now requires a reservation via recreation.gov and was full when we drove through.

name: Mill Creek Campground
description: 7$ pernight

name: Flying J
description: A great last stop in USA before crossing into Mexico. Free to camp , pay showers ( $12) , internet $ 1.99 for an hour.

name: Near Robsons Mining World
description:
ADMIN NOTE: Permits needed for overnight stay.

-------------------------

A desert camping location that is tucked back in the trees. Dry camp.  The nearby attraction has a restaurant with limited hours. Interesting glimpse into mining life.

name: Snyder Hill, Tucson, AZ
description: This is a piece of BLM land northeast of the junction of San Joaquin Rd and W Ajo Highway. To the southwest of Tuscon. The area is accessed from the San Joaquin Rd and is criss crossed with gravel tracks. It is fairly level and covered in small desert trees and bushes so it is possible to remain unseen from the adjacent roads if your vehicle is not too high. It is also possible to pitch a tent as there was one here at the same time as me. There are no facilities what-so-ever and traffic noise can be heard from the Ajo Highway. The use of the site is free. The co-ordinates are 32.156941, -111.116493.

name: North River Campsite
description:
This is not a free site its 8.00 a nite and they may raise it to 10.00 long way off road windy hilly roads make sure your breaks and transmission are good.

About 12 spots next to a creek. Pit toilets, bear trash, nice and flat

name: Pancho Villa State Park
description: A surprisingly nice and inexpensive campground just a couple of miles north of a border crossing.  There is an on-site museum dedicated to Pancho Villa's cross-border raid on Columbus in 1916 and General Pershing's unsuccessful attempt to capture him,

name: Agua Fria National Monument
description: Lots of areas for off road camping with solitude. Road starts off easy, but 4wd / high clearance needed further on & on side roads. Bloody Basin exit off I-17. Archaeological site too that you can walk around.

name: Organ Pipe Cactus National Monument
description:
Part of national parks. $8 entry fee to park + camping fees). Main campground handles RVs + group camping tents + more isolated small Alamo tent campground. Beautiful park with great hiking!
We were here in Apr and paid $25 US (entry fee)

name: Rio Penasco
description: Was $28/night for 2 cars, 3 people. They had hot showers and good wifi. There's a decent restaurant within walking distance

name: Hurricane Creek Camp
description: Trail directly off I40 Westbound in NC. Camp site just about a mile in from interstate.  You turn off interstate at the end of guard rail, not an exit.  Boondock camping. Large low hanging branches, not ok if you are taller than 8 feet.

name: Guadalupe Canyon National Park
description: Campground with tent sites and RV sites (asphalt parking lot). Flush toilets with  sinks, drinking fountains and trash cans. On a windy bluff overlooking the valley. Beautiful location. $15usd per night.

name: New Mexico Welcome Center
description: Free to camp out in their parking lot overnight. Clean bathrooms open all night. Noisy (right by highway)  but convenient & free.

name: U-haul, Las Cruces NM
description: Have propane refill facility.

name: Boron State Rest Area, Eastbound
description:
This is a State Rest Area, so note that there are signs that state maximum 8 hour stay, which is common with all State Rest Areas. Pretty easy to stay longer though as it would be state troopers that ask you to move along, and they are few and far between. 

The Rest area has a paved ring road with parking spots under small trees, within short walking distance to picnic tables. As well, a large gravel area circles most of the paved road as well, so many large units can pull over. The west side of the Rest area also has some trees that one can pull their vehicle between to get more shade/ wind cover. Semi trailers have a separate lot to park in.

The washrooms are clean enough for a high traffic Rest area, but staff were there early cleaning up (so use the facilities after they clean). Garbages are all over the place, as are the shaded and non-shaded tables. No outside water source found, but there are vending machines on site. 

Good place, but It was a little loud. The trucks (of course) run all night and there is a train that passes the Rest area once every hour (at least). There must be an unmarked crossing on the tracks, as the trains blow their horn three or four times each time.

name: Marfa Mystery Lights Viewpoint
description: A large pull out rest area with tables, restrooms and seating designed for the overnight viewing of the Marfa Lights. Overnight parking in all Texas rest areas is legal, but this one truly expects it! Added bonus is seeing the lights on the horizon. We did!!           Highway noise and trains can be a disruption. Also lots of viewers pulling on/off the road may be an issue. None of this bothered us, but be aware. No charge for this location.

name: BJs RV Park
description: Great little rv park with clean restrooms, hot showers, wifi, laundry and nice people. Fee includes electric and water -pay one price. $27.00usd.

name: Neales Propane
description: You must be able to remove your tanks at this place. They sell it based on weight!

name: Farr Equestrian Center And RV Park
description: This is operated by the city and well kept up. Features dated but clean restrooms with showers, grassy parking with water and electric and beautiful pastures all around. Call ahead if you aren’t going to make it before 4 pm.

name: Colossal Cave Mountain Park
description: $10 to camp.  Tents and trailers.  Rough roads to access some of the sites, 4WD or high clearance needed. Extremely beautiful and quiet. Pit toilets at each end of the park, a small hike from some sites.  I think there was potable water at each end too.  Not near all sites.

name: Free FS Campground - no services
description: Fire pits and a nice set of places. Mostly used by hunters in the fall. I know about the place because i own the property down the road, stop by and say hi. If you do you can probably get on our wifi and visit.

name: Rufus
description: North side of I-84 @ Rufus. Was a CoE Park that apparently got turned over to a county that can't afford to maintain it. Pit toilet. No water (other than the river.) Paved to the east, sand to the west. Blackberrys in mid/late summer.

name: Sonrose RV Park
description: A typically priced, ordinary RV park close to Space Center, beaches, lakes and inlets. Lots of grass. Some shade. Clean bathrooms. A pool. Laundry (coin op) Nearby fast food, fuel, highway and Camping World. Nice folks run it. $45 per night.

name: Raccoon Mountain Campground
description: A nice campground with a variety of sites available. We paid $18 for a site with water and electric - less than posted rate. Sounds of creek nearby all nice. Trains in the distance. Lots of people here but we picked a spot that was spread out enough to feel private. Quick access to Chattanooga. Groceries and gas within 5 miles.

name: Mammoth Cave National Park Campground
description: A very clean, green campground. 2-3 sites have hook ups all the rest do not. Tidy asphalt spaces. Near visitors center. Showers located at store near entrance. Shower's are coin operated $1.50 per 4 mins. Nothing too fancy but it works. Several fancier ones nearby in Cave City.  $25 to dry camp. Restaurant at visitors center.

name: Norris Dam State Park
description: We were there mid week in April and there were many empty spaces. Felt somewhat abandoned. Yet bathrooms were clean, spaces were nice and flat. Tables and fire rings provided. Water and electric also $20 per night included hook ups plus showers/bathrooms. Very beautiful surroundings. BTW if you arrive late, ignore the scary warnings. Just go in and pay in the morning.

name: Newport News Campground
description: This camping area is operated by the city and located biking distance from the National Historic Site. Various types of hook ups range in price from $30 to $40 per night. Clean, aging bathrooms with hot water. Level, paved spaces. A nice lake and trails. Not a bad deal for the location and proximity.

name: Gillford Pinchot State Park
description: Nearest state park to Hershey and cheaper than fancy schmancy places down there. This is a beautiful park on a lake. Spaces with and without hookups. We paid 23 for dry camp- weekday rate.  Includes hot showers, clean bathrooms, central water and playgrounds.

name: Staybridge Suites
description: Free! We stayed at Mc Donalds for free Wifi and saw this little Lake behind the Staybridge Suites. Quiet in the Night, no traffic..

name: Page Lake Powell Campground
description:
Established campground and trailler park in highway 98. Dome of the places for tents are unleveled. 
.
Showers (4.5$), toilets and laundry. 29$USD per night for dry camping, up to 50$ for full hook ups
.
Electricity and wifi at sites.

name: Pine Grove Campground US Forest Service
description: I'm staying here for Overland Expo west. Pinecone campground is a U.S. forestry service camp. As a "Senior" I only pay $11.00 U.S. Per night.

name: Muley Point
description: This area is full of great wild camp options but this is one of our favorites even though the secret seems to be out so you will probably not be alone. It can get windy up here but the views are unbeatable. Only amenity here is fire pits. For an unforgettable drive, head north off the 163 through the valley of the gods (road turns off 7.5 miles north of Mexican Hat) on your way here. Roads in are dirt and not suitable for huge rigs.

name: Hitch-N-Post RV Park
description: RV park and campground with wifi, showers and toilets. There is only water available in the camping area. Paid 30 USD per night

name: The Living Room
description: This is a the view point at the en of a great little hike near the U. Of Utah.  Follow the trail to red butte peak and you'll see the trail cut off to this viewpoint.

name: St Andrews State Park
description:
Located on beautiful Panama City Beach. Electricity and Water. $28 per night
Entrance costs 8usd per car and day to the state park, but you cannot currently go to the campsite because it is closed.1/22

name: Malibu Beach RV Park
description: Starts st USD 50.-/night

name: Marshall Lake Dispersed Camping
description: Open camp sites in the middle of a tall pine forest. About 5 minutes off Lake Mary Road. Huge open areas with lots of places to choose from. Some spots have rock fire pits.

name: Kaibab Forest Dispersed Camping
description: Free camping at about a dozen sites in pine forest with dire circles.

name: Spring Creek Park
description:
This is an urban park with 8 full service sites for RVs (water, 30/50 amp power, sewer) and 4 full service tent camping sites (30 amp power, water) Hot water showers and bathrooms. Price is free, but online reservations may be required 10-14 days in advance.  Rangers live on site and patrol constantly. There are a bunch of free charcoal grills, playgrounds, sand volleyball and tennis courts, archery range, picnic areas (except oddly no picnic tables at campsites!), disc golf course, historic monuments, and wooded hiking trails. However, for families and people new to camping, this is a good starter park. 
CALL FOR RESERVATIONS: (281) 353-4196

name: Balmorhea Lake
description: There are a few campsites around the lake which are pretty much bare bones. Fire pits, BBQ  and tables at some. Free. Better for car campers but tent campers could make do in a pinch. Near highway 10 so good if you want a free place to stop crossing Texas.

name: Lincoln National Forest Wild Camp
description: Lots of pull outs off this forest road to camp. We chose this one with a meadow, fire ring and a pile of wood. Near Rim Trail trail head. Free and very remote.

name: Isla Blanco County Park
description: 600 site park.  Very crowded, dirty restrooms, hard to find as there is no sign.

name: Les's RV Park
description:
$20/night, laundry, full hookups, speedy wifi, nice folks.

Continue 0,7 miles on turtle Road to the Campground

name: New Orleans Parking Lot
description:
Behind Basin Street Visitor Centre, walking distance to famous French Quarter. The best place to spend a night if you are totally self-contained as there are no RV facilities. Paid parking: $5/10 hours or $10/24 hours for trucks and vans, $50/24 hours for RVs. Quiet during the night, we felt safe the night we stayed there. Right next to us is the French Quarter RV Resort where campers pay close to $100/night! 

Bathrooms available when the Visitor Centre is open (8:30-5:30).

Weekend prices are a bit higher I believe. 

Paid $20.35 usd for one day of parking. (24 hours)

name: Painted Rock Petroglyphs  Campground BLM
description: So the pros: only 10 miles off freeway on our way home to CA. We had the place to ourselves. We did not pay to camp here since we were totally alone. Cons: hot as hell. No seriously, June 1 it was 104 after dark. Pit toilet, picnic tables, trash cans and fire pits are amenities. No water! Official price is $8 to camp and $4 with a Annual Parks Pass. Petroglyphs are not worth the visit unless you need to camp here.

name: Bill's Propane Service
description:
109 N 40th St
Phoenix, AZ 85034
(602) 267-0288
http://billspropaneservice.com/

The owner was willing to work on my smaller Manchester (6lb) tank (uncommon in Phoenix). Gave a discount if you are Pro Second Amendment.

name: Graceland RV Park and Campground
description: Large and nice campground with part of full hook up directly in front of Elvis' Graceland. Clean restrooms with hot water. Pool. WiFi non-reliable. Shuttle-service to Memphis Downtown 5 USD/person oneway. 28.56 USD/night.

name: Premium Parking Lot Nr. 338
description: It is very difficult to find a good overnight place in the center of New Orleans. We stayed on a parking lot at the edge of the French Quarter for 6 USD for 10 hours on daytime and 15 USD for 12 hours during evening and the night. There is no security. No facilities but surprisingly quiet during night. The only central campground "French Quarter RV Resort" would have cost around 100 USD/night!!!

name: Pecan Grove RV Park
description: Campground with full hook up in Austin. Restrooms clean, but very simple. Laundry. WiFi (slow). 60 USD/night for two in RV

name: Travellers' World RV Park
description: Campground with full hook up. Very clean restrooms with hot water showers. Slowly WiFi. Laundry for 1,25 USD. Pool. Bus station to go downtown in front of the campground. 53 USD/night.

name: Cottonwood Camp- Big Bend National Park
description: Grassy camping area with some shade. No reservations taken, but not as popular due to limited services. No cell service. No water. No power. Beautiful views and great trees. An oasis in the desert, walking distance to the Rio Grande.

name: Bradbury Mountain State Park
description: Basic state park. Campsites. Fields. Pit toilets. Hot showers. Sink station. Trash and. Fire rings. Picnic tables.

name: San Francisco I Candlestick RV Park
description: Didn't used this overpriced asphalt area - one and only real established Campground in San Francisco . ~80USD/night!!!

name: Slab City
description: Love it or hate it!  its s great place in the desert to meet others or just get some solitude.

name: Mammoth Lakes I Laurel Springs
description: A couple of free campsites and a nice little creek.

name: Bishop I Volcanic Tablelands
description: Free BLM camping near Bishop. Great place for rock climbing!

name: Bishop I Buttrmilk Country
description: Free camping in the Inyo National forest.

name: Nevada City Omega Scenic Viewpoint Rest area
description: There's a scenic overlook near Nevada City. It's a USFS area with some picnic tables. No reception for T-mobile.

name: Lone Pine
description: Free dispersed camping. With Hiking Trails, Horse Trails and Rock Climbing Area. Nice place to stay on US 395.

name: Joshua Tree South BLM
description:
Free Campsites at south entrance of the NP. The National Park has potable water and dump for $5.
Its BLM Land....so no problem for overnight camp.....official overflow camp for Joshua Tree Park

name: Painted Canyons I Mecca
description: Free desert camping. Can be soft sand at times and hot in the summer.

name: Joshua Tree North BLM
description:
Big open flat area in a dry lake bed surrounded by mountains

Got 4G 3 bars with Verizon.

name: Box Canyon
description: Very nice area with soft sand, very quiet during the day and at night. Beware: This is a flash flood area!!!

name: Cherokee Casino Parking Lot
description: Huge parking lot of the Casino, officially you are allowed to stay here for one night if you are joining the casino. We didn't and no one asked us to do so. There were a lot of other RVs. Quiet night. Free. No facilities.

name: Mount Pisgah Campground
description: One of the official Blue Ridge Parkway National Park campgrounds. Nice campgrounds for RVs and tents with a lot of privacy, clean restrooms, hot showers, potable water. No electricity. 16 USD/vehicle.

name: Linville Falls Campground
description: Official Nationalpark campground. Only toilets no shower available. Dumping station and potable water available, no electricity or WiFi. Quiet. 16 USD/vehicle.

name: Campground Doughton Park
description: Simple but nice campground. Clean toilets, no shower, no electricity, no WiFi. 16 USD/place.

name: Middle Creek Camping
description: Nice campground in the forest. Simple restrooms, hot water showers. Electricity and water on side. Laundry and dryer. Pool. No Wifi. 40.81 USD for two adults.

name: Black Jack CG
description: National Forest CG, with spacious sites, big trees & lots of shade, picnic tables, fire rings, pit toilets. Empty here on a Monday in June & weather was perfect. No water.

name: Walmart Parking Lot
description: Free overnight stay at the walmart parking lot. Walmart 24 hours - 7 days open. Restrooms in the supermarket available, free WiFi at Sam's during their opening hours.

name: Mt. Blue State Park
description: Basic state run campground in these parts. Trees. Dirt. Ferns. A lake. Bathrooms. Showers. A moose. Fee $27

name: Fancy Gap Campground
description: This place was great - clean bathrooms water and electric at every site there's even an apple orchard. The family that runs it is super nice.

name: Marion Creek Campground
description: the perfect place to stay when you go up to deadhorse. a really nice campground with beautiful spots. quiet. only 10$.

name: Olnes Pond Recreation Area
description: quiet recreation area around a lake. nice spots with picnic tables. pit toilets.

name: Hooper State Park (county park, not state)
description: Pay by the night. Gazebo, water in 4 open location, baseball fields, garbage location. Nice place.  DEQ says not potable but it is the same water as the town.

name: Kankakee River State Park
description: We paid just $8.00 per night for a basic site. No hookups. Pit toilets. Central water spigot. River access. Picnics table. Some spots have mature trees. Nothing fancy but cheap. Hook ups sites are $20.

name: Ghost Ranch
description: Wonderful landscape. Very good services

name: Heaton Bay
description:
Nice campsite on the lake. Plenty of space, managed by USFS.
24$ no hookups
26$ full hookups
the stars reflect on the lake. Top.

name: Oahe Recreation Area Campground 3
description: A nice, low priced option just outside of Pierre, the capital city.  This was $22.00 per night with electric and hot showers. Beach access. Trails. Grassy spaces with picnic tables and fire rings.

name: Fort Robinson State Park
description: Coats $25 or so per night. Offers electric hook ups or tent sites. Very dated showers with hot water and flush toilets. Great history spot with chuck wagon rides, restaurant, lodges, cabins and a pool. Great for family fun.

name: Flaming George / Green River No. 4
description: Wild camping at the river. There is a simple toilet / no showers. We were almost alone out there. No checkpoint but a reminder to pay a daily fee of 5 dollars or 15 dollars a week you put in a mailbox. Beautiful and clean. At the Wyoming site, No. 4

name: Morein Park Rocky Mountain
description: Very nice 20$...$18 off season.  One loop open year round with water and toilets.

name: Leith Recreation Area
description: Nice established campground, well maintained on Ohio River. $15 tent sites and $20 electric at sites. Hot showers and flush toilets. Park for kids.

name: Cedar Pass Campground
description:
Wonderful position, 20$.
Rates change with the season.
Showers, dump, looks out into formations / prairie

name: Belle Fourche Campground Devils Tower
description:
Beautiful campground right next to Devils Tower, shaded spots with fire pits and picnic tables. No electric hookups but there are bathrooms and water available.
$20 a night, generator use 8am-8pm.

name: Allegheny National Forest  Ranger Station
description:
Allegheny National Forest  Ranger Station - info on camping

https://www.fs.usda.gov/detail/allegheny/about-forest/offices

name: Owls Nest
description: old 1928 natural gas town.  part of Allegheny National Forest.  center of overland camping for me.  many great dispersed campsites

name: Ennis Town Meadow Lake Fishing Access
description: A free municipal camping. Right on a beautiful Lake and view of the mountains. Fire pit and grass pastures, beautiful setting. Very quiet.

name: rest area
description: kids playground, bathrooms, free coffee sometimes and a good place to rest.

name: Ft Stanton, Snowy River Cave, BLM
description: Free camp spot in BLM area just outside of historic Lincoln, NM. 5 camp spots, with shelter, fire rings, picnic tables, and 1 clean pit toilet. Awesome views, and trails. Free! We were here by ourselves. Quiet.

name: Valley of Fires, BLM campground
description: Pretty cool spot overlooking a lava flow. Also, really nice board walk that goes out into the field. Day use free with annual pass America the beautiful, $5 without. Lots of sites, nice clean bathhouse with warm showers. Tents spots $7, RV no electric $12, with $18. No bugs in winter, but otherwise a bit buggy. Just bring some spray!

name: Sweet Spot, Cibola NF, NM
description: Great mountain top spot in pine forest, with a view of the desert valley. Not too far off of Hwy 60, and just off gravel US Forest Service road. Gravel road is in good shape, however we did use 4wd to get up steep road to camp site. Perfect spot to relax for a day or more. Go for a hike, or just enjoy the view. Price....FREE. Other camping in area if you don't love this spot.

name: Cottonwood Canyon, BLM
description: Nice little spot about 25 miles outside of Bryce Canyon in BLM land. Tucked away near stream and in the shade of a few trees. Free! Clean!

name: Muley Point
description: Several nice spots here with great views. Super flat, awesome views, great rock fire pits. No facilities. Most spots accessible with 2wd. Not to be missed!

name: Bear Pooh Overlook
description: Looking for a free spot with a great view? Don't mind a little leveling, or possibly sharing the spot with some fury brown friends? This spot could be for you. Just off Forest Service road, fire pit, and has a GREAT view of the Utah landscape(hoodoos, etc). Not too far from Natural Bridge National Monument and kinda on the way to Canyonlands NP.

name: Toadstool Geologic Park
description: 6 sites with picnic tables, shade, pit toilets, no people. Amazing views across the prairie. Very basic. $15.00 per night. Nearby features interesting.

name: Lower Skilak Lake
description: As described, a wonderful big lake with mountains surrounded and a campground ; there are +/- 20 Sites and the lakeshore but plenty other opportunities at several big parking lots up the hill

name: Wild Camp in Portage Valley
description: Nice little spot right next to a glacial pond. The adjacent forest is really green and nice to walk in, but there are quite a few mosquitos. There is a walking trail (Trail of Blue Ice) on the other side of the highway that we took all the way up to Byron Glacier and back. It’s a great path and was about 10 miles round trip. The spot by the forest is the best spot, but every night it seems like several other campers accumulate in the open area at the entry to the spot. No big deal and everyone has been friendly. Lots of locals come and trout fish in the lake. We saw several bald eagles and a moose went for a swim in the pond one morning just after breakfast. We have been traveling for 6 weeks straight, so we decided to take a break for a bit. We ended up staying here for 6 nights. Great spot. We came by here 8 years ago and thought it was a nice spot, so we returned. Glad we did. Decent cell coverage.

name: Turpentine Creek Wildlife Refuge
description:
bad ass big cat refuge, 100+ tigers, lions, bears, monkeys up in the ozarks. $25 a night, but includes guided tour of the property/animals. 

Tigers/Lions to start howling in the night, but thats pretty cool IMO.

Turpentine Creek Wildlife Refuge
239 Turpentine Creek Lane
Eureka Springs, AR 72632
Call: 479.253.5841
Email: tigers@turpentinecreek.org

name: BLM- Camp Unit Improved, La Posa LTVA West
description: blm long term camping. winter $180 from Sept to April. or $40 for 2 weeks. dump station in la posa south.

name: BLM-RA Camping Unit Rec Site
description:
BLM site, $6 per vehicle. 
Rocky area so tents might be an issue. 
Some sandy sections on the road in. No exit to the road.

name: Green Lake Rustic Campground
description: Rustic campsite for tent-camping. Hiking trails that connect to the State Recreation Area. Lake nearby and pumped well water available. Super spacious sites. $17 per site.

name: Red Shale Campground
description: 14 Free campsites at this National Forest campground. Vault toilets. No water of trash, you must haul everything in and out. Picnic tables and parking sites, tall pines offering shade.

name: Box Canyon Dam Campground
description: Free campsite with bathrooms, fire pits, tables, free firewood, small lake for swimming with free life vests for use. Just off highway and free firewood included. Located next to the dam hydroelectric plant and its compliments of them. Beautiful campground!

name: High Country Gas And Supply Inc
description: Grand Junction, Colorado: refilled our 3 kg French "camping gaz" bottle. Also welding supplier so will be able to build a propane connection if necessary. Address: 1039 Pitkin avenue

name: walmart, big spring, 24/7
description: clean toilets.overnight place on the walmart parking.for free.

name: Tuttle Creek
description: Nice spot in open desert.Surprising Tuttle Creek runs through campground. Little shade available if hot. Nice view over the valley and into the mountains. 5 USD FEE

name: Susitna River Banks
description: Right next to Sustina River, next to Highway 3. you can Drive on riverbed and have a nice view on the river. You can decide how far you want to be away from highway....you can go as far as 500m. Easy drive, no 4WD necessary, 175km North of anchorage and 49km South of denali view Point South - for FREE

name: Denali Highway Pullouts, Right By A Lake With Spectacular Mountain View - Top
description: Pullout right by a lake on denali Highway, goes down a Little Hill, spectacular view of Snow-capped Mountains, beautiful...along the denali Highway are many, many beautiful spots for Wild Camping with breathtaking views over valleys, creeks, rivers or Mountains...sth for every taste. Some are loser to the Highway (gravelroad), some are more Remote....Traffic is not too bad though

name: Curry County Park at Floras Lake, NICE
description:
Campsite is open again. Dry RV site is 25 USD now

South of Bandon, nice campground at floras lake, 4,8km away from hwy 101, good for kite surfers, toilets and hot (Pay) showers are available for $1.50. wifi, First come, First serve. Be there early during High Season because this Place gets busy in the afternoon! 
Wifi is spotty. 
Dry Camping - $25 per night, E&W $30

name: San Francisco Golden Gate Bridge Toll Info
description: If you have a foreign license plate the don't charge the toll ($7,25 per van). They usually take a pic of the plate and send you the Bill to your home address....but not if you have a European Address, That World bei too much burocracy ;) so crossing the Bridge is FREE

name: Mendenhall lake campground  Juneau Alaska
description: This is a national park campground with great services. Hot showers (free) flush toilets. Flat parking. Bear boxes. Lake access.     The down side= in an effort to save money it is not staffed so you have to call in or use website to get a space and there is a $9 fee for that!!  However at $10 per space (no hook ups) it is still the cheapest place in town.  Just be prepared for the extra hassle. Hook up sites are $28

name: Orfino Campground
description: From Deer Lodge 20km on gravelroade southeast, 10 sites with tables and pit toilets in the forest.its a forest campground, you can stay for 14 days for free

name: Cherry Creek
description: Cherry creek is a forest campground with 7 sites with tables and pittoilets for free.the last 4 miles are gravel.its located 13 miles away from the west yellowstone entrence.a nice spot at the lake with shadow from trees

name: Red Lodge
description: Palisades forest campground (free) with 6 small sites for tents and small rv, with pit toilets, tables and firerings

name: Flagg Ranch
description: Forest Campground with pittoilets, tables and firerings between yellowstone and teton nationalpark for free.on a gravelroade 8 places with 2-4 sites

name: Camp Dream
description: On the top of a dune near a  nice rock. Sandy

name: Tom's Best Spring Rd. in National Forest
description: Great place, didn't see a single other person, great cell service (AT&T, Verizon & T-mobile). What more could you ask for? I would stay here again. This is probably the best free spot near Bryce Canyon NP and one of the closest as well.

name: Whale Park with hot water sinks And flush toilets
description: If you are parking lot surfing in Sitka then this is your go to spot. The bathrooms do not have showers. But they have sinks with hot water, mirrors, flush toilets.  Also some cool gazebos to hang out in and dog poop bags. Can even take the far steps to the waters edge and see a few little tide pools. However, this is posted as no overnight parking. Be warned.

name: 33km After Coldfoot
description: Nice place way off the Dalton Hgw. Seemingly, an old gravel pit, now given back to the"nature".

name: Deadhorse
description: Closest to Deadhorse. There are more than 10 similar places at the river more to the south. AT&T 5bars

name: Laundry Showers MiniMart
description: This may be the cheapest shower in town. $2.00. But bathroom costs a quarter. Laundry was reasonably  priced and empty.

name: Free Official Campsite
description:
Free site with toilets, fireplaces and picnic tables
Closed September 15 to May 15.

name: Hub Of Alaska, Tesoro Gas Station, Glennallen/ Glennallen Visitor Center, Alaska
description: On the back of the Glennallen Visitor Center/ Tesoro gas station, there is a huge parking lot where you can park and sleep. There are potta potties outside and normal restrooms inside the convenience store of the gas station. There are also 3 canteens that sell hot food. You can easily find the place. Its right at the Glennallen junction (north to Tok/ south to Valdez). Only drawback, you have to pay for wifi at the visitor center (5USD for an hour!!!!!).

name: Grand Tetons View
description: Boon-docking site with amazing view of the Grand Tetons. Fire pits, no facilities. Windy and you need 4wd to drive up to the sites.

name: Kalaloch Creek
description: Wild campspot on a forest road, just 10 minutes outside of Olympic national park and Kalaloch campground where we filled up on water. Really quiet.

name: Capitol Reef NP - West Entrance -Free
description: On the left, maybe 5 miles before the entrance of Capitol Reef NP as you head east. Space for a variety of campers

name: Garnet Ghost Town Secret Spot
description: One of our favorite Montana spots, and it is with much hesitation that we add it to the list. Don't screw it up! We are watching you!

name: Upper Skilak Lake Campground
description: Free from 7'th of september unt. 16 may.  Really good spot as we arrived 3 days after it was free again to park here. Water availible and good views to the lake. Very quiet. On the way here there was black bear on the road

name: Chugach Trailhead, Resurrection River
description: Parking spaces with views to Exit Glacier.  Near the road but because that road leads only to trek starting point then no traffic at all.

name: Big Lagoon State Park
description:
$30 something with tax 
water+electric 
clean shower bathroom

name: Bruegger Centennial Park
description:
City park campground in Culbertson. allows for 5 days of camping.
Amenities, flush toilet, water, bbq, covered picnictables and even unsecured wifi from one of the neighbouring houses.

name: Smith Lake
description: A small 7 site free campsite close to smith lake. takes about 2.2 miles of gravel road to get there. sites have firepits/bbq.

name: Riverside Before Chicken
description: Good place on riverside. Lots of good places where to park and make campfire 5 meters from river.

name: Breeze Lake Rv Park Brownsville
description: Lovely to get back to clean amenities beautiful park great location Toula the manager was very helpful the park is spotless we had plenty of room as it was off season lovely site next to the lake 30 us per night

name: Clapp Farms
description: This is a private farm with a large camping area for overlanders.  You need permission to camp, but it is free and you have access to a bathroom and water. Call the owner at 8657556663

name: Forks State Campground
description: Somewhat primitive river side campground with a hand pump well, picnic tables, fire pits and vault toilets. $13 camping fee with recreational passport.

name: Mount Carmel
description: Amazing spot on top of the hill, unlike the spots down the river its perfect cell service here for any provider. no amenities. lots of spots and campers here. great sunset, beautiful views. can get windy at night if camping on top

name: KOA Rv Park Rusk East Texas
description: Pine tree setting full hook up Bill and Pam were really wonderfull and friendly 25 US per night sure great value we stayed in the shade of pine trees log cabins available fast wifi good electricity portable water quiet wilderness setting only a couple of miles from town

name: Automotive Super Center Longview Texas
description: 1109 W loop 281  Longview Texas these guys are great friendly and solved my diesel problem in a morning and fixed it I came off the street and they stated on it immediately great price great service great coffee thanks Doug Thanks Chris

name: Salt Lake City KOA
description:
Major campground not far from downtown. Pool, showers, store, wifi. $43 for tent site with power and water, 
 $59 for RV.

name: Lake Casa Blanca Texas State Park
description:
$18 + $4 per person for overnight camping. RVs and tents. Pretty empty when we visited, and each tent gets plenty of space and a covered picnic table. 

22$ a night.

name: Fulton Recreation. And Camping
description: Great place with BBQ hot showers lots if space level concrete slabs plenty if room between sites elec dump stn next to lake fishing boat ramp excellent 22 us per night

name: Quileute Oceanside Resort & RV Park
description: RV park with 'tenting' area for dry camping. Beachfront sites. Beautiful. $34

name: Recapture Reservoir
description:
This site is located north of Blanding on a small Lake and has approximately 4-5 sites along the lake whitout any facilities.
Camping possible on north and south shore of the lake.

name: Toiyabe National Forest, Obsidian Campground
description: Just outside of the Obsidian campground, there is a giant pine tree where you can park. Deadly quiet. Only thing you can hear is the wind. The place is within the Toiyabe NF. About 10 min drive from the main road (US 395).

name: Authorized wild camping (BLM)
description:
At this point there are two unpaved roads, choose the one you want and get there : you will find a lot of places already used, just take one! 
For the water, Kaibab campground is just next.
This place is safe and well known from the locals, close from the Grand Canyon North Rim. Nice hikes around.

name: Just Past Johnson Bridge Hot Springs
description: This is a large flat area of pines with a few campfire circles and plenty of space. No services. Back at the main road is Johnson Bridge- turn hard right after the bridge. Hot springs are a series of user built pools along the side of the river. Best ones are near fallen trees. Nice soak. Easy walk or bike ride from camp. Nearest town is Pine or Featherville.

name: NF Spot
description: Good spot, plenty of space also for bigger vehicles, trails ecc. Place to turn around.

name: Apple Canyon Yellow Post Campsites (National Forest)
description: Apple Canyon Yellow Post Campsites (National Forest). Between 5 and 10 spots in a pine forest, some of them with table and grill ring.

name: Baker Hot Springs
description: Three man made pools approximately 2 meters by 1 meter. Fed by natural artesian springs one hot one cold. You control the temperature by directing the separate flows. No services. Easy road expect it to be bumpy but passable by small car to large truck. Looks like it could be treacherous in the rain.

name: Santa Teresa, New Mexico, USA to San Jeronimo, Chihuahua, Mexico
description:
Border is about 15 miles west of the main El Paso/Ciudad Juárez border. The nearest gas station to the border is at the interstate turn off to Santa Teresa if you want to get as far as you can into Mexico.   

Exit USA:  No exit stamp required from USA side I was told, as they only deal with the green slips which they staple in passports at land border crossings. 

Enter Mexico:  Went to Mexican immigration for entry stamp, no charge. Next to aduana (vehicle entry) in same office to get temporary vehicle import paper and sticker for 45 pesos or USD$3.50. You also have to pay a refundable deposit to the Mexican government for your bike/vehicle, so you don't leave it in Mexico. If you pay cash you get cash back when you exit Mexico the same goes with a credit card refund. Next, copies are needed of all the paperwork, there's a copy guy in the same building cost 26 pesos or USD$2.00. Then you're good to go.  There's plenty of PEMEX gas stations along the way.

name: Laredo-Juarez/Lincoln, Laredo, Texas, USA to Nuevo Laredo, Tamaulipas, Mexico
description: Everything you need to know to be successful in Laredo:   http://centraloverland.com/2011/12/running-the-gauntlet/

name: El Paso-PDN, El Paso, Texas, USA to Ciudad, Juarez, Chihuahua, Mexico
description:
CITY  CENTER  CROSSING - PASO DEL NORTE    BRIDGES   SOUTHBOUND  BRIDGE TRAFFIC The Stanton Street  bridge is TOLL , open 24 hours per day  and feeds directly  south from the old city center of El Paso 

 NORTHBOUND  PDN BRIDGE TRAFFIC returning to the USA  is almost certain to be  backed up   because of slow processing at the US customs terminal. To avoid long waits it might be more comfortable to select  BOTA or another   crossing such as PRESIDIO/ OJINAGA   far to the east or Santa Teresa   or  PALOMAS , CHIH  to the west   into New Mexico.

name: El Paso-Bota, El Paso, Texas, USA to Ciudad, Juarez, Chihuahua, Mexico
description:
EL PASO  FREE BRIDGE TO   CD JUAREZ           BOTA =  BRIDGE OF THE AMERICAS  SOUTHBOUND TO MEXICO  AT BRIDGE  It is open around the clock every day.   Enter only the    bridge lanes designated for passenger cars, avoid TRUCK lanes and Fast Card lanes. There is no inspection from US customs when leaving the USA. If you are not bringing any taxable goods  into  Mexico  then drive into the  Mexican lane marked NADA QUE DECLARAR ( = nothing to declare) .  You may  have to push a button for a random  green/ red light for  a possible  short inspection , then you are free to go , free to spend  up to 72 hours in the border zone  without  other documents. You do NOT need to stop here to do any Mexico paperwork , do all that at km 341. 

 NORTHBOUND  TO THE USA  AT BRIDGE BOTA  traffic is going to be slow at any time. Hence the importance of doing the TVIP exit formalities at the km341  customs facility?  Have your  border crossing documents   ready to show .Any passport   will work but US  citizens can get  back in with only a US birth certificate  plus US drivers license   .

name: El Paso-Ysleta, El Paso, Texas, USA to Ciudad, Juarez, Chihuahua, Mexico
description:
ZARAGOZA  TOLL BRIDGE  is open 24/7  and  consists of a pair of bridges. The north  span carries.  pedestrians, bikes, cars, passenger  vehicles and  small  light commercial vehicles , the south span is for commercial   trucking only  Get onto Mex 45 and go to the Customs Office at km 341.  
 LEAVING  MEXICO  AT ZARAGOZA  is also  simple and straightforward.  Reminder:  JUAREZ ENTRY POINTS : 3 OPTIONS There are three  practical border crossings   between  the twin cities of EL PASO , TX and CIUDAD JUAREZ , CHIHUAHUA   namely the  city center   Paso Del Norte (PDN)    aka El Paso Street - Stanton Street Bridges ,    the Bridge Of The Americas ( BOTA)  crossing  east of downtown   at the Chamizal National Monument and  in the far southeast   suburbs is the Ysleta Toll Bridge ( ZARAGOZA) .   IMPORTANT NOTE  :: km 341 CUSTOMS  Whichever  bridge   crossing into Cd Juarez you choose , you do NOT need to stop at the bridge Mexican  customs terminal to  do any  entry paperwork ( if you have not already done that by internet) .  For Ciudad Juarez  all entry  and exit paperwork for Mexico  is  done at the Mexican Customs Control  alongside Mex 45 at the km 341 marker  about 10km  south of the intersection with Mex 2 Libre.

name: Hidalgo, Texas, USA to Reynosa, Tamaulipas, Mexico
description:
Reynosa  City Center border crossing  from Hidalgo TX 

Research requirements for obtaining Tourist Permit (FMM) and TIP for the vehicle. Hassle free areas apply in Mexico where TIP is not required.

Take in all your documents and their photocopies get Tourist Card (FMM) the TVIP and pay the Security Deposit. If you are leaving Mexico you enter this same parking lot and first pass through the lane beside the small green and white kiosk where the TVIP canceling process is started. Then to park, go inside and finalize cancellation of the FMM, the TVIP and the REFUND of the Security Deposit.   

Standard procedure applies - Know quarantine requirements, what entry requirements apply to you,  have documents ready, obey instructions, and answer questions asked.

name: Browsville-Veterans, Brownsville, Texas, USA to Matamoros, Tamaulipas, Mexico
description:
LEAVING MEXICO  &   INTO USA   Cancel your Tourist Card  (not essential as it expires anyway), your TVIP and get the TVIP SECURITY DEPOSIT REFUND before crossing the bridge

Stay in the left -most  lanes along the customs  terminal building  and at the north end just before the toll booths  turn left around the circular island and get in line for the small green and white  shack  for BANJERCITO . If you had the TVIP sticker stored with your passport then hold it up so that the RFID  scanner may read its information. OR.... Peel the sticker off your windshield and stick it back onto the document panel from where it originally came .Then hand the entire document to the BANJERCITO  clerk . The clerk will also take a digital photo of the VIN plate on your bike or car and will then return  to present you with  a  computer printout page  titled   "Recibo de Depósito de Dinero en Garantía  por la Importación  Temporal  de Vehículos   "  to which is stapled a long  strip of paper titled  "Comprobante de Retorno de Auto Americano." Together these are your proofs that you have  properly cancelled your TVIP  ..If you did pay a cash  deposit you will be instructed to go inside  to the BANJERCITO  desk to finalize and collect the money refund .
To the MIGRACION counter  to cancel the FMM / Tourist Card  and present your passport for stamping.
NB you are  still quite legal to visit downtown Matamoros and the border zone before heading into the US.  

Standard procedure applies at the US post - Know quarantine requirements, what entry requirements apply to you,  have documents ready, obey instructions, and answer questions asked.

name: Osoyoos, British Colombia, Canada to Oroville, Washington, USA
description:
OSOYOOS  , British   Columbia and Osoyoos ,Washington  is open 24/7.

Standard procedure applies - documents ready, obey instructions, answer questions asked.

name: Windsor, Ontario, Canada to Detroit, Michigan, USA
description:
See Check-in for detailed comments on one crossing

Standard procedure applies - Know quarantine requirements, documents ready, obey instructions, answer questions asked.

name: Windsor, Ontario, Canada to Detroit, Michigan, USA
description: Standard procedure applies - Know quarantine requirements, documents ready, obey instructions, answer questions asked.

name: Queenston, Ontario, Canada to Lewiston, New York, USA
description: Standard US-Canada border procedures apply, but see check-in for more detailed information.

name: Nogales-Mariposa, Nogales, Arizona, USA to Nogales, Sonora, Mexico
description:
Nogales, Sonora, Mexico has  TWO  border crossings from Nogales, Arizona, USA.  There is a city center crossing from near the en of Interstate 19 using the old main streets of both towns and it is open 24/7. 

In the Mexican Nogales, it delivers you onto Calle Lopez Mateos which runs south and turns into Mex 15, the main highway to Mexico City and all points between and anywhere else in Mexico.  The second crossing is several kilometers to the west, served by the Mariposa Road, an industrial truck bypass from I-19. This crossing is open only a limited time each day for the duration between 6h and 22h. This route becomes the Libramiento in Mexico which runs south in a wandering track through mainly industrial sites and connects with Mex 15 at the far south edge of town

For anybody visiting Mexico, it is not necessary to stop here in Nogales at either crossing to obtain the requisite Tourist Card and Temporary Vehicle Import Permit (TVIP) for the vehicle. These documents are issues at a roadside Customer and Immigration Terminal alongside Mex 15 twelve km south of the city at the km 257 marker. This facility is open 24/7 and has a Banjercito present. They will accept payment for all the documents and the compulsory TVIP security deposit. Major credit cards are readily accepted. Do have a stash of US dollar cash on you sufficient to cover the $400 maximum TVIP security deposit should the credit card be refused by the computer for some odd reason.    

For travelers coming north on Mex 15 and aiming to cross back into the USA, this roadside terminal is where you must stop to cancel your documents and get the refund for the TVIP security deposit.    Nogales is in the "frontier zone" and you may travel around in that area, up to the roadside terminal, without need for a TVIP and with no need for a tourist card if the visit is 72 hours less.

name: Douglas, British Colombia, Canada to Blaine, Washington, USA
description:
Border Blaine, WA, USA > Douglas, British Columbia, Canada

Standard procedure applies - Know quarantine requirements, what entry requirements apply to you,  have documents ready, obey instructions, and answer questions asked.

name: Lukeville, Arizona, USA to Sonoyta, Sonora, Mexico
description:
FMM available right at border. Bank to pay fee on other side of road.

You can also go down the road to San Emiterio (31.637813, -112.809264) about 17 km south to aduana and get your tourist papers, no crowds. 

TVIP can be had at Pitiquito, just south of Caborca (N30° 41.371' W112° 01.658'). You can't do BOTH at either place. Two stops, but easy and fast. 

Be warned that when you drive from US to Mexico just after the crossing the speed drops from 90 to 40 (when you drive downhill) and straight after there is often a cop with a laser. We had to pay a fine and we decided to pay at the police station. So be warned!

name: Hyder, Alaska, USA to Stewart, British Columbia, Canada
description: There are no customs on the US side of the border; pretty easy border crossing in both sides.

name: Douglas, Arizona, USA to Agua Prieta, Sonora, Mexico
description:
--I nto Mexico  Douglas/Agua Prieta 

Need Tourist Visa (FMM) and TIP. Some exemptions apply in border zones.  Need mandatory Mexican liability insurance .

After leaving the Mexican checkpoint, the Immigration and Vehicle registration is an immediate right and another right through the yellow guard-operated gates.   Go in through the unmarked beige door and you'll find everything you need.  It's helpful to have two copies of your passport and vehicle registration. You'll need to make copies of the Immigration visa anyway so have some pesos on hand to give.

Standard procedure applies - Know quarantine requirements, what entry requirements apply to you, have documents ready, obey instructions, and answer questions asked.

INTO USA:

Pretty tough if you're not holding a USA passport. as a couple if foreigners trying to do the right thing and take our vehicle out of México before it's rego expired we were rejected. We were told we could fly in but not drive in.

name: Progreso, Texas, USA to Nuevo Progreso, Río Bravo, Tamaulipas, Mexico
description: I very easy place to cross into Mexico with little traffic or drama. Cross bridge, $3 toll. Go to the back of the building where they inspect you as you come into Mexico. The is an entrance under a little carport affair. Go in an walk past the Banjericito to the left. There is a little office on the left hand side with a single lady. You will need passport, driver license, vehicle title and registration plus copies of each. You will go back and forth between her and the Banjercito a couple of times. All fees were charged to my credit card. Took about 20 minutes.

name: near Sedona, AZ
description: good pull out off FR 525.   awesome views, not a lot of traffic and has some fire pits.

name: Mogollon Rim lookout site
description:
on the FR 371 
next to rim
beautiful views
good Verizon signal
4WD required when the road is wet

name: carefree manor rv park
description:
established RV and small mobile home park;  not too large, nice pool, nice manager and decent Wi-Fi. they were renovating restrooms so we got the wifi free; normally &10 a week.  there is a free shower on pool area to use while restrooms are closed.  very quiet here this time of year.  nice views of mountains on two sides and lots of Palm trees
44 dollars a night.

name: Jamie L Whitten Historical Centre And Park Fulton
description: Same place as Fulton recreation and camping

name: Side Of Highway- Dirt Road
description: At the top of a long climb. Turn and cross cattle guard. A few rocks but okay by car. Open area with fire ring. Trees. Grass. Easy access. It does have highway noise though.

name: Flat Area Near Meadow
description: Off forest road 212 go left on 9096. Many areas to choose from around the meadow.

name: Valley of the Gods
description: Wide open and stunning. The road in is great when dry. Dozens, maybe millions, of camp spots around. Soooo quiet. No nothin. Pack it out. I could live here.

name: Mesa verde Nationalpark (outside In BLM)
description:
It is only closed seasonally and Close to the entrance of mesa Verde national park, on a dirt road more then one spot for free with firering. In the park by the store are laundrys with coins, showers for free and fast wifi.

From Hwy 160, get off at MC RD 34, then a few hundred meters, turn right at the first gravel road. Good secluded sites, a bit noisy from highway but it gets quiet after 9 pm. Some sites showed signs of overuse and garbage was left. One site looked like it had been used extensively by "travelers", with garbage bags left at the site. Lots of coyotes around. Note that showers and laundromat inside the NP are closed for the winter.

3 bars Verizon signal with LTE.
No bars AT&T

name: Flying J
description: Truck stop, large parking lot, clean restrooms.

name: Flying J truck stop
description: Huge truck stop close to Butte. Free. $10 showers. Free potable water in the red spigot in the rock barriers between the two gas station sections, bring your own hose

name: Tennessee 2 Rivers Campground
description: Excellent has good wifi full or partial hookup hot showers great pressure friendly staff shuttle to downtown 45 us with big Sam discount other parks next door at higher rates

name: Super Bowl Campground
description: A $15 per night BLM Campground  on a dirtroad,with 16 sites every site has a table and a fire ring. Pit toilets, no water. Its 10 kilometers outside of canyonland national park (needles District)

name: Dispersed Camping close to Canyonlands NP Needles District
description: Just 5 miles outside the Park. Nice Panorama, but close to HW 211 (quiet at night). Free. No facilities.

name: Black Rock Desert View from Granite Range
description:
This campsite provides a stunning panoramic view looking east out over Black Rock Desert. It is situated on BLM land, at the eastern edge of the Granite Mountain Range, about 450 ft. elevation above the Black Rock Desert playa surface. A rock fire circle and a clearing large enough for two trucks are the only amenities. This spot quite exposed, and can be windy -- but is still somehow mostly invisible from the road below, ensuring privacy.

Access: Turn off State Highway 34 at [GPS: 40.7514, -119.2843] (just southwest of the "12 mile playa access") (closest to 8 mile marker) and drive north about 1.5 miles along a rocky trail. High clearance vehicles only.

name: Lodepole Campground, Sequoia NP
description: Nice campground. 22$ / night. There are showers 1$ 5min and a laundry at the lodge nearby.

name: Eagle Pass
description: Eagle Pass is the town on the US side and Piers Negras is the town on the Mexico side. Banjercito's office is upstairs.

name: Atlatl Rock, Valley of Fire
description: Very nice campground in the Valley of Fire. Fee $ 20 including park access. Electricity only at RV sites for extra fee. No wifi, no cellphone signal.

name: Tom Sawyer R V Park Memphis West Akansas
description: Great park on the Mississippi watch the barges go by helpful staff friendly clean restroom hot showers large sites @ $32 per night wifi poor everything else great 15 min from Graceland 5 min from shopping drive time)

name: Apple gate Cove Recreational Park
description: Run by the us corps of engineers clean spacious on the lake with boat ramp large sites elec dump stn hot showers clean would love to visit in the warmer months friendly staff fire rings 20 us per night

name: Powell Springs
description: USFS free campground built by the CCC in the 1930s.  Nice, quiet, and cool.

name: Gemini Bridges Trail Little Canyon
description: It's a BLM Campground actually but it feels like boondocking and it's free. Spectacular scenery. No facilities and you are required to have a portable toilet system. Access 4X4 only.

name: Jouflas Campground at BLM Kokopellis Trail
description: Free. Tables, firerings but no firewood. Conveniently located close to I 70. Quiet. Quite nice panorama.

name: Upper Pines Campground Yosemite NP
description:
Nice campground in Yosemite Valley. 26$ / day. Fresh water and sanidump on site. Reservation is required. Showers for 5$ at the lodge. Flush toilets.

Check campsite info carefully if in a big rig - not all sites will fit. 

Decent cell coverage - slow 4G on Verizon.

name: Yosemite RV Resort
description: Nice CG about 20miles from yosemite NP. Pool, sanidump and internet at the campground. 32$ / night.

name: Capps Home Building Center
description: Nice hardware, lumber yard that sell propane

name: Westlake Automotive
description: Straight forward shop that can work on diesel 4x4's

name: Smith Mountain Lake State Park
description: Nice state campground with sites for tents through big rigs. Some sites have electricity and water. Dump station also available. Swimming, fishing and hiking available

name: Oregon Inlet Campground
description: A national Seashore campground on the beach of the Outer Banks. Open field for the most part. Usually quite windy but if the wind dies down the mosquitoes come out! There is WiFi but only at the check in area.

name: Frisco Campground
description: A nice NPS campground nestled amongst the dunes. Can have a lot of mosquitoes if the wind dies down so be prepared. I would rate this a 4.5 out of 5 stars for a nps campground. The camp is open seasonally

name: Sayre City Park Oklahoma
description: Great RV park. 80 sites. 11 large pull thru sites. Water and electricity at sites. Dump station at back entrance.  we stayed until last day in Oct when facilities closed. Otherwise $12 us per nite. Great playground, swimming pool, mini golf, and full golf course. Great walks and lovely quaint town. Also BBQ areas

name: Santa Rosa Lake State Park
description: Lovely park 10 miles north of Santa Rosa NM coordinate  not as shown here: follow the signs  off the I 40. Great water way, clean, has BBQ, showers (cold in cold weather), dump station, elec. I had no signal with AT&T but Verizon fine. GoTalk plan was spotty. better service near the electric bathrooms.

name: Elephant Butte State Park
description: Overlooking RioGrande fishing swim boat fire pits clean restrooms  needs new cleaner remote restrooms did not seem to be cleaned in months however with care one can get by

name: McClure Campground
description: Free National forest campground with 10 sites, every one with picnic table and fire ring plus pit toilets, but not water.

name: Royal Gorge Park Campground
description:
Great place for car/van camping and tent camping, small class C and B can easily fit. Most of the sites have picnic tables and fire pits. Pit toilets were super clean. 72 hour max stay every 2 weeks. Several trails to hike in area as well as the royal gorge just 2 miles away.
$20 per site

name: Emigrant, Death Valley National Park
description: Free campground within Death Valley NP. Running water, flush toilets. 10 sites only. First come,first serve system. Tents only, no RVs! Stunning views of the valley!

name: Orange Grove Camping
description:
Only Hardshells.Nice places between lanes of orange trees.Perfect showers and cheap laundry.Fairly good Wifi.All included.30 bucks.
Loud, Trains and Higway nearby.Good location after Bakersfield

name: Texas Travel Information Center
description: A big parking lot with restrooms (24 hours) and free wifi. In Texas there are 12 travel information centers where you are allowed to stay for free overnight (anthony, austin, denison, gainesville, langtry, laredo, orange, texarkana, valley, waskom, wichita falls).

name: El mirage recreation Area
description:
This is an Area with using fee 15 bucks per day, 30 per week.A lot of motorsport action takes place around the dry lake.It is allowed to camp overnight in the Area.There are same places with firepits and vault toilets.We camped at the point marked.We like the sound of dune racers, Atv, dirtbikes....
so....it was a nice sunny place....to stay, and just look over the dry lake, watching the action.

name: Silver City Rv Park
description: In town small clean friendly park full hook up good wifi 30 us night

name: SanLuisCamp
description: Behind the church, quiet, nice.

name: Colorado River State Park Campground
description:
Very beautiful campground with all services and too much noise from de hy  and the trains  :( Tents 21$, electricity 30$, full 35
$. Park fee car (day use fee) 8$

name: WelcomeToUtahCamp
description: Beautiful landscape, I did park at the information office with tables, water and pit toilets open in the night

name: Arches NP
description: One of the more beautiful spot newer seen!

name: Camp Goblin State Park
description: Very special landscape, hot water, comfortable campsite. 23$ camping and park entrance.

name: Big Sur Statepark
description: Nice but expansive campground. 35$ whitout hookup 50$ with hookup. Showers at side. I update: didn’t see any hookups. River site $50, others $35.

name: Rancho Oso RV & Camping Resort
description: Nice CC near Santa Barbara. 20$ / night. Fire pit and table at side.

name: Ryan campground
description: Official Campground in Joshua Patk.15 Bucks.First in, self registration.Small Place.Site small and near to next site.So it could be loud...if you don't like the music from neighboursite....Pit toilets small...hmm, i don't like the place very much......perhaps i'm to old ???????

name: Box Canyon Road
description:
My opinion....the best place along the nice box canyon road.
Sandy loop, 4 Wheel usefull...Camp setup just in the middle in front of the Rocks.
Morning sun beautiful.No wind, warm.Car could not be seen from the Street,even at night. Very quiet.
Mecca is only a 7 mile drive...getting Water and food....and Mecca looks and feels like beeing in mexico!

name: Morongo Casino
description:
Free Morongo Casino parking area set aside specifically for RVs.
24 hour security.
Easy access to the specified RV parking area which is the dirt lot on the South side of the Casino (not the paved overflow parking lot). Semi truck park there and leave the fridge running. You can stay here free for 3 nights. There is also a free shuttle bus that will pick up and drop off. (1 888 667 6646) There is also a trash dumpster to trop off trash.

name: Lake Cahuilla Recreation Park
description:
Camping alongside a resevoir near La Quinta, Indio. Showers costs 25¢ per 2 minutes. 

Current prices as of 12/20 are $25 for primitive sites, $30 for "water nearby". Hookups are available at some sites - I think those are $40-ish? 

Note that there is also a $8 "processing fee" for the pleasure of making your reservation. 

There is a police shooting training area across the lake, so sometimes it is noisy.

A little spendy, but pretty if you get a spot along the water, and very close to anything you might need in town.

Great cell reception on Verizon.

name: Rood Creek Park (free camping)
description: Riverside campsites are improved with firepits and picnic tables. The campground has one vault toilet but there is no electricity or potable water.

name: Parks Ranch Campground
description: FREE. 2 sites with firepits and no other amenities. This site also has a couple of cave systems that can be explored with caution. Contact Bureau of Land Management beforehand. Rigs less than 25 feet should fit without any difficulty.

name: Furnace Creek
description: Not much more that a Walmart parking lot if you think of it, fire pits and flush toilets, nothing else for $18/night, less than the average Mexican campground would offer. Electricity only at pull through RV sites for more fee. There is some cell phone signal but no data reception.

name: Kolob Terrace Rd near Zion NP
description:
