If you want electrical and water hookups for rv's, you will need to go to a $pay fee "Nebraska State Park" or a city park, which are really nice but not free, like the free Nebraska WMA's.

name: Kiowa Wildlife Management Area
description:
Wildlife Management Area (Nebraska MWA) at Kiowa Wildlife Management Area.  Free rv and tent camping for everyone, no fees charged, that is the reason it's 3 stars.  Stay/camping limited to 3 days at a time as a general rule but, could be allowed longer.  Check signage to verify or call # below.  Nice area.  Roads are gravel/dirt.

Note* As a rule:  If you have questions or want to confirm the posed signage, call (402) 471-5531 for a Nebraska Gane and Park conservation officer/ranger.  All Nebraska WMA's are free to camp for everyone.  Check signs as you enter for each WMA's specific's regulations, if there are any.  If you want electrical and water hookups for rv's, you will need to go to a $pay fee "Nebraska State Park" or a city park, which are really nice but not free, like the free Nebraska WMA's.

name: Smith Lake WMA
description:
Wildlife Management Area (Nebraska MWA) at Smith Lake Wildlife Management Area.  Free rv and tent camping for everyone, no fees charged, that is the reason it's 3 stars.  Stay/camping limited to 3 days at a time as a general rule but, could be allowed longer.  Check signage to verify or call # below.  Nice area.  Roads are gravel/dirt.

Note* As a rule:  If you have questions or want to confirm the posed signage, call (402) 471-5531 for a Nebraska Gane and Park conservation officer/ranger.  All Nebraska WMA's are free to camp for everyone.  Check signs as you enter for each WMA's specific's regulations, if there are any.  If you want electrical and water hookups for rv's, you will need to go to a $pay fee "Nebraska State Park" or a city park, which are really nice but not free, like the free Nebraska WMA's.

name: Shell Lake Wildlife Management Area
description:
Wildlife Management Area (Nebraska MWA) at Shell Lake Wildlife Management Area.  Free rv and tent camping for everyone, no fees charged, that is the reason it's 3 stars.  Stay/camping limited to 3 days at a time as a general rule but, could be allowed longer.  Check signage to verify or call # below.  Nice area.  Roads are gravel/dirt.

Note* As a rule:  If you have questions or want to confirm the posed signage, call (402) 471-5531 for a Nebraska Gane and Park conservation officer/ranger.  All Nebraska WMA's are free to camp for everyone.  Check signs as you enter for each WMA's specific's regulations, if there are any.  If you want electrical and water hookups for rv's, you will need to go to a $pay fee "Nebraska State Park" or a city park, which are really nice but not free, like the free Nebraska WMA's.

name: Indian Cove Campground, Joshua Tree NP
description:
Official NPS campground off of the main campgrounds of Joshua Tree NP.
Mostly reservation sites but had plenty of free spots available when we were there.

A lot of climbing going on. sometimes directly in the "backyard" of the campsites.

25 usd/night (05/2022)

water is available at the visitor's center and registration.

name: Yurok visitor centre
description:
perfect spot! there's not much I'm yurok but there is a visitor centre. we parked around the back which just seems to be a pretty empty carpark with hardly any cars about. no signs or anything to say you can't park. 

there are toilets and water towards back of the visitor centre. toilets are locked at night but there are toilets at the petrol station across the road too. 

no signal but you can get pretty good WiFi ('yurok youth centre') by parking outside the second group of buildings as you face away from the visitor centre. you should see what I mean when you get here.

name: Tha Station's Inn Motorcycle Resort
description:
Just off the Blue Ridge Pky. Hotel, restaurant and small store. Live music on weekends. $75/night for solo traveler.

No wifi in rooms but, strong near restaurant. Covered parking.

name: San Juan nf
description: A parking lot for the turkey trail. No aminities. Quiet. FREE

name: City of South Bend Ron Craig boat launch
description: gravel lot by the river with picnic table. Nice view. $10 for RV, $5 for a tent. Good Verizon cell signal.

name: Soldotna, parking by Fred Meyer supermarkt
description:
Big parking by Fred Meyer supermarket. Wifi available from supermarket.
free dump point

name: Sutton, Gravel parking bij vliegveld
description:
Secluded parking near more near airport. During the day there was a lot of noise (weekend) but at night it was quiet. 

Afgelegen parking bij meer in buurt van vliegveld. Overdag werd er (weekend) veel gecrost maar 's nachts was het rustig.

name: Frontline Eurosports BMW Motorrad
description:
BMW, Ducati, Triumph motorcycle sales and service.

Gave priority service to traveling m/c.

name: Hyder, Gravel parking
description: Big gravel parking in forest. Close by platform where bears come fishing for salmon. So look out for bears.

name: Spring creek road
description: A small parking lot between the road and the river. No cars on the night. Very quiet just the noise of the river. No amenities. FREE

name: Thompson Falls, parking swimmingpool
description: Parking lot near swimming pool, we stood here from 7pm until 8am, there where no problems. The swimming pool was closed after 19th of august.

name: Silver City
description: Parking Silver City Saloon. Drink something, ask for permission and you have a place for the night. Quiet during the night. Toilets inside.

name: Deaver, BLM
description: Wild camping on BLM land, near a lake. Divers places, first come, first stay. Pit toilets and picknick benches. Free.

name: In the flowers
description: There are several free sites on this road without exit. There is a paid campground too. We stayed on the last free site, a huge grassy area with nice view over the mountains, a river and a lot of sun flowers in May.

name: E.G. Simmons Regional Park
description:
Large regional park on 258 acres of native mangroves with open land areas and intertwined with waterways.

Park has many amenities including a great campground with many sites right along the water/mangroves. Sites have water and electric hookups and there are nice bathrooms with showers.

name: Roubaix Lake, Nat. Forest
description: Roubaix Campground is a free campground in a wood near a lake in which you can swim. There are several walking trails. Picknick tables and fire rings. Toilets and drinking water. Quiet place. $ 24 per night for RV's.

name: Walmart Visalia
description: Friendly security, let us stay overnight. Pretty noisy, close to highway and there is loading/unloading at night.

name: Jackson's Island
description: A good amount of free campsites on a lake in TN. Concrete slabs for your tent and fire rings, but no bathrooms, grills, water, or tables. Beautiful and quiet in the non summer months. Can stay 14 days with no trouble, but I've heard of other campers staying longer. There aren't many free campgrounds in Tennessee so this is a real gem, be nice to it. Leave no trace.

name: Carpinteria State Beach
description:
Established Campground between the beach and a railroad. trains do not run at night, still a bit annoying though. $45  for a tent site in high season. Coin operated showers a token per 2-minutes. 
The trains can be terrifying

name: Smith Creek Campground: Creekspots #2
description:
This last weekend my girlfriend and I stayed for two nights within the first area of campsites just West of the initial RD 287 access point, a few yards from the creek itself.

I went a day early to scope out the area since I found bits and pieces of info online but nothing too detailed about this specific area. This campsite is all dispersed camping. Up RD287 (North) there are a few sites scattered on the left and right, the top-most being what looked like the biggest and most secluded, though it was taken when I saw it. The other spots seemed in rough shape but that could have been an illusion as I didn't actually get out to check any of these spots up this road. I considered these spots the official "Smith Creek Campground" as labeled on the map, and even though I'm sure the whole area uses this label, I'm gonna call this area SCC.

Almost directly across the street from SCC to the south (back on Highway 96), just to the west a few yards is an entrance to a couple sites on the creek side of the highway (I'll call these "Creekspots #1"). But these camping areas seemed lived-in and definitely weren't being maintained or cleaned. It was sad, tbh. But I kept driving west, and not even a few hundred yards farther West from the Creekspots #1 entrance on 96 was another entrance with a sign that read "Wanted: Your fire DEAD OUT", and this one led to a number of sites. I'll call this area Creekspots #2.

The first couple camping areas in Creekspots #2 had nice parking and were easily accessible by car or truck. I parked here initially since I was in a Camry just scoping out the place. There was a road up which I eventually walked up that looked like it was better suited for trucks, jeeps, or brave car-drivers only. So I stayed parked near the entrance. A short walk had me to the creek and there were a couple spots to the left (East) and many more spots up to the right (West). The creek was audible from this entire area, btw. At the time, no spots were occupied, that I could tell. It was pretty clean and user-maintained too, especially after what I'd seen at Creekspots #1 and up SCC.

I walked near the creek and followed it up, between the creek and the road, and came across some 1 or 2 more 1-4 person areas. Up the little Creekspots #2 Rd just a walk was a bigger, open area that the road cut through. A few of the spots seemed to be taken over by ants but for the most part, the spots all seemed ready for easy camping. All the spots I saw had remnants of old campfires. The road kept going across the creek, accessible by braver people with 4WD to what looked like at least 1 more site, but it could have been dozens more for all I know; I didn't get a chance to get across, the water was running pretty good (mid-May).

There were a few more even farther west than the road went, where you can walk a trail that goes for maybe a hundred or so yards. It could have even gone further, but there was a point where I decided I wasn't going to lug my stuff any further since I wasn't preparing for a backpacking-style camping trip.

We came back the next day in a truck and I drove past the first couple obvious parking spots available right as you pull in to the second obvious parking spot that was a single spot, perfect for me to back up the truck. (Careful for big rocks in the ground)

We stayed here and it was beautiful. The creek is yards away, far enough to have to walk to it but close enough to always hear it steadily flowing. It's serenely peaceful in the morning, of course. I don't know what this place looks like once the camping season really gets started but our mid-May trip was fantastic and I'm excited to come back and try it again.

If you visit the spots based on my review, please just pick up after yourself. Good camping is only good camping if we work together to keep it that way.

name: Close to homestake creek
description: Great place in a parking lot close to the river. Very quiet in the middle of the trees. FREE

name: Camp Creek
description:
$25/day to overnight camp.  Honor box.  Fire pits, picnic tables
Toilet dry, no water, no electricity

name: Kaibab Camper Village
description: This place has hookups and nice tent sites. $37 for RV, $18 for tent.  You can only stay one night at a time.  We got in late on Thursday of Memorial Day weekend and found a nice tent spot.

name: Tomlinson Run State Park
description:
Nice campground, clean bathrooms. Check-in before 8:30 PM.
Too expensive!!

name: Bolar Mountain Campground
description: A National Forrest Campground on the shores of pristine Lake Moomaw

name: Apache Trail Wild Camp
description: One of dozens of wild camping options off of Apache Trail. From Roosevelt Lake until just about this point is dirt with tons of pull offs. This one is clearly used by 4x4s. You can camp just off of the road or follow a couple of different trails down the hill to get to this spot farther from the road. Stunning views and quiet overnight. Watch out for cacti and ground covering plants with stickers that will cover almost everything that touches the ground!

name: Lake Tyler East boat landing
description:
Basically a boat landing and day recreation use with a parking area, overnight camping seems to be allowed. There are some spots for about four rigs, with picnic tables, a porta potty and garbage cans. And a nice view over the water. FREE!
Friendly people around here!

name: Little Egypt
description: Parking on Geologic Site on Lone Cedar Road, no facilities. Free. Road to here is gravel and sand, don't drive with heavy rain. You can see nice Hoodoos. Entrance/road: N38.0971º, W110.6222º.

name: Waterwheel campground
description:
Great campground at the river near interstate. We got a site for 20 bucks
New showers and wifi at office
Very friendly owner

name: Pyramid Lake RV Resort
description: Paid RV park just off I5. Some trees ..............................

name: The Ohana Family Cafe
description: A must-stop. The best small-town America experience we've had to date... Excellent pulled pork, delicious BBQ sauce and a delightful variety of yummy pies. The staff and owners are lovely and made us feel extraordinarily welcome. On top of bottomless cups of coffee, there is reasonably fast wifi (no mobile service here). Highly recommend: Roel (from Holland): "The best place I've eaten at in the US." :) Lots of free wild camping options between here and the Very Large Array.

name: Wind Wolves Preserve
description:
At Wind Wolves, The Wildlands Conservancy offers free outdoor education programs in which over 165,000 children have participated. The Wind Wolves Preserve is open to the public daily from 8 am to 5 pm for hiking, mountain biking, and picnicking. Tent camping is available by advanced reservation. There are seasonal wildflower and wildlife viewing tours by vehicles. For more information, call 661.858.1115.

ACCESS

16019 Maricopa Hwy.
Bakersfield, CA 93311
661.858.1115

name: Peshtigo River side camp by small bridge
description: Small site, by Peshtigo river. Good fishing! Private and very forested.

name: Mike Freeze Wattensaw NMA dispersed camping
description:
This is an area of large, flat dispersed campsites of the department of wildlife and fisheries near Hazen. Several campsites are available. FREE!
Nice and quiet, even on Memorial Day weekend! 
If your navigator sends you to a dirt road, take the next one, #708, then go right on #122. It will lead you to an archery club; the camps are around there.

name: silver bells
description:
national forest service campground.
$15. river access.

name: Silver Queen
description: Forest Service campground. 6 sites near river. $15

name: Fillmore Recreation Area
description: Campground maintained by the Dubuque County Conservation Board.

name: Mud Lake Park
description: Campground owned and maintained by the Dubuque County Conservation Board. Sites are generally $23.00 per night. Reservations must be made three days prior to the date of reservation, but can be made up to a year in advance.

name: New Wine Park
description: This campground is owned and maintained by the Dubuque County Conservation Board. Reservations must be made three days prior to the day you wish to camp but may be made up to a year in advance. Camping rate is $23.00 per night.

name: Massey Marina
description: This campground is owned and operated by the Dubuque County Conservation Board. Reservations must be made three days prior to the day you wish to camp but can be made up to a year in advance. Camping fee is $23.00 per night.

name: Recreative area
description: a typical rest area of US, but this particular one with a GREAT view of the mountains! there is a lake where is also possible to fish. really nice place to stay. Free

name: Public parking Behind high school
description:
Nice place to stay for a night.
It's a public parking so staying all day is allowed.
Good start to visit Boston with ferrys

name: Near Lost Lake road
description: There are a total of 9 different camping sites along the length of this road (4 miles?).  All  with lots of shade and set back off the road nicely.Many hiking trails in the vicinity. Many with rock fire rings and nice views. National forest. free.

name: Multiple logging fire roads, multiple camping spots
description: There are plenty of trails going into the woods with plenty of camping opportunities. It's very dry, so it's probably not possible to make a fire.

name: Glacier Meadows RV
description: Private but reasonable campground that accommodates big rigs as well as tents

name: Carrizo Plain National Monument
description: Quail Valley Road Primitive Site

name: Bonelli Landing
description:
Beautiful place nearby Lake Mead. 
Very lonesome and without any service.

name: lower antelope canyon
description:
here starts the trail in the lower antelope canyon. 33 dollars per person but it worth. It really amazing.  
$40 each plus $8 (cash) to Navajos. Very busy. May check out other slot canyons for free.

name: Oh Be Joyful!
description: BLM campground just outside of Crested Butte. Riverside, pit toilets, fire rings, tables. $10 for sites with tables and $5 without

name: Tent Camping on Lake
description: Nice Free Campground on the Lake. But with the Car you can only stay in the Parkinglot! but its just 30 Meters down to the Lake! With Tent you can camp next to the Lake. Beatuful......:-)

name: North of bear tooth.. Behind limberpine campground. Free
description: Follow the gravel road across the river past the national forest camp grounds.. The road go's for 8 miles up the valley with a lot of great spots for any size.. Gets busy in summer..

name: Red rock lakes national wildlife refuge
description: Upper and lower lake campsite. 7$. The upper one has a fresh water spring and some trees and shade. The lower one puts you in the middle of valley right by the lake, no shade. But you can't beat the stunning 360 views..

name: Sams and Home depot
description: Called ahead and they were ok with one night stay on east side of parking lot.

name: Soup lake spot
description: Nice place near lake and highway with a few firepits.

name: Taylor ranch road
description: A single place between the trees. View on the snows montains and bording the river.  A few meters from Taylor Ranch road, on a dirty road (but driveable even with a 2 wheels).

name: Grasshopper National forest campground
description: NF Campground just below Elkhorn Hot Springs. Free, when we were there, maybe a small fee during summer season? This is just the southernmost NF Campground of many more along the scenic byway (all paved) through the Pioneer mountains.

name: KOA Livingston/Paradise Valley
description: We stayed in a tent site.  They are really nice.  They are in the trees with grassy areas for pitching your tent, and not in a corner of the parking lot.  Plus, it was only $13 a night for a site with electricity.  Friendly people and hot showers.  They have breakfast on the weekends.  We stayed one night on our way from Yellowstone to Glacier.

name: Kombi Haus Sacramento
description:
Solid workshop specialized in VW and Audi, old an new. They have a separate body shop two blocks away where they do restoration (incl. insurance work). I had quite a lot of issues with my 1984 Westfalia Vanagon (damaged valves, had cylinder heads replaced etc.), so I spent some time here and can only recommend them.
They’re busy (call ahead if you can), but everyone is focused. I was especially glad they let me have a look at my car with the mechanics and talk to them in person (many US workshops will chase you out the door if you try that). They got all the parts needed and are really familiar with Bugs, Kombis, Vanagons, Rabbits, Golfs as well as the newer models and do quality work. Labour rate is USD 118/h, but all in all I got a good price (for US standards). Could sleep in my van in the parking lot every night for almost three weeks. Justin (owner) is a really professional, calm, friendly and genuinely nice guy. Highly recommended.

name: Roseville Automall Chevron
description: Water & dump, Is now $10.00 flat fee with or without fueling and fuel is more expensive than other stations.

name: Lake Fork campground
description:
National Forest Service site. $16.
paved flat parking with views, table, fire pit, restrooms. Close to the road, but works for a night.

name: Black Canyon NP
description: National Park. First come first served camping in Loop C. $16. Loop A and B are reservable and have electricity ($22) Bring all your water. Great, expansive views.

name: Ampitheater Campground
description: high above Ourey,  national forest service site. Pricey at $24, but amazing views and extra hours of sunshine. weak cell service. water, pit toilets.

name: Shower Pismo Beach
description: Hot shower in Pismo Beach at "oceano campground - county of san luis obispo", mendel drive. 3 minutes for 1 dollar (quarter only)

name: Thistledown Campground
description: US Forest Service site. Raging rapids, big mountain views. fire pit, table, pit toilets. $10

name: Lake Cascade State park
description: Great State Park off of Hwy 55 Idaho.  Camping next to lake

name: Monument Valley KOA
description: New (opened April 17) campground - not everything is finish yet - with a beautiful view to the mountains.  David is a very friendly Manager who takes Care of his guests and has a lot of good ideas. No wifi at the moment but there will be in a couple of weeks.  Quiet at night.  30.- $ for full hook up, special prices for dry site. Close to NP.

name: Burr Trail - beautiful Place in red Long Canyon
description: Great, quiet spot in the red rocks of Long Canyon. Close to a small river.

name: Mountain view at Uinta-Wasatch-Cache National Forest
description: Found this place on our way to Springville. We didn't camp there but the view is breathtaking. Wild camping spot with a little fire place in a national forest.

name: Bobs Creek, Hells Canyon BML
description: Free BLM Campsite with pit-toilet and free wifi-hotspot. There are several such places along the western side of Hells Canyon on Homestead Rd (gravel) along the Snake river. Swimming possible, too.

name: Telluride Town Park
description:
It's all about the location. Tell yourself that as you pay $28. Then, enjoy the immediate proximity to town and all the greatness that is Telluride. Campground has fast wifi, showers, riverside spots, etc.
Go camp somewhere free for the next few nights to make up for splurging.

name: Camp coeur d"Alene
description: Gorgeous campground on the lake plus with pool, laundry, and free firewood. A former KOA there are tent sites, rv sites and cabins. Super hot showers and only 8 miles from town.

name: Cedar Rest Motel
description: Great budget motel dor travellers and families! One of the cheapest in the area but strongly recommended! Great place to stay when you want to visit Bryce Canyon and around. Very clean, fresh, renewed. Very kind owners from Fiji. AC, great internet, microwave, TV and fridge. Close to the shops, laundry and gastronomic places. Safe big parking, even for RVs. Breakfast in the morning. 45$ for two people.

name: Riley Store and Archery
description: General store, gas, approx. 10 RV hookups, free tent camping for motorcyclists.  Riley, OR.

name: One spot next to river
description: One straight pull-in site with good early and late shade.  Could accommodate a big rig if your back-up skills are good. The road to get here is 2-3 miles of easy dirt/gravel well graded road. Any vehicle can do it.  Fire ring.  Sleep to sound of the river, assuming it flows like this always, which it probably doesn't (I'm here in June).

name: Simard automotive
description: Auto service on chevron gas station. They fixed our Ford Club wagon. Really good people there.

name: Forest Road 006
description: many spaces on this road, some are occupied with Trailers, may be for weekend. Verry quiet, in spring the creek nearby has much water. Pit toilets at entry.

name: cottonwood road
description: This is a large clearing just off a moderately trafficked and well maintained dirt road. There’s a nice river and a beach-like spot. Also has a couple fire pits and a picnic table. This is the biggest spot on the road but there’s more spots as you continue towards Cottonwood Lake.

name: Hunter Peak Campground
description: A nice little Campground at the River, good for relax also for a few days,  15 $.

name: Willow Park
description: Open grasy land between forest,  street and River. A lot of space, free Camping limited for 16 days. A good place for overnight standing while visiting the Yellowstone Park. Only 12 miles from the north east entrance. Its quiet but not very private.

name: Pilar
description:
Free Water drink visitor center rio grande!

Water is by unattached restrooms/outhouses.

name: Florida Welcome Center I-10
description: Large trucks parking with security. Lot's of 18 wheelers and a couple of RVs. Nice staff, 24/7 restrooms/vending machines, free OJ when you arrive (before 5:00).

name: Hole in the Ground
description:
Huge marr crater in Oregon's high desert, national forest. Multiple established campsites around the rim. Please do not cut or destroy vegetation here! Dry and dusty most of the year. Avoid in winter as the roads are not cleared. Expect wind and cold nights. 
DO NOT drive the roads in winter, they are posted CLOSED until March 31 for a reason! Respect the proper use of our public roads here so that they stay in good condition.

name: C Lazy Moose RV Park
description: This RV park can accommodate large rigs, has full hookups and for the motorcyclists, also has a grassy tenting area. Best of all are the hot showers (no extra cost) and a coin operated laundry. Tent +2 people $20.00US.  Full service site 30amp  $38.00.  There is no store here but you can buy breakfast sandwiches at the office that they will heat in a microwave. Also sodas, coffee and ice cream available. Just showers $5.

name: Lost Creek Campground
description: Small secluded decommissioned Campground. 15 spots right on Big Lost Creek. 7 miles of gravel forrest road to get there. Pit toilets, no water, picnic tables,  and fire pits. I filtered water straight from the creek. Free.Free for up to 14 days.

name: America's Best Value Inn
description: Nice, clean rooms. Best price in town. We checked several hotels/ motels. the Motel 6 wanted to charge $130! This place was $99. Staff is very kind. They are pet friendly.

name: MOTEL Majestic Rockies
description: Great and not so expensive place to stay in the city. Motel with every convenience. Tv, sat, wi-fi inside, AC, parking, heating, big beds, bathroom, fridge and hot water. Very clean and comfortable. Near you have a gas station and Subway. The small room for two I called for pricing and was told $350.00 weekly.

name: Lower Piedra
description: Forest Service campground. $22. A pleasant stop for a night - camping under pines and near a river. Clean restrooms.

name: Near Race Track Road
description: After 7 miles on an easy dirty road, we found this huge grassy flat place. Several fire pits. Between a forest and mountains. Nice view all around. Close to a river but we didn't try to fish. This place is in a national forest. Free.

name: Milford Lake - West Rolling Hills Park
description:
Basic primitive campsites in a special area of the park for free camping. 
Very beautiful and close to the lake for swimming. 

More well-equipped, paid campsites further down the road. 1st turn off is day use, next is basic camping, on down the road is the paid campground with an RV area and a tent camping area.

name: Rice Lake Wildlife Management Area
description: Beautiful spot at the end of a small gravel road close to the lake. Very quiet and lonesome.

name: Hidden Lake
description:
A wild huge free spot in the Lolo National Forest. Lake, view, wood for fire pit, quiet, fishing, toilet...solid Verizon service. amazing spot and definitely still a local secret.
2 bars of 4G T-Mobile

name: Dismal Nitch Rest Area
description:
MODERATOR NOTE: 8 hour parking limit.
----
Very scenic rest area right by the highway, free and legal to overnight. Beautiful view across the Columbia River, to Astoria and the bridge. Picnic tables. A paved walkway takes about 15 minutes to do the loop - stretch your legs and watch the river.
Some traffic noise during the day, quieter at night. Level.

name: Econolodge, Limon
description: very clean. great price. nice staff. right off the highway.

name: 4 Corners Park
description:
Farthest Northeast city in the US. If you're doing a 4-corners tour of the US, this is the place.

Nice park with photo-op monument, dedicated pavers and a small gift shop where you can buy souveniers

Free admission.

name: Up Hill Wild Campspot
description: Nice Place above a Hill with a absolut amazing 360 view and amazing view down to Fairbanks!!! a local guy showd me the Place! but a lot of Trash up here...:-(

name: Fossil Falls Camping
description:
perfect on the way to death valley. nice landscape.  not much Shelter  from the wind
$6pppn

name: on the roads to Big Sand dune
description: between beaty and Vegas. Watch out for the sign "big sand dune". follow the road and you will find plenty of space on both sides. no 4wd needed. too windy for tent. no shade. beautiful  views.  quiet and hidden from the main road. Good VERIZON Signal.

name: Colter Bay Campground
description:
RV dump only for those staying the night with camping fees. No public dump

At the General Store (500m away from campground) there are also showers, laundry and free WiFi. Electricity at laundry and drinking water tap outside to fill water containers. $38 per night

name: Grandview
description: Nice campground among pinion and juniper. Very sunny and dry, but there is shade to be found. Located 18 miles NE of Big Pine. Road climbs 4500 ft with steep grades and many tight curves and dips. $10 suggested donation. Pit toilets, no water.

name: Cowboy Camp BLM
description: Cache Creek Natural Area - in BLM-Land. A free spot in a nice area. A lot of singing birds. Really quiet at night. No cellphone signals. No bins, bring it in - take it out to keep this beautyful place clean.

name: Rainy Lake Campground
description: Free forest campground next to clear lake with great views. About 8 spots total, but 7 are walk-in, so if you're in a vehicle you have to hope that spot #1 is available. No overnighting in the parking lot, designated camp spaces only.

name: Amber Inn Motel
description: Cheap place to stay for travellers. 54 $ with tax for small double bed for two. Nice, clean with everything you need wifi, fridge, microwave, bath, tv, AC and heating. Not crowded, you can see it from the highway. Near gas station and 2 bars-you can get 10% off from owners in a motel. Recomended. The cheapest option we found.

name: White Pine Lake Campground - Superior National Forest
description:
Rustic Camping for FREE! 
There are 3 campsites with table and fire ring, nearby the lake, good for  swimming. You can stay here for max. 14 days. Beautiful area in the National Forest.

name: Carlsbad Caverns - Visitor Center and Entrance
description:
This is the carlsbad caverns visitor center and the location where you enter the cave. 
$10usd fee to enter
you can take an elevator down to the main cave, or you can do a hike through the natural entrance. the hike in and out takes you 750ft. up/down in about a mile, but it's a comfortable hike in the cool cave temperature.
beautiful caves, very developed with lights and trails, but amazing none the less!

name: Oxbow Campground
description:
Privately owned (non govt) campground. Small store, shuffle board, horse shoes, swimming, boating and fishing ponds. Cabins available.

$20/night for non-electric site, solo motorcyclist.

name: Milk Creek Rd. Fs585
description: This spot is up the Millcreek Road which is forest service Road 1708. Take the 585 Spur Rd. and stay left large overlook. Can be a little windy

name: Waterfront Bridge by Portage Lake
description: Gravel turn off before bridge and tunnel for boat launch (next to visitor center but no access from parking lot only road). You can camp right next to the water with views of the glaciers. Toilets and restaurant uphill from site.

name: Wenatchee National Forest
description: This is a place just outside of Plain Washington near Lake Wenatchee. You need a high clearance 4x4 to get there. Road is a little rough. Beautifully quiet with lots of flowers in old burn forest. Bear was near camp so keep food closed up he was curious more than anything.

name: Toyota Barstow
description: Great mechanic, ask for Tom in service and Jimmy as mechanic; had us back on road in 12 hours. Very accommodating, great service, fair price.

name: Anaheim resort even park
description:
Will take overlanders with roof top and enclosed vehicle. Sites 569 to 574 have shade
It will suite if you want go visit the parks Disney and universal. Gas food food  close by. Shuttle out front that runs all day so you can leave your vehicle and get to most places. It's not free but clean secure and like I said great for the parks. Water/pool/laundry/ internet on site

name: Nice but trains
description:
Parking in front of the lake.
If trains were not pass, it would be perfect !
But ok for one night...

name: Nice restaurant nearby
description:
Nice parkings near Maumee bay brew pub ! Top for a night.
Gas station not so far

name: Clackamette RV Park
description: RV Park at the River ,25-25 Dollar, no showers, no wifi, near small shoppingcenter

name: Elwha RV Park
description: Great Place. We had a Tentsite for 25$. Very nice people who also do dogsitting. We took the ferry to Victoria and left the dog here for one day. We loved it here

name: PGE Pelton Park Campground
description: beautiful size directly at the lake. swimming area, boat launch and small store as well. 18$ a night for a tentsite. got rv sites and tentsites with Power as well. no wifi. bathrooms and showers are nice and clean

name: Stevens Lake Campground
description: Several small sites right on lake. No amenities so no RV's or yahoos! Quiet, safe, good fishing. Tables and fire pits. NOT big rig friendly.

name: Gooseberry Falls Campground
description: Big campground, 5 different waterfalls, views of Lake Superior. Amenities. Pay to camp $$

name: 12 Foot Falls
description: Small County campground, 7 sites. Very forested. Tables and fire rings and shade. $10 a night.

name: Moab Valley RV resort and campground
description: Expensive! Typical RV resort with pool, laundry, etc. Came into town late, couldn't find a spot in one of the BLM campgrounds, so this was my only option - $55 for a covered tent spot!!

name: El Capitan State Park Campground
description: State Park camp ground on beach. Nice sites with tables. Coin paid hot showers. $45 per night. This fee allows access to State Parks for day use further up coast. During Summer may need to book in advance. Reservations via website only.

name: Lost Lake Campground
description: Big campground in national forest. Pay to camp $$. Trees, shade, nice calm lake.

name: Twitley Branch campground State Park
description: State park on the Okatibbee lake. Place for tent sand camper cans w/o service on site except portable water for 12$/night. RV sites for 20$ with electricity. Dump station. Hot showers. Nice place and clean.

name: Rico Dolores River
description: A large space between the road and the river. right on county line marker

name: Texhoma Parky
description:
Free overnight (24 hours only) RV parking (all paved) with electricity, 50,30,20 amp, dump station, water, restrooms, and playground. You can leave a donation if want in the box. 

It is next to active train tracks, so may not be a good place for light sleepers.

Full facilites for RV and overlanders (not really suited for hammock camping). Att no showers.

name: Bakers Hole Campground $ 20 or 28$(electricity)
description: We stayed two nights. Clean bathrooms, water throughout the site, each site fits two cars or one MH and one car. $ 16 per day check out at 2 pm. Additional car pays only 7 dollars. We got our RV and two friends who arrived the next day with a truck and a camper paid $ 7 as an additional car. Show..dump and potable water for free customers.

name: Walmart
description: Parking lot on the left is very calm Many RVs. Store is closed during the night.

name: Horse Camp Campground - free
description:
Free dispersed camping area in Sequoia National Forest, ~ 1 mile off the Generals Highway, off Big Meadows Road. There's no sign saying "Horse Camp" but its shown on map you get when you enter Sequoia National Park. No facilities but beautiful area, some sites with views of the mountains. There were only a few others campers (also in tents) when we were there. OK for trucks and camper vans but entry road is likely not accessible for big rigs. The location is for our site; there were many sites before this one. Free. 

ADMIN NOTE: user reports: "The campgrounds are further down the road (approximately 2 1/4 miles from Generals Highway), and are well marked. There are corrals along the entrance road so it's hard to miss. Buck Rock Campground is at the same turnoff. "

name: Stevens Lake Campground
description: Nice little quiet Campground. In National Forest. Nice lake and shade. Swimming. Cost $12.

name: Bagley Rapids Campground
description: On the Oconto River. Nice shady spot, pay to camp $$ in National Forest. Very nice area.

name: salt river - campground - free
description: several campsites with picnic tables close to the river. 5 day limit.

name: Showers at Patricks Point State park
description:
Not perfect but great when you need a shower...
Located in campground at Patricks Point State park (in direction to agate beach).
1 quarter for 1 minute, mini 2 quarters

name: Copeland
description: Smith lake seemed to be nice but was crowed. We foud this flat place near a river with restroom and fire pite. 20 km before or after the border. Quiet at night.

name: Keller Lake County Park
description: County park lake camping. Boat launch. Pay to camp $$

name: Los Banos KOA Campground
description: Standard KOA campground, good costumer service, playground for kids, mostly RV "camping" but a few tent sites.

name: Stovepipe Wells Campground
description: Not the greatest camping. Lots of RV spots, if you tent camp you are left with placing your tent on the gravel parking lot they have created. It is next to a restaurant, general store, fuel station, and has bathrooms. Overall a decent place to camp in Death Valley.

name: San Simeon Campground
description: Nice campground near Hearst Castle in Cambria, CA. When you want to dump, it's 5 $. Fresh water included.

name: kaibab forest off of desert view dr
description:
can access this wild spot from the scenic drive on grand canyon national park. 
turn south down coconino road and drive till you see kaibab national forest signs. at first the road says no camping, but when you pass into national forest land it is fine.
a few other campers, several flat-ish spots, nice and quiet. great spot to stay while exploring the grand canyon.

name: Distant Drums RV
description: Just off I 17

name: Williams Bottom
description: Nice BLM campground, some shade on some sites. Beautiful view at night and fairly quiet (it's along a street, but has very little traffic in evening and night). It's $15 with self registration.

name: Lake
description: A huge parking lot close to a fishy lake. No amenities. We stop here just for the meal. FREE

name: Irish Canyon
description: Nice free campground with firepits picnic  tables and restroom. Short hiking nearby.

name: manti lasal national forest
description: there is an established campground here, certains with fees.  We were à few miles further in the canyon  and sept for free with a scenic view.

name: Death Valley Visitor Centre
description: Dump station and free potable water to fill in front of the Death Valley visitor center.

name: Ponderosa State Park
description: big site directly by the lake. plenty of shade, spots to swim. all sites(including tents have water/power hookups. very expensive, 35$

name: Next to the road near a Stone ruin. Shadow.
description: couldn't find the Spot nearly, so we took this. nothing special and some trash, but good views and quiet. a bit away from the road.

name: nice places near river. quiet
description: hot  springs on opposite site. nice walk down to the river.  lot of wildlife.  shadow.  good gravel road. no 4wd and no high clearance  needed.

name: Snow Canyon State Park
description: State Park about 100 miles northeast of Las Vegas.  $25 hook up $20 no hook up.  Not just a stop going someplace else.  Nice site and hiking.  Reservations call either 800 322-3770 or 801 322-3770.   Almost On the same level as Bryce or Zion.

name: Seaton recreational area
description: very nice spot to stay one night . one barbecue place and some table below a shelter . it' s free for this night at this times.

name: Chevron station
description: you can use the dump station if you take some petrol at the chevron station . And the regular is less expensive than gasoline in Canada border . and free potable water at the left of the station.

name: Off highway
description: Quiet place far away of the highway , on the wood, just a rating of the river. A moose crossed the river in front the camp . One fire place, no sign, free and calm . ok 24feet rv

name: Meadowbrook Public Campground
description: State run campground with hot showers and flush toilets. Close to lake Placid and Saranac lake.

name: Free campsite on gravel Road 59
description:
This road ends 1 km further on the parking lot of the hiking trails - nice trails. So nobody drives this road at night - and very quiet during the day. This campsite is alongside the river where you can refresh yourself and there is a fire pit. If you don't need portable water and toilets, this spot is as good as the campground is but for free.
There is a similar spot 100 m before.

name: Bryce Canyon Market Area - Laundry & Showers
description:
Near the lodge.
You can pay for showers and laundry here, as well as goods in the store.
$2.50 for 1 load of laundry, .25/ 4 minutes for the dryer.
Shower tokens can be purchased in the market, $3 for 8 minutes of shower time. 
Showers and bathrooms are cleaned daily from 2-2:30 (closed during that time) so best to shower right after that. Close at 5:30
No services in the winter. Says it opens in March but no specific day.

name: Showers and laundry in Florence
description:
Showers in the laundry (near the thrift store, on 37th street), 4 dollars for 8 minutes, so great !!!
And you can wash your clothings in the same time !

name: Rouge River NF outside Crater Lake
description: Disperse camping at NF. Turn right after the Sno parking. Follow the dirt road  350 m to the left. Fire pit. Space for tent or van.

name: Tower traveler center
description: Gas station with bakery and smal restaurant alot of room to park big truck or rv good place to rest

name: Chevron Fuel Station Dump. FREE
description: free dumping at chevron fuelstation. we asked inside and they said it is free. potable water is also available.

name: Bunk + Brew Historic Lucas House
description:
Amazing new hostel. They allow you to stay in their parking lot. There is a package called "dirt bag", that includes a bottle of beer, shower, wifi and laundry for $10pp (off season),$15pp. (High season). Very friendly staffs and clean place. There is no sign outside yet but the building is a beautiful brick house.  
They no longer allow you to stay overnight outside in your van

name: National Forest free campsite at ohv trailhead
description: tables and benches. fireplaces.  no 4wd needed but lots of off-road trails nearby. very quiet.

name: Buffalo hot springs
description: I did not  camp here but stoped for shower and swimming in hot springs pool  there is  camping rv sight water is hot sauna hot tub  coold tub to 8 $ for pool and shower all day and  clean place

name: Rock Art and BLM Camping
description: Many rock art sites along this road (pick up guide brochure at tourist info). Also, several (paid) BLM campsites.

name: South Kaibab Trailhead
description:
water refill station at the South Kaibab Trailhead (also a shuttle bus station for the Grand canyon orange line)

Sign that says DO NOT ENTER. 
Please confirm, walk in only...

name: Chickasaw State Park
description: Lots of sites. Can accommodate bigger rigs and tents also. $13.75 for tents and $24 for hookups. Good fishing nearby. Has showers and lots of shade.

name: Akwesasne Mohawk Casino Resort
description:
No free camping in the parking lot. The Casino said that if you stay with an RV you need to stay in there Campground for $32. 

Free dump station.  Very quiet and sage. Many restrooms and restaurants are available inside of the casino.

Also, RV parking with water and electricity are available but you need to pay at hotel desk.

name: Flaming Gorge, Green River no8
description: Camping is free with America the Beautiful pass or $5 per night/$15 week. 2km from highway to waterfront locations. Very quiet.

name: Camp Branch
description: lake front sites.  Perfect for rooftop/tent camping.  $20 for unimproved $35 Water/electric hookups.

name: Free Camping Chicken Downtown
description:
You can camp for free at Chicken Downtown up to 2 nights. 

*Please check in at the saloon*

No services. Big gravel lot. A lot of mud after rain. Very cool saloon and a small restaurant with homemade food. 2 tables and a moose....

name: granite hot springs campground
description: national forest campground with host. 15 dollars a night. most sites are shady and fairly secluded from one another. some with excellent views. its 9 miles down a dirt forrest road. loys of pot holes but we saw plenty of road cars on the route. 1 mile past the camp is a hot springs. its 8 bucks per adult and is very nice. in the summer its basically a community pool

name: Close to the Dalton highway
description: A big parking lot with toilets. No noise from the road.

name: Close to a pit
description: A parking lot close to a pit. In the Brooks range, in the middle of the trees. Enough far away the Dalton so with no noise from the road. FREE. No aminities.

name: Close to a small lake
description: Close to a lake, no noise from the road. Really quiet. No amenities. FREE

name: Eagle campground, Alaska
description: nice wooded site just out of town run by BLM. Very quite.  Water is in town by court house.  $10 a night per pitch

name: off road to eagle
description: large gravel area with great views over the hills.

name: Eagle claw motorcycle campground
description: 2 wheels only.  set in wooded area, quiet friendly place.  cabins available and sauna with fire wood.  $15 a night

name: Seward
description: No sign about fee. Water and dump, next to rv park .

name: Free parking
description: We slept 1 night on this free parking. It was a very peacefull and quiet place.

name: Beverly RV storage
description:
RV storage in Los Angeles.
20$ for dump station use
Water request was denied.
closes at 5.30pm. Opens at 8.30.

name: Steady Idle Garage
description:
Although the two friendly business owners are power stroke engine specialists, their team can professionally handle any kind of engine from regular fleet maintenance to performance customization. Which includes RV and overland vehicles such as my Dodge Cummins Diesel. Bruno and Eddie are a breeze to talk to and they've handled my truck maintenance for a fair price while talking about travels. Definitely the place to go should you need a mechanic before heading south to Baja!

DOES NOT WORK ON RVs

name: Gilahina. Old bridge
description: This place is above the new bridge where once the old one was. You can still see the remains of it, but can't step onto it. There is camping just off the new bridge, too.

name: Under Kuskulana bridge
description: Very cool spot! Under the bridge. Space for one small rig. 4x4 recommended. There is another place to park before this one. Decent LTE service.

name: Tempel Mountain Park
description: A huge place for free, 100 RV's possible, we were just two.  Two pit toilets, many fire rings and further behind are more other spaces. Absolutly quiet.  This place is used as overflow from the state park campground who is very expensive. Also in daytime used from offroader to hook up, but they all were quiet and considerate.

name: Wave community recreation center
description: Super nice community center. very nice private (curtain) clean showers, pool, gym, steam room, etc wifi w good lobby and lounge area. $5

name: Sven Basecamp hostel
description:
Wooded site with friendly people.  good facilities.  Bit noisy as next to road. $17 a night for a tent more for cabins. $27 for tent and two people.

There are tent sites but no space for overland vehicles. You can park outside the gate and use there cabins or pitch a tent.

name: Laundry at Avila beach
description: on the port, after the rv park there are a laundry for 2$, showers for 2$ and restrooms

name: Love's Travel Shop
description:
Place to fill any kind of propane tank. 
3.49 USD/Gal

name: Firehole Canyon NFS Campground
description: Nice site directly at the River. Not a lot of shade but every site has it's own concrete shelter with bench and table. firepits also. hot showers are free.

name: Welcome centre Alabama
description:
Super nice rest with information center. Lots of pic-nic tables. 
Dump station for rv and water available.

name: Chickahominy Reservoir
description: Small lake (reservoir), BLM land, has put toilets, fire rings, and some water access

name: Valero gas station
description: next to space center. quiet at night. big area.

name: Boulder County Fairgrounds
description:
Web site says temporarily closed!

Basic RV camping. Bathrooms and showers. Self pay kiosk. Ask other campers for bathroom code as there is no attendant on site. Water at all sites.
$15.00/Night for no hookups.
$20,00/Night for electric only.
$25.00/Night full hookup.

name: Alabama Uno
description: Small spot on top of a rock off the spur road off the movie road in the Alabama hills. road goes back a little further, but it looks like something for four-wheel drive or higher clearance than I had with my van. quiet, beautiful view and no traffic while I was here. still able to see down on the road below for security. :-) Zero cell phone signal here and in most of this area.

name: Next to a River
description:
Road that leads into the Riverbed.
several tracks to follow.
Firerings and far enough from the road.

name: Ft Independence
description: Dirt lot adjacent to travel plaza. Good to catch a few zzzz

name: Owens Uno
description: Flat area with several spots for tent, trailers, RVs. Road is paved but old, but no potholes. We had excellent T-mobile service.

name: Crestview rest area
description: Above average rest area in the pines with good water including a hose for filling tanks.  Nearby is the "Lost Cement" gold mine.

name: Sault Ste. Marie - Free overnight parking
description:
Nice Picknick Spot right on the river. Perfect for ship spotting. 

Note - "No Camping" sign  said to refer to the grassed area.

name: Sierra National Forest, wild camping
description: Beautiful spot in the woods with a fireplace, surrounded by trees. A little dusty, no 4 x 4 required. We spent two nights with our be t2 here and the only annoying thing was the sound of the cross bikes. But nevertheless a beautiful spot!!!

name: Lakeside Landing RV Campground
description:
200+ sites on Logan Martin Lake. 

Can dock a boat on the Coosa River

name: Nature Trail carpark
description: Just a parking lot off the road. Partially concealed by trees for privacy.  Not much traffic, very quiet.

name: East Four Mile Draw rec area
description: East Four Mile Draw rec area. Hwy 139 South of Rangley CO.. Great roadside rest area with 4  mile loop trail. No ATT and low Verizon signals.

name: Goose Island Campground
description: This is the closest rec area campground to Arches NP.  Only 5 min drive.  Get in early for self registration, $25 night.  Next to Colorado River,  Gets shade in the late afternoon to help keep cool.

name: Forest Road 219 - Gunnison National Forest
description: A couple of wild sites with fire rings beside the river. Very quiet.

name: Cinnamon Pass boondocking
description: Quite a lot of boondocking sites on the road leading up to cinnamon pass. lots of people all over the place.

name: Haines Garage
description: Refill of propane tanks : 9$ + tx for 20 lbs or 4,50$ + tx for 10 lbs. Can fill RV tank too

name: Great Chazy River Boat Launch
description: Parking lot of the boat launch alongside a small river that opens on the Chaplain lake. Very quiet and nice. Pit toilets not very clean. Free. Very quiet

name: Dairy Queen parking
description: Nice place quiet, d'art and super fast WIFI . Use SSID MikeMurphyNet Guest

name: Along Mt. Loop Road
description: There are several disperse sites along the road just by the river however it's get very dusty when heavy traffic. This place is on the other side of the road, follow a turn up the hill 100m. Fire pit. Not easy to level.

name: Off of 24 outside Colorado Springs
description: Designated sites along dirt road. No facilities.

name: Camp Creek campground
description: Lovely campground in the woods in Mt Hood NF with pretty unique stone-built fire places. $21 for the night and often fills up, reservation recommended. Day use area is free of charge.

name: Cape Henlopen State Park
description:
VERY nice spot. Sandy beaches. WW2 history nearby. Pine forests. Nice new bathrooms and great private showers. On the expensive side though $$$ -  reservations can be made online which was convenient. 5 minutes from the Cape May - Lewes Ferry.

31 $ for a non electric site in September 2017

name: Gifford Pinchot National Wilderness
description: Forest Road 3062 has several dispersed sites immediately accessible from the road. We parked a quarter mile from the Falls Creek Falls trailhead and mountain bikes to one of the most beautiful 100 foot falls we've ever seen. You can also hike the 2 miles to the falls as well. There is a pit toilet at the trailhead.

name: Mt St Helens near
description: Lots of dispersed spots right off the road just north of national Forest Road 83 on 8100 Road with views of Mount St. Helens and access to many trailheads.

name: Klamath River
description:
On Highway 96 there is a short gravel road with a sign "Ferry Point River Access" down to the Klamath River. Here you will find plenty of space. Either next to the river or more in the shade. Allowed to camp up to 14 days.
No bins, bring it in - take it out to keep this beautyful place clean.

name: Free - Camp Hart Mountain
description: Nice Campground between Warner Wildlife Refuge and Hart Mountain National Antelope Refuge. Nice Area, picnic tables, no shade - can be hot, but there is a shelter with additional picnic tables, really quiet

name: Mann Lake
description: Free BLM campground in the shadow of Steens Mountain, beside Mann Lake. Two main camping areas on either side of the lake, with pit toilets. With low lake levels it is also possible to camp beside the water. Very open and exposed, would be hot in the summer and potentially windy.

name: CTRV Service and Rental
description: Service and rentals and RV whith great service for good price. You need calling for 587.8610 or email: bozmt@ctrvrentals.com

name: great river bluffs
description: Very nice place above the Mississippi River. Restroom and showers Ok. No dump station. Drinking water available.

name: cross 83/200
description: This is a Montana State Park Dump Station in a rest area located across from the gas station. The fee is $4 and there is a honor system box with envelopes.

name: Walmart Carencro
description: Big new 24h/7 walmart in the north of Lafayette. We asked the management of Lafayette walmart to sleep on the parking lot and they refused because they are not open 24h. They told us that this walmart in Carencro is open all night. Near the road but not so loud. Ok for 1 night.

name: Ocracoke Campground
description:
National Park System Campground, reservations required (www.Recreation.gov), $28 per night. 

SEASON: Second week of April through last weekend in November

FACILITIES: Only accessible by ferry or aircraft (ferry is free from Hatteras to Ocracoke). Campers are encouraged to bring extra long tent stakes. Flush toilets, drinking water, cold showers and grills are all provided for a more comfortable beach camping experience. The campground is conveniently located on the ocean side, separated from the beach by barrier dunes.

NATURAL FEATURES: The Campground sits on a barrier island along the Cape Hatteras National Seashore. The shore is a recreational oasis for beach lovers. This ribbon of sand provides some of the most dazzling scenery that the Atlantic coast has to offer.

name: Tigard Dump Station
description: Free dump station that's easy to find. No potable water on site.

name: Eldorado Outpost
description: Parking lot at the Outpost across from Uwharrie Off Road Training Center. Both companies are friendly to Overlanders. Great food, fuel etc available. Also great knowledge if the entire Uwharrie NF if you as at the store. Tons of trails and camping in this area!

name: Sullivan Pond
description: Nice place to camp with views of mountain, close to town, no water, good road, be careful of fires.

name: Turnagain Pass Rest Area
description: Big parking slot \ Rest Area with pit toilets and tables. Hiking trail and nice landscape. The road is load and the place busy but okay for a night. What we saw the other day: there are a lot of possibilities to camp from here on the way to Seward! NF Trailheads for example.

name: Seal beach boulevard
description: Street located between a residential area and a US Navy Seals basecamp. Street sweeping 2nd and 4th mondays of the month (you need to be away on these days) Keeping low profile, curtains closed, should allow you to spend a few free nights. You can park all along the boulevard. 5mn walk from the beach.

name: Mountain Home Reservoir
description: Free. Lake side preserve with a few level areas for parking. Sand on the beach is hard enough to drive on so you can camp right on the lake if you want. Popular on weekends with fisherman. Pit toilet. 8200 ft altitude.

name: Borealis riverside Wild Camp
description: Two spots here down a trail marked for a river launch. There is a fire-ring and enough space for larger rigs. A it buggy here at dusk, but what are you going to do?

name: Van Hook Recreation Area
description: 30-40 sites on grass with decent bathroom facilities, picnic tables, fire rings, and shade. $10.00 a night for camping and $8.00 firewood. Moderately crowded but we got lucky with a decent open area around us.

name: West Yellowstone
description: Free parking allowed for the night despite signs that say no camping. Parking lot on both sides of the street. Great for large and small rigs. Tons of space and close to town. 3-5 bars of Verizon.

name: koa  camping
description: expensive  (50$ for a Tent for One night).  Pool and spa.  WiFi only One Hour for free and mit Not Really Working. lot of noise.

name: kickapoo s.r.a
description:
campground recreational park
8$ tent 
10$ place dry 
20$ 50amp

name: Agency conservation area
description:
15.06.2021 Sheriff came by and politely told me camping is not permitted in the area so I left
Parking Lot Camping Area - Individual Campsites
Fires are permitted only in designated camping areas
Camping is permitted only within areas designated
by signs or brochures. Camping is designated
primitive. Stays are limited to 14 consecutive days in
a 30-day period. Only two camping or sleeping units
are permitted at each site on areas with established
campsites.
Camping is allowed anytime in designated camping areas. These may or may not have defined campsites. Seasonal closures and restrictions may apply.
Camping is limited to a period of 14 consecutive days in any 30-day period. Personal property must be removed at the end of the 14-day period. Unless a special use permit is obtained, total camping days on all department lands are limited to 30 days within one calendar year.
Groups of more than 10 people must obtain a special use permit prior to camping. Contact the area manager at the phone number listed for this area in the Online Conservation Atlas.
Quiet hours are in effect from 10 p.m. to 6 a.m. daily. Visitors who are not occupying a campsite are required to leave the campground by 10 p.m.

name: rest area goodland
description: This is a nice rest area with restrooms, staffed during the day. Signs say camping is allowed for one night. Hours of welcome center: May 15 through September 15, 8:00 am - 6:00 pm; September 16 through May 14, 9:00 am - 5:00 pm.

name: Real Alaska RV Campground
description: Private small Family owned  Campground very quaint, clean and friendly as well as inexpensive.

name: Salida North BLM
description: 14 day limit. BLM. Just north of Salida. Nice, quiet setting. A few rock fire rings. No other facilities. Decent Verizon and ATT cell service and ok Tmobile.

name: Silver Reef Casino
description: Overnight allowed at rear parking lot (south side Lot D). Serveral vans and rvs. Quiet. Security car patrol at night. Must register inside.

name: Lees Ferry  Campground
description: Basic campground.  Across the road is a nice white sand beach next to the cold Colorado  River. Great place to cool off in the high temp in this area.  Stays hot all night, Page is worse!  $20

name: Vermillion Cliffs Historical Marker
description: Good roadside pulloff area, 100m from highway. great views of the cliffs.

name: Nehalem Dump Station
description: Dump station for $5. Up the road on the left hand side. No potable water at site.

name: Quiet campsite near Rushmore
description: This boon docking site is just off highway 16 on Calumet Road. We parked in a little pull off that had been cleared by recent logging. Not a place for big rigs, but we had plenty of room for our Sprinter.

name: Lane farm campground
description:
Free* Campground on national forest ground, next to highway 26. there is a stream next to it that can be used for washing. good enough for one night. 
A few miles further north is another free campground next to a covered bridge, much nicer than this one but at the time of check in it was temporarily closed. 

*there was a note on the info board that all free campgrounds in the national forest will have a few of 10$ in the future.

name: BLM black canyon
description: BLM land just outside of Black Canyon on the Gunnison South Rim. It's 1.7 miles south on CO-347 from the national park entrance, past 2 cattle guards. Turn right onto a dirt road just past the second cattle guard (coming from the national park). No amenities, but lots of good flat spots for tents if high clearance and 4x4. This area seems to be used mainly for ATVs and dirtbikes.

name: free parking, camping and swim area
description: free parking with picnic tables and a swim area ... very quiet and nice place to stay

name: Glen Hwy across from Matanuska Glacier
description: Phenomenal view of the glacier on side of road with plenty of space for parking RV.

name: Ruby Chow Park
description: 2  triangules small park next to Boeing Field. there are big motorhomes parked here  (looks like for ever). picnic tables in the park. no bathroom. 10 minutes from downtown. We stayed here with a truck Camper. Not the most quiet place on earth but it's OK.

name: rv dump station
description: free dump station next to the lake. no drinking water. Non potable water available

name: Rest Area
description: Dump station, potable water onsite and a pet area.

name: Koshko Snow Park
description: Big parking lot. Really quiet. It us a sno park during winter.

name: Momo Lake School
description: quite road parallel to 395 with some shade and picnic tables. nice view east place to pull off and camp. momo lake visitor center is walkable distance.

name: Cabelas
description: Store parking lot, allows overnighters. Near the I5, store has restaurant & washrooms

name: Skyline Drive easy walking trail
description: Limberlost trail. Easy walking in the beautiful Skyline Drive, VA.

name: Camp lamoille
description: Dispersed sites. No bathrooms. Little to no cell service. Really rocky rough dirt road, van couldn't make it but a truck could

name: Outside of bend
description:
Cell service, dirt road. No services no water. About a 20 minute drive from down town bend. 

Lots of sun to charge solar panels. Quiet with a bit of noise from freeway

name: Phantom Canyon
description: There are several pull outs for camping along the gravel road to Victor. Depending on the weather you need 4x4 to get back on the road again. See pictures. This is BLM land, so camping is free. There are pit toilets at the start of the trail.

name: Mountain View RV Park
description:
Cheap at $25/night for tent/car camping.
Showers, laundry, Wi-Fi.

name: end of greenhaven Dr
description:
end of greenhaven drive. has a one car wide roundabout around some concrete thing. there's a gate you can go through, but I dunno how passable the dirt would be without 4x4.

room for one or 2 cars, no tents. better signal than horse corral.

name: Glacier views 360 degrees
description: The best spot to camp. Glaciers all around you. Wonderful views and right next to Hwy.

name: free parking near museum road 66
description: We stayed 1 night here. there is a playground and it is just near the museum of road66

name: Brushkana river camp
description: set beside the river.  BLM campsite with host.  very helpful.  Quiet and nice trails. $12 a night pitch

name: Base Camp Kennicott
description: Pay to camp and pay to park. Quiet with nice views of mountains.  $30/night.

name: Bruno Gulch Public Horse Stables
description: National Forest Service. Free. River access and rock ring firepits. no other facilities. many good spots!

name: Pullout on Hwy 88
description:
Big pullout on the side of Hwy 88.
No amenities at all and a bit noisy, but it was OK for a night.

name: Essential Fuels + Propane + Dump + Water
description:
Diesel, gasoline, propane,
Free water and dump

name: Nanny Creek
description: Quiet spot in National Forest, 10 km (6 mi) from South West entrance of Lassen Vulcanic NP.  Spot for only a few RV's, flat and along a perfect gravelroad. No facilities. Some noise from the CA36, but quiet during evening and night. Good accessable, not for big rigs.

name: Mount Hopkins Road
description:
On the way to the observatory, on the side of the road, there is a kind of pullout with nice view on the mountains on both sides. There was an old campfire there when we arrived, so we are definitely not the first to spend a night in this spot.
It is really quiet, just a few cars passed by in the morning.
No amenities, but free.

name: Lake Bottom
description: Turn north off Big Creek Rd. there is a trail leading to the lake. the trail is always muddy and a 4wd high clearance vehicle is most definitely needed. No cell service. It is best to camp during the fall, as the lake is down. Mid-summer, the lake will have possibly flooded some of the trail.

name: Forest Route 828
description: This site is in an open area within the forest. There is a picnic table, and fire pit. There are also several mud holes ranging from 35 to 50 inches deep if that's your sort of thing. (This site doesn't require you to go through these crossings) This road is traveled by hikers and horseback riders more than anything, and you'll seldom see another vehicle. The road is an easy route except for one steep downhill washout. high clearance recommended, although if driving slow Subaru should be fine.

name: Pacific Power Group
description:
Service and Parts for Mercedes Benz, Detroit Diesel, MTU etc.
Parts department was extremely helpful and went above and beyond in getting us back on the road. 
907 522 3434
www.PacificPowerGroup.com

name: Jim Creek
description: Great little informal site next to Jim Creek. Beautiful!

name: willow lake
description: wild camp, place for 5 tents. car or 4x4. maybe small rv. no water. pit toilet. national forest.

name: Horseshoe campground usfs
description:
usfs site. pit toilet, well water, tables. fee area.

keep driving down the road and there are many free sites along the river for many miles

name: Fairbanks University Parking Lot
description: Huge gravel Parking lot, parking free from 5pm to 8am and no 'No Overnight Parking' Sign. Security service drove by but didn't talk to us, we were two campers. A student told us they won't say anything if it's just for a night and it doesn't look like a Walmart parking lot. Quiet at night! And a secret: you can receive wifi from the University, its to slow for uploading photos but good for checking emails....

name: Dead end road plateau near Fairbanks
description: This is a huge gravel place up the hill. Quiet at night, no service.

name: Murphy Dome Road - wild camping
description: This place is on a plateau usually with a nice view. Quiet rough so 4wd or high clearance recommended.

name: Hidden wild camp spot
description: A narrow gravel road goes from Highway 3 right to a small place with a fire pit on a little stream. It's between trees and high grass and only space for one small vehicle. Unfortunately some mosquitos but not too bad, you should make a smokie campfire ;-)

name: Grand Park Lot Wild
description: Really calm and open space near the forest. No amenities but free. Also OK for big rigs.

name: Crawford City Park
description:
A great little city park with about 10 spots, four of which are dead-level gravel pads with 20/30/50 amp service. Water is available, as is a dump station. Restrooms and playgrounds as well. Some sites have good shade from large cottonwoods.

The town center is only a few blocks away and has a market, post office, and package liquor store.

NO LONGER FREE. 

The trains can be kind of loud, but it's not bad unless you're sensitive to that kind of thing.  

there is a bridge with a 5 ton weight limit, this is NOT big rig friendly and not easy to turn around.

name: Anglers Cove
description: Great place, Mark who runs it is a wonderful guy

name: Niagra Campground
description:
$8 sites no water.  clean pit toilets. awesome creek canyon a shirt walk down hill through the woods. check it out!!

not busy even in summer. 

free camping also available outside the campsite.

name: Holbrook (also refill ARG bottle)
description: We refill our argentinian bottle. Laundry. Diesel.

name: Grand Canyon Visitor Center
description: Grand Canyon visitor centre with water, dump station, and shower. Hike, enjoy the views.

name: Off Road
description: Nice place to camp for a few nights. The entrance is a bit narrow, but you can make it on a motorcycle or a small car. Beautiful view, hidden from the road. Fire ring and some trees for shade or wind protection. Very calm and pleasant place.

name: River bed of South Fork Koyukuk MP 156
description: Just south of the bridge go to the west under the pipeline to the river, there is no gate. Big rig friendly, approx. 4 meter high "goal like" structure to cross (those you find everywhere in front of the pipeline). Very nice spot, no/few moskitos and bugs. Primitive camping with only pit toilet on the east side of the highway on the parking lot. Rocky gravel riverbed.

name: Verry big gravel pit next to Dalton Hwy at MP 39
description:
There are two exits from Hwy at Milepost 39. Follow1/2 Mile up the hill, there is a huge Gravel pit Area.
Space enought for many Campers.

name: North of Radio Tower Road, Clear Air Force Station
description: The entrance is right at milepost 285. Just approx. 1/2 Mile north of "Radio Tower Road" (some street gps show that name, it's an Air Force facility, you can not stay there) there is a small paved road to the west, not far to a dam and two very nice gravel pits on lakes. You can hear the trafic from the main road but it is o.k. at night!

name: Tunnels to Nowhere
description: The end of this road overlooks the mts. less people. great you watch the full moon rise.

name: Little sand point
description: Perfect small campground at Piseco Lake. Beautiful location and we didn't have to make a reservation in advance.

name: Shadow Mountain
description: Quite a few spots on top of shadow mountain. There is already and entry but the coordinates are quite off, thus a new one. Very pretty view of the Tetons. Fire pits, there were quite a few mosquitoes when I was there. The road is a little bumpy but not too bad, 4x4 not required unless it has rained recently.

name: Custer Gallatin National Forest
description: Dispersed camping in the national forest at the daisy pass road, very close to Cooke city and the Yellowstone northeast entrance. 4x4 recommended, steep and stony road.

name: interesting 4x4 track
description: one of the very few 4x4 tracks you can drive with a good car and not only with an ATV. It is the old now unmantained highway to Kenai lake. Very bumpy, not wider than a normal car, a little muddy. Even in wet conditions we did not need 4WD but good high clearance. Some camping possible along the track. Turning difficult.

name: Twin Lakes
description:
many free sites up above Twin Lakes with great views. Rock ring fire pits. Cell service.

Verizon gets 4bars and ATT gets 1-3 bars

name: Falcon State Park
description: $8 for water only sites, $16 for water & electric. About the same as you'll pay in northern Mexico with the current exchange rate. There's an easy border crossing here, too, we came into the US from Mexico with no line or wait. Showers, bathrooms, hiking trails and a lake.

name: Fish Creek
description: Here is the place where you can see the bears fishing!!! Really unique opportunity!!! Grizzlies and black bears come here to feed on the coho, chum and pink salmon. 5 dollars a day (from 6am-10pm). 10 dollars, 3 days pass. highly recommended

name: Bayside RV Park
description: Established RV Park with camping sites on gravel. Noisy as by road and dog pound but walkable into Valdez.  Excellent showers included, propane, WiFi and laundry services.

name: Salida East BLM
description: BLM campground, $25 for camp site, pit toilets, on river. Close to highway but fairly quiet at night.

name: free WiFi and library
description: great public  library and only free WiFi in talkeetna.

name: The moose's gravel pit
description: If the spot at buffalo lake is taken this is a little further on.   Gravel storage,  but plenty of space and a few fire pits dotted around.   Peaceful,  good views in the distance if lacking a certain ambiance nearby! We had a couple of moose grazing nearby.

name: East end drive
description: small pull off with space for one vehicle with stunning katchemak bay view. we didn't camp here as had paid in town but wish we had!

name: Denali's expensive!
description: small side road off the parks hwy,  about 10km from the parks entrance.  only 50m from the main road but hidden by trees.  space for larger vehicles but the entrance track is pretty narrow. .. not a spot to worry about your paintwork!

name: Riley Campground
description: Within the national park and cost is very reasonable. It is dry camping but really nice scenery.   Free during the winter seasons.

name: Ojo Redundo Campground
description:
Nice primitive campground in the middle of the forest. To go there we took a dirt road but if there is no rain or mud, a high clearance is enough. Nevertheless the dirt road is not really Big rig friendly even if the campground offers 1 or 2 big sites. Maps'me says to take another road and arrive from the north. This road is in much better shape and no need of high clearance. (We took this road to leave the campground) Big rigs can pass.
No services just a pit toilet, tables and  possibility to make a good fire as the evening can be cold at 2.700 meters !! Really Nice place !

name: Hyatt Lake
description: Quiet spot along Hyatt Lake. Not for big rigs. Watch for soft soil near the waterfront. Easy accessible. No faciities. Several tent spots, only a few RV spots.

name: Bear Lake Campsite
description: Great place with superb sunset-view directly at the lake. Clean toilets and  trashcans available. Close to light-traffic road. Supermarket 15 mins away. $20 for first vehicle, 15$ for additional ones.

name: three bears, Tok
description:
park overnight behind the green Three Bears Convenience Store and Shell station,
free, 
next to RV Stop with basic bathroom facility

name: Pioneer Trails
description:
Lots of trees. Dogs allowed
Large sites. Well run Park

name: Pokagon state park
description: State park with campground. $7/9 for entrance to the park Perfect for a night. They have a park with trails, a beach and camping store. If you drive in and require electric, etc you’ll pay a little more but beats a hotel

name: Eagles rest RV campground
description: set in the middle of town, with a nice patch of grass for tents.  good facilities.  crowded.  $ 20 a night for a tent site with free showers and wifi

name: Pike National Forest
description: Wildlife preserve area with pronghorn. Many areas with rock firepits. Wide open spaces - lots of room. Cell service.

name: Grand View Cafe and RV Park
description: Lovely little place to stay in or have a great meal. They have 10 full hook-up sites, other 16 are with power, water and cable tv only. 3 grasy tent spaces with water available. Fast wifi. Restaurant serves giant pizzas and lots of other meals. RV site 23-43 USD, tent costs from 23 USD per night. Showers take quarters. Very friendly owners and staff.

name: BLM Goblin valley
description: Parking place with 10+ places and double restrooms. Plenty of space near the Goblin State Park and Little Wild Horse Canyon.

name: pike forest
description:
very nice Free campground. From the by way just a couple of miles of very easy dirty road we made with our converted front 2WD. 
9 places very big and leveled.

name: Meeker Park
description: Forest campground. 12$ per night with fireplace tables and bear box.

name: grayrocks reservoir
description: Free established campground managed by fishing and water management. free directly on the lake.

name: Buffalo Gap National Grassland
description:
Beautiful place with plenty of space. Nice view over the badlands and amazing sky in the night.

(43.8897021, -102.2267093)

name: Bighorn National Forest
description:
the entrance is from the 16, you drive less than half a mile on a gravel road and you can start finding places. 
There are several places, the limit is 14 days.

name: Priest Lake National Forest
description: informal campground next to the river. plenty of spots.

name: Priest Lake Campgrpund
description: public dump station outside the campground with free potable water .

name: Carlson Center Fairbanks
