name: Granite Springs & Petroglyphs
description: This is a spot on the old Mojave Road. 100 % 4x4 only trail. Soft sand driving to get here from the Colorado River where the trail starts. A little off the "trail" is the granite wall with the petroglyphs. Just below the Petroglyphs is the spring. At this time we can see wet sand, but no running water. We camped a night in front of the petroglyphs. Quite and beautiful. No cell service when we arrived in the evening, but got a little 4G in the night. Big rig only if you have a unimog.

name: Tolkan Campground BLM
description: BLM campground 4 miles north off Shelter Cove Road on King's Peak Road.  Near Paradise Royale mountain bike trails.  Nice campground.  Fee is posted as $8/night.  No cell service.

name: Bernardo Veterinary
description:
Friendly vet for dog check before entering Mexico. Offered text consultations for emergencies while we are on the road. 
We walked in without an appointment and our doggie was taken care of immediately 👌

name: Sunland Park Racetrack & Casino
description:
Nice... lane for big Rigs with power and water individuali. U$15 OVERNIGHT. Sanidump free in rear. You needed talk with man the security car. 
Vans and Rvs welcome here. For overnight parking and playing in Casino is free off amenitis.

name: Fort McAllister State Park
description:
Located close to I-95 south of Savannah on the banks of the Ogeechee River, this scenic park showcases the best-preserved earthwork fortification of the Confederacy. The earthworks were attacked seven times by Union ironclads but did not fall until 1864—ending General William T. Sherman’s “March to the Sea.” Visitors can explore the grounds with cannons, a hot shot furnace, bombproof barracks, palisades and more, while a Civil War museum contains artifacts, a video and gift shop.

Nestled among giant live oaks, Spanish moss and salt marsh, this park is a beautiful location for camping, fishing, boating and picnicking. Seven cabins sit on stilts near the marsh, surrounded by palm trees and palmettos. The shaded campground is bordered by tidal Redbird Creek, a boat ramp, fishing dock and nature trail. A large picnic area offers river views and playgrounds, while another boat ramp provides access to the Ogeechee River.

name: Absolute on Hoover
description:
I had a bad experience with this Land Rover „specialist“. Didn’t do the work I asked him to do and was expensive. 
If you travel in a Land Rover, look for somebody else.

name: Santa Clara above
description: Several dispersed sites located off the dirt road with beautiful views and immediate access to mountain bike trails. High clearance is nice but not necessary for access to all sites. This site is further in than most.

name: Lake of the Ozarks State Park
description:
Campgrounds alongside the “Lake of the Ozarks”. “Off Season” November 1 to March 32, (honor camping) only pit toilets and water in the winter. 190+ campsites, in a grove of beautiful deciduous trees, rolling hills & trails. Horse riding in summer season. 
Basic camping - $12
Electric - $19
Electric premium (50amp) - $21
-$2.00 for seniors 65+

name: Junction City Park- Tent camping only
description:
Moderator note: Tent camping only. 3 night max limit.

Cops come every 30-45 mins, and we have some great views for the am of the llano river. Dog, walker, and fisher friendly. The views are stupendous!

name: Price dump station free
description: Free Dump station. Water no potable......m.m.

name: Kumeyaay Lake Campground
description:
Campground in the Mission Trails Regional Park. Only open Friday & Saturday night!
Near trails and lake, a nice place to stay. 
$24 per night, $1 for the dog.

name: Toad Suck Park
description:
Yup, you read it right...Toad Suck Park! Army corps of engineers!
Nice place on the river, lots of shady trees. I’d guess it’s full all summer so call ahead. $20.00 for electric, water and free showers. $10.00 with US senior pass.

name: Potable water Wildrose
description: Potable water and free in Wildrose campground. Open all year.

name: Surprise canyon
description: Great and lonely place on surprise canyon road. Goods views to the valley.  Easy to access. Near ballorat and chris wicht camp. There are many places before, after and on indian ranch rd.

name: rest stop on I-5 south
description:
8 hours parking allowed

Pet area, but no dogs on any grass

name: Napa Auto Parts and Repair
description:
Small town garage with good pricing. 

We drove by and got really good advise and an overheating issue fixed which Dr. Google and other shops couldn’t fix. The people are honest and can order difficult parts fast when necessary. We where offered to stay a night a could fill our water. The pizza next door is really worth to stay for an oil change. The garage isn’t that big so call in advance if you’re unsure about weight or hight.

name: Dinosaur Tracks
description: Can only camp in established campgrounds now. $20 per night.

name: Gamble Rogers Memorial State Recreation Area
description: nice oceanfront campground at highway A1A. $30/night.

name: Sleepy Valley Rv park
description:
Very good campground. Low prices. 
Good Services, swimming pool, Jacuzzi,  
Billard and more.

name: Calf Creek Falls Campground
description:
BLM campground on the creek.  Length limit of 25 feet.
You can hike to the falls.

name: Turn out on Bolinas Lagoon
description: Turn out on side street of highway #1 with view on the lagoon. Not ideal due to traffic noise (quites down in the night) but in this area with tons of "no camping" sign and "private properties" an option to spend the night.

name: Turn out near lake Lucerne
description: Turn out on side street of highway #1 near lake Lucerne. Ok for a night if arriving late and leaving the next morning. A bit of traffic noise (quites down in the night) but in this area with "no camping" sign everywhere and very expensive beach camping (most start at $35!) an option to spend the night.

name: Admiral Baker RV Park
description: This is a military park available to the general public. Full Hook UPS are $47 USD per day. Good location near San Diego with lots of amenities.

name: Between Onion Beds and Canyon Flat
description:
Off Burr trail road, this remote campsite is worth the detour. Awesome views, perfect silence. Lots of deadwood ready to be gathered and fire ring provided. 
Only for high clearance and 4wd, do not attempt if wet.

name: Fort Piute - Piute Creek
description: On the Old Mojave Trail Road. If your doing the trail this is a bit of a detour since after this fort this road is closed. The road out to this detour is rockier than the road getting out here.

name: Old School Bus- Mojave Trail
description: The old school bus amongst the Joshua Trees off the Old Mojave Trail Road. Looks like an area a convoy could and has camped.

name: Lots of Petroglyphs
description: Off the old Mojave Trail Road about 2.5 miles, but worth the detour. LOT of petroglyphs and you can pull right up to them and take your pictures. Definitely 4x4 only!

name: Spooky Canyon
description: Spooky Canyon is a slot Canyon to an old mine. We didn't bring in flash lights and turned back before finding a mine. It's pretty neat short hike. be careful for falling rocks and debris. the fun part starts where you need the flash light.

name: Blue Creek Park
description: This is a free campground on the creek. The road to get there is a little sketchy but doable with our front wheel drive van. Very quite, there was only one other group there and it was on a weekend.

name: Hillside Family Campground
description: Very nice, quiet. Lots of trees. Very nice people.

name: Dubinky Well Rd #1
description: Dispersed camping off of Dubinky Well Rd.  There is a large “cul-de-sac” here with a fire pit in the middle.  The spot is large enough for multiple rigs.  This location as a few trees, which we camped in between.  There are no signs that prohibit camping here and it got quite busy on the weekend after we arrived.  Great rocks behind the location to climb and watch sunsets.

name: Mojave NP, NY Mountains
description: A large “cul-de-sac” location that has good protection from the wind on three sides.  Large enough for larger rigs and truck/trailers to maneuver around.  It’s at a higher elevation than the desert floor so temperatures are cooler.  We were here at the end of May and over night temps were in the low 40s.

name: Mojave NP, near Granite Peak
description: Very secluded location mixed into the rocks at the base of Granite Peak.  Very difficult to get into with a full-size truck pulling a trailer, but we managed.  I would recommend not going back into where we went and stop short before it gets tight.  We jockeyed back and forth for 45 minutes trying to fit.  Great rocks to climb and areas to explore here.  We passed a park ranger on our way in and got a friendly wave, so this is a legal spot.  Lots of additional camping in this area as well that can be spotted via Google Maps.

name: Mojave NP, near the Mojave Cross
description: Camping in the largest Joshua Tree forest in the US...so the sign said.  Just spectacular.  Good rocks to climb to watch the sunset, nearby trails to hike and easy access.  The Mojave Cross is at the entrance and there is camping at the base of the cross as well.  The access road has a number of pullouts to camp in as well.

name: Juniper Campground on the ID BDR
description: A minimalistic little campground with a half-dozen or so spots.  No fee.  Right on the East Fork Jarbidge River in a deep, steep canyon.  The road to this location is dirt, but it is well managed as this is a popular hunting area and it’s the only road into Jarbidge NV from the north.  The road becomes paved a few miles north of the camp ground, but it’s dirt all the way to Jarbidge and beyond for some time.

name: Observation Point
description: This exact location is about 100 feet from the designated camp ground called Observation Point.  Although there is a toilet here, it might as well not exist.  It’s pretty primitive.  We elected not to stay in the campground proper, but that was because the view at the turnaround is spectacular.  There were no signs stating “no camping” but we can’t say if a ranger would have made us move if one had come along.  The view to the east is incredible here.  Of course, the walk to here from the campground is short as well.

name: Falls Flat Campground
description: A large established campground with lots of room for groups and larger rigs and trailers.  Some areas are in the trees, like the area we had, but other areas of the campground have no shade at all and are very exposed.  This campground is at the east entrance to the Magruder Corridor.

name: Cayuse Junction on the ID BDR
description: A medium size field where we were able to camp with four vehicles easily.  There is also space across the road for additional rigs if your party needs more space.  Since it is right off the Lolo Motorway (that’s the name of the dirt road) you can be close to passing vehicles.  But the field is large enough that you can get back off the road to avoid any dust.  This is bear country too.  We had one stop and check us out from about 50 yards away, so be aware of that danger.

name: Trinity Lake
description: A real beautiful campground.  The campground has two dead end roads...there is no way to drive around the lake.  We stayed in space #8 which is the first space as you go to the left upon entering the campground.  It’s a bit of a walk to the toilet, but it appeared to be the most secluded space and it sits high up above the lake with great views.  A picnic tables and fire pit is available.  There are great hikes that start on the far side (down the same road you take to space #8) and there is a hike that goes all the way around the lake as well.  This place can get busy as it’s just close enough to the city that lots of people can make their way out here.  We were here mid-week and it was quite, but started getting busy on Friday morning as we left.

name: Evans Creek Campground
description: A very busy campground on the weekends in the summer.  We arrived on Friday, early, and people were still showing up after the sun went down.  Although it was full, everyone was real polite and we felt pretty isolated.  Since we arrived early, we picked this spot so we could walk down through the trees to the shoreline to set up our chairs.  It’s a nice intermediate spot to stop on your way along the BDR, but unless you have a boat or large trailer that can’t go off road, this isn’t somewhere I’d stay more than a sleep over.

name: Maverick Gas
description: We didn’t use this water but spoke to a couple filling up.  You need to bring your own hose.  I didn’t check to see if they charge for the water, but that wasn’t my impression.  I didn’t see hours posted here, so I don’t know if water is available after hours.

name: Farm & City Feed and RV Supply
description: Standard propane rates apply.  $3.99/gallon Very friendly service. We filled a standard household USA BBQ bottle. Out tank was 7.5 gallons and there was another guy there filling up standard 5 gallon bottles.

name: Mtn Village Service Station
description:
RV Propane, free potable water. Gas/diesel is ghastly expensive tourist pricing, avoid the gas. ($1 additional per gallon)

Free water behind the gas station.  There was a very worn out hose when we used it but it wasn’t long enough so I would bring your own hose to help a bit if filling a trailer.  Further, I would bring some type of filter too.  I’m sure it’s perfectly fine, and it’s 100% potable, but who knows what is creeping and crawling up that hose.

name: Walmart military road
description: Good place to stay during night, no more than 2 because walmart security tell you please to leave

name: Picnic area
description: Free camping area, good place to stay on night, normal noisy from the highway, nice river that seems to be clean. Shade areas under big trees

name: Brady lake
description: As of 2/22/22 it is not free. 10 dollars no hookup. Beautiful park though, right next to the lake.

name: Walmart
description: Big parkinglot with walmart facilities, fast wifi inside

name: Choctaw casino and resort
description:
Beautiful casino with free overnight parking.  We spoke to front desk and security.  They said park on the north side.  We parked in the event center.  Lots of traffic so if u can't sleep through noise not for you.   

There appears to be an established KOA campsite right next door. Something to keep in mind, if correct.

name: Calderon Automotive Repair Services
description: Did a good job on our Motorhome Toyota Landcruiser HZJ79.

name: Apache trail
description: Free campsite, great views, no amenities, Close to Phoenix.

name: Rest Area
description:
Restrooms, water,  picnic tables.
Good place before Death Valley (40 min)

name: Showers- Lake Padden Park
description: Nice park with picnic tables and a lake. Inside the bathroom house there are free warm showers. main bathrooms and showers are separated but shower room do have the toilet stall and urinary on the men side. community shower heads like the one in college/high school

name: Johnson's Corner
description: Large truck stop- an easy place to catch a quick night of sleep right off the highway.

name: Mount Shasta riverside
description: Fairly easy access with the GS. Would be very tight in a car. 100 yards from an accessible road. Lots of spots to tent. Calm space.

name: Meteor Crater Rest Area
description: Eastbound. Westbound on the other side.  Overnight parking allowed. No camping. According to overnight parking rules in Arizona on Interstate Rest Areas.

name: Pena Blanco Rec Area
description: Small rec area west of I-19. There is a pay camp ground ($10$ or you can find some good spot in the hills surrounding. Good swimming hole to escape the heat before or after crossing boarder. No service, the stars provide the entertainment.

name: Rufus free camping with toilet
description: Large gravel lot next to columbia river.  Long drop toilet. One can stay 30 days in a row. Favorite of the local kiteboarding crowd.

name: Sunset Death Valley NPS CG / Furnace Creek
description:
Huge graveled lot (270 sites) on east side of Hwy 190. Walking distance to town center. Not the nicest place but ok for a night if you don't want to leave the NP.
Water, flush toilets (clean), dump station. 
No firepits & picnic tables.
Generators allowed from 7am to 7pm.

$ 14/night in Nov-2017. 
Pay with credit cards (Visa & Master) at one of the fee stations or (cash) at Furnace Creek Information Center.

Open mid-Oct to mid-May. 
1st come - 1st serve.

name: free RV dump @ Pinnacles National Park
description:
Free rv dump, opposite the showers, visitors centre and pool.
Water non potable, but ranger says there is some in site 86 in neighbouring campground for free.

name: Parking lot in St Helenas
description: Parking lot next to the train track, behind main strip (highway). Parking 3h from 8h00 to 18h00 but no "no overnight parking" signs so you are good from 18h00 until 7h59 !

name: Quechee State park campground
description: No hook-up. Dump station and water available.  More quiet if your site is in the found of the campground. Trail to Quechee Gorge, Nice place. 22$ per night in october  2017.

name: Piscataquog River Park
description: Parking lot near playgrounds. No signs for no overnight parking. Pit toilets. Noisy , highway not so far.

name: Franck Butler Park West boat ramp
description: parking boat ramp. No signs for no overnight parking. Restrooms and running water. Quiet at night.

name: St Augustine parking lot for RV
description: Free parking lot for RV. Best way to visit St Augustine. Overnight parking possible with permit 35$ but it must be noisy near main roads.

name: Bell's landing boat ramp
description:
Parking lot of a boat ramp. Quiet at night.  Amazing sunset. 
Really nice place by the water. Lots of locals come by, even throughout the night strangely enough. Got the knock though around 11pm. Officer took my information but then told me I could stay. I don’t think there are any laws against parking here overnight though they may come by and check on who’s here. You can tell it’s a spot where young locals might come to act reckless, and we get the blame unfortunately. So just be respectful and leave no trace.

name: Sierra Trails RV Park
description:
RV Park close to Hwy 14. Some sites with trees. Simple restrooms (showers & toilets closed with curtains only) but very clean. 
Laundry available as well ($ 1.25 washer - $ 0.75 dryer).
Small club house.
WiFi reception with MacBook Pro good- iPhone 5 & iPad 4 average to bad.

name: Alascom Access Road
description: Drove quite a ways down the access road and found a nice quiet/flat spot. There was already a fire ring there which leads me to believe we were no the first ones to have stayed. Overall it was wonderful for just the night.

name: Small forest with Cows
description: Nice flat and quiet spot to stop and get some sleep. There were already fire rings and a little bit of trash that led me to believe it was well used. When we woke up in the morning there was an RV little ways away. Was a perfect spot to crash, the views were great and little to no road noise.

name: Mendocino MF - Davis Flat Campground
description: National Forest campground near Stonyford OHV area and hiking trails in Snow Mountain Wilderness.  $5/night.  Pretty basic.  Multiple campsites in this area along the creek.

name: John Prince Park Campground
description: Nice camping near Palm Beach. $ 33 per night.

name: Ocotillo Wells svra
description:
State Park & OHV recreational area (85,000 acres) with some large camping sites and some sites with tables, and sun shade cover. Free.  Overnight camping allowed: 30 days per year. Fires to be contained in fire rings. 

Decent Verizon coverage in most of the area.

name: Frontier Glass
description: Windshield repair. We had a chip repaired while we waited. Nice people!

name: Gravel lot with a view
description:
This spot is a 100m dead end dirt track off hwy 89. Nice views, legal, level, free.

Downside: Visible from the road. Some traffic noise. This might bother you if you're in a tent. Very little traffic at night though.
It's pretty much on the highest point along that stretch of highway which, depending on the season will be good or bad - anyways, it's colder.
Big rigs will fit, will have to back out onto the highway though. Second person might be helpful for that.
I am pretty sure this is legal. As visible as the spot is, the cops must have driven past without bothering me.

name: Kalaloch Campsight
description: Just down the road from the Lodge (they can help you find it if you cant) Not to expensive, great view of the ocean!

name: Laguna Seca RV Park
description:
We have Verizon wireless it is full bars over 100 Mbs Super fast. Campsite run by Monterey County. Up in the hills, fabulous views. Next to the Laguna Seca raceway but no issues with noise. Nice open sites, hot showers, dump station. $40.00 Electric and water 35.00 Dry camping in developed.
There is a gun range on site so be prepared for pistol noise.

name: Green Valley Road
description: Several good boondocking sites 6-8 miles from the coast at Cambria. On Highway 46. Well set up back from road with views down coast to Mirro Rock at some sites.

name: Morrison Lake
description: Beautiful lake with multiple camp sites. Lots of trails to hike.  No services

name: HillcrestHostel.com
description:
Please LIKE and Follow!  We offer budget rates for travelers!   We offer a seasonal per person overnight “facility fee” to come hang out as a guest and use our shower and hot-tub... and to meet lots of other Interesting International travelers!  We also have communal foods left by current and previous guests and we appreciate any of your camping donations that we pass on to travelers that come through. This unique house converted into a hostel full of Art and Love.

Best to write on INSTAGRAM @thehostelcalifornia

name: Chevron Dixon
description:
Dumping Station next to I-80 On West A Street in Dixon.
Mo drinking water.

$ 15. Ask for key at cashier.

name: Starr Spring Campground
description: A BLM campground with pit toilets, fire rings, and picnic tables. It's got a nice view up high over the desert valley, and it's protected from the wind and sun. There's also a network of mild 4wd roads here that have many offshoots with awesome views (and no shade).

name: Buckeye Hot Springs
description: The campground is closed this time of year, but we camped in an area next to the river right next to the bridge. The road is good getting here from just north of Bridgeport- about 6 miles, last 2 miles gravel road. Hot springs next to the river work two smaller tubs on the side of the hill.

name: maverik
description: free dumping station. very easy. maverik

name: exit 90 on highway 70 Visitor center/rest area
description: dump station and water with restrooms. No drinking water

name: Local Overland Vehicle Spot
description: Fascinating couple of blocks of parking here. Each one has a different day of the week with street cleaning so as long as you pay attention it Gould be fine. There are about 10 vehicles that look like permanent residents though if assume the move from spot to spot as needed. I didn't stay here but found it while walking around, my only concern would be the safety at night but I don't see why it'd be less safe than any other.

name: cracker barrel
description: Asked management said yes very nice people no more than 3 days. We stayed 1 night.

name: Above Santa Clara 2.0
description: In the hills off various dirt roads. The other Santa Clara spot is now very close to a housing development.

name: Granville recréation area
description: Several places (7) under the trees. Free. Narrow gravel road. Very quiet. 0,1 mile from the road. Restroom. Picniq table. Fire rings. Very beautiful.

name: Bicknell Howies gas station
description:
Closest place from capitol reef NP
For Propane tank refill
Big Rig access

name: Pony Express Lake, East Camp, Missouri
description: Free Camping in State Park with 10 sites on a Lake. Open all year Beautiful location.

name: Cahokia RV Parque, St Louis Illinois
description: Great camp site on the Illinois side of St Louis. $20 for camping off season. Owner offers shuttle service to the city.

name: Sweet Grass Rest Area
description: Rest Area right at the border. Quiet at night with minimal road noise and clean washrooms opened all night.

name: Butte General Store & Marine / Gas Station
description:
We refilled our propane tank at USD 2.90 per gallon (Nov 26, 2017). This gas station is open on Sundays and will fill-up your motorhome's propane tank.

Our tank has an ACME valve connector (or also called QCC [Quick Closing Coupling] or OPD [Overfill Protection Device]). But I'm quite confident that they would be able to handle other valve connectors, such as POL (Prest-O-Lite).

name: St Charles lake
description: 22 a night on the lake. Water elec dump on site

name: Sedona outskirts
description: Some roads are rough. Quiet spot though and has cell service.

name: Little America Flagstaff
description:
Ample parking. Some spots darker than others. Private bathrooms are $15 for up to 2 people for 1.5 hours. Room includes shower, sink, toilet, and large bathtub. 

Travel Center with Gas, Convient Store, Bathrooms, and Pay Showers. Open 24 hours. I stayed in the parking lot for 2 nights. Very quiet, but was during the week and cold, so not many people around. I would assume it will be busier and louder place during the summer. WiFi from the building reaches the parking lot fine, and I was streaming YouTube videos on my tablet most of the night.

name: Rest area en route to Needles
description: Large rest area for trucks and nice parking and lawn for vehicle or tents. Lots of traffic, but it works and has bathrooms. 5G t-mobile and 4G Verizon.

name: BLM "roads"
description: This road exists on Google Maps more so than real life, but there is a faint path off the highway. It requires high clearance and slow going, but we just wanted to get a few hundred feet off the highway. There are several side roads like this in this area, some of them might be better for 2wd. the valley is very desolate and beautiful to camp in. But it could be very windy and there is no shade.

name: Texas air museum
description: airplane museum next to Stimson Municipal Airport. Just a safe parking spot next door to police station. tour museum ask ask for permission.

name: graveyard flats
description: A good place for a night just passing through. this site isn't the quietest from the highway but I'm sure you could find more peace the deeper you go as this road is peppered with informal campsites. road is in good condition for most vehicles

name: Four Mile Campground
description: BLM Campground with flush toilets, water, picnic tables, trash service. $5/night. We were the only ones here.

name: Aguilar Accesorios
description: We had a leaf spring break on the way into Santa Rosalia and we would have been in serious trouble had it not been for these folks who came to the rescue and jerry rigged the RV trailer so we could take it to get repaired. The spend two days repairing it as well as other minor repairs and charged us what seemed to be pennies for the custom repair.

name: Rest area's dumping station
description:
Free dumping station next to the Rest area!
Rest area's safe, not so quiet but ok for the night.

name: Pacifica - San Pedro Park
description: We asked at the ST. Peter Parish Church, if we could stay on their parking lot. However, it turned out that the non-paved part of the parking lot belongs to the park. We stayed two night with our 26 feet rig without having any troubles.

name: Washout right next to the Road
description:
These "Cima Road" has a lot of washouts, 4x4 is recomended! partly sandy, partly rocky road but great landscape.
We found a place for the night direct next to this road. realy quite!

name: On hill, between the trees
description: Place next to an Watertank, right between the yoshua trees. great view down to the valley.

name: Gander RV - dump station and drinking water
description: Dump station, tank rinse spigot, and potable water spigot at a RV store. they take good sam discount and also sell propane. open all year and 24/7

name: del norte
description: free dumping station and free potable water

name: Arroyo hondo vista point
description: Vista point just off of southbound 101. Great views of the sea. No services. Good for one night. Trash cans available. Verizon 4/4 bars

name: Vines RV Resort
description:
On 88 Wellsona Road, Paso Robles, CA 93446 - just off Hwy 101

Nice and very well kept RV park. Very spacious and clean bathrooms with free hot showers. Outdoor heated swimming pool and hot tub, library, lounge, small convenience store, laundry and fitness room.

As all established campgrounds in CA pretty expensive but they accept Passport America, giving a 50% rebate from Sundays to Thursdays.
Standard sites (the ones closest to Hwy 101) $ 54, Deluxe site $ 76, Pull-Through sites $ 80.

name: Aspen grove
description: A hard to spot two track leads goes for a couple hundred yards to a nice Aspen grove with good views and a flattish spot for vehicle or tent camping.

name: Dump Station Kent Kwik Texaco
description: The dump station is in front of the Kent Kwik gas station shop. The dump station provides sewer for grey/black water and potable water. The available green hose is intended to rinse your sewer hose. Use your own water hose to fill-up your fresh water tank. The dump station provides standard tap water. It is potable according to the shop’s staff. We were happy to fill our empty drinking water tank. The dump station and potable water tap is available 24x7.

name: parking lot behind fire station
description: quiet and safe place according to friends who live near by.  seems to be overflow parking for apartment residents and for firemen.  trails on the bay out your back door.  no ammenities, but cell signal is great.

name: Oscar Scherer State Park
description: quiet state park with a lot of hiking trails, 30$/night

name: Bass Pro
description: very nice people check in first they said sure. we stayed 3 nights. They said we could unhook to look around. we stayed in the north west corner. plus many of place to eat and shop plus fuel

name: Ponderosa Grove Campground BLM
description: Nice campground with fire places,  bench and table at each site. Vehicle length maximum 24 feet.

name: Cattlemen Trail boondocking site
description:
About 20 miles south of Silver City, on the west side of the highway near the top of the Continental Divide, there's a turnoff to the left that takes you into this boondocking area. It's a gravel/dirt road that was in pretty good condition when I was there, and you don't need to drive far on it to find the boondocking sites.

I stayed here for a few nights in June 2017 It's quiet and secluded - only one other camper while I was there. You can find sun or shade, with spaces in between the trees.  I had good T-Mobile cell service, so was able to get some online stuff done.

At 6400 ft elevation, it was a welcome breath of cool air compared to the lower elevations. There's also a trailhead for the Continental Divide Trail right here, so you could hike either direction on it however far you desire. 

Cattle also use the Cattlemen Trial site (surprise)!  There were some cows that wandered through my site in the morning one way, then back in the evening.  They didn't bother me.

All in all a comfortable, safe, easy place to stay, with good hiking, and it's free!

name: Forks Campground
description:
This is a free National Forest campground, in the Gila National Forest. It's up on a bluff, overlooking the Gila River, with  beautiful cliffs right across the way.  You can walk down a short trail to get to the river access for swimming, wading, or just enjoying the views.

The campground is fairly small, but it was empty when I got there mid-week, starting to fill up for the weekend.  There's a vault toilet, and no water available except for the river.  Most of the sites have a nice view.

You drive up a very windy road from Silver City to get here.  It's a slow drive, but the scenery is outstanding. 

Very quiet at night. No cell service.  Just beautiful!

name: Burro Creek Campground
description:
BLM campground, 30 sites washrooms water on site sewer dump on site. some pull through sites. 
Tenting area and day use area. Some hiking in the area. NO wifi but decent cell reception. 14$ per night self registration.

name: Wild Rivers (Rio Grande del Norte)
description:
This is a beautiful area on a plateau between the Rio Grande Gorge, and the Red River on the other side.  There are 5 different campgrounds, all very similar.  Campsites have shade structures, picnic tables, fire rings, and grills. Campgrounds have vault toilets (clean), garbage service, and water available.  No electric hookups.  There are probably some of the sites you could get a big rig into, but the sites where I stayed wouldn't really fit anything over about 25 feet.

Many of the sites have views into one of the gorges, and there are superb hiking options.  You can either hike around the mesa top, or hike down into the gorge, and along the river.  It's beautiful there, and worth the hike back up!

name: FR5 Carson Forest boondocking
description:
Gorgeous high-elevation boondocking along Forest Road 5 in the Carson National Forest. It's a wide, well-maintained dirt road that should be passable by any vehicle.  Getting off the road to the individual campsites depends on where you pick, but I saw several options that looked like they'd be no trouble.  It's boondocking, so there are no facilities.  

I was there in July 2017, and everything was remarkably green.  There are evergreens spaced around green grassy areas, and a small creek flowing by. There was nobody camped within visual distance of me, but I did see a few other vehicles head further up the road, so there much be more campsites past this.  At night, it was very quiet, and in the morning,  just the sound of the birds.

Beautiful, peaceful, green and cool (it's about 9,000 ft elevation). And it's free!  (-:

name: Dawson Cemetery
description:
In its day, Dawson NM was a booming mining town.  Today, there's not much here besides a lonely cemetery, and some informational signs about the place.  

It's atmospheric, with just the wind and the grasshoppers.  I boondocked just outside the cemetery gates. A couple of other people came by to look at the place in the afternoon, but I had it all to myself at night.  When I left the next day, I passed a herd of about 30 elk along the road.

No facilities, no cell service.  I'm sure there are places you could put a tent, but it's a bit gravelly.

name: Jawbone OHV area
description: Large area with numerous pull-off options. Free dispersed camping with pit toilets at several (but not all) locations.

name: Lake Louisa State Park
description: Nice campsites on a lake, a lot of trails. $27/night

name: Santa Cruz Lake, Overlook CG
description:
Lovely small campground at the top of a bluff overlooking Santa Cruz Lake.  It's a BLM campground, and $7/night.  Very near Chimayo, and makes a convenient place to stay if you're traveling there.  There's a bit of a dirt road to get here, but it was in good shape when I visited.

The best campsites have views out over the lake, which are really lovely.  Sites have shade structures and picnic tables, and there is a vault toilet.  No plugins.

There's also a hiking trail down to the lake level, where you can walk around the lake and find a shady spot to relax.  I loved it!  (-:

name: Taos Junction boondocking
description:
This is a boondocking area along Forest Road 557 in the Carson National Forest.  It's about 10 miles north of Ojo Caliente, the famous hot springs resort.  You can easily use their facilities for a day, or go hiking there, too. (There's an old mica mine that's pretty interesting.)

Just drive down the dirt forest road, and you'll see a selection of spaces, some sunny, some shady. This is a boondocking spot, so no facilities.  Just a fairly quiet place to camp.  There was nobody else here when I stayed.  A little bit of traffic noise, but quiet at night.

The dirt road in was fine when I was there, but the ruts indicate it could be a problem if it's been rainy.

name: Jacob Lake Lookout Tower
description: Quiet spot for camping near the lookout tower. You can also enjoy a quick chat with the ranger who look after fires in his tower in the morning.

name: Eureka US-50 Rest Area
description:
Rest area at the entrance of Eureka where you can stay up to 18h.
No toilets but there are picnic tables.
Parking just beside the road but not too noisy at night.

name: Pullout Kings Canyon rd
description:
Pullout on the kings canyon road at the crossing with Cove ave.
No sign prohibiting it neither private parcel on this land.
Not the best place but good enough to spend a night before entering the NP. A little bit nosy at night.

name: Azalea Campground
description:
Azalea Campground. $18 for a spot under a pine and sequoia forest. No reservation. 110 places lost under the trees. One place with water and toilets at the entrance.
Very nice.

name: Free Parking in Noe valley district
description:
Good neighborhood where you can park your car for free for the day while visiting san francisco.
Not permit needed and no time limit. Very good for WE.
Look for the streets around the current points.
Officially it is not permitted to sleep in the car in SF. We stayed 3 nights here and we kept low profile.
Don't forget to check for the day when the municipality cleans the street. You must NOT park on these days.

name: Kent business campus
description: here are really some spots. But there is a extremely loud railway close by. We are told that the trains are running all over the night because it is a mainline.

name: Rockport pullout on Martin Rd
description:
Pullout on Martin Rd in Rockport town.
There is no sign prohibiting it.

name: YMCA community centre
description:
Place where you can get a shower for free.
Just need to ask, subscribe and go!
we got information to buy a 10$ daypass

name: Rest Area
description: Nice to stay on night, very coldin this time of the year, bonneville Salt flat is really beatiful, not very clean restrooms, it has some picnic tables

name: Neches Bluff Campground
description: This is one of two free campgrounds in the area with no amenities used mostly by hunters in the Davy Crockett National Forest. There is one poorly maintained outhouse on location. The access road FS 511A, off highway 21, is a very well maintained gravel road. Medium sized RV's should have no troubles accessing this site. The other campground is half a mile SE on FS 511.

name: Limestone Lake Park
description: This is a beautiful day use park that allows free camping with all paved access and maintained by the Brazos River Authority.

name: Public Use Area #3
description: This is a small county park with a boat ramp, lake shore fishing access and about half a dozen camping sites with many dispersed options. The area is clean and well maintained.

name: Lake Limestone #2
description: This is a county park with lake access that allows camping

name: Back Bay Laundromat
description: Great value for your money, machines clean but not the newest. Baywood is a cute small town with awesome bay views.

name: Lovell Canyon Road
description: BLM Land, many places and 2 Group Campsites. Excellent overnight or weekend primitive campsite. Located approx 4 mi from NV-160 along paved but narrow and rough at speeds over 35 mph. Site is big rig friendly and has a pull through layout. However, there are few turnarounds for big rigs on Lowell Canyoun Rd if the entrance is missed. Approximately 1 mi north on Lovell Cyn Rd is a fairly steep downhill portion. There is a large level turnaround area on the left at the foot of the downhill section. Site has great views being located at approx 4500 ft elevation. Located 100 ft from LC rd but traffic is very minimal during the day. Great OHV trails in the area. There are several excellent sites along LC rd but the area gets a fair amount of Las Vegas campers coming to the area starting mid day fri and through the weekend during moderate temperature months.

name: Mojave Desert/Aiken Mine Road
description: Quiet place under the volcano, on the way to the tubes.

name: Pullout on San Gabriel Cyn Rd in NF
description:
North of Azusa there are a multiple pullouts off San Gabriel Canyon Road in National Forest area.
We stayed at a pullout a few meters further north (forgot to fix the GPS coordinates there) which is bigger and you can pull a bit further away from the street. You can see the dam from the reservoir.
No cell phone reception. Good for a night.

name: Ehrenberg BLM land.
description:
BLM land with a lot of open space.  Very quiet.

*Watch for horses when driving at night.*

4GLTE Verizon with 2 bars

name: Ehrenberg BLM land.
description: Open dessert very quiet in December.  Located off I-10 exit 1 in Arizona.

name: Chloride Murals
description: Bright colored murals outside of Chloride, Arizona.  Dirt road access OK for high clearance vehicles.

name: Black Nugget Mine camp
description:
Near the Hummingbird Springs Wilderness area off of North Eagle Eye road. Tons of BLM camping in saguaros. Great walkabout place. 
Please stay on existing roads. thanks

name: Blue Springs State Park
description: Lovely campsite next to the St. Johns River. Manatees spend the winter in the warm springwaters. 27$

name: Midway Service
description: $10 per RV site with electricity hook up. Shower $5/person. Convinience store nearby.

name: Abandoned lot next to 24hr McDonald's
description: Right off the highway. Some road noise at night. Quite a bit of train noise. Pretty stealthy after dark. Minimal street lighting. WiFi from McDonald's. Real bathrooms at McDonald's all day except midnight to 5am.

name: Land Cruiser Heritage Museum
description:
Museum housing almost 100 Land Cruisers. Many domestic and international Land Cruiser from early 1950s to 2020 model years. Historic and original LC's on site. 

$10 per adult and $5 for senior or children 12+.

Open Wednesday through Saturday, 8a-5p.

Parking and entrance is in the empty lot next to the building.

name: Childs, Ajo airport road
description:
Mead road. 
Nothing special, just a place to stay the night.  Nice gravel road that goes north over some old railroad tracks.  Can pull over right after the tracks or go further. Very quiet, except for a few military jets.  
Please stay on existing roads.
thanks

name: LeGore Bridge
description: 4 wheel drive only! There is a turn off on the southern side of the bridge that dives down a steep road to the bottom. There are many trails down at the bottom. Along the trails are plenty of camp sites to choose from. It will require some hard trail to drive however. I can not stress enough that you will need 4 wheel drive.

name: Morongo Travel Center
description:
Gas Station with Dumping Station.

$ 5 for tribal members
$15 for all other customers

Free if you purchase 60+ gal of fuel.

Water fill is free, only need to pay for dump.

name: Galvez boat ramp
description:
Police have approached campers and said this place is NOT okay for overnight camping. 
Big parking lot of a boat ramp. Near a restaurant where you can listen local music (concert). The restaurant closes at 10 PM and the night was very quiet. 
Please update if you come here and share your own points for all travelers. Thanks.

name: Wakefield Municipal Overnight Parking
description: Five improved lakeside sites with water and electric. A couple of the sites are big rig friendly. First come first serve. Suggested donations $30 for hookups and $15 for no hookup to help keep this place open.

name: Upson Park
description: This is a township park. tents and small campers will fit the best. The park is next to a beautiful waterfall. There metal bbq boxes, electric and hand pump water well. $10/night

name: Big Knob State Forest Campground
description: This is a primitive campground with pit toilets and a hand pump well. The campsites are just a few yards from sandy beaches on lake Michigan. It's heavily wooded with nicely spaced campsites. The fee is $20/day.

name: Jean  Lafitte town Rosethorn park
description:
Small parking lot before the fence.  OK for RV 22 feet long back in. No amenities. A little noisy at night, road and boats on the river are not so far.
Police patrol came but said nothing. 

Please update if you come here and share your own points for all travelers. Thanks.

name: Memorial Hospital of Salem County NJ
description: a quality Hospital with Cooper doctors. free parking and friendly staff

name: Boat Landing at the Eufaula Lake
description: A good , quiet overnight place away from the main road.

name: Lake MacKenzie
description: Beautiful place on a lake with different options to camp. 4$ plus 5$ p.P. Entrance fee

name: San Jon City Park
description:
A nice small park in San Jon, close to the Interstate 40

Very quiet, clean and safe. Well lit. It's a city park of San Jon that allows overnight camping. Bathrooms closed in winter. Picnic tables and BBQ grills - all free!!

name: Villanueva Statepark
description: A beautiful Statepark at the Pecos River, clean Bathroom with hot shower, hiking trails

name: Pathfinder Regional Park in Florence
description: A large recreational park close to the Arkansas River, a lot of room for parking. A good, quiet overnight place for free.

name: Cave Lake State Park - Lake View Campground
description: A beautiful park nice for swimming and hiking, table, firering, cool in the night- 2230 m, clean restrooms with hot shower

name: Borrego Springs/Galleta Meadows
description:
This is a great place to camp with a dirt road in good shape. the dinosaur statues are right around the corner. Fabulous desert vistas, sunsets, and sunrises. you can even go further out for more privacy, although these spots are nicely spaced. It's a little bit hard to find level as the spots are bumpy. Usable T-Mobile service, but my Verizon phone didn't do as well.

Dirt road with various pullouts. *Please use existing pullouts and don't create more due to local issues with campers and also there is lots of deep sand that only looks solid*

Private property, camping was previously allowed by sculpture artist/owner (although he died a few years ago, and there have been some locals unhappy with the campers here over the past two years).

name: Kumeyaay lake state campground
description: State campground close to lake. Clean showers (included) and toilets. spots with firepits. off-season only open on Friday and Saturday night.. 24 usd. Firewood sold by rangers.

name: One of many nice places on the Denali highway
description: Nice pull off from the Denali highway, about 100m north of the road. Access is a little rough, but drive slowly and pretty much any rig can get in here. Great view of the mountains, short hike to a pretty little lake. Good place to pick huckleberries when in season. About 6 or 7 km east of Brushkana campground, which cost $12 per night, this place is free.

name: Clearwater Creek Bridge
description: At milepost 109, south side of the highway, right across from the entrance to Eagle Trail state recreation site. Two sites. Good for rigs under 20 ft or so. Gravel road access, fairly level. Nice creek view.

name: Lake Martin
description:
At the east entrance of the lake. Dirt parking lot near the boat ramp.  Quiet night and day. 
Very nice place. We've seen bald eagles. 

Please update if you come here and share your own points for all travelers. Thanks. Please no Generators.

name: Wallenius Wilhelmsen office
description: This is where I processed the paperwork to release my car, shipped RoRo from Brazil. Bring the delivery order and notice of arrival.

name: Tram Road (equestrian) campground
description: 4 sites, some can be booked Reserve America website (or app). No horse necessary. Gets some AT&T reception. Peaceful and private.

name: Lake Griffin State Park
description: Small State Park, clean bathroom, $20/night

name: Manatee Springs State Park
description: Nice campground closed to the Suwannee River. $22/night.

name: Pilot Station dump and water
description: Pilot station. $10 dump and water rinse. Fresh water at air fill station. Propane. RV parking spots.

name: Next to McDonalds
description: Go in the back and open a small metal door. Written water on it.

name: Bandera Wash House 24/7
description:
Very nice and clean laundromat.
wash: 2,25usd
dryer:1,75usd

name: Flying J - Eagles landing
description: Flying J Truck stop. Showers here are $12 and they provide soap, two towels, washcloth, and a private shower room with toilet and sink. The front clerk told me I could park anywhere for overnight parking. Even pointed out the best spots for less noise, lower light, etc. options are the Flying J lot, Wendy’s lot, and even behind the hotels across the street. Good for a night of sleep while passing through.

name: Dixieland MH & RV Park
description: Retirement community for 55 year's old and more. About sites for 100 mobile homes and 25 recreative vehicules.

name: La Paz County Park
description:
114 RV Sites. Most of them near the cristal clear Colorado River. Bathing, Boat Ramps...24$ per night and RV. 


Price is $27 for electric and water. Dump station on site. River access 
Tent sites/dry camping $18. Hot shower

name: Portola dog park on the river
description: There's a parking lot just off Hwy 70 across from Dollar General. The park has picnic tables,  a river, and flat ground for tents. No signs saying you can't stay overnight although I doubt it happens often. We stealth camped here in tents (no car) and the park cleanup crew we met in the morning were not bothered. The road was a bit loud. Restaurant across the street will let you used their bathroom.

name: Crane Creek Camp
description:
Great spot near a creek with room for a few separate spots. 

Water crossing (2 crossings to get back to the most isolated clearing). 

Approach from West is slightly technical. We were in two JKs (lifted w/ 35” tires) and a 100 Series (small lift on 33” tires).

name: Anaheim Harbor RV Park
description: Walking distance from Disney parks, cheaper than neighbouring place at 45$+taxes. Good showers, full hookups.

name: Hot showers @ Armijo Pool
description: Public aquatics center with hot showers. 3,- USD. Mon-Fri 9-14h, Sat-Sun 13-15:30h. Quick wifi.

name: Sawnee Campground
description: Army Corps of Engineers campground on beautiful Lake Lanier.

name: Ron Diaz Toyota Land Cruiser mechanic
description:
Don is a real Land Cruiser expert. Very helpful and knowledgable. Works mainly on 40. 50. 60. 70. Land Cruisers. 
25b Buena vista Ave. in Gilroy. 
Send him a text message on
(408) 842 3540 or try ccfj40@gmail.com

name: Nellis Cove
description: Nice quiet beach.  4x4 not needed but be careful of sinking into the sand

name: Six Mile Cove
description: Nice beach. Can get crowded / loud during peak times and on weekends. Beware of high winds, tents have blown away here.

name: Trees by River Crossing
description:
A pretty nice spot: Some level patches of grass right between a river crossing and a bridge. Some trees. Can also park on gravel (access road to bridge which is only used during high water). Quiet, lots of trash and gun shells, free.
Perfect for tents, no problems for big rigs (can turn around right after the river). Easy access on good gravel about 1/2 mile from highway.

name: South Bay Autohaus Defender Mechanic
description: Very good mechanics, got our Oil changed there. One of the few ones in California that know how to deal with (European) Landrover Defenders. Of course they also work with other cars. Friendly, quick, fair price.

name: Walmart
description: Pretty quiet for a Walmart near I10. We were parked on autocenter side.

name: Cattlemans Steakhouse
description:
Great Steaks at resonable prices. 
Stay for free after dinner.

name: Cochiti Lake Campground
description: Very nice place with an amazing view on the lake. Restrooms and showers are heated (on April). I never seen an as clean campsite! Table and fireplace at each site, no water but it's never so far. 12$ without electricity/ 20$ with. it's THE perfect place!!! 10mn by car to Kasha-Katuwe Tent Rocks.

name: Kingman Wash
description: The road out here is rough but you don’t need 4x4 just a lot of patience.  The grounds are very clean so let’s please try to keep it that way.  Pack in pack out.  They do have pit toilets which is super convenient.  I saw 4 burros and there is rumored to be sheep in the mountains.  The cell service out here is excellent.

name: Cabeza Prieta National Wildlife refuge headquarters
description:
Visitors center with all the information about camping in the area. Get your permit here for camping in the refuge. 

PS. Permit for bombing range is online. 
https://luke.isportsman.net

name: Olsens IGA store
description: water here as well as a couple of other places. All the same price - buck for 5 gallons. Biggest store in Ajo. deli has WiFi.

name: Starlight Solar Power Systems
description: Larry Crutcher has an Store in YUMA and can help with Batteries and Solar system problems. He has great experience and is absolutely helpful.

name: Big sheep road south (next I59)
description:
Informal spot along the Gravel road next JEM trail. 30 feet max. 
Sunny. Good stop for a night or to ride Mountain bike trails.
ATT and T-Mobil signal 4G

name: Limekiln Canyon - Next Climbing Area
description:
Huge, relatively flat parking with plenty of space for lots of vans and rv’s and tents. 
New pit toilet!

About 14 miles drive on white rocks road (10.5 miles big and Gravel and 3.5 miles dirt mountain).

The 10 miles of dirt road is mostly washboard, not very pleasant. In the last mile before the Lime Kiln parking there are a few steep hills that can get quite rutted and high clearance-y. It is definitely a rattly 10 miles of dirt road. Don’t recommend going over 30mph.

name: Militairy checkpoint
description: You need a special US military issued document to pass this point if you drive the FR-728 road from Sonoita to Sierra Vista.

name: Tysons wash
description: LTVA south of Quartzsite AZ on hwy 95. lots of area for boondocking. good  access from hwy 95

name: 7035-7099 Fountain Ave, LA
description: Parking lot near Hollywood Boulevard, good to leave your car/rig if you want to walk around the area (no overnight). Ask inside the West Hollywood Urgent Care for permission as this is allocated to their patients but they let us park for a couple of hours since it was very quiet that day.

name: West Lake Davy Crockett Campground
description: Established waterfront campground with pit toilets & picnic tables. Gravel loop with about 7-8 pullouts with relatively flat parking pads. I believe there is a fee but didn't see a drop box. I arrived after dark and no one else was in the campground. Very quiet and makes for an epic sunrise.

name: Lake Bruin State Park
description: quiet, nice, on a lake. $28/night. open all year.

name: North fruita desert
description: many flat free sites right next to the north fruita mountain bike trailhead. Great views and accessible with most vehicles. there is an established campground just up the road if that's your style

name: Ozark Campground
description:
Quiet, pitch-black and right on the Buffalo National River. We heard coyotes howling through the night and saw an incredible amount of stars. Open year round and has 31 campsites available on a first come, first served basis. Picnic table, fire ring, and lantern hook included.

Off Season (Nov. 15 - Mar. 14) = Free 
We camped in Dec., vault restroom only and trash pick-up, nothing else. 

In season = nightly fee, but not sure I imagine around $10.
Running water and flushable toilets.

name: Devil's River State Natural Area
description:
If you are looking for a remote, wilderness destination in the Texas Hill country look no further. The campground is a long 22 mile drive on a dirt/gravel so 4X4 and decent ground clearance is recommended. You can bring an RV or trailer but it may be tough given the road conditions. It's ONLY OPEN ON THE WEEKENDS (Fri/Sat/Sun check-in, leave on Monday) and limited to 7 spots (we called ahead to reserve a spot)- $10 per night.

It is a short drive to the river, hikes or camp headquarters. Potable water and hot showers are available at the headquarters, and the rangers are incredibly knowledgeable and helpful. 

Note: You will have to hike .9 miles to the river, so don't expect to lug heavy watercraft. We loaded our inflatable SUPs on our back and do no regret it one bit though. We floated the entire day on the Devil's River and the views/fishing were well worth the trek. We were the only people on the river the entire time, but have heard it can be well traveled in other months/conditions.

name: White Rock Mountain Recreation Area
description:
Incredible place to take in a sunset/sunrise, but is a bit of a drive on washboard gravel roads to make it (well worth it in our opinion). The last part of the drive up the switchback to the top would be interesting in a large rig/rv and I am not so sure I would recommend it (there is Shores Lake a bit away from the mountain that may be better for these vehicles).

Only stayed one night ($11) and arrived just a bit before sunset, which was quite amazing as mentioned above. Had to pack in/pack out everything, although trash does seem to be available during the 'regular' season.

name: Love’s
description: Gas station and truckstop. Gas, general goods, propane, places to park & sleep and microwaves. Subway as well. Clean and seemingly safe. Lots of lights and through traffic

name: Eagle pass Kickapoo casino
description: RV park at the casino. Sites with full hook-up, water, sewer, electricity. No bathrooms. 15$/24 hours. Quiet. 4 bars of verizon lte.

name: A mighty wind
description: Beautiful stop on the bluffs over looking Fruita. Just outside Colorado National Monument. Drive through the park to get to the rattlesnake canyon access road. Can get reallly windy

name: John Pennekamp Coral Reef State Park
description: There are four state parks to camp in the Keys. All are open for camping except Long Key at this time which is still under reconstruction.  Reservations are hard to get but you can reserve 11 mos. in advance thru ReserveAmerica.  Depending on the weather, Pennekamp has great snorkeling, as most do in the Keys. Camping by the mangrove side of the campground means mosquitos.

name: Mission beach Main parking
description:
Free day parking.
Can't park from 2ham to 4ham but San Fernandino street next to this lot is available. Great location right by the beach

name: Sunshine RV Resort
description:
Sunshine RV Resort
1900 Grace Avenue 
Harlingen, Texas 78550
800-456-4137

name: Richardson Automotive
description:
Chris is a trustworthy guy. I had an oil change at another place and was told what all was wrong and needs to be replaced. Chris told me its all fine and saved me a couple of hundred $.
1100 East Kingsbury Street, Seguin

name: New Brighton State Beach
description: Bike campsites, group sites, hook ups, premium campsites. Open during winter. $35 for regular site, $50 for premium and hookup. Premium sites are on a huge cliff overlooking the beach but beach access is only at a specific point.

name: Streetside in business park
description:
Streetside parking along a wide but quiet avenue in a business park. Some trucks parked as well (not sleeping there). Well lit, clean. Okay for a night, not a beautiful spot.
Rooftop tent people might want to continue down the street where there are no businesses across the street.
There is no overnighting at the Walmart next door (busy, noisy, lot of movement). It was actually their security guy who referred me to this street.
Not sure whether legal, but free. Felt pretty safe. Restrooms at Walmart, 3min walk.

name: Parking san fernandino
description:
Next to main beach parking lot (mission beach) 

Possible to park until 8am on Monday to Friday

name: Mohegan Sun Casino
description: Free parking for RVs in oversized lot. Call security office when you arrive. Phone number is listed at entrance.

name: Why fuel station
description: Propane, fuel and Mexican auto insurance available here. Fuel in Lukeville but not sure about propane. Duty free store in Lukeville. Why Not travel is the last mini Mart before border. If you need to print anything, go to Coyote Howls. $.10/page there. Propane connector looked like the standard USA connector.

name: Coyote Howls  campground
description:
Neat place with everything you need. Nice people. very reasonable rates @ $10/ night! 
 Hot showers for $0.25. Nice washer/dryers. Clothes lines if you want. Huge book exchange. Computer room. Great sunset.

name: Crikside
description: Spot by a creek but no cell service. Very quiet and secluded. Small rigs only. Our sprinter was ok

name: Lone Tree BLM campground
description: Large gravel parking lot on the east side of highway. Lots of RV’s of all sizes parked here. A dirt road leads further into the hills, seems like more (and much more private and quiet) camping up there.

name: Small turn out next to Parc Scott Creek
description: Small turn out very flat for small campervan or private car along hwy 1; you can park in front of the sea; and be very discret ! No "no sign" and no one bothered us :-) a bit noisy but after 10pm there is less cars

name: Panoramic Highway Trailhead
description: Big parking on side of the road with view of the ocean and near the town of Stinson Beach.

name: Old Rag Mountain
description: Beautiful hike, about 9 miles, with a scenic view of the Shenandoah.

name: Wickham Park Campground
description:
12/22-30/2017
Convenient to Uncle Michael. 
Hard to access during activities such as the Space Coast Light Festival.

name: Near the campground
description: At the entrance of the campsite dump station with water.

name: Galveston-Port Bolivar ferry
description: Free ferry, takes about 20min, waited 1hr.

name: Holtville Blm 14 day stay camping
description:
Desert camping. 14 days stay. No fee. 
This is not the best camping for a big motorhome.  
Roads are rough getting in.

Cell reception ok.  (At&T)

name: Planet Fitness
description: We found many other campers staying at this parking lot. The gym is actually 24 hours so cars are actually coming and going. WiFi is also available :)

name: Silver Lake campsite
description: State campsite. Also two others nearby. Book online at Reserve America. $15-25. Water and power. Pets OK. No alcohol. Picnic table and fire ring with wood collection OK. Noise from the interstate not bothersome. Good AT&T reception.

name: Bashfords Hot Mineral springs
description: 6 hot tubs, pool, jacuzzi and  laundromat. Very friendly residents, some permanent. Camping area with fire pit is on gravel. Lots of visits by motorcycle riders and their groups.

name: Everglades - Long Pine Key campground
description: $25-30 per night, reservations accepted now. 108 sites. Lovely place, quiet and peaceful. No shelter from the sun. Fire pit and picnic table at each site. Unfortunately a lot of light-seeking bugs in addition to the mosquitos. Patchy mobile phone service.

name: Flying A campground - Myakka State Forest
description: Approx $9 per night per site. Very quiet and private loop of 10 sites behind a locked gate. Booking online is easiest at Reservations America but there are also first-come sites. Port-a-loos provided with toilet paper but are a LONG way from most sites except 7-9. BBQ, fire pit and big picnic table at each site. No water or power. Some reception with AT&T.

name: RV Park Beacon
description: small RV Park closed to the sea. nice meeting room, free coffee. $40/night

name: MANDY’S TIRE
description:
Armando “Mandy” has wide selection of new and used tires for my Overlanding Vehicle. Special orders will be overnighted to his shop. 

He was kind enough to let me sleep at the shop while my special order came in.

name: Braley Pond Campsites
description: Four campsites with rock fire rings. Maybe one site where a 25’ rig could back in. Pit toilets. Picnic tables at day use area not the campsites. Pretty sure the Pond is Stocked with Rainbow Trout.

name: Pilot travel center (+ camping option)
description: Dump station ($10) with potable water and free air pump. Gas and diesel, restroom, shower. Propane. You can sleep in the lot for one night but it’s a small lot and fills quickly, and rigs over 25 feet may not fit.

name: Mudrak Custom Cruisers
description: Gary Kardum is a Land Cruiser enthusiast and operates a large shop working mostly on land cruisers at any point in time you're probably going to see 20 or more customer vehicles in there. He's been running his shop for more than 20 years. He's not cheap but he does top notch work. He does anything from regular maintenance to big custom jobs. While specialized in Land Cruisers, I'd trust him with any 4x4, big or small. If you ask nicely, he can probably offer you a place to park overnight if you have a bigger job.

name: Presnell’s RV Resort
description: Very nice. Boat ramp. Very clean and neat. Heated pool.

name: Bynum Creek
description: Decent, free spot to stay for a night if you're passing through. Near a drained lake bed and boat launch. Only one or two flat spots for vehicles. Restrooms and trash cans available. A few rowdy trucks came by in the night, but were far enough away to not bother us too much. Great 4g signal.

name: Citico Creek
description: Several good spots along Citico Creek in the Cherokee National Forest. This is site 9 out of 14, but one of the better sites. One pit toilet and garbage cans available about a mile up the road from here. Quiet and beautiful. Please pack it out!

name: Boulder River
description: Only four sites, very quiet during the fall, winter and spring.

name: Point Reyes Station
description:
parking near church.  
Very quiet. Table available.
free WiFi 
Overnight possible.

name: Buckhorn Hunt camp
description: Primitive camping in the forest. No charge but the only facilities are port-a-loos. Dirt road access. Some AT&T and Verizon reception.

name: Walmart brawley
description: Big and confortable parking lot in brawley Town ...im staying 2 days no problem 🙂

name: Southern tip of Anza Borrego state park
description: Nice spot up by the rocks but there are a lot of little roads with pull outs all around here after you pass the wind farm.  this is state park but it's BLM land before the park.  No campfires unless you can keep it off the ground. Cell signal is OK, have 4G data if you climb the hill a little or head East.

name: Gold miners RV Park
description: Stoppedshower not very clean here for showers ($5 each) and fast internet. They have a laundry as well.  Campground in open field.

name: Tim's Ford State Park
description: Campgrounds, golf course, boat ramp, walking trails. Very well maintained.

name: Los Coyotes Reservation Campground
description: Indian Reservation campground and trailhead to Hot Springs Mt.  Pit toilets, no electric hook-up and water has a sign saying it's not potable.

name: Bodega Bay
description:
parking side the road a little noisy
nice view on the lagoon

name: Lake Waramaug State Park Campground
description:
Open field campground with lake access.

phone # - 
860-242-3200
email - deep.stateparks@ct.gov

name: Cochise Stronghold
description: Secluded quiet spot in valley.  In January it is cool so nice spot with sun.  Good views on hill. Historic native Americans site.   If summer there is a state campground with shade a few miles up the valley.

name: Sure Stay by Best Western
description: right off interstate 10 went  in and ask if we could stay for the night. They said sure go down to the back right by the BBQ pit. There is a dump in the ground by the BBQ pit.

name: primitive Camp site on Arroyo Tapiado Rd by mud cave
description: Quiet spot in the canyon next to the mud cave.  No services and no cell service.  good stop when exploring the caves, but there are many other places to stop too.

name: Pictograph Road  in Anza Borrego
description: sure there is a campground at Blair valley with a pit toilet, bit there were also 5 other cars there.  As you drive out pictograph road there are many primitive spots to choose from.  we kept going 1.3 miles to this spot where we could see no one else.  Quiet spot next to a hill with great 4G cell signal.  Must bring a metal container for a fire as per all of Anza Borrego park.

name: Fort Worden State Park
description: Nice state campground right in front of beach at Puget Sound. Upper Campground in forrest available, too. Starting at 25$.

name: Chinook RV resort
description:
Driving with motorcycle, very cheap for tent camping, just USD 10
RV is USD 20
They are friendly and helpful
Fullhookups are $50 -10% for AAA

name: Salmon Creek
description: parking side the road No prohibited sign Nice view on the sea

name: pompano beach
description: Quiet street with free parking space and restaurant nearby. Beach about 1km.

name: Suburban propane
description:
Due to covid policy changes this location no longer provides propane to the walk in public. Propane only provided to account holders.

Awesome stop. Very glad with the service. Knowledgeable. I think they can handle quite a few different types of connections since all they did was handle propane.

name: Alpine RV Park & Campgrounds
description: Private campground right across from the Safeway grocery store, a local hardware store, and a 30 minute walk to the center of Leavenworth.  Leavenworth has a shuttle bus that runs most of the day, a bus station is across the highway near the traffic light and pedestrian crossing.  $45 for a water/electric/sewer/fire pit and WiFi.  They have a sliding scale for pricing, campsites that don't have a fire pit, or sites without sewer are a lower rate. Narrow spaces but clean and mostly level.  Heated bathroom/shower facility which is very nice in the middle of winter, and kept very clean.  Frequently fully booked during the high season.

name: Jim Creek
description: Restricted, Access available to Active, Retired or Military Civilians and their dependents. Great place quite, extremely friendly staff, laundry and shower facilities.

name: North Ranch RV Park Escappees RV Club
description: RV Place with reasonable fees, 12,76 $ for dry Camping and 28,18 $ for Full hook, very clean showers and laundrys, mostly Snowbirds , propane available.

name: Copperfield Park
description: Campground maintained by the Idaho Power Company. The one further up the 71 Hwy is much more picturesque though (Woodhead). During winter the rates are very cheap $8/night. There are showers but they were all locked. There is running water in the bathrooms. Electricity hookups and water hookups at every site. There are picnic tables and fire pits. There is camp only sites as well. You can pay $5 a day for WiFi. It saved our day because we ran into car issues and had to google.

name: Off I90
description: Plenty of sites to pull off an camp along the road. Inside of safety corridor so no target shooting allowed. Water is available from nearby river. Can be quite crowded during summer.

name: FR712 boondocking
description: Boondocking site off forest road FR712 in the Carson National Forest. Gravel road was in decent shape when I did it, at least as far as this campsite.  I saw several other vehicles pass going further, so there are probably more options up there. No facilities, camping on grass  in an open area surrounded by pine trees.  Very quiet at night, and lots of stars.

name: Brazos Overlook
description: Free camping in the parking lot at the scenic overlook of the Brazos Cliffs. There are picnic tables, shade structures, bathrooms, and garbage cans. No signs saying you can't park overnight. There were a few people stopping by during the day to look at the vista, but it was totally quiet at night. It's a high elevation, so gets pretty chilly. Wonderful views, and free!

name: Echo Amphitheater CG
description:
National Forest campground not far from Ghost Ranch. It's set in an area of sculpted red rocks, one part of which is a natural echo chamber. It's a small campground, and there's a day use area as well. There are picnic tables (no shade except in the group/day use areas), flush toilets, and potable water. Beautiful views, super quiet at night. I had decent TMobile cell service from some sites, not others.

This was free when I was there, but you can see the signs that they used to charge $10 for camping. The prices and deposit slots were taped over, but I don't know if it will be free permanently or not.

name: Datil Wells CG
description: A surprisingly nice campground, definitely more than I was expecting! Big sites, well spaced among the pines, and some hiking trails right from the campground. There's water, picnic tables, garbage service, bathrooms. And there's also a visitor center, with info and photos on the history of the place (lots of cattle drives through here), and they had wifi available at the visitor center too. I had no TMobile cell service here. Hosts were super friendly. $15.

name: Lake Como Rd boondocking
description:
Boondocking off this road which leads up to Lake Como in the Sangre de Cristo mountains. The lower portion of the road is a good gravel road, through open fields. This part is easy enough for any rig, and there are a couple of spots pretty far down.  As you climb higher and higher, the road deteriorates, until it turns into one of the toughest 4WD roads in Colorado. There are lots of places available, it just depends how far you want to go.

This is boondocking, no facilities. I had decent TMobile cell service from my spot. You can hike up the road if you don't want to tackle hard core 4WD, and there's an old ghost town. There are also three 14ers you can reach from here, so plenty of hikers out to climb the peaks. Free.

name: San Luis Lake SWA
description: Free campground, with free electricity! This used to be a state park, and they set up a big campground, well designed with good facilities. Then there was a problem with the water supply, and they turned it into a State Wildlife Area and made it free. You have a view of Great Sand Dunes right across the lake (easy drive from here). No water available. Need fishing/hunting license to camp.

name: East Fork Rd boondocking
description: Gorgeous boondocking site!  Continue on East Fork Road past the official campground, and you'll start to see boondocking sites along the side of the road. There are quite a few possibilities - some right down by the river, and others higher above it. Boondocking with no facilities, and I had no cell service. There are some gorgeous spots, and it's free!

name: Robbers Gulch boondocking
description: Boondocking on BLM land along Robbers Gulch road.  You need to go in at least 1/2 mile, because the first part of the road is State land (no camping). After that, it's BLM (free and open for boondocking). I didn't see any sign showing the border. Tons of open space and places you can go. The gravel road was in decent condition when I did it, but looks like it could be tricky when muddy. No facilities. Free.

name: Ring Lake campground
description: Small campground beside the lake in a Wildlife Management Area.  Pretty area, nice lake views. Campground is basically a grassy area by the lake, with pit toilet, and stone fire circles (fires were prohibited when I was there, though, due to fire danger).  Good gravel road to get here. Free.

name: Buffalo Valley boondocking
description: Boondocking off Buffalo Valley Rd, just a bit east of Grand Teton National Park. I stayed here to see the total solar eclipse at the Tetons, and even with the crowds then, there were spaces available out here. It's a good paved road, and you'll see various camping spots scattered along it. Easy drive to get into the park for hiking and sightseeing. No facilities. Free. No cell service. This is a group site and can accommodate multiple rigs, unlike many of the smaller pull-offs in the area.

name: Big Sandy Reservoir
description: This sizable reservoir has small established campgrounds on the east and west sides. I opted for wild camping on the south side, on the bluff overlooking the lake. The campgrounds have toilets and a few picnic tables. The wild camping has no facilities. Whichever you choose, it's free!

name: Bisbee breakfast club
description: Great place for American breakfast. Not a greasy spoon.  Parking for big rigs

name: Parking on Ocean Ave
description: Free until 9 am street parking, fairly quiet. Within 0.5 mile from multiple bathrooms though those say they close at 8 pm (sink looks to always be accessible). Close to pier too.

name: Lake Martin
description:
Large boat ramp parking in front of magnificent swamp. 
No service but good phone signal.

name: Johnson Valley OHV
description: Open camping next to Cougar Buttes in an OHV (Off-Highway Vehicle) area. 4x4 is recommended due to loose sand and can be busy/loud on weekends, restrooms too.

name: Chassahowitzka River Campground
description:
This is a really pretty spot on the river. You can rent kayaks or canoes to enjoy the river. There are two separate camping areas - one for RVs with services and the other for tents without. We paid $25. for the two of us and a nice treed site.
Amenities include clubhouse, showers, and coin laundry.

name: Parking au calme
description:
Parking at a sports center with outdoor pool and children's playgrounds. Good free wifi. Closed at night, we stayed 2 blocks away, on a street next to a sports park in a residential area.
Very very quiet, 30-45 minutes north of Los Angeles.

name: Hot showers @ YMCA Ocean Springs
description:
The friendly folks at this YMCA let me take a great hot shower. It's free if it's your first visit to this YMCA. If it isn't it's 8 USD.
Nice pool, too.
Free wifi available.

name: Govt Wash Road
description:
NOTE: You cannot camp on the first part of the road (even if it looks like there are spaces). You have to follow the road *past* the parking lot with the bathrooms. (Camping *in* the parking lot is also not allowed.) 

From there you have access to camping and the lake. Plenty of spots for big rigs or smaller ones. Roads start out great, but many get much sandier as you get closer to the water. I saw a couple of trucks get stuck on the sand. Be careful the further down you go. 

Really quiet even if they were a lot of RVs on the road, quite impressive ;) We had some coyotes around 5 am making some noise, kind of wild! ;)

Excellent Verizon coverage.

name: picnic area
description: on I10 east. no rules posted. Slept the night there. lots of truckers. pls.park respectfully

name: ST Joseph Peninsula State Park
description: Beautiful place right on the Gulf of Mexico

name: Desert flats near Needles
description: Dirt road out to some nice quiet parking spots. No fires, no water, no bathroom. Safer than staying in Needles.

name: Tims Ford State Park
description: Open year round. Office is open until 6:00 p.m. 30- and 50- amp service. Some sites are FHU (Full hook-up: water, electric, sewer)

name: Trace State Park
