description: On Old Natchez Trace Lake. Lake was drained when I was here. Still beautiful.

name: Hurricane Creek Camp
description: Very secluded campsite tucked away off of hurricane creek trail. You will pass a big mud pit to reach it. Very open. Could fit 6 or 7 rigs. River not far from firepit.

name: Carlsbad
description: Public free dump station, no potable water

name: Soft Suds Laundry
description: big laundry, $7 wash and dry a big machine, nice people

name: Millard Trail Camp
description: Hidden gem of a campsite. just a few miles outside of LA, but you wouldn't know it. As far as I know this site is manned and all locals assured me it is very safe. The gate closes at night barring access to the road here. From the campsite you can access many hiking and biking trails. There are the usual drop toilets and fire pits with benches. I stayed here on a Sunday night and it was quiet. Remember there are bears around so be bear aware. Safe storage is provided for campers.

name: Pohick Bay Regional Park
description: One of the closet campgrounds to D.C.  Nicely shaded sites, playground, water activities, trails, good facilities with flush toilets, hot showers. Also a water park for younger travelers.  May need a reservation on weekends and holidays. Electric hookup and full hookup available. Around $40 per night.

name: La Quinta Public Library
description: Free WiFi, desktop computer use. Copies 15¢. Big, new library, with covered parking (9ft or so and under).

name: Snake River RV Park & Campground
description: Both tent and RV friendly. Laundry and bathroom/showers plus propane. Dog friendly too.

name: Jessie M. Honeyman Memorial State Park
description: Established state park. Has showers, full hook up, playground for kids, partial hook up and tent sites. Paid $21 for the night - no hook up. Paths lead to the dunes. Lots of dirt bike trails for ATV. Quiet, clean and safe. Small wood bundles for $10. Drive 1 mile north of state park on side of road to find large bundles of wood for $10. Beautiful campground.

name: Ridgeline
description: Large spot at top of ridge line. Large fire pit set up and dried wood all around. Amazing views of Olympic mountains and stars at night. Large enough for a few vehicles. Road can be narrow coming in and a few switchbacks, there will be some scrapes. 2-3 bars of Verizon 4G

name: Snow to Sun RV Resort
description: Great RV resort, over 55's only.  Lots of activities and amenities with heated pool, hot tub, exercise room, billiards room, library, cards room, crafts room, shuffle court, horseshoes pitch and dance hall.  Happy hour every day except Sunday where beer is $2.00 a glass.  Live music dance every Saturday night.  Rates are $21.00 to $35.00, $10.50 to $17.50 with Passport  America membership.  Full hookups.  Easy access off of Interstate 2.

name: near big cypress national park
description: parking near the road but quiet. No permit needed for overnight stay (we asked). be careful with snakes in the grass.

name: Point Arena
description:
public parking at the center of the town
no prohibited sign

name: Papalote Encino
description:
BBRSP, site: papalote Encino
Water trough for water.  Need to boil or filter. No natural water source. No cat holes for restroom.  Must use bucket to pack out waste.

name: Santee Coastal Reserve (Free) DNR Campground
description: Beautiful, established DNR campground with eight spots. Completely free! Hiking trails through swaps with gators and wildlife. No facilities, no restroom, no trash cans. Pack it in, pack it out! Maximum stay is 4 days.

name: Oasis Visitor Center
description: Free potable water in the north end of the visitor center parking lot. Spigot box unlocked when visitor center open.

name: National Forest dispersed camping
description: An open parking lot off of a gravel road, about 12 minutes from Bishop. Very quiet.

name: heart of the mohave - needles
description: BLM space with tons of room and multiple fire pits. A little noise from the road and can be windy. Overall good place for a night.

name: John's Canyon
description: Remote camping west of Goosenecks State Park. Dark skies and solitude. High clearance four wheel drive highly recommended.

name: La Posa LTVA South
description:
$40 / 2 weeks, water, dump, trash 1 mile down, ugly scenery, no good groceries (928)317-3200, 3/12/20 (didn't stay)
BLM_AZ_YFOWEB@blm.gov https://www.blm.gov/visit/la-posa-long-term-visitor-area

name: Alps Haus Cafe in Marleeville
description: GREAT place for a breakfast burrito or lunch! They have WiFi. Across the street is a public water bottle filling station. Very welcoming to a traveler.

name: DeMartin beach picnic area
description: Beautiful place to wake up to. Stayed here one night and I wasn't the only one. Not too noisy and nobody came to tell us to leave. Didn't see any signs either.

name: Cayote Valley Casino Parking Lot
description:
RVs only, no vans, SUVs, etc

Free overnight parking in the back gravel overflow parking lot of the casino. Just walk into the smoke filled casino towards the back and check in with security. Simple and easy. Friendly staff and security. Safe place to crash overnight. $2 beer specials. Breakfast specials too. Parked with other rigs and RVs. Cheap fuel at the cayote valley gas station near casino. We also pick up the free wifi from inside if parked closer to the casino. No problemo.

name: Wild Horse Canyon
description:
Super easy flat spot for at least a few vehicles. Also a few fire pits. If you have 4x4, you can continue west on Wild Horse Canyon road and there are more spots. 

Close to the Information Center and hiking. 1/4 mile north is Hole-In-The-Wall Campground with water and dump station.

name: Mississippi welcome center
description:
Free dump station with water! 
(Sign says no overnight parking)

name: Mountain Spirits RV Park
description: nice people, clean bathrooms, $28/night. propane gas

name: Chiricahua National Monument, Bonita Canyon Campground
description: Nice Campground in a forest. $20/night. A lot of hikes. No Blackwater dump.

name: White Earth Dam
description: FREE. Incredibly beautiful location other than the view of the oilfield in the distance. Located right near a beautiful canyon next to a river within the mountains. You'll have the opportunity to watch thousands of nesting birds right over the camping shelter. :) Picnic tables, multiple sites. No services, a couple of pit toilets.

name: Kelso Dunes
description:
HUGE camping area with tons of space and fire pits. 

The hike from camp to the top of the dune is definitely worth the view!

name: Hole-in-the-wall campground dump
description: Free dump at Hole-in-the-wall campground. There’s no running water here, but the information center 1/4 mile south has water.

name: walmart
description: Walmart parking rather quiet. shop open 24/24

name: Hog Pen Landing
description:
16 sites, not all have picnic tables, but almost all are lake side.
Two nice pit toilets.
Beautiful views.
Easy to get to.
Spent one night. It was quiet and clean.
$10 a night

name: Heather Lake Trailhead
description: Graded gravel lot, occasionally rowdy yahoos come up but never cause problems.

name: Mountain Springs Trailhead
description:
Trailhead parking on dirt/gravel area right off the highway. Room for multiple vehicles. A bit of noise from the highway but a good place for the night. 

Looking at google maps, it appears there are more parking spots if you continued north on the dirt road, but we didn’t make it up there.

name: Your Dream Garage DIY
description:
It's a DO IT YOURSELF garage !
30$/hour for lift and tools
Open 7/7
Very cool for save money on the road ;)

name: Linville Falls Campground
description: Permitted wild camping site off of a dirt track with some fairly steep climbs. Nearly all in woodland with lots of hikes and trails and a gorge to explore. Quiet. Fires allowed and most of the pitches had stone fire places with plenty of fallen trees to use as fuel. No facilities.

name: Shell gas station
description: Gas station with eatery and Indian shop with a couple of areas just off the forecourt where trucks stop over night.

name: Motivated RV
description:
We are a French couple who used Motivated RV (Austin Texas), service + repair + renovation to advise us on the purchase of a used motorhome for our 1 year trip to the United States. They also have
carried out various work on our motorhome.
This company is serious with a friendly, available and qualified staff in all areas of RV repairs and renovations.
For information they renovate and sell completely campers but also campers of all types and Airstream ....
We recommend them warmly.
Fab and Domi
http://www.nomadchannel.com

name: Guller Ice Cave
description: Large ice stalagmites with ice formations year round.

name: Gunnison river overlook
description: Many small but gorgeous flat spaces with fire rings along a huge mesa.

name: Yankabillys
description: nice couple and fair price's. natural environment and super walk along the rim.

name: Walmart
description: as in all Walmarts you need to park along the back parking lot. Staff friendly

name: Lowe's parking lot
description: We stayed in Lowe's parking lot by there utility trailers. 3 days nice and quit. We asked first.

name: Palmetto State Park, Texas
description: Pretty State Park off I-10 90 km east San Antonio on a river. They have 2 separate campsites, 1 for Tents & another for RV with power & showers. Tent sites $12 + $3 pp park fees

name: Bottomless Lakes State Park, Near Roswell
description: Nice State Park near Roswell. $10 for tent site with shelter, table & water & pit Toilets. Also area in park for hookups with showers (Lea Lake, reservation-only, $14-$18/night plus $4 reservation fee 9/2021). Showers might be seasonal. They were not operational when I was here, 5/7/19. Showers are outside showers.

name: Walmart - T or C
description: Walmart parking lot.  Not that many space for big rigs because there is solar panels all over the parking lot.  If you park close to the garage area you can have free wifi.  Open 24h for toilets and fill up bottle inside.

name: MacMillen RV Park
description: Nice campground. Quiet.  Close to the city.  All hookup for 30$. Cash or check only.  Hot showers. Laundry 2,50$/load. Wifi.  Cable. Manager very friendly.

name: Wild Goose Can. Rd
description: Several good flat spots along the forest road. Some have fire rings. Road is in good condition but need 4x4 in wet and snowy conditions.

name: Schultz Pass RD.
description: A multitude good spots along the Schultz Pass RD and Lockett within the National Forest. Very quiet, flat. fire ring (when fires permitted).

name: Snowmobile trail head
description: Stayed the night here. Super quite no one else was here. Just follow the signs for snowmobiles.

name: BLM camping-Lone Mesa Campground
description: This is BLM camping 7 miles down Lone Mesa Campground Rd. A few sites along designated road. 4x4/High Clearance recommended.

name: Bunker Hills Campground
description: Nice pretty quite for in the city. Hiking, cross-country sking, walking/biking trails,   water park. Clean sites

name: Curtis Creek National Forest Campground
description:
Campground in the forest run by National Forestry. $10 per night / Car (October 2017) Only for small RVs.
Between Blue Ridge Parkway and Highway No. 40 to Ashville.

name: Great River Road State Park
description:
Was in former times a Campground within the State Park, but was destroyed due to a flood in 2011 and since then the Campground is not in function anymore. 
There is a sign at the entrance of the Park "day use only". At the beginning of the Park there is a parking lot with boat launch beside a small lake. We where there for 3 nights and nobody bothered us. Police drove through but didn't say anything. There is another parking lot opposite of the boat launch, where overnight parking seems to be also tolerated. There is are restroom but was closed when we have been staying here. 
A few feet after the parking lot there is a bridge with a gate and a sign "Wednesday to Sunday 8am to 5pm". After that sign overnight parking was not tolerated! We tried to stay there but a ranger came and asked us to leave that area latest at 5 pm.

name: Sherburne WMA
description:
Free Campground run by WMA of Louisiana. Stay max. 16 days allowed.
Nice place but noisy because located within shooting and hunting training area.

name: Fort Pickens National Park Campground
description:
White sandy beach and beautiful dunes. Operated by the National Park Service 15 $ fee for the park (valid 7 days to go in and out) lot of sites, all paved with electricity and water 26$ some are to short for big rigs.
Just few trees, no privacy
No pets at the beach

name: D&D South Free Camp
description: Quite a few more or less secluded camp spots. Take the road left from the boatramp. Free. Easy access for all rigs. On the other side of the Farm to Market Road you will find D&D North with more amenities (warm shower). On North you pay $10. There is a boat ramp and a pier to go fishing. Easy entry to 2 hiking trails.

name: Mutual Mine Campground
description: Well-established campground next to former quarry. Reservation is required

name: Oconee boat ramp.
description: Quiet. Boat ramp. Had some fire rings. Ranger pulled up, checked my fishing license. I told him I was spending the night, he didn't bat an eye.

name: Peek a boo Trail head
description: Big parking. Table and pit toilet. You can tent up easily. Cold in winter. Phone service is pretty good.

name: Baker Creek Campground
description: Nice county campground on the creek with shade in summer. Quiet and away from the highway.

name: Taboose Creek Campground
description: Nice basic campground with excellent Sierra views along a creek. Not far off highway 395 for travelers.

name: Tinnemaha Campground
description: Basic county campground, out of the way but not too far off the highway. Very quiet.

name: South Mountains State Park Campground
description: Small established campground inside the South Mountains State Park. Some sites are relatively secluded. Backpacking sites are available. All camping by reservation only. Can be reserved on site but will only be guaranteed one night. Reserve in advance online for multiple nights. $20 a night. Gates open from 0700-1900 Dec to Feb, till 2000 November, till 2100 Mar, Apr, and Oct, and till 2200 May to Sept.

name: Moss Knob Shooting Range
description: Small 7, 25, and 100 yard range. Passes must be on your person, can be attained at many local general stores and gun shops for $3. See website for further details: https://www.fs.usda.gov/recarea/nfsnc/recarea/?recid=48682

name: Sage Flat Campground
description: Forest Service campground along Big Pine Creek. BBQ, picknick tables, bear proof storage, pit toilets, (potable?) water and garbage/recycling container service. Firewood for sale. All sites First Come, First Serve. No cell coverage. Nice location a mile or so from the Palisades trailhead.

name: Big Pine Creek Campground
description:
Note: closed seasonally in winter.

Nice forest service campground along Big Pine Creek at the end of Glacier Lodge road with good access to trailhead, pack station, and food at the Glacier Lodge.

name: Upper Sage Flat Campground
description: Forest Service campground along Big Pine Creek near trailhead.

name: Perez Tires & Service
description: Perez Tires recently opened a tire repair and vehicle service shop in Big Pine. This would be a good stop if you need any repair done before/after heading into Death Valley or beyond.

name: Hi Country Market & Hardware
description:
This little market has groceries, prepared food, and even a well provisioned hardware section with fuses and basic RV and automotive parts.

This location is also a Chevron gas station and the owners run the attached bristecone motel and adjacent laundromat.

name: Glacier View Campground
description: This county campground best feature is that it is at the intersections of Highways 395 and 168 so makes an easy stop before getting an early start into Death Valley or destinations beyond. It has hookups and showers so it can be a good place to clean up and reprovision in Big Pine. Nice views but be prepared for some road noise and there is not much privacy.

name: Goodale Creek Campground
description: Nice BLM campground located on Goodale Creek. Nice Sierra views.

name: Eastern Sierra Visitor Center
description:
This visitor center has good info on roads etc as well as clean bathrooms.

https://www.fs.usda.gov/recarea/inyo/recarea/?recid=20698

name: Sawmill Meadow Campsite
description: This beautiful remote spot is on the Inyo National Forest and shown with a camping symbol on topo maps but is not a staffed campground.

name: Crooked Meadows Campsites
description: This is a primitive Forest Service camping area with dispersed camping sites

name: Sagehen Meadows Campsites
description: This is a primitive Forest Service camping area with picnic tables and dispersed camp sites.

name: Taylor Creek Campsites
description: This is a primitive Forest Service camping area on Taylor Creek in the Glass Mountains.

name: Glass Creek Campground
description: This is a primitive USFS camping area not far off of the highway on good unpaved roads. It can get pretty crowded at the peak of summer. Free but asking for $10 donation.

name: HNF Twin Trees
description: large campsite in the Hoosier National Forest. Dispersed camping is legal. No Amenities

name: Holder Mine
description: Well-established campground. Almost no mosquitoes. Reservation is required.

name: Rocky Creek Boat Ramp
description: Quiet, wide open space to park for a night or two. No signs prohibiting overnight camping. There's evidence of trucks 'mudding' and doing donuts but it was quiet and peaceful for us. Lots of mosquitos though, even in January. No restrooms or trash cans. Please pack it out!

name: Near Tarpon Springs Florida
description: Big parking lot with a few shops as a flew market and thrift store, further commercial shop are nearby

name: Welcome center Mississippi
description: Big and nice rest area. There are signs no overnight but security told us that overnight is allowed at the truck parking and not at the picknick area. Toilets open from 8 am-5 PM. Must be WiFi but din't work when I was here

name: Welcome center Mississippi
description: Great place to overnight! Clean toilets, WiFi at the information center

name: Louisiana Welcome area nearby Vicksburg
description: Nice rest area near the highway. Signs said "no overnight" but security told us that overnight is Welcome at the backsite from visitorcenter.

name: Walmart Jasper
description: Quiet place near garden center, wifi, open 24/24

name: Rest area
description: Same as on the other side of the road. Nice place!!!

name: Elephant Mountain Wildlife Area and camping
description:
Great place with several camp sites free. 1 mile from paved road. Fire ring , tables, toilet, water not potable

(Coming from the north, drive 1/2 mile passing the picnic area. Once you make the next left, signs to primitive camping will guide your way)

name: Picknick area with nice view
description: Picknick/rest area near the quit road, tables and electra

name: Rest area San Simon
description: Rest area near interstate. Little bit noisy thrue traffic and train. Clean toilets, fending machines

name: White water draw wildlife area
description:
Great place to stay! Near Tombstone. On a lake with a lot of crane-birds. Stay here with a few other campers. Picnic tables and toilet.

Organization operating this site is struggling with funding cuts. Please, consider it when visiting and staying there, regardless if birding or just camping. Donation can be made over web site (info available at the site).

name: Dear pass trail road
description: 1 mile from the paved road, pit toilet at the entrance road near the trails. Nice view over the Red Rock mountains . Fire rings. Fine for small rigs when dry weather

name: Parking lot near chinees restaurant en casino
description: Big and Great place to stay. Police told us that overnight parking in whole town is accepted at any place. Fast WiFi free in casino and good food at the chinees and lot of other restaurants in town

name: Tonopah station
description: At the front of Tonopah station with casino, hotel and food. At the back-site is a RV-parking with full hookup places. In the front and in the front of the supermarket you can stay for free. Inside toilets and laundry and WiFi

name: Rest area between Tonopah and Ely
description: Big rest area with fire pits and toilet. Great view and 20 mile from warm Springs for swimming on cross Hwy  6 and 375

name: Burr Rd Great place
description: Big and nice place for overnight parking and horse driving

name: Long Canyon Overlook
description: Stayed here amongst a handful of sites just east of the Long Canyon Overlook. Good views of the Circle Cliffs and east towards the Waterpocket Fold and Henry Mountains. Access to the site we were in required driving a pretty slanted hill, which might be tricky for a Sprinter Van or similar vehicle. However there are also sites suitable for bigger vehicles. Very little traffic on the Burr Trail Road overnight. No Verizon LTE service.

name: Mant-la Sal NF
description: In the NF is 14 days camping allowed. Several place in the forest. I stood just before the cattle end of paved road for a night in RV

name: Overton Wild Life Management Area
description: Great official spots for max 8 days with fire-rings and picnic tables

name: Callville Bay campground and free day use
description: Nice campground (10$ annual pass) with dump outsite the campground with drinking water. At big parking lot for boats are toilets, laundry (1$) and showers (1,50) you can use when not standing on the campground. Fuel not diesel.

name: Near casino in center Beatty
description: Parking lot besite a casino. At the opposite from the casino is No-overnight parking or by paying 15$. Beside Its free. Use toilet and WiFi from casino. Several restaurants in 500 meter. Night quite.

name: Mojave NP view Point
description: Small viewpoint and good place to stay for a night. No signs No-camping. Was here with 23 ft RV

name: White Spar NF campground
description: Nice and quite small campground in the forest.  $14.00 & $7.00 with federal pass. Entrance parkinglot for hiking and mountain-biking

name: Sand Dunes
description: Everywhere beside this road you find big campspots. Thousands of ohv and 4-Wheelers came over for driving in the sanddunes. Lot of places have pittoilets. Need a permit for overnight 50 dollar for a week. In weekends several hamburgertents on the parkingspots

name: Corvina Beach campground
description: Primitive State Campground next to the Salton Sea off Highway 111. Water faucet near the recycle cans. Cost is $10 a night. The trains and big rigs seem to stop passing by after 10:00 p.m.. This spot is just a peaceful place to stop for a night. Picnic tables and fire pits are available

name: Tortoise Rock Casino - Twentynine Palms
description: Big parking lot of a small casino. You get a free permit from security for max 3 nights staying. Permits are for 24, 48, or 72 hours. Picture ID will be requested. Fast internet, restrooms and restaurant in casino. Very safe due security. Camping only allowed in designated areas in the far north east corner AND far north west corner of the parking lot.

name: Walmart
description: Closed for the night so quiet. WiFi and restrooms inside, several restaurants nearby

name: Parking downtown Palm Springs
description: In Palm Springs are several places, also in downtown, Where you can park free for 24-hours. We stayed on this place with our 23 ft RV with No-problems also not in the night. On thursday evening streetfair in downtown. Lot of restaurants and also casino with all-you-can-eat restaurant and fast internet 5 min walking distance

name: Bobcat meadow campground FREE
description: 58/25 mbps on Visible LTE (Verizon). Free if you have an America The Beautiful pass. So I guess not technically free. There aren't many level spots at this location. A few miles of washboard roads and pot holes on the way up but it's mostly a small paved road closer to the Campground. I wouldn't try bringing anything larger than an extended tall van up here. A couple of clean picnic tables. Lots of fire rings but fires still aren't allowed. I was camping at an unmarked flat spot off of the road coming in and the USFS told me it was illegal and I had to move. They threatened me with a citation. USFS in this area only allows camping in designated areas.

name: Desert and Spring RV Park (DASP RV Park)
description: The campground is not that pretty (large gravel lot) but it is uphill and you have a nice view all around on the mountains.  So nice sunrise and sunset.  At night you can see both town Presidio and Ojinaga, Mexico shining in the dark.  Only one toilet and one shower for all the camping, but clean and warm water if your are lucky.  Full hookups 25$.  Dry camping 10$.  Camp host was very welcoming.  *Don't miss the Don Jose Panaderia in Presidio, a real mexican panaderia*

name: Christoff Landing
description: Nice, free campground in the woods provided by the NW Florida Water Management District. 3 available spots with picnic tables and fire pits. You must visit NWFwater.com and make a reservation (no cost). No restrooms, one trash can.

name: Route 66
description: A remnant of Route 66 starts here and follows US 95 towards Las Vegas. There are signs for photos.

name: Cibola Nat. Wildlife Refuge
description: Across the street from the Cibola National Wildlife headquarters.

name: Ronald W. Caspers wilderness Park
description: Nice campgriund 20 minutes from the beach and up in the trees with many hiking and biking traiks nearby.  great amenities and good cell signal (T-mobile).  $20 a night in a place where free spots are hard to find.

name: Rasor Road wild camping
description:
Another spot to wild camp on this road. You can camp pretty much anywhere. AT&T reception patchy.

Edit: zero T-MOBILE service, 4 bars of Verizon

name: Coin laundry
description: washers and dryers. next to a convience store that has laundry soap.

name: Big Bend Adventure rv park.
description: 120 campsites available, hotel, laundry, hot showers( for 2 dollars), restaurant on site, propane. A note on the propane. They charge a flat fee for the size tank you have. So if your tank is not empty, you pay as if it was.

name: Wyoming welcome center
description:
ADMIN NOTE: a user reported on 2019-10-03: Wyoming rest areas are not for camping. The highway patrol will move you on if it is obvious you are camping. 
---
Welcome center , super clean bathroom free wifi, rest area  portable water hookup , big parking lot to rest off the hwy

name: Uhaul supply
description: Open 7 days a week from 7 am to 7 drive to the propane tank and ring the bell

name: Broke mill rv park
description: Fancy place, priced  (check on line brokeMillrvpark.com) but very clean , good wifi good and hot showers, electricity and water. Still good value for your money,  15$ dollars more that the nearby 3 river rv park but totally worth it, different service. Fitness center, swimming pool .....

name: Borrego Springs
description: It’s camping along a busy road. Camping for big rigs available. Need to ensure sand is hard or you will get stuck.

name: Littlefield, Arizona
description: Quiet and flat campsites with views of the Virgin River and Arizona Mountains. 14 days limit camping. Cellphone service available. Close to the freeway i-15 and the old highway. Tmobile strong and loud!

name: Speedway Express Gas Station
description: Free dumping for Speedway Express (prev Arco) customers but they do ask that you donate $5 to their current cause (eg Muscular Dystrophy Foundation) and if you do so you also get a 20 oz Pepsi product. Potable water available. (I wasn't offered a Pepsi product both times I donated, but I didn't ask either).

name: Informal Campground at begin of Saline Valley Rd
description: Nice pullout before entering Death Valley via Hunter Mountain.

name: Emma Long Metropolitan Park, Austin
description:
Nice campground located at Lake Austin. Approximately 30 minutes drive (about 20 miles) from Autin downtown. 
Prices (January 2018): 
Primitive sites (no electricity) 10 USD per night (plus one-time entrance fee of 5 USD for the vehicle valid for the whole stay, see also xfootnote at the end of description) 
Developed sites at waterfront 25 USD per night (plus one time entrance fee) Developed sites non-water front 20 USD (plus one time entrance fee). 

×footnote: Attention: One-time entrance fee of 5 USD for the vehicle is valid only Monday to Thursday. Friday to Sunday 10 USD! 
Map of the campground please see photos.

name: Badwater - lowest point in NthAm
description: Badwater salt lake is the lowest point in North America 86m below sea level.

name: Tacoma Center YMCA
description:
Place to take free hot showers, you only need an official id. “Monday-Friday: 10-11am, 8-9pm. Saturday: 10-11am, 6-7pm. Sunday: 10-11am.”
Not the cleanest but nice showers. 

https://www.ymcapkc.org/tacoma-center-ymca/programs/community-showers/

name: Arjencía Water
description: Water kiosk on E Fort Lowell Rd. near N Mountain Ave. 15¢ a gallon.

name: Chevron - 2232 Biddle Rd, Medford, OR
description: Propane refill came as a recommendation from a RV dealership. The awesome staff totally knew how to fill up our Eurovan camper.

name: Fas Fuel Oracle and Prince Tucson.
description: Gas station at the Northwest corner of Prince and N Oracle. Propane is advertised as $1.89 per gallon, but this price is only if you get 10 gallons or more. Less than 10 gallons is $2.39 per gallon. Visited on 2/3/18.

name: Alabama Hills
description: Amazing collection of huge rocks. Beautiful and lots of free camping.

name: Stampede RV Park
description: GREAT PLACE, great folks, Country style breakfast AWESOME, 2 walking blocks to town full hookup and $30 plus per night, HOT shower and 50/30amp

name: Harrris Beach Rest Area
description: Nice rest area away from the road. Only 4 hour stay limit. No over night.

name: south bay rv campground
description: palm Beach county campground, dry camping as well as full hookup

name: Gloucester
description:
Small parking near visitor center.  There's larger parking lot but closed at night. 
No many options on this coast.  Quiet night until young drunk people came here  to listen loud music. Saturday night fever.

name: Sweetwater family campground
description:
Closed October 31, reopens April 2021
30$ per night for dry camping. More if you want full hook-up. Dump station available. Water faucets near sites.  Clean bathrooms. Better option than Nickerson SP campground. Very quiet.

name: Nickerson SP campground
description: 35$ per night.  Very expensive for what you get.  Showers very far from the site so you must take your car ! Quiet at night.

name: Mixville Park
description:
No signs for no overnight.  Free off season. Some trafic around us in the evening but we had no problem. 

Please update if you come here and share your own points for all travelers. Thanks.

name: Gate15- area B - BMGR East
description:
BMGR is a military land manage by Fish and wildlife Department. 
The Area B is a Gorgeous Wilderness Public recreation area where backcountry camping is allowed with a free permit.

First: get your permit online (Cabeza Prieta   Headquarters in Ajo (for location see Ioverlander) could provide more info and maps). 
Secondly: drive 10 miles on 85 state road to gate 15, open the lock with the 4 numbers you have been given with your permit and lock it behind you. Call rangers when entering.
Third: choose  your spot and enjoy.

If you are lucky you can watch bighorn sheeps.
No shade. 25 degrees Celsius in February.

name: Candalilla Primitive Camp - Big Bend
description: Primitive camping area in Big Bend National Park. Minutes from the Hot Springs. The road has a few pullouts but is quite rocky so be prepared. Must buy a backcountry permit for $10 per night. Lots of privacy in the wilderness. No services.

name: Rattlesnake Mountain - Big Bend NP
description: Established primitive roadside camping with the park, room for two vehicles and there's a tent area as well. Completely isolated, just you in the desert. :) No amenities. $12 permit for 14 nights.

name: Free showers with park admission!
description: This park is super cool to visit and is only $4 per person. This also includes access to their showers and bathrooms for free!

name: Leaf Verde RV Park
description: Large pull through clean sites, Curtesy and Customer Service are EXCELLENT, clean, restrooms and HOT showers , laundromat, pickle ball court and 1.3 mile walking distance to Walmart and restaurant, and pet friendly and like the fact that they have 100 spaces for in transition over nighters.

name: big lot off perknsville rd.
description: big area off main road next to bill willams benam trails. Alot of trees down but no body here camping.

name: Pilot Knob
description:
This is a boondocking site on BLM land. There are lots of rigs here, but it seems fairly quiet. This spot is very close to the highway, so there is constant highway noise. The site is wide open and fairly flat. There seems to be two main areas that are occupied by boondockers, but the land on the other side of the road from this spot is BLM land also and if you head just a little bit west down the road there is another open area with a homemade fire ring.

The access road is on OSM, but Google maps didn't want to route me here because it doesn't show the road going all the way through, but the map is wrong. Exit I8 at exit 164, make a left onto Sidewinder Rd. Turn right directly before the long term camping area.  You will see a sign for the 14 day camping area 1.6 miles.

Got a good cell signal here for Google Fi.

name: Secluded Campsite, Mojave National Preserve
description: We entered the park travelling North on Kelbaker Rd.  Directly East of the Sweeney Granite Mnts Desert Research Centre (which appears on Google Maps) turn right on a dirt road near the power lines.  The road has no name.  Eventually, the road opens up to a small, fenced in camping area with a fire ring, right under a small mountain range!  The road goes off in many directions, so lots of space to explore.  A great spot for hiking, or just hanging out.  We drove in on a 2WD GMC Savanna camper van with decent clearance, but a car could easily make this trek, just go slow.  Bring water, firewood and stuff for s'mores and enjoy your private vacay in Mojave.

name: Mojave Phone Booth, Mojave National Preserve
description: Eight miles of back country driving finds you in the spot that Google Maps says the Mojave Phone Booth is located.  You know you're close when you see  the telephone poles! We didn't find the phone booth, but we found a nice flat clearing amidst the Joshua Trees where we could boondock for the night.  The road is sand/gravel and there are some deep pot holes and trenches, but we got through in our 2WD Savana, a converted camper van.  A lower clearance vehicle may have trouble, drive slowly.  If you find the phone booth, let us know!

name: white ridge bike trails
description: parking area for mountain bike trails big gravel parking lot and two picnic tables

name: Los Alamos Main Gate Park
description: There is a designated camping area on the east entrance of Los Alamos. It’s basically a parking lot, but it has bathrooms and a dump station. The cost is $10 a night and you can find pick up a permit at the aquatic center in town. A day pass at the center is $3.75 for adults and gets you access to the locker rooms.

name: Street next to public pool
description: Excellent spot for spending a few nights, the street is quiet at night except for the city bus. The pool is free during the winter, the parking is right alongside a biking/walking trail with bathrooms a bit east.

name: AVI KOA RV PARK & CASINO
description: KOA RV section takes AARP & AAA discounts, with receipt you go to hotel front desk for key cards to have entry in to pool area and the gym. Casino allows smoking but the restaurants and movie theater does not, also dry camping is free and available besides the parking garage of the casino/hotel.

name: Alamo Lake rd
description: This is a parking lot not far from AZ93. The road does lead to Alamo Lake after 40 miles, but it is a rough road. Just past the parking lot is AZ State Trust Land on both sides of the road, and is off limits. Lots of ranchers have leases to graze their cattle and don't seem to appreciate folks camping there. There are safer spots closer to Wickenburg and near Congress (Ghost Town Rd). I would not recommend staying on Alamo Rd beyond the parking area, close to 93, unless you want hassled. :(

name: Grassy Banks
description: Campsite is inside of the Big Bend State Park (not to be confused with the National Park next door). We paid our daily entry fee of $3 (non peak season rate, otherwise it’s $5). The campsites have to be picked out in advance and paid for there as well. There is backcountry($5/night) primitive ($8/day) and equestrian ($2 per day/horse). We picked Grassy Banks because it has an outhouse and is on their river. There is a boat launch and I highly recommend site #15. It’s on the river and close to bathroom. There is a picnic table and a fire ring. No running water or WiFi here. That seems to be the same throughout the park (minus the outhouse)

name: Monte Christo NF
description: Small but nice campground in NF. 12$ and 6 with golden age:acces or senior

name: State Trailer outdoor & RV supply
description: As mentioned by iOverlander heroes Slowcarfasthouse this is a RV dump site but it’s also a easy place to sleep. It’s allowed and they have some spots reserved for it. Next to that they have a amazing store. So a great alternative from the casino’s.

name: Bloody Basin Road - Agua Fria BLM
description: One of the many beautiful places to wild camp on Bloody Basin Road. Quiet, amazing views, windy! The road condition is good also. Free, no amenities.

name: Large Pullout
description: One of the many large pullouts on FR 525. Free, no amenities. Arrive early because when we first arrived at 18h on a Wednesday night expecting it to not be very busy, it was hard to find a non-occupied spot on the entire FR 525 road. Ended up having to share with multiple large rigs.

name: Walmart - Mesquite NV
description: There is a not overnight parking sign but the Walmart Management and the city of Mesquite are very flexible and you can park here the overnight. Many truckers, RVs, Vans are staying here and shopping at Walmart. I will recommend you to park where the white lines are because far away from the entrance and we will not disturb the customers with small vehicles and shopping carts. Please do not leave your trash away and please dump it in the proper areas... they have a lots of trash cans but some people just don't care and leave their trash everywhere sometimes. Tip: If you park your rv close to the auto center parking area, you will have the chance to use the Walmart WiFi.

name: Oasis RV Park
description: Great location on Mesquite Blvd. Quiet and very safe RV Park. Full hookup, cable, water, bathrooms with showers, laundry ($1 washer and $1 dryer), pet friendly (not deposit) and friendly staff. We paid $20 plus tax per night and maximum 14 days. They are patrolling several times per day and during the night. It's seeing very safe. Not restrictions about the age of your rv.

name: Tom Wells road
description:
At the intersection above the truck stop.

Can see the city but no road noise and great star gazing.

It requires more clearance to get up further, but there are spits all along this road since its BLM. 

We went further up the road but cell data was unreliable. Good T-Mobile coverage here though.

name: Cabelas,  Fort Mill
description:
Safe place many other RV and also a couple of Trucks. Do not stop here for the dump station, there is no more dump station
Trucks park here overnight. They even have RV parking. A one night stay is fine or a two night as long as you leave for the day.

name: Big Rock
description: There are a few boondocking sites in the area. BLM land. This site has a table and fire ring. Big vehicles will not fit in this particular spot but maybe closer to the main road. Lots of rocks for exploring. There is no cell phone coverage here.

name: Picayune state forest
description: Nice campsite on grass ,peaceful and not much road noise,  tables and some fire rings,  basic $10 plus $ 6.50 reservation fee and taxes totaling $18.81. They want everyone to pay online now.

name: North D&D (Public Use Area #4)
description:
This is a Brazos River Authority owned and managed park.  Designated campsites with nice covered tables, grills, and fire pits.  Nice bathrooms with flushing toilets, sinks, and showers with hot water and electricity.  

The sites vary in size and there is also an open field area for large RV's or camping trailers however no RV hookups or dump stations are available here.  A boat ramp is available as well.  

The camping fees are $10 per campsite and an additional $3 fee per person per day.  Credit cards and cash are accepted but checks are not.  During the off season there is no charge to use the campground from the weekend after Labor Day through the weekend before Memorial Day weekend.  (During the winter you may have the park to yourself.)  During the summer, weekends tend to be very busy.  The holiday weekends during the summer are...just don't even bother coming out.  It's packed.  Alcohol is allowed and the park is regularly patrolled night and day by local police officers and sheriff's deputies.  

Ask about the nearby trails and boat rentals while you're here.

name: Outside Town of Index
description: Forest Service camp site next to a river. Level with tent sites down by the water. It is next to train tracks and a road so it can be a little noisy. Few bars of T-Mobile.

name: Moss Park
description: Nice state park with a lake, $23 for out of staters.  They will tell you a thousand times no alcohol/pets to where it gets annoying.  Electric hook ups, dump station and hot showers.  Lots of wild life, nice place to relax and recharge your batteries.

name: Hopewell Playgrounds
description: Just beside police station.  Arrived late at  night.  No signs for no overnight. Quiet.

name: French Creek SP campground
description: Nice and quiet. Campground under trees. Dumpstation. 24$ per night.

name: Walmart Manassas
description: As all walmart parking lot. Very noisy night.

name: Walmart Front Royal
description: As all Walmart parking lot. Very very noisy night.

name: Big Meadows Campground - Shenandoah NP
description: Campground in the middle of Shenandoah NP with all facilities.  Dump station. 30 $ per night. Nice and quiet. Deer in the campground.

name: Oronoco free campground
description:
NOTE: Realized the morning after my stay (9.25.2020) as I was heading out that this campground is technically closed until March!! There is construction happening on part of the property but the front gate was open and I somehow missed the signs saying it was closed when I drove in. I wasn’t the only person staying there either! Most spots were filled. It rained all night and my spot was very muddy, so I mostly stayed in my car and headed out first thing. Decent place to park overnight, if only for its proximity to 60 and relative calm. I was concerned about the amount of trash, but if it’s technically closed, I’d imagine it’s not being maintained regularly. 

Quiet rustic campground in Washington and Jefferson NF. No amenities. Only pit toilets and fire rings.

name: Walnut Flat free campground
description:
Free campground under trees. No amenities. Only pit toilets. Very quiet because at the end of long dirt road, 4,5 km. No problems with my RV 22 ft long.

Please update if you come here and share your own points for all travelers. Thanks

name: Elkmont campground - Great Smoky Mountains NP
description:
Nice campground under trees but very busy on week-ends and no amenities. No water and no dumpstation so very expensive for what you get $25 per night.
Very quiet when all campers turn off their generator.
Dumpstation with potable water available at Sugarlands visitor center until the end of the first november week-end.

Please update if you come here and share your own points for all travelers. Thanks

name: Dreher Island State Park
description:
Very very nice and quiet campground. Full hook-up. Clean bathrooms. Wi-Fi at the office. 28$ per night.
You can see many birds like great blue Heron from your campsite. It's wonderful.

Please update if you come here and share your own points for all travelers. Thanks

name: JB Barker Public Boat Landing
description:
This place has three names depending on where you look: Hope Ferry Boat Ramp, Lake Murray Boat Ramp, or the JB Barker Public Boat Landing.

All are the same - a large parking lot at the end of a short dirt road. Trash receptacles, but no other amenities. Cell coverage is acceptable. Alarm for rising water levels.

Please update if you come here and share your own points for all travelers. Thank you!

name: Columbia boat ramp
description:
Very large parking lot of a boat ramp on Congaree river. Very quiet. A trail along the river.
Police came but said nothing.
We've seen other options along old state road.

Please update if you come here and share your own points for all travelers. Thanks

name: Lake Marion boat ramp hwy 260
description:
Very large parking lot. Pretty quiet. No amenities.

Please update if you come here and share your own points for all travelers. Thanks

name: Big pine fishing lodge - campground
description:
Campground with all amenities. Full hook-up or rustic campsite. Very clean bathrooms. Nice swimming pool.
Unfortunately, destroyed by Irma hurricane in September 2017. They are reparing so dirt campsite for the moment. Paid 44$ per night for 2 adults and 2 kids on a rustic campsite. So much mosquitoes. Very noisy, near main road.

Please update if you come here and share your own points for all travelers. Thanks

name: Miami North Beach P107
description:
Small parking lot ( parking number 107) head in with 5 places for long car. No problem with my RV 22 ft. RV to 25 ft will fit at this place. 5 minutes walk to North Beach and to the bus stop for Miami Downtown.
Quiet night for such a site in town.
Free from 6 pm to 8 am. $1.35 per hour after that. Maximum 6 hours.

Please update if you come here and share your own points for all travelers. Thanks

name: king sooper
description: water refill 39 cents a gallon, inside @ entrance

name: Fortuna Pond, BLM
description:
Nice 14 day camping area around the pond. Close to town. Has trash dumpster and fishing piers.
There is a small lake with a bunch of places to camp around it. There were some spots in the shade and others that were more open. The spots in the shade were under the trees and the open ones were closer to the water. There were a lot of people there and the portable toilets were full to the brim. The spot we had was beautiful and large enough for several campers.

name: dirt lot
description: This is a large dirt lot just north (300 yards) of the 8 west freeway off the Algodones exit on the right side of the road going north. Trains run all night long across the roadway. No facilities.

name: Giant Rock
description: Famous boulder, Giant Rock, supposedly the largest free-standing boulder on the planet. More than a few spots available to camp at (use ones with existing fire rings please) with expansive views of the valley floor back towards Landers. Backed by a mountain of piled boulders the area has some protection from desert winds. Pretty quiet during weeknights, a bit less quiet on weekends. Road into the area is dirt/sand (not too deep) but with long stretches of rolling terrain close together so you have to go slow or you WILL break things. Probably best for short(er) wheelbase vehicles. We got a pretty good 4G signal on AT&T here. I had good Verizon LTE - go slow avoid if raining!

name: Tumble In RV Park
description:
Small RV park just outside of Marfa.  It is a basic park with showers, bathrooms and laundry. It is located between the railroad tracks and highway so it is a bit noisy. There are 16 sites, plus a small dry camping/tent area.   

Prices as of Jan 2020 were:

$32 full hook up
$27 Electricity and water (two 30' sites)
Dry camping/tents: $15 for one person or $25 for two. (This area can accommodate a van or truck camper but not anything large.)

You can make reservations in advance (up to the day before you plan to stay) on their website. They don't take same day reservations and all open sites are first come.

The manager is very nice and all of the small sites were taken when we arrived but he gave us one of the larger pull through sites for the same price.

name: Front of Ramada and Motel 6
description: Busy street, free to park and free WiFi, stayed at two different times.

name: Fort De Soto Park
description:
Nice large park to hang out at during the day, multiple beaches, dog park, RV campground, boating, cycling, fishing.
$5 entrance fee/day pass, $1.75 for bridge tolls.
RV dump station, pay by donation.
Cold showers in bathrooms at the east beach and outside at other locations.
Restaurant, picnic areas, trash bins, and shops on site.

name: fantasy springs casino truck and rv lot
description: very large dirt lot across from casino, free camping, no limit,  no services

name: Big Bend Motor Inn
description:
Gas station and propane (tank is close to the horse stables).

Available connections not known, but a VW vanagon with a 3 gallon propane tank was filled it with no problem.

name: Dragoon mountains
description:
West side of the mountain range offers lots of little pull outs from the forest service road. 30-45 mins from Tombstone.
Great area. Worth the slow drive down the gravel road. I made it pretty easily in my minivan - I stayed here 5 days. Good AT&T and Verizon. Definitely need to be ok with possibly some cowpies in your camp but they don't smell. Possibly some cowbells at night but I didn't have that.

name: Mt Rainier View #3
description: Muddy two track not maintained. There is a spring about 2/10 of a mile up the trail. Gorgeous view that can't be beat.

name: Kings Bottom
description:
A nice, established campground about 20 minutes from downtown Moab.

The campground is along the road, but it's not as busy/loud as you'd expect.  

The campground is very busy, as it's so close to Moab.  

Nice toilets.  No water or hook ups.  Easy access to the river bank.  

Easily parked our full size truck and camper.  The spots are wide with plenty of room and a picnic table.

name: Willow Flat, Canyonlands National Park, Utah
description: Nice campground in the park. Free in winter months. Sites have shelters, Fire Rings & tables & pit toilets. No water available

name: Lake Mead BLM
description:
BLM of dirt road, only couple km from road through Lake Mead Recreation Area but feels remote. Road in recommends 4x4 but was ok when we drove in. Fire Rings. We saw wild horses come through early in morning.
 - Bitter Spring Road, Lake Mead Nevada

name: Dirt turnaround behind Super 8
description: Large turn around area near I-10, close to the end of Darby Ave. Road noise is moderate and the lights from near by businesses are visible.

name: Bonita Canyon Campground (Chiricahua NM)
description:
26 site campground open year round.
$12.00 per night
Each site has a table; there are grills and trash/recycling bins.
It is quiet (no road noise, trains, or aeroplanes).

name: Basalt - US-6
description: Highway pull out. Good enough for a night or rest. Far enough from the road not to be a distraction. Flat open space. Extremely dark and can see billions or stars.

name: Shasta Lake #2
description: Day use area. Okay for a night stay. Campgrounds were closed for the season, which I thought was odd. There are some run-down camp sites near the day use area that I didn’t notice until morning. They were gated off too.

name: Los padres nf Vista Point
description: Nice and clean Vista Point parking. No No-overnight sign at all. Quiet at night

name: NF-110
description: couple of places along the road. Some are large enough to accommodate large groups and some have water source nearby. There are trailheads with long drop toilets along the road.

name: Mojave Bus Campsite
description:
We didn't stay the night here, but we did drive through and visit.  It is a very large cul-de-sac with a large tree in the center.  

Large enough for large groups of truck/trailers to park and maneuver.  There is some private property to the south some distance.

name: Willow Lake Rv Park
description:
hot clean showers without timelimit 5$ closed between 12 and 2pm 
we didn't camp came just fir the shower

name: Davis Creek Regional Park
description: Really nice county campground up in the forest with year round camping, water, bathrooms, and coin showers. Sites include picnic table, fire pit, bear box. Moderate road noise from 395. Decent cell coverage (att).

name: Big Tesuque Campground
description: Free established campground. Stay up to 14 days. Open in winter but gets cold up here (likely to have snow)! Toilets and picnic tables.

name: Lake Panasoffkee
description:
Free camping!  

Make reservations online at 

http://www.swfwmd.state.fl.us/recreation/camping.php

I got a response in less than an hour after submitting an application and got approved for the same day.


Ringed fire pits, picnic benches, flat camp sites in a relaxing environment.  There are a few miles of nice hiking trails as well.

name: Yellowstone truck stop, exit #330
description: We pulled in late at night during snow storm. There was lots of other cars, campers and trucks parked here. Nobody bothered us at night or morning. There is lots of traffic here so it's not very quiet, but good emergency spot to spend the night.

name: free Wifi at Cannon Beach Visitor Center
description: free good wifi at Cannon Beach Visitor Center, parking for RV nearby

name: Lone Pine - Alabama Hills - Movie Road Eastern Sierras
description: 2 level truck spots, view of whites and sierras. Great spot, secluded. Foot trails around

name: Rolling Hills Casino/Chevron
description: A big parking lot for semis and RVs behind the Chevron. Trucks running all night, otherwise an ok spot for an overnight. There is a pay RV campground associated with the casino, however we did not check it out. We stayed in our RTT and had no problems.

name: Linville Gorge Area - Last Camp Site
description: Nice open site with room for 3-4 Vehicles. Established fire pit with plenty of flat space for tents.

name: Best View Site
description: Best view of Table Rock and Lake James. Can not drive vehicle directly to site.

name: Little White Dog
description: Great camp ground with pit toilets. $12 a night with deposit box (really a pole) Very friendly ranger will come check in with you and make sure you paid. He was very kind and has been doing it for a very long rime. need any info on the area ask him. No running water. Right on the river with many campsites. can be popular in the summer. many other campgrounds along this river.

name: Chevron
description: Propane fill station. Nice people, convenient location.

name: Walmart
description: Walmart Parking lot. Home and Pharmacy back corner is best. Its in a strip mall so market side parking is along a shared lot.

name: Walmart refill station
description: 39cents a gallon. Refill station is located in the front by the customer service counter inside the store

name: Hawk Canyon
description: Awesome canyon in Anza Borrego state park. Not far from the slot canyon. Well marked roads, and camping areas. No fires (unless you can keep it up off the ground). No cell reception, but quiet and down out of the wind! Leave No Trace!

name: Governor’s Landing
description: Small campground with 14 sites. Potable water, vault toilets, no hook ups.  Right off highway 90. $10 a night or $5 with federal parks access pass. Access to the reservoir from the campground. Shade structures, picnic benches and bbq pits at each site. Gravel lots.

name: Chief Mountain South Trailhead Free Camp
description: Free spots with bbq and shadow places. All gravel. Easy access for all rigs. 0.3 mile from the main road.

name: Pismo Beach Golf Course ( water refill+dump station)
description: Water refill station in dump station area. There are two faucets one on each side of parking lot.

name: Park and restrooms
description: Nice small park with restrooms, water and swimming pool in the summer. No overnight but there is one nice place further on the hwy near Ragged Point

name: Henderson beach state Park
description: Florida State Park, $30 gets hookups, large clean sites, easy boardwalk to the beach

name: Open Street parking lot next to Rivera park
description: Good and quiet place for one night sleep. There are fairly clean bathrooms in the park open till 9pm.

name: Quiet place next to the park
description:
Quiet place for a night right next to the park. Bathrooms available in the park. Toilets don’t have doors though? :/ 
I said we went to the gas station - but they don’t have Bathrooms. Went to Walmart.

name: parcometer parking for oversized
description: Parking on the street with parcometer (3,50$/hr) ONLY for oversized 24 to 40 Ft. 5 hr. limit no overnight but good to visit Clearwater beach by foot.

name: Cajun Propane
description: Place to fill propane! 17$ for 20 pounds bottle

name: Russell Harber Landing Park parking
description: Parking of the park. You can reserve a picnic table (with electricity) for a small fee (call 983-5466). No sign of no overnight parking. Spent 1 night. Really calm, by the river.

name: 17 mile campground
description: Free campsite (hunt camp) in the Osciola National forest.  Up to 14 days max stay. Very calm, some sites, ok RV. Trash cans. Some mosquitoes.  Road has potholes

name: Baseball field parking Highlands
description: Zachary Park. Large gravel parking lot, next to the Baseball field. During winter very calm!!! Nobody came. Toilets were closed. Village of Highlands in the mountains, lot of trails around here, falls, etc. Accessible via Aunt Dora street.

name: Treebones
description:
More than a few nice turnout spots on this graded dirt road. Go further up and spot pictured has a great view of the ocean and valley below. Waves crashing and sounds of seals travel up the valley. There are several tent sites near this spot in the trees. 

Go up Willow Creek Road (23S01) off hwy 1. Look for the Treebones Yurt Resort and turn left up the dirt road with "impassable in wet weather" sign.

name: Big Bend NP - Robbers Roost
description:
Primitive Campsite in the Big Bend National Park. In middle of the prairie with nice view to the mountains (enclosed photos). Very quiet and lonesome!
In our opinion 4x4 vehicle recommended (at least high clearance necessary) 
Prices 2019 (April) 
Park Entrance: 30 USD (valid for 7 days, or annual entrance pass for 80 USD)
Primitive Campsites: 12 USD valid for 14 nights. 
We got a map at the entrance and had to check in at the visitor center Panther Junction. There we had to reserve the spots for the whole stay! But was possible to change the reservations during the time. We have been here with a 4x4 Sprinter. Even though it worked, it was quite challenging for the van! We would not recommend this dirt road for a Sprinter or comparable van.

name: Big Bend NP - Twisted Shoe
description:
Primitive Campsite at the Big Bend National Park. In middle of the prairie with great view to the mountains and a great overlook (see photos).
In our opinion 4x4 with high clearance necessary (we hiked to this spot, we would not like to challenge our 4x4 Sprinter that much)
Prices 2018 (Feb):
Park Entrance: 25 USD (valid for 7 days, or annual entrance pass for 50 USD).
Primitive Campsites: 12 USD valid for 14 nights.
We got a map at the entrance of the park and had to check-in at the visitor center at Panther Junction. There we had to reserve the spots for the whole stay. But was possible to change the reservation during the time (only in the visitor centers).

name: Big Bend NP - Government Springs
description:
Primitive Campsite in the Big Bend National Park.
Prices (exactly the same as La Clocha and Robers Roost also in iOverlander).
Spot is a little bit busy. Some cars passing by during the day, the evening and sometimes also during the night. Gravel road, but no 4x4 and no high clearance necessary.

name: Big Bend - Ocotillo 1
description:
Primitive Campsite. Beautiful view to the dessert and Mountains. Near Santa Elena Canyon. 
Prices exactly the same like La Clocha (also in iOverlander)

name: McCoy Mobile Home/RV Park
description: This is a small RV Park near Winterhaven that is in a rural, quiet area. Mostly mobile homes and snowbirds camped here for the winter, but has some spots for travelers. Full hookups, laundry, shower, good internet, and a swimming pool & spa. This is a great place to catch up on chores before/after traveling in Mexico. Friendly people. We paid $22/ night for 2 nights.

name: 1st Travel Inn
description: pride in ownership in this older hotel. my room was spotless and updated. $52us for a single. nicest room I've ever had at this price.

name: Burrito Del Sol
description: Really good Baja style tacos. Possibly best in Florida. Only street parking available. Dogs welcome for outside seating.

name: Gravel road spot
description: Little gravel spot off Highway 41 in Big Cypress NP, near a native village. It's the entrance to a private property but before the gate there is some space. Park on the side to leave the property owner some space to park, too. Highway noise, but quiet at night. Might want to try to stay out of sight from highway. Good spot. Not for huge vehicles. Tents fine! Free, level.

name: Locals hangout
description:
Level gravel/grass lot on a canal, among the fields out of town. Very quiet, breezy, no shade. Possibly not 100% legal, but no signs. Stayed out of sight from highway. Water authority car drove by, didn't bother. 
Some trash and gun shells but other than that it's a pretty nice place. I'd probably avoid staying here when the surrounding fields are being sprayed with pesticides. 
Nice for tents or with pets if you stay closer to the road with less trash.  
Huge rigs might catch someone's eye as you'll have problems hiding and may have problems to turn. 
Free.

name: Blackwater River primitive camp
description:
A few sites scattered near a boat ramp, note this is outside of the state park, follow the signs for the boatramp and you will find it, beautiful river and white sandy beach

On the edge of att and Verizon coverage, was able to pull down decent internet though

name: Lk. Mead National Rec
description:
Just off the Hwy. Far enough away to not be seen. Sign a little way in says 4x4 recommended. Not really necessary tho. 
Can see the glow of LV over the mountains. 
Next time I would go further in. 

Excellent Verizon cell service.

name: Chickasaw Cultural Center
description: An amazing cultural center to learn about the  Chickasaw Native Americans. They have a small village you can walk through as well as a nice museum with many movies and reenactments daily.

name: motorcycle museum
description: A fantastic collection of antique motorcycles. Absolutely free of charge to enter the museum. I have old Henderson, Indian, Husqvarna, and many more I've never heard of! Amazing place to come spend a few hours!

name: Walmart - Crestview
description: quiet parking, Walmart close at 10. lot RVs at overnight. McDonald’s is 24 hours

name: White Rock
description: BLM land, BLM signs going in.  Two large rock domes.  Zero facilities, good chance you'd be alone.  Road in probably good for a passenger car.  Google Earth says turnoff from Hwy 196 is at N40 19'54.61" W112 44' 40.57" (I don't use a GPS).

name: Zuni Village RV Park
description:
Clean park. Annoying wifi requiring frequent logging in. Great laundry, washrooms, hot showers. Located in Kingman AZ a short drive north of interstate. 

Wifi: zunirvguest
Z864R82OO3

name: The Scenic Road RV Park
description: Private park in Quartzite, AZ. Clean park. On Hwy 95. Small, single washroom/shower. Has laundry and well equipped dog wash with tub and blower. Water was undrinkable. Wifi extremely limited with only one device at a time per site. Paid $17 with PA

name: Otter point
description: Very beautiful point Very big view on the sea and the rocks

name: Showers - Ocotillo Wells RVSA
description:
Showers $.50/2 min
Really hot water. Clean. 
Bring your quarters because change machine doesn't work.

name: Drinking Water station
description: drinking water filling 7/24. 25 cents per gallon.

name: Marina boat & RV
description: We managed to fill our Argentinean bottle without issues.

name: Jerry Johnson Campground
description: Simple campground near the Lochsa River.  Kid friendly, located in Idaho.

name: San Antonio Riverine Park
description:
Nice BLM campground next to San Antonio NM. From San Antonio town go east toward rail road crossing. Turn left on dirt road after a second canal which is just down the road after the railroad crossing. This is a large low flow canal. There is a sign at the road about fire dangers.  

The dirt road immediately splits. Stay on higher road 1 block and take first right into camp area. There are tables and fire rings but no other facilities. 
Dirt road decently maintained, easy access when dry. Could get muddy and deep with rain. 

Small amount of traffic noise. Close to town and good access to Bosque Del Apache wildlife refuge which is well worth a visit, and yummy green chili cheeseburgers in San Antonio 

Good place for the night. Free. Good cell reception. Overgrown and messy looking but it was fine. No sketchy characters. Other campers were quiet. No amenities. Pack out your waste.

name: Indian Bread Rocks
description: BLM lands with picnic area and pit toilet. 3 miles up a good gravel road. Tucked up to hillside with very cool rock formations. Very pleasant campsite.

name: Chiriquahua
description: A few miles from Portal on the creek, several spots off the road before you get to the summit. Lovely, quiet in early March. Lots of trail hiking and beautiful rock cliffs along the way. Better than the formal campgrounds in the area.

name: Burns Campsite
description:
Nice and quiet campsite with hook-up in the middle of bayou on the mexico gulf coast. 

Nice place for fishing or for just relaxing and have good time. There's a boat ramp too. 

Free wifi and hook-up for sewer at site.

14$/ night

name: Selah Creek Rest Area
description: Rest area with clean bathrooms. Wait with the rattlesnakes. Nice views.

name: Red Rock park campground
description:
A very nice campground !
Near the city in the park
Have power ,water ,shower...
Only 25 dollar or $13 without electricity
Dump point on site

name: Utah welcome center
description: Rest area 24/7, clean heated bathrooms, pay phone, picnic area, good visitor information center open until 5pm, free coffee! ask for wifi password. Off Hwy 40 westbound

name: Coachella Vista Point
description: A little chunk of BLM land sitting just above the vista pull out.  Surrounded by highway on all side but got quiet at night.  great views of the city below and mountains around.  Nice star gazing as well.  Great 4G service on T-mobile. LTE with Google FI.

name: BLM LTVA campground and rest area
description: BLM campground with Fee area. At the foot of sand dunes. Huge.

name: Pico de Piedra Beach
description:
Nice and Beautiful west coast beach , Great Restaurants, people are very Polite  and pleasant, Town are 2-3 miles away .
Deserves a visit !!!!

name: Barnhouse Campground (free)
description: Ochoco National Forest - Off highway 26 about 7 minutes up a paved road (Buck Point Rd / NF-12) with a few switchbacks, this great free campground has beautiful trees, nice sites and some views. The back of the campground has a trailhead. Quiet and clean. The Forest Service rangers frequent the site and are very nice and informative.

name: womack creek campground
description: small, wooded campground,  right on a boat ramp. electric and tent walk in sites. iron ranger for payment or reserve america.  Lots of primitive and light rv camping in this area.

name: Under the Bridge
description:
Several parking spaces (for cars) under/next to bridge across the Intracoastal Waterway. Next to marina. Level, lit and, surprisingly, pretty quiet at night.

Other campers told me not to park too close to the marina entrance. Big rigs would fit if parked across several parking spots.
Breezy, shade in the morning. 
Free.

name: Austin Automotive
description: The go to for Toyota and all other imports and trucks.

name: Bayou Chicot
description: Wonderful camp spot with clean bathroom hot shower and free laundry in the chicot state park picnic tables dump station , full hookups free Wifi ! It’s normally 20$ but we arrive after 6 pm and no one was there to collect money so we paid nothing! North campground don’t know about the south one !

name: Bermuda Flat
description:
Campground in lake Roosevelt, 8$  [now $12] per night and you need to pay the fees at the visitor center [or Cholla next door] ~6 miles from the site. Very nice campsite with no amenities expect toilets [toilets may not be available] but you can shower at the campground next door « cholla campground » for free [not anymore, showers at Cholla say they're for Cholla campers only]. No spot specific to park so it allows you to be anywhere you want in the campsite with immediate proximity of the lake and great views! We stayed there 2 nights with our truck camper no trouble expect for the nocturne visit of a raccoon and some mosquitos ! 

[Updates made 2021. Decent Verizon, strong ATT.]

name: The Home Depot in San Diego
description: We stayed one night at the Home Depot in San Diego with no problems.

name: Monument Lake Campground
description:
Nice campground at the lake. With luck you can see alligators swimming in the lake. We had a wonderful sunset. Unfortunately, a lot of mosquitoes after sunset.
Fireplaces and camping table on each place.
Toilets available, but no showers.
USD 28.-/night for a van and two people.

name: Walmart in Perry
description:
24h opening hours. Some other RV‘s were there. Not very quiet, but ok for one night.
There is a Subway in the store and some fast food restaurants nearby (like Domino‘s Pizza, Taco Bell, KFC, Mcdonalds...)

name: Jones hole hatchery
description: Wild camp about 2km from hatchery. Turn off just before no hunting sign. Couple fire rings, place for tents and cars. Deep ruts on the way in. You can't see this spot from the road. We spend here one night in the winter.

name: Visalia/Sequoia KOA
description: This is a well run KOA (Campgrounds of America) just a few minutes off 99. Hot showers, laundry facilities and very organized and clean. Big rigs are separated from the tents and they also have a pool. They sell propane and have holding tank dumps. Nice to be on grass after a month of sand. This is a rather expensive place to stop but if you are heading north through California and are not a Walmart type then this is your place.

name: Premier parking lot - downtown Nashville
description:
There is a fair amount of free street parking around this area but we opted to park up our camper in this automated paylot for $10/24 hours

Walking distance to downtown and Germantown bars/restaurants 

We stayed here for 5 days and no one bothered us.

Parking attendant only came by once

There are many other paylots in this area, we liked this one because it was flat and fairly empty

I also found out that you can park across the river near the football stadium, overnight, as long as it is not a game day 

Look for the pedestrian foot bridge from the stadium over to downtown, that is where I saw the free stadium parking

name: Lynchburg municipal campground
description:
Kind of a run down spot but good enough for a night, water and power hookups, and clean bathrooms. No shower

Supposed to pay $20 at the courthouse or "mail it in"

No one else was here or checking anything for the day/night

Walking distance to jack daniels distillery

name: Nicks landing
description: very isolated site, no power no electricity, right on a small river. big site.Very nice. at least 20 minute drive from nearest fire road.

name: tates hell, new river #4
description: very isolated. right on the river. has a higher level that any camper can get to, and a lower level on the water that a 4x4 can get to.  large site, heavily wooded around. call florida state forest for reservation.

name: deserted area above industrial park
description: this is a open space with one path to a water tower from an industrial park. overlooks the city and hills. one dog walker in the morning who didn't bother us. the entrance is at the end of a dead end and is grassy/dirt and we had no problem in our car.

name: Visitor center
description: Water and bathroom 24/h at visitor center. Water fill up spigot in parking lot and bathrooms connected to visitor center

name: Mystic Springs
description:
Free camping at Mystic Springs. Needs to be reserved ahead of time at sunrisereservations.com but can be done one day away unlike most camping in Florida. 

6 spots with fire pits, tables and a toilet. Stayed here two nights and it was quiet.

name: Lincoln Hardware
description:
Very complete hardware store!
We needed to do some work in our van and we found everything here.

name: Parking place near downtown
description: $20 for overnight parking til 07 am right next to Beal st , big rigs cannot fit tough :/ no facility just an open air parking

name: flat area at the side of the road
description: nice area beside the road not a lot of cars passing. spend one night without any problems

name: Queen Mine RV park
description: Nice quiet place. Walk to town. $35/ night with full hookups. Call (520)432-5006

name: Lizard Road
description: Another beautiful spot. Thanks for Public Lands in America! May it always be so. A train in the distance. Coyotes yipping. No trash!!! Great Tmobile.

name: Flamingo campground
description:
Quiet campground for tents and RV. 
Close to the Mexico’s golf in Everglades’s Park. 
25 $ / night 
Solar shower (not hot today but it rained) 
Dump station

name: Jacksonville FL Customs
description:
Shipping Zarate Arg. To Jacksonville FL USA
Ford Truck with Pop-Up Camper via RORO. 
 
(Too tall to fit into container by 4".)

ARGENTINA PROCEDURES:
We contacted Wave Logistics (Montevideo) (iOverlander listing) via email while we were in Chile and indicated we were interested in shipping to USA. 

After a few days we finally heard back from Martin Flores (operaciones@capri-arg.com.ar) (011 5031 4015) who told us about a KLine ship going to Jacksonville in five days. Could we get to Zarate Arg. In that time?

We could and we did. 

But in the meantime we asked via email where exactly to drop off the truck, how much, what documents were necessary and what were the procedures exactly. 

Martin said we would need to get the following to get the process going: (which we emailed to him):
 1. Owner's passport copy including page with Arg. Entrance. (Husband). 
 2. Vehicle Title copy (luckily our Title named and Owner name are the same.)
 3. Make, Model, year, height, width and length dimensions and weight details. 
 4. Argentina TIP paper. 

Also he said we would need the originals at the Port.

And after numerous requests via email, he finally gave us a quote of:
A. Argentina fees $500 (cash at Port in Arg. Pesos)($9 per cubic foot)
B. KLine shipping fee $2800
C. USA port fees $500

Martin told us to go directly to Port Security (correct gps coordinates in iOverlander) and he would send us the Bill of Lading. And that we should contact Ignacio Luna at the Port upon arrival. 

We arrived at Port at 8 am on Friday, Jan. 19th and parked in the small parking lot to the right of the Security gate, but Ignacio didn't arrive until 9 am and Security didn't have the Bill of Lading (BOL). Finally after Ignacio arrived and Security had the BOL, they had a security guard drive us and another gentlemen shipping his hard-sided truck camper to the Payment Office. 

There, after the BOL was sent electronically, we both paid $583 even though quite clearly his vehicle was bigger, longer and heavier. 

We walked back to Security Office, showed payment receipt to Security Office Clerk and received stamped receipt, unloaded all passengers and luggage that wasn't being shipped in truck, and the Owners were directed to drive through security dates and directed to a section further in the Port. We had taken everything loose out of truck cab and put into camper before we drove to the port. Only had a large locked storage bin in truck cab. 

And turned over the truck key only. No inspections of any sort and they returned to the Security Gate where Security called two taxis to take us to the Buenos Aires (BA) bus terminal. 

Process took approx. 2
1&1/2 hours after BOL arrived. 

First needed to buy a transportation card called a Sube and put enough fare on it to pay for the bus ride into BA. 

The next day Martin emailed us the BOL and told us to check http://apps.klineglobalroro.com/tracking/ for estimated arrival date in Jacksonville using the BOL#. 

He also later informed us when the ship actually left Zarate on Jan. 24th. 
(We also found vesselfinder.com to be handy tracking the vessel by name.)

US PROCEDURES:
We flew into Miami and traveled around FL ( and Cuba) while waiting for ship's arrival.

Finally on Feb. 27th, we contacted KLine, Jim Randolph, RICBCARCUS@us.kline.com, on when, where, how to pay and procedures to get truck out of the Port. 

He gave us a contact Lisa Cotman, Lisa.Cotman@us.kline.com. 
K” Line America, Inc.
Ro/Ro Services
PCC IMPORT CUSTOMER SERVICE
Phone: ‪866-233-6875‬ OPT 3
EMAIL: ricbcarimp@us.kline.com

After a number of emails, she sent a "Delivery Order template" to complete and instructions on how to make payment. ONLY via wire. 

We wired the funds of $3114 on Monday 5th and sent email same day to KLine advising them of wire details.

Three days before Estimated Time Arrival (ETA), we received an "Arrival Notice and Invoice" with more info via email. 

Then I called KLine again on Friday 9th (ETA) to find out if ship was in Port (although VesselFinder.com said it hadn't arrived yet.) 

I had to send the wire info email again to Lisa since wire hadn't posted. 

We had to make several calls to Customs since KLine didn't lift the Hold notice.  We called Customs on Friday 9th and they advised us to call again on Monday 12th which we did. 

Finally we showed up at US Customs 
(10426 Alta Dr.) 
(Operational Hours: 
8:00 AM-5:00 PM (Eastern) Weekdays (Monday-Friday)
Phone: 
(904) 714-3100, ext. 2)

at 9am and within 10 minutes they stamped the Arrival Notice. They required 
1. BOL, 
2. Delivery notice from KLine, 
3. Vehicle Title
4. ID for consignee. Passport was acceptable. 

KLine said to call again (866-233-6875, ext. 3) after Customs cleared which we did but was told the wire still hadn't posted. Sent wire info again via email.
