Was advised by Accounting they didn't have info and wanted to know what date wire was sent. Sent another email with that info. 

CAUTION: Keep contacting KLine to ensure they post your payment because nothing gets done without it. 

After 20 minutes received word from Accounting that payment had posted and to contact the terminal. 

Called the terminal and after approx. 10 minute hold, said they had the paperwork and to come on over. (904-757-3357).

(BLOUNT ISLAND TERMINAL 
8998 BLOUNT ISLAND BLVD. BLDG 2 JACKSONVILLE, FL 32226

Proceed on Blount Island Blvd to red brick building on right where they will give you directions on which gate lane to get into. 
Far right lane #2, Escort lane. 
At the toll booth, they will check documents, want to see both drivers' licenses and make arrangements for Escort Service (which cost $125 payable with credit card). 

No TWIC card necessary and Escort arranged promptly at Gate. Gate process took approx. 10 minutes. 

Escort led the way in their vehicle with us following directly to storage Lot and directed us to Terminal staff building. 

Staff took papers, made copies and directed us to small side Lot where truck/camper was. Took 10 minutes. (But they take lunch break from 11:45 to 12:45.)

Escort led the way back to main gate and we were on our way. 


No damage to truck. Battery turned over right away. Bag containing shoes inadvertently left in truck cab arrived intact. No inspection at all. Camper not broken into.

name: Cocopah casino
description: Large paved parking area with designated sites by the casino. 10 USD per day or 50 per week

name: Red bird boat ramp
description: It's a boat ramp parking lot, on Cumberland river, quiet. No services, good for an overnight stop

name: Street parking
description: Very quiet area. Good for a couple of nights. Nobody bothered us.

name: Homestake Pass Trailhead
description: Camping permitted in the National Forest.  The trailhead parking lot has stationery ramps for dirt bikes and 4 wheelers.  It is located at Exit 233 off I-90 east of Butte, MT.  There are pit toilets. Homestake Lake with picnic tables and it's own parking lot, is located a short walk from the Trailhead.  Miles and miles of OHV trails and roads lead up into the mountains and to Delmoe Lake and surrounding area.  There are a lot of campsites in those areas also with fire rings.  Pipestone Trailhead is another spot off I-90, 8 miles or so east of here, also with camping.  The back country trails connect all of these sites.

name: Holtville hotsprings
description:
We camped on the road next to the hot springs without any issues. 
Wake up early and take a dip.

name: We‘ll wash Laundry
description: Self-Service Laundry. You can also let wash your clothes.

name: Crozier Ranch - Route 66
description: Lots of roomy campsites; use US Public Lands or similar app to confirm you are on BLM and not private land. Very clean. So little trash I'll be able to carry the litter out of my big campsite in one hand. Well done, previous campers. 1-2 bars of Verizon, enough for email and similar. 0 bars of T-mobile.

name: Crab Cooker Hot Spring
description: Parking for about 4 cars max. Good sized tub that stays nice and hot in 10degree F nights. Spent the night here, wind can be bad sometimes. High clearance vehicle advised but 4x4 not necessary. Cheers!

name: Close to Zion off Hwy 9
description: Up the old highway and turn left into big open area with lots of room. Got trailer in no problem. On busy nights you won’t be alone.  5 stars, what you hope every car camping spot would be. 1-2 bars Verizon LTE. some AT&T.

name: Cape perpetua
description:
Nice view of the sea, Thor’s Well, and Cook’s Chasm. 
Access to Captain Cook Trail.
Thor’s Well pullout area is level and you can parallel park or straight in park. Great view from parking and the trail here does a .4 mile loop with another larger trail system connecting to it. Verizon LTE 2-3 bars.

There is no “no overnight parking” sign.

name: Casa Roland
description: Very nice hotel, $80 usd a night. Free Pool access and free WiFi. No need for hotel reservations to access pool. Food is American style, beer is plentiful. Wouldn’t recommend camping at this location. But it’s a very nice place to spend a day.

name: Off road 525
description:
One of the many Boondocking spot to be found on this road. But we were there on a Thursday night and all the designed spots were taken so we went further down the road and found one empty and quiet ! 
Very beautiful location, great view over the mountain !

name: Flying J
description: Flying J Travel Center off highway 93. RV parking near casino side of gas station. 6 rv spots that would hold big rigs and regular parking. Great service with AT&T and Verizon.

name: Stafford, Walmart
description: Surprisingly quiet place behind Walmart. From 5 am noisy because of delivery trucks.

name: Chickahominy Riverfront Park
description: Nice campground with trees directly at Chickahominy River. We have been alone during off season. In Summer it will get crowded because the lots are tiny.

name: Sandbridge Beach
description: Municipal Parking at the Public Beach. Until 10 pm very noisy because of military jets, from 5 am very noisy because of traffic.

name: Ocracoke Harbor, Outer Banks
description: Big parking lot of the visitor center directly at Ocracoke Harbor. Very quiet during off season.

name: Mill Stone Landing, Hardeeville
description: Big parking lot at Mills Landing Boat Ramp at the Savannah River. Very quiet

name: Traders Hill Campground
description: Small Campground close to Okefenokee Main Entrance with tent sites ($10) and RV sites ($20) shaded from big live oak trees. Quietness disturbed by some trains. We stayed for 4 nights. No one came to collect the camping fee and no one cares for the campground during our stay.

name: Forest Road 10, Ocala National Forest
description:
Bushcamping along Forest Road 10 in Ocala National Forest. Absolutely quiet.

During Oct - Jan, it's officially hunting season. you cannot camp anywhere unless it's in a designated camping spots. Rangers will fine you or there could be risks of getting shot by hunters

name: Forest Road 37, Ocala National Forest
description:
Bushcamping along Forest Road 37 in Ocala National Forest. It es better to have 4 WD because the dirtroad has some sandy spots. In the evening a little noisy from military airplanes.

During Oct - Jan, it's officially hunting season. you cannot camp anywhere unless it's in a designated camping spots. Rangers will fine you or there could be risks of getting shot by hunters

name: Paisley Road, Ocala National Forest
description: Camping in the Forest 200 yards down a small and sandy spur road from Paisley Road in Ocala National Forest. Ok for one night overnight parking.

name: Wabasso Island
description: Not easy to find a place to stay overnight at Southern Floridas Coastline. All public beaches have parking restrictions, campgrounds are fully booked. Finally we parked on Wabasso Island under the bridge across the Intracoastal Waterway.

name: Myakka River State Park, Big Flat Campground
description: Nice State Park Campground, clean, shaded from Oaks. People are quiet but the restroom pumps are very noisy especially in the morning from 6.30 AM.

name: Withlacoochee River Boat Ramp, Dunnellon
description: Boat Ramp at the beautiful Withlacoochee River with a nice sunset. There are some homes quite close but it is absolutely quiet.

name: Ichetucknee Springs Campground
description: Nice and natural private campground in the forest very close to the north entrance of Itchetucknee Springs State Park. The Campground appears more like a Forest Campground than a privately owned one. The sites are big and you have a good distance to your neighbor. Rate: $ 22 & up

name: Morrison Springs Park
description: Big Parking Lot at the Morrison Springs Park Boat Ramp. The Springs can be locked with a gate, but the parking lot for the boat ramp is outside the gate. The Spring is natural and beautiful with a temperature of 68°F. There is a swimming area with toilets.

name: Point Washington State Forest
description: Bushcamping in Point Washington State Forest. Very natural, very quiet, close to the perfect white beaches of the emerald coast. There is a primitive Campground with 4 sites a half mile further but the tree branches are at ca 10 ft clearance.

name: De Soto National Forest
description: Bushcamping along a forest road in De Soto National Forest. Distant noice from Hwy 15 but not disturbing. A lot of rubbish is all around in the National Forest.

name: Atchafalaya Basin Henderson Leevee Road
description: Boat Ramp at North Henderson Leevee Road. There are several more remote parking lots and boat ramps along the spillwayto the north, but we are not sure if overnight parking is allowed.

name: Cypremort Point Boat Ramp
description: Boat Ramp at the entrance to Cypremort Point State Park. We spent the day in the quiet State Park at the sandy and grassy beach with shaded picnic tables and free wifi. For the night we moved just out of the park to the adjacent big boat ramp. Can only stay in the park itself overnight if you have a tent and pay $6/night

name: Stage coach rv park
description: Campground big and clean, hot showers and bathroom but expensive (55$/night)

name: Stillwell Campground
description:
Because of spring break all campgrounds in the Big Bend NP were full. Around 9 miles before the park entrance we‘ve found this campground. It’s huge, especially for primitive camping.
We paid for an electric site (without water) 20.-. With water it’s 22.-. 
The primitive sites are also 20.- and you don’t have a toilet or shower nearby, but you’re in the pure nature.
The toilets and showers are at the store/reception.
It was very quiet at night and we‘ve seen a clear sky with hundreds of stars.

name: North Twin Trailhead
description: 3 miles off the highway on a good dirt road leads to this trailhead that has a large parking area, toilet, and creek. There are two smaller sites beyond the vault toilet with fire rings. Little to no cell service, very quiet.

name: Flagstaff KOA
description: One of the KOA campground, 38$ per night, sites are big enough and surrounding by lot of pines, friendly staff and great hot showers include.

name: State Park
description: Free entry to the state park, water spigot in one of the picnic areas.

name: pickle parking
description: large place to pull over on the side of a road. pull off 38 onto DEAN CR RD and the spot is directly to the right. niose from 38 dies down at night and there's almost no traffic on dean's. this spot is not hidden and there are no signs, and we had no one bother us. parked here because we didn't want to pay for camping or risk parking in a signed area, and the winter months closed the other ioverlander spot we wanted to try in coos bay. seems like this area is used to lots of overnighters and have signs posted against it in every little spot we checked including the elk viewing areas.

name: Fisherman’s Cove RV Resort
description: Beautiful RV Resort in Terra Ceia (Palmetto) FL

name: Grandview Sandbar
description: New River Gorge near Prince, WV on Glade Creek road. This campground is moving to RECREATION.GOV soon. Please check the website before coming here after June 2022.

name: Hall's Crossing Chevron
description: Gas station and small general store.  Campground nearby.  Pumps operate even if store is closed with a credit card.  Expensive. but not many other fuel options this side of the river for a long ways.

name: Bolivar Beach at Rollover Bay
description: Nice Camping at the beautiful clean sandy beach at the Bolivar Peninsula. There is a beach parking permit necessary (they are available come March 1st), valid 1 year, $10. During the day several day visitors are on the beach but it is far away to get crowded. In the night we had been alone. The nearby street is not disturbing because you sleep with the sound of the waves.

name: Freeport Beach south of Brazoria NWR
description: The best beach for camping on this journey up to now. It is as nice as beach camping at Padre Island. Very clean, fine sand, smooth waves, very quiet. We had 3 miles of beach for us. Driving is no problem for a 2 WD vehicle.

name: sandys restaurant and rv park
description:
full hookups. greasy spoon on site. basically a dirt lot with seasonal long term renters. laundry next door.
Wi-Fi from the restaurant

name: caballo lake State Park Riverside Campground
description:
State Park on riverside below the dam.
A nice quiet Campground with a lot of feral cats. Hookups and dispersed, primitive camping.

name: Paulino's Service Center
description: Accessories and mechanic for RV.  They had a fresh water pump to replace mine.

name: Brian booth state park
description: Parking on the road with access to the beach

name: Blue Ridge Overland Gear
description:
The Blue Ridge Overland Gear production facility and shop in Bedford, Virginia. Meet the BROG team, do a quick tour and check out our gear in real-time and see where all the action happens! We're in a brown metal building. When you get to the loop at the end of the driveway, just turn right and you'll see us. Parking is in front and in back of the brown metal building.

Store Hours: Monday to Friday (9 am - 5 pm)

www.BlueRidgeOverlandGear.com

We have free camping on-site and off-site overflow camping on Private Land available for anyone that has stopped into our store and received verbal permission to camp.  If after store hours and you cannot get a hold of anyone here, Peaks of Otter Campground is 9miles to the NW of Bedford, VA just off of the Blue Ridge Parkway and costs $20/night.

While you're in town check out all that Bedford and the surrounding area has to offer - including restaurants, wineries, breweries, hiking, camping, and outdoor adventuring of all kinds. Setup base camp at the Peaks of Otter, do some day hiking on the Appalachian Trial or other local hikes, go deep into the Washington and Jefferson National Forests, and go exploring along the breathtaking Blue Ridge Parkway.

name: No name public boat launch on levee
description: This is a public site referred to us by a local (employee at state park up the road) to park our van in to sleep overnight. Simple gravel parking lot with a boat ramp. Beautiful and free location!

name: Turnout at Highway 236
description: Nice little,flat turnout right beside the #236, shaded with big Redwoods, less traffic after sunset, had a quite night, no NO signs, please keep it clean!

name: Pier Wharf at Golden Gate
description: Passed through here moments ago and there are no signs prohibiting overnight parking / camping.  Park Ranger was nearby and didn't blink an eye at us in our camper.   Decided not to risk it after all and just camp at the Vista Point / H. Dana Bowers rest area but thought I should update that there are no 'no overnight' signs.

name: Trinidad Lake State Park
description:
fully establishes. awesome view. plenty of flat spots. kind of pricey for a SP. $7 day pass and $18 per site. water and electric. showers. laundry.
Online reservations are available at any time.
By phone:  Toll free 1-800-244-5613
For park or policy information:  CPW Call Center 1-800-678-2267 or 303-297-1192

name: Hero Market
description: Propane Service, Fuel Gas Diesel, Food, Water,Store

name: Rancho Tapango
description: Nice place with bathrooms and showers.  This is a desert environment so there are no trees.  The sites have no power, water, or covers but there are picnic tables at each site and water faucets are nearby for anyone to use. $30 per person.

name: Streetside parking Kingsbridge (Bronx)
description:
A couple of parking spots (90 degree angle parking) in a quiet side street off Broadway in Kingsbridge, West Bronx.
Subway station 238th St one block away (50min to Times Sq.). McDonalds with restroom and wifi next door. Laundry one block, grocers and food nearby. Public library three blocks. Across the street is a police station.
Parked here overnight for six days and nights in a row and didn't get bothered. Not 100% level. Free, no time limit (apart from citywide limit being seven days for cars and 24h for RVs). No parking (street sweeping) Tuesday 9:30-11:00am, but no-one cared and no-one got a ticket.

Now here's the catch. It's only about ten spots at this very location, and there is very little movement, meaning you have to be very lucky to get a spot. Small cars (up to van size) only. Stealth camping probably good idea. Pretty sure you get bothered when popping a roof-top tent or sth. However, there is no law in NYC prohibiting sleeping in vehicles.
The neighbourhood as such feels alright though, and you might find another spot nearby.

name: Walmart
description: Nice place, quiet, enough room for a few Rv, right off the highway.

name: Skull Creek Recreation Site
description: A nice BLM campground with a pit toilet, fire rings, trash cans and tables. Several spots available. Completely free!

name: Trinidad Lake State Park
description:
Nice and quiet campground for USD 31.-/night (Entrance 7.- and camping fee 24.-). Showers with extra charge per minute. Laundry is also available. 
Close by the lake.

name: Route 66
description: service center gas station with propane just off of Illinois route 53.

name: Casino Quapaw Miami
description: Nice place, free for 3 days, full hook up. Large pull through. Very quiet . Beau spot, 3 jours gratuits. Tranquille. 3 service.

name: corte del rey
description:
small campground with 4-6 pull through sites for transients, 20 or so long term. nice hot clean shower, laundry facilities, full 30 amp hook ups. lots of amenities near by.
 $15 US a night.

name: Free Wifi at visitor center
description: Free Wifi at visitor center / restroom / nice view!! Wifi may only be available during open hours.

name: Walmart with park lanes for RV
description: Nice place to stop, semi's and RV lanes. Park in designated spot.

name: Joshua Tree - Crossroads Cafe
description: $5 beers and generous mimosas. Ruben excellent, can’t miss cappuccino! Pancakes YES!!

name: Empty street with place to sleep
description:
Nothing more than a street without buildings or anything else. We stayed one night and nobody interrupted us. 
If you’re just looking for a place to sleep it is ok.

name: Home Depot
description: Overnight at the Home Depot Parking-Lot. We slept with our RV on the right side near to small trees and nobody cared about us. Good wifi from the market inclusive.

name: Houston Mesa Campground
description:
$29/night. 
Established camp site Has showers at $3 for 6 minutes. Host was super nice. Nice place to stop by for a shower. Showers are coin operated only. Host was able to provide change.

name: Hole in the Wall Dispersed Camping
description:
Just pull off to that unpaved road at least one mile and you can camp for free. Lots of great places! Even possible with 2WD.

very hard to find it after dark

name: Beatty Dispersed Camping
description: Another BLM-spot near Beatty. Easy gravel road for 2WD. This one is better reachable because the street to the other spot is quite bad with lots of holes. But there are also plenty of other good spots around! Verizon cell service ok here.

name: Lake Hill Dispersed Camping
description: Beautiful spot right next to Panamint Springs and Lake Hill with an amazing panorama. It's free and legal a mile or more away from the highway. It's a gravel road and 2WD is okay but some medium/high clearance may be helpful because there are some washouts on the road. But altogether a good street! Can get very windy out there!

name: Municipal parking spot in Northbend
description: 12hours parking lot free in the city not so much noise ! Verizon service 3 bars.

name: Chisos Basin Campground
description: NP Campground. 14$ per site per night. No showers , only toilets. Dump station. Very quiet.  Often full. It's better to arrive in the morning to get a site.

name: Pic-nic area
description: small picnic area parking. Just on the side of the road so a little bit noisy due to trafic.

name: In front of oceano community center
description: Quiet place for a night. No prohibition signs anywhere and nobody bothered us.

name: overnight pull over spot
description: a nice pull over from the road. there are several like these on the side of the hill. minor noise from the road, otherwise safe and peaceful. we stayed just one night.

name: Bakery general store
description:
A store where you can refill or buy propane (refill is 20$) and there is also some general groceries 
Just a cross the street of where are the showers

name: Walmart, near A10
description: Another Walmart in Las Cruces. Quiet place. WiFi in store. Many others RV.

name: Visitors Center
description: It's a parking lot located at the Visitor Center and it's directly behind the police station. If you stay here, make sure to check in with the dispatcher at the police station. The Visitor Center staff offered the lot to us. We stayed here for 4 nights. You can get showers and use the pool at Aquatic Center for $1.50.

name: BLM mile marker 10
description:
Drive along a dirt road from mile marker 10 on highway. Look for fire pits for campsites. Very quiet but very windy. 
No amenities. 
Good cellular reception.

name: Kiva koffehouse & Kiva Kottage
description: Very nice coffee place with organics products fresh coffee and a variety of drinks and food like breakfast or salads or gluten free pasta... it’s up in a hill so the view is gorgeous and it as a lovely outside for warm day. We really enjoyed stoping here and recommend it !

name: Sandy Hill/ Keyesville
description:
A bunch of great spots right by the river...
FREE BLM Keyesville

name: Tropic power station
description: A place for a van (maybe not Huge Rvs) just next to the Tropic power station. Good place if arriving late to Bryce canyon.

name: Presque Isle Downs & Casino
description: Nice place, free, quiet, level, good food, good bar, shuttle.

name: Rudy’s Inn General Store
description: You can ask for showers there and pay it 5$. very good hot showers and clean bathroom!

name: Graves Creek Campground
description: We were advised to camp here by the Quinault Ranger Station as it was currently off-season and free! Beautiful, serene location along the river. The road turns to gravel and gets pretty rough as you get deeper in to the park, but well worth the trip.

name: Dump station Mission Bay Pwky
description: Park with boat ramp and dump station and free non-portable water. Located west of the bathrooms.

name: Weed street parking
description: Just off the highway, parking down side streets of Weed. There's a few car empty free car park lots but heaps of trucks park in these and all through the town overnight so try not to park in their way. We stayed on the road out the front of Starbucks with no problem at all and even got wifi. McDonald's and lots of other places close and open late. A bit noisey because of the trucks but fine for a night.

name: Kaibab forest dispersed camping
description: Wild camping, no services. Pretty quiet both during the day and at night.  There are many informal sites along this road, this was as far as we drove. There is a fire pit, and fairly flat grounds. We drove a 33' Class A down the gravel road and in.

name: Pacific City Thousand Trails RV
description: No WiFi or phone reception but pool and Hot shower and running water and some full hook up sites and some not but back in sites up to 45 foot RV’s

name: Scenic Park Campground
description: Big RV Park, good Restrooms, friendly staff. $30 per night all sites.

name: Siding 36 Motel and RV Park
description: Big RV Park next to the Highway. Just one Restroom with showers, very clean. Laundry. 20 $ for small RV. Friendly staff.

name: One stop coin laundry
description: Clean laundry. Personnel sympathique. Easy parking

name: The Springs at Borrego Springs golf and resort
description: Dry camping, big beautiful overflow parking area. Setting is in a golf resort with sandy area around the lake offering fishing, catch and release. Golf is 27$. With a cart.   Twilight after 1. But if you don't golf, if it's not your thing, it's still a great place. 30$ a night. With a 20$ discount for the 1st night. So 10$. Access to all the resort facilities, pool hot tub, laundry, and social events.

name: Winstar world casino rv park
description: FHU pull throughs.  Bath house dog run pool and hot tub.  Laundry lots of room between sites.   Shuttle to casino.  One night free w new player card.

name: Camping World
description:
Update Aug 2019: You can only stay if you are a member of camping world. 

Camping world stores offer their parking lot for free to sleep in your van. Better than Walmart!
Bathroom available when store is open.

name: Wal-Mart Roswell
description: Grocery store is open 24h, bathrooms inside and WiFi, the Roswell UFO international museum(has free wifi) and all ufo related shops are 3 miles from here on main road, there is plenty of parking also there.

name: Walmart Claypool
description: A fine place for overnight! Good WiFi and free

name: Wallmart
description:
Big wallmart, new, we spend a night, it was quiet, more than we thougth. More than the other I checked and wich is farrest from the highway.

If you look on wall mart locator, don't trust their information, it out dated, we've been to two others wall mart, no success.

name: Kaibab NF Pullout
description: Tiny pullout on the National Forest road with a fire ring. Right next to the road but there are very few cars at night. Quiet, no amenities.

name: Long Jim Loop Road
description: Many spots along Long Jim Loop. Most are fairly flat and easy to access, there are a few that would require a little maneuvering and that the drop off from the edge of the road to the campsite is somewhat significant. The dirt road is packed and in good shape. I'm in a 25' class C with a toad and had no trouble, but I did move spots because my first one was very unlevel. I've seen several big rigs. I had a herd of elk in my campsite the other night, which was cool. Verizon service is fast at certain times of the day, and drops to almost unusable at others. I've only seen this type of intermittent slowdown at crowded RV parks when everyone is trying to stream videos at the same time, so I'm assuming that because it's very close to the park entrance that the service may get overwhelmed when there are long lines. I'm showing a consistent 3 bars, but the actual service is anything but consistent. Overall, it was mostly reliable but very slow at times.

name: Ruby's Inn: Shower, Laundry
description: Amazing place particularly in the off season when facilities in Bryce are closed. $5 showers (unlimited time), wash $2.25, dry $1.50, free WiFi. Also groceries available in the shop and a warm place to sit!

name: Las Vegas RV resort
description: Rv park at Sam’s Town near the city (25 min drive), very secure with a garde  all night. It’s a rv park so you don’t have many privacy and you are parked in a parking lot but it’s cheap for Vegas (32$ per night full hook up) and the bathrooms and showers are great (you have your very own bathroom with toilets and hot shower inside!) after few weeks of Boondocking it feel nice

name: Rest area north of lubbock
description: Big rest area with clean bathroom, pick nick table, just off highway , nearby dairy farm make it a bit smelly...truck also park here, if you stay behind the building a bit less noisy

name: Chinook Winds Casino Resort
description: 24/7 Casino just off the main road as you enter Lincoln City - we stayed in the main car park from around 10pm through to 7am with no issue. The restrooms are obviously accessible throughout the night if you don't mind wading through bright lights and clouds of cigarette smoke first. They have Wifi but it doesn't reach very far out the main building unfortunately.

name: Longview Walmart
description: Overnight-camped in the car-park with no issue. This branch isn't open 24 hours. Restrooms and wifi indoors.

name: Gila NF Dispersed Camping
description:
Nice, quite dispersed spot not far from road on a ridge. Nice view. Fire ring. High clearance recommended. 4WD not needed.
Good overnight spot on the way to Gila Cliff Dwellings.

name: Kentucky Camp / FR163
description:
Multiple dispersed campsites along FS road on the way to Kentucky Camp (historic site).
Campsite on a knob with a beautiful view.
No 4x4 needed.
Shade - No. Cell reception - Yes.

name: Mojave National Preserve
description:
Free established campsite within Mojave National Preserve. Beautiful spot surrounded by big rocks and cacti.
4x4 not needed, but high ground clearance would be better.

name: Grandstaff Campground
description: Nice campground on the river. Sites aren't to close but not much trees. Canyon provides plenty of shade in the morning and evening. Road is noise durring the day but quite at night. Now costs $20 a night

name: Shafer (backcoutry) Canyonlands National Park
description:
This site requires a Backcountry Permit from the Canyonlands National Park office.

Nice campsite with beautiful views. Big area to set up tents, However not much area to stake in your tent due to the rocky ground. Plenty of rocks to hold them down. Be careful of high winds threw the canyon. 4wheel drive road to get there with spectacular switchbacks and views.

name: Hittle Bottom
description: Quite campground. One of the farthest from Moab so it fills later in the day.

name: Loves Truck Stop in Hardin
description: Good for the night, clean restrooms in loves and free WiFi in Hardee’s not so noisy. Super windy, Showers$$ in loves (don’t know how much)

name: Walmart in Ephraim
description:
Nice mountain views and next to a auto zone. 
Stayed 1 night no problem

name: parking Conoco / Crown mercantil
description: Ask Conoco management if we could stay here and no problem.

name: Dump station next to Lewis Park
description: Dump station but there is no potable water here. Just cross the road and go into the park and you will find plenty of water faucets to connect you to.

name: Jessen Park
description: No facilities in winter, although there is access to the parking area. Halfway between Dillon (Patagonia outlet) and Big Sky in the town of Twin Bridges. Can be windy.

name: Ridgecrest
description: Site overlooks Ridgecrest city, so at night you get to see the whole city. Road up the hill isn't 4x4 required, but possibly high clearance would be good. Go past the college and stay on the main road(quite a few side paths out here) and follow it up the hill, turn to the right and you'll come to an area that has a fire pit. Weekends might get company but on weekdays, we haven't had any visitors.

name: La Sal Loop offshoot
description: shortly down a double track road off the main paved road, there is a dead end with a very big view that would probably be a nice place to camp. Anytime outside of summer/fall it may be quite cold at night or inaccessible due to snow, but otherwise a great way to get out of the Moab heat.

name: Walnut Ridge Campground
description: Established Campground with full hookups and laundry mat.  Very clean and friendly.

name: Campo Coronado
description: Secluded camp North of La Gringa, nothing here so bring everything.  There is many ways to get there but the best one is turn left to the dump (the road before the ´welcome’ hill and go north on a 2wd path (need a little clearance only). Turn right at a fence. Many opportunities for pulling to the water a few times before this but if you keep going you will be rewarded with quiet and seclusion and a few little bluffs that overlook the water. There is a sign that says campo Coronado and it says campo on the hill in white rocks.

name: Ajo Heights RV Park
description: Large sites, Full Hook ups, Very clean, Great Hosts... Across from the IGA Store which is very convenient. $35/nt

name: Meriwether Lewis
description: On the Natchez Trace Parkway. Has service for phone and text but no internet service.  Flushing restrooms and potable water

name: Westworld Convention Centre
description: The sites are at the Westwood Convention Centre.Lots of sites. Mostly pavement and dirt. Water and electric at sites. Dump station on the grounds. A few grassy areas. Close to Interstate $28.50/nt

name: Maple canyon
description: Parked with our 27 foot class c rv on one of the spots. Next to the climbing crag.

name: Desert between Sanderson and Marathon
description: Place for overnight parking in the  Desert at the railroad tracks just beside a water tank where the railroad leaves the highway. It is not easy to find a place here because both sides of the highway is fenced private land and you cannot move from the road. We had a nice talk to the Border Partrol. The guy said we are fine here but should not move further down the dirt road where private land begins. Expect some noise from trains, but there are not so many passing by (7). The highway is also a bit disturbing.

name: Big Bend NP: Grapevine Hills No 4 & 5
description: Primitive Backcountry Camping in Big Bend National Park. You need a backcountry permit which is $ 12 for up to 14 nights. Grapevine Hills No 4 has a much nicer view of the Badlands to the North East than No 5, which is more secluded between shrubs. The dirtroad is 7.7 mi long and a bit rocky in places. It was no problem for our 4WD Truck but high clearance is an advantage.

name: Big Bend NP: Pine Canyon No 4
description: Primitive Backcountry Camping in Big Bend National Park in Pine Canyon at site No. 4. You need a backcountry permit which is $ 12 for up to 14 nights.  It is a 5 mi bumpy dirtroad to the site, high clearance is recommended. There is a perfect view of Chisos Mountains. Absolutely remote and quiet.

name: Big Bend NP: Camp de Leon
description: Primitive Backcountry Camping in Big Bend National Park in Camp de Leon along Old Ore Road. You need a backcountry permit which is $ 12 for up to 14 nights. Old Ore Road is a 4x4 Road but the aproach to Camp de Leon is not worse than the other rocky backroads. A 2 WD/HC car will be fine. Absolutely remote and quiet. CORRECTION: Cost is now $10 per night as of 1/2/20.

name: Big Bend NP: Gravel Pit No 3
description: Primitive Backcountry Camping in Big Bend National Park. You need a backcountry permit which is $ 12 for up to 14 nights. Gravel Pit is easy accessible by a 2 WD car. You are just 200 yards from the Rio Grande where you can cool down and put in your kajak and paddle down to Hot Springs or Rio Grande Village.

name: Big Bend NP: Camp Chilicotal
description: Primitive Backcountry Camping in Big Bend National Park. You need to book that in advance for 10$ p. N.. Camp Chilicotal has one of the best views in the Park! The road is very bumpy all way long. Absolutely remote and quiet. Very little T-mobile reception through a Weeboost.

name: Big Bend NP: Black Dike
description: Primitive Backcountry Camping in Big Bend National Park. You need a backcountry permit which is $ 12 for up to 14 nights. There is a lot of vegetation around Black Dike and you don't have a nice view. But there is a trail to the Rio Grande with a nice Basalt formation where you can swim. Just above the Dike is a nice viewpoint. We moved there to spend the day. 1 car passed by along river road during 24 hours. The first 6 mi of the River Road East are fine but then it get´s very rough in some spots. It is 11 miles dirt road to Black Dike. Absolutely quiet and remote.

name: Big Bend NP: Terlingua Abajo No 3
description: Primitive Backcountry Camping in Big Bend National Park. You need a backcountry permit which is $ 12 for up to 14 nights. There are 3 Sites at Terlingua Abajo, all of them with a nice view to Santa Elena Canyon. The Dirtroad is in good condition until Ocotillo Grove, then it is getting a bit rough through a small canyon.

name: BLM Land north of Carlsbad Caverns
description: Camping on BLM Land north of Carlsbad Caverns Nationalpark. The dirt road is very rough and you'll need a high clearance vehicle. There are several camping spots along the road. So you can go as far up the hill as you want until you are far enough away from the highway. You have a spectacular view across the plains below and you will be very surprised how many lights you will see when it is getting dark.

name: Acadiana Park Campground
description:
A beutiful and quiete campground in Acadiana park near Lafayette.
25$/night

name: Cracker Barrel Parking Lot
description: 4 RV spots in the back. Stayed overnight, no problem in 20’ skoolie. One other van there.

name: Stratosphere - Las Vegas
description: Go up the Stratosphere for a happy hour cocktail!  Fabulous views from the lounge and then up to the top for even better views. Great fun.

name: Vegas - Fashion Mall Parking
description: Fantastic spot for rvs to park to visit the Strip.  Above ground self parking, no height restrictions.  2min walk to Strip, 5min walk to Wynne hotel.  Free.  Go to the dinner and Le Reve deal at the Wynne - you won't be disappointed.  $200 for show and three course dinner including wine each at the elegant Jardin restaurant.  We camped at the Stratosphere for free.  Great stay.

name: Ruedi Reservoir
description: Lovely boondocking site.  Overlooks water.  Fire pit.  Tucked out of view of road.  Could not find dispersement camping.

name: Rest Stop - near Wiggins
description: Huge rest stop - some trucks park overnight - tons of space for any sized rig.  Need earplugs- near highway and rail crossing but good overnight stop.

name: White Mountain Oil and Propane
description: Fill BBQ tanks.  $17 to fill 20lb tank.  Situated in North Conway.  the connections are for standard North America bbq tanks.

name: Upper East Side
description:
Great spot between 5th and Madison.  Lots of free parking just check the street cleaning days and hours:  example - mon and thurs 9-10:30am means that if you are parked there, between 9-10:30 you get your coffee and sit in the drivers seat of your car.  Sometimes the street cleaners don't come along but the police do.  You don't get ticketed if you are sitting there (all the locals will be sitting in their cars too).  If the street cleaners come, they all double park on the other side until they are done and then move back.  You are then good to park until Thursday.  Sundays are a complete free day in New York - you can pretty well park anywhere (even near Times Square).

Coffee in Central Park - walking distance to Times Square.  We also found a spot on the upper west side for a couple of nights.  Walking distance to Central Park at the Hudson parkway.  Give yourself lots of time to find a park - it's worth it to see New York for free accommodation!

name: Huntington Sewer Treatment Plant
description: Free waste dump place.  Great friendly staff.  Non potable water available

name: Park and Ride off Long Island Expressway
description: Exit 49 Long Island expressway.  Nice spot for overnight but obviously need earplugs.  We started at Walmart in Commack but they don't allow overnighters.  Be aware that this is a spot for gay guys to hook up - they didn't bother us at all but they drive around making a connection.

name: Brooklyn
description: Brooklyn- appears this lot is no longer available as construction for apartment or businesses going up. However, around these streets there is free parking if you can find spots.

name: Service area
description: Overnight camping - big truck stop.  Water/air - no dump station.  Starbucks and Cinnabon- gas

name: Delanco Light Rail Station
description: Lovely quiet spot for an overnight.  Light rail train quietly travels by.  Parking for commuters.

name: Philadelphia municipal parking lot
description:
One of the best finds of our two year journey as far as city sightseeing goes!  We parked here for four nights.  Not even two kms from city centre - we toured the
Mural routes, walked to the kimmel centre to see the philharmonic, independence square and the Arts Museum at the end of Ben Franklin Boulevard (yep - in our fifties so did the Rocky thang).  Not far from the Italian market.  

Free and absolutely no restrictions.  Trick is to actually get a spot - worth hanging out in the morning or late afternoon at the diner next door to wait.  There are other free municipal lots - check out visitphilly.com but we added two screenshots to this post of the spots.  We have a truck camper - anything bigger will not fit here.

Loved Philly!

name: U-Haul - propane
description: Tank refill.  By the gallon but will top up tanks.  Open 7 days/week (No propane at Costco in the US).  $4.19 per US gallon - so 20lb tank costs us$20.  the connections are for standard North America bbq tanks.

name: I95N Rest Area
description: Great place for a night.  Also, free dump station and non-potable water.  Washrooms.

name: I95N Rest Area
description:
Free dump station. Out of service Apr 2022 
Should check with the attendant.

name: Washington DC - East Potomac Park
description: Place to park your vehicle for free all day.  There are closer spots to the Mall for free but they have a three hour time limit.  All closer spots are paid and limited time parking.  We drove to this spot and cycled to the Mall in 5-6 minutes - it was fantastic!  It’s about 1.5kms to the Washington Monument.  If you have your own bikes you are set - this is the way to do DC on a budget.  Lots of bike rental options too.

name: Davis Travel Centre - Stony Creek
description: Free dump station.  Truck stop away from main highway so good for a night.  Restaurants nearby.

name: Petro travel centre
description: $10.00 pump out and potable water.  Truck stop so could overnight here.

name: Cotton Landing - Apalachicola National Forrest
description: Absolutely beautiful spot.  A must if you have a kayak, canoe or SUP.  Lovely Cyprus grove to kayak for miles.  We were here late November/ early December.  Only people here with the odd local hunters who drove by.  No bugs, leaves on trees largely gone but spectacular scenery.  Campfires at night - so quiet.

name: Flying J
description: Dump station fixed and working. $10 fee; pay inside and get a code. Has a water spigot with black hose attached. We did not assume it’s potable water.

name: Rest area I-10 westbound
description: Free dump station with potable water.  Nice restrooms and picnic areas.

name: Walmart - El Paso
description: Great spot for a quiet night!  There is extra quiet camping near the “pickup” area if you have a smaller rig.

name: Riverside Water Treatment Facility
description: Free dump station and non- potable water.  Check photo of sign for opening hours.

name: Rest Area
description: Rest area good for the night. Camper parking area back off the highway so not bad noise-wise. Clean and picnic tables. Nothing else. Rest area on other side too.

name: Tecopa Hot Springs and Campground
description:
$25 gives you a camping spot with electric plus two 24 hour passes to the hot tubs (worth $9 each).  Nothing fancy at all but worth it especially on a cold February night.  Men and women baths are separate because it is mandatory nude.

Dump out and non potable water available.  Potable water available in town (see other post).

name: Tecopa
description: Water vending machine.  25c / gallon.  Fill your garafon or any container.

name: King’s Row RV Park
description: $5 (cash only) - dump station and potable water

name: Lavanderia
description: $4.75 for a triple load.  Drying is free!  Busy on this Sunday afternoon.  Fluff and fold service.

name: Valley of Fire State Park
description:
Phenomenal park and great value.  Spend an entire day here- there are several hikes and the scenery is jaw dropping.  

$10 gets you a day pass (this includes the use of the dump station with potable water).  

$10 to camp overnight (plus park entrance).
$20 to camp overnight with elec hook up (plus park entrance).

name: Kelso visitor centre
description: Kelso visitor centre. Free potable water. NO HOSE CONNECTION.  Washrooms.

name: Route 66
description: Kind of a neat spot to take a photo of your rig with the Route 66 sign.  You can also buy gas at $5/gallon!

name: Indio
description: Cold, fresh potable water.  25c/gallon.  Kiosk open 24 hours.  Ice available too - $3 for a 20lb bag.

name: Del sol laundry
description: $2 for double load.  25c/8m dryer (good dryers!)

name: Agua Caliente County Park
description:
Use hot tubs all day (8:30 to 5) for $3 pp (you don’t have to pay $3 vehicle charge if using hot tubs).  Pay $3 vehicle charge to hike only.  $24 for dry camping.  Self check in so exact cash necessary.

Main spa pool (102f) under conservatory type clear structure - really pleasant.  Two outdoor pools that are solar heated - also lovely.

Hot showers are 50c/4 minutes - $1.25 for 10 mins.

Lovely campground.  We just used the pools and wild camped nearby.  Well worth the money.

name: State Trailer RV
description: Potable water at dump station.  Says not for culinary use but it’s potable.

name: State Trailer RV
description: Propane $2.19/gallon.  Will top up.  40 characters: fantastic rv store.  Camp overnight and get all your chores done in one go!

name: Centennial Park
description: Lovely street parking alongside the park.  You cannot park overnight in the park but this is right on the edge.

name: London Walmart
description: 24 hour Walmart- fine for overnight.  We parked opposite the auto bays.  No one bothered us.

name: Merrigans Arizona Road-Runner RV
description:
Free 24 hour dump station. This is provided as a courtesy by a private company. Please go inside, browse the store, and if you see something you need, buy it there. They are also a service center. Need something worked on? Have them do it. 

It's by the street in front of the store, on your left.

name: Cotton wood canyon end of road at the cotton woods
description: This is the end of the cottonwood canyon road. You can walk 100 yards to some good spots to camp in the cottonwoods. But there are lots and lots of good spots along the way. We stayed 0.3 miles down the road in a nice spot. Stock 4X4 would make it fine when we went, but it’s driving in an arroyo so a rain could completely change the road.

name: First creek trailhead
description:
This is a large quiet parking area at the firs creek trailhead in the northern part of Mammoth caves national park, trail normally used by horses so there are some large spots you can fit a camper in

Got decent Verizon service with our booster 

Perhaps not 100% Legal to camp here but we did not see any no camping signs nor encounter any rangers, it's about 30 mins from the main cave area

There are a few other trailhead parking areas if you continue down the road which might be good options as well

The trail itself is a muddy mess, tore up by horses, do not recommend for hiking

name: Dazzos Best Ever RV Park
description: Water and electric at all sites. Nice country store and good restaurant . $20./nt Clean bathrooms, laundry .

name: 123 Wash & Dry
description: Dry Cleaning times 8-6 (Mon-Fri) and 9-5 (Sat), self-service open until 11pm, last washing time 10.30. The usual: Good industrial machines, 3 different sizes, decent prices, fairly clean. We recommend this place!

name: 525 Boondocking site
description: Last pullout we could find for our 33' rig. Entrance is rough, go slow and use caution, tore our muffler down getting in. ATVs and jeeps go down this road continually, so be prepared for dust and some road noise, however this would be the same at all sites on this road.

name: Jetty Park Campground
description:
Nice campground run by Port Canaveral. Walking distance to beach and biking distance to restaurants. Nice bathrooms and showers with laundry available for $2 wash/dry. Fishing pier. 

Good place to watch rocket launches from the cape!

name: Bear Creek Lake State Park
description:
Campground at the waterfront of the Lake.
Camping and cabins. For information on availability of overnight accommodations, particular park amenities or to make a reservation, you can reserve online or call 1-800-933-PARK. Reservations are highly recommended. Prices vary depending on season.

name: Caltrans Rest Area near a Chevron g.s.
description: One of the Caltrans rest areas with toilets next to the Chevron gas station. Overnight parking is permitted and free. Tenting is strictly prohibited!! No freeway noise. I felt safe and slept well.

name: Whiskey Flats RV Park,Hawthorne, NV
description: Sites concrete and level. Some nice grassy areas . Full service. Washrooms clean. $29./nt

name: Off of Loop Rd.
description: Large, somewhat flat site. Large fire ring, and as of presently, good amount of wood around in fallen trees. Located in Coconino National Forest. Maximum stay for canping is 14 days. Accommodated 33' rig, lots of room to back up and adjust if necessary.

name: Beachside State Park
description: Nice campground directly to the beach with hot shower and power for RV. Good spot for some nights! $21 for a Tent, few bucks extra for out of state folks

name: Florence Creek Forest rte
description:
Lots of primitive camp sites can be found along the trail.

Lots of birds chirping, deer, and other wildlife.

name: Laguna Del Sol
description: The place is a clothing optional resort which allows persons of inappropriate behavior to lurk and prey on innocents. The Management (Gen. Mngr) has no integrity, is Bias and unfair and the establishments cleanliness is questionable. Beware management does not make any effort to protect or treat everyone equally, favoritism is exhibited regularly. The restaurant is a joke.

name: Park Hitchkiss
description: Street like that spot. Good night quit going n Los Angeles near Venise beach parking in front of the park. No sign saying that is not allowed to stay overnight. Nice and quiet. Free. Public Restrooms in the park! And open free WiFi!

name: Free dump station - Hyperion Water Plant
description:
Free dump station near LAX airport. They wouldn’t let me have any water 09/2019. Dump only. 

closed on weekends

name: Rocky Mountain Cummins
description: Cummins and Onan generator parts and service.  Heavy duty Cummins diesel repair center.  Overnight parking with electric connections for customers only.

name: The Village at North Fork
description: Small RV park with full hook-ups in a beautiful valley full of wildlife.

name: Frew rd primitive roadside
description: Room for Six vehicle plus tents easily. Call to the local MNR for free site registration required. Fire pit, cooking grate, no washrooms or facilities

name: rest area highway 99
description: usual state rest area. 8 hours parking permitted

name: The Fountain of Youth Spa and RV Park
description: Tennis courts, 2 pools, 4 hot tubs, laundry, pool hall, bocci courts, horse shoe courts, dog washing station, lots of clean facilities (showers and bathrooms), hiking chocolate mountains, flinstone golf course, frisbee golf course, hiking and biking trails. Full hookup, cheap dry camping. Best RV park I've ever been to. Discounts for staying longer. 10% off with AAA or Good Sam. Website reservations not working as of 1/1/2020 - call for reservation.

name: Trimmer Springs Road
description: A nice spot on the side of the road for a quick break or an overnight stay. No signs mentioning “no parking”

name: River park RV Resort
description:
Grants Pass. Beautiful small family campground.
Grassy sites with cement pads. Full services at all sites. Riverfront lots are   $41. ...spaces that are not on river are less.

name: Green Dickson park Shiner
description:
A beautifuf and Little campsite inside the City Park of Shiner. 20$/night
We were alone

name: Big Bend NP - Rice Tank
description:
Primitive campground without amenities. 
Access by a dirt road - no major difficulty (around 30 minutes of the main road)
Need a permit of 12$/14days. bought in the visitor center. You have to say how long you’ll stay at each place. CORRECTION- Price was increased 1/1/20 to $10 PER NIGHT. reservations can now be made online at recreation.gov in addition to the visitors center on arrival.

name: Big Bend NP - Paint Gap
description:
Primitive campground without amenities. 
Access by a gravel road - no 4x4 needed
No shade 
Need a permit of 12$/14days bought in the visitor center. You have to say how long you’ll stay at each place. No possibility to modify the duration when the permit is created, you’ll have to buy a new one.

name: Battery Systems
description:
All batteries you need. 
Very nice and helpful team.

name: Camper Services Laundromat & Showers
description: Laundry service and showers in Grand Canyon National Park

name: Forest Service Road 568
description: There are several nice sites along the gravel forest service road.

name: Stills Landing - Francis Marion National Park
description:
Lovely quiet camping spot right on Wambaw Creek - to the left of the boat ramp drive in to either of the two spots.  Free.  Call ‭1 (843) 336-3248‬ and they will email you a permit (we never managed to get hold of them and no-one bothered us).  Or check the website to register.  Great kayaking in cypress grove. There are gators but they are really wary.  Sites are level.  Lots of dead fall firewood.  In early April - no bugs.

Late October into early November is peak time for leaf color change.  Bugs are light to mild during this time of the year.

The clearing offers some views of the night sky for star gazing.

name: Boles Field, Sabine National Forest
description:
Warm showers !
6$/night with water and electricity. 
No dump station.

name: Owl Canyon
description: BLM fee campground at Rainbow Basin Natural Area. $6 per night. 31 campsites with covered picnic areas and grills. Lots of pit toilets and play areas for kids. Supposed to have potable water, but didn't during my visit. Beautiful site with nearby hiking trails.

name: Walmart moses lake-no mooses
description: Walmart supercenter. dowtown Moses but unfortunatly no moses dowtown.

name: Big Lake, TX - County Fairgrounds
description: Referred here by town hall. No one else here - 5 Apr 2018. There is a sign stating Overnight Parking - 15 $ but no one to take the $.

name: Chevron
description: In the Chevron station you can fill with water for $ 1.50 in the machine and have a well behind. we supply water.

name: Best dog park ever!
description: Awesome dog park! Right next to the river, huuuuge space super lovely!!

name: Kaibab Paiute RV Park and Campground
description: Flat, gravel RV park, offers all services, including nice facilities in the clubhouse (laundry, showers, common area with satellite tv). Nightly cost is reasonable, $25/night for site, $12.50 with Passport America membership. $12 tent sites. Park is very clean with friendly, helpful staff.

name: Hawkins Bridge Campground
description: Campground within Wharton State Park. No amenities other than a fire ring, pit toilets, some cell service

name: County Road 772 Intersection
description: There's a BLM road at the same intersection (it's to the north of the 4 lane road), There's one spot about 100' from the 4 lane and then plenty more up the rough BLM road.

name: U-haul propane
description: Easy access to fill up your propane tanks.

name: Self parking LINQ
description:
Self parking LINQ oversized vehicles . $18 for 3 to 24 hours. Near the strip. Noisy for the night but good location to visit Vegas. 20 $ for RV - 24 hours
PRICE now, 24 hrs, $18 for regular vehicles and $30 for oversize vehicles. See note from truck struck below about oversized vehicles.

name: Coal Mine Rd BLM
description:
North turn off of 24 and a couple minutes in are pit toilets and enough room for many vehicles. about 5 more minutes down the road is a turn off large enough for couple campers/rv's. road is good condition and has good drainage control so little worry during rain. 

Nice n quiet, small amount of dirt bikers, but mostly silent.

name: Fremont Granary Site
description: Multiple spots. Enough room to turn around 30ft rv. Right off hwy

name: Purified water
description:
$1 for 5gallons. 
On the parking of the Walmart.
Easy to use.
The cheapest we've found.

name: Roadside Parking
description: Slept here overnight in my Sprinter Van (doesn't look like an RV though). Needed a place to stay after spending a night in Crested Butte and wanted to do some mountain biking the next morning at Mt. CB. Drove up out of town and parked on the side of the gravel road near here. Few other cars were camping nearby. Didn't see any signs against it there. No one bothered me, but I did get in after dark and left early.

name: Desert Parking
description:
Camping among the Joshua trees a short drive off the highway. Can hear the highway noise from here, but it would be easy to follow the dirt road farther and find quiet.

Mid way point on a long trip we needed a place to sleep , run/play ball with the dog (off leash), & get back on the road quickly easily in the morning. We have a very capable off-road RV class C size (converted M1079 military truck) & pulling our little Scion car. Our RV could take all of the ruts easily but it took careful, slow, creative driving to get our little car with very little ground clearance through the ruts  to the camp site. Campsite is an fairly close but okay distance from the highway & train tracks since it was quite windy we couldn’t hear either of them. We would not have attempted getting to the site if it were muddy or with rain in the forecast because our truck would leave incredibly deep scars in the earth if it rained & our little car couldn’t have handed it.  It is in a dry lake bed & we would highly recommend avoiding it if it’s raining especially if you don’t have 4x4. If it is dry, with careful driving, we believe any camper, van or even passenger car could make it. It was exactly what we needed!

name: Riverside Campground
description: Nice 34 site campground just downstream of Canyon Ferry Dam. Outhouses, water in summer, some pull through campsites. $15/site/day in season and 50% discount with National Park Access or Senior Pass. Free in winter (no water). Strong cell signal and Verizon LTE.

name: Chinamen’s Campground
description: Rustic 39 site dirt road Campground on the shore of reservoir. Small sites, outhouses, water during season, a few concrete sites. $10/site/night in season and 50% discount with National Park Access Pass. Free in winter(no water). Verizon LTE strong

name: Morrow Mountain State Park Campground
description: Good campground with plenty of spots. If using RTT be sure and bring something to level your rig. Showers, toilets, and sinks available. Gate opens at 7a and close at 9p.

name: Court Sheriff Campground
description: Nice 48 site Campground on the shore of the reservoir. Paved, outhouses, some large sites. Some sites are reservable. Water in regular season. $15/site/night during season and 50% discount with National Park Access or Senior Pass.  Free in winter (no water).  Good cell signal.

name: Roadside campground loop
description: Big area with bumpy roads. it is better for small rigs with high clearence and tents. we stayed close to the entrance with our truckcamper. in the forest.

name: FREE HOTSPRING DOWN BY THE RIVER
description: Under the bridge, across the street from my camp spot is a free hotspring super awesome. Clothing advised but go with what ya feel.

name: Quiet spot off San Marco Pass
description: Half a mile up a rocky road is a semi-flat spot big enough for a 4x4 ideally with rooftop tent. 4x4 and ground clearance required. Quiet and just far enough off the road. No signs and 4 bars of LTE.

name: Schnebly Hill Road
description: beautiful forest with big pines, lots of firewood, rock fire pits, wildlife, open camp sites, riding trails, free

name: BLM land
description: Wild land, remote, half a mile down Horse Canyon Road behind a rest area.  Beautiful, calm and peaceful. Some garbage around but we found a flat, clean spot.

name: McHood Park Campsite Winslow.
description: Free campground at a lake. Picnic tables, fireplaces/barbecues, trashbins, toilets. Even showers, but I don't think they are working. 20sites or so, many are large pull throughs.

name: Free Dump Station. Los Lunas.
description: free dump at the heritage park in los lunas. has also water but we are unsure if it is potable. trash bin.

name: McGeorge’s RV and Camping World
description: Free dump station.  Non potable water.  Open 24/7.

name: Trona Pinnacles
description: Free BLM boondocking site at the Trona Pinnacles. Sites located all around Pinnacles driving loop. Road is ok - can be a bit Rocky, but you don't need 4x4. There is an ok pit toilet - bring your own TP. Beautiful landscape.

name: Cortez gaz co
description:
Refill station for propane tank. 
Less than 4$/gallon

name: Artesian Pool
description: Great for a cool dip on a hot day. Day use only. No fires. Water not potable!!

name: Upper Sweetwater Campground
description: 6 sites available at this established BLM campground all with covered picnic tables. Great for rigs of any size. Clean pit toilets, about 40 min from Pinnacles. Hard to believe that places like this are FREE!

name: Abandoned KMart Parking Lot (now Planet Fitness)
description:
We checked in at the Albertsons grocery store next door and we were told that truckers stay overnight here. So we did it as well with no problems. It was quiet and fairly dark.

Edit: not so quiet anymore, at least on a Saturday night. Drag racing + loud music.

name: Veterans Memorial Park and area, Lake Charles
description:
A beautiful park on the Lake Charles waterfront.  We parked in one of the several parking lots available in the area. There are no signs warning against overnight parking or camping.  In fact, one city parking sign said parking was allowed anywhere in the city that was a "designated parking spot". No maximum number of hours was posted anywhere.
The park has flush bathrooms, electric outlets (you've got to look around for them, but they're here.  They work at night when they turn the lights on), and a play ground on the far South side of the waterfront (Millennium Park) for the kiddies.  Close to restaurants, bars, and downtown shopping.  Beautiful view across Lake Charles.  Really good find for city parking.
Big Rigs won't fit.  Incognito is best.  We parked in our self converted GMC Savana.  Campervans and small RVs should be just fine!
No generators please.
The pictures are not exactly where we parked, but are close to several parking lots.  You could also park streetside without issue.

name: Street near beach
description:
Just a street where u can park for free as long as u want. You also can stay for overnight. Noisy at the day and quiet at night. Really nothing special but ok for one night and during the day. Walk distance to beach: 5 min. 
We stayed with our RV and had no issues.

name: James Canyon Campground
description: 2 sites for smaller RV under 16 feet.  Tent site available across metal bridge, but motorized vehicles can not go over bridge  Picnic Tables and fire pit available at each site.   Fuel and limited supply available 2 miles east on the town of Mayhill or 15 miles west in Cloudcroft.   Cellphone service is either sporadic to no service at all depending on your phone carrier.

name: Montgomery Bell State Park, Tennessee
description: A lovely state park with flush toilets, hot showers and laundry facilities. It is about 10 miles off I-40 with good signage. And sign-in wifi. Not sure of the cost but for a tent site it may be $14 with no services. $39 full hook-up.

name: Myrtle st St Simons Island
description: What a find!  one street from Cedar , either street is great. Quiet except for the sound of roiling surf. :) No signs. No move on.  First picture is the Myrtle street parking lot, and the second is the place where we stayed.

name: Cherokee Casino
description: Space for about 5 rigs. Full hookups available, garbage and easy access to restaurants in the casino and gas station. 2 night stay allowed. Keep it clean!!!!  Free!!!!!!

name: Off of hole in the rock road
description: Next to a gated cattle run. Somewhat flat, but very dusty and sandy. On BLM land so pets are OK.

name: Free campsite in Coconico NF
description: Free campsite. No amenities. Very quiet.

name: Canyons of Escalante RV park
description: All services, big rig friendly. Accepts Good Sam cards for 10% discount. Also has cabins however many are "dry cabins" (basically a bed, step up from a tent). Owners are very nice also. Laundry available, however it is a bit pricey.

name: Chevron gas station with very large paved overnight parking
description: Football size paved parking used by large RV and truckers.  Secure but trucks engines can loud depending where one parks.   About an hour from Las Vegas

name: Osage Hills State Park
description:
Very nice state park. Hiking trails, nice swimming pool, Tennis courts, ball field.Fishing, bass, crappie, catfish and perch. Boats can be rented. 23 tent sites and 20 RV sites. Dump station, They have nice wall tent "cabins and stone cabins. Toilets and showers with hot water.
No cell phone coverage. There is a pay phone..

We were there off season. There were a few RVs and 8 or 10 tent campers. Quite. They lock the gates at night.

Per web site:
One bedroom cabin (sleeps up to four people): $90 plus tax, per night.
 Two bedroom cabin (sleeps up to six people): $105 plus tax, per night.
 Pet fee: $15 per night. 
 Two-night minimum required on weekends.
 There is a $25 per night holiday fee and a 3 night minimum for Memorial Day weekend, Independence Day and Labor Day weekend. 

 Swimming pool admission:
 Adults (12 & over): $4 
 Children (11 & under): $3

 Camping rates: 
 Tent sites: $14 
 RV sites with electric & water hookups: $22

name: Sunbelt Rentals
description: Fill (will top up) standard North American bbq tanks.  Great service.  Reasonable prices.

name: Monongahela NF - Gandy Creek
description: Dispersed camping on Gandy Creek.  Alongside road so can get busy but pretty rushing creek.  No facilities.

name: Monongahela NF
description: Grant’s Branch.  Absolutely beautiful and peaceful spot on branch off of Gandy Creek.  Right near babbling brook but much better than the other sites along here because it is off the road and out of sight of the road.  Fire rings.  Tons of firewood.  Hiking trail along other side.

name: Durbin - Greenbrier River
description: Quiet spot off the road amongst the rhododendrons and hardwoods.  Right on the river.

name: Whitney Pocket
description: Free BLM site in Gold Butte National Monument. Lots of sites with fire rings. Beautiful site. Road to Whitney Pocket is paved, but very rough and has lots of potholes, but you don't need a 4WD - despite the signs that suggest you do.

name: Lookout Mountain Summit
description: The road up is a rutted but was passable in April in our 4wd SUV with standard clearance. On the last leg up, there were a few snowy and muddy spots that may prove more challenging if there have been recent rains. In the summer it is a breeze to drive up with a 2WD sprinter. No services but amazing panorama views for sun set and sun rise!

name: Earthquake Fault
description: A 6 mile unmaintained road with various earthquake fault sights. The site shown was at the first turn off after only a couple of miles. We camped in the gulley / ravine but there is a nice photo opp by driving the trail to a steep peak. How far you decide to go might be vehicle weight and bravery dependant. Super quiet, just a couple of cows and the navy jets for company.

name: Camping World - near Roanoke
description: Free dump station and non potable water available 24/7.  Store closed Sundays.  Propane available when store is open.

name: Camping World - Roanoke
description: Propane refill - standard bbq tanks.  Opening hours attached.

name: Jackson Creek Fish Camp
description: Primitive campground with groomed area for tents right along the Columbia river.  Paved area with picnic table and bbq pit.  No campfire area.

name: Short Fence trailhead (BLM)
description: A small, quiet BLM trailhead parking lot for the Short Fence trail. Legal and almost no one passes by at night. Very quiet and calm area to spend a few nights. 35 min from Pinnacles. Not a huge spot so probably not ideal for bigger rigs. No amenities. FREE

name: Fire Rock Navaho Casino
description: Overnight parking okay in west end of lot. Trains, trucks, and traffic present but slept just fine.

name: East Creek Road
description:
Take the turn to East Creek, then right at the fork with the scratched out unreadable sign. There's a mostly level pull out on the left side of the road up to East Creek in Humboldt National Forest. We stayed there in our truck camper, could fit 2 vehicles or small RV. Has a stone fire pit and is surrounded by trees. Very quiet. Nice views. 
Free.

name: Pyramid Lake Paiute Reservation - $32
description:
Pyramid Lake is gorgeous. PERMIT Required for camping on tribal lands. $32 per vehicle per night. You can buy the permit online https://pyramidlake.us/permits

No fires by non-tribal visitors and camping must be done at least 100’ from shore. There are several gravel roads along the south west side of the lake where you can access potential camp sites. There are a few spots near the road with picnic tables or pit toilets. Get more privacy parking with no services.

There is also a marina with a $50/night RV Park in Sutcliffe.

name: Bisti Badlands - Parking north
description:
Parking north of Bisti Badlands. 
No amenities. 
The dirty road to join the other informal campsite of Bisti Badlands is cut, use the main road.

name: Graves Creek Campground
description:
Really nice campground with a lot of spots. Some are right next to the river. Nearby the campground there is a nice hiking trail. Restrooms included. We were the only one in February and we didn’t have to pay (but you pay $20 in high season)
(Pets are allowed on campsite, but not on the hiking trail)

name: National Forest near Monticello
description: A grassy spot in an oak grove. Little bumpy. Rock fire ring. No facilities. We slept here one night without any problem. It would fit more cars/campers.

name: American Legion Free Campground
description: A campground by donation in Wisdom, MT with water, outhouses and a kitchen shelter

name: Fuelman Exxon (+propane)
description: $10 rv dump no water pay inside to get a key. you can use a Credit Card or cash. Easy to access. They have propane as well (American connections).

name: Meteor Crater RV Park
description:
Very nice and well maintained campground close to the Meteor Crater. Clean Bathrooms with hot showers, laundry and good Wifi. You can buy some food and drinks in the store. They have places for all sizes of RV and Vans. Also tent sides are available. We paid USD 32.- (before tax) for our van (incl. water and electricity). We absolutely recommend this place.

ADMIN NOTE: User reports "arrived at 8:30pm and was closed!?! There’s no information in the website or google maps about this issue! Very disappointing!!"

name: Lookout Mountain Rd
description:
This is a perfect campsite with 360 degree views on a flat knoll hidden off to the left 1.7km up Lookout Mountain Rd as you approach a cattleguard a few km in from the highway. There are noticeable tracks leading off to the left of the main road which disappear as you approach the campsite 100m later. It is absolutely peaceful up here with no signs of parties or frequent activity. No vehicles went by during the time we were here.
No highway noise however you can see it in the distance from the knoll.
There is room for several rigs however there is no shade or privacy on this spot. There are likely other spots like this higher up Lookout Rd.

name: Flying J
description: This is close to downtown Indianapolis and just off Interstate 465 on the south side where it intersects with Highway 37. This location has a large parking lot with two separate sections; one is mostly used by truckers and the other is used for RV, vans, and cars. Arby’s is adjacent to the building and McDonald's and Taco Bell is close by. It's pretty quiet also. It offers showers (for a price), restrooms, driver services and more!

name: Very quiet Pullout
description: Very quiet pullout directly to the street. You have a lot of space for a tent and for fire. The streat ends 1000m ahead and so its a good free spot for a night.

name: Woodruff Narrows/Bear River access area
description:
State land camp site. Toilets and right on the lake. Good place to stop while traveling through.
Free

name: BLM Land at Dark Canyon Road
description: Camping on BLM Land north of Carlsbad Caverns Nationalpark. Several spur roads turn off from Dark Canyon Road. There were some more Campers around. The place is more quiet than along the National Park Highway, but the view is not as nice.

name: Williams Road to Gypsum Dunes, Dell City
description: Wild Camping in the desert along Wilson Road leading to the Gypsum Dunes of Guadelupe Mountains National Park. Absolutely quiet with a nice view of the mountains. 2 very usable bars with att and a small mimo antenna facing west. Nothing on my Verizon cell.

name: Military Road Trailhead, Gila National Forest
description:
Wild Camping in Gila National Forest along Spirit of the Mountains Scenic Byway before going down into the valley of the Gila River. Nice views of the Gila Wilderness. Absolutely quiet.

Several pullouts coming up the main road, but this takes you further from the road.

name: Camp
description: I-17 exit for Hwy 169. Go East for numerous camp spots. Many for big rigs. This spot is a little further back and quiet. Not for big rigs.

name: Juan Miller Road, Apache-Sitgreaves National Forest
description: One of many absolutely great Campsites at Juan Miller Road leading to Blue Creek in the Apache-Sitgreaves National Forest. Great view, absolutely remote and quiet.

name: XXX Ranch Road, Apache-Sitgreaves National Forest
description: 2 WD Trailhead to Blue River Canyon and Hannah Hot Spring. We came back from our day hike to the Hannah Hot Spring (24,2 km + 9,4 km along the very rocky Jeep Road) at 8 pm, so we didn't move the car anymore.

name: Eagle Peak Road, Gila National Forest
description: Wild Camping in Gila National Forest at Eagle Peak Road near Reserve. Absolutely quiet. Great view.

name: Socorro at Rio Grande River
description:
Along the dam of the Rio Grande in Socorro are a couple of quiet sites. We moved a bit south from the main entrance at Otero Avenue to be more private.
Full in garbage, don’t even think about bringing anything over 20foot not room for it.

name: road side on hwy 1 heading north (opposite side of the beach)
description: section of road has RVers and vans obviously being slept in(unknown how long they are here). site good for one night, maybe two. road is noisy, and traffic is nonstop

name: grasse lake
description: In the middle of nature with a lot of possibilities. The way a little broken but it passable. After 8 miles unpaved road we arrived at the lake ... no amenities but fires allowed.

name: Lake Isabella
description: Parking at the lake, very quiet, lots of places.

name: Parking librairie
description: quiet place. no facilities. Near park and library

name: Valley of fire free dump station  (+water)
description: Free dump and free portable water near the campgrounds of the valley of fire park! Entrance fee for the whole park: 10 Dollar.

name: Nashville Education Association paying car park
description: Pay at the machine with cash or card. $11 24 hrs. Railway line nearby with great v slow moving trains. Also horses next door which are used for pulling carts so slight smell. V central & restaurant just across the road.

name: Wilkins Creek Overlook
description: Up a couple of switchbacks and a fairly rutted road you will find a sweet little spot for an overnight stay, you can hear the interstate below you but it’s not horrible.

name: Stan Hedwall Park
description: Rough Community Park, RV sites, water and electricity, up to 50 amps. Toilets and showers. Cheap, $20.00.

name: Camping World - Colfax
description: Free    dump    station.  Non     potable     water.

name: Coastal Car Care
description:
Excellent mechanic. Family owned. Honest and affordable. I’ve had them perform work for me and several referrals I sent to them. All had the same experience as I did with fair prices and high quality service. 

Personally I had brake work, coolant system work, and evap work done.

name: Lowes Camping at Bowie
description: Stayed here one night. No signs to say NO Camping. Didn’t get moved on :) Toilets inside Lowe’s. WiFi average.

name: McIllroy WMA
description: FREE campsites maintained by WMA, we camped at the site nr. 6, which is big with 3 fire rings. There are in total 23 campsites spread accross the forest. Need to drive a couple miles on a gravel road to get there. Really quiet place.

name: Berryman Trail Campground
description: FREE campground in the Mark Twain National Forest, 7 or 8 spots with table and fire ring. Restrooms but no water and no trash service. Trails (hike, horse ride, bike) nearby. Paved road. Very quiet.

name: The Cove Campground
description:
The Cove is a privately owned, certified tree farm. The Cove covers about three thousand acres ranging from one 
to three thousand feet in altitude in the Appalachian Mountains and a part of The Cove has been developed to 
provide outdoor recreation for the general public. It is the desire of the present owners to share the charm, 
solitude, and beauty of The Cove with those who love the outdoors.

name: Walmart - Greensboro
description: Surprisingly   quiet!     Great   for a   night.

name: Sundance Wal-mart
description: Loud speakers play music 24/7. Lots of Rvs here. Right off the 10. Good for a night.

name: Berryman Campground. Free.
description:
Beautiful Berryman Campground in Mark Twain National Forest. 8 spots in the forest with picnic tables and fire pit. Plenty of wood for fire in the forest. Pit toilets. No water. Ozark Trailhead. 
There are some other free campgrounds in the NF as well.

name: Waverly Lake. Free.
description: It is allowed to camp for 4 days at the recreation area of Waverly Lake. A few spots between trees, maybe a handful. Pit toilets, trash bins, picnic tables, fire pits, boat launch. Very quiet.

name: Aubuchon Hardware
description: Easy to find, friendly people, fair rates.

name: Canadian, TX County Fairgrounds Campground
description: Ok place to spend the night. $20 self-registration. And, I'm Canadian :-)

name: Happy Time RV Park
description: Really nice, well-maintained campground with some long-term residents, really close to the highway. Not so much that the noise is a problem.  Pilot/Flying J across the street. Big Rig friendly. Pull-thrus. Call in advance, full most nights. Really friendly and helpful Manager (Sheila). Laundry, free hot showers and swimming pool. Like Sheila said, "we're not trying to be the Ritz", ticks all our boxes at $25 a night full hook up! Great spot!

name: Oak Flat Campground
description: Nice quiet shaded campground, free with the America the beautiful card

name: camp site
description: nice little site off the road. has been stocked with wood, please don't use it all of you visit.

name: Sylvan City Park
description: Municipal campground with water, electricity and a bath house. Close to downtown night life and amenities. Nice playground for kids, plus a fishing pond on site.

name: Perry Lake
