We found a road while looping through the campground that climbed up above the lake. set up camp here. away from the loud campers and great morning views of the lake.

name: Rest Area
description: MODERATOR NOTE: Place removed because camping is illegal here.  Signs posted and enforced

name: Best Holiday Trav-L Park
description: RV Park outside Chattanooga with full hook ups, bathroom, shower, and pool

name: Group camping meadow in San Juan nf.
description: Large meadow, short and steep entry to the site.

name: El rito
description: Three and a half  miles dirt road in the National Forest road outside of El rito. Great fun climbing destination if you're looking to spend a day on the wall

name: Parking lot for Fallen Roof Ruin Trail
description: Nice spot in the trees on a very quiet road.  No ammenities and BLM permit is required for day use.  Sign said no fee for camping in car at trailhead.

name: Muley Point - Alternative
description:
There were quite a fee cehicles at Muley Point so we took this rught turn before the point and came to another point on the rim that was just as beautiful but secluded.  you need some clearance to get back here, but not 4x4.

We got a weak GSM roaming signal, but our friens with Verizion bounced from nothing to 4 bars of 4G.

no ammenities at all; just great views.

name: Deschutes National Forest - Sisters
description: Pulled of onto NFD Road 060 off of nfd road 15. 10 min West of Sisters. Quiet spot back in pine forest.  Really scenic. Looks like others are camping up the road.

name: Sudz unleashed self service dog wash
description: self service dog wash, $10/10 minutes. In the back behind the muffler shop .

name: Rock Island Land Co.
description: direct quote from sign. " Rock Island Land Co. private property. no discharge of firearms. pack out your trash. 5 night maximum." enough room for maybe 2 small to medium rigs.

name: Frisco visitor center
description: free water(drinking fountain so if your water bottle is big might not work, filled my 5 gallon without a problem) and public restrooms

name: DaNgLeBoNg boondock
description: Pull out at the end of the road that fits one vehicle. low-key.

name: The Truck Shop
description: Toyota specialized mechanics. Best in San Diego to repair Tacoma trucks.  These guys are serious 4x4 enthusiasts and never try to sell you on a part or repair they don't need.  I've had them actually not charge a friend for a repair because it was easier than they thought.

name: Moab Rim RV Campground
description:
Spots: 
- Full hookups, electricity/ water only or dry camping
- leveled 
- benches and tables
- BBQs
- some spots with shade 
- don’t use the spots near the high voltage lines, you can feel the electricity on the metal of the car 

Bathrooms:
- hot showers (no additional charge) 
- clean toilets
- soap and paper 

Wifi: 
Yes, not the best but good enough for WhatsApp, Facebook etc 

Price :
35 USD with electricity and water 


435-259-5002

name: Lyon Ponds FS Rd
description: Lyon Ponds Fs Rd Camp near 3 small lakes and a creek. Just off the highway but far enough you can't hear the cars. We stayed for one night, not much wood around but there are small stone fire rings. Road is accessible for all cars.

name: Steamies Burger Bar
description:
In the little touristy town of Telluride.

Burgers start at 5.95$/7.95$double and fries start at 3.95$

Burger was really food but the fries were pretty bad(being nice)

name: Tent camping at foot of Black Bear Pass
description:
Park at the switchback and walk across the dodgy wooden bridge to a nice flat spot overlooking Telluride. Site accessible from Telluride by 4wd trucks and SUV based rigs. Perfect for motorbikes.

10,000ft - great views of the mountains and bridal waterfall.

Note: Black Bear Pass beyond this point is a one way trail from other side and doable by Jeep and dual sport bike only.

I

name: Thaxton rest erea
description: Very clean bathrooms! My reason for the stop. I would have attempted a tent out if needed. There are pick nick tables and a grill also. Very good shade for hot days.

name: Chevron gas station
description:
Gas station with possibility to refill propane. 

Caution, they have a minimum to refill propane so we had to pay for 3 gallons even our tank is only 1 gallon :(

name: B.A.Steinhagen Lake Camp
description: There is a campground right at the lake, but it was closed when we were there. (Probabely open only in peak summer season?!?). But there are three tables in a well maintained grassy and shaded area right before the entrance gate. You can park in the parking lot and use tables and lake access (swimming) or you put your car on the grass right next to the tables. We have no idea if camping is allowed here, but there ar no signs and the residents from the neighbouring houses did not send us away. Very quiet, clean & spacious. An almost perfect camp!

name: Canyon village campground
description:
Quiet and nice campground under trees. Open only from 25 may each year. Dumpstation and water available. Restrooms. Showers only at the entrance and only 2 showers per day per site even if you are 6 people. 30$ per site per night which is expensive for what you get but in the middle of the national park. 
Low ATT reception.

name: road side vogel state park
description:
Large paved roadside with additional space on the grass
Not much traffic here, quiet night
in the park you have free open WiFi
near the spot a table with running water and electricity, picnic tables and BBQ spots
trails, toilets, lake to swim with beach all free
also they have a laundry place you can use

name: forest roadside by helton creek
description:
not far from helton creek falls, a camping spot down at creek level and a large space to park vehicle on the road side
beautiful nature and a bit humid

name: Laundry west end
description:
Washers and dryers         
Open until 10pm 
(locks at 10, if you're inside after 11pm alarm goes off and police are called)

name: Maverick gas station Dump
description: There is a dump station here at the Maverik. You can dump for free and take water. Thank you Maverik!

name: Martin Luther King Jr Way, north of E Yesler Way
description: Flat unrestricted street parking. Nothing special, but a spot where you can park your rig for a few days. Other vehicle dwellers are often found in this location. Can be loud with car traffic during the week. Weekends are quiter.

name: Chiriaco Summit Dry Camp Area
description: Great little free campground courtesy of owners of the restaurant and gas station here. No frills, just several nice level campsites tucked behind the George Patton Museum. Comfortable distance away from the main highway noise. Great Patton Museum right in front of the camp. Several spare military tanks are parked right in front of the campground. There was a camp host there when we visited. Services are just about 100 yards or so right off the freeway. I was very impressed with this nice little place.

name: Charleston Marina RV Park
description:
$ 40.48 / night. Quiet. Nice place to stay during the Covid-19 Pandemic times. : Great location / great internet. Clean / Security 

Cons: It’s one big asphalt parking lot

name: Codgers Cove RV Park, Pierre SD
description: 15 min from Pierre SD on Oahe reservoir. Across from marina. Absolutely horrible check in system. No office. Reserved on line to find our site occupied. They would not accept reservation by phone, directing us to online. Website showed park empty with every site available. Arrived to find Park almost full with seasonals. Finding staff and a site took 45 minutes of frustration. Full hookup, no washrooms or showers. 50 amp. $25. Newer park with no large shade trees. Campers who have a boat and enjoy fishing will find this place a Nervana.

name: Hogan's Corner Laundromat
description:
- Nice laundromat
-Competitive prices
- Some parking out front
- Generally no sketchy folks hanging around
- Near a very nice park (Ravenna)

Hours: 7:30am to 10:30pm, everyday

name: Manti La Sal National Forest
description: Quiet, nice and level place, surrounded by trees and rocks. Two spots with fireplace.

name: Chiwawa River
description: A beautiful boondocking spot right on the Chiwawa River, just off Chiwawa River Road. Abundant wood, rock firepits from previous campers. Stock up in Plain on the way there. Our longbed Dodge Ram was able to negotiate a sharp turn just after leaving the road but anything longer, or a trailer, will not make it. Lots of spots in this area for car or tent camping. Likely a known spot for locals so it might be busy in the summer time.

name: Beckler River
description:
This is a boondocking location. DO NOT confuse this with Beckler River Campground which you will pass on the way to this location if you're coming north.

Nice spot beside the Beckler River at the confluence with Rapid River, just off Beckler Road. High tree canopy of dense old growth forest. Lots of hiking nearby, and of course the two rivers.

We were in our Dodge Ram with a camper. A few rock fire pits in the area. Tents would work well, or a small trailer if you can back it in.

name: alternate rest area
description:
the gold rest stop is closed for consruction.
trucks stop for over night about 1 mile east near the gas station and CHP. Ridge road exit. near Dutch flat RV resort

name: Multnomah Falls parking lot
description:
Due to the devastating fires in the Gorge area in 2017, many backcountry roads and camping near here are closed. 💔

This is basically a rest area. It’s noisy - between the two sides of the Hwy 84 - but it’s free. There’s a paved trail here that goes up the famous Multnomah Falls. Restroom available in the lodge at the base of the falls.

name: Gros Ventre Campground
description: $47 for site with no electricity or water. Toilets. Moose and bears have been seen in the site. picnic tables, BBQ, shaded wooded site.

name: Black Rock Road
description: Take the exit for Black Rock Road. On the right is a dirt lot. There were about 10 semis when we showed up and a couple vanlifers. Felt very safe for a night here.

name: Walmart
description: The quietest Walmart parking lot we have slept in. No loud semi’s, no loud generators, a few noisy cars & trucks but nothing overwhelming and mind you we stayed on a Saturday night. Slept a solid 9 hours and after days on the road it was much needed.

name: Radium SWA
description: Top of the world campsite. Windy but almost 360 views.

name: Maverick Gas Station
description:
Dump and non-potable water for free.
The water spigot is in the truck diesel pump area between pumps 17 and 22.

name: Red Lake
description: Beautiful little lake on national forest land. Easily accessible with any type of car. Enough space for a camper.

name: F525 - half way to Palatki Heritage site
description: There area couple of large car park style dispersed camping sites on the F525 but this one is tucked away a little bit and small, single group - one or two vehicles only. One or two bars LTE too on ATT and Verizon.

name: Silos Pink Flamingo Grill
description: Great food Inc veggie burgers, all served up in a pink school bus! You can use KOA's free fast WiFi (next door) too

name: Big lot across from a hotel casino.
description: Nice rv spot just off hwy 50. A level lot the casino owns and let's campers use for free

name: Free dump point between tourist info and museum
description: While stopped at the tourist information centre in Newport we spotted that there is a dump station next door, before the museum. Appears free, not potable water.

name: Pull out to river
description:
a small piece of asfalt down to the river, leading to a field.
slept here for 1 night.
After talking to locals this was the best place to sleep in our van.

name: Oak Harbor Walmart
description: 24hr Walmart. Seems fine for one night. I read elsewhere online that they allow overnight parking for one night. I stayed in a car far from the entrance and had no problems.

name: Spring cove campground.
description:
Was not sure on the category for this campground. I think it is a bit spendy. $37 a night?  They collect in the AM.  This is a forest service campground. It is on Bass Lake. There are 3 or 4 of them this is in the middle of the lake west side.  There is a rustic resort nearby and some nice ski boats on the lake.  My guess good fishing and very scenic. 

There are toilets, water not sure on showers.  For our 4 wheel pop up the sites are pretty level. Some overlook the lake,  which were more crowded. I went to site 45 in an opening surrounded by huge redwoods?  Very private and quite.  There are fire pits and picnic tables.  For an organized campground this is an A. We normally wild camp but could not find much around here. Found this on “park advisor” app. 
4 bars cell ATT.

name: Alpine Meadow Campground
description: Nice camping in the forest. Small lake to fish trout (sport fishing). They have water but no dump station. 20us$ a night, with anual pass 10us$.

name: New Gold Butte Rd
description: Camp above the Virgin River overlooking the flood plan.

name: Maytag service laundromat
description:
Laundromat. Big parking lot.
--
Laverie automatique. Grand parking.

name: East West Trailhead
description: Just of the highway. Paved access. You can hear the highway traffic, but the forest is just gorgeous. Ferns, horsetails, and at the bottom the Chulitna river. Picnic benches and fire rings.

name: Buffalo Park
description: Beautiful campsite on Sarvis Creek overlooking Buffalo Park. There are also plenty of other free campsites along County Road 19.

name: san juan nf road 567, near mancos
description: wide open field with aspens surrounding and views to the west looking over mancos.  seems to be mainly used by utvs/ATVs, maybe popular with hunters during the season.  road to this site will require high clearance, maybe 4x4 depending on conditions of the road. we had slow Verizon LTE, but enough for checking email.

name: Bear Valley Car Park
description:
Car park/ Picnic Area for Bear Valley. Only open in Summer.
Arrived late, Left early. Do not suggest staying long term. Car park is right next to Sheriff station.
Starts to get very noisy around 6:30-7AM.
Port-a-loo available. Gas station/ convenience store open 9-5pm. 
No reception for T-mobile.

name: Sunsets West Co-op Eatery
description: Nice little food co-operative with organic coffee & home made food. A bistro in a small town (next to great haircuts), and down the road from the public library. WIFI

name: Fillers Resort and campground
description: Nice established resort.  Fullers established in 1887 on Clearlake.

name: Lake Catherine state park
description: Full hook ups ~ 38 usd all including beautiful lake, 10 for canoe 1 hour. Many options paddle boat and can even rent a motorboat. Ranger talks every day 2-3 times in various topics. Good option for at least couple of days. 30 minutes to famous baths

name: Olancha Campsite
description: Resturant and Camping a little bit before these coordinates. Just off the main road you can't miss it. We didn't stay there but as there wasn't a camping entry on here for a bit I thought worth adding. They have glamping sites.

name: Parking lot for the Skyline Trail
description: Small parking space for about 8 cars. Start of a one hour loop hike. We stayed one night and had no problems. You are allowed to tent camp in the park so people would need to leave their cars here overnight. Near residential area. Not for tents but you could walk a while into the park. There is a map which says where you can camp. There is also a sign which says they hope to improve the parking lot and add toilets.. Take Skyline Drive and follow it to the site

name: Prineville Reservoir State Park
description: There are numerous year round camping opportunities within the state park on the reservoir.  In the developed areas there are deluxe cabins with full amenities, full hook up RV sites and tent sites.  Flush toilets and hot showers are also available.  For those who like to rough it, there are many primitive drive in and boat in campsites around the reservoir as well.

name: Sundance rest area
description: Dumpstation and potable water available for free. Clean bathrooms and quiet for overnight parking.

name: Walmart
description:
Quiet parking lot in a 24/24 Walmart.
Not busy and clean.

name: Birmingham South
description: RV park, 30amp hookup, dumping, cable tv hookup, showers, pool, general store...

name: Wawona - in Yosemite
description: At #26. Overlooking the river. Quiet. Not overlanding but saves about 2 hours getting into the park.  No cell service. We got in as a space available from a cancellation. The cost was $22 as I recall and 50% off for a seniors.

name: Kanab by the reservoir
description: Very nice and calm spot. Nice views of the cliff and reservoir. People come in the evening to walk their dogs and ride bikes on the paved trail. Trash can onsite. Excellent cellular reception.

name: BLM- Round Mountain Dispersed Camping
description: Dispersed camping 1/4 ml just past the regular campsite. Some firerings, tree cover, plenty of space even for an RV (not sure how rough the road gets past initial 1/2 mile)

name: B.L.U.E.S.
description:
A little slice of Americana. Oldest blues bar in Chicago. They have live music every night. 

If you want to experience the blues scene in Chicago this is a great place to do it.

Dive bar, small and can be crowded but great overall experience.

10$ cover

name: Patrick Henry Boat Launch
description: This is a nice quiet spot not too far from richmond.  Large parking area, a bit sloped.  Shade from trees.  Grassy area for tents.  Not sure if camping is officially allowed but we had no issues for a night.  Kayakers came in the morning to launch their boats.

name: Toketee campground
description: Forestry campground on the road to Toketee falls. Sites on A loop in trees next to the river, B loop along a meadow. All with benches and fire pits. Pit toilets available, price $10 per night or $5 per night with interagency pass. No more than 20-30 sites total, all beautiful.

name: Bull Mesa Pullout
description: Large campsite/pullout on the side of the road up Bull Mesa with nice views of surrounding area. Good proximity to the highway; convenient stop between SLC and Moab.

name: Blue Pool Wash Corral
description:
Old corral on BLM ranching land, two minutes from the highway. Access from dirt road on the west side of Highway 89 just south of Blue Pool Wash. Close the gate behind you; corral is 200 yards/m along a dirt road.

We accessed it with a 2WD Sprinter; not recommended for big rigs or low-clearance vehicles.

name: Windwhistle Campground
description: BLM Campground, $15/night, great view, some shade

name: Ninilchik State Park
description: $20 a night. 35-40 established camp grounds

name: Walmart parking lot
description: Walmart parking lot with free wifi if you park near the Pizza Hut

name: Wasta RV campground 5$
description: For only 5$, sites with electric hook-up. Potable water near the dumpstation.  Good ATT reception. Very close to the Interstate but not very noisy.

name: Flat, open camping spot
description: Large, flat, open camping spot off FR 29N22 past the Heart Lake TH. Great views, very quiet, some bugs. No services but there is a creek a short way down the hill from the spot.

name: National Forest FREE Camping
description: Free camping all along this road - 127A.  The first site on the left is the only one that is big rig friendly with large turnaround. Our 2wd Transit van camper did fine about 5 minutes up the road over rocky sections to a mellow and private site.  No water in early June - drought season, so check in at the Cedar Creek Ranger Station for any wildfire/closure info.

name: Cedar Creek Road
description: Cedar Creek Road has it all!  Water spigot across the road from the Ranger Station at the entrance of the right hand gravel parking lot.  You can also overnight in this lot for free. There are TONS of awesome biking and hiking trails that start right there - an EPIC downhill mountain biking trail that you can shuttle up to and paid camping spots up the road, restrooms at all the picnic areas, and free camping at the trailhead parking lot at the very end of the road < well maintained gravel, relatively easy cul-de-sac to turn around in if you are a larger rig. Ours is 15' and we were fine.

name: Boiling Springs State Park
description: Nice clean camp - electricity + Water On Saturday there were plenty of sites. Went for a short walk behind campers saw few deers.

name: Beaumont rest area
description:
Free dump station.
You can sleep here also FREE

name: Beaumont rest area
description:
Overnight parking allowed, on the 400. Spots for RVs and trucks. Flushing toilets and picnic area.

There is also a dump station and non potable water.

name: Round Lake
description: Beautiful forest campsites with view of snow covered mountains. Some of the campsites also overlook the lake. Most sites have fire rings, plenty of wood around. Not ideal for wider rigs because of brush on sides of road when coming in.

name: Park Lane BLM
description: Blm land off Park Lane. Primitive road to get in, kind of a steep berm on the side of the road big rigs wouldn’t make it. Lots of mesquite trees in the area. On second look, there appears to be another way to get in with less of a ditch to get over.

name: Grocery, Whittier, Alaska
description: Medium size grocery, all the usual stuff for a small town. The building also houses the museum which is excellent ($5). There is also a hardware store near the ferry terminal, a hotel, and another grocery reported to be in the big high rise building (I didn’t check it out).

name: Walmart. Superstore
description: Asked the store manager. She said no problems. Stay right down towards the hotel. Quiet and less traffic

name: Walmart Supercenter
description: The Walmart in Sheridan, Wyoming. It’s not open 24 hours but it says on Google that they allow overnight parking. We parked in the back with a few other campers. It felt safe with most cars clearing out after Walmart closed at 10pm. A few vans and campers parked at the backend closest to the road. The road is quiet at night. Feels safe.

name: Riverside Park - FREE
description: FREE 2 night camping in the town park, has nice bathrooms w/ showers, water for RVs, dump station, 10-25 spots to park, large grassy area, picnic tables w/ grills, next to the river. There are places to pitch a tent but they do warn about the sprinklers turning on at night (Monday, Wednesday, Friday, and Sunday).

name: Hot Sulphur Springs State Wildlife Area
description: Pleasant place at the edge of the Colorado River under shady trees. Several spots with fireplace. Camping is limited to 14 days. Free.

name: Gorge lake campground
description: Currently free. Will be going to $10 USD in 2019. Right on the river. Restrooms, fire pits, tables, boat ramp. Nice place

name: Black Mesa summit
description: 4.2 miles one way gets you here. Great views of Wild West especially on mile 3 ( also the only steep mile rest is fairly flat). Pit toilets at the parking. Take lots of water.

name: Rouge River Campspot in NF
description: Nice spot right on the Rogue River, away from the road. Easily accessible with 2WD. No big US style motorhomes, trucks with camper tops would be okay.

name: Buzzards Roost
description: Free campsite with 5 sites. Portable potty.

name: Tundra RV Park
description: great rv park with huge spaces owned and operated by a very nice couple just minutes from food, groceries,and shopping. they offer full hookups if needed, all spaces are level. they also offer tent sites

name: Pike National Forest
description: Beautiful meadow. Plenty of space for RVs of all sizes. 2wd on the road is good.  Verizon 4g lte. Amazing views.

name: Paisano Village RV Park & Inn
description:
New RV Park. The owner Chuck is an extraordinary gentleman. The sites are very wide concrete patches, 50 amperes. 
--
Nouveau RV Park. Le proprio Chuck est un extraordinaire gentleman. Les installations sont très larges avec patio de béton, 50 ampères.

name: Cherry Creek Gravel Pit
description: Great pull-out for a quick stop or for a few days of exploring around Durango. We stopped here in route to Moab and would definitely stay here again. Several rigs showed up later in the evening, but it was quiet and peaceful. Plenty of down wood if conditions are good for a fire. There was unfortunately a few mule deer carcasses that had been dropped there, but that is expected with spots so close to the highway.

name: Wild turn off
description: Dirt road turn off to the north of hwy 3. 6 or so individual camping spots. Most with little Rock fire rings. Noise isn't bad and theres a nice breeze that keeps most of the mosquitoes down. 4wd not necessary but higher clearance vehicles recommended.

name: Tri-valley gas
description:
Laundry and showers ($5) open 24/7
Showers are clean. Didn't use the laundry but there's several machines so I'm sure they'd have the ability to do a few loss. Next to an rv site on the side of the hwy.

name: Lake Erie State Park
description:
State Park.  Beautiful campsites on Lake Erie. 17$ w/out hookups $22 w/hookups.

June 9th 2018: non residents pay more, we didn't stay.

name: harvey county west park
description: shower. 30 amp hookups. fishing. dry camping. 21-10 dollars a night

name: Strawberry Hills viewpoint
description:
No signs prohibiting overnight parking and breathtaking views. Also a cool giant chuck wagon for funny photos.
MIGHT be a good boon docking site but we didn't test this theory :)

name: Dixie campground
description: Forestry campsite with about 10 sites dispersed around a forest clearing with a small creek nearby. There are pit toilets, picnic benches and firepits provided. The road to it is a little bumpy but easily passable, should be enough room for a full size RV. Cost is $8 per night or only $4 with an interagency or OAP pass. Maximum stay 14 days.

name: Cataract Gulch boondocking
description: Small turn around on the CR35 just feet away from the cataract gulch trailhead. Right on the cotton wood creek.

name: Norris campground - Yellowstone
description: It's a campground in the Yellowstone Nationalpark. Very central, so you can start from here your daytrips. The campground is 20$ per night, with water and flushable toilet- no electricity or showers. It's a come first, save first campground. I stayed here on the 4 July, so the campground was full from 8:30am!! The campground has also "walk in sites". So if you are a hiker or a bicycler and you stay there, the fee is only 5$

name: Canyon village campground - free dump station
description:
Free dump station at the entrance of the campground. 
Potable water.

name: Star Gazer Inn
description: At the gas station across the street from the Star Gazer Inn is a gas station that also offers public showers. Clean, lots of hot water, lots of pressure and for the low, low price of $2.00 honour system. Just a few minutes from the Great Basin National Park

name: Stoddard Creek Campround
description: Nice little FS campground right off interstate 15. Clean, quite and a great camp host.

name: Walmart carpark
description: Walmart. 2 miles Centre of city. Noisy with generators and trucks at night. But safe. Walmart here more expensive than most

name: Pine Flats, Boise National Forest
description: basic forest campground with amazing hot springs

name: national forest land. free camp
description: Plenty of space for all, up a dirt track. signed for  camping

name: Ocean city Screamin' Eagle campground
description: Great site, v friendly owner. $28 + tax for pitch without electricity or water. R V with electricity and water $35. Horses accommodated! 2 mins from beach. 2 mins from small supermkt & great take away coffee shop + woodcarving. Very small, quaint, quiet, friendly place. Delightful. ATMs. Trees and hillocks shelter you from any wind. Beautifully maintained. Picnic tables and firepits

name: Ron's alignment and auto works (labour 90 USD hour)
description:
Professional garage, able to do a wide range of work on cars and commercial vehicles (mechanical repairs, service, exhaust, alignment, etc)
info@RonsAlignment.com
(406)752-7290

name: Lake Meridith
description: Shoreside camping surrounding the North shore of man mad reservoir. No fees or permits required.

name: Lake Henry
description:
Shoreside camping and bluff camping surrounding the South shore of man mad reservoir. Primative restroom, no fees or permits required.
Boating and fishing.

name: Chicopee woods nature reserve
description: This is a nature reserve with a fair amount of trail systems, the trails work their  way towards a reservoir. The trails are decently maintained and is under the shade of the trees the whole time. Overall nice hike, we did the long loop and was about 5 Miles

name: Guebara Tank
description: Great views. Plenty of spots in National Forrest lands.

name: Route 103 Pull Off
description: This is just a large gravel pull off along Route 103. It's great here cause there's little traffic, awesome views, and Verizon internet is strong.

name: Metric Offroad
description:
Toyota Repair, Restauration, Parts & Sales. 2489 Commerce Blvd, Grsnd Junction.
Mike helped us on very short notice, he was quick and uncomplicated. He and his crew are very friendly, helpful and they did a great job for our Toyota.

name: Canyon Disperse Campground National Forest
description: This is a nice side FREE road dispersed campground in the Sequoia National Forest. Beside of the river. I think that you can fish 2 trouts in the river witout permit...ask before. You have to ask a permit for a fire. Fits one or two rigs.

name: Kirkham Campground and Hotsprings
description:
No overnight parking.
Signs say day use only.  7am to 9pm.

An established campground in Boise National Forest with around 20 sites, pit toilets and potable water for $15 a night. Biggest highlight are the hot springs which were often empty and very clean. Can also park outside the campground to just visit the hot springs!

name: Cedro Peak - 542DC4
description:
It is a loop, kind of, that contains a number of wild camp sites and a couple of iron fire pits. Quite nice, tucked in the tree. Very quiet and completely empty when we walked through. Decent ATT service, poor-ish Verizon despite claiming full LTE. This road would be tricky on wet conditions. If dry, doable in 2WD driving with caution. 

Look for the 542DC4 signs (service road 542 dispersed camping 4 I guess)

We got to a few spot before this one: all busy. So we went in this rough road and found a lot of sites. We didn’t very far because of the tricky road and we are in a 2 WD. We wouldn’t come here in wet conditions. Very quiet. No body else in this area. Fire pit but couldn’t make a fire because of the windy conditions. The ranger went by and waved at us.

name: Swift Creek State Dirt Road
description: State road that is gravel after taking baker street north along the east side of whitefish lake. There are a few pull outs once it turns to gravel. You're in the wilderness here.

name: Cedar Breaks National Monument Campground
description: nice campground in Cedar Breaks National Monument with tables and fire grills. $24/night. Open mid-June to mid-September depending on weather.

name: Coal Creek BLM
description: Free camping just outside if Cedar City.  On the creek with about 8 spots if you pack in pretty close.  Right before dark more people started filling in.  its clise to the highway, but the creek noise slightly drowns out the highway (if you get a spot by the creek).  Barely any T-Mobile service, no AT&T.  Considering nothing else nearby and the proximity to town, its not bad for a night.

name: Abandoned campground in the National Forest
description: There are about seven sites in a loop each very private and most with a fire ring made from rocks. Beautiful hidden forest sites.

name: Laundromat in Lima New York
description: Nice coin operated laundromat.  Clean,  restroom,  wifi.

name: South Fork campground/White River National Forrest
description: not really close to the water but it's near there is a natural spring to refill water cans at the entrance, you can boondock but you will need a 4x4 and it's up the road well before the campground entrance look at the picture I posted.

name: Outlaw 21
description: Stat forest campground. Great location. Off the road. Up high zero cell service. There is another place south of here off 395 Chris Flat. Nice but close to road. It is right on the river however which might be a plus.

name: Mulberry River bank wild camping
description:
Beautiful rocky spot alongside the Mulberry River just before you get to Oark. Coming from the south, you will cross the bridge over the river. Immediately to the right will be a discreet dirt road leading down into the woods. May be doable with 2wd but 4x4 recommended. 

We parked under the bridge for some shade, and enjoyed the warm river water, teeming with crawdads. Our kids loved it. Seems to be a spot popular with the locals, as we saw a few come and go during the day, but no one else camped there that night. As a bonus, we were treated to an amazing lightning bug display at night.

name: Lower Grays Meadow NF Campground
description: Nice Campground with shade and a creek at the Campground

name: Near HWY40
description: Very nice spot off hwy 40. No camp fires. A lot of places to pull off and set up shop. Pretty quiet but can hear the hwy now and again.

name: Echo Park Campground
description: A primitive camping ground in dinosaur monument national park. ~17 sites and a vault toilet. 10$ a night in summer and 6$ a night in winter. The path to get to it is an 11 mile dirt road that has 10-15 degree slopes so a high clearance 4x4 is recommended. Takes about 30-50 minutes to get to  and would probably be inaccessible after a rain. If you have the time definitely check these campsites out as they are some of the most beautiful I've seen.

name: Valley Spring Service
description:
Awesome repair shop for all your suspension needs with great staff and and very reasonable prices. Ask for Matt of Phil.
valleyspringservice.com

name: Picnic Area
description: Large open area surrounded by trees next to the river, and set back from the highway.

name: Cedro Peak - 552DC3
description: We preferred this to the DC4 Warren a few metres along the road. A smaller site, likely suitable for one group. One fire ring. There is a rocky back in area which gets you a nice view over the tree tops (better if you have a taller rig or pop up camper). We have a full ton pickup and pop up camper, i would not want to take anything much higher in here.

name: Missouri state fairground
description: Full hookups in 1000 sites, dry camp available too. Gets muddy in places if it has rained a lot.

name: Steele Creek Park
description:
User roadtriptime2018 reported on 8 November 2018: Nov 28, 2018 closed for season 
---
Campground maintained by Corps of Engineers. There are approximately 20 campsites in two areas. The campsites are free and the two boat ramps are free.  Each area has pit toilets.

name: Dispersed Camping near Mtn S Helens
description: Many spots along a well maintained Forest Service road. Some offer partial views of the mountain. Unfortunately trash left by other campers...mainly in the fire rings. Aside that a nice, quiet spot close to Ape Cave.

name: Forest Service Road 151, Carson National Forest, to Rio Chama
description: Wild Camping along Monastery Road (FR 151) leading to Rio Chama in Carson National Forest with a stunning view to the colorful rocks around Ghost Ranch. Perfect sunset location.There are 3 free forest service campgrounds along the Rio Chama and many bushcamping spots.

name: San Jose Badlands
description: Nice and quiet camping at the beautiful San Jose Badlands. There are 3 dips at the last 500 yards, so high clearance is useful.

name: Blanco Wash Badlands
description: Overnight parking at a small pulloff from the rocky dirtroad leading to several oil drilling stations with a great 180° view of the badlands east of Nageezi.

name: Bisti Wilderness
description: Camping in the beautiful Bisti Badlands at the end of the road ca 1 mile past the two parking lots for Bisti Wilderness. Nice view, quiet. You can camp at the Bisti Trailhead but there will be a lot more campers.

name: La Plata Badlands
description: Free Camping at La Plata Badlands north of Farmington near Jackson Lake Wildlife Management Area. The Dirtroad leads to several Oil and Gas Stations and is in good shape. The place is surrounded by badlands and would be nice, but there is quite a lot rubbish around.

name: Burnham Badlands
description: Wild Camping on Navajo Tribal Land along Indian Service Road 5080 at the Trailhead to Burnham Badlands. The view across the badlands to Shiprock is absolutely gorgeous but wild camping on Indian Reservations is always a bit tricky because you are not really on public land. We had a nice talk with a woman living some hundred yards away, so it was ok to stay here over night.

name: Recapture Pocket
description:
Perfect Camping at the beautiful Recapture Pocket. There are plenty of great hoodoos and rock formations around. It is really surprising not to find this great place mentioned more in the web or in travel books.

Very quiet.

name: Butler Wash, Pedestal Ruins Trailhead
description: Wild Camping at the trailhead to Pedestal Rock Ruins overlooking Butler Wash and the Comb Ridge. The view is absolutely gorgeous. The sandy sidetrack from Butler Wash Road up the steep hill requires 4 WD.

name: Bishop Tank at the Road to Stud Horse Point
description: Camping along the road to Stud Horse Point with a great view over Lake Powell and far enough away from the Highway 89 to be really quiet. There are more spots to camp further up the road and also at Stud Horse Point itself with a gorgeous view and great hoodoos. You will need 4 WD to reach Stud Horse Point but to this place 2 WD is fine. The road is quite sandy but ok with 2wd (no rain)

name: Olson’s Resort & Mason’s Lodge
description: Waterside camping for tents, RV’s, has some cottages and rooms for rent. With the beach at its side, it’s a beautiful spot. Has a marina, boat launch, trailer parking, bait & tackle shop, water access fuel for boats, small necessities store, gas pumps for car, onsite fish processing( fillet & freeze your catch), wifi, showers, and walk to a little diner down the road.

name: McKinney Spring
description:
Primitive campsite in Big Bend National Park, off of Old Ore Road (first campsite on the northern side of the road). 4WD with high clearance required to access. 
Great views back on the Chisos Mountains and a nice spring about 300m behind the campsite. One of the best primitive sites we’ve run across on our drives through the unpaved roads in Big Bend.
Must carry in your own water, permits are $12 and must be purchased from park headquarters before heading into the site.

name: Uinta-Wasatch-Cache National Forest
description: Nice places, some with fireplace, on forest road 715 to Strawberry Lake. 4x4 and high clearance recommended.

name: Tiogga National Forest sign, south side of Hwy167 good cell service.
description: Views of E Yosemite mountains parking in the desert.

name: Beaver Bay
description: This is a state campground. Very nice for a campground. It is on a beautiful lake. The sites are wooded and not on top of each other. $21 a nite no cell service.

name: Dixie Foreat outside of cedar breaks national monument
description: we checked out the campground at the monument and space were not level, small and close to each other.  plus, they wanted $24 for a toilet and water as only ammenities.  We decided to drive 3 miles away get on the forest service road and find our own perfect spot in the trees wirh no one around.   We saw dear and marmots from our spot.

name: Dump + water + propane (Shell)
description: We filled with gas and propane at shell station and used the dump and fresh water for free. Not sure if they charge to only dump or water.

name: Bend Public Library WI-FI
description:
ADMIN NOTE: Camping no longer allowed.
----
Excellent public library, fast free WiFi, restrooms...  also very nice place for kids to play. Parking lot across the street for free and unlimited hours. Great!

name: Dump + Water at Camping World
description: Free dump station and water at camping world store. Must have Good Sam membership (can be purchased in store). Big rig friendly.

name: Abquiu Army Corps of Engineers Campground
description:
Some nice spots overlooking the lake, managed by the US Army Engineers it seems. Several different camp areas, many with shade and tables, one section with water and electricity. There is a separate dump station, drinking water, hot shower and flush toilet block adjacent to the sites. Great ATT and Verizon coverage. Sites are $12 no electric / $16 electric.
Note: Closed over winter, check dates but looks like it is closed mid October to Mid April.

name: Dispersed Camping Site
description: You can park and camp along most of the main roads in the National Forest, so long as it’s within 300 feet of the road. This site has a fire ring, but no toilets or cell service (ATT) and is only a little ways past the “Black Forest NF” site. Mildly buggy, no mosquitos. This place is beautiful.

name: Fire pit wild camping
description: Wild camp site between Capital Reef and Lake Mead

name: Walmart
description:
Parking lot noisy but ok for now night 
Just over the border

name: Lee creek campground
description:
Nice campground near to Waterton Park
24$ : dry campsite / 28$ : power and water / 32$ : full hook up
Laundry : 2$ for washer and 1.25$ for dryer. 
Good WiFi

name: Forrest across from Navajo Lake
description: quiet and off the road, many spots ro choose from wirh rings.  some trash in some, others better.  barely a bar or 2 of GSM signal.  convenient to the lake from here.

name: Isle Casino Bettendorf IA
description:
FREE camping, no hookups. Right on the banks of the Mississippi River.

However because of flooding on the river they have two VERY LOUD pumps running that can be heard anywhere in the Casino parking lot.  DEC2019

name: Tower Rock Campground
description: Free campground in Shawnee National Forest. Sites have firering/grill and are flat. Right on the Ohio River however careful on the ‘beach’ as you might sink into the sand! Access in is paved however quite thin and windy (may not be suitable for big rigs). There is a drop toilet and a LOT of bugs at night!

name: Burkesville City Park
description: City Park on the Cumberland River. Free camping. Several sites.

name: Dog Creek Campground
description: Nice campground on the lake. Restrooms, showers hookups.

name: Clear Lake Campground
description: Beautiful lakeside US forestry campground with swimming and boating and lakeside campsites. Electric and water hookups for $26/night. Prohibition was never repealed here, however. For lakeside, it’s dry, dry, dry.

name: Up from Boat Launch
description: Cross bridge, drive past boat launch. Pit toilet at boat launch, just up the road past where paved road ends, there’s a clearing on Rt and a fire pit. Level place to park. Quiet spot to pull off.

name: Sumas R V park
description: V friendly welcome. Tent pitch with water and electricity $20. R V pitch $30. Slight noise from road & more from railroad but the lovely train horn makes up for it. WiFi at office, book exchange, laundry ($1.50 wash $1.50 dry). Showers a bit jaded but fine. 2 miles S from the Canadian border.

name: Haystack Mountain OHV Area
description: Actually an OHV area but it have 4 site for camping. site include a canopy, grille and fire pit.  one vault toilet.   PRICE is $5.00 per vehicle or $2.50 with an interagency pass

name: Keyhole State Park
description: This is a state park with several campgrounds throughout (check their website for fee's etc.) We stayed at the Cottonwood campground that overlooked the reservoir, amazing views, hiking, fishing, taking naps, all the good stuff..

name: Grand View Point Road/Island in the Sky BLM
description: Found a nice little turn off with nice level ground off the dirt road that heads south from Grand View Point Rd/Island in the Sky road. No facilities but if you have a 4x4 and don't mind boondocking this place is a must! Was able to get a 200kb/s LTE signal from the T-Mobile tower 140km northwest.

name: Champion Road Near Lee Canyon
description: Off of 158. There are a couple dozen camp sites in National Forest land on a dirt road.  Free and easy to get to.  Great way to escape Vegas heat.

name: Camp Powerline
description: Recreation area right off the hwy. mile marker #237. Clean carved out spots for miles with fire pitts. Ever present hum of high voltage power lines crossing through might be your only disrupter. Good spot for a night.

name: Albuquerque Airport
description: Free overnight parking at the ABQ airport. They allow 1 night stay, it's pretty quite as the airport is not that busy.  Plenty of room as it is on 3 acres. It looks like an empty field, but is specifically for RVs.

name: Bay horse campground
description:
BLM campground on the river, green and plenty of trees, pit toilets and lovely hosts. $10 per night or $5 with pass or off season. Near to Bayhorse ghost town.
Also the recreation area has a boat launch.

name: Deadmans Hole - free BLM campsite
description: No fee, maximum stay 14days. No cell service. Brand new pit toilets x2, picnic tables, and covering. Only 5 sites for big rigs or vans and another side for tent camping. No shade or trees besides the gazebo so it could get hot!

name: Stanley ranger station Dump station and potable water $5
description: Dump station just outside Stanley, follow signs to the ranger station and its on the right. $5 fee to use. Drinking water free. Closed in Fall and Winter.

name: Free campground
description: Concealed entrance and very rough track around the site. Unknown what facilities are available. Site at entrance reachable with a normal car, tent friendly and right tb the river.

name: Free campground
description: Entrance not signed, go slowly and keep eyes peeled! Lots of other free sites on this road also. Pit toilet available, spread out sites, some tent only and all near the river. Shaded from road by trees. No trash facilities or dump station so if you pack it in, pack it out! :)

name: Laundry and showers
description:
On the way to Redfish Lake, public laundromat and showers.
Prices: 
$2 for 5 minute shower
$2.50 each for the washers and dryers.
All only take quarters, change machine located outside the building.

name: Wellington Recreation campsite
description: $10 a night, near the river, far enough from the road to not be bothered by noise. All sites gravel and mostly level. NOT MAINTAINED TOILETS, rotten sheds with huge holes in the floor. Not worth staying unless you have your own toilet.

name: Walmart
description:
Walmart supercenter 24h
Big parking lot ..perfect for one night

name: Chamise Flat
description: Dispersed Camping along Kern River with good fishing spots very close to campground.  Not as windy as the south side of Lake Isabella.  Campsites not as close as pay sites but other campers can get rowdy and noisey because they think they are miles away from other people. No AT&T cell service at this location

name: Devils Tower KOA
description: Visit website for more details. Amazing view of Devils Tower from the campground, has everything a KOA should have except no hot tub here. Getting good Verizon coverage but there is also WiFi available.

name: Lighthouse Marine Park
description:
Cool little county park campground right across from the water (2 min walk). Convenient to the BC ferry terminal at Tsawwassen. Point Roberts is a small appendage of USA attached to the Canadian mainland, totally cut off from the rest of the USA. Be aware you have to go through Border Control from Canada to get in and out of the area, but the wait was nonexistent and guards friendly both ways because it is such a small border crossing. We were there on a summer weekday and CG was almost empty. One of our favorite camp spots on our cross-country trip in 2017. Free hot showers, flush toilets, etc.

Gas stations in Point Roberts also have lower US gas prices compared with just over the border.

From the park's website: 
This 21 acre park has become known as one of the best places to view Orca whales from land.  There is a great deal to discover at the park including camping, beach access, a boardwalk, picnic areas, fishing and wildlife viewing.
Phone: 	360.945.4911
Located at:  	811 Marine Drive, Point Roberts, WA 
Reservations (we just showed up, though): https://secure.itinio.com/whatcom/lighthouse

name: Snolquomie Casino Wa.
description:
no overnight parking because of COVID. 8/3/20

Just before the Pass. Good RV Parking and lots of grass.
Quiet

name: West Beach Resort
description: This resort is primarily focused on their cabins located on the shoreline of West Beach. The campground takes second priority to the rest of the resort. Fire pits dug into the ground, goose poop in the grassy areas (don’t know what you do about that) no privacy between camp sites. There are some nice sites 39,40,41,42. A great beach and view is a short walk away. Nice beachside bar with kayak rentals and guided tours. This is the place to rent a cabin!! Camping has yet to be fully optimized.

name: Mammoth Springs Dispersed campground
description: nice campground down a slightly rough dirt road.  pit toilets and fire rings with a creek running very clise to most of the spots.  heavily wooded and very quiet.  No cell service.

name: Dixie National Forest dump and water
description: outside of the Panguitch Lake campground there is a free water and dump station

name: Pine Creek Rock Climbing Parking
description: Nice place to sleep close of a lot of sport climbing spot. The weather for sleep is far better than Bishop. There is pit toilet and a creek for fresh water. Climbing is shady. 4g not working.

name: Mike‘s Offroad
description:
Mike is specialized on 4x4 and also rents out the Cruise America RVs. 

We had  a horrible noise on our Land Rover Defender and couldn’t find the reason for it. 
Mike jumped right away into my car and we did a test drive. After that 2 guys were working on the truck immediately. 30 minutes later we found the problem and solved it. 

They were extremely friendly, helpful and hands-on. And they know Land Rover Defender and have some expertise with them which is rare in the US. 

Recommended!

name: Roadsidewerx Land Rover Specialist
description:
Matt is an extremely friendly guy, very honest and hands on. 

He changed the brakes, stub axles and bushings on my Defender and did a very good job. 

Price: 126 USD/hour but that’s the US and expertise with Land Rover Defenders is scarce. 

He had to order some parts as problems occurred while he was working on the car. He has very good contacts and parts arrived overnight. Excellent. 

Even if you don’t have any problems with your Landy. Go and say hello to Matt. 

https://www.roadsidewerx.com

name: alternate to red rock canyon
description: Red rock canyon area is small and already had a couple vehicles.  this spot was in the tree and had a fire ring and ame wood already.  100m to a pit toilet through the trees.  Decent T-Mobile 4G service. arches hike is right there and a must do, very pretty.

name: Tanana Valley Campground
description:
Little campground on the north side of Fairbanks (10min to downtown). It was 30 for electric (only no water) hook up and 25 for dry. The campground itself was ok but we had an awful night thanks to the hundred of mosquitos (the campground has a little river that drowns them here) flying around our truck. It was a lovely day but no one in the camping was outside thanks to the mosquitos. The shower is included in the price but the bathroom were very aged and not very clean. 
So to conclude it’s cheaper than the others rdv parks in Fairbanks but we were able to see why.

name: Sheep Creek rest area
description: Rest area off highway 95. Maximum stay 16hrs. Shade trees and next to the river. Running water toilets and potable water available. Great for one night or if unable to find anywhere else. Also has shaded picnic benches and grills.

name: Aztec City Government Parking Lot
description:
Gravel lot next to the Aztec City Government. Potable water, non potable water, dump station and dumpster on-site for FREE! 
Free city WiFi and within walking distance of grocery stores, restaurants, etc. There’s also a splash pad and playground behind the government buildings!

name: Granite Peak RV Resort
description:
Nice Campground with all facilities. 

With our Land Rover we got a tent site with electricity and water. 

Facilities:
Pool
Laundry
Minigolf 
Full Hook-ups 
Small shop 
Tables
Fire rings 
Hot showers included 
WiFi 

Everything very clean and staff very friendly.

Price:
32 USD for ADAC members 

Recommended.

name: Bogan Flats Campground
description:
Very nice National Forest Service campground right by the Crystal River off of County Road 3.
Quiet and peaceful. Mature trees for shade. Beautiful location.

Can be busy on holiday weekends and peak tourist season. Closed in winter. Max RV length 40 feet.
USFS camping fees apply and there is a campground host.
Toilets and water.
No electric hookup and no dump station.
No cellphone signal or internet.

name: Alascom road view spot
description: Site was up the hill towards the tower off into a dirt side road that was easily done in 2WD with our camper.  Narrow due to bushes, would be muddy in rain.  Great view of the surrounding valley and lakes down below.

name: Gravel trail towards Panum Crater
description:
if you take the gravel trail from the main road there will be a pullout. perfect for cars or small vans. i fit my sedan and a small tent. beautiful view of lake. very close to road but not visible from road. drive slow, but no 4 wheel drive required. 
no amenities.

name: Grass area away from the road
description: Take the dirt road. At the end you will find a big loop where you can camp. All sizes vehicles will fit. Tent camping shouldn’t be a problem. We had a few bars of AT&T coverage.

name: La Barge Creek
description: Beautiful place in a lovely lush valley near the river la barge

name: Ruins Road RV Park
description:
Very close to Aztec Ruins.  It’s a normal RV Park, but dry campaign mg by the river is only $10!

$25 for water and electric.

No showers.  Toilets are portable toilets.

Great place to hang out and spend the night.  Plenty of shade, too.

name: Fruita Campground
description: Located inside Capitol Reef National Park just past the visitor center. They have potable water to fill up tank and dump station. They request $5 fee to Dump, water is free of course. Used this before boondocking about 6 miles from visitor center.

name: off 97
description: forest road off 97, just a pull off on the dirt road. Follow to the fork and take a right. It’s directly on your left. good for a night.  good Verizon signal.

name: Camping off pull-in
description: Gravel Road off pull in leads down to the rivers edge where there are at least 3 camp sites with fire rings. Free. No toilets / water. Road noise and lights shielded due to bushes. Very nice spot! Usual forestry regulations apply (fire only in designated ring / pit / blanket, pack out all trash) and obviously it's a first come first served site :)

name: Knife Edge River Access
description: River access with marked camping spots and pit toilet, also has changing area for boaters. Temporary restrictions on sites 2, 4 & 5 - only sites 1 and 3 available for overnight between 1 May and 30 June.

name: Fort Peck
description: Free campsites at Fort Peck on a lake. Tables, firepits and pit toilets.

name: Coconino National Forest
description: Dispersed camping site west of Sunset Crater National Monument cell service available.

name: Fox Park
description: State park right on Lake Michigan. 15$ a night. Beautiful views. It was stormy so not sure how buggy it would be in nicer weather.

name: Boreas pass road
description: A few pullouts on the side on a good dirt road inside a national Forest. Amazing view in some of the pullouts too. There's a 14 day limit. It's a seasonal road. 2 bar Verizon

name: Stinson Flats, WA by Klickikat River
description: Put in / take out for boats and rafts. Beautiful campsites by the river.

name: Castle Lake Road  turn off
description: Located before the actual Castle Lake primitive campground. Wide gravel road that looks like a scenic photo spot or turn off but leads to a maze of dry/ primitive camping. No fees. No facilities. 1st spot off the road can fit large RV but down the road and maze it narrows a lot at some points. Sedans able to get down during this time of year. medium good cell service with Google fi

name: Quincy Lakes Unit
description: Lots of free camping spots along fishing lakes and near ancient lakes hiking trail head. Nice area for a night or two. ATT and T-Mobile okay, probably Verizon too.

name: Teton recreation area
description: Free BLM campground. clean pit toilets. on a lake.

name: Penny Hot Springs
description:
Free hot springs right next to the lovely Crystal River.
Open year round but usually overrun and washed out by the spring snowmelt during May and June.
Otherwise a perfect spot to sit in a hot water pool anytime, even if it's snowing.
There's a wide pullout for parking, then you climb down a short slope to the river.
Mountain wild sheep, elk, and other wildlife are common.
No camping or facilities, but a great spot to relax for a while.

name: Salmon Creek road
description: Endless amounts of logging roads that can be camped on.  I found a convenient spot 2 miles from Oakridge right off Salmon Creek Road

name: Delta River
description:
100 yards from the bridge.
Nice open space with a riverside spot.

name: Ho-Chunk Gaming RV Park
description:
This place has everything. You can dry camp no water or electric.
You can camp in their RV Park that has full hookups or electric only, you choose what you want to pay.
If you stay in the RV Park they give you keys to access the hotel pool and gym.
Casino, restaurants all on site. Shuttle bus to hotel lobby if the weather is bad.
Good Sam club discount around $33/night full hookups. Dry camp $0.

name: Free USFS campground
description: These are a handful of sites on the lake, some with picnic tables and all with fire rings. Hand-pumped water available. Buggy.

name: Poplar River
description:
Small Campground with 4 sites for tents or smaller RV. For free.Here are no bin's, so you have to pack in, what you have pack out.
pit-toilet available.

name: Toohey Lake
description:
Its one of 17 FREE Campgrounds in the National Forrest. In the pictures you have a map with all Campgrounds here in the Forrest. This small Campground has 7 sites for tents or smaller RV. The sits have all firerings and Tables. There are no bin's, so you have to pack in, what you have pack out.
On the campground is also a pit-toilet.

name: Four Mile Lake
description:
Its one of 17 FREE Campgrounds in the National Forrest. In the pictures you have a map with all Campgrounds here in the Forrest. This small Campground has 4 sites for tents or smaller RV. The sits have all firerings and Tables. There are no bin's, so you have to pack in, what you have pack out.
On the campground is also a pit-toilet.

name: Whitefish Lake
description:
Its one of 17 FREE Campgrounds in the National Forrest. In the pictures you have a map with all Campgrounds here in the Forrest. This small Campground has 3 sites for tents or smaller RV. The sits have all firerings and Tables. There are no bin's, so you have to pack in, what you have pack out.
On the campground is also a pit-toilet.

name: Viento State Park
description:
State Park campground
Good for tents through large Motorhomes

name: Walmart
description:
Walmart supercenter 24hours 
Big parking lot ...no  noisy ,perfect for one night

name: Green Lake State Park
description: Very Nice local! Have site with eletric and water, or only site.

name: Camp Site in Honobia WMA
description: Camp Site near old washed out bridge. There are several areas to camp as you can see where others have done so prior. You must have Honobia / Three Rivers WMA permit to access this land. Oklahoma Wildlife Dept. can help you with this.

name: Granite Creek @ Bridger-Teton NF
description: Amazing sites along Granite Creek. At the end of the road are private hot springs @ $6 per person entry fee.

name: Arapaho National Forest
description:
Well designated spots with fire rings within the national forest on country road 4. No need for 4WD. Pine trees and aspen trees.
Close to the entrance of the Rocky Mountain National Park and the lakes. 
Perfect spot ! 
Cell service on and off...

name: Trapper Creek Inn & RV Park
description:
Located at mile 114.6 South Parks Highway.
Nice campground under trees.
Campsites are narrow.
Free dump and water.
Wifi is free.

name: Forest spots off BLM 610B
description: All along this BLM road are some level clearings in the woods that are clearly for camping. Most have fire pits but when I arrived there were stage 2 fire restrictions so I couldn't make a fire. 610B becomes a pretty rough road the further in you go so high clearance or 4x4 is probably recommended.

name: Oak Orchard Marina & Campground
description: Great place, in marine, front a Lake. Pay $35 for RV (water + eletric)

name: Wrightsville beach
description:
Little place in the forest a little south of the entrance of wrightsville beach entry when on the 2 rd.
Good spot for private night in the forest. Nice quiet place in the forest clean and near a super kayak lake

name: Skagway Pullen Creek R V Park
description: $45 + taxes per night Inc electricity and water. Right beside the ferry terminal for the Alaska marine highway. Surrounded by snow capped mountains. $1.25 5 min shower. Pay WiFi available (free in library). Few mins walk to shops & restaurants. Some noise from the train horns from about 5 am.

name: Dicksie Bridge Recreation Ground
description: Campsite immediately after bridge over river when travelling East. Free to stay max 14 days. Roughly 10 sites with picnic benches and fire pits. There is another similar site a mile or so west along highway 43 called East Bank, also free.

name: Fosston Campground
description:
Small and nice city run campground. Tent $5,- and RV $16,-  Dump station $3,-
The toilet and shower are in the building closest to the gate.

name: Waterfowl management area
description:
Just a spot to park and camp for the night at the entrance to the Waterfowl Management Area. There is a wide spot parking area at these coordinate big enough for a few vehicles to park. The gate to the WMA is here and was locked when we were there, so we parked for the night right next to the Green River in this parking area.
We have a truck bed camper, so there was plenty of room. Larger RV's  and long trailer campers would find things a little tight here, but for smaller rigs like ours it's no problem.

Some fishermen showed up early in the morning and parked their Jeep before walking off into the WMA, but they were quiet and didn't bother us at all. There are no signs forbidding overnight parking, just some signs about what kind of fish it's legal to catch and what kind must be returned to the river.

A few houses are across a pasture a few hundred yards away, but it's very quiet here and nobody bothered us.  I nice place for a quiet night's sleep if you're tired after a day on the road.

name: Swinomish Casino
description: Nice RV park behind casino $32.00 fee but lots of grass and good power

name: Chestoa View Overlook
description: A nice place for overnight, quiet and a great view. One of the better overnight spots on the parkway.

name: Machias - on the water
description:
Off of Main Street (US 1) there is a lot behind the hardware store along the river where overnight parking is permitted. There are a few shops and a gas station, but no services on-site. From the lot, you can see the waterfall and a park is across the river. 

Look for signs along the river that say “overnight parking back row only between signs”

We didn’t stay, but stopped for lunch. Great 1-night hold over when headed along the coast.

name: Romavi International Freight Forwarding
description: Used these guys to get our container (2 motos, 20ft container from SeaBoard Marine) into port, through customs and out of the port. Seaboard messed up so much of the process (that's another story) but Carlos got everything figured out and done. His cost was $350 to get everything done. Well worth it because we had flown home weeks before the container arrived and it took customs 6 days to even release it. carlos@romaviinternationalshipping.com

name: Powell Meadow
description: Above a beautiful remote meadow in sequoia national forest. Fire ring but no facilities. Easy access off a paved side road of Sherman Pass Road, however, not for oversized rigs. Little creek is an unreliable water source. Legal and free.

name: Pines Campground
description: Small campground operated by the National Forest. Nice spots, some trees, but enough sunny lots. Very clean pit toilets provided as is a water faucet and trash container. Every spot provides a table/ benches as well as a parking, bear box and BBQ. 21$ per night. Check out at 1pm / we arrived at 4pm and were alone on a Monday, by 7pm all spots were taken.

name: Sweet Water
description: Well managed, small National Forest Campground. Every site has lots of open space, benches/table, BBQ and a bear box. Clean pit toilets, trash container and water faucet provided on campground. With 24$ not cheap, but one of the closest options to the NP, where everything is booked weeks in advance. Only public showers are provided at household campground in the NP Valley at an expensive 5$ per shower, however, no time limit and soap & towel are provided.

name: Mono Vista Campgrounds
description: It’s a RV park and campground but very well managed and grand after a backcountry hike at Yosemite. They provide different sites, a dry site costs $ 28 per night including showers (5min hot water per person). You have a sink to wash dishes, a super clean facility block, a coin laundry and WiFi provided. Recommendable.

name: Laundromat + Showers + RV dump
description: Small laundry machines $3.50. Showers cost $5.5 for 20 minutes (no sharing according to the signs) plenty of washing machines and dryers. Large machines cost $11, small $3.50

name: Boat Launching Parking Wide Hollow Reservoir
description: Nice place to stay a night with the view on the reservoir. Ther is some fisherman inthe day but noboday in the night. Look good for fishing. No big rig please...let the space for fisherman with his boat trailer.

name: Foothills Cafe
description: Great breakfast (and lunch?) spot outside of Yosemite. HUGE portions of tastey food, very reasonable prices.

name: forest camping
description: several places with fire rings, trees for hammock and a little shade. some cars are passing by, but the night was absolutely quite. nice place, accessable for  2wd. no AT&T reception.

name: backroad spot
description:
small patch just off the 97, take a right when you see Napa, it's quiet and free, no big rigs.
you can also camp in the osoyoos recreation area a few feet back with bathrooms and hookups for 16$ a night

name: Simard automotive (2 locations)
description: Great mechanics, they also service old cars (VW and others). Really friendly people. They helped us really well. They have a shuttle service (free) and also a really nice waiting area. Not the cheapest but for sure good quality.

name: Deer Mountain Snowmobile Park
description: No frills, 8 tent/rv sites, pit toilets. Clean, quiet and free.

name: Green Waters Park
description: Rest area good for toilet, naps, picnic...spent lots of time here during my week in Oakridge.  Located on river

name: Belmont Eco Laundry
description:
Good laundromat. Double load for $3,25. Dryer 7 minutes for $0,25. Washing detergent available for $1. 

Free wifi.

name: Martin's Landing Campground
description: $10 a night. Near the river and plenty of sites. very quiet. Lots of mosquitos so bring bug spray. No hookups but they have a bathroom. Choose this over Cow Hallow

name: 559 Just east of Medano Pass
description:
Open area along 559 near the beginning of the Medano Pass 4wd Road.

I often see camper trailers here and there is at least one fire ring in the edge of the woods.  There are both open grassy areas and places to park and tent along the woods.  

Access from east via 2wd dirt road or 4wd Medano Pass Road from the west.

There are also some small sites along the 4wd road before the Pass and entrance to the Sand Dunes National Park.

name: Bear creek CG
description:
Free forestry camping site with pit toilets, horse hitches, horse pens, fire pits and propane recycling bin! Beautiful location, you can stay for up to 16 days. Be aware that this is in grizzly bear country and its accessed via 7+ miles of dirt road. There is a ranger station in this campsite also.
This area is closed between the 1st of December and the 15th of May each year to protect wildlife.

name: Glacier view
description:
Parking to a trailhead 
Super spot to view the Glacier.

name: Sevier Lake boondocks
description: Great spot in salt flats . 2-3 miles off US 50

name: Turn off near forest falls aka Thurman flats
description: A nice and quite place to park for the night. Seems to be an area people go to shoot guns. We came in late and it was too dark for us to try and drive back so we just parked right where the road meets the dirt. You can see the cars on the highway but they are far enough to not be too noisy.

name: Arctic Import Repair
description:
Excellent mechanic for imported cars. Can even identify imported cars by VIN. Finds spareparts not available anywhere else. Makes honest recommandations on necessary repairs.
Our experience with a Landcruiser Prado where the Toyota dealer was absolutely overburdened and hopeless.
Reasonable prizes.

name: Roman Nose State Park
description: campground, rv and tent, fishing, hiking, day use areas, and golf course.

name: Devils Backbone
description: A great view and a very quiet place for overnight. The Ranger came, but he let us stay! 3-4 bars of Verizon LTE

name: power cycles inc
description: this place is awesome! and he can fix anything--he can read error codes on BMWs and do the work too. originally from Argentina, and his shop is super great. machined a part for my husband's bike that was lost in cargo transit. highly recommended!

name: Hellgate Campground
description: Long Campground with numerous sites along the shore of Canyon Ferry Reservoir. Several group sites. Outhouses, water in summer. Beach. Boat ramp. Many sites by reservation at Recreation.gov or 1-877-444-6777 during summer season. $10/site/night during season, free in winter (no water).

name: Hap Hawkins Campground
description: Primitive site. Outhouse. Hand pump water. Picnic tables, some covered and fire pits. Free year round. No trees. Windy at times.

name: Wissota State Campground
description: We stopped for an overnight heading home. Got in late office was open. $20 plus $11 park fee. Bathrooms were dirty. Lake is big.

name: BLM easy access
description: Easy access dirt road 2WD cars ok. Few spots here and there along the road with home made firepits and lots of wood to burn. Lots of trees there for wind protection. Quiet. Pack it in pack it out. Leave no trace. Cougars in the area.

name: Outside Diamond Lake
description: North of Crater Lake NP, this is closest gas station. It’s at the corner across from Pony/ horse rides. About 1.5 miles north of Diamond Lake reaper south entrance

name: Valentine City Park
description: $5 donation. Nice park, lot's of shade, restrooms with showers.

name: Black Hills
description: Great spots, dispersed camping, may need 4 wheel drive in wet weather, bring water

name: Nice pullout on Highway 2
description: Big pullout or more a parking lot behind some trees so that you‘ve protection from the street. Good for one night. No facilities.

name: Obstruction Point Trail Head Parking
description: Most beautiful spot we've ever camped, we were the only ones there other than the 4 deer that loved to lick our van. You're not supposed to park over night however due to the road you have to drive down I'm almost sure no one will bother to patrol it. The road is not recommended for RVs or trailer's, we did it in our 92 dodge ram just fine. The road is a single lane winding dirt track with near vertical drops, there are a few small turnouts but luckily not many other cars. As long as you aren't afraid of highs and a good driver you should be fine.

name: Target parking
description: Target parking, quiet in night. Free and calm. Near the woodbury premium outlet .

name: badlands interior motel and campground
description: nicer looking than the Badlands rv park itself. only a mile away with views of the wall. you can have a fire or buy alcohol here. a bit pricey for a full hook up at 34.75 but would come here again. you may have to drive through the Badlands to get here ($20 for a 7 day park pass). they have a small cooked food area inside as well as dry food section.

name: Walmart
description:
Walmart parking lot in Wasilla.

Asked inside and it id OK for self-contained RVs to overnight around the edges of the parking lot

name: Forest above Boulder Town
description: Forest Road 165 just out of town has dispersed camping all along the road.  we kept climbing to get out of the heat and found a nice flat spot with a fire ring at 9200 feet.  It was cool and full of wild flowers.  We were among aspens, deer and cattle.  There are a few lakes and trails to other lakes  nearby but not accessible to camp near by car.

name: Byre Lake Recreation Area
description:
Large grass area on a Lake. You’re officially allowed to camp here for a maximum of 5 days. 
Has 6 spots for electric hook up at $20 per day.  But is free if no electric is needed.
It's just 10 minutes away from the highway, but very quiet. You drive from an Asphalt route on an gravel route, but it's ok for small and big vehicle. On the Lake you can drive boat, swimming, fishing, have an BBQ, and has pit toilet.  There is a covered pavilion with electric and light.  Also get about 2 - 3 bars of Verizon service, 4 bars of AT&T. 

Please keep the place clean.

name: Rest area 99 Highway South
description:
Dump, highway  South Golden State. 
The rest area to north not working dump. 

Free to dump. No potable water.

name: Sky Ranch Big Bear
description:
Tent-camped here for 2 days with my dog.  Private campground on private property located minutes from downtown Big Bear City and Lake.  Property borders National Forest and in quiet area with 3 Air BnB houses. Property is only a couple of miles from Pacific Crest Trail.  Star Deck is located at top of a slope in the forest.
$15/2 people.  $5/extra person.

name: Deschutes NF Spots
description: Lots of nice spots in the forest, about 10 mins to town. Fire rings. Mountain bike trails nearby. 2wd friendly.

name: Wal-Mart
description: Overnight parking, semis, camper trailers, and RV's.

name: Big Horn National Forest
description: beautiful spot right by the river with lots of wild lupine. lots of campgrounds but none of them occupied when I came through. easy access for camper vans and cars and even smaller RVs. large swimming hole as well but the water is freezing.

name: minute man RV and camp
description:
right off the interstate.. showers laundry water don't recommend any of them but its here. tables with minimal shelter. spots are close to each other. but almost empty. No pricing info: we were booked at the campground in Badlands National but our camp site was totally under water so Minute man put us up for free because we had already paid for the other site. 
…

name: Okanogan
description: Free dump station with a river view. Easy access.

name: Grave Creek Campground
description: Free camping, 4-5 sites. Beautiful location listening to the river! 1 bar Verizon 4G if in right spot. 2-3 bars of AT&T with booster.

name: Camelot  Resort
description: Lodge has 9 bedrooms and 4 bathrooms with 3 external cabins.  Also there is camping area.  Beautiful spot nestled in strawberry pinnacles.

name: Ten-X campground
description:
Big camping with 70 spots, both reserved and unreserved. We arrived at 6pm and could still choose a place. Really nice places with lots of trees and a picknick table and BBQ at each spot. Costs 10 dollars per night, self check-in, max. Stay is 14 nights. Pit toilets and drinking water available. The campground host Bob is a super nice guy who led us to a great spot. 

$25 per night for RV

name: Foster Park
description: Ok small campground for one night in Ojay valley. Much cheaper than at the Coast: 21 dollars for non-hook up. Very clean toilets

name: CO 125 Pullout
description:
Dirt road leads west 150 yards from CO Route 125 to an impacted campsite with space for 2-3 vehicles. Columbine flowers, nearby creek, and mountain views make this place unique, yet still easily accessible.   

Bumpy road not good for low-clearance vehicle, but flat enough that 2WD is sufficient.

name: Hollywood RV Park
description: Well kept campground. Price around 65$ per car per night. The majority of the guests are longer term residents. The places are reasonably sized, most have shade from the trees. About 20 minutes drive to Universal Studios. Home depot within walking distance.

name: Bus from movie into the wild
description: Here you can find the bus from the movie into the wild. The movie tells the incredible story about Chris Mccandless (Alexander Supertramp). Inside the bus you can read more about his adventure. It’s behind the Brewery’s gate and fencing. If they are closed you can’t get close to the bus.

name: Rock Wall Camping
description: cool spot with fire pit and lots of space for tents right against the wall for early morning shade

name: La Cieneguilla Trailhead & Petroglyph area
description:
Parking lot at the trailhead. 
Nothing there but good for the night. 
Cell service. 
Close to Santa Fe

name: Finger Lakes National Forest
description: In the national forest, About 20 places with a firepit. Some one a pond. I would not go here if iT rains a lot, because of the Road. Road can be muddy and bumby.

name: Rastplatz
description:
quiet rest area off the HW60, west of Magdalena NM
---
ruhiger Rastplatz abseits der HW60, westlich Magdalena NM

name: Oak Flat Campground
description: Oestlich von Phoenix Arizona auf der HW60, sehr ruhig, Plumpsklo

name: Wildlife preservation area near Mt. Shavano
description: sites all along this road suitable for big rigs RVs and tent camping, if you have a travel trailer or a large RV the first couple pull outs on the right are the most ideal. the road is rocky going past that but even and I saw many people with RVs pass those pull outs. great place to base camp for hiking multiple fourteeners in the area

name: Country View Campground, LLC
