description: Normal campground. Nothing special naturwise but the owners are really friendly. Free showers and a pool. Paid laundry machines available. Very little road noise. 28$ for a tent site. Grounds are well maintained. (No mosquitos in late June or late July)

name: Free dump station
description:
Dump station free 
Potable water 
Dumpstair

name: Lowe's Lexington
description: More quiet than Walmart and nobody disturbed us. Good for overnight

name: wash o matic
description: it is a clean laundry and there is WiFi👍

name: Little Camas Reservoir
description: turn right at "public access" sign. nice flat spot at reservoir's edge. sand hill cranes as neighbors right now. pit toilet.

name: Big gravel pit behind the trees
description: Great flat gravel pit behind trees 100m beside the road, it seems this was a old hunting camp, fire rings, lots of fire wood. we enjoyed the silence.

name: Willits SafeWay
description:
Free dump and drinking water on the SafeWay gas station in Willlits. 

En Willits, en la gasolinera SafeWay es posible descargar aguas negras y cargar agua potable. Gratis!

name: Desert Hills Motel
description: Big place with lots of parking no matter what size vehicles. Big rooms for about $50 a night, king size bed, air con, cable tv, fridge/freezer and hot water etc. bit of a luxyry compared to my experience in south america but good value and on historic route 66 too! wiifi is the phone number.

name: Switzerland trail
description: On national forest route 233A off of the Switzerland trail. Some high clearance spots but Subaru-able. Plenty of spots and room for groups. Wild flowers in the spring. Fire pits, views, WiFi.

name: Lindbergh lake
description: Free National Forest campground in the forest close to the lake, pit fire and lots of timber available.

name: Walmart parking
description: a wallmart parking, quiet, and no problem for overnight.

name: Boat launch and camping
description: This is a boat launch on a smaller lake for fishing only. The sign next to the gate allows for camping. It’s a quite secluded spot that doesn’t see much traffic during the week. Weekend could be busier? But probably relatively quite. No toilets or potable water. Not too many bugs and was a nice place to stop for the night

name: On the top
description:
nice freecamping area in the National Forrest. On a gravel road you will find 3 spots with fire pits. Maybe not suitable for big RV'S
There are no facilities, but if you drive 3 miles down the hill, there are toilets on the campground. 
very quiet in the night.

name: Propane - Colter Bay
description: Propane fill available at RV Park entrance.

name: Susitna State Park
description:
Boat landing and campground. We are still not sure if it’s public-owned or private-owned. Anyway reasonable prices (starting at $15 for no hookups, see pictures for more prices) and no highway noise.
Good LTE phone reception with AT&T.

name: walmart Sparta
description:
quiet walmart parking, we are past a great night. 

parking du walmart, tres calme.

name: Hunting Island State Park
description: Camping, RV, electrical hook ups, and an ocean view make this a beautiful location for sunsets and swimming. Rates vary

name: North Llano River RV park and resort
description:
Nice campground. Tent sites are shady and right on River.  Wifi reaches all the way around the campground.  Bathrooms okay.  24 hour laundry and pool.
  Easy on and off the freeway.  Great overnight stop.  Tent $20, RV $37

name: Medora Campground
description: RV park with tent sites, flush toilets, barracks style showers, a kids playground, and small camp supply store. Location is nearby a city pool. conveniently located next to Theodore Roosevelt National Park.

name: Stoney Pond
description:
Camping is allowed only at the 17 designated campsites and requires a camping permit between May 1 and September 30. Call 607-674-4017, ext. 602 to reserve a camping site. These sites generally fill up at least two weeks in advance, so please plan accordingly.

The camping sites are varied. Two sites are accessible only by foot and are for tent camping. Most of the sites are nestled among a white pine plantation at the south end of Stoney Pond. Each site contains a fire ring. A latrine services the camping area. There is no water well.

name: Cedar Grove
description: Sentinel Site 55. opening night.  nice site near meadow

name: Turkey swamp Campground
description: Camping in turkey swamp park. Very Nice local, quiet, playground for Child. $40,00 For eletric and water. Have dump station

name: Walmart Rensselear
description:
walmart parking very quiet. two trucks park near.

parking du walmart calme, la route n est pas bruiyante, 2 camions ont dormis a no coté.

name: Spring Creek
description: $7. nice sites along the spring creek. no cell coverage, may have spring flooding.

name: Sound of Music Meadow, D37, Rt 274
description: Great view, fire pit, no water, gather your own wood, Big Sky, Snow Capped Peaks!

name: Hyalite Free Dipersed Camping
description: Free camp sites within a few hundred meters of the parking lot. Beautiful site with river and creek access.

name: Bliss ID
description:
Large gravel lot behind Ox Bow Diner and probably shared w the Sinclair station. Huge and flat. Fine for the night. A little noisy at times with big trucks pulling in to also rest, but much more peaceful than a rest stop. 
Bliss is a sweet little town with some interesting history. 
Ox Bow Diner is fantastic. We had dinner, then stayed in the lot with no troubles, had breakfast there too and hit the road! 

Water Spigot located near wooden pavilion/ white historic looking building to the right of the diner

name: Rest Area BP
description: Rest area truck stop with free dump station, gas station McDonald's and Subway.

name: Newton creek campground
description: Forestry campground (there are 6 others between Yellowstone and Wapiti) with basic facilities. Hard trailers only at this site (due to bears I presume) and currently only 12 sites available, the other half of the campground is closed (it's over the river). $15 a night fee, level sites with picnic tables and fire pits.

name: Sully state park
description: Nice campground a couple miles from Theodore Roosevelt National Park. Hot showers no longer require payment.

name: Black Canyon Rd
description: Big boulders and a few fire rings next to BLM Wilderness. Washboard road is slow but worth it once you get here! Lots of evidence of rabbits and coyotes/bobcats! Keep an eye on your critters! Great place to photograph. Look for two windmills and boulders, turn towards the boulders.  There are several camping options. The road is good enough for our 2WD Sprinter van to negotiate. Enjoy!

name: Broken Hills Road
description: A large, level gravel pull off with easy access for 2wd vans and mohos. There are several established fire rings. In good weather there are many wild camp spots along this road. 4bar LTE service!

name: Sportsman’s Beach
description: This is a developed campground at Walker Lake with sun ramadas, picnic tables and fire rings. No hook ups, but at the newer campground near the boat launch there are lots of mostly level, pull thru spaces with fabulous lake views. We  paid $6/ night. Pit toilets, garbage dumpsters, no water. 4bar LTE cell service, too!

name: Modoc NF near Lava Beds National Monument
description: Large level camp spot with fire ring on mostly level ground nestled among the pine trees. 2 Bar Verizon LTE service.

name: Coos Bay Peninsula 4x4 Trail
description:
Great secluded spot right off of a little used sand 4x4 trail. We parked in a spot the width of two truck with a small dune between us and the beach/ocean. perfect amount of breeze and  wave sound. * recommended: 4x4 and ossible tire deflation.

You need a red flag and permit (10$, valid 2 years) to enter this area.

name: White pine river access
description: Near the river, beach, pit fire, quiet, very nice place for enjoy the river and the forest ! Near to the beautiful  Wier Hotsprings (5min drive).

name: Escalante Petrified Forest State Park
description:
Nice Campground @ Escalante Petrified Forest State Park
Quiet, Dog friendly 
Aks for Overflow Camping, if the Campground is full

name: Silver Lake campground
description: Established rv, tent sites. Hotel and cabins. Right on the lake

name: Gorge campground
description:
Little campground, only 8 sites, on the lake. Boat launch, tables, bbq, toilets.
$10 per night.

name: Alaska Stoves
description:
Lovely Campground made with heart and brain and low prices.  Self Service. Space for tents, small and large RVs. 

Had a look at several campgrounds around town and nothing comes close to this one for price vs facilities. Might get wifi in the office at a couple of others but it will cost you double for the convenience.
Couple of small cabins, a teardrop trailer and a 4 berth tent available if you can't be bothered putting up your tent. 4 nice tent sites among the trees.  Dump point and water. 30 amp supply to several RV sites plus charging outlets in the amenities block.
Close to airstrip but no night flying so not a factor and good separation from road too

name: King Mountain State Recreation Site
description: Campground close to the river. Most sites are quiet.

name: Seaview RV park, Hope
description: Very quirky, basic site with portaloos or pit toilets. May have WiFi at the library if you are lucky. Live music at bar next to site at weekends ($5 or $10 cover charge), cafe + sea views. Power if required $25. Without electricity $20. Tent $10. Best to book for weekends. 4 bars LTE with Verizon.

name: Summit Creek CG
description: Pit toilet, fire rings, no trash service, water source from creek can be accessed from short but tricky hike down.

name: National Forest on White River
description: Dry camping with some informal fire pits. Easy access to glacier run off water. Close to highway but rushing creek water drowns out anything else. We have about 24ft and 9.5’ and made it in easy. No facilites. Leave no trace.

name: Antilon Lake
description: There are a couple 4 campsites at this location. Great for tents, campers, vans and smaller RV's.

name: Chevron
description: Dump station and potable water available !

name: Rest Area
description: Many Rv's and campers, simple night stop in the rest area with 24h bathrooms and well lit.

name: walmart berlin
description: quiet walmart, we ask to the manager and his ok to stay the night.

name: Forest Rd
description: Great spot. Only had a few cars drive by and even though I parked near a atv trail no one went by. River near by and a great place to chill. Have a good one.

name: Whitewater campsite
description:
Amazing spot to spend three free nights per month or take a dip in the little creek. super clean toilets. potable water. just incredible really. 

Long RVs or trailers will probably be turned away. You need to arrive before 5pm otherwise the gate is closed.

name: Castle Peak Campground
description: Beautiful campground in a valley down a nice 4x4 road. Right off Castle Creek that is more like a river after it rains. Road can be difficult after heavy rain but worth the drive!

name: Iron Creek Campground
description: Nice campground right outside of Custer state park. It is a horse camp so each campsite has a horse corral that were clean when I stayed there. Price is higher then other Blackhills Campgrounds due to the horse pens.

name: Hanna Campground
description: Beautiful campground not far from Lead SD. very nice campground host who was very helpful giving us advice and firewood. Sites are right off the creek with a hiking trail out of the campground. First come first serve. Popular during the summer.

name: Sylvan Lake Campground (Custer state park)
description: Busy but quite campground. Make reservations. Free hot showers! We used them a few days after we stayed there and no one seemed to mind. right outside of Black Elk Peak hiking trails along the Needles Hwy. Big rigs cant make it due to the low clearance tunnels.

name: klamath river rv park and campground
description: expensive but awesome campground! 35 per night - ask for one of the spots right on the river if you're in a smaller rig. great bathroom and showers, coffee included in the morning. weak but available wifi. gorgeous river views!!

name: Parking @ Matanuska River
description: Big parking lot next to the river and highway. Nice view and not very noisy. Good for one night.

name: Road Closed camp
description:
Decent little pull-off of the main Glenn highway, used to be another main road going through here but it is now closed off, can hike the old road or many ATV trails around

Lots of moose in the area! 

Good for a night on the way to Matsu glacier

Was able to get ATT LTE with booster

name: Flying J Station
description: Dump station and fresh water for 10 dollars.

name: Many wildcamp spots. On river or in forest
description: Nice place in the forest. Many spots. Some on the river and some in the woods. There are pit toilets. Some sites have there OWN toilet. You can have a free shower 10 km more up at the campsites

name: Wetland Watchers Park Army Corps of Engineers
description:
Cute park access thought dirt road but 2WD fine.
We stayed there one night no issues. No « no camping » sign.
Perfect close to New Orleans.

name: Kaka’ako waterfront park
description: Seems like a quite place to camp out. A few van lifers here and there that I can see

name: Big Arm State Park
description: Beautiful state park campground right at Flathead Lake. Some sites are literally right next to the water. Sites have tables and fire rings. 28$ or 34$ if they have electric hook-ups.

name: Turpin Creek-Natchez Trace
description: Small parking lot w a picnic area. Good for a night. Not sure if you’re allowed to post up here but nobody bothered us.

name: Self service Pet wash at the Rapid Wash Car Wash
description: 5 dollars for 5 minutes. bring your own towel

name: Marathon Campgrounds
description: Marathon Campgrounds in Bienville NF. 34site campground for $20 night includes RV hookup. Less for tent only. Flat, wooded, asphalt and hard gravel pads. Hardly anyone here on 4th July weekend. Campsite is on lake that is stocked.

name: Abram’s Creek campground
description: Campground with pads and tables. Fire pits. BEWARE you need to register online to get a space, even though there are available sites. Sucks because there is no cell reception there. Plan ahead. Cute campground on stream.

name: Colon Hollow Shelter campground
description: This is across the road from est. Campgrounds of North Creek. Go up hill on gravel after timber shelter. Sign for camping. Loads of pads almost all on slopes but there are occasional fire pits. Gravel road had about 10 cars pass in one evening. Head across to North Creek campgrounds for potable water and toilets.

name: Elbow pond, New Hamshire
description: 2 places near route 118. You can go there with an RV. But if you follow the road you get to the pond. There are 3 places. No road noise on the pond and in the woods. You cant get to these places with an RV over 25'.

name: wild motorcycle camping
description:
On the outside of this turn there s a small spot probably 3-4m down a little downhill. 
plenty of space for your bike and your tent. fireplace and privacy. the spot is accessible only by bikes or motorcycles. if you dont feel adventurous you can leave your bike up and walk down. you can still keep an eye on it from the spot. lots of flies now so make sure you have nets repellent and a nice tent. they go to sleep at night though.

name: General Creek Campground
description: I hate campsites, but this one was very nice. Most of the campsites are well-spaced from each other. Clean, flush toilets, 4G works well, firewood for sale. Screaming children are the only bad part of the experience.

name: Parking lot
description:
Parking lot of a building for evenement in a small town near the river. Nice people around, they came to say hello. Not a lot of noise. Really better than a rest area. No service. 
FREE

name: Jct 80 Blue Ridge Parkway
description:
Parking lot for 10 cars just off the Parkway
Possibility for a tent on grass
nice view
shade in the morning until 9 am
week At&t signal with data, ok Verizon signal defo good enough for texting.

name: RV parking of Tamarack
description:
Nice parking with grass, shadow and very quiet! Site is ideal for RVs and van campers.

All amenities (showers, toilets, potable water, dump station) are located at the adjoining Beckley Service Area. The Tamarack (open 10am-6pm) offers meals and restrooms as well.

name: East Fork Hood River
description: There are about 4-5 sweet spots right along the east fork of the hood river plus another 2 that are off the river.  The spots right on the water with nice fire pits and level ground.  Easily accessible with our camper van.  There are some areas with soft sand but if you stay off of it you shouldn’t have any problems.

name: Wild camp site
description: Wild camp site near Upper Mesa Falls. Beautiful spot in the pines with a rock fire pit.

name: Diamond head fountain
description: You know, I’m a big fan of the out of sight out of mind adventure type of thing. Most good fun and beautiful places are off limits or questionable at best. I have jumped in one night I was really sweaty and had libation confidence. Was the coldest water I ever felt but in a pinch and super quick who’s gonna say any better. Plus there isn’t a sign that says no.

name: Walmart closer to the city
description: Walmart superstore. Quiet. Level. Clean. Great spot. Stayed one night.

name: Pine Oak
description: RV Park with a nice, helpful owner (eg. organizes for an adapter from RV to conventional power outlet). Accepts small RVs & camper vans as well as overnight stays, even though it is mainly used on weekly and monthly basis. Somewhat overpriced for what you get, but at 38$ you get electricity & water as well as access to WLAN and bathroom. There is only one bathroom with a single toilet/shower for all guests, not very clean but ok. Hot shower at $1 for 7min. No sink for dishwashing.

name: Manzanita Lake Campground
description: Large campground in the woods by the lake. Not too crowded, you should be able to find a spot without prior reservation. National Park Camp at $26 per night and site. Sites provide benches/table, BBQ and bear box. Water tap/ dishwashing sink and facility blocks w/ toilets & lavabo never far. Also provided at the entrance of the camp are showers (1.75$ for 3min), coin laundry and a small shop.

name: Butte Lake Campground
description: In Lassen Volcanic National Park. 100 sites, but only 1/4 used during week.  weekend in summer it can be completely booked. clean facility blocks w/ toilets & lavabos as well as dishwashing sinks. In winter no water. But in summer avdrinking water fountain. Every site has a parking, table/benches, BBQ and bear box. Lovely setting in open woodlands near the lake, quiet. hiking and water options at walking distance.

name: Laundry & Showers at Rain Forest Village
description: Laundry and pay showers. We spend a lovely afternoon on trails and on the lake. If you would like to stay the night, they also offer nice RV sites w/ water & electricity, Wifi, toilet/ shower block at 39$ (low season much cheaper). Trout Restaurant next door.

name: Showers at Gold Beach Campground
description: Free showers with entry! Entry is free with a national park pass, otherwise $8. Amazing, free, hot showers.

name: Wild camp in National Forest
description: Huge area in the Gifford Pinchot National Forest just seconds outside of the Mount Rainier National Park boundaries. Right in the forest next to a river. Many opportunities for camping for rigs of any size. Road is a little rough coming down but should still be doable even if you're in a larger vehicle. Plenty of fire rings and no mosquitoes! It's paradise out here and can't get much closer to the park. Please keep it clean!

name: NF Pullout
description: Not easy to find camping on this road in the NF! This was the only pullout we were able to find and we tried a lot of side roads. Nice spot, the road to get up here is a little rough (decently level dirt road, no high ckearence necessary but 4wd would help because it gets steep) but it's secluded with a fire ring. Not a huge spot so probably not ideal for big rigs. Minutes from a developed campground. No amenities.

name: Dungeness Recreation Area
description:
Incredibly beautiful place to visit (not free to camp here, $7-$26 per night, but access to the Wildlife Refuge is covered by the National Park Annual Pass). Coin-op showers, 1 quarter for 2 minutes usable by non campers.

For reservations visit http://www.clallam.net/Parks/

name: Showers at Olympic Peninsula YMCA
description:
YMCA has changed policy. No more $2 showers. You may purchase a day pass for $15. The William Shore Pool close by has showers for $6.50.

Nice hot showers 
No towels anymore. Bring your own.

name: Cerro Rodadero summit
description: Peak of Cerro Rodadero. An amazing hike with view of the mountains and southern coast. It’s a lesser known spot you can backpack and wild camp on foot.

name: Cerro Rodadero trailhead
description: Trail-head to a 30 min hike up to the summit of the mountain. Here you can park the car

name: RKS Cabins on the Trail
description:
ADMIN NOTE: location appears incorrect. Please check in and correct GPS coordinates. 

Cabins for rent. No electricity or water. Fire pits, grills, comfortable accommodations.

name: Countryside Motel and RV Park
description: RV Park with long pull thru sites. Water and Electric no dump station. Quiet, pet friendly. Motel on site, bar within walking distance. Gas and convenience station at end of block. clean bathrooms and showers.

name: Oceanside RV Park
description: Small but right in town.  $36.00-night All hook up and the view to die for !! $20 tenting

name: Stine Cove Recreation area
description: Very nice place, on the Lake Isabella. Free, many places.  No designated spots. Permit is required to make a fire.  Rough road towards the water, but enough spots for vans.

name: abandoned grading station.?
description:
real quick off the road look for North Umpqua trailhead.
not really sure what this was but it's pretty cool and private.

name: Large gravel lot
description: This is a huge, flat gravel lot adjacent to the Port of Willapa Harbor building, located right on Hwy 101, that has no signs posted disallowing overnight parking. Plenty of room for large RVs towing cars. We did not stay here, but stopped to check it out to potentially help others. Two bars of Verizon cell service here as well.

name: Epic View
description: Incredible views and a large flat camping area along the forest service road. A bit exposed to the wind but totally worth the view. Verizon LTE signal available. Very quiet road.

name: Conoco Gas Station
description: Free RV dump and water.  Super convenient,  located across street from Super Walmart.

name: Gravelyard
description: This is not the best spot on this road,  but I put it in here in case all the other spots are taken. It's not marked as a campsite,  but it's a gravelyard,  large and flat-ish and you are in NF,  so I figure it's OK.    Road goes on miles past this point.   At 3.5 miles past this spot is an open meadow with 4-5 designated spots, right near and before the bridge.  Maybe check them out before deciding this is the only game in town.

name: Paradise Divide
description: head up gothic or slate river road and you'll get up to the lake and many spots at high elevation with great views and cool nights.  no cell service and no ammenities.  a rough road up and you might eant clearance and 4x4.

name: Yampa state park
description:
Typical state park. Clean showers $1 for 4min . Cost: $24+$7 so total $31 USD.  shaded picnic tables. Electric hookup only.
1-800-244-5613

name: Liabrary with free wifi
description: We needed to print (20c per piece) n scan which they did. Free wifi also had a book sale 3 for $1. Some Good finds

name: Uncompahgre National Forest - Blue Lakes Trailhead
description: Several RV and tent sites along CR 7 between mike markers 6- 9 on the dirt road that leads to Blue Lakes TH. There is a primitive hut available , reservations required. You will also find few nice tent sites (not RV accessible) along the creek at the end of the road in the first parking lot.  Lots of day hikers on the Blue Lakes Trail. Creek is a source of water with an appropriate filtering device.

name: Silver Falls State Park
description: Clean Dump Station with portable water. State Fee!

name: Plumas national forest
description: Near lake Almanor.  North of the town Almanor. Off hwy89. Nat forest land. Fire ring. Quick pull off off highway for fast quiet camp site.

name: Crystal Crane Hot Springs
description:
RV, camp sites, cabins. Mild warm water pond.

Showers, bathroom, and kitchen also available.

name: Windmill flats
description: Turn to the north and travel a two track about .2 mile over a small rise and camp off the road. It’s dispersed and high desert camping. Could hear some road traffic from SH 377. Nothing worth visiting, but a decent place to lay over for the night. We found lots of flys in the morning.

name: Box Factory Park
description: 6 miles back a county road, snow runoff can block this area at times. Small vehicles only, 4x4 recommended.

name: Carbondale Rec Center
description: Showers available for $7 per person. Clean bathroom has lockers to hold your stuff, need a lock. Also has drinking fountain to fill up water bottles

name: Cape Resort
description: This is an established Campground that is owned and operated by the Makah Tribe.   25 dollars got us a dry camping spot in a quiet corner of the large lot near the office. The park itself was densely populated and was not appealing to us.

name: Graves Creek
description: Primitive camping on a creek. Accessible by a decent dirt road. Turn left at the sign indicating that the overlook is a half mile further up and the site is a few meters away.

name: Bush Camp in Stockton State Forest
description:
Approximately four sites down a gravel track. The marker is on a large grassy site just before the end of the one way road.

We found it empty and quiet. Camping is allowed, and old camp fire spots exist.

Wild camping with no facilities, but a good option not far from the highway along the lake. We had decent cell signal with AT&T.

name: Old cherry mountain Road, 10 places
description:
We stayed a few nights at campsite #7. It’s by far the largest out of the 14 sites on this road. Big fire ring in the middle. Our 40’ bus and Jeep fit in here with room for 2 more full size buses and vehicles. The entrance to this site has a large bump/mound you need to drive over. RVs with low ground clearance may have an issue.

You are allowed to stay up to 14 days and have upto 15 people per site.

There are at least two black bears in the woods surrounding this particular campsite. They walk into and out of camp every day. (They don’t bother us) May be a good idea to bring bear spray if you have it. But black bears are pretty docile. Just yell at them and they move on. None the less, Be aware. No cellphone reception at all... zero. So, plan your exit route before you get here.

name: outfitters
description: nice little camping with cabins, tent space, hot water, WiFi (close to shop), liquor shop, laundry and restaurant, all for 8 USD per person...

name: A hole in ground 2
description: Great camp area RIGHT next to Hole in the Ground. We had two tents, a Jeep and my parents truck/camper.

name: St Cloud Campground and RV Park
description:
pool
trees
2 bathhouses w/laundry
store
nice place  
1 mile from town
Called up and asked if I can take a shower without camping. They let me do so with a $5 (guest) fee. Nice workers.

name: BLM on the Arkansas River
description: it was packed at the campground on the other side of the river so we came here.  it's a little hard to find the proper road in and you want a little clearance to get in here.  there are spots all along the river for 1/2 mile, some better than others.  all the riverfront were taken so we got in the trees.  Good 4G signal on T-Mobile.

name: Rancho Kingamongo
description: Personal property, but open to overlanders. Lots of space to tent camp or park your rig. Knock on the door and say hi!

name: Indian Flat RV Park
description: Decent little campground next to the Cedar Lodge motel. Great option to stay just outside Yosemite NP. Friendly, helpful owners. Sites are very close together but most are shaded by large trees. Hot showers and free use of the pool at the Cedar Lodge! $30 for dry camping. $42 for full hook up. Tents and cabins available for rent. Wifi available at extra cost (we didn’t try it). They charge $10 for WiFi.

name: Tuolumne Meadows Campground
description: Beautiful NP campground. Reservations recommended but we lucked out and found a spot for two nights on a busy week. Portable water available. Flush toilets. No showers. Fantastic hiking right from the campground! Enjoy.

name: I wash express
description:
Wash : 3 to 5.5 $ 
Dry : 0.30 $ / 7 min 
Cash or credit card

name: Jefferson County Fairgrounds RV Park
description: Hot shower, water sewer and 15, 30, 50amps hook ups, drop box good Sam And AARP DISCOUNT OF $2 off call first check Allstay app also it is In Madras Oregon off the HYW 26 /97 converge friendly staff $20 per night 30 amp and little phone 541-475-6288

name: Dump Station
description: Located at the front of the campsite, we didn't pay and couldn't see any fee signs.

name: Poutnef Lower Access
description: Free Dry Wild Camp with at least 7 sites along the river next to the railroad.  Nice Canyon and river close to Lava Hot Springs Village with tubing and several Resort Hot Springs.

name: Beckler River
description: Multiple sites.  1 on the river, one approximately 100’ from the river.  A couple of walk-in sites.  All nice sites, all with fire rings. Small trailers okay, not room for larger.

name: BR #1
description: Large campsite near river.  Fire pits. Space for multiple vehicles

name: Sixmile Lake Dispersed Camping
description: This is a nice dispersed campground next to Sixmile Lake, there are about 10 sites in well shaded forest, most sites should fit an RV with no problems, also there is a pit toilet and boat ramp. Come prepared for bugs though as they are everywhere you turn. Pack in pack out and keep it clean.

name: Walmart
description: Perfekt for overnight, to start next day to the Falls!

name: Unknown wild camp
description: Tired of the desert heat? Climb up here for a cool summer breeze. Views are killer. 2 hour dirt road from Big Bear. No 4x4 needed just high clearance. Some shady spots nearby. We had great cel signal here.

name: Coin-op Laundromat
description: Coin-op Laundromat, 2101 Abbott Rd, Anchorage, AK 99507, Verenigde Staten. Simple but good laundry. $2.75 for a machine. 25c for 5 mins of drying. No wifi.

name: Indian Ford Campground Sisters Oregon
description: Simple 15 RV sites, 45 ft. Max, toilet His/Hers,  go to www.hoodoo.com, table and grill at each site off the HYW 20, 5 miles out of the town of Sisters Oregon, close enough to town for cellular phone service, for camp host see picture

name: kwik trip
description: gas station with shower.  it's a truck stop, than a little bit noise.

name: Sand Island State Recreation Area
description: As I skated on through the pine trees and the Smokey bbq pits on my short board with my big shark wheels I came across camp site after campsite. I assume only few know about this place as it’s hidden well out of the way past ship yards.

name: 296 Gravel Campground
description: Great camping spot right of route 40 small gravel road 296 there is about 7-8 camp spots. Gravel road is kinda rought a little but all cars should be fine. VERY CLEAN PLEASE KEEP IT THAT WAY.

name: 130 camp dead end
description: 2-3 rig, not much wood. not visible, easy to block with a turnaround. No Verizon or T-Mobile signal.

name: Chez Jacqueline
description: Very nice family. Cajun restaurant. 18$ the plate. Great place.

name: James M. Robb - Colorado River State Park
description: Really well maintained campsite lake/river access. Day use is $9 and you have to pay that even if you camp overnight (which is a little odd). Campsite fees: $22 walk-in tent site (no car), $24 basic site (water & electric), $28 full hookups and sewer. Has very clean showers and LAUNDRY (both are coin-op). Convenient right off highway but not too loud. Site #30 is where we stayed and had some nice shade midday. Highly recommended.

name: bear camp shelter
description: bear camp shelter bordering boulder creek wilderness. a good place for solitude. would not recommend large rvs. No services near.

name: Craters of the moon
description:
Nice campground. Great place for kids.
$35 water + electricity
free breakfast waffle and coffee

name: Wild river rafting company
description: Whitewater rafting! Fun beautiful scenery that you wouldn’t see unless on he river, they do over nights, full days, whitewater trips, and scenic floats ask for sarah as a guide!!

name: Iron Creek Campground
description: Forest Service Campground, sites are spread far apart, normally $24 a night for single site. $44 for double. half off with America the Beautiful pass. They charge $8 for an extra car, there's overflow parking Old growth forest, you can see why Mt. St. Helens was so popular for camping before the eruption.

name: Boy Scout Point Campground
description: Lightly used campground with power.  Beautiful views...fishing pier.  $14 a night.

name: Blankenship bridge
description:
MODERATOR NOTE: WARNING! Flash floods reported in this location. Please use caution 

Its a free Huge area in the Flathead National Forest with many places to stay. The stay limit is 3 days. From the asphalt road goes a little narrow bumpy road to the river, then you have to drive approximately 100 yards along the river. I am not sure if it's suitable for big rigs as the road is a bit rough. 

On the Parking places on the street you can find Pit-toilets.
Excellent AT&T reception! 
No problem for 2WD. VW Eurovan/T4 ok!

name: Potawatomi State Park
description: RV parking electric only $35/by for non residents plus a one time park pass $38. pass valid for 1 year for ALL Wisconsin State Parks. Dump station available for another $10. Tent camping available, fishing, boat rental.

name: Chuck Swan State Forest
description: Pretty raw campground consisting of a small winding dirt road through a field. Nice and quiet with not too many bugs. Many a firefly at night. Good spot although no amenities. It is free!

name: Walmart Barbourville
description: Same old shiz. Not 24 hour but nobody bothered us. McDonald’s, Arby’s, Pizza Hut, little caesars, all close by.

name: Rock Castle
description: Overgrown, decrepit, closed down campground in Danial Boone NF. Camped in the parking lot for a night without being bothered. Other people showed up and accessed the campground. Was spooky as frick in there so we opted for the parking lot. This spot was free.

name: Walmart Tappahannock
description: Standard Walmart parking lot with plenty of space. Slept here for one night without any issues. We positioned our van in bottom part of the parking lot in between two trucks.

name: Oak Creek Campground
description: Dixie Forest campground off forestry Road 169. Paved access, 8 sites some tent only, not suitable for huge RV's. Right next to a creek and away from the road. $12 a night even though the forestry info says only $9 a night!

name: Free Blueberries - Charlotte’s Blueberry Park
description: Public park where you can pick up blueberries for free.

name: VFW campground
description: Next to the VFW building in town.  Don’t have to be a member and it’s $20.00 night with power. $10 to park in the grass.

name: Hilltop Cafe & Truck Stop
description: Elliot Highway. A must-stop truck stop cafe with good food and a shower. If you are headed north up the Dalton Highway, this is your last stop before the Yukon River. There are only very basic groceries here, not a place to stock up for a week.

name: Deadman River Camp
description:
Once you turn off the road then there are a few rocks to drive over before you reach the large dirt area. This can accommodate 10+ rigs for camping. 

There is a green gate that you can walk past and down to Deadman River. There is fishing and a great swimming hole. The river is fed by snowmelt so it’s cold! 

The camp site is a great place for dogs. It has large pine trees for partial shade. 4WD SUV or Truck is recommended. 

There are some large boulders to explore.

name: Salt Tram
description:
The Salt Tram above Cerro Gordo mine in the White Mountains is a spectacular and very special location. 

It has a view of (the lowest point in the United States) Death Valley on one side and of Mt Whitney on the other (the highest point in the United States)

The drive up to the Salt Tram from either direction is very technical and difficult. Only lifted vehicles, with 35” + tires and at least one locker should attempt this trail to camp. This is not accessible during periods of snow. 

There is a cabin at the top but I wouldn’t recommend sleeping in it. There are rat droppings and potential of Hantavirus. 

The area can accommodate 8+ vehicles. This is a dog friendly area. However there are no fires of any sort permitted. 

Most of the area to camp is off camber due to it being a ridge and it can be windy.

name: BLM at the end of the road
description: Between Mexican Hat an the San Juan river. The road is steep to go down to the river. We have a 20 feet RV, it was ok.

name: Pioneer Park
description: Open Parking for RVs. Price per night is $12 (Aug.2019) payable on site. Free Dump station just less than a mile down the road at Sourdough Fuel

name: Dead horse state park
description: A beautiful campsite- 2 miles nice walk from famous horseshoe bend view point which is spectacular. Electricity at sites, dump at exit. Running water toilets with basin but no showers. Bring potable water from Moab. Concrete campsites with covered picnic tables, fire ring. 40usd including entry fees. We absolutely loved the place wish could stay longer one of the most beautiful hikes around including from where Thelma n Louise jumped in the last scene 😊

name: Airport Campground
description: wide gravel spot for any rv skirt certainly an old campground, good for a night and close propane dealer

name: East Fork
description: For cyclists: free campground with river and a possibility to camp under a roof for a nice rain protection!

name: Hunt Propane
description: Good place for RV Propane. Fair prices great service

name: Deer Creek
description: Three large campgrounds right on a beautiful creek. Well maintained dirt road to get here.

name: First Nation suspension bridge
description: Inside the village of the Gitwinksihlkw. Right next to the native Institute. Around the corner is a brown wooden house that has sign that says “Gifts and Creations”

name: Chewing Black Bones Campground
description:
Located between the Blackfeet Indian Reservation and the Glacier National Park, this campground is run by Native Americans (Blackfeet Tribe). Most sites are nothing more than a piece of grass, some are next to trees and a few are right at the water. The campground comes with hot showers and wifi (at reception). Approximately 100 sites, starting at 25$ (non electric) up to 55$ (electric & lake side).

A bit pricey, but with a beautiful view of Glacier National Park and with a fantastic lake for swimming.

name: Denali Campground Registration
description: Free Portable water and Free Dumpstation ($5 to non guests of campground); several other amenities like Hot showers 10min./4,50$ with tokens and Laundry/Dryer

name: henness pass
description: very quiet, beautiful view into the sierra black buttes. its about 6miles or so from the paved road passed Alleghany along the historic henness pass road. the lowest crossing over the sierras in the region at 6800ft

name: Hidden Springs Campground
description: It’s okay. Pretty expensive at $35 a night. CASH or check only!

name: Nugget casino
description: In Reno I called Nugget Casino and they allow parking on the west side of tower in the back free. Little noisy but for free!!! . Dry camping

name: Dyke Hot Spring
description: Camping at Dyke Hot Spring with a great view of the Quinn River Valley. There are bathtubs in a ravine of the hot spring to soak in. Access by Woodward Road!

name: Mt. Hood NF, Lolo Pass Road, Pacific Crest Trailhead
description: Overnight Parking in Mt. Hood National Forest at the Pacific Crest Trailhead located at Lolo Pass, which is ok for one night. To the north Lolo Pass Road is heavily washed out. Within 100 ft walking you have a nice view of Mt. Hood. Many more camping spots are nearby on FR 1825 to Ramona Falls trailhead.

name: Beauty creek
description: National Forest campground, primitive with pit toilets and fire places. Firewood available for 8$. Very quiet in the Middle of nature. 23 dollars per night.

name: The remerhotel
description: Friendly clean reasonably priced close to gas and food

name: Walmart
description: Standard Walmart parking lot which is obviously used by fellow travellers. A bit noisy from the road plus the jets from 7am. Slept here one night without any issues.

name: Blue Island Avenue
description:
This is a *free*, legal stretch of Chicago that works great for stealth camping.  Chicago requires permit parking almost everywhere that is residential and pay parking everywhere else, so stealth camping can be a real challenge.  The entire stretch of Blue Island from Ashland to Western is free parking and there is *plenty* of ample parking, with lots of large open spots. Where I have marked, there are green-space plantings and some open lots that are perfect for dumping pee without being a bad neighbor.  It’s very industrial on the south side of the street so there just isn’t much foot traffic or people to worry about.   Plus, it’s right on a bike lane, so if you have bikes, you can quickly plug into Chicago’s terrific bike infrastructure.  The CTA Pink Line El is just a few blocks north, which is a fast and easy way to get to the downtown.  There are also many bus routes in the area.

You can find water at any Chicago Park that has a field house, which are free to enter and use.  Some have showers and pools. Most parks also have drinking fountains that operate from spring-fall, but those are a PITA to use for filling water cans. Nearby parks:  Dvorak Park has a historic fieldhouse plus free outdoor swimming pool in the summer from Memorial Day to Labor Day.  Ping Tom Park in Chinatown is super cool.  There is a new fieldhouse/boat house that is free, with beatiful bathrooms, indoor swimming pool, and fitness center.  While Palmisano Park doesn’t have a fieldhouse or water options, it is worth a visit for stellar views of Chicago and a fascinating history (it used to be a quarry!).

I teach at a nearby high school and have spent several nights camping in my minivan for multiple days with no problems—even without moving the van.  (Note:  normally I take the train and bike commute from the suburbs, but there are times when it’s just too much of a pain due to needing to stay at work until 10 pm for special projects or due to coaching).  I have cooked on a camp stove more than once, in the open, with no one blinking an eyelash. 

Chicago moved it’s market district about 10 years ago to just a few blocks south on BI Ave due to gentrification and expansion of the University of IL-Chicago.  As a result, this street gets morning traffic, but is remarkably quiet at night.  It is well lit all night.  As a single female who bike commutes 95% of the time, at all hours, I have never felt in danger or worried here, but I consider myself to be pretty street smart. I don’t see much foot traffic along here other than some of my students going to school and an occasional person waiting for the bus.

Crime concerns:  I bike this route daily, and I teach at a high school for students that specializes in kids who are in gangs, so I know the ‘hood better than most.  When I spend the night, I put up blackout windows and I don’t leave anything of value visible.  I have seen some broken window glass farther south on Blue Island which usually indicates break ins.  And I see a LOT of graffiti tagging—but mostly on new gentrification digs or public ways.  I think if you left your van in the same place for a week, you might have problems.  If you are moving it every 2 days, even if its just half a block, I don’t think you would need to worry.

This is close to downtown, plus it’s in the Pilsen neighborhood, which just got voted one of the 10 best neighborhoods in the world.  There are tons of great food options within blocks, mostly Mexican but also some fusion and new American, mostly on 18th Street.  Check Yelp for ideas. I am addicted to Taqueria Tayahua on Western Ave, which has the best vegetarian quesadillas (on handmade tortillas!) in town.  I die for the Huitlacoche and Flor de calabaza quesas...  For vegans, the famous El Faro is about 1.5 miles away in the Little Village neighborhood.  I also love Sora Temakaria for unusual but delicious sushi options.

Locals sell excellent tamales & champurrado at the nearby Plaza Tenochtitlan in the mornings (and sometimes right on the corner of Cermak/Blue Island/Ashland) on all but the most glacial of days.  It’s a cheap and delicious breakfast. You can also find great summertime street food (fresh fruit cups, paletas (popsicles), etc.) on mobile carts around the neighborhood. Speaking of which, the paletas are terrific, in flavors like cinnamon and rice, coconut, fresh strawberry, mango, etc). 

This location is half a block away from an Aldi, so cheap supplies are at hand if you want to cook your own food.  There are many bodega style small vendors in the neighborhood as well.  If you want to go to a “real” grocery store, check out Pete’s Fresh Market on 18th St., just west of Western Ave. They have a fabulous produce department and a great prepared food area, including a banging salad bar.

Chicago’s excellent Chinatown is a straight shot down Cermak (22nd St), an easy bike ride due east. There are so many delicious restaurants here that I suggest you browse Yelp for specifics. The outdoor mall is pretty cool for strolling around in, but parking is a bear—and you want to pay to park in a nearby lot because of *very* tight free parking lots if you drive it. A bit farther north is the very hip Randolph Street food area, home to many Michelin starred and highly reviewed venues ($$$). There is also a great Greektown, just a half mile north on Halsted.  If you like fish, I can’t recommend Santorini enough.  Finally, little Italy is a bit north and East of here.  If it’s summer, it is well worth going to Taylor Street to get some homemade Italian Ice at Mario’s, and if you eat meat, check out the famous Italian beef at Al’s (although Al’s is open year round).

name: Delta State Recreation Site (State Park)
description: Small State Park in Delta Junction at Richardson Highway. $15 per site/night. Some sites just walk-in. Was quiet at night. Drinking water available, firewood for sale. Good for one night.

name: Pilot Travel Center
description: Standard truck stop that will do in a pinch. Very busy with lots of trucks so expect some noise. We parked in the back lot along the lefthand side to leave room for the trucks. Didn't see any other travels here, but no one bothered us.

name: Rock Creek Campground
description: Established campground with 11 sites operated by NPS. A few sites along the river and hiking trails nearby. Dry camping only, but there is a pit toilet, garbage, and food canisters available. 25 ft max in all spots. No cell service on ATT. Must make reservation on recreation.gov as you cannot pay when you get there. $10 per night, $5 with senior interagency pass. They do not apply discount for regular America the Beautiful pass (even though guy on the phone said they do).

name: BLM
description: BLM dispersed camping near the highway a short ways down a forest service road. Level spaces, but rocky, not suited for tents. Road is 2WD accessable.

name: Water spigot at the 7/11
description: Water spigot at the 7/11 adjacent to Big Bear Blvd.

name: Water spigot near parking lot
description: water spigot near parking. does not look like it at Google map but there is a parking lot here. free

name: Gravel road, great views
description:
Take Park Moabi Rd exit. About 2 miles down a good gravel road there are several boondocking sites.  We have a class A 36' plus tow car. No problem. Stayed 3 days. 1 other van. Beautiful sunset.
WARNING: do not have any fires here because of the gas pipe lines

name: Metropolis Parking Lot
description: We park our 25ft class C in this lot during the week. We do not sleep in the rv overnight. We’ve seen others stay overnight. $12 a day, uses the app. No cash.

name: Large pull out that at least two card can fit, private
description:
High above the clouds, a pull out on a very windy, rural, wild road. 
This spot was good but honestly throughout this whole street there are so many pull outs that are great for camping, come early because apparently this is no secret and there are angry van lords who don’t want to share pull outs. We had a great night and a peaceful morning waking up and having breakfast here. Less then 15 cars have driven by in the 12 hours we’ve been here 9pm-9am
Highly recommend if your car can make the steep mountain drive.

name: Mojave View- Next one down
description:
Another beautiful  spot along this road that would best best w high clearance small cars (no where to turn until the campsites). This one with a view & 1-2 bars Verizon. No shade so I imagine it’s hot in the summer but perfect in December. Some bugs.

A spot for a van, small camper, or trailer a bit past the first spot on this road. Established fire pit. No other amenities except for rocks, sunsets, and coyotes howling. Road was bumpy but not sandy. No problem for 2WD. Might be difficult in a Prius, but I saw a sedan pass me after I set up camp. Remember that in Mojave you can only camp in established spots (generally marked by rock or metal fire pits). Pack it in, pack it out. Spotty 4G on Verizon in this location. Happy camping!

name: Joshua mine
description: You need to have serious confidence in your vehicle to get here - sand pits & rocky road - so 4WD and high clearance definitely. But the payoff is big. Fire pit at the base of the mountains with Joshua trees around & next to an old mine shaft which is super cool. Nice view. Also 2 bars Verizon LTE. This is the only site for miles I think.

name: Escalante outfitters
description: Public laundromat. Can change quarters at front desk. Open when the store is open. Also has nice showers, pay at front desk, too.

name: Walmart
description: One night only. Park out by Ruby Tuesday restaurant.

name: Drinking fountain
description: Water fountain, right between the beach and the parking lot, to refill your drinking water bottles

name: Walmart Supercenter
description: Overnight parking allowed in Walmart parking lot.

name: I-10 Westbound Rest Area, Monticello, FL
description: Parked on truck and RV side. Relatively quiet night as most trucks didn't idle all night and interstate traffic was minimal.

name: Walmart #468 Supercenter
description: Standard Walmart camping. I stayed here one night. There were at least five 18 wheelers nearby in the lot, so I assumed there would be no trouble, and there was not. Peaceful place, nothing but the sound of trucks.

name: Pacifica Beachfront Public Lot
description: After being told by a cop that I couldn't stay at the church parking lot near here, he directed me to this parking lot 100 ft from the ocean and said I had to stay here if I wanted stay in the area. Don't have to tell me twice! Apparently it's considered a rest area which is what he referred to it as, but it seemed like more of a paid beach access lot, but is free from 8pm-8am according to the signs if I remember correctly.  Wouldn't stay here in a large RV, but great spot next to the waves with my minivan, and big thanks to the kind cop for letting me know.

name: Ron’s seed and supply
description: Ranch supply store that fills propane cylinders

name: Walmart Pineville
description: Walmart parking lot. Stayed off to the side of the building near the pickup area because the WiFi was strong but quite a bit of traffic comes through here. Out towards the back of the main lot there were a few Semi trucks but the WiFi was no good. Good for one night.

name: Cabazon Dinosaurs
description:
Parking lot outside of gated parking for Cabazon Dinosaurs, to the left of looking at T-Rex. Was given permission by folks inside Cabazon Dinosaurs to park here. It’s right next to a gas station and the main road so a bit loud. No one else was here. 

Note: do not park to right when looking at T-Rex - signs say no overnight parking

name: Cracker Barrel
description: A few other RVs here. No signs. Cameras on building. Close to gas station for rest rooms. Lots of road noise.

name: Cracker Barrel
description: Back parking lot of the Cracker Barrel with plenty of room for buses, RVs, etc. Flat and not too bright. No WiFi or services but a nice place to spend one night.

name: cracker barrel
description:
I simply called ahead and asked the manager if I could park overnight, was no problem. Only a half hour to G.Smokey Mtn N.P.
You are literally camped out in the middle of a big shopping plaza but its quiet enough...and FREE.
Im surprised this location was not already on this app being so close to the N.P.
Gotta love Cracker Barrel!

name: cracker barrel
description:
Nice location, on busy road but overnighters are told to park outback....where it is nice and quiet and adjacent to trees. Don't leave food out you could get visitors.
Great location if your going into the park

name: K2 Camping
description:
Large space, enough for 6 of your friends vans too. Loop for RVs.
Serene and beautiful. Fire pit. 
Low spaced out brush makes for easy hiking, dotted with pines. Perfect balance.

name: K2 Camping Coconino Dispersed
description:
Large pretty area, several sites in this location. Fire pit. Pine needle floor (nice for taking walks) with tall dispersed pines. Had acres to myself.
Drove a minivan in, be careful of a few pot holes, easy to get around them.

name: South tip of Ibex Wilderness
description: This is open land with two entrances, one before and one after a power transformer site set back from the road. Interesting terrain for hiking. The more southern road was a little soft/sandy in a couple of places so I was a little nervous to get stuck, but just kept my momentum up with front wheel drive van and was fine. I tested the more northern road entrance on the way out and it had at least one pretty deep wash that encouraged me to turn around and head back out the southern road. These are coordinates for a nice wide open spot where the two roads conjoin. Road continues further in. Wind started howling overnight. Not sure if that’s a thing here, but it sure is now! Great expansive views.

name: Lookout Point picnic area
description: Found this site using other apps. stayed the night there was one other car camper.  Quiet all night and beautiful view in the morning!

name: concrete blocks on the dam road
description: A small pullout at the border of the state park. The Kachess Lake road was closed by snow so we took this spot.   The highway noise was noticeable but sounded more like a river than an interstate.  Had good cell service.

name: Street parking
description: We were booked at the Quality Inn here but arrived a couple of days early to pick up some stuff.  Noticed a motor home parked on this dead end block in back.  Decided to try staying here before our reservation and had no issues.  Shops and restaurants nearby.  Strong cell signal.  There are traffic and train sounds but otherwise quiet and no one bothered us.  There's a fenced up junk yard next door so not pretty but free if you want to be in Yuma.  There is a wifi signal from the hotel but without a voucher you have to buy time/data.  A few big trucks park around this street and around the corner.  We also found free wifi a block away at Navy Credit Union.

name: Walmart Parking Lot Opelousas
description: Large parking lot with quite a few dining options nearby. I parked for one night off to the side of the building near the pick up area. It was pretty noisy and at times didn’t feel totally safe. You can still pick up Walmart WiFi if you park close enough.

name: Sunny mountainside
description: Small clearing with fire ring in the forest surrounded by tall pines. Not a destination site, but a nice solid, shady spot! No cell Signal. Recommend high clearance, small vehicle, 2wd should be fine if dry. Turn off Rt49 at Brandy City Rd, Continue past campground. Left onto Fiddle Creek (gravel road). then a bit down the road, there will be a dirt road on the right leading up a small hill where there is a small level clearing. If you have high clearance and/or willing to clear some branches, you can continue along dirt path to the fire ring. FYI it appears someone lives at the end of Fiddle Creek so not 100% sure the spot is legal. No one bothered me!

name: Medium Trees
description: 3 spots in the forest surrounded by tall pines - this is the nicest since it has a fire ring! You have to back into the spot (there’s not enough space to turn), so don’t recommend trailers. Road to get here is hard packed dirt with big deep potholes and steep sections. But you can make it with any 2wd if dry (I made it with a Prius). Road looks scarier at night than it is. Lots of trash lying around Please help keep it clean! No Verizon service. Additional spots along this road and along forest rd 5N52 a bit further down - that road is officially a dispersed camping area as listed on the national forest website. Enjoy!

name: Tanbar Ridge Overlook
description: Pull-out near Asheville and the BRP with a view of town and the valley. Pins further down this road were closed due to weather, but we were able to sleep here without being bothered. This spot was very busy with many cars stopping by throughout the night. No amenities. Two bars of service on ATT.

name: Yellow Gap Site 13
description: We checked out all 14 established sites on this road. The majority are definitely meant for tent camping as there are designated pads for your gear, fire rings, and the parking spots are only big enough for cars. Site 13 accommodated our 170” sprinter just fine and it was near the creek (site 9 would be nice too). This would be a great spot in the summer due to the natural wading pool a few feet away. Several cars drove by during the two days we spent here, but otherwise very quiet. I would not recommend any big rigs down this road as it can get very narrow and  bumpy (also too big to fit at sites and no where to turn around). Just an FYI, there is a gate blocking the road not far after site 14 so this is not a thru-road at this time. No amenities and minimal cell service on ATT. Free!

name: Chevron
description: Dual pump propane refill at the Chevron gas station

name: Greenie Peak
description: One way and one way out loop on Greenie Peak near Red River. Areas available for a wild camping

name: Mary’s Peak
description: Radical spot, 4x4 recommended depending on season. Beautiful scenery all around. Tons of room. Windy. Some traffic

name: Coconino national forest
description: Dispersed camp site in the pines near Snow Bowl. You can still hear traffic from US. 180 but a nice place to relax for a few nights.i have no reception for T-Mobile.

name: historic tennis court parking
description: Large parking lot on tennis court premise with lots of restaurants around the area. Lights were on at night until 9pm and then shut off. Super quiet, no one bothered us. Even had garbage cans for us to dispose of our trash. definitely recommend

name: Boulder Spot
description: Nice site next to a boulder, very limited cell coverage but very beautiful! Stayed one night and will be back.

name: Large clearing in the Forest
description: Very large clearing in the National Forest. the Forest Road that's turns off to lead down here is fairly decent but I would definitely not recommend a trailer or during wet weather. You are within ear shot of a cattle farm. So every now and again you will hear a cow mooing

name: Needles Mountain Road
description: Area used by OHVs and RVs.  Gravel road from Highway 40.  Many informal campsites with campfire rings.  No other amenities.  Lots of dirt tracks for walking and OHV use.  Views of mountains.

name: Gas Station
description: Propane, gas, diesel fuel and certified scales

name: Chevron
description: Propane for $2.65 a gallon. They do have water here. you have to ask. they give you a thing to use the water but the spigot is attached to a dirty hose. so I decided not to use it for drinking water.

name: Speedway
description: Water spigot next to ice machine. Ask first. also, propane for $3 a gallon. and a carwash but low clearance.

name: Cleaners & Laundry
description: Decent laundromat. Coin operated. Change machine. Friendly service.

name: state line campground at Avery
description:
Moderator Note: Please note this location maybe seasonal

------------------------------------------------


Free.  Pit toilets and nice sites along the Columbia River. Adjacent train traffic is very bothersome through the night but otherwise it was a good place to stay.  Regs say no winter camping but we were totally left alone. Good cell service.

name: Mesa camp
description: Free.  Secluded spot on top of the mesa just off road 27.

name: Beachside
description:
Dead end side street next to hotel. Bathrooms with running water and cold showers adjacent(park). Im in a minivan but will fit large vans too. Not sure about RVs? The only noise I hear is the ocean waves :)
**FYI: It is 15 min parking during daytime hours (11am-6pm) so I simply move to the free beach lot adjacent which is open 4am-10pm.

name: HERFORD CITY RV PARK
description: CITY OWNED RV PARKING WITH ELECTRIC AND WATER

name: Greenridge SF site #5
description: Open level site on top of plateau. During winter very open to wind across site. Blue marked trail runs across site.

name: One tree turnout
description: Lovely turnout with a single tree.  Fire pit.  Not far off main road.

name: Susan Campbell park
description: The best place to experience Annapolis. In the heart of it all, right on the water, next to a park — and overnighting is allowed. It’s frequently patrolled, but no hassles. Because it’s a business district, keeping a relatively low profile is proper. All cel signals are strong, the lot is flat and you can see the Maryland state house from your window. Paid during the day; free overnight.

name: Flat Creek
description: Several pull outs off forest service roads.  Views of the Tetons.  Verizon reception.

name: Large site off the road a bit
description: A big site with an established fire pit. Right next to train tracks that woke us up a few times during the night. Close to the freeway but not too loud in the van. The path back might be a little tight for big rigs, but it's pretty smooth and there's plenty of room to turn around.

name: Home Depot
description: Quiet night away from road in car park of Home Depot but close also to a Cracker Barrel. Managed to get WIFI too from HD.

name: Beautiful BLM in Pinto
description: Great spot. Isolated. Dead quiet. Lots of spots. Multiple fire rings. No ATT service, gorgeous nonetheless.

name: Walmart Supercenter
description: I called the manager and they said we could stay here for two nights. Please camp on the outskirts of the lot.

name: Planet Fitness
description: Planet Fitness with huge parking lot for RVs and campers. Nice hot showers

name: Water spigot at 7/11
description: Clean water spigot at the 7/11 adjacent to Big Bear Blvd.

name: Chimney Creek BLM
description: Boulder trailhead. Short pullout on the left immediately after a massive boulder. Not level and not more than 40’ deep. However, there is usually 1 bar of AT&T here

name: National forest lot
description:
Nice pull off along the main road through the forest. Easy access. Room for a couple rigs 

It is a parking lot for a shooting spot

name: BLM dispersed
description: Traveled up a myriad of networked dirt roads outside of VOF SP. Easily accessible, neighbors were very spread out. This dispersed spot was large and flat and had great views. There are others in every direction. Much less populated than Poverty Flats side (that was a zoo)! Great sunset and sunrise. Good ATT 5G signal.

name: Gravel Pile
description: Found a nice spot behind a gravel pile just off the road near the Boulder Reservoir turn.

name: Miller’s Canyon Rd
description: Nice pull off we found (on the way to another spot). Quiet gravel road but not overly level. Good enough spot to get away from the crowd along US101.

name: The Piñon Cafe
description: Awesome breakfast!! Much more than you can eat. Good prices.

name: Flying Eagle Preserve
description: This is a preserve run by the Southwest Florida Land and Wildlife Mgmt. You have to reserve online and can stay up to 6 nights. All free. Each site has a fire ring and picnic tables. All size rigs can fit.

name: Scenic overlook
description: Great views, best sunrise. Four bars of ATT. Windy when I was there. Some road noise but not much.

name: Katherine’s Landing Campground
description: $20 a night, fire pit, bbq, picnic table, flat spots. super clean bathrooms. We came here to fill up our water tank and decided to stay a night since it was getting dark. Good place to get water, dump tanks, shower. We were here in December and it was almost empty.

name: Off Vekol Valley Rd
description: I really love this spot, just the area in general. There are  few more spots I saw in the area, can’t go wrong with any of them. The area is very calm and quiet which is super pleasant. The topography is nice here, there are not many cactuses for my pups to step on which was really nice. More bushes as opposed to cactuses, but some saguaros around and mountains surrounding. I had good T-Mobile service in this exact spot, which is part of the reason I camped here. I made a little fire ring as there wasn’t one here. Enjoy :)

name: Hidden Valley Road Option #2
description: This is a perfectly flat gravel parking area maybe nearly as large as a football field and it's wide open. Traffic noise is not too bad.....sleeping was not a problem. Certainly not the cleanest area so use a flashnight at night. Verizon service was pretty good here.

name: Space Station RV park
description:
Stopped here for just one night to clean up and shower. Propane was expensive at 3.99/gal.  Highway noise was a major problem. The pull thrus are dirt.  The wifi connects but is very slow. Many barking/howling dogs...both inside campers and outside. Low pressure in the men's shower. So overall all we're very disappointed with this stop. But it served our purpose, then we happily got out.

Also...we went to eat at the Sourdough Saloon which was awful. Everything was broken and disgusting. The fries were good, everything else tasted terrible.  The bathrooms were likely last cleaned sometime in 2017.

name: Gantt fields
description: Huge open space in the woods with 3 separate fire rings. We didn’t find much level ground so traction boards are a plus.

name: Los Palmas Oases
description: Parking lot on top of hill. Caretaker/Ranger approached us and told us to stay here if we like. He said you can stay up to 14 days. Staying in the parking lot below, next to the restrooms is not allowed. Absolutely beautiful view. Gorgeous hikes. Pit toilets are available below parking lot.

name: Pilot Rest Stop
description: Hanging with the truckers. It’s getting cold out here.

name: Riverside
description: This campsite is next to a river and has a small open shelter for tenters, a fire pit, picnic table, and a lantern holder.  The site is not very level at all but with a little blocking, most smaller rigs can be adjusted.

name: Chevron
description: Free dump and water at the Chevron.  Off to the side of the fuel station.

name: Snag Lake
description: Pull out in the road to Snag Lake. The lower spots were taken and further up the road was another pull out. Nice quiet spot with 2 bars of Verizon service.

name: US campsite #P4
description: Lakefront Tent pad and picnic table on lake Santeetlah.  There is a pit toilet at the first site down the road.

name: Liberty Lake Regional Park
description: This campground is run by Spokane County.  With showers, a kitchen wash up area, room for tents and RVs, this is a wonderful little spot.  We paid $37.50 per day.  We also had good reception with AT&T.  Open from May through September.

name: Zumwalt’s Garage
description: A mechanic’s shop to help get you back on the road. They swapped out our radiator, and it only took 2 hours.  Super friendly and helpful.

name: MedHero Urgent Care Parking Lot
description: Parking lot of urgent care building. Camped here 3 nights. Very quiet. Some lighting. A few others coming at night. No signs for any parking restrictions.

name: Chickasabogue Park
description: Small park with big sites.  $15.60 per night.  Showers, laundry, hiking, biking and disc golf.  Ranger Carlos is top notch

name: Crystal Mtn Summit
description: Dispersed campsite with super view of Lake Winona. Most of the Forest Roads are easily handled in a standard 2WD vehicle/van. However the last little short road to the top is very rocky. There is a rock fire ring and AT&T LTE was good.

name: Nelson Hardware store
description: Propane fill service on the right side of the building

name: Speedway
description: RV Propane and free dump at this Speedway

name: Freeway Express / Valero
description: Southbound exit. Water spigot on side of the building with potable water. Gas station with ice, food.

name: Frazier Park
description: Gas is even cheaper here than in Bakersfield. Right off the freeway in Frazier Park. Multiple gas stations.

name: Luna Park Road
description: Varied sites 6 miles from Monticello on Luna Park road just inside the National Forest boundary.

name: hungaro
description: supply of propane gas with very good and fast price the service is worth

name: Gainesville Travel Information Center Southbound
description:
Rest stop. Good for a night. Just passing.
through

name: Dirt road before sitting bull falls
description: You can camp off the road here but if you go up this dirt road you can get 4GLTE Verizon signal.  Otherwise you're in a valley with no signal.  The first spot thg is easy to get to with high clearance.  The second spot definitely needs 4x4 and the road is very rough from there.  Beautiful views and close to the falls in the AM.

name: Cline's gas station
description: Free water hose bib between pumps.  I asked the staff and they said it was potable.

name: Fastrip - Glacier Water jugfill
description: self service water machine - use your own container December 2020 - 30 cents per gallon $1.50 for five gallon - potable water - would have given five stars but there wasn't convenient parking for lugging a big water container.  Also the app wouldn't let me change the star rating to four stars like I wanted.

name: Buckeye BLM
description: There are lots of places for dispersed camping here. Unfortunately there is so, so much trash. We picked up the trash in our area and left it at the gazebo near the entrance, which I've heard is maintained by the county.  This place is convenient because of its proximity to Buckeye, and its easy roads in (level dirt, some washboard).  But the amount of garbage and shooting debris (shells and garbage that's been shot up) makes it kind of a depressing place.  Decent Verizon and AT&T reception.

name: oversize vehicle beach parking for Pismo and Grover beaches
description: Stopped here, lots of trailers for horses and RV's parked. Relatively flat, no signs. Nice place to stretch legs and walk on the beach.

name: Arizona Land Trust Permit Required
description: Open area with dispersed camping. Good cell signal and quiet. Big rig friendly. You can order a permit online, very easy! Just search Arizona Land Trust permit.

name: Arabia mountain
description: beautiful hiking and biking trails with lots of scenic views

name: Walmart front lot
description: The parking lot was almost empty when we rolled our van in at 10:30 pm. No other campers, RV's or truck rigs were detected. We saw no signs prohibiting overnight camping, and we had no interaction at all with any security or anyone else for that matter. Pretty quiet compared to some Walmart lots. we slept in, walked the dog and rolled out 8:30 am. Very good Verizon cell service.

name: Marathon Travel Plaza (aka King's Plaza)
description: Take the TRUCK entrance and see the dump station, on the right, just after entering the property.  There is a sign. Non-potable water

name: Boondocking near Carondolet Park
description: Arrived in the neighborhood after dark and it was quiet the entire night. Close to the Mississippi River and Carondolet Park. No issues parking overnight in our retro high top camper van. The park also has public restrooms but not sure the hours.

name: Lennox Ridge Rd campsite
description: This is a dispersed campsite in the Winding Stair Mtn National Recreation Area. Lennox Ridge RD is a well graded Forest Rd that any standard 2WD car/van and trailers can handle. There a rock fire ring with a large open area that can fit several vehicles and trailers. No AT&T LTE or even 3G.

name: Cracker Barrel #271
description: 1625 Jim Johnson Rd, Fayetteville, North Carolina.  Just off I-95.  Three designated RV spaces on south side of the restaurant with additional parking for smaller rigs on the north side.  We stayed overnight in our 21 ft Travato camper van, parked in a normal parking spot on the south east end of the restaurant property.  Trees provide some good noise dampening but like any location beside a major highway, there is traffic noise.  Parking lot is not flat but this one is certainly NOT the worst we've seen in our Cracker Docking.  Please do patronize either the country store of the restaurant to ensure CB continues to allow us 'overlanders' overnight use of their facilities.  We've encountered three CB's recently which no longer allow overnight.

name: Sonoran Desert Monument area
description: Lovely. Wide open. Scattered cactus in places. Plenty of spots to choose from. Just beyond here there were some steep road dips that would require 4wd but up until here just fine. Large flat open space plenty of room for multiple vehicles. Fire ring.  A couple of bars of LTE cell coverage.

name: Beaver Lake boat ramp
description:
Peaceful, lakefront gravel lot at the end of a forrest service road.  This area is frequented by hunters who park here to enter the wma.
Do not park blocking either the launch ramp or the gate to the right of the ramp.

name: Arizona Fluff n Dry
description: Extremely nice attendant. Clean, not too expensive. In the middle of upgrades.

name: gyp spring canyon
description: Open gravel lot at the end of a dirt road. enough space for multiple tents or camper. access road is in good condition. beautiful views.

name: Mall parking lot
description: Nice quiet parking lot. Home Depot and other stores here. Lots of other campers here too. Also campers in the Sam’s club on the other side of Home Depot

name: buckwheat basin
description: Awesome and remote site along a 2 track road west of Ibex mine. Near sand dunes.  No outlet that we could find. Marginal Verizon signal.

name: Near Lost Horse Tank
description: BLM with level sites off old SR 84.  Good for overnight.  Better spots to the east near Freeman exit, but were taken.   Road noise from I-8.  Easy access to/from I-8.

name: Sam's Gap Overlook
description: Stayed here at the overlook on the border of Virginia and North Carolina. Dark, quiet, no other people. Had to leave part way through the night because of VERY high storm winds.

name: Faraway Ranch Parking
description: Nice place to fill your water. Faucet right next to curb.

name: Left Coast Diesel
description: Ross is an excellent mechanic, takes the time to explain things. Very attentive, knows his stuff, highly recommend. **Does not work on sprinters**

name: Ibex Spring below Ibex Mine
description: Palm trees mark this spot. Mine relics and ghost buildings. Fair ATT signal. Marginal/spotty Verizon signal. Magical spot. High clearance and 4WD helpful.

name: Bull Creek WMA
description: Awesome established place by the WMA (do not camp in the actual WMA). This is a hunters camp, if you are fine with that enjoy, if you're not - stay away. Even has a pit toilet.  Big rig friendly.  Solid cell with Verizon and T-MOBILE. Enjoy!

name: Stone Church Campground
description: Established horse camp. Multiple sites. Small fee. New pit toilet.

name: Urban South Brewery
description: Free street parking outside of Urban south brewery. The street itself doesn’t have a lot of traffic at night but the streets on either side of it does. Almost all day and most of the night. Not a peaceful night sleep but it felt safe. There is a shell gas station about 2 blocks away.

name: Fancy Creek State Park
description: Camping area with really great trails. The trails go through a variety of biodiversity.

name: Great spot with Amazing Views
description:
If you keep skipping camping spots around Sedona due to human feces, waste, litter, etc, head to this spot.  Has great views and the small suv/sedan crowd wont be able to get to it to poop all over the camp site. It's far back and the final climb to the spot you really need 4WD high clearance to get up to.  PLEASE buy at least a $20 luggable loo from REI. camping in this BLM land can be beautiful but the crowds have taken their toll... most spots have visible human waste and toilet paper all over the place. There are a lot of big rigs closer to the highway running generators.  

1 bar Verizon LTE. Sent a few pics but not very fast.  Great text / calling though!

name: Willow Loop Campground
description:
Sites facing the lake are largest. those on the side of the lake smaller. Has full hook ups, cabins, bathrooms, 7 lakes. pets allowed though extra charge. close to San Diego.

Location updated

name: Cracker Barrel restaurant
description: Very kind management when I called, said they always welcome overnight stays. Right off I-26, a little traffic noise from interstate and hotel next door, but not too bad. 3 dedicated RV pull-through sites about 30’ long each behind the restaurant, plus lots of extra open parking - two larger rigs over 40’ were parked around the perimeter. Grassy area for walking pets, trash cans. I’d plan to leave early to not take up their parking spaces for long - weekends especially.

name: Mile 8 post
description:
Small pull off spot for van or tent camping. 
Fire ring beyond barbed wire fence. 

I parked parallel to road. Used leveling block for the van. Great views, but the road was really busy for New Years Eve. Lots of traffic till late at night. Didn’t expect that 8 miles in on a windy rough dirt road.
