Sunset and sunrise was spectacular here, but this spot and the many I saw before here, were littered with garbage and debris from people target shooting up here. It’s a legal activity, but what a mess left behind by shotgun shells and everything they are shooting at - glass and plastic bottles, clay targets, and random junk. 

Aside from the litter, totally worth the views. Might not be as busy on no holidays, but I have a feeling it is a popular weekend 4x4 and ATV destination.

name: Gasoline Road
description: Free.  Look for the gas pipeline markers on the north side of 66. Beautiful chocolate colored mtns to the north. Many options to choose from. Very faint hiway noise. Good ATT service.  No Verizon signal.  We were going to stay in Mohave but it was windy and cold up there, so we continued.  It was warm, sunny, and calm here on New Years Day.

name: Rest Area on I 22
description: Rest area with ample parking for larger rigs on truck side. Lot of semi traffic, but an easy place to spend the. night.

name: Miner’s Corner
description: Simple spot set back a couple of hundred meters from the main road so quiet. This spot is a large flat area along what appears to be a road leading toward a mine. No private property signs anywhere so likely fine to stay here. No trucks but we were here in Jan 1 so perhaps no mining activity due to holiday. Sweeping vast views.  The road is solid unlike some of the sandier roads in the area. Some washboard but no real ruts. Didn’t explore any further but roads definitely continue. Nice spot.

name: Kiamichi Trail #1
description: This is a dispersed campsite along the K-Trail (FR6025). It can be easily accessed from Hwy 259 from the east. The Forest Road is well graded, and can be done in a standard 2WD car/van. Access from the west would require a rugged 4x4 vehicle. There is a rock fire ring. AT&T service was only 3G, no LTE.

name: Southern Palms RV Resort
description: We are currently staying at Southern Palms for a week and we are very pleased with the park.  Staff are very friendly and helpful in leading us to our spot.  Some may find the sites a little snug, but we were comfortable with that.  It is also a park that has a rare 12:00 checkout time which gives a little more time to prepare for leaving.  Would definitely come back again.

name: Shared Starbucks / Breeze Ski Rental Lot
description: Parked at the back of this lot for one night and the following full day without any problems. There are no "No Overnight Parking"  signs and I was able to connect to the Starbucks WiFi from the back of the lot. I went into Breeze Ski Rentals to rent a board after staying here and someone said they saw me out there and liked my van. Didn't seems like they had any problem with me staying.

name: Timberlake Campground
description: RV Campground with the usual amenities. Quiet enough at night. Within walking distance of a shopping center with grocery.

name: Kathryn Hanna Campground
description: City run park and campground. Hiking trails, playground, and beach access. $33 per night (including taxes) which we thought was a bit steep considering the sites are crowded with limited privacy. Most sites come with electric, water, and sewer. Could be worth the money if you are in need of a dump, water, and shower. Good cell service on ATT & verizon.

name: Pilot Truck Stop, with free Water and Dump Station
description: Pilot Truck Stop with fuel, propane, air, water, dump station. Water and dump are free, air costs money. Water is next to the air which is on the south side of the parking lot. There is a Subway and pizza place inside.

name: I-95 St. Johns County, St. Augustine, FL
description:
I95 rest stop. 
Dog walk and vending machines. Ice cream coffee and drinks. Bathrooms open.

name: Wooden Eagle
description: Follow unmapped dirt road along creek. Take first left dirt road branch to end where you will find a beautiful open camp site with fire ring. Short hike to clear water creek from here. Super quiet and private. Lots of places to explore. We had a great time with our doggo here.

name: Artesia Public Library WiFi
description: Free Open WiFi here. Fast.

name: Access Trail off highway 16 (BLM)
description: Small makeshift campsite down by the creek. Gate was open and the trail is narrow and required 4WD low to reach.

name: Modoc National Forest adjacent to Lava Beds NM
description: Flat place of earth just outside the Lava Beds NM on the way into the park from the north. 1 bar AT&T and T-Mobile that comes and goes.

name: Green Swamp Wilderness West Tract
description: This is part of Southwest Florida Land Management. Camping is free with an online reservation. Once you reserve you get access to the gate code. There is alot of land surrounding the sites and big rigs can fit (lots of horse trailers in this site this weekend). https://www.swfwmd.state.fl.us/

name: Pecan Park
description: Slept in the corner of the parking lot it’s a nice flat spot. There are bathrooms you can walk to. You will probably hear cars drive by at night but I found it relaxing

name: Pilot travel center
description: Corner of the parking lot next to air and vacuum is a free water hose

name: Clear lake boat launch
description: Quite secluded place to park about a mile of paved road from the freeway. There are plenty of flat spots for a van or rv. There is also a truck stop you can park at right off this exit

name: Grand isle beach #25
description: If you surf check the forecast. I was able to get some super fun waist to chest high waves on my inflatable paddle board. No one bugged me at this spot and for the most part it was quiet. Way better then having to pay at the state park just a couple minutes down the road. Oh and across the street is another park if someone is already here or you have a bigger rig

name: Stealth neighborhood parking lot
description: If you can pull in and be quite (no generator) this spot is great! I was parked by the beach just a couple of blocks away and it was so loud. So I found this super quite safe spot. Just be respectful and this spot is great

name: Harrahs casino
description: Great place for overnight. You can gamble watch sports and crash... not what I would say... if you want to stay in a big rig, call them first

name: Prince William Forest RV Campground
description: Concession campground for national park. Electric/water or full hookups. Open year round with self check in when office is closed.

name: Walmart/ Anytime Fitness
description: Parking lot. not signs saying no overnight. Stayed one night there where a couple of other rigs staying as well. No one bothered us. Anytime Fitness is open 24/7 of you have a membership. Quite from 11 to 6 or so.

name: Old Boat Launch, Beach Access
description: The best “beach” I’ve seen at Salton Sea, and this abandoned boat launch provides water front access and lots of room to camp, both on and off the beach. Peaceful, quiet, no smells, no bugs, no trash. No wind during our stay. Currently hard packed ground with easy turnaround, but could be different after heavy rain. 3 other RVs present with plenty of distance between. Felt safe. 3 bars of AT&T 5G(E). Exit Niland Marina Road off 111 and drive to the end.

name: Cactus Storage, Propane, Water, & Laundromat
description: Propane cheaper here: $2.90.   Water for sale in a little building.  Laundromat prices start at $1.50 and go up to wash and start at .25 and go up.

name: Tates hell SF high bluff primitive campsites
description: In Tates Hell state Forrest, there are quite a few primitive campsites in the area (see map). This post is for number 49 on Pidcock road, really beautiful spot right by the river with big grassy area, picnic bench and fire pit. It is hard to find, none of the roads are labeled and little service, make sure you scout out on the map before going in. You need to make a reservation on reservation.gov, 9$ a night. Muddy road, but doable in any vehicle. A few hunters, some foxes and lots of birds.

name: Rest area
description: Water available at faucet near restrooms.  Located between three protective wooden posts.

name: home depot parking garage
description: Stayed overnight at this home depot 2 story garage! we stayed on the 2nd floor, theres no roof its just a open garage space. Another overland was here with us for the night.  great spot, nobody bugged us and it was fairly quiet all night! recommend!

name: Sunset Beach
description: There are a number of fresh water spigots to fill tanks in the parking area.

name: Walmart
description: Walmart parking lot in complex. Parked in the back corner with a few tractor trailers. Strong Verizon signal.

name: BLM
description: BLM camping at Sierra Vista Trailhead. Once you get off I-10 on the opposite side of the shell you go over the cattle rails and drive maybe a mile or two up and on your left hand side there will be a sign in the bushes for Sierra Vista is you drive in that for maybe 100 meters you will hit the parking lot. There are fire rings and spots for plenty of rigs even large ones. I’ve been there multiple times the first time was a Saturday night and there was one other rig there and cars parked there the next morning to hike the trail, I just parked towards the edge as not to be bothered. The other times when the weather chilled and on weekdays no one was ever in the lot. People do live up the road a little so cars will pass but it’s tucked in the brush enough. It’s a beautiful view for the sunrise and sunset! On one side of the lot I got some LTE Verizon service while on the other side I got no service. There are no amenities but such an amazing spot and so close to El Paso if you do need anything!

name: Santiago St
description: A quiet street behind a hotel. Some tree shade. Other trucks and cars campers overnight. The nearby Walmart does not allow overnight, the one 4 miles to the west does.

name: US border patrol
description: Looks like a weigh station but all vehicles have to stop. Waved through if US citizen. Friendly

name: Northside Overlook
description: Ridge on the north side of KOFA Butte.  Excellent views in every direction. 1-2 bars of Verizon.

name: Airport Cell Phone Lot
description: Stayed in a 20' van with a bike rack. Ideal for semi stealth, or at least something you could justify saying you're picking someone up in. Nice clean bathrooms 24/7. Big parking lot with ever revolving cars waiting to pick folks up. No "no" signs and never saw security. I was dropping a friend off for an early flight so this would have been the justification if we got a knock but no one seems to mind. Parked at 2A, dropped off at 5:30A, then went back to nap until 10A. Planes start taking off around 6A and they're often right over top. Not the best, not the worst, but definitely better than nothing.

name: Merritts Mill Pond Boat Launch
description: When the trails and boat launch at Cavern State Park in Florida were closed due to flooding and storm damage we asked the ranger of another place to kayak. He directed us to the boat launch for Merritts Mill Pond off Hunter Fish Camp Road, west of Marianna, Florida. There’s a large parking lot where we stayed overnight. The parking was a tiny bit slanted but not bad. Big rigs could fit in but probably not advisable because boat trailers need room to park unless you come late and leave early. It was fantastic. The pond (about four or more miles long) has at least four springs coming into it so it’s crystal clear with cypress tree groves on each side. We went left and paddled up to Blue Springs Recreation Area at the end.

name: Poteau Mountain Rd #1
description: This is a dispersed campsite along Poteau Mtn Rd. The road is hardpack dirt and maintained by the county. Any standard 2WD car/van could get here. There are plenty of tall pine shade trees, and a fire ring. There is also a pond about 50 yards east. The is an old concrete foundation slab where you could gather chairs. AT&T LTE coverage is excellent.

name: Brown wood Paddock Square
description:
MODERATOR NOTE: WARNING! Thefts and vandalism reported in this location. Please use caution.

Empty parking lot behind shopping area, overlooking a marsh with birds and fauna. Quiet night, lights not intrusive. Coffee shops and deli nearby.

name: Planet Fitness Parking Lot
description: Parked in the lot in front of Planet Fitness. Unfortunately due to COVID, showers were closed. But restrooms were still open (to members). There were other campervans parked near us as well. No signs posted, and no problems! Also near a Walmart and several other dining/shopping options.

name: Coal country pullout
description: Right off the highway. Some noise. Good cell coverage. Turnaround suitable for rigs of any size.

name: Casa Blanca
description: Hotel Casino in Mesquite, Nevada, has a paved RV parking area on the west side of their property.  Sign says parking for 72 hours max.  It isn't level, but far enough away from the freeway that there isn't a lot of noise.  There were three other RVs there while we stayed there for one night.

name: TA truck stop
description:
MODERATOR NOTE: No overnight camping allowed, please respect the wishes of the locals. 

Rest room clean, parking space safe, shower available

name: Loves
description: Travel center. Open 24/7. Has propane refills and a small dog park.

name: Elizabethtown crossroads campground
description: Campground with showers, restrooms, store, pool

name: Walmart
description: This is an OPEN Walmart. Quiet with lots of room. You can get wifi from Walmart

name: Skaggs RV
description: RV sales, parts, and mechanic available here

name: Broadwater lighthouse campground
description: This place is crazy! It’s like you are camping on an island. Which can be good and bad. It rained and was really windy last night so I definitely didn’t sleep good. And it is a little Sandy going here but any vehicle can make it. Definitely a spot to check out

name: Peoples Creek Campground
description: Established campground belonging to Corps of Engineers overlooking Lake Wappapello. Quiet and beautiful even in winter. Electric and water at each site.

name: BLM / trail head
description: Nice spot couple hundred feet off the main road. Also a trail for hiking. Could fit a few small rigs

name: Pilot Truck Stop
description: Parking is small for travelers, restroom was cleaned when I visited location, conveniently next to the I-5 going north, overnight stay for travelers is very safe but not room for RV’s or campers wh trailers.

name: Hoodoo Cabin
description: A working windmill marks this spot. A refurbished line camp cabin is open to the public. A covered water hole draws lots of wildlife. We saw 100+ quail when we were there.  Peaceful. Awe inspiring. Spotty Verizon.  No ATT signal. We definitely needed 4WD getting here.

name: BLM outside of KOFA
description: In a wash after leaving KOFA.  Plenty of firewood and distant views.  No cell service of any kind.

name: BLM North of KOFA
description: Finally found signal ... after a week in KOFA.  Out of gas. Out of water. But all is well.

name: Water mill Express
description: $0.25 per gallon. $1.00 for 5 gallon. Buy 4 get 1 free

name: Brawley Ace Hardware
description: Press the button in the right rear of the tank for service. Customers service was expedient. $2.49/lb

name: Brick House Campground
description:
23 campsites with tables, grills, and lantern holders, Extended Stay Designated Campsites: 9, 12, 18, 19, 20, 21, 22, and 23 – all other sites have a 14-day stay limit.

This year-round camping facility provides an opportunity for many recreational activities such as wildlife and plant observation, horse riding, mountain biking, hiking, and photography. Abundant wildlife populations provide some of the most desirable hunting areas in the upstate.
Eight campsites have been designated for extended stay use during big game hunting season: September 4 through January 4 and the month of April.

name: Crawdad Cove Road Pullout
description: Nice, fairly level pullout along the Crawdad Cove Road. Good Verizon reception. 1 car passed durning the evening. Crawdad Cove Rd is very washboard so we stopped here instead of driving another 1.6 miles to the cove.

name: Oak Plantation Campground
description: Full service RV park about 20 min from Charleston. Challenging to turn into it when traveling from the south in Rt 17

name: Little Tensas Bayou Boat Ramp
description: Just your average boat ramp, there are generally always trucks parked there overnight. Big space in the back corner. If you’re into fishing, trout and catfish can be caught. No amenities here.

name: Chattahoochee National Forest
description: There are several beautiful primitive campsites along Chattahoochee River Road, with plenty of space for car camping. The road is long, unpaved (graveled), narrow, and winding along the mountain, but relatively flat. I don't know that AWD is essential, but I was glad to have it. In hindsight, I don't think the road was too risky under normal circumstances. I didn't make it as far down the road as I'd planned, because it was due to rain in the morning and I was worried about getting in too deep. But the drive back out in the rain wasn't too harrowing. There is a sign at the entrance to this road saying the road is closed ahead, but it's unclear at what point it's closed. I didn't encounter any reason for it to be closed, at least as far as I went in.

name: Rodman Mountains Canyon
description: Remote place to camp on the side of the trail. Road in is rough but we did bring our small trailer. Hiking in the canyon was easy but cool rock formations to see. Huge area for pets to run around for lots of sniffs, if good off leash.

name: Dome Rock BLM
description: Free BLM. Fire ring. Very minor freeway traffic. 3 bars Verizon.

name: Cracker Barrel
description: What to say? It’s a Cracker Barrel. I always check in with a manager just to let them know we’ll be there overnight. This particular location is walkable to so many grocery stores and other restaurants. Good location for resources but a touch loud as it’s surrounded by busy streets. RV Pull through spots available.

name: NF Pull Off
description: A small pull off off Buckeye Ridge Road with pre-existing fire ring. It appears to be on National Forest land. Rangers drove by and didn't stop. Requies backing in, but a trailer could fit in.

name: Pine Meadows Campground  (primitive area)
description: An Army Corps of Engineers campground on the edge of Cottage Grove Reservoir. Many nice level sites, many with a view of the reservoir. Main camping area (1000 feet to the north) has hook-ups and costs $22 / night.  The primitive area where we stayed costs $14. 3 Bars Verizon LTE.

name: Cottage Grove Lake Campground
description: Free with paid campsite. Just inside main gate area.

name: Riverside gravel meadow
description: Less than 100 feet off HWY 58, this is a large gravel meadow with plenty of flat spaces for big rigs. Very close to the river too. But, at the expense of considerable road noise. Traffic slows down around 6pm.

name: Wikiup South Point - edge of lake
description: Along the edge of this now receded lake is a trail accessed from the Reservoir Campground waypoint on Google. Along the edge of the lake there are places to tuck in for the night. 4x4 suggested. Great views. Lots of wildlife. Can be windy.

name: China Hat Campground
description: Basic National Forest campground with fire rings and picnic tables.  Seems to be free.

name: Pull off of NF-4606
description:
There are many pull offs along NF-4606.
Most are suitable for trailers. Just keep 100 ft back from the road and keep your camp clean.

name: Mineral Springs CCC
description: A small CCC campground with about 7 sites.  All have tables and fire rings. $5 per night.

name: Former forest road - Iron Creek
description: There is a large open area about 100 feet to the west of NF 25. (I think this used to be the old paved roadway...) Can be accessed from the south off NF25. Plenty of room for several larger rigs. Large clearing gets sun most of the day. Gravel flat spots for tents. Large cement fire ring. Nice clearing. Let's keep it clean. No cell reception.

name: Dog Lake CG
description:
Located on the edge of Dog lake, this campground has about 10 sites. Boat launch and nice area down by the lake with very nice views. Pit toilets are provided but closed due to C-19. Picnic tables and flat spots suitable for RVs, trailers and tents. Please keep this (and places like it) clean or they threaten to close it. 
Currently there is no charge.
No Verizon servive

name: NF-1207 - large sunny area
description:
There is a large flat pull through site off the NF road which could hold one or two big rigs. One entrance is better than the other, but the site is so large you can probably still turn around. Sunny spot good for solar. Existing fire ring. (There is currently a fire ban in effect.)

There are also many other smaller spots on the river side of the road suitable for  tents.  These are accessed on small roads that lead towards the river. Some of these sites will hold 2 - 3 cars.

No Verizon cell. One bar of roaming for text.

name: South Fork Tieton Dispersed Camping
description: Just off HWY 12, on a parallel National Forest road, there is a large area by the side of the river with multiple flat areas. Shade and sun.  Take Tieton Reservoir Road and then shortly thereafter take a right on NF-580. Clearings will be on your right. This large area has room for dozens of vehicles. Most sites have access to the river, which is flowing swiftly. No Verizon. One bar of roaming for text. Please help keep this area clean. Pack out some extra trash if you can.

name: Windy Point CG
description: Potable water available.  Faucet near site 8.

name: American River
description: On the west side of the bridge crossing the American River there is a road that leads down to this area. You might not be able to turn a trailer around down here, but everything else should be fine. Level areas for 2 or 3 cars / RV. 3 or 4 spots for tents. Small rocky beach area on the river. Shallow pool for swimming. No verizon cell coverage.  No roaming either.

name: NF - open clearing
description:
Small clearing about 50 feet off NF road.
Flat and big enough for 2 - 3 rigs.

name: Lake Gilette Campground
description: In a National Forest campground there is free potable water. Spigot does not have threads, so you will need to hold the hose onto the faucet.

name: Camp spot near river close to Bagby Hot Springs
description: Great spot good for multiple rigs. Dispersed camp sign with two fire rings. Close to road but the noise isn’t too bad

name: Spot with a view on the side of the hill.
description:
Great spot but it’s a long uphill slog to get to it. Had to put my truck in Low range in order keep the transmission from overheating. But the views were pretty epic and even on a holiday weekend it was pretty low traffic. Bear droppings around so be careful of that. 

Update: 18% grade I would not recommend heading up unless you have 4x4 and Low range!

name: Free camp site at designated spot
description: Dispersed camping where there are signs that say you can camp. It was a busy weekend and we pulled into about eight areas until we found this one. Nice enough spot, no neighbors, close to the highway so you can hear it. Close to the river to hear it as well. Steep hill to get down to it and it’s moving fast down there. Flat ground easy free camp on a busy weekend night.

name: Wash N Go
description: Laundry and showers. Relatively clean place newer machines. $1 for 8 minutes. Worth every penny!

name: Showers at day use area
description:
$.50 for 3 minutes showers
RV dump
Flush toilets 
Steamboat Rock Northrup point 
Picnic tables
All included with your $35 WA outdoors discovery pass

name: Town Pump Showers
description:
Clean showers $10 with a towel.  But for the two of us we used one shower so we’re good there. Quick easy clean and no time limit! 
The shower is in the gas station store, ask at desk.

name: Riverside pizza and RV
description: $5 token for 15 minute hot shower good pizza and super friendly staff great place to stop and clean up. Pizza starts at 5pm

name: Logging road gate pull off
description: Nice spot just off the main road.  Great view. A few established fire pits, not super level but workable. Probably not a good idea if wet.

name: Blackrock Canyon OHV staging area
description: Parking area for staging OHV. 14 day limit BLM. Off road traffic through the night but a solid flat place to camp with clean pit toilets

name: Public land near ohv
description:
Sign posted when the road turns to to dirt 14 days Max stay. 

The road in had a lot of bumps and holes but going slow you should have no trouble getting in for most vehicles. 

Verizon service seems hit and miss, there may be better at different spots. There are several pull offs, some with fire rings, we didn’t go all the way down the road I am sure there is more. 

No facilities and no trash, so please pack it out. 


There were a few people setup in tents nearby as well.

name: West BLM at Saddle Mtn
description: Many places to choose from here.   We had good Tmobile and Verizon signal. A little hiway noise but couldn't hear I10 at all.

name: Red River Boat Ramp
description: Spent 1 night in the large parking lot near the boat ramp. There is an amazing dog park in the vicinity which was great for us to get the pup some exercise. Public restrooms are open in the parking lot all night. The night was quiet other than train noise.

name: BLM 8114A
description: A sweet little 2-track that lead us to a flat spot near trees and saguaro cacti.  Views in every direction. Spotty T-mobile service.  Good Verizon signal.  Plenty of firewood nearby.

name: Red Rock Scenic Overlook
description:
Great views from this overlook! It's right off the main road, however, last night there wasn't much traffic. No Verizon/Visible service but Tmobile and ATT worked. 

There were no "no overnight" parking signs and all along the road to this location are other lookout points. I stayed to catch the sunrise and was not disturbed. A few others were here as well, overall quiet place with a view for a night.

name: Mardi Gras Truck Stop
description:
Go to pump 16 and you will find a dump station for use while you get diesel/Def. Also has water, but you will need your own hose.
$ 10 for water, $ 25 for dumping

name: Water spigot
description: The one next to the restrooms is probably most accessable. There's another by the swimming pool entrance.

name: Pullout. Roadside
description: Pullout along Painted Canyon Rd (there is a barrier of dirt between you and the road) there is a fire pit and a beautiful view. I have a 2wd sprinter van so I was super scared of getting stuck on this but this spot is totally flat and fine. I didn’t drive all the way to the Painted Canyon trailhead but I’m sure I could have. I’m just too scared of getting stuck! The gnats are annoying tonight. 1-2 bars T-mobile okay. There is a pit toilet up the road a bit. Enjoy the view and the amazing hikes here! Xo

name: Tamarack Beach on Walker Lake
description: On public land, can drive right up to water’s edge if you like. Freeway behind but not a bother if you’re far enough away which is definitely possible. Toilet in parking lot. Wasn’t crowded in January with about 3 other RVs/trailers. 2-3 bars LTE w US Cellular. Can get windy!!

name: AC&T Truck Stop
description: Gas, Propane, Sewage Dump ($10), showers, water, ATM, laundry. same services as Loves. Five stars. Super nice people.

name: Tea Creek Campground
description:
The road in is Gravel and 500 ft miles from a paved road. Tea Creek Campground is open April thru Oct. There are 16-29 campsites at this location and the maximum RV length is unlimited. You may stay 14 days at Tea Creek Campground.

$10 per night. Honor box

Tea Creek Campground is a rustic 28-site developed camping area located on Forest Road 86 via the Highland Scenic Highway (State Route 150) one mile north of the Williams River Bridge turnoff.Each site is equipped with a wooden picnic table, lantern post, and fire ring. Many of the sites also have tent pads. Three bear-proof trash cages are located throughout the campground to provide convenience to visitors while encouraging trash removal from sites.  A campground host is available to offer information to visitors during much of the open season.Popular activities at Tea Creek include picnicking, fishing, hiking, mountain biking, bird watching, and relaxing.  One day-use area parking area (up to 10 vehicles) is located on the right as visitors enter into the campground.  A second day-use parking area (up to three vehicles) is located at the end of the road spur following Tea Creek. Directions:From Marlinton take US Route 219 north 7 miles to State Route 150, which is the Highland Scenic Highway. Turn left onto State Route 150 and drive approximately 9 miles to the Williams River Bridge turnoff, located on the left. Turn left at the stop sign onto Forest Road 86 and drive 1 mile. The campground is located on the right.

name: Day Run Campground
description:
Day Run Campground is open 4/1 - 11/30. There are 6-15 campsites at this location. You may stay 14 Days at Day Run Campground.

Honor Box - $10

$8/night

Description: This small campground includes 12 rustic campsites located along the scenic upper Williams River.

Location: Located on Forest Road 86 via the Highland Scenic Highway (State Route 150), 4 miles south of the Williams River Bridge turnoff.

Directions: From Marlinton take US Route 219 north 7 miles to State Route 150, which is the Highland Scenic Highway. Turn left onto Route 150 and drive 9 miles to the Williams River Bridge turnoff, located on the left. Turn right at the stop sign onto Forest Road 86 and drive 3 miles to the intersection of Forest Road 216. Take a hard right onto Forest Road 216 and drive 1 mile to Day Run Campground.

Facilities: Each campsite has a parking spur, picnic table, fire ring with a grill, a waste receptacle and a lantern hanger. Several campsites also have a tent pad, although all sites are suitable for tent or trailer camping. Vault (pit) toilets and one hand pump well are located in the campground. There are no electric or water hook-ups.

name: Dubl R RV Campground
description: Small level RV campground. 15 sites. Some pull thru. Full and part hookups. No tents. Pets ok . Registered over phone with very nice woman.

name: Whippoorwill Motel and Campsites
description: We offer grassy, level sites with water/electric and full hookup options. We are big rig friendly and pet friendly. Some amenities include a pool, arcade, playground, access to a bike path, access to the Lake George trolley line, laundry, firewood, propane tank exchange and much more.

name: Walmart Supercenter
description: Very quiet overnight. Positioned on a bluff adjacent to I80. Only one other RV here overnight. No interruptions.

name: Hugh Taylor State Park
description: Awesome place to spend the day. No camping but can enjoy the intracoastal waterway until 6pm for $4 (I think additional $2 per person). Perfect place to open the doors and enjoy Vanlife living!! Highly encourage you to visit.

name: Cooper Lake
description: Lots of pull offs and parking on the gravel road surrounding Cooper Lake. Beautiful views, quiet & peaceful. We stayed two nights with no problems.

name: Cracker Barrel
description: Cracker Barrel located off the highway. Arrived around 8 and had breakfast then left around 9. Few other RVs and camper vans. You can always stay at Cracker Barrel’s as long as you eat or purchase the next day

name: Circle K
description: Called and asked if they had a water hook-up on the outside of their building and they said they didn't know but we are welcome to check. We found one on the right side of the building behind the fence that you can open. Already had a hose connected to it. We filled up our 30 gallon water tank no problem!

name: Oak Mountain
description: Plenty of space and clear area. Has a couple of trails you can follow for a quick walk. Great view of the sunrise

name: Cedar Falls Creek
description: TONS of space available, we counted 5 fire rings that were spread out. Two other fire rings were available across the road. Could easily have 4 or so different campers at once. This site is right next to the Cedar Creek, which makes the nights slightly colder. There is also a trail that follows the creek across the road and one trail that goes beyond a road that is closed to traffic.

name: Primitive Site
description: Very open camp spot! With enough room for multiple tents with flat ground.

name: Primitive spot
description: This location has plenty of space for tent campers and even rv campers.

name: Primitive Camping
description: This is a good little spot for tent campers! It is right off the road and pretty flat.

name: Primitive Spot
description: This is perhaps one of the best spots in this road. It is flat and OPENED. A stream also runs next to the site and provides easy access to water.

name: Primitive Spot
description: This site has a slightly difficult entrance that is rocky and uneven. Once you enter, this site is wided open and flat with so much room! A small stream also runs along the site.

name: Buena Vista Campground
description: Beautiful campground surrounded by water.  Good place for boating, walking, gathering with friends.  Kid friendly.

name: Ohio river view
description: A riverside pull out with a boat launch on the Ohio. There’s dozens of spots to park, and it’s lighted okay. Great cel service. It’s maybe 5% sketchy, with cars pulling in for an hour and bouncing, and there’s a bit or trash along the banks, but it’s in a nice neighborhood and I never felt unsafe.

name: Roadside lot
description: Small lot right off the road. Room for a few rigs. No signs stating no over night. Good spot for 1 night. 1 bar of AT&T service.

name: AZT trailhead with a view of the lake
description: nice spot with great views all around.  1 mile down road to lake or 1.5 on AZT (take a right at the big sign on the left with a small sign pointing eight and indicating water)  no services, but quiet pleasant.  VZW coverage is great, no TMO.

name: Alabama point east parking area
description: Nice chill spot very near the Alabama Florida state line. Had a few cars pull up and be kind loud around dinner time but from 10pm-6:30am didn’t hear anything and traffic dies down on the bridge and slept great through out the night. There is also an outdoor shower and place to get water as well as toilets. If you have a bigger rig you could probably park under the bridge and be fine.

name: First site in a line of sites
description: There's a handful of pullouts up the second dirt road off of Lovell Canyon Road (Bootleg Spring Road - in an area managed by the Dept of Agriculture: wild camping permitted). Amazingly strong cell service (Verizon gets 5G, 4 bars). Pretty quiet at night, except for the cars coming in to get to spots further up the road. If you want total peace, just go up the road a bit further.

name: Quarry Camp
description: A very neat spot up on the quarry loop just outside Organ Pipe NM.  Good T-mobile and Verizon service.  Looks to be an abandoned open pit mining operation.  Very isolated with great views and a mountain backdrop.

name: 5th St Marina
description: Spots in a small lot as well as side street parking down along the water. Probably want to be stealth but there are no signs anywhere indicating no overnight or a time limit. Right on the river with views of the old railroad bridge and the marina.

name: Black Canyon Trailhead Parking Lot
description: Dirt parking lot with a couple of flatish spots. 2 bars Verizon LTE.

name: End of Forest rd
description: End of Forest Road looks like it has been cleared in the last year of all brush and Briar patches. Tons of area to camp. The "road" leading in is in fairly decent condition but there are some very deep ruts and potholes. High-clearance vehicle is a must. We stayed for a week and didn't see you another soul.

name: Moaning Caverns
description: Moaning Caverns is a solutional cave located in the Calaveras County, California, near Vallecito, California in the heart of the state's Gold Country. It is developed in marble of the Calaveras Formation. It was discovered in modern times by gold miners in 1851, but it has long been known as an interesting geological feature by prehistoric peoples. It gets its name from the moaning sound that echoed out of the cave luring people to the entrance, however expansion of the opening to allow access for the public disrupted the sounds. The portion of the cave developed for tourists consists of a spacious vertical shaft 165 feet tall, which is descended by a combination of stairs and a unique 100-foot-high (30 m) spiral staircase built in the early 1900s. It is open to the public for walking tours and spelunking. Including the off-trail areas, the cave reaches a depth of 410 feet (124 m).Moaning Caverns is a solutional cave located in the Calaveras County, California, near Vallecito, California in the heart of the state's Gold Country. It is developed in marble of the Calaveras Formation. It was discovered in modern times by gold miners in 1851, but it has long been known as an interesting geological feature by prehistoric peoples. It gets its name from the moaning sound that echoed out of the cave luring people to the entrance, however expansion of the opening to allow access for the public disrupted the sounds. The portion of the cave developed for tourists consists of a spacious vertical shaft 165 feet tall, which is descended by a combination of stairs and a unique 100-foot-high (30 m) spiral staircase built in the early 1900s. It is open to the public for walking tours and spelunking. Including the off-trail areas, the cave reaches a depth of 410 feet (124 m).

name: Schat's Roadhouse Restaurant
description: Large restaurant.  Last year we had a fantastic sit down steak dinner.  This years due to Covid, we got delectable four napkin Reuben's to go.  I'd give it 5 stars especially if you've driven 8 hours and need a good dinner.

name: FR525 Pull out
description: Huge dirt lot. A few other campers here. Quiet. 2 bars Verizon LTE.

name: Chevron
description: Propane fill up. Not self serve but it was simple, just ask the attendant inside.

name: McWay Waterfall Trailhead
description:
Bathrooms and water in the parking lot for the waterfall trailhead. No beach access or overnight parking, but great view of a unique waterfall. 
$10/day fee deposited via honor system.

name: Pigeon Forge Landing RV Resort
description: Pigeon Forge Landing RV Resort offers the newest accommodations and amenities set along a natural lazy river in the best location in Pigeon Forge. Pigeon Forge Landing RV Resort is big-rig friendly offering Premium and Executive pull-through spaces as well as Riverside Back-in spaces. All sites include full hookups with 30/50 amp including water, sewer, wifi, and cable TV. Enjoy the beauty of the Great Smoky Mountains, which is just minutes away from all the attractions the Pigeon Forge and Sevierville area have to offer!

name: Street Parking
description: I slept for one night here with my stealth minivan with no problem at all . Had a good night's sleep and made coffee in the morning, charged my phone. relax in my van . Neighborhood is pretty safe and quiet .

name: Hide-A-Way Harbor RV Park
description: Hide-A-Way Harbor is an RV and manufactured home community on the shores of beautiful Lake Harris in Astatula, Florida. The park offers the use of a fishing pier, boat slips, full restrooms, showers, laundry, full RV hookups, a furnished single family home available for lease, and permanent mobile home lots available for lease.

name: Springhill campground
description: This is the actual location of about 5 sites with water and electricity on the banks of Massard Creek as it flows into the Arkansas. Not staffed at this time of year and I think you are supposed to register at recreation.gov. Great site!!!

name: Georgia Camping Area (Goose Road Camp)
description: Clearing right off the highway down a dirt road. Easy to miss turn off. Passed it twice because of tail-gaters and not wanting to slam on the breaks. Fork is almost immediate. Keep right to pass up into the clearing. A couple of fire pits and ample space to pick your spot. Won’t be private if there’s anyone else. It’s really just a clearing. You can hear the traffic from the highway through the trees but it got quiet over night.

name: Overgrown Parking Lot
description:
Located behind Red Roof Inn alongside a small lake.

I stayed here one night. It was very quiet and private for a parking lot, aside from the occasional plane. Personally can’t stand noisy lots like Walmart. This was nice as a quick spot in town before moving on.

This parking lot doesn’t seem to be affiliated with either hotel because it’s not swept and many of the bushes are growing well into the parking spaces.

name: Las Vegas Bay Campground
description: Free dump station and free clean water. You do not have to camp here & no camp fee required to use these services. FREE !

name: Parking area
description: huge parking area good for all types vehicles. looks like a spot used by trucks a lot. very level and lots and lots of parking

name: Riverside
description: ok spot for the night.  good spot to catch dust from anyone passing by and there are 4-wheelers out but not that often so it will do for a night.  the cool spot by the river was full so this is a decent make-do alternative.

name: Near Interstate
description: lots of space. big rig friendly. lots of empty space right off the freeway but you can get far enough away to minimize road noise

name: Street Parking
description: Informal parking space. Epic view of Narrows Bridge. Great place to walk your dog. Park along the righthand side of this whole street. Legal to park 7 days then you have to move 1 mile every 7 days. Neighbors can’t complain cuz it’s legal. Nice neighborhood so be discreet.

name: 522 USFS
description: A sweet spot just inside the Forest Service boundary.

name: Uhaul
description: Cheap and fast. Will fill rv’s or tanks. The guy was cool 3.57 a gallon

name: Cline Gulch BLM
description: 6-10 dispersed sites along a creek. Very private and clean. Dead end dirt road and very little traffic. No Verizon service.

name: Rippling water hideaway
description: Along fs2419. Below mt. Eleanor trail. Absolutely beautiful and quiet. 1-2 bars Verizon. Lots of pullouts in addition to this one. Good for one or two nights of peace if Knowl with a view is taken. Tents welcome but we stayed in our storyteller van.

name: Riverside spot
description: Along the Big Quilcene River off FS2700-040. Coming from 101 on Penny creek road it’s on the left. Tucked away from the road down a rough entrance. 4x4 is needed. Beautiful place for absolute peace and to listen to the River. No service.

name: Riverside
description: Verizon available but no  AT&T. A level spot big enough for 2-3 easy Campervans or one trailer. We spent one night and saw nobody. Listen to the River and enjoy the woods!

name: Mammoth to Cooke City in Winter. Grand Loop Road North US 212.
description:
Wow, if you like winter travel and wild life this is the road.
-In summer, this road gets backed up like an LA freeway with people stopping to view the wildlife but;
-In winter, you almost have the road to yourself. ( The road does get plowed during the day in winter. )
-The road is closed east of Cooke City in the winter, so you have to come in and go out thru. Gardiner MT. The other roads in Y.N.P. are also closed to private vehicles in winter. 
-In winter there were many places to pull off and hike and view the Bison, Elk, Moose, and others?
-High water proof boots and or show shoes would be good to bring / rent. 

Warnings;
-Both days I drove the road it was covered in snow and ice!
-Going east there was two different vehicles that slid off the road including a Toyota 4x4!
-NPS recomends Real Snow Tires or chains in winter. ( Not all season or M+S ) If you can air down this may? help you.
-Take your time and drive slow, you don't want to stop quick if a 2000lb. bison is on the road.
-I drove the road in a two wheel drive small class c mh with good snow tires and had no issues. ( drove very slow on icy spots. )

Safe Travels,

name: Easterlin Park dump station
description: There is a dump station just next to the drinking water station that is available for a fee. Not sure what the fee is but the dump station has a padlock on it and says the fee is available from the park office. It’s a nice park so this is a good place to get water and use the dump station. They only charge $1.50 for entrance on weekends and holidays but during the week it’s free. Didn’t use the dump station but figured I would mention it here since I’m filling up water right now

name: Ashley Lane RV Campground
description: Large flat campground with many permanent residents. Potholed roads, pleasant managers (no mask) who gave us wrong password to poor wifi and there is also poor cell phone reception. Charge $30 for full hookup. I probably would have tried the High Point RV camp next door which has wifi and charges $35 with AAA discount.

name: Tennessee wall wild camping
description: Wild camping spot for climbers near Tennessee wall, 6 or so informal campsites marked by fire pits, trail down the to river to swim, canoe, or rinse off! :)

name: Springdale Coin Carwash
description: $10 dump Station at south end of the wash building. Right in front as you enter on the left hand side.

name: Napa Autowerke Inc
description: Great VW Vanagon mechanic. Andrew knows his stuff.

name: Minersville Campground
description:
5 Stars
RV and tent sites on Rocky Ford Reservoir.
Improved level sites with shelters and fire pits.
Hot showers and flush toilets.
Outdoor fresh water faucets (turned off in winter).
All clean and well maintained.
I stayed here Christmas Eve, in my van. Winter rate $5. for "tent" site.
$10 for RVs.
The place was empty until the ice fishermen showed up about 6:30am.

name: Santa Rosa rest stop area
description: There are two rest stops just right off the freeway. Westbound and eastbound right across from each other. Id advise to park in the back with the diesels. It seems to be a bit quieter with the building blocking the road.

name: Coyote Keith’s RV campsite.
description: Very basic with 15 level full hookups. Easy self checkin. $30. Very good WiFi. No trees. Grass by gravel pads with picnic table. Some light highway noise. Easy to find and navigate. Friendly helpful people via phone.

name: BLM above the petroglyphs
description:
Free. BLM land. Continue past the cattle guard. There's lots of garbage littered around but the place we found was relatively clean. Tucked in the trees near privately-owned property. 
Excellent ATT and Verizon signal.

name: Cholla metal craft inc
description: Welding and iron work. We needed a new axel in our trailer and he was able to fit us in. Job well done. Very good communication. Very nice. Rick. Is the owner. We walked up after calling and leaving a message.

name: Water
description: Water spigot at trail head. Located about 20 feet from parking spaces. no signs indicating if water is potable or not. We filled our tanks and can confirm that we did not die.

name: Rim overlook
description: Amazing views of the rim with many sites available for free

name: AZT/Brody Seep Trail Junction
description: Two beautiful clearings just off trail to the east. Fantastic sunset views. 1mi S from Chilson Spring on the AZT.

name: Parking next Cascades Park
description:
Lots of unregulated parking near this park.

I parked in front of the amphitheater for the night. The spots are pretty long and fit my 21” sprinter van. If you’re bigger than that there are a few lots nearby to accommodate.

It was a Friday and the restaurant there stayed busy but once it closed it was a very quiet night. It’s always nice to wake up next to a park.

name: Eagle Pass Public Library
description: Fast WiFi available here with parking. Nice park and a nice walkable downtown.

name: Lafayette park
description:
Water spigot at the corner of Cherry and Ingleside Ave in Lafayette park.

Potable water with a dog bowl beneath it. I parked on Cherry and my 50’ hose was able to reach for a fill up.

name: Dispersed Camping
description: Amazing spot with a fire pit. ATT, TMO and Verizon all have great coverage since the cell tower is close by. Great place to stay for a few days.

name: Catalina Spa and RV Resort
description: Wanted a spot to chill at a pool for a few days. This places worked well. One adult pool and one family pool are both open now. Both with jacuzzis but those are closed now due to COVID. Lounge chairs aren’t out now but at least the pools are open! This is your typical RV resort with all the stuff - laundry, tennis court, showers, hook ups. $55/night for 30 amp but book over the phone to get that price. It’s a couple dollars more If you do it online. I think they give a passport America discount as well. Friendly people and warm weather!

name: Rest Area
description: Clean rest area with water and bathrooms, no accessable electricity. Adding here mostly because there are shaded, partially enclosed picnic tables that were a lifesaver for cooking in the wind. We spent a couple hours here in the afternoon just to get out of our van, but escape the wind.

name: Konza Prairie biological center and wildlife trails
description: Konza Prairie is associated with Kansas State University. It’s is a biological research center with a variety of nature trails.

name: Gila Cliff Dwellings visitor center
description: Potable water with east access spigot available for free, year round at the Gila cliff dwellings visitor center. Currently with covid the center is closed and water is still available.

name: Mt. Hebo overlook campsite
description: Room for a few vehicles and tents.  Amazing view!  We could see all the way to the 3 Sisters

name: Coon Bluff Recreation Site
description: You need a recreation pass to access this area but overnight parking is allowed Friday and Saturday only. Wild horses can be seen here!

name: Marfa Stop Sign
description: Great town and very interesting little museum. Short term parking before the stop sign here for the museum and a walk round. WATCH OUT FOR LOCAL POLICE! The stop sign is a haven for patrols, we sat and watched non-stop tickets given for 20 minutes. Full stop at the stop sign and MIND THE SPEED LIMIT!

name: Lake Powell Boat Ramp/Park
description:
MODERATOR NOTE: Place removed because camping is illegal here.  Day Use Only, Signs posted and enforced 

NO OVERNIGHT PARKING signs. But this stop is perfect to come hang out, watch the sunset, make dinner, and then head over to the Walmart for sleep right down the street. nice little lake with a dock you can swim off. pretty dark, not too buggy, but the bathroom's a little gross. be respectful of surrounding area.

name: Potts Preserve- North Dee River Road Primitive Camp
description: Primitive campground with 7 campsites for equestrian and Primitive use. Tent, Rv, campers, Equestrian allowed. Pet friendly. Reservations required online before trip, but are free. Site is: swfwmd.org

name: Bachelor Loop Pull over
description: Small loop with one spot tucked into trees right off of road. Good for car / small campervan. Quiet in winter, imagine the road is busier in summer.

name: Overlook - Roosevelt Lake
description: On 625 Amazing over look of Roosevelt Lake .There are 3 sites that are fairly spread out on the cliff. Spectacular views! Not good Verizon service. 2wd with clearance ok. Would need 4x4 if wet.

name: County Road pull off
description: This spot is just a short distance away from the BLM boundary line. This quiet dirt county road, located off a frontage road services road, only a remote RV park with a main entrance on the other side. Very quiet. There are a couple pull off options just past the cattle guard. this makes a very easy and nice overnight.

name: Mohave desert recreation area
description: Amazing that this one isn’t already on the map. It’s a bit of a drive off highway I40 (10 miles) but it’s AMAZING!!! I spent the most wonderful, quiet, peaceful night that I have spent in a long time. In five hours I counted four cars going by. The campsites are dispersed and not obvious but there is a paved road leading right up to them. Do yourself a favor and give this place a try.

name: Shell station
description: Spotted two water spickets next to the pumps on the end. Pump 1 and pump 13.

name: Cracker Barrel
description: Ask, and Cracker Barrel will provide. We have stayed at so many CB parking lots in Florida and I will check-in to every single one of them. This one was particularly quiet and had several other overnight travelers. No issues at all.

name: Park and Ride White Marsh
description: Quiet parking lot near woods at bus stop.

name: Veggie Farm turnout
description: Nice little turnout seems to be friendly to overnight camping, We were not bothered by the police, other overlanders camping here. Close to Mavericks beach

name: Choctaw Casino
description: Casino parking lot. I stayed and no knocks but I did not go in to ask permission. Next to highway but more quiet than a truck stop.

name: State St.
description:
State or Trinity St right next to the apartment building is free parking with no restrictions. 15min walk to the WeWork building (downtown) or 3min bike there. Basically, it’s close to downtown. If you don’t work downtown then downtown Houston sucks during the pandemic. But this spot will be better for travellers once things open up again.

also close to the Historic 6th Ward neighbourhood (the only beautiful neighbourhood in the whole city).

name: FishCreek Little Hill
description: Nice quit spot! It's probably a few minutes before the sandstone canyon sign. Stayed one night on 1/15/21. No issues whatsoever! Others campers throughout the state park dispersed! Just be respectful and smart and you will have not an issue camping during these times!

name: Sam Houston SP
description: Just off a multi-use road/trail, road is not terribly busy but it's a Monday in January so pretty sure it would be in season. Quite a bit of human poo/TP which I'm finding almost everywhere these days in these type of areas (lots of atv activity). I came for the hiking trails, a couple of nice ones nearby.

name: Hughes road
description: This is a turnout off of Hughes road with an amazing view of Casteic Lake and canyons below. There are no signs indicating that you can not park here or stay over night. We parked around 2pm and went on a 3 hour bike ride (it is an awesome ride if you are looking for road biking). We have a 22’ trailer with pick up. No 4wd necessary. No cars parked here, no one drove by all night, no one asked us to leave. Awesome sunset AND sunrise.

name: State Trust Land just off the paved road on a decent gravel road
description: Nice open camp spots on State Trust Lands. Permit needed. Cost about $16/yr and available online. Was able to get my Transit Van and 15’ trailer to a camp spot easy. Lots of trails and UHV trails in the area.   Good Sprint cell service here.

name: Three Rivers WMA
description: Excellent views. Overlooks the old Mississippi River. Has a dumpster and a pit toilet.

name: Public showers on the beach
description: Several public showers along this beach. We showered in our bathing suits and no one cared. The beach is open from dawn to dusk. There are also bathrooms and water fountains.

name: Morgan mountain camp spot
description: Nice large camp area off the side of the road with a decent view. Other sites are scattered along the forest service road.

name: Propane
description: propane filling station available is at this gas station

name: Midland LTVA
description: BLM disperse camping. Dump site but no water. Great place to boondock overnight or long term. A $40 permit is required for short-term (1-14 day) stays. Long-term/seasonal permit fee is $180.  Not certain if ground tent camping is permitted. Visit Blm.gov

name: Old building foundation
description: Concrete slab of an old building foundation where the road splits off onto cool water drive. Not suitable for vehicles. Okay for one night.

name: 12th St Laundry
description: Standard laundry, nice place. Wall charging outlets and a bathroom. 18 pound load 2.75 USD, 30 pounds is 5.50. Drying 25 cents for 4 minutes, 50 cents for 10 minutes etc. Clean, staff on site to help with problems.

name: West side road(90rd) National Forest
description: Very easy access. Check the wind and weather first especially for RTT. Dispersed camping only.

name: Mobil bulk propane
description: propane bulk fill is $3.49/gal. also RV specific fuel lanes here.

name: Paragon Primitive Campground
description: Free primitive camping in designated sites. 7 sites available. Inside Daniel Boone Nat’l Forest. Great for vehicle or tent camping.

name: White Cliffs ACE
description: Looking for a stay over and discovered this little Army Corps park. Site 1 has 2 fire rings one right on the water. Good spot if you’re traveling with kids as it has a playground and is adjacent to hiking trails that wind through exposed chalk cliffs. Water and electric available at sites. Good place to recharge and refill while still providing points of interest.

name: Pull off
description: Pull off on the side of the road - not far from the interstate highway but also somewhat close to the Union Pacific tracks. No signs prohibiting overnight camping, Fairly level. No amenities. Might have been more comfortable at Texas Canyon Rest Area east of here. Good Enough if You're Tired Enough

name: Copper Basin Road Dispersed
description: Camping in designated sites only. First sites along the road are here, more farther up. Road is a winding 2wd dirt road. Quiet, surrounded by tall trees and miles of trails.  Could easily spend a few days exploring from your site! Great Verizon service at the coordinates, enough to work from without a signal booster.

name: Easy Level Pull-off Near Hwy
description:
Circular site next to a dirt road, off the road enough to minimize highway noise. Nothing too special, but safe and quiet for the night.

Near cell tower with good data speed (I have t-mobile)

name: Havasu State Park
description: $15 fee at the front office to dump. Has potable water too.

name: East Ten Sleeps Lake
description: Beautiful views of the lake once you hike up the hill from the parking area. There are two different trails to get to the parking area one is for atvs and hiking, the other is accessible by stock 4x4 vehicles but you must really take your time as it is very rocky in places. It’s worth the time of the trail ride and hike to the lake. A great weekend trip for us to get some for wheeling fishing and camping done.

name: Ferdinand State Forest
description: State forest with camping, shelter houses, swimming, fishing, & utilities.

name: walmart
description: walmart lot, didn't see any no overnight parking signs, good spot if headed to blue knob ski area in winter. 4 bars Verizon.

name: Beach Camping is Allowed S. of Access Road 6.
description: the ONLY free parking between Port Aransas and Padre island is south of mile marker 100 on the beach. You can camp north of that mile marker but you must have a $12 beach permit and your only allowed to stay 6 days a month, no more than 3 consecutive in one place. I just don’t want to see anyone get in trouble for camping north of mile marker 100 without a permit. 4X4 recommended.

name: Shell water spigot
description: Water spigot on the back of the building.

name: Tanque Road BLM
description: Lots of space all sizes, roads are fine, cell reception is good, super quiet.

name: Cracker Barrel
description: About 15 minutes from Disney World so an easy overnight option after a full day in the park. Several other vans and RV stayed with no issues.

name: Gladwick Street
description:
An unincorporated part of Los Angeles although patrolled by Carson Sheriff it is not technically Carson. Therefore there is an unwritten understanding to leave RVs alone. In fact it was a deputy that recommended it to us. 

Be advised to adhere to parking restrictions as they passed out a notice that street-sweeping would be observed & enforced. 

It is an industrial area so there is truck noise. But you can observe the quieter areas if that’s an issue. 

We’ve been here for over three months now - with our slide-out out. It’s just a street. No hookups or dump site. 

It certainly is a relief to sit for a bit and not have to move every 1-3 days while being in the city.

name: Riverside Side road
description: Good spot for one night. It’s a side road in residental that’s pretty wide. One side has a tall brick wall and a there is a house across the street.  It’s dark and quiet. A few cars drove past through the night. Felt very safe.

name: Mittry Lake
description: Several wide spots on the west side of the road.

name: KOA RV Park
description: $10 dump fee; Free for registered campers

name: Dorsey Park
description:
We stayed here last night in our Promaster with no trouble at all. It’s parking for a baseball diamond, playground, and skate park (all covered with snow for now). There were no “no overnight parking” signs but there were lots of signs that say “no dogs”. The lot has a gate too but stayed open. There were also a couple cameras- not sure if they’re used in the winter. We were the only car there. There’s a stream behind the parking lot to add to the Vermont mood. 

Only 3 minutes to Okemo base tower.

name: Cuyama river
description: Small dirt road in the middle of the dry river valley. Flat, quiet, easy. No cell service or fire rings.

name: Cotton Lake
description:
A handful of camp sites available.
free up to 14 days
Near boat ramp.

reservations@nwfwater.com

name: Murray family farms
description:
24 hour gas station next to Murray Family Farms. 
There is a large dirt lot in back of the gas station. You can stay the night on the East side of the lot near the palm trees. 
It was quiet and there are porta potties by the gas station.
Don’t set up camp, it is just a good spot for a quick overnight.

name: Walmart
description:
Stayed overnight, no problems. 

The Murphy gas station has a hose attached to a water spigot, but I didn't try to fill up here so ymmv.

name: Just BEFORE Indian Bread Cul-de-Sac
description: Just off the road that leads to Indian Bread Rocks day use parking. Spacious and level. Good cell. Super private!

name: Dirt Lot - Across from Flying J
description: Big dirt lot across from the flying j gas station. Plenty of room for big rigs. Some noise from trucks also using the lot but not bad for a spot to spend the night.

name: rest area
description: This is a rest area on RT 60. the law allows parking for 24 hrs. I pulled over on the way to VLA observatory cuz it was snowing, I tried "the box" east of this location but didnt have a good cell signal (att) at the trailhead, so I came here and had full signal.

name: Hilltop Hunters Camp
description:
Nice level clearing on a hilltop.  Road in is well maintained.  There is no fire ring so be careful if you decide to build a fire.
You could get a bigger rig in here.

name: FS Road 150
description: Private forest service road in Apalachicola National Forest. The pin takes you to a small cul de sac and we only saw one other car drive by. The road in can get bumpy with a few deep ruts. Would not recommend if rain is in the forecast, but we made it in a 2WD sprinter. No amenities and intermittent cell service on ATT. Free!

name: Cracker Barrel
description: RV Camping behind the restaurant, the parking spots aren't really long like they are at other Cracker Barrels but RVers are welcome to stay.

name: I-10 Westbound Rest Area
description: Potable water spigot available next to the sidewalk and parking.

name: Charleston sailing school parking lot
description: This is a paid secure parking lot. It’s 16 dollars a day and has bathrooms.

name: Pilot j travel center
description: Not the best pilot j showers, but they were clean and hot. $12 and close to Everglades and Big Cypress.

name: Oceanside RV Resort
description: 180 space RV Resort with 30/50 amp and sewer hook ups. Heated pool, jacuzzi, guest showers, laundry, security, game room, reception facilities, dog run, 2 Glamping tents, RV storage, close to beach, small store for amenities and snacks, friendly staff

name: Rockaway big tree trailhead
description: It’s a trailhead parking lot right next to the highway and is very hard to spot at night but the parking lot is big. We got here after dark cause the trail is open only till sunset. No overnight parking signs so we stayed till morning. Decent amount of traffic noise.

name: Sunset Reef Campground BLM
description:
Sunset Reef Campground is fairly new. It has space for 6 tents and 5 RV pull-throughs. There are no connections here for water, sewer, or electricity. Each site has a grill, a covered picnic table, and a trash bin. There is a vault toilet on-site.

You can't see this campground from the highway, as it is blocked by a small hill. Turn at the Washington Ranch Road and take the first right into the campground.

You may stay here up to 5 nights. Then you have to move 25 miles away.

I have Verizon and I get 75Mbps download and about 10Mbps upload speeds.

name: Sam Houston National Forest
description: Follow the road as if you are going to Stubblefield Recreation area. Shortly before you get there, the road will curve and there will be a little dirt road on your left. Take the dirt road about a mile and you should see another small dirt road on the left. Take that road and you will see spaces that have been kept clear. We parked a few spaces down the road. If you follow the road to the end there is a turn around at the bottom with another space or two. We were in a 2wd Nissan Rogue and we did just fine. It was a little muddy from recent rain. There are no amenities, this is wild camping, but the campground at Stubblefield does, however it is $15 for a day. I don’t know if a permit is needed, we saw no signs saying we could not camp and there was another group camped at the bottom. We did have a signal and could use the internet, but it was a little slow. This is a beautiful location.

name: TA Express Truck Stop
description: truck stop with a Subway and Caribou Coffeep. Fuel, lots of parking space. at night the place fills up with trucks though. it was very quiet, no hassle, but you do hear diesel engines idling throughout the night.

name: La Quinta Inn & Suites Parking Lot
description: Right off Interstate 55. Pretty quiet considering it's right off the interstate. Pulled in at 12:20 a.m. & left by 6 a.m. No problems. Parked in the back along the guard rail & backed in (SUV).

name: dillahunty rd
description: Further down dillahunty rd, found this side road. Bumpy but doable slowly in camper van. Nice views, quiet. Intermittent LTE.

name: Steep Hill Rd
description: Near Alamogordo on the way to Cloudcroft, no signs saying no overnight parking. There are a couple of pulloffs here, this one is fairly level, I'm in a skoolie. Views are spectacular. I walked down the steep hill to see if there were any other spots, didn't see anything but the road is wide and well maintained, met a couple of dirt bikes. Some road noise but not horrible. Good Verizon signal.

name: Cracker Barrel
description: Very quiet parking behind the restaurant. It was closing as I parked, with a lot of staff activity and no-one seemed to mind. One other trailer with it's slide out.

name: Ironwood NM flat pullout
description: There were people parked at the Agua Blanca entrance and one other pullout after so I kept driving and found this large flat pullout. Big enough for multiple vehicles. Came in with a 2WD Sprinter Van okay. Def bumpy and can get a little tight with branches for a bit. Watch for grazing cows. Had a couple surprise me. Great views. 2 bars TMobile.

name: Matagorda Beach Public Beach Access
description: Wild camping on the beach. Access is via Beach Road approximately .8 miles before the visitor center. $10 permit is required for parking on beach and available at the visitor center. Camping is permitted on the beach for up to 72 hours. As you enter the beach the sand is very soft and deep. 4X4 is required for access to this portion of beach. Trash cans are provided on the beach. There are port-a-potties and trash cans at the entrance to the beach. The packed sand is firm and drivable but the loose sand is very soft and deep. The drivable portion of the beach is narrow and requires you to pay close attention to both tides and surf conditions. Our Sprinter 4X4 navigated the beaches well but we left the second night due to rising tides and heavy surf. We camped along the river and it was very pleasant and safe there.

name: Flying J
description: Dump station, water spigot, and propane in one stop. Easy right off of the highway

name: Bishop RV Park - Tri-County Fairgrounds
description:
Bishop RV Park & Campground located just 2 blocks off of Main Street (US 395) in Bishop, California. It's within walking distance to downtown
shops, dining, parks, entertainment and world famous Schat’s Bakkery! It's 30 minutes from Mammoth Lakes and only 10 minutes from hiking and fishing in the Owens River.
There are 42 spaces with full hookups (water, electricity, sewer) and over 135 spaces with partial hook ups (water and electricity – no sewer). Wi-Fi, showers and great cell reception. $35 for RV spot, $20 for van 120v hookup, and $15 for anything else.

name: Rough Creek Park
description: Lightly forested public park with boat ramp, picnic tables, grills, and rest-rooms on a pretty lake. Posted sign says camping up to 10 days is allowed! We stayed overnight and into the afternoon in our converted sprinter at one of the picnic areas, in a dirt pull-off. There is a larger paved parking lot for the boat ramp with long spots big enough for larger rigs. Tent camping seems tolerated as well. The bathrooms were locked when we were here, may be seasonal, but there were port-o-potties that weren’t too bad. Overall a nice peaceful spot to spend a night or two not far from Fort Worth!

name: Bat Rocks Campsite
description: Great little spot a quick drive off the highway. No other people or cars nearby and far enough from the highway that traffic was not heard. Occasional headlights would be seen in the far distance but nothing more and very few at that. We camped at the base of some pretty cool rock formations. Bats appear to use some of them to sleep in and came out at night. The star viewing was great and no cactus so our dog was able to walk around without issue. There was some crude fire rings but be cautious of the wind and red flag warnings at all times.

name: Right off I-40
description:
This is on the road that leads to another posted campsite but instead of going all the way to it I decided to stop here to be closer to the interstate for the morning.
Exit off I-40 and this spot is to the right just after the paved road turns to dirt. Awesome views of mountains surrounding the place. To the east are train tracks that seemed to have trains coming through very frequently, and the west is the interstate so it isn’t a silent spot but for being just off an interstate I can’t complain at all. Plenty of room for any size rig here and multiple can fit. Road is accessible by any vehicle. I have Verizon and have 4 bars

name: Kern Canyon Rd pullout
description: Stopped here on the way to the Remington Hot Springs. Perfect spot for a camp out, quiet, amazing views and even a nice spot for a tent. Big enough pullout for a few campers easily. Didn't stay the night but no "no parking" signs. Beautiful.

name: O Reilly's Water Spigot
description: Spigot at the back corner of O Reilly's auto parts, next to waffle house. Employee inside offered it to me to use. Free water

name: Cracker Barrel Parking Lot
description: Asked management if it was okay to park overnight and they said it was no problem. 3 long designated RV parking spots. Plenty of other spots as well. Close to shopping center with many stores. Great for a nights stay

name: Star of Texas RV Park
description: 60 full hookups, gravel lot, all pull thrus, open all year round, next to rodeo grounds, has a "horse hotel", easy in, easy out

name: Prairie Creek Campground
description:
Prairie Creek Campground is situated beneath moss-draped oaks on the banks of Woodruff Lake. The lake is part of the scenic Alabama River in the region's Black Prairie Belt. 

For sportsmen, the campground offers a wonderful opportunity to relax between fishing and hunting trips. Water sports and hiking are also popular activities.

name: Buffalo campsite entrance
description: With most side roads not plowed and inaccessible in winter this is a spot to spend a night. The campsite is closed for the season. It’s large parking lot used by many snowmobile riders. Very close to the freeway but quiet enough. 2 bars AT&T LTE.

name: Loves Propane
description: 24/7 propane. Higher price then the mom and pop shops but if you’re stuck on a Sunday and need propane it works great.

name: Cactus Field BLM
description: Wide open level spot near but not on Arkansas River- no facilities. Beautiful views. 3-5 informal sites. Trailhead right at site- no ATVs

name: Dept of fish and wildlife land
description: Bolt hole off route 101. Lots of room and not visible from the road. No amenities just a flat spot to spend the night.

name: Burger Shack , don’t quote me
description: Awesome burgers, nuff said, best for sure south of La Paz

name: Crooked River Rest Area
description: Public restrooms, parking lot right off highway 97

name: Speedway
description: Showers at the gas station

name: Howarth Park
description: Parking lot with port a potties in the lot. The park technically closes at night but there are no no overnight parking signs around

name: Pilot dirt lot
description: This is a huge packed dirt lot across the street from the pilot (muddy spots so be on alert). Overflow parking for semis. The lady at pilot said we were welcome to park here. Great spot next to a big field. As peaceful a place for free that you could find in this area!

name: discreet residential street
description:
Quiet residential street with a park on one side. Park is gated so no zombies wandering around, but at least you’re not parking right in front of someone’s house. 

Camped one night, were very discreet. Felt very safe. Good for a small camper van, but not an obvious RV

Good cel service and free Xfinity wifi

name: Lovelock Wild Camping
description: Great spot down by the lake near Lovelock.  Take exit 93 and the frontage road across the train tracks.  A bit of highway noise but far enough away for privacy.  Road is washboard for a few miles and then softer playa sand.  4wd recommended.

name: Low traffic side street
description: A very small handful of cars drive through during sleeping hours. Please keep clean and low profile.

name: Cross Timbers State park
description: Beautiful lake. Awesome trails with a mixture of habitats. Some more rocky than others.

name: Salome Market
description:
bulk propane at this location for $2.15/gal.

also free air and water for your car (don't think it's intended to fill your RV's fresh tank)

there is a sign that there is a "laundermat" here as well but we did not see it ourselves.

name: Haskell City RV Parking
description: Great! Free for the 1st night, then $20 a night after that. Full hookups and just a couple blocks from the town.

name: The Cracker Barrel
description: 800 Kings Hwy. Port Charlotte, FL. Stayed over no problems, slightly close to highway, can get loud around 7am. Stayed and had breakfast.

name: Levinski Parking Lot
description: Big Sky allows parking up to 3 days. Many other campers and RVs. Walk to the lift. Low bars on cell for Verizon. Better with AT&T but not great

name: Solitude Overnight Parking
description:
$20 for overnight parking from 12am - 5pm next day. Walk to the lifts from the lot.

dogs aren’t allowed in big cottonwood canyon due to watershed concerns.

name: Gooseberry Mesa
description:
Moderator Note: If there was recent rain, please be mindful as the dirt roads become impassable into Gooseberry Mesa.

----------------------------------------------------

Wild camping with a pit toilet. Next to great biking trails. 4x4 not required, but road is not usable after heavy rain.

name: trailhead parking lot
description: small lot near trailhead, not very level, but big enough for a few vans or a small rv. can be crowded during the day. no indication you can't park over night. spent the night after riding the trails.

name: Whitetail Butte Overlook
description: This is a great little primitive spot off of NF-2406 in the Umatilla National Forest. About a mile or so down the gravel road, there is a pull off, room for a few vehicles, pretty flat ground. Great for tents as well. No water source nearby, no cell service. But GREAT view of the forest valley from the fire ring.

name: Governor Printz Park / Holiday Inn
description:
Mostly empty parking lot outside Holiday Inn next to Governor Printz Park.

Park is a great place to watch the sunset over the Delaware River. Park hosts a farmer's markets on Wednesday nights during the summer. There's a splash pad, playground, gazebos, etc.  This park is heavily visited by locals - best to park your van closer to the Holiday Inn (a row or two away from Park entrances.) Located in a safe neighborhood. There is an active police presence, but they are unlikely to disturb you if you only stay for 1 night.

name: Austwell Park
description: As described in the water source description. About 10 sites with water and power hookups; no signs with any information. Had a lady come by at 9am to collect fees and have us fill out a form. $10 a night for tent (or conversion van) and then something like $15, $20, or $25 depending on amperage used for power. Not much to the park; covered picnic tables, bathrooms (didn't use), BBQ pits, swings and monkey bars, there's a primitive baseball field and poles that probably used to have a volley ball net. By the bathrooms is a covered meeting area with many tables and a beast of a smoker. No stores or gas stations around that we've found.

name: Linen Laundry
description: Coin op laundromat, $3 for normal washer $5 for larger.

name: Cachuma Lake
description: Multiple restrooms with showers in the Cachuma Lake recreation area. Pay $10 for the daily fee then 4 quarters for 3min OR ask for the 15min pass to check things out and take a very quick shower. Campground's currently closed for covid, but all the amenities seem to be open. Nice place to stay for the day!

name: Small Hill
description: Small hill with a somewhat level top. I found it on Kern Canyon Rd it looks like you can get to it from the highway too. Slept here for a night after a long drive. Good Tmobile. Tons of pullouts on Kern Canyon rd.

name: RaceTrac
description: Red spigot free water by the gas fill up on the far left.

name: Glacier water refill
description: Glacier water refill outside of the Family Dollar in Salton City - $0.30 per gallon.

name: West Rim Rio Grande
