description: Walmart parking lot. We parked on the far end of the lot with several other rigs.

name: Water at carwash next to Shell
description: Water spigot next to air and vacuums in front of car wash. Second spigot near parking on side of car wash building. Clear. Strong chlorine taste.

name: Near CO/UT border
description:
This is a good flat spot if all the cliff-side designated spots to the east are full. That’s what happened to me (it’s the weekend). 
Not as good of views, but better if you want solitude away from the other campers. 
“Welcome to Utah” sign about a mile away. 
Great Verizon service.

name: Chevron Truck Stop
description: The water spout does not work. The small grocery store inside the gas station, next to the Subway, has a lot of groceries though! Meats, produce, canned, frozen. Even has plumbing supplies and other misc items. If you’re needing anything in this area, it’s worth a stop. Just no free water.

name: Independence BLM
description:
There are several clearings to camp on in this BLM land just west of Independence. Great cell service for all carriers in the BLM area, but as you get closer to the mountain you lose reception.

Great views of the mountains, very quiet and peaceful. 

No amenities.

name: Malaquite water
description: Drinking water at the dump station. 2 locations

name: Bennett Park
description: Free. This country park is right on the river with a couple dozen picnic spots that are great for camping. No toilets or trash containers. Great for canoeing or kayaking and quiet on the weekend that we stayed. Being Texas, the fishermen do leave their trash, so do like we did and clean up your space to make it a good campsite. Overall, one of our best camp sites in TX.

name: Riverside Park RV
description: Acceptable campground if you want to spend time in town or if you canoe or kayak the paddling trail here. Full hookups for only $12. Looks like a few sites are taken by people who live here, and no reservations accepted. Best to arrive early as there are only 18 sites total.

name: Juju's Crawfish Shack
description: Fantastic place for crawdads. Eat with your hands and byob.

name: Propane Tanks Filled here
description: At the Chevron station between the gas station and truck parking area is a propane fill area. There is also fresh water here at the Island to the left of the gas pumps. This station. You can even stay the night in the parking area across the street. This station also sells diesel gas. There is usually a taco food truck parked in the lot for some fast to go food. Easy access to I-15. They even do a fireworks display most nights!

name: Stovepipe Wells Gas Station
description: Gas here is about 30¢ cheaper than Panamint Springs and $1.20 cheaper than Furnace Creek at the time of this posting. Only 87 fuel available. No cell service or open WiFi in this area.

name: Wind Cave Wall
description: Fine sand /compacted riverbed pull off to the West, below the Joshua tree forest. Early morning sun protected by the wall, beautiful sunsets at night.

name: Bonham State Park
description: Texas state park with electric, water, clean restrooms with showers and a dump station. Tent camping sites with electricity and water as well as primitive tent sites are also available.

name: Hidden Creek 2
description: I'm adding this second location at Hidden Creek because this site has creek access. Its not dried up. This place is a little confusing too. Not sure if there are several loops to choose but there were different roads you could take and we weren't really sure where to go. Satellite map view wasn't much help either. Other than the creek, theres just a rock ring fire pit and not much else. Its nice and quiet here. Didnt see any other campers but saw several cars go by on a road in the distance. Not sure if that leads to another set of campsites or what. Plenty of wood to collect and burn. 1-2 bars of spotty T-Mobile service. You can kind of see the creek in the distance in the photo I added. Its not far from the campsite.

name: Sonoran Desert National Monument
description: Parking area off  Hwy 238/west Maricopa Rd. we did not stay the night, but lovely hike on wide trail with the pups. Did not say no overnight camping and clearly some had evident by the fire ring. 3 bars Verizon. Road was not super busy.

name: Duds and Suds
description: Neat little laundromat that sells beer and cocktails while you do your wash. Pretty clean and friendly environment too. We parked our 40' skoolie in the mall parking lot directly across the street (gps coordinates correspond to our parking location). I'm not sure if you could get away overnighting here as I did see mall security pass by a few times during our 2 hour stay. There was plenty of parking here (not sure if covid was a factor or if that malls aren't that popular any more...)

name: Walmart Supercenter Taylors
description: Slept here overnight in my Promaster van with no issues

name: Flying J
description: Propane refills at the Flying J gas station.

name: Flying J
description: Dump station at the Flying J gas station. $10

name: Sunset Reef Campground
description: Established campground with 6 tent sites and 5 pull through trailer sites. No water but does have a vault toilet. Nice concrete pads with picnic tables and roofs to keep the sun off. Absolutely gorgeous sunsets over the Guadeloupe mountains with the Carlsbad Caverns visitor center off in the distance. Each tent site has fire pits and everywhere has a charcoal grill. Not a lot of firewood in the area though. Free of charge and 100% worth the stop. For some reason I couldn't change the stars but I'd give it 3.5-4/5 for tent camping.

name: Murphy USA Water Spigot
description:
Very friendly staff
Asked to fill my 40 gallon water tank and they said no problem

name: Progression Climbing parking
description: Campervans (not RVs) welcome to park in parking lot. Park towards back of lot.

name: Open Pond
description: Open Pond Recreation Area, Conecuh National Forest. Developed sites ($16) have electric & water, undeveloped ($8) do not. All have fire ring, grill, table, etc. Showers & restrooms on site.

name: Mesa Sunset RV Resort
description: Sites for short term and long term stays available. 20/30/50 Amp electricity, water, sewer hookups. The sites have pee gravel in the RV spaces, and concrete pads for parking / patio. Nicely maintained bathrooms, swimming pool, jacuzzi, fitness room, etc. Helpful and friendly staff. $53 / night with Good Sam discount. Open to all ages.

name: Holiday
description: Propane gas and diesel also RV dump station with purchase

name: Lehi County transfer Station: trash only
description: 10 dumpsters open. no recycling or other services.

name: Edge of Shasta Lake
description: Nice spot near the edge of Shasta Lake. Picnic table, fire pit, but unfortunately a decent amount of trash. Room for car camping, vans or tents. Got a walk under the power tower then down the hill to get to the site. Good ATT LTE service.

name: Sun Flower Flats
description: A small free camp ground with several sites. It's a little rough getting here but I made it in a sedan. Very close to Sycamore Falls.

name: Dump Station
description: Dump Station as you exit the northbound rest area... go thru the truck parking to get to it.

name: Parker Public Library
description: Friendly library with fast WiFi, shaded parking, and a shaded picnic table outside. Restrooms at the park across the street. The library staff are also very nice and have a rack of 50 cent used books outside the door.

name: Bentonite Hills, Capitol Reef National Park
description:
Clay/Gypsum hills in red, bluish, white colors. about 6-10 miles off the pavement. 
Gravel and sand road. There is less than 5 mins of steeper hills, otherwise fairly flat. Small river crossing within the first 5 mins of leaving pavement. Must have vehicle with higher clearance. In April, river was about 18 inches at the deepest part (deepest at the opposite bank when going in). As you cross River going in, drive on the right side in the river and cut left quickly to exit water. Keep a good pace to maintain momentum

name: Cathedral Valley
description:
Viewpoint of the Valley and perfectly carved "cathedrals".
High clearance vehicles recommended, through gravel roads to this point.

name: Naturita Sales
description: Water available - ask inside. Also a gas station, café, car wash, convenience store.

name: Naturita Sales
description: good food, free WiFi, coffee, breakfast.

name: Secluded spot off road for car or small RV
description:
Space here for one car or small RV to pull in. 

It’s one degree uneven if you pull in 25 feet, four or so degrees if you pull in further. About 100 feet in (my guess) it dead ends and there’s a small space for a fire or tent. Beyond that is a small hill downward. No space for a fire ring.

You can hear the water running in the distance.

You’re legally required to follow National Forest rules if you stay here which you can find online (only stay for a limited time, no fires during fire ban time periods, etc.)

name: Potable Water Spigot
description:
Blue spigot near front entrance of Heritage Center
It’s next to the bushes across from the house

name: Miller’s landing resort
description:
4$/5 minutes public and hot shower, you purchase the tokens in the store (you can pay with card).

Laundromat (coin operated):
2,50$/30 minutes washer
1,50$/60 minutes dryer

Showers and machines were dirty, also 5 minutes of showertime is really short.

Open 8am/8pm

name: Green Valley Campground
description: Large 80 site campground in Cuyamaca Rancho State Park. Very busy. $35 for dry camping spot. Not sure about hookups. Horse camp area. Showers. Water. Flush toilets. 1 bar AT&T 5Ge

name: Wagon wheel off-road staging area
description: Many pull-offs onto dirt roads marked by signs designating camping areas.

name: Sulphur Cracker Barrel
description: Smaller than other Cracker Barrel’s but otherwise the same. It’s right next to a Super 8 motel. We were the only ones parked here overnight however several big rigs were parked at the Super 8.

name: Street Parking
description: We were going to stay the night at the Sutter’s Landing Parking but the area was sketchy so we moved down here. Another van joined in back of us and it was quiet at night. Felt safe and there is a BBQ place across the street for your cravings!

name: Circle K
description: Gas station with 2 water pumps next to the gas pumps

name: Pilot Travel Center
description: There is a spigot right in front of the building. I went in to ask if I could use it and the clerk said I could if it was working. It was.

name: Del Taco - Riverside
description: 24-hour Del Taco. While ordering dinner, I asked if I could park my (class B) RV for “several hours.” The nice young woman behind the counter said that was fine and I wasn’t bothered all night. It’s next to a highway so it’s a bit loud. Use earplugs.

name: Sage Hen Dispersed
description:
Right off of Sage Hen Rd on the way to Sagehen Campground there's a nice open clearing on USFS land.  Snowy in early April but beautiful and warm.  Very quiet. We didn't sleep here but spent the day in this area and didn't see another soul.  There's a private residence up the road so watch for land ownership before picking a spot to camp. Lots of fresh horse poop on the roads but we didn't see any wild horses, sadly. 

OK (not great) ATT and Verizon, but no T-mobile.

name: Roadside just past Laguna Mountain Entrance
description: With the no reservation policy at the Laguna Mountain and Upper Sweetwater BLM Campgrounds, it can be hard to be sure of a spot. Fortunately there are a few roadside camp-legal spots (verified with the ranger) that are actually quieter than the campground itself. There's one directly adjacent to the campground entrance, and one across the road, but we went to a wide spot a couple turns down which gets you away from the in-and-out traffic (not that it was too bad). Actually a very pleasant spot with a beautiful view of the galley. Walk to the campground pit toilets is about 10 minutes...also where the trailhead is for the hike into The Gorge and its waterfalls when water is running.

name: Ta travel center
description: 15 $ hot unlimited showers. Me and my gf switched half way and no issues with that. Also laundry 3$ each load and dump station (not free but unsure on price ) also a dunkin, store , clean bathrooms and some other fast food place

name: Spurling Landing
description: Two small campsites available for free through the Northwest Florida Water Management District. Campsite #3 no longer exists. Trash service and a portable toilet (very clean). Spots are small and not level. Suitable for a small setup such as vans, cab over campers, tents or pop ups. Boat ramp with fishing for bream, bass and channel cats. Fire pits and grills. Very quiet. Insects weren’t terrible late March. You’ll need to obtain a Special Use Permit (SUL) ahead of time (nwfwater.com)

name: Rock Chair Camp
description: Same road as “camp by a rock”, continue South on dirt road to this camp site. Fire ring, level pull through off road and a rock near fire ring shaped exactly like a chair (surprisingly comfortable). Several other sites along this road before and after this one. Loose pea gravel road, 2wd should be ok, but very low clearance beware. Limited turn around spots on road. No road noise, secluded, nice desert setting with small Joshua Trees. Great stars despite light pollution from Vegas to the East. No cell reception (Verizon) here.

name: Grundy county conservation campground
description: Newer campground with multiple sites. Pull throughs, back in, tent, grills, bath-house with shower. Picknick tables, elec & water, RV dump. Lakeside.  Playground. Paid $15

name: Forest road 7160.   Ranger creek airstrip near Crystal Mt
description: Great site.   Lots of flat sites with picnic tables.  Room for all kinds of rigs.   Bathrooms were closed April 2021.      Quite Monday night probably gets rowdy on weekend

name: Forest Road 320
description: Dispersed camping along Forest Road 320. There are spots all along the road but if you continue a few miles it opens up with a nice view of Pikes Peak. I had no problem in my 4Runner but the road was very tight and still snowy on 4/6/21 so I wouldn’t suggest it for bigger rigs. However, I did see a 30ish foot rv parked up the road a little bit. I’m still pretty blown away they got that beast out here. 5G signal on AT&T wasn’t great but I bounced between one or two bars and could still load things on my phone.

name: Walmart
description: This Walmart is on high alert due to a shooting that happened a year ago. There are security and police on site still and I asked if it’s ok to park and they had no problem with me staying.

name: Maverik water
description: Maverik gas station. Water spigot on front wall. Ok to use per clerk. Also has propane tank exchange.

name: Forrest spot near highway
description: Other people in spot marked nearby so we found this place. Lots of pull ins on this road but these cords are for the largest back in site. I’d rate it a 9/10 way better than a rest stop. There’s a creek next to the site and a river behind . No “no camping signs”. Met a guys saying it was ok and no one bothered us. You could prob fit any size rig in/ camp behind your car. There’s also some tables and firepits nearby

name: Gibraltar Rd Pulloff
description:
This is one of many pull offs along the road here, but this one is plenty big enough for a dozen cars and seemed a lot more level then the first one lower down the road. Incredible views of the mountains, ocean, and Santa Barbara. Fairly quiet during the day and almost silent at night. 

WARNING: very steep climb for about 8 miles and hairpin turns. I’m in a shuttle bus and the engine started heating above normal operating temp on the way up. Also beware of bikers bombing the hill road.

name: Carter’s Home Cooking
description: Good, old-fashioned, cafeteria-served (or off the menu) Southern-style food!

name: Little Black Creek Campground & Park
description: Beautiful! Large camping, cabins Full-RV hookup sites on a large beautiful lake. Golf course included on grounds! Would return.

name: Monadnock hq state park
description: Pretty cool camp area. One of the few open all year round! 35$ w tax. The site says walk in tent for all but it’s like private spots and a 20’ walk so you can sleep in vehicle if better. Sites are fairly private but no one was here w us. But expensive due to dump station and showers being closed (winterizarion) but no where else to go. 6/10

name: Walmart (no overnight parking)
description: This is good for short day parking, but tried to stay overnight and Security came over and said no overnight parking. I'm guessing this is because the Walmart shares the building with other vendors.

name: Fire control road
description: Many spots along road to pull off. Busy on weekends with motor folks but quiet during the week. The road was in great shape when we camped

name: Orangewood RV
description:
Free. Hard to find near propane refill tank under rock hole in the ground with metal flap. Business hours only. 11405 W Bell Rd #9656, Surprise, AZ.
Wednesday	8AM–5PM
Thursday	8AM–5PM
Friday	8AM–5PM
Saturday	9AM–5PM
Sunday	10AM–3PM
Monday	8AM–5PM
Tuesday	8AM–5PM

name: Orangewood RV
description:
Propane Refills. 11405 W Bell Rd #9656, Surprise, AZ. Cheapest in area.
Business hours only
Wednesday	8AM–5PM
Thursday	8AM–5PM
Friday	8AM–5PM
Saturday	9AM–5PM
Sunday	10AM–3PM
Monday	8AM–5PM
Tuesday	8AM–5PM

name: Orangewood RV
description:
Free.  Potable. 11405 W Bell Rd #9656, Surprise, AZ. Faucet to add hose to. Near the propane refill tank.
Business hours only.
Wednesday	8AM–5PM
Thursday	8AM–5PM
Friday	8AM–5PM
Saturday	9AM–5PM
Sunday	10AM–3PM
Monday	8AM–5PM
Tuesday	8AM–5PM

name: Love’s Travel Shop (Truck Stop)
description:
Open 24 hours. 
Love’s Travel Shop is a gas station and truck stop. Overnight Parking. They have showers inside (you just need to wait until your number is called). They have a water tap outside (not potable) for free. They’re website says they have RV dump stations, laundry facilities, and Wifi but I’m not sure if this location does. 

According to their website:
“Love’s Travel Stops has more RV parking spots and amenities than any other national travel stop network. Whether you need a propane refill, an RV dump, a private shower, laundry facilities or a place to stretch your legs, you’ll find that and more.”

name: Tractor Supply
description: You can stay over night in the parking lot of tractor supply. i seen a few rvs parked out front

name: 4 B’s Wash Mart & Car Wash
description:
Laundry Facility and Car Wash
Old Buildings but machines work great.

name: H.M. Yeager Fuels
description:
Yeager filled my Travel Trailer propane tanks while I was living in an RV park nearby. I thought it was worth posting incase you need to get your propane tanks filled and you’re in the area. I’m not sure if they’ll fill them on site but they are a family owned small business so it’s likely they will. Very nice Guy he always took care of me. The wife however, can be a bit hard to deal with. 

His Sign says: Gas, Propane, Kerosene, and Diesel

name: Young’s RV Park
description: This is a well-maintained Intown RV Park. It has nice bathrooms showers and an Onsite laundromat. You can walk into town for food and such.

name: Upper Sharp Tank
description: Quiet at night. just few car go by the highway 260

name: Hermosa Beach,  CA
description: On Hermosa Ave & 21st Street,  there's a middle lane with 24 hours parking spots, $1.25/hour, enforced 10am to midnight.

name: Leeds Creek Rd site #11
description: Good for tent small RV, small pull behind, RTT or tent. Lots of scrub brush. Pack in, pack out. Two bars of Verizon, no T-Mobile service.

name: Rim Road
description:
This is a great spot off of UT 14 and Rim Road. 
Several spots, fire ring and wide open.
Great road when dry, no need for 4X4. Wet and snow conditions that would change. 
Here in April, some snow and wet spot but didn’t need to lock in. 
It’s NFS, so don’t think there is a pet policy, my dog loved it!

name: Flying J Gas Station
description: Lots of big rigs stay overnight here so it’s going to be noisy. I was in a van. I checked with the gas station about staying the night and the staff said okay. I parked near the dumpster. Dairy Queen is closed. Showers available.

name: Fishlake National Forest-Side of Road
description: Pulled in here last night late. It worked great if you're just looking for a spot to overnight. Interstate noise wasn't too bad and we slept well. There are 2 spots here - one on each side of the road - neither is flat but they're fine for a night. Excellent Verizon service here.

name: Street Parking
description: We parked beside The Story Ashland Church for the night. We came around after the sunset and left when the sun started to rise. Also we have a stealth van so we were to blend with the other vehicles

name: Boulder Gulch Campground
description:
This is a National Forest Service campground on the lake side of the road. There is also a second campground directly on the opposite side of the road. All campground camping is $30 night +$2 extra on holidays. Half price with national parks pass. 

It has more than 100 sites—some in the trees, some in a more exposed area with a granite Boulder background. 

We were here on a Wednesday night, so it was quiet as far as campers go. There is definitely road noise, but it quiets down at night. The sites are pretty close to each other, so you better like your neighbors. There was a fair amount of trash here, and I’m not sure if it’s from the campground or blown up from the lake. 

The main road in has a great site set into the boulders—dont camp here. I did. This seems to be a main thoroughfare for local traffic at all times of the day to blast through to the day use part of the lake that is accessible, then blast out. Stay up in the trees...more road noise, less local, weird, suspicious traffic. For what it’s worth, I felt safe here even with the suspicious in and out traffic—they just drive faster than anyone ever should in a campground. Keep an eye on your kids and pets. 

The instructions say to find a spot and occupy it, and a “uniformed“ for a service officer will come by and take your payment. A woman came by to take my payment, but she was wearing super short “juicy“ shorts and a printed tank top. She did, however, have California government plates and she filled out the paperwork and gave us a slip to put on our site post.

There are a number of other options in the area. I have stayed directly on the shore of the lake in the national Rec area. If I come back this way, I’ll do that again and avoid this campground. It wasn’t terrible, but as I listen to the local Harley fire up it’s pipes before 8am to leave after being here 15 minutes this morning...it kinda sucks. 

*I had my Tundra and 24’ toy hauler and it is TIGHT in here. My friends had their 28’ RV and it was super tight. I wouldn’t recommend anything over those sizes.

name: Turnipseed Campground
description: $5 a night forest service campground. Beautiful hiking trails right from the campground. 5 minutes from the state park/high point. Pit toilets. Really quiet. I would definitely stay again! The app won't let me change the star rating, but I would give it 4/5!

name: Walmart
description: Just another walmart, there's a hot spring up the road a ways in Cañon City!

name: FR181
description: TONS of established spots with fire rings,  no att cell service.  road is a bit bumpy but all vehicles could drive this.  room for tents, vans,  trailers & 5th wheels.  trees for shade,  sun for solar! 14 day limit. about 45 min from payson I think

name: Shell Gas Station
description: newer gas station with propane. lowest price in Overton.

name: Maverik gas station - Free water
description: When looking at the front of the building: look on the right side of the building, there is a Red Box / Ice machine. To the right around the corner is a hose with free water. You don’t have to ask to use it, just pull up and get what you need. Good pressure!

name: RV Country
description: RV parts and service and they also have propane. Was slightly more than the others listed here but not much more and it was on our way. $3.10/gal

name: Coin-op shower & laundry
description:
Awesome place to refresh and resupply. 

Found this place as a detour around the “lake” while the roads were being worked on. Clean and hot shower at campground. 

Coin op: 12 quarters to start, $0.75 per minutes. Recommended minimum $4.50 for 6 minutes. Instructions on wall. Laundry next door. Water $0.10/gallon. Trash disposal $3 for medium white bags and $5 for large black bags. Ask attendance inside “RV & Camping Reservation” office

name: Laundry
description: effecient laundromat, basic, clean, coin machine on site, bathrooms.

name: Next to church
description: Flat street (unlike the other “street parking spot”) parking spot next to the church. We had a quiet night sleep. No one bothered us. There are some tables in the back of the church where we had lunch. University students neighborhood. Night is free and then it’s pay parking from 8-18hs (2$us an hour)

name: Walmart- Navasota
description: Thankfully they let you stay here as I was getting fairly desperate and there seems to not be a lot of overnight places near by. (at least not on the app) I went in to ask if an RV could stay overnight they said yes but I have to be gone by 7 am the next morning. It seems like this is a spot to get to after dark and leave by the sunrise. The only other thing they said is that you need to park in the back of the lot.

name: Navasota Public Library
description:
Open to public monday 1-7pn, Tuesday- Friday 8:30 am-5:30pm, sat-sun closed.

Really fast wifi, but I think they only have the wifi on during library hours not sure.

name: Cattails Marsh walking/biking paths
description: This is a great place with 5+ miles of walking and biking paths. Tons of parking available. I saw about 8 alligators and tons of birds on my 1 & 1/2 hour walk. A nice place to get outside for awhile. Also on the way in I saw tons of picnic tables and I believe a disc golf course. This is an awesome park!!

name: Port Arthur Library
description:
Really nice library with bathrooms and water fountain. The wifi is really fast but you can't get it from your car and I think it is only on when they are open. 

Current COVID hours (as of April 6th 2021):
Mon-Fri: 9-6pm
Sat: 9-1pm
Sun: closed

name: Walmart Port Arthur
description: Stayed one night at this Walmart with a couple semis around. I stayed on the South east side of the parking lot which is the garden center side. Had no problems all night. Little to no traffic noise but there is a train that goes through close by a couple times during the night. Other than that just like every other Walmart. Also you can reach their wifi from most spots in the parking lot. For Walmart Wifi it was pretty fast and let me stream a movie.

name: Walmart
description: Stayed here one night with two other RV's. Didn't have any problems but the street sweeper comes through at around 11:30, not that big of a deal. There is a little bit of traffic noise but nothing terrible. Park in the back on the garden center side. There is some patchy Walmart wifi, it works if you need to look a few things up.

name: BLM Dispersed Camping
description: BLM Land near LCNP. Flat ground but only a few bushes in the area. Nice for a 1 night stay or for MTB Riding. Hiking possibilities but I think it would be too hot in the summer. 1 bar Verizon.

name: Vermillion canyon Trailhead
description:
large flat area for several vehicles or RV. beautiful canyons all around. no signs prohibiting camping.

Coordinates are not accurate, we had to continue for approximately half of mile to get to the large spot.
Very quiet..

name: Maverik potable water
description: Water pump is located between fuel pumps 3 and 4.  Hook up your hose to the normal threaded spigot, lift the handle as you pull on the bigger spigot that water gushes out of, then a suction is created and water will come out of your hose. Blue spigot handle for potable water. Free.

name: 50 Mile Bench Switchbacks
description: Above Sooner Slide just off the right side upper third, 1.5 miles below 50 Mile Bench Road. Sheltered by Juniper trees but exposed to road. Little to no traffic.

name: Payne lake
description: Public boat access. Gravel parking area 2bars Verizon  good place for any size rv with room to turn around. no issues with a 29’ C

name: Paradise on the Hill
description: Wonderful site at the top of a small hill on BLM land. Fell in love with the view and the wind on hot days keeps us cool! Great Verizon service in certain sweet spots. Perfectly level for an RV, also has a fire pit!

name: Potable Water Spigot
description:
@ Exxon 
Near the Diesel pumps (14/15)
Would definitely recommend a water pressure regulator for this one

name: Green Parking Garage
description: it's a multistory parking garage next to a Whole Foods, shopping, restaurants and nightlife. the area is called "The Domain"

name: Parking lot Shell
description: We arrive to Walmart and there were a lot of signs of “no overnight parking” so we saw the shell and a big parking at the back so we came, there was no sign but we decide to ask anyway and the girl from the Shop said we could stay for the night. Its 9 am now and everything was good. No problem! Good spot! We have a 22 ft Rv.

name: Library
description: Super big library with tons of places to sit with many outlets. The Wifi is super fast and you might be able to reach it from your car.

name: Alum Cave Trail Head and Pit potty
description: Best to camp out the night or morning before you hike up to LeConte Lodge because parking is minimal. Very quite after the late hours when there minimal traffic. The great sound of running water for white noise as well. Zero cell service for miles in and up.

name: Lake Deaton Boat Ramp
description: 24 hour boat ramp. Super quiet and dark. Don’t park too close to dumpster or outhouse, or park and rec will ask you to move. Found this place taking motorcycle off hitch staying at Brownwood Paddack Square. Decided to move, 4 minutes away. Much better upgrade! Enjoy

name: Fort Nashboro
description: Down by the Cumberland River. Across Nissan Stadium. free parking after 6pm otherwise 2.25/HR in meter. Sundays free all day

name: Somerset Airfield Campground
description: I stayed here for three nights... it was lovely and peaceful.

name: Large Truck stop
description:
Not ideal or scenic but this stop is large enough that you can tuck yourself away in a quite spot. 
Free overnight. 
Restrooms and showers inside if needed.

name: Roadside Park
description: This is a quite long pullout on the southside of a highway which appears to provide parking for the town park. It's fine for a nights stay with traffic slowing down at night. The highway got busy in the morning. Excellent Verizon service here.

name: City water at the park
description:
Yeah you will need the square spigot tool to turn on the water

Water spigot located on the kids drinking fountain by the kids play park

Another spigot located by the men and women’s bathrooms

I used a 100 foot hose from the playground 

The distance from the other spigot is shorter

name: Builder's Supply hardware store
description: Propane tank refill. Pull into the parking lot to the left of the store

name: Love's Truck Stop
description: Easy access from I-80 and room for any size rigs. Above average noise level, but lots of people around made us feel safer than some of the rundown rest areas nearby. Good cell service on ATT and large garbage cans. Small dog park was a big plus.

name: Rim view
description: Fantastic spot for a jeep with a tent or a small trailer. The roads a bit rough off the main road but once there it is gorgeous and private

name: Spring Valley State Park
description: This is a very nice and well-maintained state park campground called Horsethief. Very nice restrooms and very nice showers next to reservoir and about a mile away from a nice hiking trail. It can accommodate pretty large rigs we saw classes and some fifth wheels in there. Be aware that there is no cell service there at all. There is a landline if you have to call an emergency. And there is satellite Internet available for purchase for eight dollars a day in 2021

name: CWS  propane
description: monday - throu  - friday  8-5   saturday 8 -12   propane supplies in store

name: Citico Creek
description: Jake Best Campground / Cherokee national forest. Great creek views in spots along gravel roads. Some defined parking spots with fire rings and pit, some just off the road. Federal land with some $6 fees. We visited during a really cool controlled burn. Seen some large trailers but drive slow for about 8 miles in with zero cell service. Very tight roads. My sprinter did great!

name: Water and restrooms
description: Here is a place where you can fill drinkable water (filling water jugs) and restrooms next to the river. Awesome place all along the river to spend the day (no overnight allowed).

name: Off the 155
description: A nice little spot right 155 up a little hill. Road still visible but quiet at night. Great views of The valley and a beautiful sunset. No one bothers you. Staying one night only. No AT&T or T-Mobile signal. Just nature.

name: Gene Rush WMA
description: Wildlife Management Area with 6 - 8 pull off spots down a dead end road. Fire rings at each one. Super quiet and remote. No amenities. 2 bars on Verizon. Love this spot!

name: Virgin River
description:
After passing the majority of the crowd the first 0.25miles from the highway, there are more spots and more secluded with fire rings. The road can be a little rough but I saw a minivan pass us. We were in a Jeep pulling a teardrop trailer (non-off road wheels) and it did fine. Just go slow. Took a picture of the road/rock condition. After a rain though, it’ll probably be pretty muddy. 
There are spots near the mesa, overlooking the Virgin River with a spectacular view! We were about 0.1miles from that spot and still had great views!

name: Picnic Area Hwy 281
description: Picnic Area 281 North near Evant. Nice picnic area on west side of road. Set back from road - noise from large truks but overall not super busy - nice view since it is also om the side of a hill looking into town. Texas allows 24 hours in its picnic areas - no problem.

name: Danby State Forest Site 3
description: Small pull off of Bald Hill Road near the Abott Loop hiking trail. Call Ranger for permission.  Busy during deer season

name: Great Seal State Park
description: Simple and safe... Reservable sites via online or phone. Equestrians, mountain bikers, and hikers seem to use this park often.

name: Sauk Trail INDOT Rest Area
description:
Old school primitive rest area with picnic tables and a well pump. Sign says no camping or overnight parking. (Can't imagine why, it's nowhere)
There's a historical marker about a pre colonial Indian trail.

name: Flying J
description: Has parking for overnight parking. Haven't had any problems after buying fuel here and putting receipt in front window.

name: Sam's club
description: very quiet,flat parking lot. no issues. starbucks And panera, Walmart all nearby.

name: Cracker Barrel
description: Called and asked if they allow overnight parking. They said Yes :) I didn’t see RV spaces but had plenty of parking. Quiet and comfortable.

name: Bishop Lake Campground
description: Great Campsite with 3 parks: Murry for weekend only. Brighton for the Big Rvs and Electric sites. Appleton with rustic picnic table & pit outside bathroom. Plan your visit on Michigan.gov/dnr

name: Valero
description: Propane fill up at the Valero gas station.

name: Black Kettle Campground
description: very quaint little free spot near the border of Texas. extremely pretty if ya hop the fence and go climb a little hill/sand dune to overlook the lake. sunny, everyone else that was there kept to themselves, and large enough space to accommodate any sized rig. awesome little find!

name: Lake Meredith overlook
description: feels like you should pay for this place, but it's free as a bee! wonderful overlook of the lake, you can hike down (although quite steep, we did it) to bathe in the lake, firepits, 4 toilets and 4 showers (quite gross if you asked me though... we bathed in the lake instead), and a few pavilions for shade and picnic tables. great view and wonderfully kind people we met in the rig behind us. I'd get here around 2-3 in the afternoon as well as it filled up by 6pm! popular little spot!

name: Monocline Valley 1
description:
We stayed at the iOverlander spot called, "Near Valley of Fire State Park" from April 3 - 7, 2021 which is just below this location.  I am just documenting the other spots in this area that are being mentioned since we stayed here for four nights.

This spot is on a knoll overlooking "Near Valley of Fire State Park."  It is not very level but people did stay on it while we were at "Near Valley of Fire State Park."

It is rocky, steep, with loose dirt and off-canter.  But clearly it is doable.  If you are over 40' long, you may struggle with this spot.

I would recommend 4wd and if you are pulling a trailer, I would say 4wd is probably needed to get up to it.  There isn't a lot of room to turn around at the top either.  We looked at this spot before choosing the lower spot simply because we were pulling a trailer and maneuvering on this knoll was going to be more difficult than the big turn around below at "Near Valley of Fire State Park."

name: Monocline Valley 2
description:
We stayed at the iOverlander spot called, "Near Valley of Fire State Park" from April 3 - 7, 2021 which is just below this location. I am just documenting the other spots in this area that are being mentioned since we stayed here for four nights.

This spot is on a knoll overlooking "Near Valley of Fire State Park." It is not very level but people did stay on it while we were at "Near Valley of Fire State Park."  

It is rocky, steep, with loose dirt and rocks and off-canter. But clearly it is doable. If you are over 25' long, you may struggle with this spot.

After watching others struggle to get into this spot, I would say 4wd is probably needed to get up to it. There isn't a lot of room to turn around at the top either.  The person we watched in a mid-size van pulled up to it but couldn't turn around for fear of rolling down the knoll.  He backed down, then backed up it again to get his rig turned around to face the right way.  

We looked at this spot, but because of our trailer, immediately passed on it and chose "Near Valley of Fire State Park" simply because of our trailer.

name: Monocline Valley 3
description:
We stayed at the iOverlander spot called, "Near Valley of Fire State Park" from April 3 - 7, 2021 which is just nearby this location. I am just documenting the other spots in this area that are being mentioned since we stayed here for four nights.

This spot is the last of three spots on the dirt road coming off the pavement before you have to go up a small hill to get to the other three.  

This spot is very large with lots of room to maneuver and turn around.

2wd is all that is necessary to get into here.  When we arrived, there was a family in this spot with their Nissan pickup and 35' Airstream trailer.

name: Recycling Dumpster
description: There is a recycling dumpster behind city hall. There is tons of parking back there I believe it is Visitor parking back there. The dumpster is pretty big and dark green so super hard to miss. They accept most everything that has the recycle sign on it. (but I don't think colored plastic or plastic bags)

name: Pull out
description: A little pull out. No amenities. Good for one night. Only vans

name: Walmart
description: Spent one night here in a 24 ft RV with no problems. Just like any other Walmart, park towards the back near the gas station. Also fairly good wifi from Walmart too.

name: Grand Staircase Escalante -
description: Cell reception (AT&T) spotty.  Road to the spot can be rutted.  High clearance 4x4 definitely a plus.  Not recommended after rainfall.

name: Defeated Creek Park
description:
Sits on the banks of Cordell Hull Lake on the Cumberland River System, seven miles from Carthage, TN. 
155 sites for tents and RVs, all with electric hookups. Bathhouses and laundry facilities. Two first-come-first-served or reservable large group shelters with water and electric. Boat ramp, playground, beach, tennis and volleyball courts. Marina adjacent to campground.
Make reservations via Recreation.gov

name: National Forest Service Road 89
description: Drove up one of the service roads and found a spot right away. Doesn't seem very used but there's some old tracks from where people might've gotten stuck when it was wet up here over the winter. There's still snow on the roads and a bit of mud but it wasn't an issue with a 2WD Sprinter. It's very flat and we didn't see anyone until around eleven. I'm getting Verizon LTE with two bars but it's not enough to use very effectively.

name: Waterway Inn
description: A private motel with rentable mobile homes and rooms, enough parking for trailers and cars, nestled just off of I-75 in Indian River with easy access to the North Central State Trail. Kitchens available in the mobile homes, not standard rooms.

name: Lowe's
description: Austin Lowe's parking lot in Shoal Creek area.

name: library
description:
A small library with place to sit and charge your devices. The wifi is super fast. 

This place is open week days 9-4pm, Saturday 9-3pm,closed on Sun

name: Collins lake campground
description: Hot Showers operated by quarters. Clean and a beautiful landscape!

name: Little blackely trail head
description:
-Narrow path to get here. Truck got some racing stripes. high clearance definitely needed. 4x4 highly highly recommend. Not much off-roading experience still made it here with no issues. Across the lake from the state park. Room for 2 setup. There was mosquitoes and a fire ring.
-Rocky, very bumpy and some ruts
-Verizon is all over the place no service to 1 bar LTE. No booster
-this national forest has areas with a lot of trash. This campsite is not too bad. Leave it cleaner then when you found it
-not that level

There is also spots around that are not hard to get to. Google maps shows all the dirt roads

name: Conservation Road
description: Dispersed camping is allowed in many areas of the Tahoe National Forest, including this one, approximately one mile up Conservation Road off Highway 20 outside of Nevada City, Calif. There are numerous pullouts with camping potential, but we went for this fairly large flat corner area and made it our mountain bike basecamp for two nights. With the Pfeiffer Trail literally running through the site, it made for great bike-in/bike-out access to Pioneer Trail, then the area gems Hoot Trail on the north side of Highway 20, and Scott's Flat Trail on the south side of the road. Faint, spotty internet service, no toilets or water, but all-in-all a great boondocking location.

name: Creek Smoke Shop
description: Gas station across the street from Wind Creek Casino. Dirt parking lot for tractor trailers. It’s not too busy, has a 24 bathroom, no showers, and right next to a casino.

name: U-Haul
description: moving trucks and propane refill station

name: Rocks River Park
description: West side of US Hwy 301 on the north edge of Claxton Georgia. Nice shaded area with ample room to pull in and turn around along the Canoochee River. A few picnic tables and areas to fish. No 'no parking' signs.

name: between Cottonwood and Sedona
description: parked along a dirt road with a view of Sedona..equidistant from Sedona and Cottonwood

name: Peg Leg
description: Peg Leg State Park. Big rig, tent, toilettes. Plenty of hiking around

name: Beaver Creek Trail
description: Flat spot right where the road is closed until June.  Nice hike trailhead. Could be impossible to get to after a storm so use your judgment based on your vehicle. Not amazing but will do for an overnighter. Large enough to turn a trailer around if you had to and no other cars were here. Washboard road so use caution with larger vehicles.

name: Leconte Parking
description: Free parking during the day. You can ride the tram to the experiences around Pigeon Forge.

name: Hickory Knob State Park
description: State Park campground on the water.  Restaurant and cabins.  Full hookups and toilet/showers. $23

name: Fruita Community Center
description: Showers only for $4. Swimming is $7. Bring your own towels and toiletries. Same entrance as the library.

name: Hydraulic House
description: We had such a hard time getting custom made propane hoses. Until we finally found this place. They are pricey but they have a lot of parts and fittings for propane and other hydraulic stuff.

name: Shell Water
description: Spigot on the north side. Asked attendant and she said it was alright! I had to use two flathead screwdrivers to open the valve, didn’t have a turnkey.

name: Greenfield City Center
description: Lots of public parking in quiet "city". No signs whatsoever. Just choose a quiet corner spot somewhere and hit up Shelburne Falls Coffee in the morning.

name: Halterman's RV
description: Best prices on propane we've found in the northwest.

name: Texaco Truck Stop
description:
The Texaco gas station on the north end of town is a truck stop. They have showers (only $7 for a warm, private, unlimited shower, towels included!) and other trucker amenities, including overnight parking. 

When I asked the attendant inside if they allow overnight RV/camper parking, she said it’s normally just truckers but if there was space, she didn’t see why vans/RVs couldn’t stay too. This place has tons of space, including a mostly-empty quieter dirt lot behind the paved truck lot. I can’t imagine this place filling up. 

I spent the night with no issues. Some sirens and barking dogs, but none of the train whistles that plague the Walmart parking lot in town. I ran a white noise app on my phone and slept great. 

Close enough for day trips to White Sands. 

There’s a restaurant inside that used to be 24/7 but closes from 10pm-6am during Covid times. Google reviews say it’s good, I didn’t eat there.

name: Pine Canyon #2
description:
Reservable permit-required backcountry “primitive roadside campsite” in Big Bend National Park. 

Rocky road after the first two miles, and the road gets significantly tougher after Pine Canyon site #1. I’m in a short skoolie and I never want to bring my bus up this road again. A couple of the uphills (downhill on the way out) are steep and very washed out, with big eroded spots perpendicular to the road, so it does a number on your vehicle. 

Definitely not big rig friendly, probably not trailer friendly unless it’s an off-road / 4x4 trailer. There are a few washes where the road abruptly dips and goes back up again. I imagine those aren’t friendly to towing. Biggest rig I’d want to bring up here again is a van. 

No AT&T or off-network cell service.

name: Molino canyon
description: A small parking lot at Molino canyon. Space for 2 or 3 RVs. No „No overnight“ signs. We ask a Ranger and he told us we can stay on spaces where it is not forbidden. No services here but quite in the night and cooler than Tuscon (1250 m high)

name: Tire/truck mechanic
description: Huge fenced lot. No problem for any size vehicle.  These guys were able to take us in for brakes on short notice.  They let us spend the night in the rig, in the shop.  Worked fast, priced fair.  And if they don’t want to do the job, they’ll tell you.  They also do roadside assistance. Call them if needed at +1 318-345-3080.

name: Kraemer Wisconsin Cheese
description: Incredible assortment of cheeses (including vegetarian). Free samples. Fudge. Krinkles (a baked desert) honey, sausages and a few random items.  Great stop and decent prices. Large parking lot with room for any rig.

name: Vintage Sewing Center and Museum
description: Yes! A sewing machine museum.  It is beautiful and much to see and learn. ALSO if you have a sewing project of any size or scale, you can use a machine to do it.  Leather, canvas, crafts, backpacks, panniers, etc. This guy loves a challenge and will help you! A woman was bringing in her sails to repair them while we were there!  Large adjoining parking area will fit any size rig.  Call ahead to confirm hours of operation and availability for sewing machine usage.

name: FR360 out of Timber Camp
description: FR360 is accessed from the day use parking area. Numerous camp areas on USDA land. Not big rig friendly due to narrow windy trail thru the trees. 4x4 recommended if you go back past 0.5 mile. A little further from 60 so quieter than the campground. No facilities. Good Verizon signal.

name: Laufman Campground Area Pullout
description: Found a few spots up the road from Laufman Campground with good views. Soft dirt for digging catholes, don't forget to pack out your TP! Ok Verizon LTE, 2 bars.

name: Southwind RV Park
description: RV sites. Short term or long term. Deluxe sites near the town of Fort Myers, FL. Short drive to beaches and shopping

name: Victoryland Casino
description:
Victoryland has a parking lot for buses and RVs. It's somewhat quiet, but you can hear the interstate traffic nearby. Be careful with small children and pets because occasionally a car cuts through the RV lot on the way to the casino, thinking it's a shortcut.

You're not allowed to park in the main lot, and the RV lot is not signed, but you can tell you're in the correct lot from the long pull through spaces painted in the asphalt.

This is a good place to hang out when the ground in other places is too muddy.

name: IHOP parking lot
description: Go in and and ask nicely if you can spend the night but the folks working here said it was no problem for us overnight in their parking lot. Lots of road noise but any port in a storm eh?

name: Carson NF
description: All the forest roads with dispersed campsites along the "High road to Taos" are closed in winter. This place is a possibility if you need a spot just for overnight, nothing special. It's a larger pulloff for a van, truck camper or class-c, nothing bigger. The forest road itself leads to a cemetery and some houses further down. The gravel road is in very good shape, no 4x4 needed. No big trees around you.

name: Lone Rock NPS
description: Lone Rock NPS, Glen Canyon, Lake Powell, Page AZ. An expansive beach with fine clean sand. Plenty of room for dispersed camping. Much of the sand is soft and part of the entertainment is to watch stuck cars and RVs get free. Be careful. 4x4 and AWD have more success. 3 bars Verizon, sometimes slow. Scenery is spectacular. Water is 130 feet below 20 years ago and 30 below last year, but still clean and gorgeous. The wind blew fine sand everywhere during our two days here. Dump station and water are a couple of miles away at another Park service RV Park. Here there are pit toilets requiring a long walk. The automated fee station wasn't working so we couldn't pay.

name: Mackay Laundry & Showers
description:
Coin-op laundromat with coin-op showers. The shower rooms are large, clean, and private, with a toilet and sink. Showers are $1.75 for 5 minutes of hot water with great pressure. Washers are $1.50 per load. There is no change machine or detergent, but you can get quarters at the nearby gas station or bank and there is a grocery store across the street for supplies. Hours are 7AM to 8PM.

This is a great, affordable resource for travelers, let's keep it that way!

name: Corrals
description: Large area that has room for a group. Sunny areas and shady areas in the trees.

name: White Earth Campground
description: Solid campsite with views. Free in off season until may. Great Verizon LTE speeds. Suitable for large and small rigs. Pit toilets.

name: Spin City
description: Large laundromat with large parking. Also offers drop off service.  Has wifi, atm, bathrooms, hand wash sink and a Planet Fitness next door so you can wash your smelly self!! This is a score for an Overlander.  (Also a Little Free Library for you to trade books and magazine)

name: Old ferry landing Westbank
description: Site of the old St Francesville ferry abandoned on 2011. Can park up on the road next to the sign or down at the river's edge, if the river is not at flood stage like when we visited.

name: Love’s Travel Stop
description: Typical Love’s with typically Love’s highway noise. We felt safe staying here with several other overnighters. Easy and convenient. Good cell service on ATT.

name: 2 M’s RV Park
description:
This is a simple, bare bones “RV park” in the tiny town of Eldorado, Texas. Calling it an RV park is a stretch, there are no bathrooms, showers, wifi/cable, or even an office. Basically hookups on someone’s farm land. They do have water and sewage though. 

Not much, but does the trick on a long haul across Texas and its lack of public lands/camping (ugh, Texas!). 

The owner lives in a house next door, she’ll probably see you come in and drive over in her truck. 

Only about 7 spots, some of them look to be full-timers, but I can’t imagine this place ever being fully booked. 

$20/night. I paid cash and am not sure they take cards. 
Strong AT&T signal.

name: Temporary Border Patrol Checkpoint
description:
A temporary “tactical” border patrol checkpoint for Northbound cars. 

The permanent checkpoint up the road is closed for now, and Border Patrol set up this location with tents and cameras and trucks, just no permanent buildings. This location is closer to where they perceive the action to be, I guess. 

They asked a few more questions than other checkpoints I’ve been through, things like “where are you going and where are you coming from,” but nothing major. Didn’t need to show ID. Friendly enough.

name: Library wifi
description: Really nice library with tons of places to work. There is a poster that says the wifi is on Mon-Sat 8am-8pm which I believe you can reach from the parking lot.

name: Coleman Rv Park
description: Free 5 days electric water and dump station ( donations accepted) please

name: Cracker Barrel
description: 4 pull- thru RV spots by left side of building

name: Cracker Barrel
description: Great location away from the interstate, Walmart in walking distance. Only two designated RV spaces at a bit more than 40 feet long. Shorter RV no problem and a very experienced Big Rig driver might not have issues with the short space IF you’re without a TOAD. Quiet and reasonably level place for the night.

name: Old ferry landing
description: Site of the east bank of the old St Francesville ferry, abandoned in 2012. Lots of parking in a big lot between the boat ramp and the bayou. When we visited, the river was at flood and most of the area was underwater. We drove to the other side of the river to camp. This is also a pretty place to see the occasional river boat cruises.

name: MN Welcome Ctr/Rest Area
description:
This is a super nice rest stop.
CLEAN, Safe, with PLENTY of parking among the manicured lawns and perfectly pruned trees. Nice playground for kids, plenty of pet rest areas, sparkling restrooms, and vending. Tons of picnic tables (who does that nowadays?) Two pavilions, and a colonade.
Official MN law says 4/24 hr parking limit for cars, 10/24 hr for commercial vehicles. Not enforced 4/2021. LOTS of overnight cars/vans with NO ISSUES and a ton of empty spaces.
The place is like a park in Scandinavia.
A++ FIVE STARS.

name: Ghost Town Road
description: Off Ghost Town road. There is a small area. 10 rigs max, i’d guess. Good for a stopover. There is a fuel station and convenience store at Congress Junction.

name: carona del mar plaza
description: mall with free WiFi throughout the parking lot

name: Albertsons
description: Large recycling dumpsters (7-8) open for public use. They're right along the edge of the parking lot for the Albertsons, so you can see them while driving along NM-423/Paseo Del Norte Blvd. Forgot to take a photo of the Recycling Do's/Don't posted on the dumpster so check before you dump.

name: Dump and water fill
description: Free! Just across the street from the campground. Clean fill water.

name: Springdale Park
description: Next to the Springdale public library. Water is next to the pavilion and bbq grill area. It’s a big faucet so you could fill up large jugs of water. There are also bathrooms and a place to dump trash up the road by the amphitheater. Great park to chill and relax.

name: Pilot Travel Center
description: Small but clean room with sink, toilet, and shower large enough for two. $12+tax and comes with a clean set of towels (ask for an extra set if there are two of you)

name: Pilot Travel Center
description: Clean and newer washer and dryers (4 or 5 sets). Have credit card readers too. $2.75 wash and $2.00 dry

name: Gila Monster Parking Area at Taos Ski Valley
description:
Gila Monster Parking area at ski resort (first one on the right when you enter the parking area.

$28 (includes tax) per night for ALL lots that allow overnight parking.

name: Orvis Hot Springs
description: This is a clothing optional hot springs resort. They offer day passes, hour quick dip tickets and camping/lodging. Camping in either tent or RV is in their parking lot. Official business hours are 7am-9pm BUT if you are camping in their parking lot, you get to soak all night as well. Camping is 49$ per adult/$20 ages 4-12 per night and you get 2 full days of access to the resort(arrival and departure day plus night). In addition to the Springs they have bathrooms, showers and a community kitchen. This is a family friendly resort as long as the kiddos are good. Very nice, friendly and relaxed place with a nice view of the mountains.

name: Bus & RV Street Parking
description:
Free Bus & RV Street Parking near the visitor center and historic Lexington.
I asked the visitor center if it was ok to overnight park and they said it shouldn’t be a problem but it is near Greek Housing/Colleges.
I stayed on a Wednesday night and didn’t have any issues.  A few cars drove by that were loud, but that’s it.  Tons of green space for dogs with doggie bags and trash / recycle cans.

name: Clear Lake state park
description: At the entrance of the park, you pay 8$( and use the facilities), then showers are coin operated. Hot and clean

name: Ocean Blvd
description:
No "no parking" signs of any kind. Just down the hill in the State Beach Park there are public washrooms. Gorgeous views and sunsets. 

It is busy and in a neighborhood but if you are discrete you won't have any problems.

name: Stinker Gas Station
description: Has shows facilities for $5.00. I didn’t use it so couldn’t verify the quality. But the shower stalls look very clean.

name: At the 76 gas station
description: Propane refill available on the south side of the building.

name: Road closure on FS 708
description: Gated closure for unknown reasons to motor vehicles. Hiking this trail is strongly discouraged as well.

name: Mackay Laundry & Showers
description:
Coin-op laundromat with coin-op showers. The shower rooms are large, clean, and private, with a toilet and sink. Showers are $1.75 for 5 minutes of hot water with great pressure. Washers are $1.50 per load. There is no change machine or detergent, but you can get quarters at the nearby gas station or bank and there is a grocery store across the street for supplies. Hours are 7AM to 8PM.

This is a great, affordable resource for travelers, let's keep it that way!

name: Ray & Donna's
description: Great spot for a spot in town. level, clean, and relatively empty. completely free spot with no one checking in on ya. clean water, dump pipe, picnic table, and electrical hookup all for free at each site. 9 sites side by side and right next to a 40 mph road. loud trucks and all is the worst of it, free electric charge up was the best of it! 5/5 for us for one night - although please note, there is no toilet.

name: Wal-Mart
description: There's no overnight parking signs but I spent the last 2 nights here.  There's a couple big rigs and a rv here also. Even left my trailer here while I explored Boston both days.

name: No Name Bay
description: Accessible by either the Martin Bay or Arthur Bay entrances. Cost is $8 for vehicle and $12 for primitive camping. Plenty of beach access for parking if vehicle can accommodate. Pullout is available midway between Martin and Arthur that was private and peaceful.

name: Free camp sites next to the river
description:
There are about 10 spots available, 5 directly next to the Arkansas river and others on the other side of the road. Place is open from April 1st till the 15th of October as far as we understood. You are allowed to stay up to 14 days.

Most sites have a place to sit with a roof, very quiet at night. 1 person is living here in his camper, sort of controlling the area.

Pit toilets available.

All tarmac road to get here.

Good Internet reception on our phone (USMobile).

name: Hole in the Rock road
description: This part is BLM area just a 1/2 mile off the main road of Hole in the Rock. Nestled amount the junipers and pinion pines, that is very quiet. It's a pack it in and pack it out area. Nearest vaulted toilet is at the "Dance Hall".

name: Hole in the Rock road
description: This part of the "Hole in the Rock" area is managed by the Bureau of Land Management. The road in was very heavily wash board so it was slow traveling and the road in is wide enough for any size RV. There were no toilets where our group camped and plenty of room for any size RV, just be careful of some soft sand areas. We had 2 bars on our cell phone at this location service was Verizon and AT&T. Vaulted toilet toilets are at the main attractions like the "Dance Hall", "Devils Garden" and "Peek a Boo" trail. Also note that this is a highly used road till you get to the Glen Canyon boundary.

name: Hole in the Rock road
description: This part of the "Hole in the Rock" area is managed by the Bureau of Land Management. The road in was very heavily wash board so it was slow traveling and the road in is wide enough for any size RV. There were no toilets where our group camped and plenty of room for any size RV, just be careful of some soft sand areas. We had 2 bars on our cell phone at this location service was Verizon and AT&T. Vaulted toilet toilets are at the main attractions like the "Dance Hall", "Devils Garden" and "Peek a Boo" trail. Also note that this is a highly used road till you get to the Glen Canyon boundary.

name: Pateros Wi-Fi Hotspot
description: Gravel parking area with picnic benches and free Wi-fi.

name: Kaiser Springs Trailhead?
description:
This is a trailhead for Kaiser Springs.  The walk is about 45min to an hour one way, heading west, in a wash.  

To get here, take the side road off 93 North, just after you pass the sign for "Kaiser Springs Canyon".  The "trailhead" is under the overpass.  We recommend parking along the farthest pilars because that has the easiest way down into the wash.

Really gorgeous spring.  Not much farther down from the "hot" spring (the water is warm), is the river which really shouldn't be missed because the colors of the rock are just so pretty.  

Enjoy

name: Garland Ave Laundry
description: Basic coin laundromat with ATM and bathroom. Nothing fancy, next to convenience store

name: BLM
description: The other spots along this road were taken so when I saw some old tracks going up this little incline I decided to check it out. Nice spot! The ground off the tracks is a little soft so be careful. Panoramic views and excellent T-Mobile 5G! No highway noise and only the occasional train. Hardly noticed them with a fan on. 30ish minutes from Arches National Park.

name: Old forge year round campground
description: It’s a resort campsite , basic rv 35, tent 25 open all year which is cool for this area, we didn’t end up staying but it didn’t look to resorty.

name: Black river Forrest camping
description:
8/10 site, the one we stayed at was massive. One site down the road from us past the rail tracks and one further down before the locked gate

Sign says only need permit for parties over 10 or for longer than three days m

Open all year round! 

I also believe there are more sites like these across the road but didn’t check. Sits on lots of hiking trails nearby. Pit toilets down the hiking trail about a mile but open all year round

Also camping backcountry sites throughout this area

name: Cecile Poche Memorial Park
description: In town park next to Bayou Teche. $15 per night (though no one came to collect when we were there). Quiet setting with large shade trees. A few concrete pads for rv's, some on grass. Playground for kids. Backed in our 37 ft RV.

name: Lobster Creek CG (National Forest)
description: Seven sites at this first-come, first-service campground on the Rouge River. Operated by the National Forest Service so sites are pretty affordable ($15 per night, $7.50 with an interagency pass). Potable water, garbage, pit toilets, and fire rings available. No dump, showers, or electricity. Water available at camp hosts site (he'll lend you his hose). 1 bar Verizon

name: Ouray Hot Springs Pool
description:
Perfect to merge a much needed shower with a fun activity. Outside pools and hot springs pools have a beautiful view. Adults and kids will have fun here. Next to municipal park. $18/adult for pool access. 

ADA showers: two "roll-in" showers with grab bars. No seat. A portable shower seat in the women's changing room.

name: Ridgway parking at municipal park
description: Municipal parking lot, without sign about night parking. Nice and quiet, next to marshall. Cute city with bars and restaurants. This option saved us late at night, without signal to reserve a camping at the state park.

name: Hole in the Rock road
description: Just off the Hole in the Roc road you can find a side road that wanders among the junipers and pinion pipes. We found a nice spot for our group of 4 truck campers. The soil is soft once off the well traveled road in but well worth it for the night is dead quiet. This area is managed by the Bureau of Lands Management up to the Glen Canyon Rec. Area.

name: Shell gas station
description: Water spigot with blue handle at a shell gas station.

name: Throndson Oil & LP Gas Co
description: Oil, gas and propane available. Propane filling station (not self serve) is in the chain link enclosure in front of the office. Hours are 7am-5pm Mon-Fri

name: Rest Area Crystal Springs
description: Good rest area all services, water, good cell services, clean restroom and electricity

name: Just North of Alabama Hills Recreation Area (BLM)
description: Road in is 4wd high clearance (e.g. stock Jeep).  Verizon reception was in and out, 2 bars then 1x.  The recreation area was packed with campers, trailers, motor homes and tents.  This road put us into the Alabama Hills in seclusion as it is not passable with a trailer or van.  Stayed 2 nights nestled in the rocks to shelter from the wind.  Fire ring there.  Only traffic was a few dirt bikes.  Nice views of Mt Whitney.

name: Davis Truck Stop
description: Free Dump station... pull up to the right of the building. There is a lone gas pump and the dump station is about 4 feet before that pump under the metal lid.

name: Dispersed Site
description: Secluded dispersed site near Nutrioso, AZ and Hulsey Lake. 1-2 bars with ATT 4G.

name: Ferrellgas
description: The propane tank is visible from the highway. Pull behind Performance Fitness and push the button for service. Attendant will come from fitness center.  Getting LP refills in Hurricane is hard. Tractor supply is up the road, but system was not working.

name: Beach access ramp #43
description:
Slept here last night and it was amazing! Heard the ocean all night and I don’t think another car came in the parking lot all night. There are signs that say “no camping on beach” but no no overnight camping signs. 
I did see reviews on google maps saying the ranger is very rude. 
There is a paid camping spot just down the road if you don’t want to risk it. But can’t beat free camping with the sounds of the waves.

name: Creekside Campspot off Hwy 153
description:
There's a pullout off of Hwy 153 about 7 miles east of Beaver with space for several vehicles set back from the road right next to the creek.  I love camping next to the sound of a creek with lots of waterfall action. There's a fire ring, flat areas for tents, trees for hammocks, and plenty of beaver sign (knawed on trees).  I enjoyed my one night stay here at this spot I scouted on on Google Earth in advance during my motorcycle trip.

The road is visible from the campsite, but traffic was very minimal after dark.

No verizon cell service at this spot, but there was service just a couple miles down the hill toward Beaver.

(the GPS coordinates marking this are exact) 38°15'21.4"N 112°31'30.5"W

name: Camp Lake Jasper
description: RV private Resort. Reservations required. Beautiful setting on Lake Jasper. Very well maintained. Laundry, Showers & WC.

name: Parking Lot
description: Quiet parking lot. Spent one evening no issues. Near Colorado River.

name: Diamond lake state park
description: Stunningly beautiful state park 9 miles off 80.  Electric hookups or tent sites. I’m using my truck camper at a tent site. Tent sites $10 electric $20. Open all yr.  I think there’s a three week max

name: Unionville Village Park
description:
Located at the village park, newly built four campsites with water and electric.  Free use of dump station for registered campers, otherwise $5 per use.    The park offers a 1 mile walking/biking path, four ball fields, playground equipment, tennis court, basketball court and two pavilions.  
Cost: $20 per night.
Call the village office at 989-674-2244 to reserve.

name: Unionville Village Park
description: $5 per use.  Free for registered campers.

name: Creek Side Resort
description:
RV park located in Hays, KS, south of I-70

Sells propane, ice, and some RV supplies

Nice place to overnight or extended stay.

Standard Dump Fee: $10

name: Hidden Valley State Park
description: 30 campsites nicely separated.  No hookups.    Put toilet.  Water.  Fire rings.  $15/ night.

name: Westport Park & Ride
description: Park & Ride location up the road from Sherwood Island State Park. Safe, quiet spot. Stayed overnight. Not crowded at all. Well lit and clean.

name: Walmart
description: Plenty of cars parked overnight, but there’s a loudspeaker announcement every 20 minutes or so. A little hard to fall asleep with “THANK YOU FOR SHOPPING AT YOUR LOCAL WALMART” blasting every few minutes. I’d try to avoid this one.

name: Periwinkle Park
description: Only campground on Sanibel Island - old Florida charm, close to beach

name: Rome Riverside Campground
description: The camp site is just outside Kettle moraine in Wisconsin. Campers and tent sites available. Clean. Quiet. Good fishing.

name: Fort Ross Store
description: Small market had free public WiFi access (in a desert of no service.) Also a bathroom outside store.

name: Walmart supercenter
description:
Moderator Note: Although the User received permission to stay overnight, the description also suggests that overnight parking is not usually allowed. Always check with customer services. 

Parking at Walmart , big and quiet with wifi free . We asked the manager for permission to stay for one night , hé says yes , although it was forbidden  we have a motorhome 29 feet. It’s a great place if you visit Crystal river , that is just at 15 minutes away !

name: Chalk Mountain picnic area
description: Chalk Mountain picnic area rest stop. Sweet views of the surrounding valley from the covered picnic tables. Clean and great for a stop.

name: Fort Myers
description:
Moderator Note: The User description suggests that overnight parking is OK but it does not appear to be legal. Category changed to Short-term Parking.

Downtown Fort Myers has a lot of street parking with parking meters.  Usually only from 7:30am-6pm.  We parked on the east side of the library which has parking meters only during weekdays, but we came on a weekend so we don’t have to pay.  Successfully parked overnight with no problems and there were other cars that parked overnight as well.  We stayed in a shuttle bus, so I’m assuming a van and similar can get away with even more stealth.  There is a huge lot next block over but it seems to be private property.

name: South Lake
description:
Stayed here April 29th-May 2nd 2021. Three bars of Cricket cell service.

Showed up on a Thursday hoping to get a good spot.  Thought this location would allow you to camp at the banks of the lake, but was wrong.  I didn't see another human being in the 34 minute drive up to the location, but there was a bunch of people there when I got there. The last 25 minutes or so of the drive is nothing but dirt and gravel, and this must get awfully muddy during the rainy season.  Wouldn't go up the mountain in this weather unless you have 4wheel drive. But, in late April, my 2wd Mobile Traveler motor home made it up the hill fine.  There is one stretch that has some serious potholes in the dirt and gravel.  If you have a luxury car, keep it at home.  I saw one guy with a BMW trying to get up this road.  Don't bring it up here.  Also, leave your big rigs at home.  This location is good for tent camping and very small trailers. 

I found a good camping spot and made camp.  At one point, someone turned off my generator at around 9:20PM at night, and stole the magnet I had on the side of my vehicle.  They also opened up the black water tank valve.  So, keep an eye on your stuff when here. 

Went fishing one day and enjoyed myself.  Nothing was biting.  There were tons of tiny fish in the lake, but the the big ones weren't biting.  

The weekend had a number of drunken characters who were speaking language you wouldn't want your kids to hear.  By Sunday, 90% of everyone was gone.  It was quiet and relaxing.

I would recommend to arrive on a Sunday or Monday.   

Also, bring plenty of garbage bags.  People don't seem to know how to clean up after themselves.

A pit toilet is there.  This is National Forrest Service Land.

name: Closed restaurant next to Salty Dog in Siesta Key Village
description: There are about a half dozen parking spots that would fit a Class B or smaller in front of a single story, white vacant building right at the North Entrance to Siesta Key Beach. The building/parking spots are to the immediate right of The Old Salty Dog restaurant. The building has been vacant for the better part of a decade. Great location for a Class B to park, bar hop in Siesta Key Village, catch a good night sleep then perhaps lunch at Salty Dog in the AM.

name: Vista Park Showers
description: Hot showers in Vista Park. Just past the main office when headed to the beach area. Park has paid RV sites, but day use is free. Showers are coin operated, 50 cents for 5 minutes. Water was nice and hot and there was even heat in the stall!

name: NF284 to See Canyon TH
description: A few pull off areas along forest road for car, tent or small rv. Great spots if hiking the trails. Good Verizon

name: Barnhardt TH Road
description: Various pull-offs along a maintained but rocky road, just take it slow. Good Verizon and AT&T. Why leave your trash behind...

name: Control Road - Rim Views
description: A few spots on gravel Control Rd but this place just before the cattle guard allows you to get back away from the road dust.  Looks like could get muddy if wet.   Verizon spotty. Pack it in, Pack it out.

name: Lava Hot Springs KOA West
description: $45 a night here was about the cheapest I could find close to the hot springs with full hookups. If you want to walk to the famous hot springs the East KOA is closer but west is still walkable. Pets cost extra $5.00 a day. If you want better WiFi it’s another $6.00 a day. My laptop wouldn’t let me login to the WiFi because the connection isn’t secure. You can hear trains all night. The campground isn’t secure. Public traffic can drive through because half of the grounds are along public streets. Only good things about this place are the laundry and bathrooms and proximity to hot springs. Very expensive

name: Blue Creek Boat Ramp
description:
A large flat grass/gravel spot that can hold several dozen campers & boat trailers.  Great spot meant for fishermen. Has a posted sign (image attached) which clearly states "upto 3days followed by a 7day absence." Tonight (Sunday 4/25) there was 4 of us overnight all 50+ yards apart. Found via FreeRoam, "Behind the Cowlitz Trout Hatchery located on Tacoma Power land. Pit toilets and trash. 3 day limit. No fires but BBQs OK

Please respect this space and throw away your garbage!"

name: 18 hour rest area
description: Found this by accident.  A free Sani dump with non potable water.  You could spend night here as well because there is an 18 hour limit.  Flush toilets (with TP), picnic tables and trash bins.  Good LTE signal. There's a fountain best the tables and a water pump but water was off - maybe when it's warmer....

name: Chevron
description: There's a 7 space RV park here for $30 a night full  hook ups or you can park out back of station for free.  Fewer big trucks here than Loves. They sell propane too. We parked at outer reaches of back lot to be further from road noise. LTE Google Fi.  We had a surprisly quiet night.

name: I70 rest stop with sani dump
description: Regular freeway rest stop with bathrooms and picnic tables. There's a large driving circle you can park along for one night we were told by maintenance staff.  At beginning of the circle there's a sani dump with non portable water.  Good for one night.  Usual highway noise.

name: Harper Ferry Civil War Battlefields KOA
description:
Full service KOA near Harpers Ferry National Historic Park. 
$43 for tent site with hookups.

name: Fowler’s Hollow State Park
description:
12 sites with hookups.  Nice brook bubbling by. 
$35.50 (power and water sites) for non residents of PA. 
Basic tent sites are less.

name: Showers at Sinclair general store
description: Private showers for $8. Shower was very clean, but a little old. It is also possible to sleep in the parking lot for the night. Nothing magically but will do!

name: Pueblo La Plata area
description: Nice site with firepit. Road is rocky and high clearance recommended.

name: Valero (Lonestar)
description: They have propane at the pump. You can just pull up and go inside and they will come out and fill your tank

name: Tijuana river valley campground
description: Literally on the border. Brand new facility and it is gorgeous. Token showers, yurts, tent and RV sites. Tons of trails for walking and mountain biking. This place is way better than I imagined. Down side is lack of trees to camp under. Only firewood from the ranger station can be burned at this campground due to pest control.

name: Coal Creek off highway 14
description: Along this road there are a few pull offs that you can camp on. This one has about 4 spots not visible from the road. Not big rig friendly.
