Couple deep ruts but my short school bus made it just fine and pretty much anyone could pull in here. Road traffic is loud as you’re right off it but you’re hidden from it so that’s a plus. Night time of course the noise dies down. There are paths that lead down to the river. If you go to the most westward camp area and look around you’ll find a path lines with rocks someone made all the way to the river. Felt a little magical if you don’t pay attention to the trash! (Bring a bag and take some out with you!) stayed here two nights, so did a couple other vehicles. A great spot if you want to be near town but not in it.

name: Parking lot. Three Sisters Springs
description: A good place quiet of short parking with free electricity and tables on big trees.

name: Rest area / historic site
description: Clean bathrooms, running water, truck parking, potable water (by truck parking) and water fountains inside. Plus picnic area and trash.

name: Cenex
description: Just adding because no where near the park has diesel , we were almost out and falsely were told there are stations by the west entrance. (3.09 #2 may 2021

name: RaceTrac
description: Great place to fill your gas tank and water tank. its been our go to place in the southeast.

name: Peters Point Park
description: Tons of free parking and access to the beach. They also have 3 or 4 indoor stall showers in the bathrooms + two outdoor showers. Not sure if they lock at a certain time but I was here from 5-6pm and they were still open. There are also water fountains too which is nice.

name: Rest Stop
description: Rest Stop on the northboard side. Really nice clean bathrooms with water fountians. Cars are on the left and all other vehicles on the right. We had a 24ft RV and stayed on the left with the cars because we could fit in one spot. Also the the truck side was full of semis in the morning. So if you are on the smaller side of RVs don't go and take up a full semi spot. Also there are vending machines!

name: Walmart
description: Walmart parking lot stay in the way back towards the road. I was able to get the Walmart WiFi all the way at the back of the lot to stream a show. Just like any other Walmart..

name: Walmart
description: Just like any other Walmart. Park on the garden side away from the building. I was here with one other RV and had no problems. Also I was sort of able to reach there WiFi which was nice. There was a helicopter that went right over head very low three differnet times in one hour other than that it was very quiet all night.

name: Walmart
description: Just like every other Walmart. Park in the way back towards the road. No problems all night, a little noisy but by 11pm everything was quiet just some road noise.

name: Cash's Auto shop
description:
Super nice staff! I brought my diesel RV here after being turned away from a few places, I just needed an oil change. 
Were very helpful and made sure they got the right oil, etc.

name: CA62/CA177
description:
Vacant lands at the junction of CA62 and CA177. Right along the road. easy access. Good for big rigs.
No shade or facilities
ATT 3bars LTE

name: Flying J - Sanitation Dump
description:
$10 per usage.
Located on the right side (beside air pump) as you enter the gas station.
Fresh water hook up spigot available

name: Flying J - Fresh Water Spigot
description:
Located right beside air station, and sanitation dump.
Standard threaded spigot

name: Lodgepole Campsite Dumping Station
description: Lodgepole Campsite Dumping station with water hoses to clean off, located by the stream, Besides restrooms and large parking lot. There's a clean water station next to dump station.

name: Lodgepole Campsite Clean Water
description: Located by the stream, by dumping station, restrooms and large parking lot. Hose attached.

name: Hwy 180 Pull out
description:
Paved Pull out along a corner. Large enough for a big rig. No facilities here.
There is more area beside the paved pullout, but it slants to one side.
I didn't stay overnight here, but in the National Forest area by YMCA camp further up. but i parked here for hours to work and use hotspot off AT&T LTE.
AT&T - 4bars + LTE. Good connection.

name: Linville Gorge Camp Spot
description: small camp spot, room for one car, fire pit, 4g lte.

name: Truck stop
description: Truck stop between i5 and McDonalds and Subway. Not the typical loud truck stop. Except for freeway noise it is pretty nice with food right there. Other vehicles besides trucks parked here for the night with no problems. Lots of fast food restaurants around. WiFi from McDonald’s.

name: glacier water station
description: water fill up at united food center- 40 cents a gallon, 2$ 5 gallons

name: Safeway / Strip Mall
description:
Pulled up here late at night, no one bothered us & we even got to sleep in a bit, we first tried Harbor Freight but it was way to loud and close to the train tracks 
Safeway was a little lively throughout the night but nothing crazy, decent spot if you can’t find anywhere else

name: Mobil gas station
description: Water next to the vacuum near the exit to the car wash

name: Camping World
description: Free full Hookups for 1 vehicle, free dump, propane for pay.  For Good Sam members only after 7pm leave before 9am

name: Moab Gear Trader
description: New and used outdoor apparel, camping equipment and supplies sold by a knowledge staff.

name: Cortez Recreation Center
description: Community center with fast WiFi, pool and showers available for a fee

name: WalMart main street
description: Small parking area near Freddy's is where  I was told to park, one night only.  Reasonably level, has good cell and you can get WiFi from several of the local business.

name: OHV area
description: This is a fine campsite, not great.  Good if you just want to spend the night somewhere on your route.  Better than the other site nearby on this app as you are hidden from town, and away from the power lines.  Gets shaded about an hour from sunset which is nice when it’s hot.  It is an OHV park but on a big turnout, quiet at night.  Road in is sandy but doable in anything without an absurd wheelbase.  Again, not a great place to stay for a while but quiet and secluded for a night.

name: Greenpoint quiet street
description: Quiet industrial area. Wide street with easy parking. Not really near anything but good to get away from the crowd.

name: Picnic area on 283 near Coleman
description: I didn’t spend the night here but it looks like a convenient place to stay if needed. Classical Texas Notice sign seems to say it’s ok to stay for 1 night but no tent. Near the road but probably quiet at night

name: Baca Campground
description: wonderful little find!!! free for up to 14 days, we stayed 3 days and 3 nights. no one around to see or bother ya - it's a 6 mile drive on a small dirt road. beautiful mountain views and land to explore. highly highly highly recommend this spot if you're passing through NM! also perfect AT&T service. 10/10 spot!

name: top of a gravel hill, quiet
description: free spot on the top of a gravel hill just turned off from the highway. supremely dirty with broken glass, but if you get over that, it's not a bad spot. nice views, great sunset, and quite quiet in a tiny home. would not suggest tenting here ! perfect AT&T service. overall, 6/10 but it did the job for a night

name: If you want to have a fire and relax, this is the place
description: wonderful little spot! dead and dry wood for a fire is everywhere, no other people in sight (except for the few vehicles we saw pass by our site on the dirt road), and a beautiful spot tucked into the woods and trees to keep us out of the mountain winds. great hammocking spots, cool mountain air, and close to Sedona. had a wonderful time here... 9.5/10 - only bad thing is zero signal. makes it better sometimes though ;)

name: 6.5k elevation with a view - free and loely
description: this spot has a few switch backs, but we saw long RVs up here too. just be careful and avoid the rocks and you will be fine. avoid mud if it rained recently and pull into a spot away from others - it's serene, quiet, and full of nature. lovely little spot we stayed for 3 days when we were going to only do one. clean up your trash & enjoy!!! 9/10

name: an absolute MUST stop - free and quiet
description: this gem of a place is great. we stayed for two nights and thoroughly explored Red Mountain (super easy trail up to the slot canyons and red mountain views - not to the summit). I ran up the left hand side and saw an incredible view of the Grand Canyon in the distance along with white capped Flagstaff mountains to my right and a wonderful sunset to my left. well worth the stop, no one else around, and plenty of firewood to have a calm night of chats by the fire. a bit windy at times but a very secluded little spot. we were in a tiny home pulled by an f150 so plenty of room to have a large rig. bit of a bumpy road coming in but you will be fine. pick up your trash!! 9.5/10

name: Middle of unfinished forest road.
description: Dirt road off beyond Henne’s Ridge Road. Stopped here due to clearance. Parked in the middle of the dirt road. This ain’t for the faint of heart and pretty sure it’s not legal.

name: Cenex fuel station with free dump station
description: Cenex fuel station with free dump station and water. They also have shower and laundry facilities available.

name: Rest stop
description: Small and well lit. Bathrooms, etc. The standard. Other vans when I got here. Felt safe.

name: Conserv
description: Propane and dump station. $8 to dump. No potable water.

name: Hi Country Rec V Center
description: I was traveling through Arizona and had a propane leak in my camper van. I stopped here and they were able to assist me ASAP and correct my issue. Some of the best customer service I’ve ever received. They have a full shop of RV parts, I highly recommend using them if you need anything. Family owned!!

name: Plaza Go Truck Stop
description:
Truck stop with a gas station and restaurant (inside, including restaurant, closed while I was there, but says open 24/7, could be covid related) 

Nice quiet sleep on the restaurant side by a few other cars in my van. There’s a Loves across the way as well if one or the other spot is particularly busy or loud.

name: Pilot truck stop
description: Little bit noisy but for overnight is ok

name: Limestone lake park
description: Free 10 days by the lake , enter by hwy 79  ( don’t use hwy 7 ) gps take me that way and is not access to the campground , just couple spots for big rigs , about 15 to 20 spots

name: Cracker Barrel
description: Nice Cracker Barrel easy to get to off of I55. Quiet.

name: St Albans Dump station & water
description: In a public park on the river across from Kroger. When you pull in it is on your right. There is a dump station and also potable water to fill your tanks.

name: Hollins Hunt camp
description: Large area of campsites located off of Bull Gap Rd. Plenty of room and level ground for multiple campers. The road in is good but I’m not sure I’d try it in anything much bigger than a Sprinter type van. No amenities. You’ll have to be self contained. Very quiet and lovely at the end of April.

name: Turkey Run state park
description: Very wooded area 169- some sites not as wooded. Older bathroom & showers but clean, with nice warm water. Early week so it’s pretty quiet. Spots vary in size but ours fit well- most have plenty of length-there is nice distance between sites. only 1 vehicle per site- not all super flat but not bad. Most are concrete or paved.

name: Point Reyes Petaluma
description:
A few beautiful pull offs on the side of this road with several large lots each. all overlooking the meandering lake. 

no signs for no overnight parking, stayed here one night without problems.

2 bars of LTE service

name: Silver eagle
description: Propane in middle of town! Good price, good customer service.

name: Walmart moncks corner
description: Big parking of Walmart, good place for one night, we ask to thé manager to stay and hé says ok , parking at the end next garden center

name: Lawrence E. Wood Picnic Area
description: Great overnight stop. 5 spots to park but on a Friday night, there was only one person here. We were visited by some wild boars that we watched from the safety of our campervan. Big rigs may find maneuvering tricky but some spots do have the room.

name: Pine Canyon #5
description: Amazing camp site. Right on the road but it’s the last site before a trail head so no overnight traffic. We made the road slow and steady in our front wheel drive Promaster with cross climate tires and it had just heavily rained. So the road was very rough in spots. Ideal conditions would be okay in any vehicle with semi higher clearance.

name: FS 525 Large Camp for multiple spots
description: Large pullout on west side of NF road. Multiple spots for different campers, RVs or tents. Some shady areas with beautiful views. You’ll be able to watch the sunrise over the red rocks or the sunset over the brushy hills. Some small rock fire pits scattered about. Easy to find a semi level spot but best to have some leveling blocks for RV. Verizon cell is 1-2 bars only.

name: foothills water
description:
can fill water jugs/bottles
also is a visitor center with bathrooms

name: cute dried creek area
description:
nice easy trail by dirt pull off we stayed at
hiked in the morning expecting water down here but is all dried up BUT is very much a nice shaded spot to kick back and relax 
lots of spots to sit

name: Dirt road with lots of spots, unsure how many
description: stayed close to the entrance, looks like it goes in a decent bit with quite a bit of spots. saw about 5 vehicles leave being sprinter vans and SUV's. no fire pits to be seen. left early morning, no disturbances.

name: Deschutes NF BLM land
description: great area for a night or two, lots of spots to use and not many I see in use right now (end of april) -campfire pits already made, lots of sticks to grab around to burn. feels safe for a single person traveling alone. dog friendly of course, plenty of spots for a hammock, funner trail next to us. stayed close to entrance at first big flat spot. 1 bar at&t, 1 bar t-mobile

name: water spigot that boat launch
description: Two water spigots next to boat launch parking and Dumpsters

name: Water spigot backside of pavilion
description: Water spigot right by the outdoor showers

name: City water spigot source
description:
We came to Starbucks after hours and saw the spigot with hose

City water

name: Food lion grocery parking lot
description:
This is a quiet strip mall parking lot, plenty of space of a larger rig 

There was a semi parked near the back as we showed up so that made me feel comfortable

name: Free Daytime beach parking
description: After driving the whole island twice, we found two spots on the street with free day tome parking

name: Water and day parking plus huge dog park and playgrounds
description:
This is a very large park for dogs and humans

Water is found at the older restroom area near the back

We are 38 feet long and pulled off to the side easy, needed a 50 foot hose for the water spigot in the men’s bathroom

Or 100 foot hose for the water spigot at the back of the building

name: Free beach day parking
description:
Free beach day parking along Ocean shore Avenue with beach access walkways

We are 38 feet long, if you get here early I am sure there will be room for a longer rigs

name: Monterey free RV parking
description: About eight long spaces that will accommodate any size rig. Great spot for the day. FREE.

name: Buckskin Gulch Canyon (short walk)
description:
Permit is required to hike the canyon. $6/ person & $6/dog. Can be purchased online or at trail head, bring exact money as you deposit it in an envelope & into lock box. 
Plenty of parking. Popular hike. We did 10k each way. Kids loved it! Hiking boots or sneakers work. No cell, no camping, maintained pit toilets.

name: Losee Canyon
description:
BLM land, easy dirt road access. Perfect camp to mountain bike Losee Canyon (blue) trails. 
Flat camping, plenty of space. Dinosaur tracks & petrified felted wool slippers from early man at trail entrance.  2 bars cell service. Pack out all garbage.  Very quiet, recommended.

name: 180’ view, Valley of The Gods
description: Holly crap it’s beautiful here.  Totally worth the effort.  Large enuf to turn around our 27ft truck. Used rocks to level. Majestic views, sunset is gorgeous!

name: Newspaper Rock Petroglyphs
description: The first emojis. 2,000 years of petroglyph carvings. Paved road. Pit toilet. Hiking there too. Must see!

name: Beachfront RV Resort
description: Big RV resort on the beach. There’s a restaurant and bar here as well. Staff is really nice and the park comes with WiFi. Paid $80/night

name: Cracker Barrel
description: Your typical overnight Cracker Barrel parking.

name: Chevron
description: 4.10 per gallon on 5/1/2021.  Chevron gas station with propane refill

name: Huntsville Public Pool
description: WiFi is public without needing to sign in or provide email. Is fast from the parking lot which is empty on weekdays.

name: Granbury Public Parking w/ electricity
description: Free public lot. Overflow for beach parking. Has 12v outlets that you can use.

name: Lamplight Lane RV Resort at Glen Oaks
description: Small campground off the highway. The campground hosts are incredibly friendly and had no problem with us arriving late in the evening after 9pm.  There’s plenty of highway noise but it’s an okay spot to stop while traveling through the area.  $35/night

name: RV repair shop with propane
description: Had a hard time finding propane in the area. Found this place just off the highway. It’s was $2.99 a gallon as of 4/2021

name: Walmart
description:
Nice quite night I parked by the canal on the east side of Walmart. There is also a dollar store, subway, and Chinese restaurant. 
If you need to kill a few hours I highly recommend cypress park. Beautiful hike in the park (picture)as well as a skatepark. There is also a electric outlet at the park next to the tennis court if you need to charge anything.

name: Dump station with water
description: Right as you pull in the park to your left across from the ranger station. Free if you’re staying at the park $5 if not. I was not charged to get in the park and didn’t see anyone to pay the $5 dump fee.

name: Walmart
description: Super quite night. And good WiFi. Would stay here again

name: Mango car wash
description:
South padre island has a boil water order so I found this car wash on the mainland that had a hose I was able to fill up with. It was $2 but that’s better than getting sick from bad water!

Ask the attendant how to do just water because it’s not simple (photo attached)

name: Lassen National Forest spot
description: Such an amazing spot! we were looking for the other location near here but ended up finding our own spot right on the ridge overlooking Mt. Lassen! Great cell service for Verizon and Sprint too! the dirt road here was really nice, maybe not driveable in rain, but our low clearance Honda Civic made it without any issues easily! Caution!! if you bring a big rig up here there are limited places to turn around, I'd recommend a spot closer to the main road instead maybe (not sure though i have never driven a big rig)

name: Shasta View in the Trees
description: Nice spot! in a strip of trees surrounded by desert, plenty of space for several rigs!

name: My mechanic
description: This is a great place to get stuff done. I had to wait a few days to get my electrical issues sorted but there’s great camping nearby. The guys are very personable and knowledgeable and they relate well to RV folks. I highly recommend them. They  even offered to let me park in back if the work had to take overnight. They even have a loaner vehicle for you to use

name: Easy camping alongside Hwy 20 and Malheur River
description:
The listed coordinates will take you to the turnoff from Hwy 20 and onto an unmaintained road. No terrain or clearance issues here. About 800m down the road it'll open up into a wide area with enough room for multiple vehicles. This is also the only space wide enough for longer rigs or rigs with trailers to turn around. The road does continue another 800m and connects back to Hwy 20 but this western side of the road is rougher and the intersection on a blind corner. 
If you miss the turn just continue a bit farther down the road and make a u-turn using the gravel pull offs. 
Some rockfall here so consider parking away from the cliff face if possible. Cactus so watch your step, your pets and bikes. No cell service here (or for about 10 miles in either direction). 

Looks like this is primarily used as a gravel storage area for road crews. Stayed one night without issue.

name: Cracker Barrel
description: Standard Cracker Barrel just off freeway behind Arco Gas Station. 4 parking spaces for RVs and many more for other vehicles. Food is standard corporate Cracker Barrel. Beats a rest area or truck stop.

name: Fort Meade Rec Area, Alkali Creek Trailhead
description:
Camping at a trailhead, also sites just down the road at the horse camp. Overnight parking allowed, you might still have to pay in the summer as there is a host. 

$8 a night May 15 thru September 30, otherwise free. 

Closed for 3 weeks in late July & early Aug due to Sturgis Motorcycle Rally

14 day max, then gone for 3.

name: BLM land near Craters of the Moon #2
description: Flat area on BLM land alongside Blizzard Mountain Road which is well maintained gravel road with no vehicle size/clearance issues. An alternative to site #1 and #3 which are listed in separate entries on iOverlander.

name: Honey Lake Campground bulk propane
description:
$2.99/gal for propane 
there's also a dump you can use if you aren't staying the night it's $10

name: Honey Lake Campground dump and water
description:
$10 to use their dump.  They had us fill our fresh water tank at one of the hookup sites.  Friendly people!
There's also bulk propane here.

name: Bogard Dispersed
description:
Open clearing off of the road, large enough for several vehicles.  Relatively flat. Very quiet, didn't see anybody else at all. You can hear road noise from the freeway as well as train noise. 

Lots of logging activity in this area, it's possible this space is a logging staging area.

Zero cell service for any of the 3 major carriers.

name: KOA dump
description:
Dump is $20 if you aren't staying at the park. 
As has been our experience with all KOAs we stop to dump at, the staff is very very friendly.

name: $7 dump and water at Chevron
description:
Self pay with credit card, includes dump and water. water has green handle on spigot, so we filled our tanks with it. 

There's also bulk propane here at $2.29/gal

name: Schroeder County Park Campground
description:
Decent place if you need a place to stay close to town. Non hookup / tent sites are $20/night, partial hookup is $25 and FHU is $30.  Self payment, cash only, no reservations. 
Some people seem to be long term residents and some look a little rough but we felt safe here for the 2 nights we stayed here. Hosts make regular rounds through the park. 

Right on the river and dog park and kid park are adjacent. Free hot showers!

name: Cantrall Buckley County Park
description:
$22/night. Flush toilets and free showers. We stayed here on a Friday night in late April and most sites were open and the place was very quiet. Minimal road noise. 
Water spigots and trash bins in park. 

Larger rigs should be wary. We had trouble navigating our 26ft class c. The campground loop is narrow with potholes and so many trees. 

Nice place. Hosts on site. Our neighbor looked homeless, but that seems to be the case with all the campgrounds we've stayed at in this area.

name: Kaibab National Forest FR682
description: Dispersed camping in the National Forest. Quiet, flat, easy to access. Jackrabbits abound. Few coyote calls at night. Pretty close to East entrance of Grand Canyon NP.

name: W Vermilion Cliffs NM Lone Tree House Rock Rd BLM North AZ
description: Multiple sites along rough single lane road. High clearance required, 4x4 AWD very helpful. Turn into this site okay for 18ft TT, choose another site for longer, just before this one. Fine sand and huge junipers. Very quiet and private. Designated sites only. Intermittent frustrating Verizon. Free. There are other easier sites along House Rock Rd.

name: Vermilion Cliffs National Monument House Rock Road 5 Mile mountain Road South Utah
description:
This is a parking lot at five Mile mountain Road number 710 adjacent to House Rock Road number 700. Nothing unusual just a parking lot. Quiet at night and traffic to the popular slot canyons nearby during the day. House Rock Road in the area is bumpy rough and we had to take it slow with our 18 ft trailer.
Three bars of Verizon. Free.

name: Dukes Slickrock Campground and RV Park Hanksville UT
description: Very nice newer RV Park that has a dump station for which we paid $5. very clean and friendly and inexpensive.

name: Mule Canyon US95 west of Blanding Utah
description: Just off the road open spot free. 3 bars of slow Verizon. Some traffic noise but quiet at night. Sandy, no bugs. Good enough for an overnight. Near entrance to Mule Canyon.

name: Blanding Utah Recapture Reservoir
description:
Going north out of Blanding, the second road to the left just past the reservoir. Open, reasonably flat, some fire rings, next to water. Unreliable Verizon. It's okay, nice to have water nearby. There is some traffic noise but quiet at night. Across the reservoir are several big rigs. On this side, big rigs may have trouble. The access road is the old highway and is higher than the surrounding. Free. We saw one picnic table and one portable toilet. 

A short swimming distance from the north shore there's a rock that's fun to climb on to and jump off into the water 😀

name: Rest Area alongside Hwy 395
description: A highway rest area alongside Hwy 395. No amenities other than a vault toilet and a covered picnic area. Did not see any signs discouraging overnight parking.

name: Walmart Supercenter
description: Huge parking area. Stayed to to back along with others.

name: I-8 W. Rest Area, MM-108
description: Sanitary dump and water. Not positive if it is potable. Not many long spaces for RV’s. Suggest arriving early.

name: Little big econ barr street trailhead
description: huge parking lot for the backpacking trail. website says they allow overnight parking and we did not get bothered staying here for a night in a suv. close to a road but near the back of the lot was quiet.

name: BLM near City of Rocks #2
description: Another option just south of Aldo. This one is close to the main road but the traffic is very light. Mostly level.  Good for longer vehicles or trailers. Good cell service.

name: Potable water spigot at Visitor Center
description: Water spigot at entrance to NPS City of Rocks Visitor Center. Bring your own hose.

name: Heisler Park
description: Car parking spots by the street at Heisler Park right in front of Laguna Beach with a great view of the sea. No “no overnight” signs. The place is in a residential street area and there is a parking meter that needs to be paid for between 8am - 7pm (we left before 8am) There is a public toilet next to it. Two other campervans stayed at the same place for overnight and no one bothered us. Very silent place with only a few joggers in the morning. This place is ideal for stealth builds as it is a residential area. Good for one night.

name: Free Camping: Bald Eagle SF Site #2
description: Free camping with permit. 1 mile from I 80. Able to request permit via phone or email during business hours.  Two picnic tables and a fire ring. https://www.dcnr.pa.gov/StateForests/FindAForest/BaldEagle/Pages/Camping.aspx

name: Between Great Sand Dunes & Alamosa
description: Tons of boondocking spots off of 150, flat at first and better for big rigs before the road gets a bit rougher. We have a 2WD high clearance van and we continued up the slope a ways until we found a level spot. Fire rings, occasional vegetation (for privacy) on the mountainside. Relatively crowded on a Monday night in early May but there were plenty of spots and additional roads veering off. Nice place for an overnight en route to southern CO destinations!

name: Snake River pull off
description:
Pull out on the side of the road, first area we had LTE with Verizon. There are a few established free campsites nearby but they were full at 5pm on a Friday. 

There are several formal sites with tables and fire puts, and several pull outs with no signs.  There are pit toilets at various pull outs, definetly one at the nearby boat launch. 

The train tracks are right here so there may be some noise.

name: Flagstaff Mobile Mechanic
description: Quality mechanic open 7 days a week. Doesn’t work on traditional RV’s but was able to help with my converted 2005 sprinter. Owns a towing business too. Ask for Mike. 2109 E 6th Ave

name: Sheps Canyon State Recreation Area
description:
About primitive 15 campsites with fire rings. Many sites have direct beach access to their own little private beach. Signs displaying to camp at fire rings only. Big rig friendly. Super quiet.

Park Size: 22 campsites, 11 horse campsites.

There is electric hookups at the official campground at the entrance. If you make a right and drive 2.6miles, you will see all the primitive camping. There is a horse camp at the end of the road. Full Verizon and four AT&T bars.

name: Ernst Tinaja
description: A Big Bend NP Backcountry Campsite on a beautiful spot overlooking Chisos Mountains. Reservations through recreation.gov required. $8 with the “Geezer Pass”.  No cell service but near a nice hike up to the Ernst Tinaja feature (1 mile round trip).

name: Big Bend NP - Paint Gap #4
description: A remote campsite despite being relatively close to the main road. Campsites 1 through 3 are easy to get to with any rig. However, campsite #4 which is about 1/2 to 3/4 of a mile past #3 will require a high clearance preferably 4x4 vehicle to get to. You will be rewarded with privacy as this is the end of the road and a fantastic view through the Paint Gap. Like all back country campsites in Big Bend a permit is required. 2 bars with Verizon!

name: BBRSP - Vista Del Bofecillos
description: A nice back country campsite with views for miles. There is a nice breeze which helps with the temps. The site is large with plenty of space on the top of a Mesa for multiple vehicles or tents but will require high clearance 4x4 to get here. 1 bar with Verizon and a permit is required which has to be picked up the day of your stay at the Fort Leaton SHS (or maybe at Sauceda Visitor Center)about 20 miles to the West.

name: Deer head CG - Lincoln NF
description: A nice little NF campground right off Hwy 130. We were going to boondock further down but it has snowed over 6 inches and is still coming down and we didn’t want the risk of getting stuck even in our 4x4! $25/12.50 depending on if you have a pass or not. Good Verizon service.

name: Burnt Cane Lake State Fishing Access
description:
This is a free place to camp with a 14 day limit that is a sloped gravel area next to the lake. There was no one here and according to the book Free and Low Cost Camping the site is free to use. Limited Verizon signal. Access is by a gravel road (about 2.2. miles) that was a bit soft due to all the recent rain but did not required 4x4. A larger rig might have trouble turning around here...
We were also visited a few times by locals who were surprised to see us there but there wasn’t any issues.

name: Twin Lakes Campground
description: Beautiful campground right next to the lake. Drove through some farmland in Woonsocket for quite a few miles but it was well worth it. Very quiet. A few people fishing at the lake in the evening but I was the only one camping there overnight. Really buggy so bug screens would help. There are about 5-6 campsites here, each with charcoal fire pits. Clean pit toilet as well.

name: Walmart
description: Worst Walmart parking lot I’ve ever slept in. Traffic noise is incredibly loud with cars revving their engines all night into the early morning. I’ve never heard so many car engines this loud in my life. A few trains went by at night, and several car alarms went off in the morning. Earplugs didn’t help much. Do yourself a favor and try the other Walmart down the street.

name: Anza-Borrego Desert State Park - Yaqui Pass
description: This is a large compacted dirt lot advertised as primitive camping within the park (although there are no signs located here indicating so). There are lots of other areas throughout the park to camp, but it is indicated on the map. I got confirmation from staff at the Visitor's Center as I needed someplace more accessible (I have a 2WD campervan; most other areas in the park need 4WD due to the sand.) No amenities. It's mostly a trailhead for hiking; we saw about a dozen people total Wednesday & Thursday in late February.

name: Walmart
description: Walmart parking lot. Confirmed ability to stay with staff. Store hours 7am - 10pm.

name: Kwaaymii Point
description: Cul-de-sac at the end of the road, flat, solid for overnighting. Beautiful views.

name: Arcata Marsh
description: Overnight parking available in the lot just outside the yellow gate of the marsh, suitable for cars and small rigs only. No facilities, but you can fall asleep to frogs and wake up to birds! People arrive early to use the marsh. Be respectful to the locals and leave no trace!

name: Amphitheater state park
description: Water near parking in front of the amphitheater

name: Shell New River
description: Spigots on the end of the diesel islands.  It is well water  and they use it for all their fountain drinks etc.  Tastes fine (I disagree).  Also propane, a water jug filler (paid) and mini mart.

name: Las Cienegas National Conservation Area
description: Wild camping among rolling hills, far enough to not hear road noise.  Many spots along main road in, as well as spots to the right after cattle corrals.  No cell service.  We saw cows hawks bunnies, and pronghorn.

name: Long Pond
description: 8 camping spots. fire ring at each site. port-a-potty next to site 7. Verizon service is sketchy seems to get best at site #7

name: Desert Sands RV
description: Large RV park. usual animities. pool, shower, laundry, exercise room. pull thu's. Clean friendly.They allow Mobile Rv mechanics and washes. Close to everything. 50/30 amp. Good water pressure. No parkside wifi. Pets ok. Dog walk I haven't used. wouldn't let me change star rating but I'd give it a 4-star rating.

name: Coastal Trail Parking Lot
description: A big flat open lot used for parking for coastal trail users. Good for a one night stopover.

name: Side road off highway
description: This is just a little side road right off the highway but it was surprisingly quite at night. One bar of t-mobile and 4 bars of Verizon. We had to pick up some trash after some other people but for the most part it’s pristine. Good place to let the dog out to do a little running around too.

name: Murdoch’s
description: Propane refill at Murdochs just under the big Murdoch’s sign along the road.

name: South Fork Reservoir - South Shore Campground
description:
Camping is open all year.  Individual campsites are on a first-come, first-served basis. Group campsites can be reserved for use by contacting the park.
Camping:  $15.00 per vehicle, per night (Non-NV Vehicles: $20.00 per vehicle, per night) + $10.00 for sites with utility hook ups

Each site has a BBQ, picnic table, and fire pit.  

Pit toilets were clean.  The trail that heads north from the campground has tons of bird life.

name: Lowe’s
description: This is a quite location even though it’s on a Main Street with traffic. Park away from building. Oversized trucks welcome. We parked right b4 close and left late in the morning and no one bothered us. Great spot

name: Walmart
description: Overnight parking allowed. Park in the parking lot east of the building closest to Unser Blvd between Walgreens and Wendy's. Don't block any traffic flow. Call for permission (505) 962-9227.

name: Adder Pond
description: A few minutes off I70, plenty of spaces along the dirt road to crash for an evening. Down a bit from where this spot is, you can pull up by the pond and spend the night.

name: Middle Spunk Rest Area
description: One of the quieter rest areas I’ve stayed at. Middle spunk lake borders the parking lot.

name: Wild West
description: Quiet location on the other side of west river road. Plenty of space for multiple vehicles, had it to myself. Beautiful views surrounding, windy af though during the early morning hours. Limited T-Mobile cell service.

name: Pelican Fish Access
description: Many camp spots along the Yellowstone river.  Limited official spots but plenty of areas to park a van as you continue through the campground along the river.  Picnic tables, fire pits and a pit toilet available.  Says 7 days max camping. Freight train can be loud passing though.

name: Harpers Lake
description: Fish and Wildlife campground. Stayed for a week, quiet midweek but filled up during the week. 7 night stay max. Pit toilet and a few spots along the river. Plenty of spots to fish if that's your thing. Cheaper if you're an in state resident.

name: Trinity River BLM
description: Fantastic spot in the woods next to the Trinity River. Someone was occupying the other spot near here marked on iOverlander and so we came here! This is just one spot alongside 3 or 4 others that can be reached by a short, steep road (not marked on google maps) on the right side of E Forks Rd. Our e250 van made it down fine, no 4wd necessary, but I would recommend high clearance because there is one pretty big drop off in the short, unmarked road as it switches from pavement to gravel. You’re right next to the river and there’s a deep pool here for swimming. No cell service or amenities. Established fire rings. Not appropriate for RVs or big rigs.

name: All German Motorworks
description: Amazing mechanics if you’re in a sprinter. They replaced our serpentine belt in a day and had us back on the road in no time. Gary is the owner. He’s great.

name: Cracker Barrell
description: Cracker Barrel has RV/bus/truck parking in the back and overnight is okay. Some highway noise because it's right next to the exit.

name: Love’s Travel Center
description:
This location has been listed as an overnight parking spot already. But it also has fuel and 3 restaurants. Subway, Chesters chicken, and Godfathers pizza 
Also 3 grades of gasoline and diesel

name: Pilot Travel Center
description: Huge parking lot for trucks. Gas and diesel. Market with showers. Pilot travel center with simple restaurants

name: Upper cougar fire rd
description:
This gravel turnout is off a paved road that goes another 3 miles to a snopark
Just pass the train bridge on the right. Can hear the highway off in the distance. Might be a loud train. We’ll see. But there is a rest stop about 3 miles north on the hwy that is gorgeous! This is more tranquilo

name: Quaker Steak and Lube
description: Large lower parking lot- shared between Quaker and TGIFridays. We ate at Quaker and asked if we could stay one night in the lower parking lot, and we're told it was okay. No amenities besides restaurant use. Please ask first. Very loud next to busy street. Good for one night. Also Walmart and Crackerbarrel nearby.

name: Tishomingo Wildlife Area
description:
Nice, quiet camping spot south of Tishomingo, Oklahoma. It's a wildlife conservation area, but hunting and fishing are allowed, as well as camping. No running water or restrooms (except near entrance) so it's best as a boondocking area!!

Camping is allowed year-round at the Headquarters Camping Area and the wildlife management unit. The Headquarters Camping Area has one accessible site and six additional sites. Seven designated
primitive campsites are available at the wildlife management unit: 1) McAdams River Access; 2)McAdams Pond; 3) Clifton River Access; 4) Reeves Ravine Pond (West); 5) Reeves Ravine Pond (East); 6) Rattlesnake River Access; and 7) Lost Lake. Camping is limited to seven nights per visit.

name: Walker River Recreation Area
description: There are two campgrounds here that are operated just like state park campgrounds. One has electricity the other campground is primitive. Both campgrounds have flush toilets and showers. Both campgrounds are next to the River. There is a dump and freshwater. There are hiking and biking trails along the River. Both Verizon and AT&T worked well here. Nice place to stay.

name: Owyhee River Site
description: This site is a camping spot right by the river. It is accessible by most rigs, you just have to go slow on a bumpy road coming in. This is a Boondocking site. When we were there four beavers were making their Beaver Lodge right across the river so we could watch them. You are next to the road that leads to the reservoir so you hear some traffic during the day but it dies down to nothing at night. There is no cell service for Verizon or AT&T at the spot. This is nice place and we would return.

name: Succor State Natural Area
description: There are a set of primitive campsites about 15 miles down a gravel road if you come from the north. They are in a nice canyon with beautiful cliffs and good hiking and mountain biking from the campsite. There’s a creek running through the camp. This is a free campground with tables and pit toilets and fire rings. There is no cell service and no trash and no dump and no water. This is a really pretty place and worth the drive down the bumpy gravel road. There are trailers 25 feet long down here a very large fifth wheel might find some of this space tight.

name: Glenwood OHV Staging Area
description: Primitive camping on BLM lands. 14 day limit with no fee. Small motocross track nearby. Nice open area for overnight RV camping for units of any size.

name: Giant Gap
description:
Established Camping at Sugarpine Resivoir in Tahoe National Forest, all sites have tables, fire pits, and flat spots for ground tent. Sites can fit 2 cars or medium sized RV.

We visit this resivoir a few times a year, water levels have dropped significantly. 

$24 a night, has vault toilets no showers or hook-ups

name: Goehner rest area NE
description:
Clean, decent rest area. 10-hour limit. 
Configuration is a little odd, RVs and trucks go round back. Three vending machines. grounds aren't really that well

name: Booneville Rest Area eastbound
description: Small, clean, rest area. overnighting is not a problem. The truck /trailer /RV section is very close to the interstate so quite noisy. Verizon signal was very good. No issues here

name: Springwater free flowing  on Tony's Road very dear intersection with Warburton Road.
description:
Spring Water free flowing from hose.
Many people fill containers for home use. 
Country road pull off room for one vehicle.  

On Tony's Road very dear intersection with Warburton Road.

name: Glacier water refill
description: Glacier water refill station in front of Vons. Paid 40 cents per gallon.

name: Speedway
description: Speedway with propane filling  for RV. On the back of the building

name: Lynchburg Lowes
description: We stayed in the Lowes of Lynchburg,it was well lit and it closes at 8 pm so the lot was pretty empty. You have to check in with the store manager before they close to tell them you are staying there. The lady that was working when we arrived said she just wanted to make sure we were parked in a safe spot. you can use the bathrooms in lowes while it's open and there is a waffles house in the same parking lot area. Our rig is 28 ft plus a small travel tote on the back but they could accommodate larger rigs if needed.

name: Marathon Laundry
description: Small laundromat. 3 washers and 3 dryers, one washer was out of order when I went. $2 per wash, $2 per dry. quarters only and no change machine on site. closes at 5:30 pm

name: Fort melon park
description: Majority of Lake Monroe has parking spots along the river. Find your place with more or less traffic. They do food trucks on Saturdays every couple weeks just a couple blocks over. Around 2-3 bars on Verizon without we boost

name: North Beach Community Park
description: Sweet little parking spot with bathroom, outside shower and beach. Pay here sign for parking... Some people keep these secret... Trail head here as well.

name: Black Canyon BLM Camping Lot
description: Huge BLM lot, 2WD accessible, some Verizon service, no one here.

name: Flying J’s
description:
Moderator Note: there are mixed messages about whether or not this place is available for overnight parking. Please report your experience.
.....
Typical Flying J’s, with a Denny’s attached. Some great, large RV spots in the parking lot for sleeping in. Stayed here one night and it was surprisingly quiet. 5 stars

name: U Save Truck Stop and Gas Station
description: Free dump if you fill up with gas. Dump station is close to the road in front of the store. Sign says “buy 30 gallons of gas for free dump”. I only filled up 15 gallons of gas and they didn’t charge me so just ask.

name: Walmart Monroe
description: Big parking of Walmart , good for one night.

name: Sierra Forest Site 6S15
description:
Fairly flat spot by the side of the Fire Service Rd, if you are camping in your vehicle/camper. Some little rocks to one side. Enough space for a 24ft rig. Turn around may be tricky, unless you can go straight downhill and exit at the other end of the Fire Service Rd. (Haven't scouted this part)
Slightly uneven/bumpy for camping in tent, unless you move further along the same spot onto the grassy patch.
Quiet spot. No shade during morning-early afternoon hours.
ATT LTE 1-3bars. LTE Internet is fair to slow depending on your phone orientation.

name: Cedars Camp
description: Semi-flat spot with some trees for shade/windbreak and a view of coyote buttes south. YOU WILL NEED 4wd! Don’t try to cross the little wash without it - it’s too sandy coming back out.

name: BLM Visitor Center
description: This is where you can get the FREE permit you need for overnight camping in the Grand Staircase Escalante National Monument. They also have road conditions, clean bathroom, a dumpster, and some cool dinosaur displays. Very nice and knowledgeable staff.

name: Poets seat parking lot
description: Parking for Poets Seat tower and other trails. Police drove by, didn’t seem to care that our hatch tent was up. Nice view of River through trees. Very busy on Saturday morning.

name: River Works park
description: Just a quaint park for sleeping in your car/van. The whole greenfield/montage/turners falls area was lovely and very friendly

name: Walmart
description: Stayed in the back lot next to the gas station where all the truckers were with no problems. I asked inside and they said they assumed it would be fine because all the truckers park there.

name: Riley Park (Wifi)
description: A really nice park with free wifi from the town. The park has a stream, playground, skate park, etc. I believe this park closes at sunset, but you could probably still get the wifi around town. The wifi was fast enough for me to stream a show which was awesome.

name: rest stop on I-65
description: Safe, parklike rest station, farther from highway, lots of parking spots for large rigs, many vans staying here. 24-hr security, very clean bathrooms. Good spot to rest for the night.

name: Trellis camp
description: First dirt road left going southeast past the bridge on 47. Take a left at the T. People fish here occasionally in the summer. Only good for an overnight. Amazing views, sunrise/sunset, fishing, osprey nest currently atop NE power pole. Pick up your trash. Ok for all cars but some potholes that are avoidable. No trailers. Ideal for vanlife. No fire ring but could make one. Highway noise at daytime. Go to hoggie doggies! PICK UP TRASH TYVM.

name: Onion valley campground
description: Super chill area, 6 or so spots. Doesn’t seem to get much use. Has a lil payment station but doesn’t say how much it costs. Pit toilet centrally located, fire rings & picnic tables at spots. Nice meadow and river/ creek nearby. Peaceful & quiet. Never saw anyone else here in May, might get busy in summer? The forest road in is paved but bumpy, dirt road into campground is a bit rocky but short & doable in any sort of car. 1 bar of lte T-Mobile but doesn’t work very well. You pass the Larger north fork campground right before onion valley at the creek but I’ve never seen that one open. Many other forest service roads branch off from here that probably have dispersed camping sites worth exploring. Enjoy!

name: Ashland Creekside bulk propane
description: $3.50/gal propane fill at this campground. Friendly staff.

name: Forest clearing/ dispersed camping site
description: Paved but bumpy road to get in, nice lil clearing big enough for 2/3 vechicles. No dispersed camping after this spot as you go into the north fork area (except at est sites like onion valley) I recommend checking out onion valley if you have the time. 2 bars T-Mobile lte & Verizon both work pretty well

name: Ashland Creekside dump
description: $15 to dump for non guests. Guests staying in non hookup sites pay $10.

name: Fort Stanton - Snowy River Cave National Conservation Area
description:
Awesome little spot in the conservation area. Just keep straight on the gravel road for a while, I made it to my spot in a low clearance Mazda so I think any car would make it. One tight uphill curve but other than that it could suit a big rig. I only saw one truck go by, it was dead quiet at night minus some wild dogs howling at the full moon. 
Trails all around if you want to do some backpacking
Stone fire pit & 2 bars T-Mobile LTE

Sorry I didn’t take a lot of pictures of the actual site

name: Pull Off Beside Road
description: This is a good size pull off area right beside the highway. It appears to be used by the department of transportation during the day but has reasonable amount of space for overnight stop. There was a really good AT&T service and marginal Verizon service and a nice view of the valley to the south. It could accommodate larger wigs because the parking lot is pretty big. There was limited traffic at night so it was not very noisy.

name: Parking lot in the center of Blowing Rock
description: this is a great place to park, it is a parking lot behind main Street on Maple Street. behind the First Citizens Bank. We were able to park here with no problem for the entire afternoon and it was a very quiet place to sleep. Full phone service for AT&

name: Rest stop on I 81east exit 107
description:
A typical off-the-freeway rest stop. bathrooms are clean. A decent area to walk pets, as well as picnic tables.

Great service for AT&T, not so great for Verizon

name: Centre RV
description: Small, locally owned RV mechanic.  Paul and Dave do great work at a reasonable price.  Cash or check only, NO CREDIT CARDS.

name: Kaibob national forest summit 89A
description: easy access to a few spots large enough for rvs.

name: Border Taco
description: Authentic Mexican food, completely homemade.  Delicious and affordable.  Located behind Carl's Jr.

name: 360’ view
description: Camped here thinking we were close to Dinosaur Nat Mon. Long climb thru the park & out the other end. No Dinos! Remote & quiet with 360’ views. Cold in May. Fire ring. Camped her the night en route yo Dinosaur Nat Monument. NOTE!!! : there no Dino fossils on Colorado side, they are all on Utah side just outside Jensen!! 3 bars 4G

name: Dinosaur National Monument
description: This is the visitors centre. $25/vehicle to enter if you don’t have an Annual Park Pass.  All the fossils are up at the Quarry Exhibit. Great for kids, ask for junior park ranger workbook & badge. Go early & avoid crowds.

name: Spring Lake ND fish and wildlife
description: Plenty of flat ground to park small RV  dirt road leading in is very smooth  Small lake with lots of waterfowl

name: Sunstone Collection Area BLM
description:
20+ miles of gravel roads to access.

Remote camping allowed as part of the BLM Sunstone Collection Area.  3 or 4 established sites at the entrance that have fire pit and metal sun shelters.  

Lots of dispersed locations on the extensive two track road system.  Roads past the entrance parking lot are generally not suitable for passenger cars.

The big draw is the numerous sunstones which are found on the surface.  Small, perhaps smaller than a dime an be found.

Long distance views, exceptionally quiet unless military jets are training in the area.

No water, poor cell service 

Private mining claims border a portion of the area.  Signs are posted to project private props.

name: Chevron bulk propane
description:
$2.49/gal. Easy access but small lot.
Will fill onboard rv propane tank as well.

name: Pigeon mountain wma
description: Free with hunting/fishing license. Two camp sights with fire rings and a picknick table. It is beautiful here with lots to see, including waterfalls, caves, mountain views, old ruins, and more

name: Wma campground
description: Free to camp with a hunting/fishing license. A single stone fire ring in a grassy area. Right next to a waterfall, you can hear the water from the fire ring.

name: Poole knobs campground
description: $20 per night for a campsite. There are around 90 campsites so getting booked wasn’t hard. You can check in at the front desk or reserve online on the Recreation.gov app. Clean campsites with several shower houses. There is a nice fire pit, a grill, a d a picnic table. Also trees for hammocks. The people at the front desk had a little trouble finding our reservation but they were very nice and eventually found it. The campsites are clearly labeled and not too hard to find.

name: Calistoga Public Parking w/ Restrooms
description: Free public parking in downtown Calistoga near creek. No “No Overnight Parking” signs. Stayed one night, very quiet, no nocks. Parking lot also has free public restrooms.

name: Canal Street Parking
description: Just a side street for an overnight stay that is shaded on one side. It is next to the La Quinta Hotel and Denny's Resturant. Parked behind some semi-truck containers for the night and we're gone in the morning

name: bulldog canyon ohv area west gate
description: this is a large dirt parking lot on national forest land. I did not get the permit and gate code to go inside the trails (roads) but I saw others do so. there is 14 day camping allowed inside for sure inside the gate. there are not any no camping or no overnight parking signs at the lot. lots of mt bikers here everyone morning and evening. slept in the car no problems. not a super flat parking lot but there are  flat enough spots. also all along the main road around here there are pulloffs where people park to bike if all you want is a place to sleep and are not concerned with "camping".

name: Ely Buyck Spur 1025
description: A very private, remote, free place to camp.  Not recommended for vehicles larger than a full-sized pickup.  Any vehicle you drive here will get pinstripes from the bushes along the track.  Plenty of free firewood from past logging operations.

name: Superior National Forest Spur 313S
description: A very secluded site located at the end of a short forest road spur.  Not recommended for vehicles larger than a full-sized pickup, and you will want good ground clearance if you attempt to drive down this spur.  The site itself is on naturally exposed bedrock so it may be difficult if you need to drive tent stakes.  Ideal for truck or rooftop tent camping.  Plenty of firewood can be found in nearby deadfalls.

name: End of Kestrel Forest Road
description: Large open space at the end of a rarely used forest road.  Accessible to most vehicles, but I would be cautious to bring anything larger than a Class A RV to this location.  Plenty of nearby deadfall for firewood.  Be careful and wear blaze orange during hunting season.

name: Pine Island SF Abandoned Landing Strip
description: This is a wide open area a few hundred meters north of Pine Island Road at the end of an abandoned air strip.  Lots of deadfall around for free firewood.  The access road can be muddy if it's been raining, so use your own judgement if you attempt to drive to this site.

name: Clearings in Beltrami Island SF
description: This is a line of three clearings located in an area that was logged and reforested several years ago.  These GPS coordinates are in the middle of the three clearings, though I personally used the most northern one for my overnight stay.  This site is very private and quiet; the only human-made sounds I heard other than my own were four airplanes that passed 30K feet overhead.  Plenty of deadfall and scrap left over from logging to use as free firewood.  Site can be muddy if it rains or dusty after a week of no rain.  Access is quite easy, though I personally would not bring anything larger than a Class A motorhome here.

name: Pickerel Lake Beach
description: This is a public beach on Pickerel Lake.  You will want high ground clearance and 4wd to drive the 0.25 mile access road to reach this point.  I was here on a weekday and did not see any other people, but there are plenty of ATV tracks which may mean the area could be popular on weekends.  There are several non-level pull-in spots in the trees available for your rig if you don't mind being at a slant.  Otherwise, the beach itself is pretty level.  There may be deadfall to be found in the woods, but I recommend bringing your own (DNR approved) firewood.  I will log this location as not having WiFi, though I did have 2 bars of Verizon 4G at this location.

name: Lady Slipper Park Artesian Well
description: This is a constantly flowing, free artesian well head. Bring your empties and fill up as much as you want. The water is excellent.

name: Fredrick-Miller Spring
description: A very popular spring with unlimited free water. Be careful when exiting this site onto the main road; limited sightlines and high-speed traffic.

name: Propane refill
description: Propane refill for $3.40. They also have showers. Probably can find a water spigot too but I didn’t need water so I didn’t look around.

name: Strand Vista Park
description:
Public parking lot open 5am-10pm. No fee. View of ocean. Staircases down to beach from parking lot. Many, many stairs but lovely swath of beach. No dogs allowed on beaches.
Public restrooms open until late and there is are open beach showers.
Park on Selva Rd directly in front of park for overnight. Quiet at night but lots of cars in the a.m.

name: Roadside Red Hill Rec Area
description: A roadside pull out on Red Hill Road. Nice crest of hill and lovely secluded road section. Room for 2 vans head to head in pullout. Some road noise from few passing cars. Very quiet at night. Grass area next to vans, hills around, and some trails. Unspoiled. Keep clean please.

name: Saul’s Creek end of road (winter)
description:
We intended to stay at a Saul’s creek location further down this road. But from Oct-April 30th the road is closed about 1 mile earlier. We ended up staying at the road closure barrier which has a large parking area, large enough for multiple vans and cars. We enjoyed our stay, there are grassy woods surrounding and good hiking trails from here. It is also a day use parking area for locals doing biking and horse riding so we got to chat with some hikers about the trails. 
At night we were basically alone with one other car on orher side of parking area. 
A quiet location with 2 bars of ATT. This is a winter hunting location so there are hunting remains scattered in the brush which at first look very strange but we got used to it.

name: Lincoln Highway near Austin NV
description: Wide open site off of a well maintained dirt road.

name: Henry Coe State Park
description: In spring time this is a beautiful place to visit. Campsites are $20, there is water and very clean pit toilets. Very nice hiking trails start from the campground and wild flowers are abundant in spring. There are also many backpacking options.

name: Gila National Forest Reserve Ranger Station
description: Water spigot between the Ranger Station and the highway.  Easy access for any size rig.

name: Just Past Hamburger Rock
description: Decent sized and levelish site. Nice views. Easy access off road. The road is very good to this point. We are able to get usable ATT LTE using a very strategically placed Netgear antenna on a Nighthawk portable router.

name: Free parking Deep Ellum
description: This block of Trunk Ave has a dirt parking lot on either side. Free, no signs prohibiting overnight parking. Easily walk to all of Deep Ellum.

name: BLM land off of Hwy 395
description: Flat circle pullout off the dirt road. 2WD can access easily. We tent camped overnight. No others were here. Caught a little highway noise but it was generally quiet. Great sunrise and we would come here again.

name: Crossroads just before Tucki Mine
description: This is a great spot with an incredible view of the range and part of the valley. Accessible only by experienced high clearance 4x4. We tent camp and it was mostly flat with small rocks. Roof top tent campers would love this area, room for a couple of vehicles. There is a visitor log at the Tucki Mine ruins. Completely alone up here, perfection! Saw big horned sheep on the way out. Super cool.

name: Hunter Pass Camp Spot
description: This is a pine tree dense area with a flat dirt area for tent camping or RTT camping. Enough space for a few tents and 2-3 vehicles. At altitude so temps are much cooler than the basin. Sheltered from the wind better than most due to the trees. Road continued down to an unlocked gate which warned of mice with hantavirus. We continued down, but liked this spot better. Saw a buck deer in the morning just beside the campsite.

name: South of Ubehebe Crater
description: This is a rocky, slightly sloped site with a view of Ubehebe just off the dirt road that goes down to Teakettle Junction. Tent camping is doable, but probably more suited to RTT camping. Very quiet after the sun started to set, but lots of traffic during the day. Saw some bats here at night. Superb night skies.

name: Firelake Grand Casino
description: no longer free your 1st night, $50 per night  20 rv sites.  go in at the 2nd driveway.  rvs park right behind scores of semi parking, so can be a little noisy, but really not that bad.  water and electric (30/50amp) hookups, and dump station.  pull in and park in any free spot, then go in the casino/hotel and register, telling them which spot you're in.   no highway noise, just the trucks idling - white noise.  cheapest fuel, too.  restaurants are open: one for dine-in or takeout, the other for takeout.  sushi bar is closed right now.  wifi available inside the building, not at rv sites.

name: Lake Overholser
description: Beautiful lakeside parking. Parked here overnight, with other vehicles dispersed along the river as well, with people night fishing. Some cars passed by during the night but the speed limit is slow so it wasn’t bothersome. We didn’t see any signs for 'no parking'. Road is flat dirt road, easy driving. Clean. We have a RAV4 with rooftop tent. I’d imagine it is busier on weekends.

name: Juniper Canyon Fishing Access
description: Nice state managed campsite with 9 newly graveled and graded sites. $9 day pass plus $14 camping. With state annual parks pass you don’t pay the $9.  Roughish access road from the west (74). would recommend 4wd as road can be impassable when wet, and tough for big trailers. Access road 53 a couple miles further E from Maybell easy-peasy.  On 53 at top of grade there’s a large free spot before you descend to the river. Pit toilet, picnic tables and fire grills.

name: 76 Truck Stop
description: Need to spend $25 on gas and or other products to stay overnight.

name: Baseball Park
description:
Moderator Note: This Place may nit accept overnight stays. Please update the description with your experience.

Gates are locked at 7:30 PM. The night I stayed they just locked the gates. Not sure if they do bother to check or just did not check for vehicles that night.

name: Cowlitz Boat Launch
description: Cowlitz Boat Launch @ Trout Hatchery. Pick a spot in the grassy area on your right, or the smaller gravel area on the left. There are bathrooms, but we did not use them. There are also trash cans. The stay is limited to 3 days. The cell reception is minimal, limited to calls/text unless you have a booster, then you may be able to get online. This is a fairly busy launch site, but nothing terrible and it stayed very quiet all day and night. It's free!

name: Oil City Trailhead
description: Where the river meets the ocean! Beautiful easy trail, 3 miles total out and back.

name: Payne County Expo Center (fairgrounds)
description: This place was designed to serve equestrian events.  But when no events are happening, they have huge open spaces for vehicles to camp.  $15 per night at the office or in a drop box.  Electrical hookups, water, dump station and clean, heated bathrooms with HOT showers.  This is a gem for any size rig. Not sure about tents, but you can ask.  Just outside town for a quiet night and easy access.

name: Chisolm Trail RV
description: Mostly common RVs. Small shop selling parts. Had surprisingly odd things like special keys and bulbs as well as general valves and tubes and stuff.  Decent prices for the middle of nowhere.

name: Slabs from Athena project.
description: Large wide open area with concrete slabs.  Nothing else nearby. Can’t see highway from here.

name: Sudz Cyber Laundry
description: Laundry mat, really friendly service, clean and has free WiFi access, movies playing, complimentary tea and coffee and a bathroom. I popped in to do one load and they provide a card and charge you when done drying. I think they also offer fluff and fold services. In the downtown area so you can easily walk around to beach, stores, food, etc.. while you’re waiting. Free street parking (2hr limit).

name: Shoreside
description: Street parking along a coastal path. residential and some businesses in area. Busy during the day with car traffic and people on path, quiets down after 9 or 10. Was not bothered.

name: Residential street near condos
description: Quiet between 11 pm and 5 am, when folks occasionally start going to work. I slept in till 6:30 am. A few other cars were parked along the street within sight, including a passenger van. Not recommended for anything much larger.  Lompoc itself has a lot of through street avenues and speed racers. Next time I’ll try the hills.

name: Industrial cul de sac
description: Spent a decently quiet night here; though there is some highway noise, it mostly dies down after 10 pm. I’m a light sleeper and was able to fall asleep. No cars passed. 2 other cars were on this street. The other cul de sacs in this complex were too busy with night shift workers, so I chose this one. Saw 2 other RVs in the area, not on this street. Slept in till 6:50 am. At 7:10 am saw a lady walking her dog here as I was pulling out.

name: Chevron gas station
description: Asked the staff for water. There’s a spigot and red hose on the left side around the corner before walking in the store.

name: Rim Lake Rec area
description: “Lake”. two sites with fire rings. Pit toilet, very quiet. Hills help block some wind, easy accessible. Has a parking area.  Has a covered picnic area. Weak Sprint service (extended network).

name: Glacier water vending machine
description: Saw a Glacier water vending machine right outside the Family Dollar store. Didn’t get a chance to use it. Next refill is INSIDE Kanab’s Glazier’s market or Honey’s market.

name: McBride Dispersed Campground
description: Campground with fire rings, picnic tables, shade shelters and vault toilets. This spot has a few sites but the other sites are secluded from each other down a dirt road.

name: Grinder's Ferry Wild Camping
description: Great gravel bar next to Buffalo River. Camp with caution, as high water can rise quickly & sweep you away during rain storms!

name: Encinal Park
description: Right next to Encinal Park. Park has clean bathrooms open from sunrise to sunset. Free street parking, must move every 72hrs. Perfect if you work at any of the nearby tech companies (30s walk to LinkedIn, 3min walk to an Apple building, prob more nearby too).

name: Walmart
description: Very quiet parking lot in Walmart near the garden center at the back with strong WiFi.

name: Cemetery #2 water spigot
description:
Moderator Note: The User is not sure that the water is potable.
.....
Walking past the cemetery noticed a water spigot on Bienville St just inside the gate. Could reach it with a 25 ft hose when parked on the side of the street.  Wouldn't recommend it as potable

name: Pilot Travel Center
description: free wifi at the travel center. decent signal even outside.

name: Guilford Harbor, CT
description: Parking is mainly for boat owners but some is available for others.  Dock master said the police don’t bother people who overnight here and that was true for me. Kids do come and party though, once they leave it’s quiet

name: Ophir Campground
description:
Dry Camping. No water. No Electricity. 
creek nearby...
Quiet. (terrible cell service in the little canyon) but pretty...
old mining town...
cool little place for $15 a night.

name: Rex Reservoir
description: Off the beaten path and beautifully quiet.

name: Cracker Barrel
description:
Moderator Note: As per city ordinance, overnight parking is not permitted.
.....
Slept overnight, pretty noisy late/early morning due to traffic right next to it but no one bothered us

name: Off road
description:
Half a mile down FS roads off 395.  The exit is marked with a right turn lane and becomes a mess of roads.  This is passable by 2WD with some clearance—probably not for a Prius or other like vehicle.  Road is firm with a slight hump in the center.  Big occasional turnaround areas.
The site can take a couple of vehicles in the afternoon shade of trees with level parking.  A 50 foot walk up the hill provides tons of flat tent spaces.  There is a fire ring, but please use it thoughtfully and legally.
Sierras to the west and rocky/trees hills all around.  Sound of wind in the trees.  Cool after the heat of the desert.
4 bars of Verison, 1-2 bars ATT.

name: Love’s
description: Typical Loves station. 6 large RV spots, plus scattered parking around. Good for a nights rest.

name: Spin City Laundry
description: Laundromat in a small strip mall. Super clean, takes coin or credit cards. Also have change machines inside.

name: WMA on the lake
description: Closer spot off highway with nice view of lake

name: Outside Ely
description: Beautiful, large spot that fit our two overland vehicles and trailer/rooftop tent...

name: Patriot Gas
description: Place to refill your propane tank. You need to ask in the shop and then, they’ll give you the directions on how to do it. In our case, they asked us to go around the block and then a lady met us there to refill the tank.

name: Peoria Public parking
description: Really nice free parking lot by a museum and river walk. 2 hr parking limit during day and then after 5 pm you can park for however long.

name: El Camino Family Restaurant
description: This diner is open 24hrs. Variety of food styles, Tex-Mex, pizza, hamburgers, steaks, and of course breakfast foods. Several Socorro Police officers and Socorro County deputies were eating there late at night while we were there. One of the only places to get a good meal overnight in town.

name: Cosmic campground
description: Pull into Cosmic campground and keep going past the campgrounds. there are a bunch of trails with dispersed camping. Wild javelina, lizards and coyote. Best star gazing around as well.

name: Pine valley
description: beautiful valley near Cathy's peak. I'd recommend 4wd if there has been any rain but I made it with a 2wd Golf on a dry day. huge open valley.

name: Ponderosa Community Trailhead Parking
description: Tons of space, no signs preventing overnight parking.

name: Old Mill Cafe Parking
description:
Moderato Note: This Place may not always be available for overnight parking. Please check with the restaurant owner.
....
Parking for the old Mill Cafe restaurant, probably not intended for overnight parking but I stayed a night without issues. And breakfast was right in front of me when I woke up so win-win

name: Wyoming
description: ATV Road. Three could pull off within the 1st mile. Easy access. First two spots both have fire rings. Beautiful view of Valley and surrounding mountains. We ere the only ones here but it looks like parts of the year could be very heavy ATV travel. Four-wheel-drive suggested but not required. There is one spot as soon as you drive-in that is too close to the road for us but, would be ideal for a  large rig. We average 2 to 3 bars of Verizon service.

name: Forest Road 508
description: First right after the cattleguard is this Boondocking site with a cool trail behind it

name: Forest Road 508
description: Second right on fire Road 508. This one has a nice turn around and are firing. Relatively level. Verizon 2 LTE

name: Dirty Paws
description: Dirty Paws self dog wash and grooming .Clean and well stocked with supplies to clean up my two furry travel companions. Staff was accommodating and friendly.

name: Goodland Walmart
description: Called ahead and they said overnight parking was fine and said It would be best to park on the Lawn and Garden side and I would have to agree. There were many Semis parked near the entrance. I arrived early evening before the snow hit and slept in until it melted and nobody bothered me for being here too long.

name: Ace hardware
description: They fill your RV propane tank. We have a 35’ RV and it was a little tight.. but you can drive through. not many places fill RV tanks older than 10 years old. Very friendly..

name: Twin bridge dispersed camping
description: Large parking lot off the salmon river. Few fire rings and lots of trees for shade and hammocks. There were about 5 others vans here the night I stayed but was very quite and we all had a lot of space.

name: Travertine outcrop
description: Unbelievable travertine deposit along a river.  Stalactites, and numerous cliff swallows nesting here. Good, big turnout.

name: Plover River
description: Ice Age Trail Plover River Segment. Quiet easy access close to highway but a bit hidden from the road. Star are stunning on a clear night

name: I-10 Eastbound rest stop
description: Free to use dump site with non-potable water.  Dump is on east end, right after the truck/RV parking.  Clearly marked with a blue sign.

name: Cenex Gas Station
description:
Potable water, RV dump, propane fill, Gas station, convenient store. This place has everything!
There was a hose connected to the water supply, but I don’t know if I trust it, as it was leading to the RV dump hole. Luckily, we had our own hose.

name: Walmart
description: Walmart - Dutch fork road. Columbia (South Carolina). Good place. very quiet and no noise from cars or people , very safe and quiet . We asked the manager if it was ok to stay one night and he said,  yes, of course . Wifi average next the store but we were parked at the end of the parking area near trees.

name: Rest Area
description: This rest area is a one-way route - so when you first pull in go towards the semi truck parking and it is on your left. The water is not drinkable but works to clean out your tube when you are done emptying the tanks -- This is an awesome rest area with bathrooms, free wifi, and vending machines.

name: Near Jacob Lake in Kaibab NF
description: Dispersed camping in Kaibab National Forest. Nice level spot along a smooth Forest road. Decent Verizon service (2 bars).

name: Cheyenne Bottoms Wildlife Area
description: 19,857 acre area (owned by people of Kansas). There’s a 20 mile dirt road through the natural land sink with 5 pools where one can see Spring & Fall bird migration. Kansas Wetland Education Center is very kid friendly.  There’s also a primitive camp ground on the property.

name: El Vado Lake State Park
description: $14.00 campsite w/power & water, $10.00 w/out. Trail connects to Lake Heron State Park, about 5 mile hike.  Showers not open for season yet & no maps available.

name: The Golden Spike Tower
description: Union Pacific’s Bailey Yard - The world’s largest rail yard. The Golden Spike Tower & museum allows one to view the whole yard & learn more about the history of train transportation.

name: Moto (gas station)
description: We had had enough driving for one day and stopped here for gas.  Went inside to ask about whether they knew a place to park for the night and told us we could park along the back.  No services although you probably could use bathrooms inside and there are trash bins.  We had 5g T-Mobile.  It's further from the freeway than a rest area and no big trucks.  Please check in first to be sure they are okay with your staying (and buy gas or something).

name: Dixie National Forest - Escalante Ranger District
description: FR419, right turn off John's Valley Road, 8.4 miles from Bryce Canyon Visitor Center. Moved from the spot noted across the road to be sure we were in a legitimate site. This spot is in a beautiful grove of pines in Dixie National Forest property, as verified by USDA map, following dispersed camping guidance from the Dixie National Forest Visitor Guide. Stone firepit. AT&T 4 bars. Verizon 3/3 Mbps up/down. Quiet so far with no other campers.

name: Baraga Shrine Campsites
description: Two informal campsites with no amenities. The Baraga Shrine foundation had the sites cleared by volunteers from Wisconsin Overland for pilgrims and wayward campers to use, donations to the shrine recommended.

name: Lupine Campground
description:
An established campground with flush toilets, drinking water, tables and fire pits.
most parking spots are unleveled. I had to lift my rig 3  inches on both wheels in the back and 2 on a single front wheel.
 
It is $35 a night and close to a lake with a beach. I suspect this area gets packed in the summer months.

Saw a bear last night and noticed there aren't any bear boxes to store your food.

There is a general store and restaurant 1.8 miles away.

name: Sinclair truck stop
description: Lots of big rigs and not a lot of parking for vans or RVs but I slept under the huge sign and they didn’t bother me. If you stay here, stay out of the truckers lot so as not to annoy them.

name: Rio Grande
description: Beautiful spot overlooking the Rio Grande. Dispersed camping. A few fire pits and other campers out here.

name: Walmart
description: Nice, large, flat, quiet Walmart parking.  Asked manager and he said OK, just park away from store. Spent a quiet night, no road noise.

name: Elizabeth Evans Park Parking Lot
description:
I had no issue parking for one night here.  I have a 21 food camper van.  Large spots, pretty calm location.

Not sure I would try it for more than one night

name: Walmart Owatonna
description: Just like every other Walmart. It is fairly quiet for a Walmart and it is far from the main highway so a lot quieter than a rest stop. Park in the back by Culver's.

name: Ives Landing
