description: Restrooms, picnic tables and grills, big parking lot, dog run. Don't ever remember this being here, but it's off the highway and set in the woods. You can still hear highway noise but it's not too bad.

name: I 75 rest area Northbound
description: 24 hour restrooms, picnic tables and grills, vending machines, and dog run. Of course there is traffic noise, it's right next to the highway. Very nice, feels very safe.

name: Agriculture RV Park
description: wide open paek few trees in park area but has trees around the park.

name: Penny Pines Campground
description: $6 campground set in oak/pines. Requires drive up tight switchbacks through previous fire corridor but campground is rebuilt and shaded. Inside Mendocino Nat'l Forrest and rangers do stop by to verify self-payment fees paid. During the day there is off-road vehicle noise and lots of stop-bys to use the pit toilets. This is mostly winter; summer is quieter.

name: Slate Mtn
description: Near trailhead, decent road in. Just 1-bar Verizon but it works. A few pullouts here and there, not busy.

name: Belleville Rest Area
description: New roadside shelter (lighted!) has one picnic table, trash receptacle, electric outlet, & well pump just off Hwy 36. No signs prohibiting overnight stay; although, we didn’t.

name: Dispersed camping past Mona campground
description: Turn in to go in the direction of Mona Campground but keep going past that campground until you reach a dirt road... it’s a little rough but if you go slowly, any vehicle should be able to make it. I came in for some car-camping in my Subaru Outback and there was plenty of room for me to turn around and go back down the dirt road. I’m not sure if a large bus or RV would be able to fit or turn around but a van or smaller should have no troubles. There are several spots with fire rings and it is FREE camping. Gorgeous view of the water and forest. Highly recommend this spot!!! No cell reception.

name: Flying J
description:
RV dump & Drinking water, classic truck stop with showers and Denny’s 

Feb 2022 - water is off - could be seasonal

name: Norton Veteran’s Memorial Park
description: Several water hydrants close to parking areas. Two covered picnic shelters. No signs prohibiting overnight parking; although, we did not stay. Rest rooms currently locked.

name: Dunn Creek Campground
description:
Nice little Army Corps of Engineers campsite approximately 3 miles below the Libby Dam, on the Kootenai River. 
2 pit toilets, fairly level sites, with decent spacing between them.
As of this writing, there is no cost.

name: Lassen NF Pulloff
description: Flat spot with 3 bars of Verizon coverage. Pretty quiet. Easy dirt road off main road to get to. Stayed 2 days and never saw one person.

name: Horse Thief Lake Campground
description: National Forest campground 2.5 miles from Mt. Rushmore. $26/night or $13/night with an Old Geezer pass. Pit toilets, picnic tables, level sites, water, fire rings and an on-site host. Some sites are reservable. We were here mid-week and got a nice lakeside site without reservations. Trails and fishing on lake, also close to Custer State Park.

name: Montrose Conservation area
description:
Primitive camping inside Montrose conservation area. Small Lake and well kept grounds with easy access. 

14 day stay limit 
Good Verizon service 3 Bars (77mbps download/ 8mbps upload)

Lake limited to 10HP or less boats
Popular waterfowl area. 

See posted images for more rules and information.

name: Los Suenos RV Park
description: RV park with about 50 sites. All sites are equally fine, and come with water/electric/sewer. There’s one bathroom in the middle that has shower stalls. Paid $45/night. Good cell reception, decent air cable channels. Plenty of cool shops in the area. I’d stay again and recommend to friends.

name: TA Travel Center
description: Large parking lot. Dump station at front near street. Ask cashier for key. $10 fee.

name: Myers Lodge East
description: A part of the Bigelow Nature Preserve and Maine Public Lands, this is a nice beach campground accessible by a gravel road. It has great views of Bigelow Mountain and access to Flagstaff Lake.

name: Waterside Campground Juniata Lake
description: Situated on a beautiful lake. This Campground with an abundance of full hookup sites for RV. Approximately 50% of the RVs are permanent. Grounds & individual sites are clean and well maintained.

name: Shasta Lake
description: Not established, no fire rings.  flat ground for parking.  no designated spots.  lake is dried up so no waterside camping.

name: Clover Valley
description: BLM land 2 miles from Hwy 93 off of Hwy 232. Dirt road leading to a turnaround. Remote, quiet and flat. Great for a van.

name: True riverside camping. Amazing spot.
description:
This is down a dead end road. department of Forestry official camping area. You will go towards the warm springs trail head, pass the forestry house on the right and drive for 10 minutes. you will see the river open up and just beautiful. beautiful. Multiple spots for camping. couldn't recommend this enough. swimming hole. kids would love it. 0 traffic.

HUGE BEACH

right next to Bonneville hot springs. recommend checking out. water comes out at 210 Degrees! be careful!

name: 5 Buck Pizza
description: Red spigot out front and the best 5 buck pizza you will ever have !!!

name: Franklin County RV Park
description: We stayed at this County RV Park because it was next to the minor league baseball stadium. It is simply a parking lot with hook ups but each spot has a tree for shade. There are toilets in one shower if you need it. You can walk to nearby restaurants in about a half a mile. There was good AT&T and Verizon service is this and is in the middle of town. It is big rig friendly. You may use the dump at a site if a site is open but if they’re all taken there is no standalone dump.

name: Holliday Inn
description: Red water spigot next to dumpster. Very nice modern hotel with heated pool, breakfast and pay for laundry.

name: Kendrick Mtn Area
description: Good gravel road on way to Kendrick TH. A few pullouts. Weak Verizon

name: Alon gas station
description: Small gas station that offers propane bottle refills.

name: Ward Rest Area
description: 24-hour rest area. Parking for cars and big rigs, video surveillance. No tents. Pet relief area. Picnic tables. Water (up to a gallon), vending machines.

name: Fenton Boat Ramp
description: Nice level place on the water with vault toilets. Nature trails. Good place to spend some time.

name: Water spigot in Ecola Park
description: Water spigot in front of bathrooms. You can pull right up to it if there are no cars parked. Clean water good stuff.

name: Street parkmeters
description: Very quiet place, we feel very safe, there is no better location in Washington DC, although there is a parking meter on site for payment, we arrived on Friday night, and we even woke up early on Saturday to pay,  but the guard informed us that it was free for RV, I didn't understand if it is always or because it was Saturday, but in the end we spent the whole day strolling through the region, and we only went out at night.  recommend the location.  I'm Brazilian traveling by Motor Home through the USA

name: San Marcos Pass
description: A shady, fairly level ground, pullout off of Stagecoach Road. Right off of the road, but very quiet and few cars have passed all night, and I stayed on a Friday night. No 'no-camping' or 'no parking' signs along this road from what I could see in the dark. Perfect for a van, car, or truck.

name: Keller Peak Campsite #9
description:
This is the last official campsite at Keller Peak going uphill. Nice setting, good views. The site fits a 25 ft rig on a pretty much level spot. Tent space for a few tents. There's one picnic table and one fire ring. Additional cars may be parked at a pullout around the corner.

To get up here you don't need 4wd. But road in parts is steep and rough and is dried mud for the last part.

Good reception of T-Mobile 4G.
Be aware: it's high altitude (7.400 ft/2.250m). May get chilly in the night!

name: Walmart
description: Walmart supercenter. Always RVs and vans boondocking here.

name: Mendocino Fence rd
description:
This site is a excellent! Park next to white fence that has a small park like setting next to it. A bus stop separates the no parking side to this spot where there are zero signs. Bathroom is 40 feet away and maintained meticulously. Views of coast and very quiet all night. Town is adorable and has tasty pizza and several choices for coffee and breakfast! 
Full bars of att cellular.

name: Top of Moki Dugway
description: Great spot at the top of Moki Dugway. You can walk right from camp to a great view of valley of the gods. Suitable for vans, truck campers or similarly sized rigs. Room for 2 at the pin. No useable Verizon or T-Mobile even with booster and antenna.

name: Just off the 156 in Prunedale
description: A spot just off the highway. In a somewhat residential area. This is not directly in front of anybody's home, but a turn off on the road by a Grove of trees.

name: Day use only area
description: This is a day use only area. Do NOT camp here. This is a huge field lined with pine trees that was great for running the dogs since I couldn’t let them out as much as I’d like in Yellowstone NP.

name: Sacramento Cracker Barrel
description: standard cracker barrel in Sacramento. the lot is not huge but can definitely accommodate campers, conversions, or vans. we have a 25 foot skoolie and we're fine. there was also a small camper with a tow vehicle same as us and they fit as well. the food is good and the wait staff was very nice. the lot is a bit noisy as it's close to the road and there were grounds crew that came through around 7am. we called the restaurant before parking to ask if they allow overnight parking and they said yes just make sure to park in the back of the restaurant. it's open 7am to 8pm. good place for one overnight!

name: Travelodge
description: Cheap hotel on 1hr notice for us. Found this hotel when it was too windy (50mph winds) to camp with our rooftop tent near Powell lake. This place was cheap and easy to book. A very basic hotel with nothing fancy, accept a pool. Lots of hotels in the area of the city and many basic accomodations to get us going again on our trip. This area has maybe 5 major hotel chains within a mile. our nights stay was $68 dollars with tax on a bargain google search. Hope this helps when your backup plans of overlanding fail. Sometimes the weather isn't in your favor, even in the sunny dessert. -J

name: Kelly’s Pond Rd. - Sam Houston National Forest
description:
Kelly’s Pond Road has numerous pull-outs that are free camping the entire length of the road. This spot can accommodate multiple large RV’s but not the other sites. At the end of the road there is a small established campground with water, electricity and showers but it is a fee area. Amazingly I get AT&T 5G cell signal here and it’s fast. 
Be aware that during certain times of the year there are a lot of hunters. It’s very quiet and secluded considering how close to Houston it is. This is my third time here and never any issues. There is hiking and dirt bike trails midway down the road. Fires are permitted but firewood is scarce. Off road vehicles are also allowed. Enjoy!

name: Witch dance
description: On the Natchez trace parkwAy rest area-little from the road spent over nite fabulous and quite

name: Cracker Barrel
description: Overnighting is allowed, please have a meal at the restaurant though. The staff is incredibly friendly. We stayed one night. Masks not required

name: Paynes Prairie Preserve State Park
description: full facility State Park. No laundry service.

name: Wynoochee River
description:
Quite place off main forestry road just before Wynoochee Falls..
Close to Wynoochee River.Established fire pit 1-2 vehicles.

name: Palouse Empire Fairgrounds
description: On Highway 26, this is a small RV park in a large grass field north of the fairgrounds.  $20 per night. Pit toilets are very clean; 30 amp power and water spigots.  Rural farm setting. Not busy most of the year.  Probably busy for annual fair in September.  Free wifi.  Sewage dump just outside east gate for $5.

name: Hollywood Columbus Casino
description: Huge parking lot that is more level toward the bottom, so you’ll probably be the only one parked as low as that. No issues throughout night. There are some signs like “no trucks” in the lot but we took the chance. There’s a long street that has all the Mack trucks parked and you hear them coming in and out a bit at night, but overall seems suitable. Spent one night and was out by 0930

name: Austwell Texas city park
description: Nice city park in a quiet small town near Aransas Wildlife Refuge (the refuge does not have camping). There are hookups and several permanent residents. There was no indication of payment. Decent bathrooms, picnic tables, covered shelter, swingset. Quiet place to spend the night. Hopper's Landing, a bit closer to the refuge, apparently has paid camping, but we didn't ask the price.

name: Rec area Near KSP
description: Easy to get to. On the river, within eyesight of a prison, many picnic table, grills. No pit toilets. Spotty Sprint service.

name: Jeffress Park Blue Ridge Parkway
description: Awesome spot to park for the night on the Blue Ridge Parkway. Great views, restrooms, picnic tables, level parking lot. Saw one other van, otherwise quiet all night.

name: Route 66 RV Park
description:
***4 stars, app not working right***
Full Hookup Utilities
tents to large rigs
Skoolie Friendly!!!
peak and off season prices
daily, weekly, and monthly rates
propane refill on site
ice for sale on site
coin laundry
free showers/bathrooms
park for kids
2 dog parks
garbage dumpsters
in the process of building small cabins
free wifi & cable hookups
food truck will start next month during peak season
CLEAN CLEAN CLEAN!!!
campground management great people

name: Creek pull off
description: On the east side of the bridge there is a rough access leading down maybe 50 yards to the edge of the creek. You can easily see the remains of past bonfires etc. The area is a bit rough and possibly muddy so be sure you can get out if you decide to drive down.

name: national forest free site near Fort Rock
description: Nice quiet spot in the high desert, dirt roads in. Plenty of space for multiple rigs, 2wd ok but not big rigs!

name: Oasis Lodge
description: This is a cluster of portables that have been turned into a hotel for workers in the oil industry around here. There are single rooms and suites with kitchens. We didn't relish tent camping in the heat and humidity and there wasn't anything in town under $100. except here. Our room was clean, beds were soft with good quality sheets, contained a tv, mini fridge and microwave. Free wifi too. Its definitely the best deal in Carranza Springs.

name: Huge free site near Fort Rock Oregon
description: Really huge camp area, lots of space in the forest near Fort Rock Oregon and wide open dirt roads to explore all around

name: Boulder Cove Overlook
description: An amazing little spot, right off the road. No need for 4x4, but it really depends on how far down the dirt trail you wana go. There's about 4 to 5 camping spots if you're all in a van, or 1 to 2 if you're in a big camper. To get here just take the road off of highway seventy, go down a gravel/paved road, turn right onto a dirt road and keep going until you see a bunch of large boulders, a beautiful view and a turn off. It will be on your right hand side. Totally free, extremely quiet. Can get windy! There's shade among the boulders. T-mobile gets bars, just gotta find a spot that works!

name: Del Valle County Park, Castaic
description: Park with lots of grass for picnics or doggies. Nice clean personal stall bathrooms. You can park, but it seems better if parked by the lower end of the park. It’s along side a main road.

name: Santee State Park
description: Nice state park on Marion lake. Wooded shady sites with water and electric hookups, picnic tables, bathrooms with flush toilets and hot showers. $25 a night. Cell coverage on Verizon.  We stayed here as a convenient staging place for exploring Congaree National Park, which is about 30 miles away. No public lands nearby that we could fine and Congaree National Park campgrounds are tent camping only and we have a small pop up truck camper.

name: Southern Trails RV park
description: Cheap, spacious, and accommodating RV park. $20/night for water+30Amp and they’ve got laundry and a pool. The bathroom is a little sketchy, but usable. Laundry is $1.50 each for washer and dryer.

name: Albany County Fairgrounds
description:
Full hookups, no restroom facilities, no showers, $30/nite, $180/wk. This is south of town - not within walking distance to downtown or university.

You can pay with cash or online by scanning a QR code.

name: Pull-off with an amazing city view
description:
Dirt shoulder. Fairly level. no "no-parking or camping" signs. Many cars pass day and night but nobody bothered us. Pretty peaceful and quiet. But the VIEW!! OMG! a MUST see at nighttime, the city view. 
Vans, RVs would fit prefect here

name: Confluence Park
description: This is a lovely local park with water and a dump station as well as overnight parking for everything from cars to Class A and even an 18 wheeler last night. The covered picnic area has electric outlets, I used one to recharge my Ebike battery, no problem at all.  The sign says the water at the dump station is NOT drinkable! There is potable water at the pavilion, however, it’s not threaded so you’ll need a water bandit if you plan to fill your rv. Nice quiet place to sleep at night, and ride my bike during the day. There are also mountain bike trails in this park too.

name: Chimney Rock Travel Center
description: Chimney Rock Travel Center is a truckstop/travel center that allows overnight parking. Located near Alturas, CA, immediately off Rt 95. It sells gas, propane, has a convenience store with restrooms, garbage cans and free Wi-Fi (slow). Very clean and the staff were friendly. The overnight lot is huge, level and quite! Verizon service was marginal.  There is a small restaurant but it is still closed due to Covid. This was a great overnight stop for me in my 20’ campervan because there were high winds, rain, hail, sleet and snow.

name: Weather Station with Gorgeous Views
description:
Amazing spot! 360 views. Totally worth the drive in. 
Follow FR663 up, up, up. Past the trailhead on the right there are three dirt roads. Take the middle road as if going all the way up to Buckles Lake. A mile or so up there’s a hard right turn, and then a meadow (some cool spots there). At the end of the meadow there is a little rutted side road. It’s short, takes you through some trees and bushes to a nice open area with a Forest Service weather station. Surrounded by beautiful aspen groves, and views of the valley and V Rock. AT&T and T-Mobile working pretty good - between 1 and 2 bars. The little side road is the only dicey bit as it’s narrow and rutted. Made it in our Transit van just fine, and 2WD would probably do fine if it’s not muddy. Great spot!

name: El Cosmico
description:
A hip vintage trailer hotel with a bar, bathhouses, and stage. They allow camping in a grassy knoll with picnic tables. Van camping allowed in parking lot. Strong WiFi. Walk to town. Little shop with snacks and beer on site.  
Cost is $21.50 per person/night.

name: Devil's Pass Trailhead - Chugach National Forest
description:
Parking Lot is closed in winter.

Overnight free parking is allowed. parking lot camping is not allowed. A primitive toilet is available at least in summer.

A free primitive campground is a couple miles up the trail.

Car vandalism is possible.

name: La Bajada Rest area
description: Rest area, 18 minutes away from santa fe. Lot of Rvs, trucks and car campers. They have clean restrooms and there is a security guard patrolling all night. This area is open 24 hrs and overnight parking is allowed. Also had full network with LTE

name: Sand Flat Wild Camping
description:
Lots of open areas, and groves to camp. Most places have stone fire pits, and fire going on. I did see a board later with no fire allowed by Sand Flats. 
Access is through gravel road from A10. Decent condition. Saw many sedans (Altima, Audi A5, Ford Focus up in this area). There is snow in the SandFlats loop where a 2WD sedan got stuck. watch for clearance.
Stellar views of mt.Shasta and Shastina. 
Fairly quiet.
Lots of bird chirping, and chipmunks running around.
3-4 bars LTE from AT&T. Good service.
No facilities here.

name: Spruce Pine Inn
description: Small little clean motel on the Trans America Trail. No frills rooms, WiFi, clean bed and towels. Good cell reception. I could not get the WiFi working. Good friendly manager.

name: Good Sense RV
description: This place was incredibly helpful. Got us in right away even though they were busy to fix our tank issue and gave us an amazing quote on exterior work no other shop would help with. They did a great job and were super helpful! Ask for Steve.

name: Trinity Gas co and campground
description:
A small RV park next to a propane gas company where you can fill. We didn’t stay at the campground but filled propane here and saw the park. Looked like full hookups with minimal services otherwise. The haul down the street did not have propane and directed us here instead.

Enter from Trinity Lane not Dickerson, park on the hill and get filled.

name: Riverfront Pkwy at Market st Bridge parking
description: Sign says $6 for anything over 3 hours and that the lot is open 24 hours. We didn’t stay the night but parked for the day with no issues. Lot was monitored by police so we felt very safe. Right near Riverwalk, Aquarium (4th best in country) and amazing shops including the pedestrian bridge to the other side of the river. Very dog friendly area and lovely spot!

name: Street parking next to Church
description: I parked overnight here in my Sprinter camper van to get away from the noise of the highway. It’s a very quite neighborhood with lots of street parking next to the Methodist church. I witnessed a semi truck (without a load or trailer just the truck) park here last night too.

name: Big-R
description: Excellent price on propane filling. $1.89 gal as of 05/25/2021. Great service and very friendly.

name: Watson Mill state Park
description:
Very clean dumpstation with running water to clean.
Potable water only at sites.
$8 to dump if not staying at campground.

name: Red Rock Canyon Visitor Center
description:
Free filtered water at the water fountain. 
For hand held water containers only. The water tastes amazing! Best I’ve tasted in Utah so far

name: Cracker Barrel
description: RV parking behind the building, good for big rigs. Cameras for safety. Next to freeway but not too noisy.

name: Newton Farm Market
description:
Nice, large farmers market. Food, alcohol, household cleaning items 
http://www.newtonma.gov/gov/parks/farmers_market/default.asp

name: Overlook in McCluskey State Park
description: Good spot for a van or suv, sweeping vistas, rock fire ring, 2 bars 4G

name: Medicine Bow NF
description: Lovely roadside spot with fire pit. No amenities but views, solitude, and wind! Verizon 1 bar.

name: Speedway Fuel: Propane, gas, diesel
description: Propane tank refill at a reasonable price.

name: Water spigots in Olympic national park
description: Water spigots on the road leading to hurricane hill which is a beautiful hike. Road is not big rig friendly, but I got here in my extended promaster.

name: Napeague State Park
description: Space for two vans or small RVs. Spotty Verizon service. No amenities. Short hike to a beautiful, secluded beach. No parking October 1 - Jan 31 (except bow hunters). Ticks here carry disease so take precautions. Very rare to find a free overnight spot in the Hamptons.

name: Jiffy Clean Laundry
description: Typical laundromat. Uses quarters. Good prices. Conveniently next to car wash station and Korean fried chicken. Others restaurants and stores close by.

name: French Quarter RV Park
description: Paid about $105/night. Expensive, yes. Worth it, yes. Very secure (gated and guarded). Only about 50 spots here, each 30ftx60ft with full hookups. In the center is a pool and hot tub, along with 4 private toilet/shower rooms. Very clean, very nice facilities. All within walking distance of the NOLA must-sees.

name: Forbes State Forest Motorized Site 6
description:
Forbes State Forest, PA 
Motorized Site 6
Enter from Mt Davis Rd, about 50 yards. 
Free as long as you make a reservation ahead
fire ring and bbq grill
Picnic table 
Only camp sites in the highest mountain in PA and more spread around in Forbes State Forest. 

https://www.dcnr.pa.gov/StateForests/FindAForest/Forbes/Pages/Camping.aspx

1-2 LTE bars 
Surrounded by many State Parks and trails.

name: Paul Ogle Riverfront Park
description: Covered picnic tables have potable water spouts next to them.

name: Speedway on 491
description:
Just a pretty big gas station but I went inside and asked if I could stay the night and they said no problem. Super nice woman working didn’t even bat an eyelash
It’s got a lot of parking spots but I could see that they would get annoyed if more than a few vehicles did this so if you see if you already... move on. The only thing they said is don’t block the pumps. So be respectful of the space you take vs the ability for other vehicles to get in and get gas or have a spot to go inside. There are lots of dogs maybe five? I think the people who work here bring them to work and they run around in the street and bark all that but other than that pretty good nights sleep here

name: Forest Rd on the way to Fish Hatchery
description: Follow signs to the fish hatchery.  Take a left on the forest road 289c, before you get to the bottom of the canyon at the Fish Hatchery.  At the first fork keep going straight.  You can stop at this spot or continue on, taking a right at the fork.  There are two larger campsites overlooking the back side of the canyon there which can accommodate multiple vehicles.  Very little to no cell reception.  Quiet. Be bear aware and store food in your vehicle or up high, as  we saw scat that might be from a bear.  Big rigs could  fit at the larger site.

name: Black Bear liquor
description: very nice lady just ask and they will let you get water and throw your trash away

name: Rock Island
description: Nice forest service campground next to Icicle Creek. Good hiking right from the campground. Good for Rigs 25 ft or less. Pit toilets kept up nicely. At the end of May, there was one water source, but only designed to fill up jugs. 30 minutes from Leavenworth. No cell service. $18 per night.

name: Hunt's Lodge
description: Cabins, tent sites, and a couple of 30amp and 15amp spots. Geared for motorcyclists, they have everything you need. Towels, shampoo/soap... Etc.  Nice hot showers and clean bathrooms.  Great wifi.  Had decent Verizon signal. Laundry is free... It won't let me give more than 3.5 rating.  I would give it a 4.5 out of 5

name: Spearfish Quarry Motorized Trailhead
description: Large clear space for ORV/ATV trailers. No signs about no camping. Maybe busy during the weekends but deserted during the week. Our Sprinter made it without issues. No trash or services but great place to overnight.

name: SUNOCO Gas $9.99
description: They have a dump here, it is $9.99. Free water at gas station.

name: Free & Quiet campground
description:
MODERATOR NOTE: this campground is administered by the U.S. Forest Service and is a fee area.

A cute little campground along SR 108. No signs  stating which campground it is, or for payment. can fit quite a few RVs, vans, tents. we were the only ones here. picnic table and grill, did not see a bonfire spot. clean composting toilets. FREE, quiet, with a great view next to a river.

name: Beckler road
description: Road with lots of free camp sites off of it

name: farmers union trading co
description: $5 dump, propane and water-bring your own hose. a little tricky to navigate but doable for our 32 ft class c

name: Harrington Casino
description: Casino parking lot. RV parking is back near fence.

name: Charles Mear State Park
description: Big park .  Almost all asphalt. $42 night. But has all of the amenities. And great beach. Good place to recharge

name: FR 3623 near Bryce. Beautiful spot
description: Lots of dispersed camping in this area. This spot is large for several cars, overlooks a beautiful meadow to watch the sunrise. Down a little is another great spot on the edge of the cliff overlooking beautiful rock formations. There’s a restaurant and gas station for supplies on the main road, as well as the bike trail that goes into Bryce. Absolutely perfect camping spot. 2 to 3 bars Verizon. Fire pits.

name: Spring Creek Campground
description: $3 shower. not bad. Not a fancy place by any means, but it's wet and has hot water.

name: Dale County US231 Rest Area
description: Rest area with free dump station, RV Parking, restrooms, picnic shelters.  Posted "No overnight parking".

name: Alabama Bass Trail Welcome Center
description: At the state park entrance there is a welcome center with a large, free parking area. There are a few picnic tables in the shade. The welcome center has flush toilets.

name: Super K Water Pump
description:
Shell Super K water pump in Raley’s Market parking lot. Free potable water, need your own hose.
Owner came out and yelled at me about taking a whole rv full and that it’s just for radiators and such. “Water isn’t free” beware.

name: Walmart
description: Signs stating no overnight. Cheap gas though

name: Bryce Canyon visitor center
description: Water bottle refill station outside the visitor center and inside. For hand held jugs only. The one outside is taller so it’s good for bigger containers

name: Ocean overlooking cliff
description: Dirt road pull off with a large round about. Any vehicle can make it. Parked right up on the cliff on a big grassy area over looking the ocean! Didn’t see any signs and was the int person here all night. Close to road, so there’s traffic noise but so worth the view. Epic sunset spot and sunrise. Right by the Bridges!

name: Maverik
description:
Dump and non potable water at Maverik gas station.

Plus general use water at pumps. Does not fit a standard hose so I could only fill containers.

name: Cracker Barrel
description: Stayed at this Craxker Barrel for one night and it was a good experience overaall. I had to search for a flat surface as the lot is not totally level. The lot  is near a Highway but was relatively quiet overnight. I would stay here again.

name: Hot spring next to river
description: Roadside parking with a short trail down to the pool. The pool is 1.5’ deep and 8’ diameter. Came at 6PM and was well worth the dip. It’s been a long drive. Enjoy yourself!

name: Flying J’s
description: Free water at separate pumps to the right.

name: Battle Ground Lake State Park
description: There is a campground here and a dump station and potable water. The dump station and water is self pay and $5. Campground ranges from 15-37 depending on amenities, cabins $86.

name: Majestic Oaks RV Campground
description: Very nice. Beautiful live oaks trees. Pool. Clean facilities. Hosts are very nice and helpful.

name: Sneaky Woodsy Dream
description: Near Beaver Campground ($20 per night!) we found this FREE wild spot right on the water. A bit of noise from the road but it’s in the NF so no heavy traffic. Fire ring, shade, river sounds and access, gorgeous green all around. No Verizon service, and not much large dead wood around so you might want to bring firewood. Plenty of places selling on the way in from Carson. Definitely some biting bugs in late may as the sun went down, but nothing unbearable with spray and layers. We fit our 18’ 2WD Chevy van in and positioned ourselves to block the access road and find level ground. Could tent camp, or bring a smaller vehicle. Can’t believe this place wasn’t already listed. Enjoy!

name: Gander RV formerly camping world
description: So there are about 4 FREE spots in the back right corner. Has power and water hook ups if needed. If you don’t need that you can park anywhere in the parking lot. Staff were super nice!

name: Christmas Tree Ship
description: Beautiful parking lot off Lake Michigan sleep here all night no problem one out house Nice size beach All Rest Stop in Michigan are No longer overnight Parking due to Cov-19 So Spot like this are a gem Must be self contained No water or Showers

name: Edwards Rest Area
description: Rest area off exit 163 - take the exit. Not your standard immediate interstate pull off. Super clean bathrooms. Quiet parking, minimal interstate noise.

name: Lake Pleasant BLM
description: This spot is a little farther down a small dirt road than the other spots. You can do it in a small class C or truck but I wouldn’t drive here in a class a or even most tow-behinds because there are quite a few dips and turns in the road. There is a view of the lake and mountains. Super pretty!

name: Clayton Geneva Memorial Campground
description: Hidden gem, camp ground hosts are second to none. Riverfront primitive sites are sanded and shaded. Rv sites offer full hook up. Wifi is great!!

name: Lometa Regional Park
description: Rodeo campground with RV sites, bathhouse with showers and dump station.

name: Sheep Mt. Overlook
description:
Edge of grass covered prairie with eastern overlook of gorgeous canyon of Badlands. Amazing and other-worldly here. Easy 2wd low clearance to "Sheep Mt. Overlook" where we saw a class A RV. Go past the sign indicating "high clearance vehicles only". The road is smooth, though hump between tire tracks requires high clearance at points.
3 bars Verizon.

name: Near Gilbert Trailhead
description: The Roads End campground located at the end of this road is closed because of a past fire. We camped at the trail head for a couple of trails that head into the wilderness. There’s a nice open spot to camp at a pit toilet. Be aware that this area has had a fairly recent fire but the views of the surrounding mountains are pretty extraordinary. There is no cell service here. The space could accommodate a small trailer truck camper or van. nothing large. The road to the campsite is a well-maintained forest service road.

name: Circle K
description: Propane, gas, diesel, and mini mart.  Propane is on the high end at $3.59/gallon plus tax.

name: Running Creek Lane
description: Water for small rigs under 25ft.  Use the spigot on front of house.  Need about 25-30 feet of hose.  Cost is $10 for up to 30 gallons of water.  Daytime only. Leave $ in red bench. If you use less than 30 gallons feel free to adjust the amount.  Sorry water around here is expensive.

name: Baylor Canyon Road BLM
description: One-way road off Baylor Canyon Drive with multiple pullouts for camping.  Great view of the mountains and sunset. Not many cars driving by

name: Farmer Boys
description: Was woken Up by an officer at Travel Centers of America and told to go here instead. No other campers around but seems like an okay place to crash for one night in a pinch

name: Wolf RV Park
description: A bit out of the way. An experience. Ask to have a camp in the shade. Don't get put out in what I call "The hot pads." You won't have to ask for the deep discount, Carrol will make sure you can get it. Paid$17 for full hook-up in the Hot Pad. Nice place to regroup. Laundry$1, shower is clean, tons of books, DVDs, pool table. Great bird watching.

name: Rosa's Cantina
description: Lots of beer on tap. Mexican menu. Get #8, chili rellenos. Yummy

name: Schermerhorn Nature Center
description: Nature center along Shoal Creek. Several trails and river front.

name: St. Jacob’s Well
description: Spring fed pool of water that was a stopping point for early settlers. Believed to be anywhere from 58 feet deep to bottomless. It’s has never been known to go dry.

name: Columbine Campground
description: Nice campground with a variety of spots. A few are first-come first-served, most are by reservation through Recreation.gov. Great trailhead in the campground. Pit toilets, cleaned daily. Potable water. No hookups. Tents, RVs, etc. allowed. A few pull-through spots, most are not. Some are flat or near-flat, many require some amount of leveling. Paved parking pads. Some spots are near the road (which has some traffic during the day but I imagine not much at night). Other spots are back from the road with only the sound of the river. Pets allowed on leash. Enjoyable spot. Verizon cell signal is spotty; works in some areas of the campground, but not others, and not consistently. Works for phone calls and texts but streaming video is problematic.

name: Sequoia National Forest pull off
description: Great little pull off from the road. There’s a dirt road next to this that I haven’t explored but it has a nice grass patch for a tent as well. Directly between Kings Canyon and Sequoia National Park but completely in the National Forest.

name: Back Road pull off
description: About 1 hour from Crater Lake national park. A dirt pull off, could fit an RV or a couple cars. A “no dumping” sign but no mention of camping. Fields all around and barely any traffic (after 9pm when i arrived) since it’s a back road. Full LTE service with Verizon.

name: Gravel Lot on 197
description: Massive gravel space off the highway with great views of the hills/fields. Has service with Verizon.

name: Single Vehicle Ridgeline Camp
description:
An established pullout on the forest road to Crystal Spring trailhead. Enough room for an SUV or Truck, would be tough if towing. 
Great view to the northwest. LTE on TMobile. 
Fire ring exists but check conditions and current status.

name: Lolo Pass Visitor Center & Rest Area
description:
Rest area - sleeping in your vehicle overnight is permitted. We planned to boondock in the forest but all the forest roads are still closed due to road conditions of the season. Heated bathrooms (toilet & sink) available 24/7. 
Tons of space and level ground for all sizes of rigs, including 18 wheelers. 
Near the Highway but not too much overnight traffic. 
No cell reception with Verizon. Trash dumpsters available. 
Visitor’s Center currently closed down due to CoVid. Rangers stopped by in the morning but did not pay mind to us.

name: Hacienda Haassen
description: Head north past the east side of the bike park, roughly 1/4 mile. There’s a metal pole marker with the coordinates welded onto it, along with a small fire pit in the center of the site. Great panoramic views of the canyons, along with night stargazing. Relatively isolated. One can go farther back, however 4 wheel drive recommended. Treat yourself to some stunning views! Great cell phone service for AT&T users.

name: KOA
description: KOA. Great campground. Has dump, propane, pool, mini golf and dog park.

name: Near Forest Road
description: Huge secluded yet open space. I was traveling southbound on 2880 - went past the “river pullout”, occupied by a man who had a large generator and a rental garbage bin, looked like he owned the spot. Continued onward, at the fork in the road, take a right. The next big area off the road just before another bridge was occupied. Thankfully, I kept driving just beyond the aforementioned bridge and found this spot, not yet posted on the app. Has a firepit. Huge. Lots of open space for 10+ camper vans if wanted. Just off the forest road.

name: FR300 south of Show Low
description: FR 300 dispersed camping site near Show Low and Pinetop. FR 300 going west of HWY 60 is smoother, but many more people to contend with, so go east if you want more privacy. Several good spots for small campers or vans, but only two spots for larger rigs, this one being the last possible spot without difficulty. There is an Indian reservation gate that blocks off FR300 shortly after this site to the east, and it is extremely difficult to turn around a truck and large camper, so only go up near gate with a van or small rig.

name: PawPaw Tunnel (C&O Canal)
description: Large camping area. Reservation required. Parking lot is free overnight parking. Walk-in or bike-in camping, just south on tow path. Lot is flat gravel and nicely treed.

name: Choctaw Nation Hospital parking lot
description: Quiet parking lot next to a gas station. Slept in our rig overnight to finish our drive in the morning. Went to the gas station in the morning for clean restrooms and good coffee.

name: Jordan Hot Springs Trailhead /
description:
This is the small parking lot for the little fork canyon little bear canyon trail. 
Jordan Hot Springs are down this trail which are simply amazing. If you can go on a hike. wow. it's been to 47 states and its one of the most amazing semi-unknown hikes I have ever been on. The canyon back their is amazing!! 
you can stay in this spot multiple nights, we have before, people do it all the time.. Especially backpackers (which I highly recommend doing)  Make sure you have water shoes to cross the river about 15 times with 1000 ft walls all around you..

name: 321 RV Park
description: New Rv Park. 73 full hookups with 50/30/20 amps. Self contained only. Quiet country setting. Gated. Free fiber optic WiFi. Concrete patio and picnic tables at each site. Playground and fire pit. Restaurant nearby. Extended stays available. Close to Hickory, Gastonia and Charlotte.

name: Grapevine Branch #1
description:
Flat spot at the entrance to a two track (posted "no motor vehicles" though) so you're not just perched on the side of the road.
The dirt road leads to the Grapevine Campground, a formal primitive camping site about a half mile further on.Up here your won't have any neighbors.
Dispersed camping is allowed in the Andrew Pickens  Ranger District, where this site is.

name: Big Basin Prairie Basin
description: 1800 acre preserve. At one point in time, this area sunk down to its current depth when underground salt and gypsum formations dissolved. Also the location of Jacob’s Well.

name: Littlefield Dirt Lot
description:
Good size dirt lot just off paved spur road. Could easily turn truck and mid-size camper around. I slept on ground (car camping) from 1:00am-5:0am while driving through. No one in area. 

0.5 miles down Hidden Valley rd (paved spur road) off hwy 91, 2 miles southwest of Littlefield. Can see/lightly hear I-15. 4 bars Verizon LTE

name: Alder Creek Logging Road
description:
Small pullout with fire ring on side of logging road. Take same left turn (marked by Discovery Pass Required sign) off Upper Hoh road as Alder Creek Rain Forest campsite and at fork in road, stay left and in the open (small clear cut area). Right goes to forest. On this gravel road, there are 3 narrow turnouts w fire rings. 1/2 mile from ‘Y’, road T’s into another logging road. Not sure where it goes. 

2 bars of Verizon LTE.

name: Dirt road off Hwy 2
description: We found this spot while looking for a place to stay and checking out an unmarked road running off Hwy 2. You have to make a sharp turn onto this dirt road that immediately leads in the woods. Once you get on the road, you can either turn left onto another road that runs parallel with Hwy 2 or go straight. Keep driving straight less than one hundred yards for a great site. As we drove through the woods towards the Kootenai River, some small tree limbs brushed up against my pickup truck very slightly. The road is a little bumpy in some spots and could be muddy during rain season. Four wheel drive wasn’t necessary for us even though it had rained recently. The road leads to a site under trees next to the river that can fit 2-3 trucks or vans. There is a fire pit in this site, but no rocks around it.

name: Griffin Park Dump Station
description: Free dump site with non potable rinse water. No potable water available. Located at end of RV Parking lot.

name: Off Rt 9N
description: Little dirt road with a grassy opening that can fit cars and tents. No “no camping” or private property signs. A bit close to the road so some noise but not bad if you’re in a van.

name: Off Road
description: good flat spot with limited traffic on memorial day weekend. view of mountain is pretty nice this time of year, very sunny.

name: Culver City
description:
Side street close to downtown Culver City. Head of the street has an inn-in-out where you can use the bathroom. Free parking, no restrictions other than street sweeping 8a-10a on Thursdays.
I’ve been here two nights in a row with no issues. Some of the spots are more level than others.

name: Pawnee Village. State Historical Site
description: Museum of a Pawnee Village. The village encompasses the archeological dig of a Pawnee earthen lodge. The village was left as was found and excavated.

name: Holiday gas station
description: Single rv dump station. $5. Gas and car wash on site.

name: Gnat Creek Rd
description:
**NOT BIG-RIG FRIENDLY!!**

Established Oregon Forestry campground early on the road Gnat Creek campground)- if you continue along the road there are multiple forks, most of them with a camp area at the end (open area with fire pit). If you continue upwards all the way from the first fork it takes you to a large forest cutting operation. I recommend keep right at the first fork. From there you’ll find more forks so take your pick. A lot of trash left in the area (don’t be that person.) I recommend bringing along an extra trash bag to pick some up and dispose of it properly (to makeup for the free camping;)) The road is great - very few pot holes & definitely do-able in a sedan!

name: Gnat Creek Campground
description: Established Oregon State Forestry campground. 5 sites - first come first serve. $20 - pit toilet. Creek close by - also a popular trail here. Park and walk 5-15 ft to the camp sites. Large parking area.

name: King park
description: Parking spot right along the water. Many spots here. On a major road so somewhat loud with traffic

name: Dave’s Hollow
description:
5-6 dispersed camping site with fire rings. Each spot is pretty much private. When you first turn down the road, there’s an area that looks like it used to be a place to camp but signs up saying 'no camping'. Drive past that and you’ll see a couple big sites on each side of the road and 2-3 smaller sites shortly after. Tons of off-road vehicles fly by during the day but most are done by sunset. Short 15 minute drive to Bryce Canyon NP. AT&T service is decent, 2 bars LTE. 

Off of forest road 088. Please take your garbage with you! Pack it in, pack it out.

name: Earp & James RV Park
description: Nothing special here. Has full hookups. Close to I-84 but no highway noise. Good place to stop over and recharge/refill. Nice to have power for AC. Clean bathroom with shower but only one for all renters. Price was $30 for 30 amp.

name: Near road
description:
Small spot for one car, a little sloped but not awful. Not sure of land status but nothing posted. No one bothered me.
Right off the road, so you can hear traffic but only about thirty cars went by after I got there in the last few hours of the day. No traffic Sunday morning. Most people turned at the intersection just south and didn't actually come by - so headlights didn't shine in my car.
I was heading to two other sites on the map but found the foot of the road is closed on this end.

name: Morton Rd.
description:
We were so happy to find this site open since we are in a 40’ Super C and need a pretty spacious spot. Early in the season there were plenty of spots available, though not all suitable for larger rigs. The roads getting to this spot were about as perfect as they could be. Forest Trail Rd is paved and goes all the way to the Lake Michigan Recreation Area where there are hiking trails and a parking lot for day use, as well as a campground. 
AT&T data was 3.5mb and allowed us to stream whatever we wanted but was a little slow at times. We do use a booster which did help a lot at this site. Verizon was very weak, 1 bar, calls were hard to make while there.

name: Wiseman State Wildlife Preserve
description: Ok spot for one night, flat dirt parking area for access to the wildlife preserve, used by hunters. Just check what season it is before you go wandering into the trails, there are warning signs for wearing bright colors etc.

name: Wildlife Preserve Access
description: Small parking area at fishing / hunting area in a wildlife preserve. Ok for one night, signs warning to wear bright colors if you walk along the road past the parking area due to hunting.

name: White river overflow lot
description: Smaller more secluded parking lot near White River Sno Park

name: Forest Service Rd - Several sites
description: We did not drive further than this GPS point, but along this road there are several wild camping spots. The first spot is large and open and could easily accommodate a couple large rigs but the rest will only accommodate one to three small rigs at most. Past the first large area the road steepens and high-clearance vehicle will do best. At this GPS marker one can position two smaller rigs.

name: Gualala Point regional campground
description: The dump station has two sides, so pulling in is easy. Non-potable water is right next to the dump station. There is a small trash receptacle. There is no fee posted. It is just off the road to the campground but not in the campground. While the campground is definitely not big rig friendly I think a big rig could manage to get in and out of the dump station with some backing.

name: 7-Eleven Gas Station
description: The dump station is on the Northwest side of the parking lot. it is a very open lot, so any rig should be able to get in. Very large rigs should take the entrance from Main Street and navigate around the store.

name: Racetrack Road
description: A pulloff if the campgrounds are full and the open field is too crowded for your liking. Short walk to the river which you can hear. No service, just spending a night in the woods eating pizza. Fire put on site.

name: Dash Point State Park
description: State park campground and day use area.  Well appointed and quite full during our visit.  Clean, modern, and presentable showers and restrooms.  Showers are token operated and a token exchange machine is available at the guard house at the park entry. Tent and small vehicle campsites with no service outnumber hookup sites, probably 2 to 1.  Cell service with AT&T is weak.  Voice calling and limited text messaging possible, other web content almost impossible to access.

name: Rock Creek Rd RV Campground
description:
Great RV park right off the highway. Reservations are online but it is easier to pay when you get here. There are signs leading the way to the phone number to call for help. Cost $20. We will definitely be back. Owners run the place. They are very friendly and came and talked with us for a while. Also Lake Eufaula is across the highway for easy access. 

Bathrooms had been closed since covid but they gave us the key regardless. Not good bathrooms. Hopefully your rig has one. We ended up using our own.

name: 'Home on the Range' cabin
description: This is the site and cabin where the song ''Home on the Range' was written. The cabin has been restored and there is a short nature trail.

name: Palisades Reservoir
description: Tons of pull-down spots right on the lake. I parked 20' from the water for 4 days or so. No issues. Gets a bit windy. Good cell bars. There are so many places to park your rigs all up & down the Hwy. Have fun & enjoy the views of the mountains surrounding this slice of heaven.

name: Laundry Basket
description: Clean and fast laundry. WiFi is also available

name: 76 Gas Station
description: Propane available, and water screw tap (not potable) available just behind the air pressure station.

name: Open Space next to Plomosa road
description: Awesome open space between cactus and mountains, turn left on Plomosa road from Bouse. You can go as far as you want. Amazing sunset and moonrise. We left a well constructed fire pit 😊

name: Open space next to the road
description: Big open area next to the road, few other RV but quiet.

name: Parking lot away from higway
description: Nice quiet area, with toilets and picnic table. Good for a night. 4G available

name: Slow groovin bbq
description: Excellent bbq place right on main road , realy quite an relaxing with 360 ° mountain view

name: Gem Lake Trailhead Parking
description: Spigot near info kiosk, about 30ft from paved road

name: Room With a View
description:
Sandy & uphill w/ tight corners.
If you don’t have 4x4 and high clearance, and also traction mats for recovery, don’t attempt it...there are other sites far more easily accessible on the BLM Road on the way here.

If you do make it, you will be rewarded with an amazing 270° view, the white rock faces of the hills, and other than a couple of dogs barking far away, peace and quiet!

name: Tuskegee Campsite #6
description: Dispersed campsite with informal fire pit, plenty of room to park, just off of forest road. Quiet, very low traffic, easy access. I imagine most RVs could probably fit here if desired. 2 bars of LTE on Verizon. Four bars T-Mobile LTE.

name: Friday Harbor Wastewater Treatment Plant
description: Publicly available dump station located on the corner of Tucker Ave. and Harbor St.  Drive through service on the north side of Harbor St.  Water on site is only for tank and hose rinse, not marked at potable.

name: Dirt Road btwn Searchlight & Nipton
description: We were headed west out of Searchlight toward Cali and it was time to find a camp site. We turned north off 164 and headed into the desert. Road eventually dead-ended at antennas with a nice flat spot for our 4Runner and Off-Grid Trailer. Definitely need 4x4 and high clearance.

name: Forest camping off NF-306
description:
We stumbled upon this site while looking for another iOverlander spot. There is a dirt road off the main forest road that dead ends at a beautiful spot. It’s very isolated, so it’s great for privacy. 

It’s not very level, so RVs wouldn’t be the best fit. We did bring our 23’ Class C but it never truly was level. Truck campers and tent campers would love this spot! 

The views are great and the birds chirping throughout the day is the perfect forest backdrop. 

Great AT&T service!

name: Alvord hot springs
description:
There are campsites with picnic tables on a gravel parking lot. Vehicle or tent camping is $50 per night (as of May 2022) as well as MASH units (Military Army Surgical Hospital) with beds, basically glorified shipping containers, which you can sleep in for $80 a night when the weather gets harsh. There is a very small general store with a bathroom there as well. 
All in walking distance to the hot springs.  
Zero cell reception. Starlink works great.

name: Clark Fork River
description:
Follow the dirt road along the river and you will find spots along the river.
porta potties scattered through area. quiet and secluded.

name: Big Rapids Rest Stop
description: Nice forested rest stop right off the highway going south.

name: Forest Road 3531
description: Small pull out near the switchback. Suitable for tents or smaller rigs if road is open. May be assessable by vehicle from the Hwy 35 entrance closest to the Hwy 26 interchange. Snow and ice still covering the road as of May 31 2021. No vehicle access from the upper end near from the Pacific Crest trailhead due to multiple trees down across the read, however, there is a nice parking lot at the trailhead to park and hike in. Beautiful view of Mt. Hood from Buzzard Point along the way.

name: Forest Road 3531
description: Small pull out near the switchback. Suitable for tents or smaller rigs if road is open. May be assessable by vehicle from the Hwy 35 entrance closest to the Hwy 26 interchange. Snow and ice still covering the road as of May 31 2021. No vehicle access from the upper end near from the Pacific Crest trailhead due to multiple trees down across the road, however, there is a nice parking lot at the trailhead to park and hike in. Beautiful view of Mt. Hood from Buzzard Point along the way.

name: Pullout near Kurt's Konnection trailhead
description: Large pullout suitable for big rig or two smaller rigs just off hwy 26. Pit toilet just down the road at Glacier View Snopark trailhead. Lots of trails nearby for hiking. Would be ok for an overnight stay, but this area gets a lot of daytime traffic due to nearby trailhead.

name: Mountaineer Casino, Racetrack & Resort
description: Huge parking lot plenty of spaces. Bathrooms inside of casino. Parked overnight with no issues

name: The Locals Secret Road
description:
Past the camground that is on this road (which is ehhh) There are forest service camps that are stunning. the one this marker is at has a river behind it and a white capped mountain front and center. There are also moose just grazing.. everywhere. Many spots on the road. Locals have it packed on labor day. long drive out. but so so worth it. 
Even a random forest service pit toilet off the road. So happy we made it here with the slim choices in the area. Locals said it's a secret. 

Lots of big rigs are back here. bumpy road though. Was honestly surprised they got up here with the bumpy road but about 50 pull behinds were at the campgrounds. 


If you have 4x4 you can get up and close to lakes farther up the road

name: Crazy Creek (USFS)
description: Lovely 16 site campground with picnic tables, fire rings, and a vault toilet.  Costs $10 per night (half price with Access and Senior pass).  Opens late May.  Has a campground host.  Your choice of shaded or sunny sites. Sounds of the fast flowing stream at most sites.  Mountain views to west in a few sites. Short trail across the road to a lovely set of waterfalls by Site 2.  Site 10 has an informal trail down to the stream with nice rapids.

name: Rael’s Propane
description: Propane refills in back of parking lot next to UHaul.

name: Homestake BLM
description: This spot is beyond the big group site when you first enter the area. We squeezed in here with our 27' TT. Ideally this spot is best suited for car, van, or small Class C unless you are really good at backing a TT. This spot is huge, plenty of solar, cell signal. Lots of boulders to climb on.

name: Willowemoc Wild Forest
description:
Turn left on Fluegertown Road and go 1.5 miles past the Long Pond Trailhead.  (Aprox 2.5 from main road). 
There are a couple of pullouts on the right with fire rings. I found a spot right on the creek, off the road about 100 feet. There are some old sites that are posted no camping from overuse. 
Bring a portable toilet system or a trowel and be sure to use away from the water and camp area. Some of the most technical fly fishing I’ve ever done. But there are some really nice little holes up and down the creek. 
Pack out more than you take in. It was pretty clean but found a lot of small plastic MOOP. 
Not sure if it is patrolled. Only one other camp set up by the bridge about a half mile down.

name: Exxon
description: Exxon has a hose bib, byo hose. Asked inside, they said it was cool.

name: Dunnigan Highway rest area, northbound
description: Highway rest area with water spigots.  Too far from pavement to fill RV tanks directly.

name: Monte Verde RV park
description:
Propane available at this RV park
You may have to text or call phone number 5753773404 if nobody is at the  desk. Very nice person and service!

name: Pandora’s boxx
description: Five campsites for most any size rig, Although if the campsites are full turning around could be an issue for rigs over 25 feet. Some are flat some are definitely not flat and a few spaces for tents. Backs up to Pandora’s box Canyon. Within sight of the town of Tori. Three bars of LTE Verizon

name: Big Meadows
description: Nic primitive campground.  No hookups or water.  Level sites, fire pits, picnic tables, pit toilets.

name: Outcropping in the lava field
description: Nice spot a little further around from the main area. Less highway noise and no neighbors.  Lots of shooting trash so be careful if you have kids or dogs with you.  Lots of sharp things about.  There a pretty established fire ring and just a touch of cell service. Could be impassable if really wet. If dry 4x2 will get you here. Lots of these spots in the area. I’m sure you could find a few if you looked.

name: truck stop
description: I prefer parking here to Walmart down the road. less brightly lit, huge dirt lot where you can park far from the noisy trucks.

name: Mud Creek dispersed camping
description:
Similar to the other location, but it's all wild camping. there may be scattered pit toilets at some of the road entrances, but that's all. 

In this loop farther back, there's even fire rings and spots back into the woods, beyond the fence and beyond where vehicles are allowed. there's at least 5 fire rings within a literal stone's throw, not a ton of flat space though. 

3-4 bars of service, plus data even if it's slow at times. lots of ATV traffic, throughout the day on the weekends. not fully filled at the end of memorial day weekend, but it seems this place gets plenty of use being one of the top fishing lakes. please clean up your garbage! pack it in, pack it out!

name: Street Parking Outside Of Safeway Lot
description: Free street parking just outside of the Safeway parking lot. There were towing signs inside the parking lot, and signs saying no parking from 10 am - 12 pm on certain days, but no other signage. Pretty level, well lit area. A few other vans parked for the night, no issues!

name: Pull off near I80
description:
Roomy and comfortable spot near the trailhead for Loch Leven. Flat spot for two vehicles. Wasn’t noisy overnight but can hear the highway. Verizon and T-mobile service is available. Can see the spot off the road so should be easy to find. 
Traffic noise from 80 is fairly loud but kind of becomes white noise after a while. We slept fine. Only a few cars passed on Hampshire Rocks Rd at night. The river is close by but we didn’t check it out since we were just passing through. Watch out for the dip down to the flat spot if you arrive in the dark! It’s not huge but you’ll want to slow down for it.

name: Pearl Lake
description: We actually intended on going to the already marked Lime Lake spot but the gate was closed. The gate is located to the left of the dirt road. Since it was closed we kept going on the dirt road we were on and not much further found this pull off to the right and got closer to Pearl Lake. This was better than we could have imagined! There is a roundabout where you can park and then a small trail leading right to the waters edge! Someone had been here before as they cleared out the area and there is a metal fire pit. You can stay in the same area for 14 days!!! Definitely the best spot

name: Oasis RV Park
description: Experience the exciting environment of Las Vegas' most spectacular RV resort. The Oasis Las Vegas, with its tropical "Casablanca" theme, helps guests relax in sunny Las Vegas by day and see the bright city lights by night in complete comfort and style.

name: Walmart
description: Quiet Walmart lot. Lit well but has shade trees.

name: Mollie B Campground
description: USFS campground (run by a private company) right on the Reudi Reservoir. It's like a typical USFS campground but much more expensive ($27/night+$2/night over holidays). Bathrooms with flush toilets were closed for 2021 season due to water shortage but they have portos. Each site has a picnic table, fire ring/grill, and food locker (for bear safety). Some parking pads are bigger and flatter than others (not sure the max but some seem at least 30+ft). Road in is paved all the way, and through the campground but all the parking spots are gravel. There's a potable water fill and dump ($10) just outside the campground, and potable water spigots throughout.

name: Cracker Barrel
description: Confirmed you are allowed to overnight. They only ask that you do so in the parking lot Cracker Barrel owns down the street clear marked for RVs/Buses

name: Roadside
description: About 5 dispersed camping spots all marked. The road to the first few is a little bumpy but I did it in my van. The others were too rough for my van but a 4WD could do it or you can just park at the first ones and pitch your tent at the ones further up the road. Next to a creek. Super lovely. Next to the road, so definitely noise but not too bad.

name: Water spigot
description: Water spigot on the side of the building

name: Cracker Barrel
description: Great spot off the Highway. Long pull ins for RVs as well as regular parking along the back, by a fence and some trees. Wasn’t bothered all night and it was relatively quiet. Left by 1115 AM

name: Ivy Commons
description: stayed here one night and no one bothered us. there are road noises, but otherwise pretty quiet.

name: Chevron
description: In the lot of the Chevron is a hose for potable water. It’s very clearly labeled

name: Alabama Hills
description:
Moderator Note: This description provides gcod information, but the User did not stay overnight. Check carefully.
.....
This was a really pretty spot overlooking Alabama Hills below Mt. Whitney. The only downside is that it was really buggy, so I didn't stay here. It had full Verizon LTE bars. There are probably 3-4 spots off this road, and the higher you go, the more off-camber it gets. Still a great spot that's very quiet compared to Alabama Hills. Stream nearby but its on the road north of this one about 1/4 mile away.

name: Yellowstone Hot Springs
description:
For $18 you can soak in natural fed hot springs and shower for as long as you like in a very clean nice resort on the river with great views.

A must stop place in the area. It's worth the extra money. They offer a few discounts as well.

name: Baldy Mtn Rd
description:
A nice area adjacent to the creek. Good privacy.  Space for multiple vehicles. No Verizon cell service.

Good access if coming from the west. If coming from the East, (from Sandpoint) you'll need high clearance vehicle, and the road is closed seasonally over the mountains.

name: Silver Island Mountains Byway
description: Unpaved road with tons of BLM dispersed campsites. Verizon cell service with full bars. Was able to drive here in a van without 4WD or high clearance. Nice views of the mountains and salt flats. The specific site at these coordinates is large enough to fit 6+ vehicles. There are at least 3 fire rings! Far enough away from major roads that it’s extremely quiet. Would definitely spend another night here!! Very tranquil.

name: Horseshoe Lake State Park
description: State park campground, nice and quiet near St. Louis. I arrived late on Memorial Day so no one was at the park office. Lots of spots open even on a holiday. Water, pit toilets, and some other minimal facilities. Adequate AT&T signal. I’m in a camper van but you could fit big rigs here easily.

name: Davey Crocket's campsite
description: Has 50 amp hook up, outdoor swimming pool, Cherokee lake,  pet friendly,  indoor hot tub, restaurant, kid friendly, camp ground

name: Smathers Beach Bulkhead
description: There is a mile long stretch of concrete bulkhead along the water where parking is free and permitted from 6am to 11pm. Short walk to smathers beach with restrooms and showers.

name: Barton Springs Bottle fill station
description: Water bottle fill station big enough for 7 Gal Aquatainer

name: Barron Flat
description: Beautiful meadow with dispersed sites in the open and among the trees. Most suitable to vans, trucks, and small campers.

name: Sulfur creek
description: Between Beas Flat and Pandora’s box on the south side of the road. Lots of established campsites and once you cross the cattleguard the road splits off in many directions with campsites all over the place. 1 to 2 bars of LTE Verizon. Dirt road that is drivable by any vehicle

name: Frisco Woods
description: Camping for RV, tents and log cabins on the property

name: Jones Bay Campground
description: Lake Roosevelt National Recreation Area established campsite managed by NPS. 9 sites total, pit toilet, no water, no hookups, boat launch. Reservations required. $23 per night. Sites have a mix of full sun exposure and shade. AT&T cell signal nearly non-existent but with Weboost I could successfully get a weak signal for text messaging and email. Access road is unpaved and one-lane at the end, but still passable for 2WD and larger rigs. No camp host but park rangers come by to check on campground daily, and while I was there a Dept of Fish and Wildlife person also came around to check on the people fishing.

name: Dallas Divide
description: Large parking area, people come here for sunset viewing, I stayed overnight once last October, no sign of prohibiting overnight camping. There were at least 3 other overnight campers at the time I was there. Full cell phone signal. No fee. Verizon gets 1-2 bars as of July 2021.

name: Cracker Barrel
description:
A Cracker Barrel Restaurant. I stayed here 1 night, not bothered, no ‘knock’. I didn’t ask if it was ok. I just parked. Ordered dinner waited until dark and parked myself. Next morning had breakfast there and was on my merry way. 
Terrapin Nature Park is close by with a beach and walking trails you might enjoy.

name: Inlet Bay Campground
description: Inlet Bay Campground is one of two campgrounds at Horsetooth Reservoir. Reservations required but can be made online up to the day of use. Multiple improved gravel sites of various sizes near Inlet Bay of the lake as well as several trailheads for hiking and mountain biking.

name: KOA- Montrose
description: Typical KOA- Expensive, clean and well run.  After over a week in the woods, it was a welcome place to relax, clean the rig, do laundry, use the WiFi and dump the tanks.  Great place to recharge in civilization.

name: Parking off track
description: OK this will be for everybody. Can you buddy with a medium to high clearance vehicle and camp quietly off of Highway 50? Coordinates are for the turn off. You can go as far as you want. I wouldn’t do it in a Prius. Nice and quiet and nobody’s going to bother you here.

name: Water spigot in the park close to picnic tables and public swimming pool
description: Water Spigot in the park next to swimming pool

name: Flat spot on side of quiet dirt road
description: It’s a few miles off hwy 90, 1-2 bars of Verizon.. I could imagine this being no fun on the weekend because it’s a smooth dirt road and obviously gets a lot of local use. But tonight at the end of the weekend it’s chillin.

name: Overnight parking lot for bike trails
description: Very noisy as it is under a freeway entrance but there’s plenty of parking. It mainly serves as a lot for C&O canal and aleganey passage bikepackers but would work in a pinch — gas stations and shops nearby for bathrooms and food

name: River spot right off road
description: Very tiny pull off (must back out) takes you to the river. Someone has made a fire ring. Very close to the road but it doesn’t seem very busy. There are more spots like this (most bigger and farther off the road) along this stretch of highway that other cars were parked in

name: Bennington Public Library
description: good WiFi that’s free,public, and strong even from the road:)

name: Packway roadside art display
description: Amazing collection of junkyard art sculpture.  Worth the short detour from highway 89.  Absolutely free.

name: Red Trail campground.
description: Showers are $10. Quit little place, super nice people. Don’t know what they charge to camp we only showered. Most the campsite have shade.

name: Hollins Hunt Camp
description: Nice primitive campground with ten sites. No water, electric, outhouse etc. quiet with lots of space between sites. Room for large RV or Trailer, if you don't have 4wd park in the first spot on right or next spot on left, especially if ground is wet. Pack out trash.

name: Coleman Lake Campground
description: The newly renovated Coleman Lake Recreation Area is peacefully nestled into the Talladega Mountains. There are 39 campsites with water and electrical hookups, bathhouses, a sandy beach, 29 picnicking units, a 21-acre lake and access to the Pinhoti Trail. Most sites will accommodate recreational vehicles up to 35 feet in length. A picnic shelter that seats 40 is available on a first come, first serve basis, or it can be reserved for $15.

name: Dirt shoulder along quiet road
description: About a quarter mile of a dirt should on a quiet road across from an agricultural field along the water. Really nice in you’re in a van.

name: Rogue Elk Campground
description:
A very pleasant county campground on the way to/from Crater Lake. $22/night for no hookups, around $30 for hookups. Great sites along the rogue river. Hot showers (25c/3min). Plenty of spots open early June.

Not much Verizon. Two bars AT&T.

name: Large Clearing in NF
description: Level clearing big enough for several rigs. Road in is easily accessible for anyone. Close to the paved NFS road, but private and quiet. No amenities and no cell service on ATT. We checked out a lot of other pins in this area, but all of them were full on a Wednesday afternoon. Be sure to have a plan B!

name: Woodsy clearing halfway up to Sauk Mt Trailhead
description: Sweet spot with level space for a few vehicles just off the road to the right. Road up is a bit bumpy but we did it with 2WD and high clearance, just take it slow. Seems to be a ramshackle shooting range but we figured with our van in the spot, no one would bother us. Heard some far-off traffic but not a single car passed by us in the 18 hours we were here. Lots of dead wood, bird sounds, and beautiful greenery!

name: Baldy Mountain
description:
For end of summer camping us locals come up here to have bonfires and stargaze above treeline. 

May get really windy.

name: Free air
description: Behind the gas station near the dumpsters is an air hose for airing up tires. The compressor is behind the dumpsters and was turned off, we turned it on and aired up.

name: Dirt Road Wide Spot
description: A Nice big turn around big enough for two or three vans, Far enough off the highway that you will not be bothered by the sound. One cattlegrate in good shape. One bar Verizon

name: Near Road
description: Nice little dispersed campsite /vehicle turnaround. Can accommodate two to three sizable vehicles. Road in (9549) is rutted and pitched, but pretty much any 4x4 could make it in (under dry conditions). Popular 4x4 tour and side-by-side route, so expect daytime traffic (noise & dust), but site itself is well set back from the road.  NOTE: Had strong AT&T signal (3bar LTE - with WeBoost)

name: Trailhead
description: Not the most private spot but a little trail head outside of Woodstock, VT that’s in a neighborhood. Stayed here 1 night with no issues. Weak att and verizon.

name: Llano City RV Park
description: Nice RV park with riverside sites for tent camping. $10 per person per night for tents. RV spots start at $30.  Restrooms on site. Bank fishing.

name: Mayo Clinic Health System - Austin
description: Hospital and Clinic and Emergency Department and Urgent Care.

name: Monks Road #74
description: Pennsylvania State Forest Boondocking, free permit required. former log landing open grassy area.

name: Kanab public library
description: Public library offers Wi-Fi that can be reached from the curbside parking area.

name: Quarry off Highway 206
description: Nothing special, just a place to pull off the road that is flat and has some privacy

name: Miguel’s Tacos
description: Great little stop in between Bend and Eugene or if you are like us... on your way to the coast! Very friendly owner! Just opened three months ago. All good made in house including corn tortillas! Great prices and such good fill! Also there is a 76 next door for fuel, propane fill, and also a dispensary called Phresh Start next door with really fair prices! Huge Gem of an area!

name: Large BLM Campsite
description:
established area at the base of the cliff. a couple of fire pits. 

2 reasonable sized camps near one another. 1st site is about 50 yards north. 

2wd is fine on the dirt road in. 

5g/LTE on TMobile. nice sunset views.  sunrise should be pretty epic.

name: Harrahs Bus/RV parking lot
description: Big lot right next to Harrahs Casino and hotel.  Ocean View.  We parked here all day and then stayed all night.  Several buses and one 18 Wheeler but it was super quiet.  Small museum and a few other restaurants and Casinos near by.

name: Wolford Reservoir campground and marina
description: Nice established campground on the reservoir.  65 sites.  Power at sites.  Picnic tables and fire pits.  Easy water access.

name: City View Van Pull-off
description: view of the whole city at night. a few little turn offs on this road. as a local I have stayed here in my van many of nights.

name: DT’s Blue Ridge Java Coffee Shop and Cafe
description: Cute cafe with good food and local ambience. Nice outdoor seating. Sat outside all day after buying a couple things and nobody bothered me. Inside lots of seats with outlets. WiFi speed slow at 3mbps. Guest code inside the store at counter.

name: Gale River Loop Road
description: White Mountain National Forest. free dispersed camping. 12 numbered sites set very far apart. easy to get to. spots fill up fast so you have to get lucky. 14 days stay. not all spots are vehicle accessible. some are tent only. fire ring. no other amenities. some sites can accommodate a big rig or pull-behind. 2 bars Verizon service at spot #7. several hiking trails within walking distance. 15 person, 3 car limit per site. pets must be leashed.

name: Bitter Springs Backcountry Byway
description: This is a boondocking spot op out of the wash. Narrow, mostly OHV sized, but we were able to get there with our rig, no problem Did not even air down on way up Echo  Wash to this spot.

name: US FS road 25
description: Off highway 199. We parked at a large fork in the road under oak and pine. Was quiet

name: Onvo Sunoco Travel stop
description: Travel Center for truck and car fueling friendly attendant let us use water spigot to fill water tank.

name: Roosevelt National forest at sugarloaf road
description: Love it here will be back sugarloaf is busy but low foot traffic and plenty of space to play and see moose :-)

name: Aeneas Lake
description: This is a very simple campground with a bit toilet and places to park. It overlooks a nice lake that you can swim in. Very quiet at night. The lake is stocked with trout. There is good ATT and Verizon cell service. Very little shade, but a nice view of the hills. We stayed one night. You could fit a rig up to 30 ft or so

name: Boneaparte Lake Campground
description: This is a nice, well kept NFS campground on a medium sized lake. There are swimming, kayaking, fishing and hiking opportunities. Jim the host keeps this place very nice. A few spots can handle bigger rigs. The one drawback is no cell service. There are fresh water fixtures , pit toilets, fire rings and picnic tables. You might even meet the emotional support duck.

name: Air BnB campsite in a pasture with a view
description: Check Air BnB in Marshall, NC. Very clean site. Very open as you’re in a pasture. We saw no animals. The view is stunning. There is a fire ring. There is mulch put down for a large site.
